headline: Week in Pictures for Nov. 30
text: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include sewage problems following Hurricane Sandy; residents returning to Ortley Beach, N.J.; and camels enjoying the Manhattan streets.

headline: Which Turkey is Healthiest?
text: ISTANBUL — This is a mind bendingly beautiful city. It is poised between Europe and Asia, between the Western and Muslim worlds. It throbs with the fusion fashion, the beaty music, the oversized watches, the way-too-pricey cars that have become the telltale signs of an emerging economy in our globalizing era.

headline: Study Shows Possible Brain Damage Caused by Subconcussive Blows
text: A hockey concussion study published Friday in the journal Neurosurgical Focus includes in its findings an intriguing element – possible radiological evidence of brain trauma caused by subconcussive blows.

headline: Iranian Channel Reports Bomb Outside Its Office in Damascus
text: Iran’s state-owned satellite channel Press TV reports that a bomb destroyed six vehicles, including a satellite news truck near the broadcaster’s office in Damascus early on Friday.

headline: On Our Radar: Ice Melt Accelerates in Arctic and Antarctic
text: A new study shows that the ice sheets covering the land in Greenland and Antarctica are melting at three times the rate they were in the 1990s. A Fox Business News host, Stuart Varney, who previously called the science of climate change a “scientific conspiracy,” called the new evidence “hard and authoritative.” [NASA/Jet Propulsion Laboratory] [Media Matters]

headline: Apple Rolls Out a Cleaner iTunes
text: Well, it finally happened: Apple got around to fixing iTunes.

headline: The Monster of Monticello
text: Durham, N.C.

headline: Chrysler Museum Is Shutting Down
text: Chrysler said it would close the museum located in its headquarters in Auburn Hills, Mich., at the end of the year.

headline: Notes on Epistemic Closure
text: I gather that philosophers are upset over the use of the term “epistemic closure” to refer to the closing of the movement conservative mind – that’s not what they mean by the term. Never mind: that’s the term everyone is using. And recent reports are a reminder of just how closed that mind really is.

headline: Perot Museum of Nature and Science
text: The museum, with 180,000 square feet of space and 11 exhibition halls, opens in Dallas.

headline: Ford Recalling 73,000 Escapes and 15,800 Fusions
text: For the third time this year, Ford is recalling vehicles with its 1.6-liter EcoBoost four-cylinder engines, citing a fire hazard.

headline: Bursting With Science, Some of It Unsettling
text: DALLAS — When you approach the new $185 million Perot Museum of Nature and Science, which opens here on Saturday, it is clear that you are not being led into a serene temple, where a harmonious cosmic order is going to be revealed. The building is alluring but unsettling. Is the museum’s 10-story concrete cube splitting apart or being pieced together? Is it being held intact by an enormous brace — a transparent protrusion on the cube’s side containing a 54-foot-long escalator — or is that a destabilizing gash that pierces the building’s body?

headline: House Votes to Ease Visa Limits for Some Foreign Workers
text: WASHINGTON — A divided House of Representatives voted Friday to ease visa restrictions for a limited pool of foreign workers, previewing a fight over how far Congress should go in changing the country’s immigration laws.

headline: Friday Night Music: Decemberists
text: On paper I should be a big Decemberists fan; lists of “if you like this (Arcade Fire, etc.) you should like that” always point me to their stuff. Somehow, however, their music never grabbed me — not an active dislike, just not clicking for some reason.

headline: A Calling Card in Shards of Glass
text: A waiter at Moustache, a popular Middle Eastern restaurant on Bedford Street, pointed at a spot on the floor and said: “It was there. The police took it.”

headline: When Counterculture of 1971 Got Its Hands on Video
text: BEACON, N.Y. — Nineteen seventy-one was an eventful year in this country: Half a million people marched on Washington to protest the Vietnam War; riots broke out at Attica prison in upstate New York; the Supreme Court ruled unanimously in favor of busing to achieve racial desegregation in schools; and The New York Times started publishing the Pentagon Papers, detailing a history of American political and military involvement in Vietnam. It is also the year Electronic Arts Intermix (EAI) was founded in New York to support “moving-image” art, which, as shown by the 23 films and single-channel videos in “Circa 1971: Early Video and Film from the EAI Archive” at Dia:Beacon in Beacon, N.Y., was closely aligned with the politics and ethos of that moment.

headline: Moves of a New Breed, in a Habitat of Its Own
text: To watch the two dancers of Deborah Hay’s “As Holy Sites Go/duet” at St. Mark’s Church is like observing members of a new species, with plenty of animal characteristics. Much of what Jeanine Durning and Ros Warby do is odd, idiosyncratic and private, but they’re so motivated and strangely coherent that the realm they make onstage is large and satisfying. We watch like anthropologists, anxious not to disturb.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Piecework
text: On the Street: The dash of black leather sleeves mixed with a cloth coat or jacket is a new fashion expression.

headline: Kaplan Blue Ribbon Pairs
text: SAN FRANCISCO — The winners of the three-day Kaplan Blue Ribbon Pairs here on Thursday evening were John Diamond of Boca Raton, Fla., and Brian Platnick of Evanston, Ill. They finished less than a quarter of a board ahead of Eric Greco of Wynnewood, Pa., and Geoff Hampson of Las Vegas. Those two pairs, with Fred Gitelman of Las Vegas and Brad Moss of Denver, won the 2010 Rosenblum Cup world team title and Spingold Knockout Teams.

headline: Lopez’s Right Foot Is Not Hurt Badly. Really.
text: Brook Lopez’s right foot has become a source of endless stress and curiosity for anyone following the Nets and, for that matter, anyone employed by them. Their entire season could hinge on the health of his fifth metatarsal — the bone that fractured last December and knocked him out for nearly the entire 2011-12 season.

headline: College Football Matchups
text: Boy, that went fast, didn’t it? The college football regular season is all but over, with just a handful of games left before bowl season begins, including several conference championships. One towers above them all.

headline: State Secret Revealed: Mitterrand as a Doting Father
text: PARIS — SHE would sneak into the Élysée Palace to see her father, the president of France, through a back door that led directly to his private apartments. On winter days, they dined together in the library, by the fireplace.

headline: New View from Inside Fukushima: Chaos and Uncertainty
text: Even in the early days of the disaster at the Fukushima Daiichi Nuclear Power Plant in March of last year, as the reactors spiraled out of control, the terse statements issued by the operator felt like an exercise in denial. Radiation readings were “higher than the ordinary level” (about 100 times higher), and a “loud noise and white smoke” had hit the No. 4 reactor (a possible hydrogen explosion).

headline: On Religion: A Search for God Through Bluegrass and Klezmer
text: Andy Statman stood in the narrow basement of an Orthodox synagogue improbably wedged among the boîtes and boutiques of Greenwich Village. He wore a plain blue suit and white shirt, and from his waist hung tzitzit, the fringes meant to remind an observant Jew of the 613 commandments. Twisting together the pieces of his clarinet, he ran through a glissando that seemed to corkscrew through the air.

headline: Traditional Flavors of Havana Made New
text: The Colada Cuban, one of a dozen cocktails served at the Cuban Restaurant and Bar, sets the tone for the entire evening: it’s sweet, rich, vibrant and a little intoxicating — a real party. It and other cocktails (a classic basic mojito is only $5 on Mondays) introduce the traditional Cuban dishes that follow. Alexis Lahens, the chef, takes these old dishes and makes them seem new. Wait until you try his rice and beans.

headline: Beckham Wrapping Up American Mission With M.L.S.
text: CARSON, Calif. — When David Beckham signed with Major League Soccer in 2007, he did not want merely to win titles or sell Los Angeles Galaxy jerseys: he wanted to sell soccer to the United States.

headline: Strike Shuts Down Los Angeles and Long Beach Ports
text: LOS ANGELES — The nation’s busiest port complex remained largely shut down here on Friday as a port workers’ strike dragged into its fourth day, raising fears that the work stoppage could hurt the region’s economy.

headline: Statue of Liberty Was Unscathed by Hurricane, but Its Home Took a Beating
text: Add the following to the long list of items that took a beating when Hurricane Sandy blasted by: a dock that was refashioned in the twisting, turning shape of a water slide; a sea wall that started to pull away from the shoreline; and a fence that took on a gaptoothed look when long sections were extracted.

headline: Clip: ‘Only the Young’
text: A scene from the documentary "Only the Young," from Jason Tippet and Elizabeth Mims.

headline: Solar Industry Borrows a Page, and a Party, From Tupperware
text: GOODYEAR, Ariz. — The neighbors had gathered on the patio of a sun-baked ranch here, eager to hear the party’s hosts talk about their products and how they could enhance their lives. But in place of the timeworn arrangement of plastic storage containers or cosmetics on the coffee table, the couple was showing off an array of a different sort: the 32 solar panels on the roof.

headline: Battle Between Argentine Media Empire and President Heats Up Over a Law
text: BUENOS AIRES — In her battle with Argentina’s largest media empire, President Cristina Fernández de Kirchner has raided its headquarters with 200 tax agents. Her supporters have accused the conglomerate’s largest shareholder of adopting two children thought to have been abducted from women killed during Argentina’s “dirty war.” Her vice president has disparaged its chief executive, Héctor Magnetto, as a “Mafioso.”

headline: Simpler Taxes Now, Growth Later
text: WASHINGTON — As lawmakers consider rolling back many of the $1 trillion a year in tax breaks now doled out to businesses and individuals, some are promising that streamlining the tax code will not only raise revenue, but also spur economic growth.

headline: After Lowest Point, Murray Nears Peak
text: ATLANTA — The first weekend of October was rather grim for Georgia quarterback Aaron Murray. The Bulldogs lost to a division rival in a crucial game, fans held him responsible for the defeat in a very personal way, and then he found out his father was seriously ill.

headline: Aid Changes Raise Issue of Diversity at Colleges
text: College and university endowments have recovered most of the losses they sustained during the recession, now that the economy has begun to grow. Yet as this year’s high school seniors begin to fill out applications and aid forms, a number of prestigious smaller colleges are straining to meet students’ financial needs. To bridge the gap, some colleges have begun revising their financial aid formulas, raising concerns about how campus diversity — both economic and racial — might be affected.

headline: A Salute to the Southwest
text: AS customers leave Truck, a New Mexican-themed restaurant in what was once a truck stop on Route 22 in Bedford, they are invited to put suggestions into a big tin can nailed to the wall near the front door. On a recent, raucous Saturday night, after four of us had survived a dinner that could only be characterized as a fiasco, we grumbled that the oversize tin could not begin to hold our sentiments.

headline: Chairman of Utility Under Fire Resigns
text: The chairman of the Long Island Power Authority resigned on Friday, continuing an exodus from the troubled agency, which has received harsh criticism from customers and elected officials for its response to Hurricane Sandy.

headline: Wright Stays a Met, for Better or Worse
text: It is a quirk of team history, or maybe just the natural cycle of baseball, that almost every significant Mets player before this era had at least one shot at the World Series. From 1969 to 1973 to 1986 to 2000, the Mets spaced their pennants rather nicely, so when you picture almost any Met of consequence, you can remember him playing on the ultimate stage.

headline: Surprising Pleasures, With Simple Titles
text: MY major regret about the Chelsea, a new restaurant in Fairfield, is that it’s not closer to my home. It’s the kind of informal neighborhood place that you’d love to stop by before or after the movies, or any time in between. I can’t think of many things more gratifying than sitting in one of the summery lime green chairs in the “Greenhouse” room, even in the cold of winter, and devouring one of the generous, well-made dishes on the menu, as sunshine danced through the windows.

headline: The Season for Shellfish
text: Local corn and tomatoes are only a memory at this time of year, but a different kind of Long Island bounty — scallops, clams and oysters — is in season for the Greenport Shellabration and restaurant walk on Dec. 8 and 9.

headline: New U.N. Status for Palestinians Could Open Door for Claims of Israeli War Crimes
text: In recent years, the Palestinian Authority has tried to have its accusations of Israeli war crimes investigated by the International Criminal Court, only to see its request go nowhere because the Palestinian territories were not recognized as a state.

headline: Small Employers Weigh Impact of Providing Health Insurance
text: Like many franchisees, Robert U. Mayfield, who owns five Dairy Queens in and around Austin, Tex., is always eager to expand and — no surprise — has had his eyes on opening a sixth DQ. But he said concerns about the new federal health care law had persuaded him to hold off.

headline: Spurs Fined $250,000 for Resting 4 Regulars
text: When the San Antonio Spurs held out four regulars Thursday night, Coach Gregg Popovich framed it as an investment in the future: Resting Tim Duncan, Tony Parker, Manu Ginobili and Danny Green now will presumably pay dividends next spring.

headline: ‘Last Best Hope’
text: On Dec. 1, 1862, Abraham Lincoln submitted his second Annual Message to Congress, in fulfillment of his duties, as spelled out in Article II, section 3 of the Constitution. (“He shall from time to time give to Congress information of the State of the Union and recommend to their Consideration such measures as he shall judge necessary and expedient.”) From that line comes the modern phrase “State of the Union,” to describe a ritual now performed, more publicly, in January. At the time, the message was a written effort, though it was read aloud by the secretary of the Senate. You can see a copy of it here.

headline: Striking Setting for Food of Uzbekistan
text: THE restaurant Kazan Authentic Central Asian Cuisine, which opened in Port Washington in October, is not your run-of-the-mill suburban spot. As one of my fellow diners put it: “Wow, I’ve never had Uzbek food before.”

headline: Isner Drops Coach
text: John Isner, who at No. 14 is the top-ranked American, has parted ways which Craig Boynton, who had served as his coach since March 2009. Isner’s ranking peaked at a career-high No. 9 in April, but had slipped by the end of the season after first-week losses at the last three Grand Slam events.

headline: U.S. to Pay $3.8 Billion for Next Lot of F-35 Jets
text: The Pentagon and Lockheed Martin reached an agreement in principle on Friday on the price of a fifth batch of F-35 fighter jets after a year of tense negotiations over how to lower costs.

headline: Ultimate Culpability for a Mine Disaster
text: Federal prosecutors have signaled a bold new move up the corporate ladder in their investigation of the Upper Big Branch mine disaster that killed 29 West Virginia coal miners in 2010. A former executive of Massey Energy, which ran the mine but has since been acquired by another company, has been accused of criminal conspiracy in hiding lethal safety violations at Massey mines and tipping off mine supervisors to spot inspections.

headline: Wizards Try to Put Worst Start, and Jokes, Behind Them
text: The first month of the N.B.A. season has been so miserable for the Washington Wizards that guard A. J. Price has been forced to alter his television viewing habits.

headline: Liberty Island Remains Battered After Storm
text: A lot of work has been done to clean up Liberty Island since it was flooded during Hurricane Sandy.

headline: In Latest Campaign, Obama Takes Deficit Battle to the Public
text: HATFIELD, Pa. — The blue “Forward.” signs with the lonely period were gone. But U2’s “City of Blinding Lights” once again blared over the loudspeakers, and some in the audience broke into a chant of “fired up, ready to go!”

headline: Deserving or Not, Rutgers Emerges as a Winner
text: PISCATAWAY, N.J. — On Rutgers’s first play from scrimmage Thursday night, receiver Brandon Coleman streaked down the sideline, away from Louisville’s pursuit, and might have run all the way to Columbus, Ohio, had the end zone not been compensatory enough for the moment.

headline: Rating a Mayor of New York
text: New Yorkers have an uncanny knack for electing the right mayoral candidate at the right time. In the racially charged urban climate agitated by a bombastic Edward I. Koch, the balm-throwing David N. Dinkins presented himself in 1989 as an ideal alternative: a black politician campaigning for conciliation.

headline: What’s Missing in the Latest Greek Bailout
text: The new Greek bailout deal agreed to Tuesday by euro zone finance ministers and the International Monetary Fund is a clear improvement over earlier deals. It recognizes that Greece’s current and projected ratios of debt to output are unsustainable. It prescribes useful steps to lower that ratio, including lower interest rates on loans from Greece’s European partners, longer bond maturities and a plan for Athens to buy back and retire some of its heavily discounted bonds.

headline: Push to Prosecute Drowsy Driving May Hinge on Its Definition
text: Roadside signs around the country have long warned drivers not to doze off behind the wheel with gentle catchphrases like “You Snooze, You Lose” and “Drive Alert, Arrive Alive.”

headline: Health Insurers Will Be Charged to Use New Exchanges
text: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration said Friday that it would charge insurance companies for the privilege of selling health insurance to millions of Americans in new online markets run by the federal government.

headline: In South Africa, Lethal Battles for Even Smallest of Political Posts
text: OSHABENI, South Africa — It was, by all accounts, an ordinary small-town political meeting. The leaders of the local branch of the African National Congress gathered in September at a convent here to discuss candidates for a newly vacated seat on the ward council, the lowest-level elected position in South Africa.

headline: Retail Frenzy: Prices on the Web Change Hourly
text: The day before Thanksgiving, Amazon was offering a discounted price of $49.96 on a popular Xbox game, the same price as Walmart and 3 cents lower than Target.

headline: Model Convicted of Killing His Lover
text: A jury on Friday convicted a former Portuguese model of murdering his journalist lover in a Times Square hotel last year, just after the victim had ended their relationship.

headline: Shotgun Report at Center of Florida Shooting Case
text: MIAMI — The case against Michael Dunn, a software developer charged with second-degree murder in the shooting of a 17-year-old Jacksonville student at a convenience store, hinges on a shotgun.

headline: Young Men Finding Their Way
text: Over the course of the 2012-13 Neediest Cases campaign, The New York Times is catching up on some of the people who were profiled in recent campaigns.

headline: Seeing Threat, British Press Hails Cameron as Defender
text: LONDON — It is hard to find much common ground among Britain’s squabbling, competing newspapers. Not only do they naturally mistrust one another, but they also tend to divide along party lines, so that The Daily Telegraph, for instance, is generally pro-Tory, while The Guardian is generally pro-Labour. (The papers owned by Rupert Murdoch’s News Corporation support whomever Mr. Murdoch supports.)

headline: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, Dec. 1, 2012.
text: People are not going to hug the president right now. They are waiting for him to take

headline: The Ice Queen of Rock Center
text: Rikki Samuels sat on a hard bench in the cramped skate house at the  Rink at Rockefeller Center in Manhattan and pulled on her well-worn ice skates.

headline: Mayor Says Rebuilt Boardwalk in Rockaways Won’t Be Wooden
text: The decree was unsentimental, no apologies to first kisses, bike rides or any other summer snapshot. Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said that the Boardwalk in the Rockaways would be rebuilt — but without hardwood, and perhaps not before next summer.

headline: Basketball Players’ Night Off Makes a Stand for Sitting Out
text: And to think what would have happened if they were given a three-day weekend.

headline: The Bad Luck of Winning
text: “We’re normal human beings,” said Cindy Hill on Friday, moments after she and her husband, Mark, posed with an oversized check for $293,750,000. “We’re common,” she added. “We just have more money.”

headline: Lottery Numbers
Cuomo Plans Trip to Washington to Press for Disaster Aid
text: WASHINGTON — Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, seeking to build support for billions of dollars in federal aid to help New York recover from Hurricane Sandy’s devastation, is planning to travel to Washington on Monday, according to administration officials.

headline: For Syria’s Rebel Movement, Skype Is a Useful and Increasingly Dangerous Tool
text: In a demonstration of their growing sophistication and organization, Syrian rebels responded to a nationwide shutdown of the Internet by turning to satellite technology to coordinate within the country and to communicate with outside activists.

headline: Pentagon Counsel Speaks of Post-Qaeda Challenges
text: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration’s top lawyer at the Pentagon laid out a vision on Friday for the legal challenges that will arise when the war against Al Qaeda winds down, looking ahead to when the terrorist network has been so degraded that the military conflict — and the legal authorities attached to it — will come to an end.

headline: Local Stop: Fifth Avenue
text: Like so much on Fifth Avenue, the tradition of extravagant window displays dates to the golden days of the early 20th century.

headline: A Playoff Call to Arms for Two Quarterbacks
text: When Wagner quarterback Nick Doscher tried to run or cut during his sophomore year, it felt as if someone were stabbing his ankle. When he tried to throw during his junior year, he heard “a pretty nasty click” in his right shoulder and felt pain with each pass.

headline: A Window on a Holiday Tradition
text: Just south of Central Park, the polished brass and limestone of Fifth Avenue’s grand apartment buildings, consulates and clubs give way to the universal pleasures of commerce. Augustus Saint-Gaudens’s gilded statue of Gen. William Tecumseh Sherman leads the charge downtown from the park’s Grand Army Plaza to the avenue’s department stores and boutiques, which sparkle through the holidays with extravagant window displays. Like so much in this neighborhood, the tradition dates to the golden days of the early 20th century.

headline: Books for College
text: Maria Lema, who this fall became the first in her family to attend college, always loved school. “It was my main focus in life,” she said, “the only thing I’ve been good at.” At age 6, Ms. Lema and her younger sister were placed in foster care with her uncle and his wife because her mother was using drugs.

headline: Farish Jenkins, Expert on Evolving Fossils, Dies at 72
text: Farish Jenkins, a paleontologist who discovered fossils of animals evolving into something new — most notably a 375-million-year-old fossilized fish with skull, neck, ribs and part of the fins that resembled the earliest mammals — died on Nov. 11 in Boston. He was 72.

headline: Subject of King Deioces
text: SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — I liked this puzzle by “Jeopardy!” showoff Joon Pahk SOMETHING FIERCE. It took a while, but somewhere around the middle of the solve I really started grooving on this grid.

headline: Corrections: December 1, 2012
text: NATIONAL

headline: Rivera Deal Is Finalized; Now Catcher Is Priority
text: In recent days, the Yankees strengthened both their starting rotation and their bullpen by bringing Andy Pettitte and Mariano Rivera back into the fold for at least one more season. But it is now unclear just who will be catching the Yankees’ pitches.

headline: Pushing the Dream
text: An empowered movement of young undocumented immigrants seeking a pathway to citizenship is gearing up for the immigration debate in 2013.

headline: Young Immigrants Say It’s Obama’s Time to Act
text: NEW HAVEN — It has been a good year for young immigrants living in the country without legal papers, the ones who call themselves Dreamers.

headline: Mitt’s Oval Office Moment
text: Our subject for today is: Important Holiday Traditions Involving Mitt Romney.

headline: Mother Promotes College, and Then Comes the Cost
text: The meeting with Berkeley College’s financial aid office last spring had not gone as Yvette Rivers had hoped. Worse than the disappointing information she received would be relaying it to her daughter Nyjhia Jones, who was soon to finish high school.

headline: To Save Congo, Let It Fall Apart
text: THE Democratic Republic of Congo, which erupted in violence again earlier this month, ought to be one of the richest countries in the world. Its immense mineral reserves are currently valued by some estimates at more than $24 trillion and include 30 percent of the world’s diamond reserves; vast amounts of cobalt, copper and gold; and 70 percent of the world’s coltan, which is used in electronic devices. Yet the most recent edition of the United Nations Development Program’s Human Development Index ranked Congo last among the 187 countries and territories included in the survey.

headline: Half of the Nets’ Core Four Provide Enough for a Win
text: ORLANDO, Fla. — Gerald Wallace stayed behind to put up some extra shots after the shootaround on Friday morning, and Joe Johnson continued to work himself into form. The work paid off Friday night. With plenty of open looks from behind the 3-point arc, Wallace and Johnson combined for seven 3-pointers and 42 points as the Nets rode the quieter half of their so-called Core Four to a 98-86 victory over the Magic.

headline: ‘Mayor of Strange Places’
text: It doesn’t take a science expert to figure out that Sundays are good for walking around and eating, but if it did, Paul Hoffman might be the man for the job. Mr. Hoffman, 56, who last fall became the president and chief executive of the Liberty Science Center in Jersey City, has run Discover magazine and published 11 books; he is also a partner in the restaurant Rucola, in Boerum Hill, Brooklyn, and an investor in several food start-ups. He lives in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, sometimes with his son, Alex, 15.

headline: The Photographs of Ken Regan
text: Ken Regan, who photographed celebrities including Bob Dylan and Senator Edward M. Kennedy, died on Nov. 25 in Manhattan.

headline: Measured Approach to the Syrian Crisis
text: Syrian rebels are making headway against President Bashar al-Assad. In recent weeks, they have seized several military bases and shot down military aircraft, reportedly with shoulder-fired missiles, but there is no end in sight to the war. More than 40,000 Syrians have been killed, 2.5 million are now displaced and more than 600,000 are refugees in Turkey, Jordan, Iraq and Lebanon.

headline: In Texas, Another Skirmish Brews at the Alamo
text: HOUSTON — As the saying goes, Texans remember the Alamo.

headline: Knicks Use Balance Against Hapless Washington
text: The striking image showed the stark difference between the Knicks and the Washington Wizards. Carmelo Anthony dribbled into the paint in the first quarter — and all five Wizards followed him. Surrounded, Anthony lifted his head and saw the absurdity of the defense played by the N.B.A.’s worst team.

headline: Lisa de Kooning, Painter’s Daughter, Dies at 56
text: Lisa de Kooning, the daughter of the Abstract Expressionist painter Willem de Kooning who overcame a chaotic youth to devote herself to burnishing her father’s fame as a giant of 20th-century art, died on Nov. 23 on St. John in the United States Virgin Islands. She was 56.

headline: Ken Regan, Photojournalist Trusted by Celebrities, Dies
text: Ken Regan, a photojournalist whose reputation for discretion earned him a backstage pass to the private realms of rock ’n’ roll stars and other celebrities, including Bob Dylan and Senator Edward M. Kennedy, died on Nov. 25 in Manhattan.

headline: That’s No Mouse King in the Double-Wide
text: Reality television viewers familiar with Chris March from his stint as a “Project Runway” contestant or his endearingly wacky Bravo spinoff, “Mad Fashion,” will know this designer and sometime drag artist as an outsize personality with a cuddly exuberance to match his girth. But that personality is largely AWOL from his holiday dansical, “Chris March’s The Butt-Cracker Suite!,” playing at Here.

headline: How Online Retailers Play With Pricing
text: Fierce price competition among retail rivals.

headline: Four Hofstra Players Charged With Burglary After String of Thefts
text: Four Hofstra basketball players were arrested and charged with multiple counts of burglary of laptops, iPads and other items taken from campus dormitory rooms and perhaps the home of Coach Mo Cassara, the police said Friday.

headline: At N.C.A.A. Tournament, a Splash From Brooklyn, by Way of Europe
text: The N.C.A.A. men’s water polo final four will feature the usual cast of powerhouses like unbeaten Southern California, which has won the last four titles, and the eight-time champion U.C.L.A. But with its third semifinal appearance in eight years, St. Francis of Brooklyn could become part of the regular cast, too.

headline: Gophers’ Stars Were Born With Ice in Their Veins
text: MINNEAPOLIS — The names Ramsey and Kessel evoke hockey memories at the University of Minnesota. Mike Ramsey won an N.C.A.A. championship with the Gophers in 1979 and an Olympic gold medal in 1980, both under Coach Herb Brooks, before embarking on a lengthy career as an N.H.L. defenseman and assistant coach. Phil Kessel, the Toronto Maple Leafs star, used one season at Minnesota in 2005-6 as the jumping-off point for his N.H.L. career.

headline: Declining Independence
text: Although the number of physicians in the United States is increasing, the percentage that remain solely in private practice is decreasing.

headline: Underwriting Abraham
text: ON a recent Sunday in November, in the domed sanctuary of Congregation Beth Elohim in Park Slope, Brooklyn, a woman sat working, dipping a goose quill in black ink and touching it to a sheet of yellowish-white parchment.

headline: Columbia’s Gang Scholar Lives on the Edge
text: FROM his earliest days as a graduate student, Sudhir Venkatesh did things differently. He came to sociology by way of math, not by the social sciences. He was an Indian-American Deadhead from Southern California who wore a ponytail and tie-dyed shirts. He stuck out.

headline: Storm Charity: 15% of What?
text: In 1983, Jerry Welsh, an executive vice president at American Express, observed from his Lower Manhattan office that the Statue of Liberty was undergoing a major renovation. Within a short time, the company inaugurated an advertising campaign promoting its interest in the project: For every new credit card application, American Express would donate one dollar to the statue’s restoration; for every transaction, it would contribute one penny. Eventually, the effort raised $1.7 million. As Mara Einstein, a professor of marketing at Queens College, explains in her recent book, “Compassion Inc: How Corporate America Blurs the Lines Between What We Buy, Who We Are and Those We Help,” this was essentially the beginning of what is known as cause marketing.

headline: Events in Westchester
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

headline: Events in Connecticut
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

headline: Events in New Jersey
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

headline: Events on Long Island
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

headline: Shawn Parker: Klinsmann’s Man in Mainz?
text: Long regarded as one of the best young German forwards in his age group, Mainz’s Shawn Parker put on a dazzling performance in his first Bundesliga start on Wednesday.

headline: Help for a Troubled Steel Plant in Italy
text: The government approved an emergency measure on Friday to allow the Ilva steel plant in the southern city of Taranto to continue its operations, provided the company invests about $3.9 billion to modernize the plant to meet environmental standards. The case, which pits health concerns against the need to protect 20,000 jobs in heavy industry, has tested the government of Prime Minister Mario Monti, which estimated that the economy would suffer losses of $10.4 billion a year if the plant closed. Mr. Monti, above, said the government needed to safeguard both public health and jobs as the plant carried out its cleanup. On Monday a court ordered the seizure of parts of the plant as a criminal investigation looked into claims of environmental damages caused by the plant’s emissions. Some studies have found that cancer rates around the steel plant, Europe’s largest, are significantly higher than elsewhere in Italy. Ilva had said that the investigation would force it to close the plant. An independent monitor will supervise Ilva’s plan to improve its technology.

headline: Pictures from the Week in Business, Nov. 30
text: Mary Schapiro stepped down from the S.E.C.; the holiday shopping season got off to a shakier start than retailers had hoped for; and new aid to Greece was on its way after officials reached a deal.

headline: What’s on Saturday
text: 10 P.M. (Cinemax) PROJECT X (2012) After Thomas (Thomas Mann), an unpopular high school student, is left unsupervised for the weekend, his friend Costa (Oliver Cooper, above left, with Mr. Mann, center, and Jonathan Danile Brown) sees it as an opportunity to give an over-the-top birthday party that will inaugurate them and their pal J. B. (Mr. Brown) into the realm of the cool kids. The result is pure chaos. “Nima Nourizadeh, the director, puts three relative unknowns in the central roles, and it pays off, especially with Oliver Cooper, who gives Costa a mischievous likability that anchors the enterprise,” Neil Genzlinger wrote in The New York Times. “Also smart: the boys bring along a video geek (Dax Flame) to film the whole thing, which gives Mr. Nourizadeh a lot of viewpoint options. He also has assorted cameras in the midst of the party, a funny script and some skilled editors cutting it all together. The ‘Animal House’ of the iPhone generation? Could be. Pretty enjoyable for parents too.”

headline: New President of Mexico Vows to Focus on Economy
text: MEXICO CITY — With protests and little pomp, Enrique Peña Nieto on Saturday began his six-year term as president of Mexico, promising big spending and sweeping changes to bring peace and prosperity to a country troubled by drug violence and uneven economic growth.

headline: IHT Quick Read: Dec. 1
text: NEWS For much of her youth, Mazarine Pingeot, daughter of the late French president François Mitterrand and his mistress, was a state secret. She would sneak into the Élysée Palace through a back door that led directly to Mr. Mitterand’s private apartments; when she got a bicycle, bodyguards followed her on bicycles, too. Now 37, Ms. Pingeot, an author and philosophy professor, has published “Bon Petit Soldat” (Good Little Soldier), a diary that includes memories of that unusual childhood. “Being unable to share a secret makes this secret very heavy,” she tells Maïa de la Baume. “You protect it rather than protecting yourself.”

headline: The Weekend Word: New Wave
text: Today’s Times

headline: Newswallah: Bharat Edition
text: Jammu and Kashmir: At least 90 Pakistani infiltrators entered India this year through the countries’ shared border, up from 63 last year, according to a Home Ministry estimate based on ground reports from intelligence agencies. The apparent increase has raised concern within the security establishment, Kashmir Live reported.

headline: When Internal Polls Mislead, a Whole Campaign May Be to Blame
text: Pollsters can expect to take their share of blame when their campaigns lose, and this year has been no exception. Not long after Barack Obama and Democrats had a strong night on Nov. 6, Republicans began to complain publicly that the polls conducted by their campaigns and by affiliated groups implied considerably more optimistic outcomes for them than actually occurred.

headline: Against Willful Denseness, The Gods Themselves Contend In Vain
text: From the very beginning of the Lesser Depression, the central principle for understanding macroeconomic policy has been that everything is different when you’re in a liquidity trap. In particular, the whole case for fiscal stimulus and against austerity rests on the proposition that with interest rates up against the zero lower bound, the central bank can neither achieve full employment on its own nor offset the contractionary effect of spending cuts or tax hikes.

headline: Christmas Tree Controversy Fires Multicultural Belgium
text: LONDON — It’s that time of year again. As November turned to December, a work gang just arrived outside the front window to set up the neighbourhood Christmas tree and mark the approach of the annual season of peace and good will.

headline: Young Filmmakers, Young Subjects
text: IT all started at a skate park in Santa Clarita, Calif., in the summer of 2010. The spot was just a few miles from the California Institute of the Arts, from which the filmmakers Jason Tippet and Elizabeth Mims had recently graduated, and mere blocks from where Mr. Tippet had grown up, a regular knockabout at the park just a few years earlier. Up skated 17-year-old Garrison Saenz and 16-year-old Kevin Conway, asking questions and bickering as if no one were watching, a teenage comic duo in the flesh.

headline: North Korea Says It Will Attempt to Test Another Long-Range Rocket
text: SEOUL, South Korea — North Korea said Saturday that it would try to launch another long-range rocket later this month, as the country prepares to commemorate the death a year ago of its longtime ruler Kim Jong-il, and as his son Kim Jong-un works to bolster his credentials as a leader.

headline: Rebels Pull Out of Strategic City in Congo
text: NAIROBI, Kenya — The rebel group that recently captured Goma, a strategic city in the Democratic Republic of Congo, pulled out hundreds of troops on Saturday, but Goma was still waiting to exhale.

headline: Kudos From the Art World He Shunned
text: Leon Levinstein never fully settled into the art world. He preferred roaming the Lower East Side or Times Square with his camera.

headline: Failed Baseball Union Helped Pave Way for Success
text: Marvin Miller deserved all the praise he received after his death last Tuesday for his extraordinary influence as the executive director of the Major League Baseball Players Association from 1966 to 1982. But the road to Miller’s winning free agency for his rank and file was paved by Robert Murphy, a Boston lawyer and management expert with the National Labor Relations Board in the aftermath of World War II.

headline: Tour Waits for Miller and Wonders as He Waits to Heal
text: BEAVER CREEK, Colo. — Racers and fans are looking for answers about Bode Miller, who has been missing from World Cup skiing this season.

headline: Drug of Focus Is at Center of Suspensions
text: The first time Anthony Becht heard about Adderall, he was in the Tampa Bay locker room in 2006. A teammate who had a prescription for the drug shook his pill bottle at Becht.

headline: Big Tax Incentives, Little Returns
text: Across the country, companies have demanded lucrative tax breaks from local governments, pitting states and cities against each other in exchange for local jobs.

headline: Highlights and Analysis From College Football Saturday
text: Mike Huguenin has analysis and insights on all of Saturday’s big college football games, including No. 2 Alabama’s SEC championship win over No. 3 Georgia.

headline: Economic Frustration Simmers Again in Tunisia
text: TUNIS — Tahar Bayahi, who runs Tunisia’s largest grocery store chain, spent the days right after the revolution toting up his losses: one-quarter of his 60 stores nationwide incinerated and another quarter pillaged.

headline: Border War: Kansas City
text: Incentives are made in the name of job creation, but the balance between lower taxes for businesses and benefits to the community is rarely clear-cut.

headline: Chiefs Player Kills Woman and, at Stadium, Himself
text: With his coach looking on, a Kansas City Chiefs linebacker shot and killed himself outside the team’s practice facility Saturday morning, less than an hour after he killed his girlfriend, according to the police.

headline: Variety: A Thought-Provoking Acrostic
text: SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE — This will be a slightly different Variety post today, because neither the team of Cox & Rathvon nor I know much about the author of today’s quote. It is simply one of those interesting quotes that captures the imagination and happens to fit well into the format of an acrostic puzzle.

headline: Amid Egypt’s Duel on Democracy, Morsi Calls for Vote
text: CAIRO — President Mohamed Morsi speaks darkly of imminent threats from a conspiracy of unnamed foreign enemies and corrupt businessmen. He vows to uncover counterrevolutionaries hiding under judicial robes. His advisers charge that loyalists of the former dictator have infiltrated the opposition, saying it would gladly sacrifice democracy to defeat the Islamists.

headline: Coming Home, Healed
text: CASTLE ROCK, Colo. — When Kathy Redmond had an important speaking engagement in Lincoln, Neb., last summer, Derek Brown decided to accompany her to the university town where they had met 21 years earlier as undergraduate students. Before they went, he made one heartfelt request.

headline: News Corp. Picks a Chief for a Spinoff
text: 2:53 p.m. | Updated

headline: Explore the Subsidies
text: Browse a database of business incentives awarded by hundreds of cities, counties and states compiled during a 10-month investigation by The New York Times.

headline: As Companies Seek Tax Deals, Governments Pay High Price
text: In the end, the money that towns across America gave General Motors did not matter.

headline: First Israeli in the N.B.A. Hopes for More Minutes
text: PHILADELPHIA — When a driving Kyrie Irving guided a nifty behind-the-back bounce pass to Anderson Varejao for a layup in Brooklyn last month, their Cleveland Cavaliers teammate Omri Casspi, leapt from his seat in fist-pumping delight.

headline: With Help, Afghan Survivor of ‘Honor Killing’ Inches Back
text: JALALABAD, Afghanistan — It is doubly miraculous that the young woman named Gul Meena is alive. After she was struck by an ax 15 times, slashing her head and face so deeply that it exposed her brain, she held on long enough to reach medical care and then, despite the limitations of what the doctors could do, clung to life.

headline: Morris Turns Heads That Griffin III Hasn’t
text: ASHBURN, Va. — While playing against Dallas on Thanksgiving, Washington Redskins quarterback Robert Griffin III and running back Alfred Morris executed a play-action fake in the second quarter that momentarily froze Cowboys safety Danny McCray. As McCray paused, wide receiver Aldrick Robinson slipped behind him and Griffin, the Redskins’ Heisman-winning first-round draft choice, stepped back into the pocket and flipped the ball 60 yards. The wide-open Robinson caught the pass in stride for the first score in a critical 38-31 victory against the Cowboys.

headline: So Far, Ryan’s Great Expectations for the Jets Have Been Fiction
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — On Aug. 15, three and a half weeks before the Jets opened the season, Rex Ryan was asked to assess his team’s defense. Calling it “a given” that the unit would finish among the top five in the N.F.L., Ryan said he believed so much in his system, his players and his staff that the Jets could start two coaches, Mike Pettine and Dennis Thurman, and it would not matter.

headline: A Health Insurance Detective Story
text: I’VE had a long career as a business journalist, beginning at Forbes and including eight years as the editor of Money, a personal finance magazine. But I’ve never faced a more confounding reporting challenge than the one I’m engaged in now: What will I pay next year for the pill that controls my blood cancer?

headline: The Buzzwords of the Crowd
text: IN his novel “Tender Is the Night,” F. Scott Fitzgerald wrote that American tourists in Europe languished whenever “no fragments of their own thoughts came suddenly from the minds of others.”

headline: In Damascus, Tense Anticipation of Strongest Push Yet by Rebels
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — As Syrian rebels and government forces clashed on the outskirts of Damascus on Saturday, with explosions rumbling in the distance and warplanes screeching overhead, the rebels appeared to be making their strongest push toward the city since the government repelled an offensive there in July.

headline: Advertisement Makes Fans’ Dreams a Reality
text: CHICAGO — During television broadcasts of the Chicago Bulls this season, the most riveting sequence has often come during a break in the action. One commercial, in particular, teases viewers, almost like a parlor trick. It starts with an announcer’s agony.

headline: More Babies, Please
text: IN the eternally recurring debates about whether some rival great power will knock the United States off its global perch, there has always been one excellent reason to bet on a second American century: We have more babies than the competition.

headline: A Closing Ends an Era, and a Deli War
text: A perpetual pastrami war has, at last, ended.

headline: Utah Hunters Criticize Market Approach to Licenses and Conservation
text: SALT LAKE CITY — Todd Huntington, a dentist from a small town in central Utah, considered himself lucky. After two years of failing to secure a hunting permit in the state’s random drawing, he won a $35 state permit to shoot a male deer.

headline: Footing the Bill for Inaugural Dancing
text: After an exhausting re-election victory that drained supporters of hundreds of millions of dollars, some of President Obama’s advisers are reportedly urging that the second inaugural scrap a praiseworthy innovation of his first: the banning of corporate donations to pay for the day’s many expensive galas.

headline: Mr. Cuomo’s Next Big Task
text: Here’s one way Gov. Andrew Cuomo can match the acclaim he achieved by getting same-sex marriage approved in New York State: persuade the State Legislature to make New York’s system of electing legislators the fairest and most transparent in the country.

headline: Keeping Score: Also for Your Hall of Fame Consideration, Scott Boras
text: When Marvin Miller, the groundbreaking leader of the Major League Baseball Players Association, died last week, it led to renewed calls for his election to the Hall of Fame, an honor that was denied him in five votes over the last decade.

headline: Spellbound by Blondes, Hot and Icy
text: WASHINGTON

headline: Many More Images, Much Less Meaning
text: THERE was a time when you’d come back from Spain, or even just the Jersey Shore, with a couple of rolls of film tucked safely into your toiletry bag. A few days later, you’d find yourself in line at the photo desk of your local pharmacy, waiting to retrieve your developed images with a sense of nervous anticipation.

headline: The Enduring Allure of Boy Bands
text: ON Monday night, Madison Square Garden will be commandeered by five young men from across the Atlantic and their fervent faithful. The old Borders bookstore in Penn Plaza has been temporarily made over in their image; people referring to themselves as “Directioners” are likely to be dawdling around Penn Station now, hoping for a moment when they can dash upstairs and see their idols in full thrall.

headline: Biz Stone
text: Biz Stone is a founder of Twitter who currently serves as the company’s creative director. He also helped start Xanga, Blogger, Odeo and, most recently, Obvious, which creates software and Web platforms to facilitate online collaboration.

headline: Sunday Dialogue: How We Punish Crime
text: Readers offer ideas for prison reform and alternatives.

headline: Beyond Black and White in the Mississippi Delta
text: WATCHING the American political conversation over the last two years, you might easily have assumed that everything and everyone was working from the same playbook of partisan and racial polarization. That is, unless you were watching the Mississippi Delta, where, over the last few years, three towns — Greenville, Greenwood and Indianola — with overwhelmingly African-American populations elected white mayors.

headline: Letter From Syria
text: Darkush, Syria

headline: What’s in Miami’s Bloodstream?
text: Miami

headline: At S.M.U., Brown Makes Splashy Return to College Coaching
text: Tim Jankovich had a good feeling when he flew to Dallas in early April to discuss the men’s basketball coaching vacancy at Southern Methodist. It dissipated when he found out that the Hall of Famer Larry Brown was interviewing for the job on the same day.

headline: Dear President Clinton
text: WHAT a year you’ve had, the kind that really burnishes a legend. At the Democratic National Convention, on the campaign trail, in speeches aplenty and during interviews galore, you spoke eloquently about what this country should value, and you spoke unequivocally about where it should head. Such a bounty of convictions, such a harvest of words, except for one that’s long overdue: Sorry.

headline: New Love: A Short Shelf Life
text: IN fairy tales, marriages last happily ever after. Science, however, tells us that wedded bliss has but a limited shelf life.

headline: Matchup: Cardinals (4-7) at Jets (4-7)
text: 1 p.m. Eastern, Fox

headline: Islanders’ Mystery Draft Pick Is Not Giving Up
text: POTSDAM, N.Y. — Among all the players drafted by N.H.L. clubs, Cody Rosen is something of a special case. He was picked by the Islanders in 2010 despite playing only 20 minutes in goal in his freshman season at Clarkson University. In the two-plus seasons since, Rosen, 22, has played only one full game and parts of five others with the Golden Knights.

headline: Dividing the West Bank, and Deepening a Rift
text: JERUSALEM — High up in an empty, mountainous expanse east of this city there is a stone patio with a pair of green metal benches and a plaque marking the cornerstone of a future Jewish community. Dedicated in 2009, the plaque promises the new city will be built “adjacent to the united Jerusalem, which will be quickly re-established.”

headline: In an F.H.A. Checkup, a Startling Number
text: DO we have another Fannie or Freddie on our hands — another mortgage giant headed for a rescue?

headline: When Partisans Became Partners
text: Williamstown, Mass.

headline: Don’t Chase Everything That Shines
text: This interview with  Sandra L. Kurtzig, chairwoman and C.E.O. of Kenandy, a software management firm based in Redwood City, Calif., was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

headline: What’s Killing Brazil’s Police?
text: SÃO PAULO, BrazilON the evening of Saturday, Nov. 3, Marta Umbelina da Silva, a military police officer here and a single mother of three, was shot in front of her 11-year-old daughter outside their house in Brasilândia, a poor community on the north side of the city. Records show that Ms. da Silva, 44, had never arrested anyone in her 15-year career. Instead, she was one of hundreds of low-level staffers, who mostly handled internal paperwork.

headline: O Que Está Matando a Polícia Brasileira?
text: This is the Portuguese version of an Op-Ed essay published in the New York Times.SÃO PAULO, BrazilNa noite de sábado, 3 de novembro, Marta Umbelina da Silva, uma policial militar de São Paulo e mãe solteira de três filhos, foi assassinada na frente de sua filha de 11 anos, na porta de sua casa em Brasilândia, uma comunidade desfavorecida na Zona Norte da cidade.

headline: Taking a Stand for Office Ergonomics
text: THE health studies that conclude that people should sit less, and get up and move around more, have always struck me as fitting into the “well, duh” category.

headline: Effort to Secure Border Crimps Commerce Along It
text: DOUGLAS, Ariz. — When the copper smelters closed, the jobs dried up and the people who used to sustain the small shops along this border city’s commercial strips left to find work elsewhere, the Ortega family looked toward the neighbor to the south, Agua Prieta, Mexico, for a new clientele.

headline: The C.E.O. Who Shocked Japan Inc.
text: THE 2011 financial scandal at the Olympus Corporation, the big Japanese maker of optical equipment, was a head-shaking spectacle. It was rare enough that a Tokyo-based company had elevated Michael Woodford, a Westerner who spoke no Japanese, to its presidency. But when Mr. Woodford discovered loss-hiding shenanigans and turned whistle-blower, he set off a tumult unlike anything that the cosseted world of Japanese business had quite seen.

headline: A Hard Sell on the Extras, Revisited
text: CYPRESS, Calif.

headline: Red Bulls: Team in Transition First Needs a Direction
text: It may never reach the heights or the hyperbole of the Curse of the Bambino. Yet from their first home game in Major League Soccer, the MetroStars/Red Bulls franchise has been beset, some of the club’s fans believe, by its own hoodoo: the Curse of Caricola.

headline: Europe’s Avoidable Collision Course
text: ECONOMIC relations in the euro zone amount to a game of chicken. Like car drivers aiming directly at one another, governments are challenging their counterparts to flinch first and give in. Unfortunately, the economic study of strategic behavior — also known as game theory — suggests that if you play chicken too many times, you will eventually crash the proverbial car.

headline: The Mortgage Challenge
text: The biggest economic policy error of President Obama’s first term was the failure to effectively address foreclosures. The administration’s efforts were far too limited for far too long. By favoring the voluntary cooperation of banks in reducing monthly payments for hard-pressed borrowers, they did more to shield the banks from losses than to help homeowners and stabilize the market.

headline: For Cotto, a Chance to Capture a Title and to Honor the Legacy of Camacho
text: Before Miguel Cotto challenged Austin Trout for the World Boxing Association superwelterweight championship on Saturday at Madison Square Garden, the timekeeper was set to toll a final 10-count for Hector Camacho.

headline: How Capitalist Are the Cubans?
text: HAVANA

headline: A Shopping Stampede, Yes, but Maybe No Economic Jolt
text: THE holiday shopping season started early, and with a roar. Whether that will help the sagging economy is another matter.

headline: Paying but Not Profiting

headline: Obama vs. Obama on the Deficit
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Snowboard Ambassador
text: I GREW up in Greenwich, Conn., and was lucky enough to travel when I was young. My family traveled to Europe many summers, and we skied different mountains in the United States in the winters. I was 18 when I met Jake Carpenter during a New Year’s Eve party at a tavern in Vermont. He was just starting what would become Burton Snowboards, and I was studying political science at Columbia University.

headline: The Art of Being Still
text: Many of the aspiring writers I know talk about writing more than they actually write. Instead of setting free the novel or short story or essay that is sizzling at the ends of their fingers, desperate to set fire to the world, they fret about writer’s block or about never having the time to write.

headline: When the H.R. Office Leaves the Building
text: WHAT ever happened to the human resources department?

headline: In San Francisco, a Voice of Moderation That’s Often Unwelcome
text: SAN FRANCISCO — As soon as the San Francisco Board of Supervisors narrowly approved a ban on public nudity last month, booing filled the ornate Beaux-Arts legislative chamber in City Hall. Half a dozen opponents sprung up from the auditorium’s oak benches and began casting off their clothes, hurling invectives at a figure seated up front.

headline: 2 Are Charged With Extortion and Abduction
text: Two hip-hop performers were arrested on charges of kidnapping and extortion after being accused of abducting a man who discussed providing them with financial backing, the police said on Saturday.

headline: Chiefs Release Statement; Should Game Go On?
text: On Saturday afternoon, Clark Hunt, the Kansas City Chiefs’ owner, released the kind of statement that he probably never imagined he would have to make.

headline: Domino Effect of a Name Change
text: Last week Michael Jordan, the owner of the Charlotte Bobcats, said that he would be open to changing the team’s name to the Hornets should the franchise in New Orleans follow through with plans to change its name to something more befitting that city.

headline: Letters to the Editor
text: To the Sports Editor:

headline: Head of Tehran’s Cybercrimes Unit Is Fired Over Death of Blogger
text: TEHRAN — Iranian’s national police chief fired the commander of Tehran’s cybercrimes police unit on Saturday for negligence in the death of a blogger in prison.

headline: Flow of Arms to Syria Through Iraq Persists, to U.S. Dismay
text: WASHINGTON — The American effort to stem the flow of Iranian arms to Syria has faltered because of Iraq’s reluctance to inspect aircraft carrying the weapons through its airspace, American officials say.

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, Dec. 2
text: Treasury Secretary Timothy F. Geithner makes the rounds on the Sunday shows just a few days after Republicans resisted the proposal he presented to avert the so-called fiscal cliff. Mr. Geithner is scheduled to appear on ABC’s “This Week,” CBS’s “Face the Nation,” CNN’s “State of the Union,” “Fox News Sunday” and NBC’s “Meet the Press.”

headline: Alarm as China Issues Rules for Disputed Area
text: HAIKOU, China — New rules announced by a Chinese province last week to allow interceptions of ships in the South China Sea are raising concerns in the region, and in Washington, that simmering disputes with Southeast Asian countries over the waters will escalate.

headline: What Defines A Serious Deficit Proposal?
text: Just a thought: if you follow the pundit discussion of matters fiscal, you get the definite impression that some kinds of deficit reduction are considered “serious”, while others are not. In particular, the Obama administration’s call for higher revenue through increased taxes on high incomes — which actually goes considerably beyond just letting the Bush tax cuts for the top end expire — gets treated with an unmistakable sneer in much political discussion, as if it were a trivial thing, more about staking out a populist position than it is about getting real on red ink.

headline: A Person of Interest
text: John McAfee, a pioneer in computer security, is on the run in Belize, where he is a person of interest in his neighbor’s murder.

headline: Lo and Behold!
text: SUNDAY’S PUZZLE — We see a lot of letter addition or deletion themes here at The New York Times puzzle enclave, and they can go one way or another: sometimes they’re really clever, and sometimes we’re left with a distinct feeling of “seen that before.” LO and behold, I thought this one was clever.

headline: Their Schedule Full, Knicks Make Rare Visit to Practice Court
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — The practice court at the Knicks’ training center appeared especially shiny Saturday. It had not been used in a while.

headline: David Schwendeman, Museum’s Chief Taxidermist, Dies at 87
text: A bald eagle, its wings spanning more than six feet, swoops toward an Alaskan riverbank, its talons spread to grasp a salmon. A steel rod, concealed by one of the eagle’s long flight feathers, is connected to the exhibit case in the Hall of North American Birds at the American Museum of Natural History, seeming to suspend the specimen in midair.

headline: John McAfee Plays Hide-and-Seek in Belize
text: AMBERGRIS CAYE, Belize

headline: Mortgage Catch Pushes Widows Into Foreclosure
text: Geraldine Bates lost her husband to kidney failure last year. Now, she has fallen behind on her mortgage payments and is terrified that she will lose her home in Jacksonville, Fla.

headline: Gray Foy, Artist and Avatar of a Gilded Age, Dies at 90
text: They all came in a body: the threadbare actors and decadent aristocrats, the Black Forest woodcarvers and prima ballerinas, the pantalooned fops and gin-soaked playwrights, the lepidopterists and sundry maiden aunts — everyone whose history suffused any of the thousands of antiques in Gray Foy’s Manhattan home.

headline: In Panicky Russia, It’s Official: End of World Is Not Near
text: MOSCOW — There are scattered reports of unusual behavior from across Russia’s nine time zones.

headline: Nun Uses Music to Convey Spirited Message Against the Vatican’s Rebuke
text: LA GRANGE PARK, Ill. — When Kathy Sherman was in college during the final years of the Vietnam War, she played the guitar with friends in her dorm room and sang folk and protest songs over bowls of popcorn. They sang Peter, Paul and Mary and Joan Baez, and some friends said her voice reminded them of Judy Collins.

headline: Underdog Takes Women’s World Title
text: Anna Ushenina, a Ukrainian international master, won the women’s world championship on Saturday in Khanty-Mansiysk, Russia. Her victory was a huge upset because she had started the 64-player tournament as the No. 32 seed.

headline: The Longest  Season Really Is Over
text: PARIS — It may be as difficult to believe for fans as it is for the Formula One teams and the media, but the 2012 season is really, finally, over.

headline: Daring Run in Super-G Gives Italy 2nd Win
text: BEAVER CREEK, Colo. — Matteo Marsaglia of Italy stood atop the podium Saturday after winning the Birds of Prey super-G in 1 minute 14.68 seconds. It was Marsaglia’s first World Cup victory.

headline: Staten Island Volunteers Fear City Will Hamper Their Hurricane Relief Efforts
text: After the floodwaters created by Hurricane Sandy began receding from the Midland Beach neighborhood of Staten Island, one of the first things that Aiman Youseff did was to set up a table on the sidewalk near what was left of his house at 489 Midland Avenue.

headline: Finding Reasons to Go to the Store for Music Gifts
text: The holiday shopping season is here, and with it comes a rise in the practice of “showrooming,” in which customers head to traditional stores to research gift ideas before buying the product from an online retailer, often at a lower price.

headline: Democrats Expect a Deal on Medicaid Despite Perry
text: Despite Gov. Rick Perry’s firm opposition to a central tenet of federal health reform — expanding the state’s Medicaid program for those with low incomes — Texas Democrats remain optimistic that the 2013 legislative session can yield a deal that brings in billions of additional federal dollars.

headline: Some See Logistical Issues and Elitism in Toll Lanes
text: For Texas drivers, the distinction between free roads and toll roads is starting to blur.

headline: Make It One More Supreme Court Justice From the Perry Camp
text: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column for the Tribune.

headline: Immovable on Line, Tide Sprint to Victory
text: ATLANTA — D. J. Fluker, Alabama’s right tackle, bounded off the field in the third quarter Saturday and shouted to anyone on the sideline who would listen, “Keep running that play right; keep running that play right.”

headline: Trusted Aide to Obama Faces Test in Budget Showdown
text: WASHINGTON — When President Obama was locked in painful spending negotiations with House Republicans last spring, his exceedingly meticulous budget director, Jacob J. Lew, went to the Oval Office to propose some complex budget changes. As Mr. Lew delved deeper and deeper into the numbers, Mr. Obama put up his hand, signaling him to stop.

headline: Alabama Hopes Thrilling Title Is Prelude to Ultimate Prize
text: ATLANTA — As the final seconds ticked off an instant classic, Alabama linebacker C. J. Mosley froze, uncertain if the game had ended, unsure if the celebration could commence. The fireworks helped convince him, as did the confetti that shot skyward and the bedlam that ensued.

headline: Galaxy Repeat as Champions in Beckham’s M.L.S. Finale
text: CARSON, Calif. — David Beckham’s six years with the Los Angeles Galaxy will most likely be best remembered for the attention he brought to the team and to Major League Soccer, which saw a jump in television coverage and jersey sales after he arrived.

headline: ‘Heartbroken,’ Hofstra Coach Says He and Staff Dug Into Recruits’ Histories
text: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y. — The Hofstra men’s basketball coach Mo Cassara said he was “heartbroken” by the news that four of his players were arrested Thursday and charged with taking part in a string of burglaries in campus dormitory rooms over nearly two months.

headline: Lottery Numbers

text: FRONT PAGE

headline: In a Full Household, Raising Young Triplets Who Share a Disease
text: On the Mercurius family’s kitchen table, a tray of medicine rests atop two plastic bins crammed full of prescription bottles, looking like a centerpiece. It evokes a pharmacy, which is appropriate given that the illness those drugs treat, and the three children afflicted by it, are the family’s primary focus.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, Dec. 2
text: Surviving spouses are trapped without a clear way to preserve their home.

headline: Another ‘Nail House’ in China Gets Hammered
text: HONG KONG — A renowned “nail house” in eastern China was finally hammered to the ground on Saturday, as the authorities demolished the house that was sitting smack dab in the middle of a new roadway.

headline: Nets Fall Apart in Second Half With Missed Shots and Turnovers
text: MIAMI — Perhaps the stage was too big, the moment too momentous or the difference in talent, poise and experience too great. Perhaps the Nets, still in their embryonic phase as an N.B.A. force, are simply not ready yet for this particular challenge.

headline: Beckham Goes Out a Winner. Will Donovan Follow?
text: Omar Gonzalez was the most valuable player but David Beckham and Landon Donovan provided the story lines Saturday night as the Los Angeles Galaxy beat the Houston Dynamo, 3-1, to win their second straight M.L.S. championship. Ian Lovett covered the game for The Times, and spoke with Beckham, who is walking away from M.L.S., and Donovan, who is considering walking away from the game altogether.

headline: Brenda Fulton, Penelope Gnesin
text: Brenda Sue Fulton and Penelope Dara Gnesin were married Saturday at the Cadet Chapel at the United States Military Academy at West Point, N.Y. The Rev. Vanessa R. Southern, a Unitarian Universalist minister, performed the ceremony, with Col. J. Wesley Smith, an Episcopal army chaplain at West Point, taking part.

headline: Rebecca Gunther, Eric Bacaj
text: Rebecca Schneider Gunther and Eric Patrick Bacaj were married Saturday evening at Ceresville Mansion in Frederick, Md. The Rev. William F. Schulz, a Unitarian Universalist minister, officiated, with the Rev. Michael Kelley, a Roman Catholic priest, taking part.

headline: Eliza Johnson and Andrew Hughes
text: Eliza deForest Johnson and Charles Andrew Hughes were married Saturday afternoon at the Hillsboro Club in Hillsboro Beach, Fla. The Rev. Terence L. Elsberry, an Episcopal priest, officiated.

headline: Megan Barshop, Benjamin Laitman
text: Megan Elizabeth Barshop, a daughter of Leslie Barshop and Ronald Barshop of Great Neck, N.Y., was married Saturday evening to Benjamin Morris Laitman, the son of Dr. Leila B. Laitman and Jeffrey T. Laitman of Great Neck. Rabbi Jerome K. Davidson officiated at Water’s Edge, an event space in Long Island City, Queens.

headline: Anita Gutwein, Stephanie Cohen
text: Anita Gutwein and Stephanie Meredith Cohen were married Saturday in Long Island City, Queens. Rabbi Jodie L. Siff officiated at Studio Square, an events space.

headline: Rupa Patel and Hemil Khandwala
text: Rupa Mahendra Patel, a daughter of Nalini Patel and Mahendra Patel of Monroe Township, N.J., was married Saturday to Hemil Nitin Khandwala, the son of Renu Khandwala and Nitin Khandwala of Livingston, N.J. Pandit Harendra R. Dave, a Hindu priest, officiated at the Venetian, a banquet hall in Garfield, N.J.

headline: Jenny Wang, Allen Ho
text: Jenny Jia-Yin Wang and Dr. Allen Szu-Hao Ho were married Saturday. Marisa E. Rolland, a friend of the couple who was ordained by the Universal Life Church in order to officiate, performed the ceremony at the St. Regis Monarch Beach, a resort in Dana Point, Calif.

headline: Rosemary Smith, Jason Szanyi
text: Rosemary Friedman Smith, the daughter of Dian G. Smith and Robert S. Smith of New York, was married there Saturday evening to Jason Michael Szanyi, a son of Carol A. Szanyi and Michael R. Szanyi of Munster, Ind. The Rev. Nora Smith, an Episcopal priest and an aunt of the bride, officiated at a nondenominational ceremony at the Loeb Boathouse in Central Park.

headline: Michelle Schechter and Brian Deutsch
text: Michelle Lauren Schechter and Brian Mitchell Deutsch were married Saturday evening by Rabbi David Gaffney at the Angel Orensanz Foundation in New York.

headline: Valerie Baron, Ari Gerstman
text: Valerie Miriam Baron and Ari Benjamin Gerstman were married Monday at the District of Columbia Marriage Bureau in the H. Carl Moultrie Courthouse. Deena Whittington, the supervisor of the marriage bureau, officiated. On Nov. 17, the couple had a religious ceremony, led by Rabbi Shimon Brand, at Crane Arts, a visual- and performing-arts space in Philadelphia.

headline: CJ Kim and Gene Lee
text: Chongjin Kim and Gene Whan Lee are to be married Sunday evening at the Pierre in New York. The Rev. C. William Mercer, a minister of the Church of Divine Science, is to officiate.

headline: Samantha Smith, Adam Skollar
text: Samantha Jo Smith, the daughter of Emilie A. Smith and Gary S. Smith of New City, N.Y., was married Saturday evening to Adam Max Skollar, the son of Marcia Skollar and Robert Skollar of New York. Cantor Bruce L. Ruben officiated at the Grand Hyatt in New York.

headline: Lindsay Brown, John Stanley
text: Lindsay Ann Brown and John Russell Stanley were married Saturday at St. Matthew Roman Catholic Church in Norwalk, Conn. Msgr. Walter C. Orlowski, the church’s pastor, performed the ceremony.

headline: Jill Jacoby, Richard Brugger Jr.
text: Jill Ann Jacoby and Richard Alois Brugger Jr. were married Saturday at Christ Church in Shrewsbury, N.J. The Rev. Lisa Sauber Mitchell, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.

headline: Eric Dyer, Michael Tino
text: Eric David Dyer and the Rev. Michael James Tino are to be married Sunday at Round Hill House, an event space in Washingtonville, N.Y. The Rev. Amy Kulesza DeBeck, a Unitarian Universalist minister, is to officiate.

headline: Alexandra Hines, David Watters
text: Alexandra Chisholm Hines and David McLean Watters were married Saturday evening at the Convent of the Sacred Heart in New York. The Rev. Thomas E. Collins, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

headline: Robert Jones, Graham Reed
text: Robert Earle Jones and Graham Marshall Reed were married Friday in Manhattan. Cynthia Weiss Asher, a friend who became a Universal Life minister to officiate, led the ceremony in Strawberry Fields in Central Park. On Saturday, the couple had a ceremony, also led by Ms. Asher, that included Jewish, Christian and Buddhist traditions as well as an Apache blessing, at Edgewood Country Club in River Vale, N.J.

headline: Lauren Shadford and Glendon Breismeister
text: Lauren Alisa Shadford and Glendon Lambert Breismeister were married Saturday in Brooklyn. The Rev. Craig S. Breismeister, a minister of the United Church of Christ and a brother of the groom, officiated at the Montauk Club.

headline: Matt Rice and Michael Krans
text: Ronald Matthew Rice and Michael Jay Krans were married Saturday evening at Haven’s Kitchen, a cooking school and event space in New York. Andrew T. Krans, the brother of Mr. Krans who became a Universal Life minister for the occasion, officiated.

headline: Danielle Dineen, Andrew Earls
text: Danielle Anne Dineen and Andrew Wyatt Earls were married Saturday at St. Jean Baptiste Roman Catholic Church in New York. The Rev. Anthony Schueller, the church’s pastor, performed the ceremony.

headline: Sarah Mendell, Keith Flemmer
text: Sarah Elizabeth Nichols Mendell, the daughter of Martha A. Nichols and Dr. Nelson I. Mendell of New York, was married Saturday to Keith Daniel Anthony Flemmer, a son of Daniel W. G. Flemmer and Patricia Flemmer of East London, South Africa. The Rev. Brian Hill, an Anglican priest, performed the ceremony at St. Barnabas Church in Cape Town, South Africa.

headline: Danielle O’Connor, Charles Nerko
text: Danielle Christine O’Connor and Charles Jude Nerko were married Saturday at St. Joseph Church in Garden City, N.Y. The Rev. Michael F. Duffy, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.
