text: Jeannette Markus and Dr. Douglas F. DeOrchis were married Saturday evening at Sundy House, a historic inn in Delray Beach, Fla. The Rev. Dan Myers, a Presbyterian minister, officiated.

headline: Eric Kite, Gregory Watson
text: Michael Eric Kite and Gregory Francis Watson were married Saturday at the Universalist National Memorial Church in Washington. Arthur S. Martinson, a Unitarian Universalist deacon, officiated.

headline: Mary Frazier, Andrew Stone
text: Mary Kathryn Frazier and Andrew Mark Stone were married Saturday evening at the Woman’s National Democratic Club in Washington. Christopher Bolyai, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the event, officiated.

headline: Shaken in First, Cotto Is Beaten After 12th
text: Several days before attempting to defend his World Boxing Association super welterweight title against Miguel Cotto at Madison Square Garden, Austin Trout declared “I’m the present and future of the sport.”

headline: College Football Replay: Dec. 1
text: Oklahoma beat T.C.U. for a share of the Big 12 title and Tulsa won the Conference USA crown during Championship Week.

headline: Newswallah: Long Reads Edition
text: “He shakes his head vigorously when a question is met with a denial. He demands answers, insisting that India needs to know the truth. He cuts off discussions to share his own thoughts before allowing the show to continue. He dislikes separatists, child molesters, racist articles in foreign newspapers, and Pakistan.”

headline: Attackers at U.S.-Afghan Base Wore Coalition Uniforms
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Taliban forces attacked a large coalition airfield in eastern Afghanistan early Sunday, detonating three car bombs near the entrance and engaging in a two-hour gun battle that killed nine insurgents, four Afghan guards and at least four civilians whose vehicle was caught in the cross-fire, Afghan officials and witnesses said.

headline: Egyptian Court Postpones Ruling on Constitutional Assembly
text: CAIRO — Egypt’s constitutional court on Sunday put off its much-awaited ruling on the legitimacy of the Islamist-led legislative assembly that drafted a new charter last week, accusing a crowd of Islamists outside the courthouse of intimidating its judges.

headline: Team in Transition Needs Some Direction
text: To say that the Red Bulls are lurching from one underachieving soccer area of Europe to another for their top management — the Scottish are replacing the Scandinavians — would be an understatement. But, Jack Bell writes in Sunday’s Times, the franchise needs to do something — again — to try to turn itself around.

headline: Nine Killed When Highway Tunnel Collapses in Japan
text: TOKYO — Nine people were found dead early Monday after their cars were crushed by slabs of concrete that fell from the ceiling of a tunnel in eastern Japan, severing a major highway leading to Tokyo.

headline: Poor Women and Children Faced With Fiscal Threat
text: As negotiating and posturing over the looming “fiscal cliff” continues, one phrase we hear less often than we should is “nondefense discretionary spending.” A boring string of words if ever there was one, it’s a category of spending that will play a role whether we go off the cliff or if we avoid it with a grand bargain, since it stands to see drastic cuts either way. Those abstract, boring words represent very concrete assistance to women and children living in poverty. A significant reduction in governmental spending in that opaquely named category will disproportionately affect programs they rely on.

headline: Field Notes in Ergonomic Diversity: Standup Workers Speak
text: Dr. Michael Roizen marches, in steady, measured steps, at the forefront of the upright workers movement. That “movement” is not a union uprising, but a reference to the growing numbers of office workers who are rising from their chairs to stand, even walk, for health reasons.

headline: When the World Ends
text: The series is featuring occasional works of fiction. This is one.

headline: The Full McConnell
text: In his interview with the Wall Street Journal, Mitch McConnell finally mentioned a few sort-of specifics about what spending cuts the GOP wants: raising the Medicare age, charging higher premiums to affluent Medicare recipients, and changing the price indexing of Social Security. But how much does all this amount to?

headline: The Real Scandal Behind Benghazi
text: For conservatives, the Benghazi scandal is a Watergate-like presidential cover-up. For liberals, it is a fabricated Republican witch-hunt — aimed squarely at Susan Rice, a candidate to succeed Secretary of State Hilary Clinton. For me, Benghazi is something else: a call to act on an enduring post-9/11 problem that both political parties ignore.

headline: Transgender Latinas Find a Refuge in Queens
text: Two years ago, smugglers buried a woman named Joselyn in Matamoros, a Mexican border city that attracts immigrants waiting to cross into the United States. Several men encased her body in dirt, covered her face with leaves and told her to wait until Border Patrol agents had disappeared to dig herself out.

headline: Disruptions: Silencing the Voices of Militants on Twitter
text: Twitter, perhaps more than any other social media outlet, has become one of the most powerful tools to promote democracy in the Middle East.

headline: The Vanishing of the Nuns
text: In 1965, when the average age of a baby boomer was 10, there were 180,000 nuns in the United States. Today there are about 56,000. But even more dramatic than this decline is the age of the average Roman Catholic sister — 74 years old.

headline: ‘Twilight’ and ‘Lincoln’ Thrive at Box Office
text: Post-Thanksgiving audiences dined on cinematic leftovers over the weekend. “The Twilight Saga: Breaking Dawn — Part 2” (Lionsgate) repeated as the No. 1 movie at North American theaters, taking in an estimated $17.4 million, for a three-week total of about $254.6 million, according to Hollywood.com, which compiles box-office data. “Skyfall” (Sony) was a close second, taking in $17 million, for a four-week total of about $246 million. Steven Spielberg’s “Lincoln” (Disney) placed third, with ticket sales of $13.51 million; “Lincoln,” a leading Oscar contender, is turning into a runaway hit, at least as far as serious historical dramas go these days, taking in about $83.7 million over four weeks. DreamWorks Animation’s struggling “Rise of the Guardians” (Paramount) was a whisker behind, taking in an estimated $13 million, for a two-week total of $48.9 million. Another Oscar contender, Ang Lee’s “Life of Pi” (20th Century Fox), was fifth, selling about $12 million in tickets, for a two-week total of $48.4 million. The weekend included one notable flop: “Killing Them Softly,” a drama starring Brad Pitt and released by the Weinstein Company (with financing from the Oracle heiress Megan Ellison), arrived in seventh place, taking in about $7 million.

headline: A Round of Golf for Presidents 42 and 44
text: President Obama took advantage of the unseasonably warm December weather on Sunday to head to the golf course with his most prominent campaign surrogate, former President Bill Clinton.

headline: European Financial Officials Will Meet, Again, to Address the Greek Crisis
text: BRUSSELS — They meet yet again. And once more, the agenda will be dominated by a looming deadline in the unfinished business of Greece.

headline: What’s on Sunday
text: 9 P.M. (Lifetime) FINDING MRS. CLAUS (2012) When Santa’s wife (Mira Sorvino) feels neglected by her distracted husband, she travels to Las Vegas to help a small girl with a Christmas wish — and to treat herself to a bit of a fling. With the aid of some magic sparkle dust, Mrs. Claus is transformed from frumpy to fabulous, and Santa (Will Sasso, above, with Ms. Sorvino) trails after her, trying to make amends. But what happens in Vegas may end up affecting the holiday around the world.

headline: Negotiators Leading Talks on Fiscal Crisis Defend Stands
text: WASHINGTON – At a stalemate in their talks to avoid a self-imposed fiscal crisis at the end of this month, the lead negotiators for the White House and Congressional Republicans used the Sunday morning news shows to defend their positions and blame the other side for the impasse.

headline: With Carbon Dioxide Emissions at Record High, Worries on How to Slow Warming
text: Global emissions of carbon dioxide were at a record high in 2011 and are likely to take a similar jump in 2012, scientists reported Sunday — the latest indication that efforts to limit such emissions are failing.

headline: Islamists Protest Egypt Court
text: Demonstrations by President Mohamed Morsi's Islamist supporters prompted Egypt's Supreme Constitutional Court to cancel its session Sunday.

headline: What’s on Monday
text: 8 P.M. (TCM) BABY PEGGY, THE ELEPHANT IN THE ROOM (2012) Peggy-Jean Montgomery, left, a daughter of a professional cowboy turned stuntman who moved his family to Hollywood, was 19 months old when she captured the attention of the director Fred Fishbach. Impressed by her plucky demeanor and good behavior, he cast her in some of Century Studios’ comedy shorts, sometimes opposite Brownie the Wonder Dog. As the third great child star of the silent era, after Baby Marie and Jackie Coogan, Peggy made about 150 shorts in all, working eight-hour days, six days a week, and performing stunts like being held underwater and escaping a burning building. In 1923 she earned the nickname Million-Dollar Baby when Universal lured her away from Century with the chance to make feature films for $1.5 million annually. But soon her father and the producer Sol Lesser argued about her salary, and Lesser not only fired her but also blackballed her in Hollywood. By the age of 11 Baby Peggy was a has-been. When she reached adulthood, she discovered that her family had spent her earnings — more than $2 million. Calling herself Diana Serra Cary, Peggy became an author and film historian as well as an advocate for laws protecting child actors. This tribute begins with Vera Iwerebor’s documentary, filmed shortly before the actress’s 90th birthday in 2008. It is followed by “Captain January” (1924), a silent feature about a lighthouse keeper (Hobart Bosworth) who raises a child found washed ashore in a ship’s wreckage, at 9; and three of her few remaining shorts: “Carmen, Jr.” (1923), a spoof on Bizet’s “Carmen” and the tango, at 10:15; “Such Is Life” (1924), loosely based on Hans Christian Andersen’s “Little Match Girl,” at 10:30; and “Peg o’ the Mounted” (1924), about a pint-size Mountie who hunts down a gang of moonshiners, led by a giant of a man played by Jack Earle, who stood roughly 7 feet 7 inches.

headline: Stores Shut in Protest as New Strife Grips Syria
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — As Syrian government forces pressed their counteroffensive on the outskirts of Damascus and a car bomb exploded in the central city of Homs, merchants around the country closed their shops over the weekend in response to a call for peaceful protest, suggesting that the civil disobedience movement, though overshadowed lately by intense fighting, still has the ability to mobilize Syrians.

headline: Nets’ Guiding Force Is Still Searching for His Scoring Touch
text: MIAMI — Deron Williams had ice strapped to both knees, his left thigh and his right wrist, none of which ached as much as his battered self-esteem.

headline: Airbus Parent Expected to Alter Base of Its Investors
text: PARIS — The board of European Aeronautic Defense & Space, the parent company of Airbus, was expected as early as Monday evening to announce a significant restructuring of its core shareholder base that would, for the first time, give the German government a direct stake in the group on par with that of France.

headline: Hollande Victory May Be Pyrrhic
text: When it ended a face-off with the world’s biggest steel company Friday evening, the French government cast the outcome as a job-saving victory.

headline: Knicks Stay Perfect at Home as Wallace Steals Show
text: In Sunday’s matinee at Madison Square Garden, the player who created the game’s most intriguing, head-scratching moment was also the player who could not stay on the court for more than two minutes. Some Knicks fans groaned and others applauded as they watched Rasheed Wallace leave the court before he could even break a sweat.

headline: Operation Rolling Tantrum
text: Oh, boy. This isn’t going to end, even when or if a deal is reached on defusing the austerity bomb; John Boehner has just declared that he’s going to hold the full faith and credit of the United States hostage every time we hit the debt limit. Nor will it be a case of holding the nation at gunpoint until it meets GOP demands; Republicans are signaling that they don’t intend to make any specific proposals, they’re just going to yell and stamp their feet until Obama soothes them somehow.

headline: What the ‘Swing Counties’ Tell Us About the Future of American Politics
text: WASHINGTON — In the eight states where President Barack Obama and Gov. Mitt Romney competed fully there were 94 so-called swing counties that voted for George W. Bush in 2004 and the Democrat in 2008; in November they split, Obama winning 48 and Romney 46.

headline: Samba Purred Serenely, With Stealthy Metaphor
text: Paulinho da Viola, limber and elegant at 70, is a messenger of samba de morro, the music of the 1930s from the hills around Rio, in its calmest form. At Carnegie Hall on Wednesday he represented an almost precommercialized culture, an idea of Brazilian popular music that hardly acknowledges the happening of bossa nova in the ’50s, let alone pagode and samba-reggae or any other digital-age development. A losing battle, you might think.

headline: Homages to Mom, With a Pinch of Sentiment and Literary Side Dishes
text: Has “Mommie Dearest” seen its day? To judge by two memoirs by New York insiders, fewer writers have mothers like Joan Crawford — or Momma Rose — than they used to.

headline: Better Late Than Never, a Nod to ‘Pierrot Lunaire’
text: If you are a classical music fan and you are breathing, it is likely that you will encounter Stravinsky’s “Rite of Spring” this season. May 29 is the 100th anniversary of that work’s tumultuous premiere in Paris, and the celebrations are already in full swing.

headline: A Growing Repertory for Swaying Hips and Busy Feet ...
text: When Robert Battle took over as the artistic director of Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater last year, it was the equivalent of being given the helm of a luxury cruise ship. In the scrappy modern-dance world most directors are still in paddle boats.

headline: ... Not to Mention the Essence of a West Indian Heritage
text: In 1978 the Jamaican choreographer Garth Fagan had an idea for a dance that would explore his West Indies origins. He also wanted to try something new: By stripping away the decorative elements of African and Caribbean dance he aimed to reveal its essence. The resulting “From Before” is one of Mr. Fagan’s most admired works.

headline: McElroy Replaces Sanchez and Leads Jets to Victory Over Cardinals
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — One after another, the two quarterbacks appeared in the Jets’ interview room. The first ambled in still wearing his cleats, his eye black and his uniform pants. He smiled. He joked. He dissected the touchdown pass that resuscitated an offense, a team, a stadium, and when he was finished, he left.

headline: Lending a Slide and Scoot to a Jazz Beat
text: Although jazz and tap dance grew up together, a tap-dancer performing at a jazz club is a fairly rare event these days. And what Maurice Chestnut was doing at the Jazz Standard last week is even rarer: not headlining or sitting in but playing as the fourth member of a quartet, the Timeline Band of the esteemed pianist Geri Allen.

headline: Missouri Bishop’s Conviction Leaves Clergy Divided
text: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — In the three months since Bishop Robert W. Finn became the first American prelate convicted of failing to report a pedophile priest, lay people and victims’ advocates have repeatedly called for his resignation.

headline: ‘Arden Court’
text: Photos of the Alvin Ailey Dance Theater in Paul Taylor’s 1981 work.

headline: Philosophy and the Poetic Imagination
text: Perhaps now more than ever, we spend our days immersed in language. We communicate—talk, write and read—through a burgeoning array of forms and technologies. But most of us rarely stop to think about how language works, or how come we succeed in getting our ideas across in words. It all seems to happen naturally. Poets, novelists, speechwriters or the merely curious sometimes confront these questions, but it is a job that often falls to linguists and philosophers of language.

headline: Monty Python Sued Over ‘Spamalot’ Money
text: The musical “Monty Python’s Spamalot” (with Michael McGrath, above left, and Tim Curry) has earned hundreds of millions of dollars on Broadway and abroad, but how some of that money should be distributed is in dispute, the BBC reported. Mark Forstater, a producer of “Monty Python and the Holy Grail,” the film on which “Spamalot” is based, is suing Monty Python members over royalty rights. Mr. Forstater argues that he has not been adequately compensated since the musical opened in 2005 on Broadway, where it grossed more than $175 million during its initial run. Three Python members, Eric Idle, Michael Palin and Terry Jones, are scheduled to appear in court in London.

headline: Alabama-Georgia Classic Merely a Warm-Up
text: ATLANTA — In the aftermath of a college football classic as close and tense as any game this season, as good or better than any Southeastern Conference final that came before, Alabama lingered on the Georgia game, on what just happened. The Crimson Tide topped the Bulldogs on Saturday, but barely, victory not assured until the game clock read all zeros.

headline: Honors for ‘Amour’ at European Awards
text: “Amour,” the latest film from Austrian director Michael Haneke, almost performed a clean sweep at the European Film Awards on Saturday in Valletta, Malta, where it won for best picture, best director for Mr. Haneke, best actress for Emmanuelle Riva and best actor for Jean-Louis Trintignant. The film follows an octogenarian couple played by Ms. Riva and Mr. Trintignant as they deal with illness; it was also written by Mr. Haneke, but he did not win the screenwriting prize. That went to Tobias Lindholm and Thomas Vinterberg for their film “Jagten” (“The Hunt”), about a teacher in a Danish village who is wrongly accused of child abuse. Voted on by 2,700 members of the European Film Academy, awards were also given to Steve McQueen’s “Shame” for cinematography and editing and to the Italian filmmaker Bernardo Bertolucci for lifetime achievement.

headline: Mix-and-Match Ensemble Erases Borders With Enthusiasm
text: Quixotic aims filled “Red Hot + Cuba” at the Brooklyn Academy of Music on Saturday night, the second of its two shows there. Andres Levín, a Venezuelan musician and producer who frequently visits Cuba, set out to bring Havana’s abundant live music to New York City, sampling some of the city’s diverse scenes — the idealistic Latin-American folk-rock called trova, the retro Cuban style rekindled by the Buena Vista Social Club and the revved-up, funked-up Cuban salsa called timba — with a group of 24 musicians.

headline: Big Boys Lay Out Their Oscar Bait
text: LOS ANGELES — At the Governors Awards banquet of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences here on Saturday three weathered honorees — the stuntman Hal Needham, the documentarian D. A. Pennebaker and the film advocate George Stevens Jr. — held the spotlight through most of the night.

headline: Leery of a Merger, a Hospital in Brooklyn Plans to Declare Bankruptcy
text: A financially troubled hospital serving a largely African-American and Caribbean niche of central Brooklyn is planning to declare bankruptcy this week, hospital officials said on Sunday, raising concerns that New York State may force it to close or merge with another institution.

headline: Sprawling Love Story, Abridged
text: It was good to catch up with the career of the Chinese opera star Zhang Jun over the weekend. When I last encountered him, in Shanghai in 1998, Mr. Zhang, then 23 and also an aspiring pop singer, was rehearsing Liu Mengmei, the male lead role in the classic Chinese opera “The Peony Pavilion” for a production by Chen Shi-Zheng with the Shanghai Kunqu Opera Company, which was intended for the Lincoln Center Festival.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: Rebound, as Demure as Ever
text: LAS VEGAS — This city doesn’t necessarily mean the end, not anymore. It’s a town of summation, site of neither genesis nor graveyard. For a singer a residency here isn’t merely a sinecure for the once-was but a confirmation of cultural saturation. If you can make it here, you’ve made it everywhere.

headline: Fall North American Championships
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Sunday was the last day of play at the American Contract Bridge League’s Fall North American Championships here. Ten teams qualified for the final day of the premier event, the Reisinger Board-a-Match Teams, led by Monaco, captained by Pierre Zimmermann. The James Cayne team, winner the last two years, was eighth.

text: To the Editor:

text: To the Editor:

headline: In App Land, Lots of Ways to Get a Ride
text: In Monday’s Times, Brian X. Chen writes about the legal struggles of Uber, whose app connects users with car service drivers. Uber has captured the fancy of many riders but faces opposition from regulators and the taxi industry. While the company is perhaps the most prominent tech start-up looking to shake up the car service and taxi industries, it is not alone. Here is a quick look at the approaches being pursued by various companies.

headline: Knightly Activity
text: The one-l lama, he’s a priest;The TWO-L llama, he’s a beast.And I will bet a silk pajamaThere isn’t any three-l lllama.— Ogden Nash

headline: A Spate of Rebranding for Spanish-Language TV
text: It’s a race to be the best of the second best. On Monday, Univision, the dominant Spanish-language network in the United States, will announce a new name and look for its second-largest network, TeleFutura. The move is a direct shot at Telemundo, a rival for second place among domestic Spanish-speaking viewers.

headline: A Cleveland Newspaper Takes Steps to Prevent Cuts
text: While workers at many newspapers owned by Advance Publications have tried to brace themselves for what seems to be the inevitable — layoffs and the end of a daily print product — reporters and editors at The Plain Dealer in Cleveland are fighting back in an unusual way: they are taking their case directly to the public.

headline: Economic Reports for the Week Ahead
text: ECONOMIC REPORTS Data will include ISM manufacturing index for November and construction spending for October (Monday), ADP employment for November; revised third-quarter productivity, ISM service index for November and factory orders for October (Wednesday), weekly jobless claims (Thursday) and unemployment for November, Thomson Reuters/University of Michigan consumer sentiment index for December and consumer credit for October (Friday).

headline: A Stalwart of Time Inc. Packs Up
text: In the decade I’ve covered John Huey, I’d never once been to his magisterial office on the 34th floor of the Time & Life building. It is large and imposing in a way its occupant is not, an unlikely landing spot for an old newspaper hack. On the wall is a photograph of William Faulkner, “the patron saint of all hard-drinking Southern writers,” as Mr. Huey, a native of Atlanta, describes him.

headline: Chinese Media Retreat After Reports of Unexpected ‘Black Jail’ Verdict
text: BEIJING — A brief news article published on Sunday by a score of state-run news media outlets offered an account of an unexpected judicial verdict: a Beijing municipal court had sentenced 10 people to jail for illegally detaining and assaulting a group of citizens who had come to the capital to lodge complaints about official malfeasance in their hometown in China’s central Henan Province.

headline: ‘From Before’
text: Photos of the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater in Garth Fagan’s work.

headline: Some Analysts Doubt Dire Predictions on Tax Increase Fallout
text: As anxious investors assess their portfolios in light of expected tax increases on investment income, hedge fund manager Douglas Kass has a simple message: Relax.

headline: Chris Stamp, a Manager and Discoverer of the Who, Dies at 70
text: Chris Stamp, who as a cockney kid from East London aspired to make a documentary film about the rise of British rock in the 1960s and ended up helping to discover and manage a raucous working-class quartet called the Who, died on Nov. 24 in Manhattan. He was 70.

headline: A New Wildlife Magazine Aimed at the Very Young
text: After 50 years of guiding children through wildlife and ecology on his own, Ranger Rick is getting a helping hand in the form of a younger sibling.

headline: News From the Advertising Industry
text: Accounts

headline: Lies! Murder! Lexicography!
text: HERE’S a tip: if you see the words “dictionary” and “scandal” in a sensational headline, prepare to be disappointed.

headline: Being There
text: IN a smart, disheartening piece in The New York Times Magazine last month, Robert Worth surveyed the frustration of American diplomats who signed up to engage the world — even dreamed of changing it — and now find themselves encumbered by the safeguards and protocols of a risk-averse Washington. It is hard to change the world when you live in a fortress and travel in an armored motorcade.

headline: Do Filibusters Stall the Senate or Give It Purpose?
text: Many want to improve the filibuster rules. But can they change without losing the Senate’s value as a counterweight to the House?

headline: Partnership Offers Support for Media Entrepreneurs
text: Can the nascent entrepreneurial ideas bouncing around Silicon Valley help reinvent public media?

headline: Rick Majerus, College Basketball Coach, Dies at 64
text: Rick Majerus, who never headed the elite programs in college basketball but who became a leading coach, winning more than 500 major-college games, died on Saturday in Los Angeles. He was 64.

headline: Book by 2 From Google Takes a Deep Look at the Web
text: “The Internet is the largest experiment involving anarchy in history,” begins a new book written by two top Google executives, which aims to explain how this experiment will play out in politics, business and even personal lives.

headline: Displaced Residents Grapple With Hurdles of Going Home
text: MAMPUJÁN, Colombia — The jungle owns Mampuján, this once-prosperous farming town near the Caribbean coast that has become a symbol of Colombia’s descent into lawlessness – and now its efforts to turn things around.

headline: Monday’s Matchup: Giants at Redskins
text: Giants (7-4) at Redskins (5-6)8:30 p.m., ESPNLine: Giants by 3

headline: Ford Redoubles Effort to Reawaken Its Sleepy Lincoln Brand
text: DEARBORN, Mich. — In the fiercely competitive world of luxury cars, the Ford Motor Company’s Lincoln brand has long been stuck in the slow lane, with stodgy models, older buyers and a distinct lack of pizazz.

headline: Lines Blur as Texas Gives Industries a Bonanza
text: DALLAS — The Preston Hollow neighborhood has been home to many of Texas’ rich and powerful — George and Laura Bush, Mark Cuban, T. Boone Pickens, Ross Perot. So it is hardly surprising that a recent political fund-raiser was held there on the back terrace of a 20,000-square-foot home overlooking lush gardens with life-size bronze statues of the host’s daughters.

headline: A Feisty Start-Up Is Met With Regulatory Snarl
text: WASHINGTON — Summoning a taxi or car service with your smartphone feels like the future. City governments around the world can agree on that. But many of them are proposing new rules that would run Uber, one of the most prominent ride-requesting apps, off the road.

headline: France’s Floating Generation
text: As youth unemployment hits 22 percent, many young people cannot find jobs that get them on the path to being taxpaying, property-owning adults.

headline: A Troubling Portrait of Domestic Work
text: If workplaces were fairer, domestic workers would be protected by minimum-wage and antidiscrimination laws and by unemployment insurance. They would also have things most employees take for granted, like meal breaks. But too many nannies, caregivers and housecleaners have none of these things. A new study confirms what advocacy groups have struggled to convey: that domestic workers, a vital but invisible sector of the economy, are suffering the predictable consequences of toiling behind closed doors in an unregulated industry.

headline: Young, Educated and Jobless in France
text: LILLE, France — Justine Forriez wakes up early to go onto the computer to look for a job. She calls university friends and contacts; she goes to the unemployment office every week, though mostly for the companionship, and has taken a course in job hunting. She has met with 10 different recruiters since May and sent out 200 résumés.

headline: Shattering Records in the Giant Slalom, Ligety Leaves His Rivals Marveling
text: BEAVER CREEK, Colo. — Ted Ligety of the United States charged to victory down the Birds of Prey giant slalom track Sunday with a combined time of 2 minutes 25.59 seconds. After setting a course record for margin of victory, beating Marcel Hirscher of Austria by 1.76 seconds, Ligety bowed and kissed the snow in the finish area.

headline: Perfidious Prosecutors
text: In an egregious case of bad judgment, two federal prosecutors in the United States attorney’s office in New Orleans surreptitiously posted hostile comments on a public news site about defendants in cases the office was pursuing and then lied about it. That conduct now jeopardizes important criminal convictions and has resulted in a judge’s call for an independent investigation of the office.

headline: Promises on AIDS Are Not Enough
text: Experts know how to control the global spread of the AIDS virus. What’s missing is enough money and political will to apply proven tactics widely enough to change the course of the epidemic.

headline: DVR Use One Factor in Networks’ Low Ratings
text: If you ask several of the top programmers in network television what is going wrong with their ratings this season, they offer a litany of answers: jarring schedule disruptions from debates, election night and Hurricane Sandy, for instance, as well as the ever-increasing defections toward delayed viewing and away from the nightly schedules that have defined network prime time since the days of radio.

headline: Amid Euphoria Over U.N. Vote, Palestinians Still Face Familiar Challenges
text: RAMALLAH, West Bank — “Now we have become a state!” Mahmoud Abbas, the president of the Palestinian Authority, announced Sunday to a crowd of thousands in the courtyard of his headquarters in this Palestinian city.

headline: A Georgia Main Street Paved in Red Carpet
text: SENOIA, Ga. — Unlike so many recession-weary towns, Senoia has a bustling Main Street. Dozens of new stores have opened, including a sushi bar, an antiques vendor and an Irish pub. City Hall has been repainted with money from the soaring tax revenues.

headline: Marine Life on a Warming Planet
text: Since the beginning of the industrial era, humans have pumped increasing amounts of carbon dioxide into the atmosphere. This has led not only to a warmer climate but also to significant changes in the chemistry of the oceans, which have long acted as a sink for carbon emissions but are being asked to absorb more than they can handle. The result is ocean acidification: increasingly corrosive seawater that has already ruined many coral reefs and over time could threaten the entire marine food chain.

headline: The Big Budget Mumble
text: In the ongoing battle of the budget, President Obama has done something very cruel. Declaring that this time he won’t negotiate with himself, he has refused to lay out a proposal reflecting what he thinks Republicans want. Instead, he has demanded that Republicans themselves say, explicitly, what they want. And guess what: They can’t or won’t do it.

headline: Chief of News Corp. Unit in Britain Is Resigning
text: Tom Mockridge, a longtime News Corporation official who served as chief executive of the company’s British newspapers in the aftermath of a phone hacking scandal, will step down.

headline: Collaboration in Gaza Leads to Grisly Fate
text: RAFAH, Gaza Strip — When Fadel Shalouf’s family went to pick up his body at the morgue the day after he was executed on a busy Gaza street corner, they found his hands still cuffed behind his back. Hamas, the militant faction that rules Gaza, did not provide a van to carry the body to burial, so they laid him on two men’s laps in the back of a sedan.

headline: Delta, Seeking London Access, Ponders a Stake in Virgin Atlantic
text: Delta Air Lines is in talks to buy Singapore Airlines’ 49 percent stake in Virgin Atlantic Airways, in an effort to bolster its international operations, particularly flights between New York and London, a person briefed on the matter said on Sunday.

headline: Young Immigrant Activists Cast a Wider Net
text: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — After a boisterous three-day congress here, more than 600 leaders of a national movement of young immigrants living in the country without legal papers voted to expand beyond their past demands for citizenship for young people, and to mobilize in support of a bill to legalize 11 million illegal immigrants in the United States.

headline: Pushing for Greater Immigration Reform
text: The United We Dream network’s platform calling for an “inclusive pathway to citizenship,” will increase pressure on President Obama and lawmakers to pass a comprehensive overhaul.

headline: A Forlorn Shuttle Points to Progress in the Rockaways
text: The travelers duck through a widened slit in a chain-link fence, a makeshift portal to a makeshift train ride above the ruins of the Rockaways. Doctor’s appointments await. So do school days. A grocery store with power. An A.T.M. And so they take their seats to travel through neighborhoods that are still missing many things. But not a subway, anymore. For two weeks now, a so-called H train has been running through a stretch of the Rockaways devastated by Hurricane Sandy, making stops at a limited number of the peninsula’s stations with the help of a connection called the Hammels Wye, which is not ordinarily used by passenger trains.

headline: Vietnam Veterans, Discharged Under Cloud, File Suit Saying Trauma Was Cause
text: NEW HAVEN — In the summer of 1968, John Shepherd Jr. enlisted in the Army, figuring that the draft would get him anyway. By January 1969, he was in the Mekong Delta, fighting with the Ninth Infantry Division.

headline: Jets’ Defense Gives Offense Plenty of Do-Overs
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — No matter how mightily the Jets struggled to score before Greg McElroy replaced Mark Sanchez at quarterback Sunday, members of the defense said their mind-set never changed. They were determined to get off the field on third down and give their offense the ball as often as possible, believing someone would eventually figure out what to do with it.

headline: Criticized as Weak in Past Talks, Obama Takes Harder Line
text: WASHINGTON — Amid demands from Republicans that President Obama propose detailed new spending cuts to avert the year-end fiscal crisis, his answer boils down to this: you first.

headline: Batch Helps the Steelers Look Like the Steelers
text: BALTIMORE — Charlie Batch hugged each teammate he encountered long and hard as the Pittsburgh Steelers streamed off the field, as if he knew this was his valedictory.

headline: Syria Moves Its Chemical Weapons, and U.S. and Allies Cautiously Take Note
text: WASHINGTON — The Syrian military’s movement of chemical weapons in recent days has prompted the United States and several allies to repeat their warning to President Bashar al-Assad that he would be “held accountable” if his forces used the weapons against the rebels fighting his government.

headline: Giant Is Full-Time Kicker and Part-Time Cobbler
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Most of the attributes that make the Giants’ Lawrence Tynes one of the best kickers in the N.F.L. are not surprising: A strong foot. An unshakable confidence. A short memory.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Reports on Alleged Fraud by 1-800-Flowers.com
text: The Senate Committee on Commerce, Science and Transportation, and the New York State Attorney General’s office have both investigated the role of 1-800-Flowers.com in an alleged fraud.

headline: David Oliver Relin, Adventurous Journalist, Dies at 49
text: David Oliver Relin, a journalist and adventurer who achieved acclaim as co-author of the best seller “Three Cups of Tea” (2006) and then suffered emotionally and financially as basic facts in the book were called into question, died Nov. 15 in Multnomah County, Ore. He was 49.

headline: A Mets Owner and Claims of Consumer Fraud
text: This article is by  Steve Eder,  Richard Sandomir and  Alison Leigh Cowan.

headline: Morgan Stanley Trader Faces Inquiry on Possible Manipulation
text: On paper, Glenn Hadden seemed to be the ideal person to run a large bond trading operation at Morgan Stanley when he was hired in early 2011. Mr. Hadden, a former Goldman partner, was one of the most profitable bond traders on Wall Street.

headline: Theater Prize Awarded
text: Amy Herzog has won the 2012 New York Times Outstanding Playwright Award for “After the Revolution,” her Off Broadway play about a politically radical family. The award, which comes with a $5,000 prize, was created in 2009 to support an American playwright whose work recently received its professional debut in New York. Ms. Herzog dedicated the award to her extended family, which inspired the characters in “After the Revolution.” The work was produced by Playwrights Horizons in 2010. Previous recipients include Kristoffer Diaz for “The Elaborate Entrance of Chad Deity,” Tarell Alvin McCraney for “The Brothers Size” and Dan LeFranc for “Sixty Miles to Silver Lake.” The selection committee included the Pulitzer Prize-winning playwrights Edward Albee, James Lapine and Lynn Nottage; the Pulitzer finalist Richard Greenberg; and current and former editors for The Times.

headline: War of Wills, Vocabularies and Virtues
text: They sure talk fancy in the clink these days.

headline: UBS Is Reported to Be Near a Deal on Rate Rigging
text: UBS, the Swiss banking giant, is close to reaching settlements with American and British authorities over the manipulation of interest rates, the latest case in a multiyear investigation that has rattled the financial industry and spurred a public outcry for broad reform.

headline: A Boulevard in Harlem Undergoes a Resurgence
text: It was not that long ago, Leon Ellis remembered as he stared from the window of his latest restaurant, when no one wanted any part of this section of Harlem, when cabdrivers would not stop here. The farthest taxis would venture uptown was 110th Street, a boundary that fractured the neighborhood from the rest of Manhattan.

headline: Spain Rodriguez, Artist of Underground Comics, Dies at 72
text: Spain Rodriguez, a cartoonist whose radical politics and hyperbolic macho imagery, all presented with sly humor, were influential elements in the rise of underground comics, died on Wednesday at his home in San Francisco. He was 72.

headline: A Day After Tragedy, a Bouquet on the Steps and an Unworn Jersey in a Locker
text: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — There was a single bouquet of flowers on the front steps of the pale green house at the end of the street. Ten minutes from Arrowhead Stadium, the house on the corner, with the wreath on the door and a stone on the stoop that reads “Dream,” looked routine, like the others on Crysler Avenue. If not for the flowers.

headline: Seahawks’ Wilson Shows He Belongs Near Head of Rookie Class
text: CHICAGO — Russell Wilson walked to the microphone shortly after Seattle’s 23-17 overtime win dressed in a sharp gray suit, crisp white shirt and dark tie. His trademark eye black was washed from his face.

headline: Gang Said to Have Been Vanquished in ’80s Makes Cameo in Extortion Case
text: When federal prosecutors accused three men of a loan-sharking scheme last week, the authorities vividly described how the men used threats of violence to ensure that they would be repaid.

headline: Homeless Man Is Grateful for Officer’s Gift of Boots. But He Again Is Barefoot.
text: After Officer Lawrence DePrimo knelt beside a barefoot man on a bitterly cold November night in Times Square, giving him a pair of boots, a photo of his random act of good will quickly took on a life of its own — becoming a symbol for a million acts of kindness that go unnoticed every day and a reminder that even in this tough, often anonymous city, people can still look out for one another.

text: THOUSAND OAKS, Calif. — After winning at Sherwood Country Club for the second time in his past two visits, Graeme McDowell joked that maybe he should invest in a membership and a lot.

headline: Liquor Baron’s Death Opens Market in Uttar Pradesh
text: Just hours after the politically connected businessman Gurdeep Singh Chadha was killed in a shootout in a Delhi farmhouse this month, thousands of liquor stores in Uttar Pradesh shut down, as did half a dozen movie theaters he owned.

headline: Fighting Hidden Illness Whose Draining Effects Are Noticed Every Day

headline: Behind a Call That Kept Nursing Home Patients in Storm’s Path
text: Hurricane Sandy was swirling northward, four days before landfall, and at the Sea Crest Health Care Center, a nursing home overlooking the Coney Island Boardwalk in Brooklyn, workers were gathering medicines and other supplies as they prepared to evacuate.

headline: Cashman’s Next Challenge: Taking a Patient Approach to Fixing the Yankees’ Offense
text: STAMFORD, Conn. — It has become a holiday tradition: on the eve of baseball’s winter meetings, the man in charge of the Yankees’ fluctuating roster, General Manager Brian Cashman, puts on an elf suit and rappels from the roof of the Landmark Building in Stamford, Conn.

headline: Dickey and Mets Enter Key Period for Contract Talks
text: NASHVILLE — R. A. Dickey is not officially the host of baseball’s winter meetings in his hometown, but he might as well be.

headline: Pentagon’s Top Technologist Joins I.B.M.
text: Last Friday afternoon, a half-hour after he said his goodbyes at the Pentagon, where he was assistant secretary of defense for research and engineering, Zachary Lemnios was discussing why his new job made sense as the next step in his career. “Exactly the right thing to do at the right time,” he said.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Monday, Dec. 3
text: It’s like we are in a shed of cows, waiting their turn for slaughtering. After what happened with my sons, I hate all the people; I even hate myself.

headline: Living With a Sound You Can’t Turn Off
text: Shortly after my 70th birthday, a high-pitched hum began in my left ear. I noticed it only during quiet times but soon realized that it never went away.

headline: Images of Brain Injuries in Athletes
text: Images of athletes’ brains illustrate the deterioration that can be caused by repeated mild head traumas.

headline: Study Bolsters Link Between Routine Hits and Brain Disease
text: The growing evidence of a link between head trauma and long-term, degenerative brain disease was amplified in an extensive study of athletes, military veterans and others who absorbed repeated hits to the head, according to new findings published in the scientific journal Brain.

headline: School Districts in 5 States Will Lengthen Their Calendars
text: The school day and year are about to get longer in 10 school districts in five states, where schools will add up to 300 hours to their calendars starting next fall.

headline: Parsi Money, Not Bodies, Key to Vulture Survival, Expert Says
text: Ask the director of the Bombay Natural History Society about vultures, and he will discuss the issue endlessly. Ask him about Parsis and their corpse disposal practices, and he will roll his eyes.

headline: Taking Photos, and Action, in Indonesia
text: In a region of Indonesia that is blessed with gold, copper and timber, the people who have lived there for centuries are cursed with poverty. The indigenous Papuans of the country’s two easternmost provinces have suffered, as they watched migrants come from other parts of the country to set up profitable businesses or get better-paying jobs.

headline: Are Digital Photographs Too Plentiful to Be Meaningful?
text: How often do you and your friends take photos? How many do you post on social media? Are there any photos, from your past or present, that are especially meaningful to you? Are those images digital only or have they been printed?

headline: The Debt Limit Is the Real Fiscal Cliff
text: Bruce Bartlett held senior policy roles in the Reagan and George H.W. Bush administrations and served on the staffs of Representatives Jack Kemp and Ron Paul. He is the author of “The Benefit and the Burden: Tax Reform – Why We Need It and What It Will Take.”

headline: How Will Aging Baby Boomers Affect Crash Rates?
text: While the number of older drivers is growing, it is not likely that these graying baby boomers will cause greater carnage on America’s roads, according to a new study by the Highway Loss Data Institute, which is affiliated with the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety. Both are financed by the insurance industry.

headline: What the Doha Climate Talks Could Do for Sustainable Development
text: While participants at last year’s climate meeting in Durban, South Africa, agreed on an extension of the troubled Kyoto Protocol, it is at this year’s meeting in Doha, Qatar, that policy makers have to agree on the pesky details, including long-term emission reduction goals.

headline: Behind the Cover Story: Nathaniel Rich on Falling in Love With a Jellyfish
text: Nathaniel Rich wrote this week’s cover story about a Japanese scientist who studies jellyfish that regenerate themselves. Rich is the author of the novel “The Mayor’s Tongue”; Farrar, Straus & Giroux will publish his second novel this spring. His last article for the magazine was about the Lower Ninth Ward in New Orleans.

headline: Terms of Greek Bond Buyback Top Expectations
text: LONDON — In a bold bid to reduce its debt burden, Greece offered on Monday to spend as much as 10 billion euros to buy back 30 billion euros of its bonds from investors and banks.

headline: British Lawmakers Accuse Multinationals of ‘Immorally’ Avoiding Taxes
text: The British government announced plans on Monday to crack down on tax dodgers as a parliamentary report criticized United States companies for what it described as tax avoidance.

headline: Cantor Fitzgerald to Buy Irish Brokerage Firm
text: LONDON – Cantor Fitzgerald agreed on Monday to acquire the Irish firm Dolmen Stockbrokers as part of its expansion into global markets.

headline: Winner Lose All
text: MADRID — The results of last week’s regional elections in Catalonia aren’t what they seem.

headline: What Ails You, Putin?
text: MOSCOW — If you type “Putin” on Yandex, the most popular search engine in the Russian language, a drop-down list appears: “Putin, Vladimir Vladimirovich,” “Putin stroke,” “Putin Wikipedia,” “Putin biography” and “Putin is ill.” In other words, the top five options include two regarding the Russian president’s rumored ill health. Even Putin’s ostensible longtime mistress is only No. 7 on this list of things that Russians want to know. The big question now is, What’s wrong with the president?

headline: UBS Approaches Deal on Rate Rigging
text: The Swiss bank UBS “is close to reaching settlements with American and British authorities over the manipulation of interest rates,” DealBook’s Ben Protess and Mark Scott report. “UBS is expected to pay more than $450 million to settle claims that some employees reported false rates to increase the bank’s profit, according to officials briefed on the matter who spoke on the condition of anonymity because the talks were private.”

headline: Malaysia Urged to Protect Domestic Workers
text: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia — Malaysia must punish the recruitment agents accused of forcing more than 100 foreign women to work as domestic help without pay and enforce laws to protect migrant workers, the Indonesian Embassy in Kuala Lumpur and a migrant workers’ support group said on Monday.

headline: Archer Daniels Raises Bid for GrainCorp
text: The Archer Daniels Midland Company raised its offer for GrainCorp of Australia on Monday, valuing the grain processor at about $2.9 billion, as A.D.M. pressed ahead with its unsolicited takeover bid.

headline: Monday Reading: Test-Flying the 787 Dreamliner
text: Test-flying the 787 Dreamliner, saying no to college, mortgage financing for small co-ops and other consumer-focused news from The New York Times.

headline: Asked & Answered | Aby Rosen
text: The German-born real estate mogul and prolific art collector Aby Rosen is Art Basel Miami Beach’s poster boy for parties, hosting A-list, superprivate dinners that bring together top art collectors, connoisseurs and the requisite fashion crowd.

headline: Designer to the Stars Takes a Stroll Down the Catwalk
text: LONDON — “When I see them, I remember every single dress,” says Valentino, as he walks down the runway, looking at chair labels in the audience reading “Jennifer Lopez” or “Carla Bruni.” The designer points to dresses worn by the famous to the Oscars — or, in the case of Jacqueline Kennedy, for her 1968 Greek island wedding to Aristotle Onassis.

headline: New York Times Seeks Buyouts From 30 in Newsroom
text: Aiming to cut costs in an increasingly troubled advertising environment, The New York Times announced on Monday morning that it would offer buyout packages to newsroom employees. While the primary goal of the buyout program is to trim managers and other nonunion employees from its books, the company is offering employees represented by the Newspaper Guild the chance to volunteer for buyout packages as well.

headline: Saputo to Buy Morningstar Unit of Dean Foods for $1.45 Billion
text: Saputo, a Canadian dairy processor, agreed on Monday to buy the Morningstar division of Dean Foods for about $1.45 billion in cash to help expand its presence in the United States.

headline: Trump Takes On a Farmer, and the Farmer Wins
text: New York’s bloviator-in-chief has landed ignobly on the losing end of a couple of recent elections. Yes, as you have probably figured out, the reference is to Donald J. Trump.

headline: News Corp. Gives Details on Its Corporate Split
text: 8:15 p.m. | Updated A phone hacking scandal and restless shareholders may have forced Rupert Murdoch to split News Corporation into two companies, but on Monday he celebrated the decision by pouring Veuve Clicquot Champagne over the head of his newest editor.

headline: New Glimpses of the Twin Towers’ Past
text: Anthony W. Robins did not set out to amass one of the most important surviving archives of the original World Trade Center. Though he is an architectural historian devoted to the buildings of New York City, Mr. Robins didn’t even set out to study the twin towers.

headline: Pete Wells, Restaurant Critic, Answers Readers’ Questions
text: Pete Wells, the chief restaurant critic of The New York Times, answered selected readers’ questions Monday and Tuesday.

headline: After Years of Indies, Will Studios Triumph?
text: The Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences handed out its Governors Awards on Saturday night. The honorees were the stuntman Hal Needham, the documentarian D. A. Pennebaker and the film advocate George Stevens Jr. But the celebratory feel in the Ray Dolby Ballroom in Hollywood had as much to do with past achievements as with the Oscar season ahead.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: Smithsonian: The strange, sweet stench of the durian fruit, explained. — Julia Moskin

headline: A Couple at a Crossroads: How to Build?
text: My wife, Julia, and I are fast approaching the end of an internship that involves building a straw bale house in Moab, Utah, with the nonprofit Community Rebuilds. We took this four-month volunteer position to gain experience in constructing someone else’s affordable green home before beginning to build our own on land Julia’s family owns near Woodstock, N.Y.

headline: Refuge for Healing Veterans
text: The Veterans’ Sanctuary in Trumansburg, N.Y., provides a holistic wellness program and rehabilitation center for veterans, with a focus on those returning from Iraq and Afghanistan.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Network TV’s Struggles, and the Pope to Add ‘Followers’ on Twitter
text: Other than at NBC, prime time ratings of network television are down this fall – in the case of Fox and CBS, sharply down, Bill Carter writes. Programmers can come up with a number of reasons why it has been hard for the networks to grab audience attention, what with all the big news distractions of an election and Hurricane Sandy. But, still, these executives concede, the shows themselves have failed to entice: the only new series to crack the top 30 among 18- to 49-year-olds is the NBC drama “Revolution.” Lately, cable has been doing a better job of making the kind of programs that can break through.

headline: Healing Veterans Find Solace in Community and the Arts
text: The Veterans’ Sanctuary in Trumansburg, N.Y., provides a holistic wellness program and rehabilitation center for veterans, with a focus on those returning from Iraq and Afghanistan.

headline: This Week in the Global Arts Guide
text: “Images of People,” at the Museum Frieder Burda in Baden-Baden, Germany, is a themed approach to Mr. Burda’s collection of modern and contemporary art. Human emotions are the recurring motif expressed in a variety of styles in the paintings of Gerhard Richter, Sigmar Polke and Georg Baselitz (with his trademark upside-down scenes). The younger generation is not forgotten: Tim Eitel paints lonely people after photographs he took himself but insists on calling them ‘‘fictions’’; Susanne Kühn, while creating narrative works that blend interiors, landscapes and figuration, favors space, color and structure over meaning; and Simon Pasieka uses a dreamy palette to paint young people living on the margins of society. Through Jan. 6.

headline: Howard Stern to Return to ‘America’s Got Talent’
text: Howard Stern will return to NBC as a judge on its summer talent competition “America’s Got Talent,” the network announced Monday morning.

headline: Old Vic Announces 2013 Season
text: Vanessa Redgrave, 75, and James Earl Jones, 81, seen together not long ago on Broadway and the West End in “Driving Miss Daisy,” will team up again as an unusually well-seasoned version of the lovers Beatrice and Benedick in Shakespeare’s “Much Ado About Nothing,” at a production next September at the Old Vic in London, directed by Mark Rylance.

headline: A Diplomatic Red Line
text: TimesCast: The United States warns Syria over its chemical weapons. | To be young, educated and unemployed in France. | Tax deals create a war between New York and New Jersey.

headline: The Giving Spree | John Derian
text: Who: The store owner and designer John Derian, whose home renovation was documented in T in “The Makeunder.”

headline: Daily Report: Car-Service App Tangles With Regulators
text: Summoning a taxi or car service with your smartphone feels like the future. City governments around the world can agree on that. But as Brian X. Chen reports in Monday’s New York Times, many of them are proposing new rules that would stop Uber, one of the most prominent ride-requesting apps.

headline: Watching the Entrepreneurial Flame Flicker
text: Every successful company I know shares a common ingredient: a leader who is an entrepreneur and who is irrationally committed to the company’s success. These people will duck, dive, dodge, twist and turn to live to fight another day and make their dreams and visions come true.

headline: Dallas Museum Volunteers to Return Mosaic to Turkey
text: The Dallas Museum of Art voluntarily returned an ancient marble mosaic in its collection to Turkey on Monday, after determining that the work — which dates from A.D. 194 and shows Orpheus taming animals with his lyre — was probably stolen years ago from a Turkish archaeological site.

headline:
Initial Deficit Cuts Are Sticking Point in
Negotiations
text: WASHINGTON — For all the growing angst over the state of negotiations to head off a fiscal crisis in January, the parties are farthest apart on a relatively small part of the overall deficit reduction program — the down payment.

headline: Dell Shares Leap After Analyst Muses About a Buyout
text: Shares of Dell rose sharply on Monday after an analyst at Goldman Sachs upgraded the stock – and mused about the (distant!) possibility of a leveraged buyout in the computer maker’s future.

headline: For Holiday Party Fare, Try a Purée
text: Here’s a new concept: view the holiday party season as an opportunity to eat more vegetables and legumes. I spent a week making Mediterranean vegetable and bean purées that we spread on toasted bread and devoured for lunch and dinner every day. My son and I managed to consume nearly a pound each of fresh spinach, carrots, and winter squash. Liam is admittedly a very hungry, athletic teenager, but this was a great indication that something healthy and delicious (and pretty, too!) on a canapé is just as likely to be gobbled up as something not-so-healthy.

headline: How Much Homework Does It Take to Educate a Nation?
text: Finland and South Korea’s school systems are practically polar opposites.

headline: A Financial Plan for Misbehaving Lottery Winners
text: Carl Richards is a financial planner in Park City, Utah, and is the director of investor education at the BAM Alliance. His book, “The Behavior Gap,” was published this year. His sketches are archived on the Bucks blog.

headline: ‘Amour’ Gains a Euro Prize, and Perhaps Momentum
text: The European Film Awards – a polling of 2,500 professional across the continent – were handed down over the weekend, and it was a near-sweep for Michael Hanecke’s “Amour,” named the best feature. The tale of an elderly Parisian dealing with his wife’s dementia, it also won top prizes for its stars, Jean-Louis Trintignant and Emmanuelle Riva, and best director for Mr. Haneke, the Austrian filmmaker and frequent Cannes champion best known for “The White Ribbon” and other cinematic tragedies. “Amour” is, as our colleague Larry Rohter wrote, the front-runner for the best foreign-language Oscar.

headline: South African Company to Build U.S. Plant to Convert Gas to Liquid Fuels
text: WESTLAKE, La. — In an ambitious bet that the glut of cheap natural gas in the United States will last for many years, a South African energy company announced on Monday that it would build America’s first commercial plant to convert natural gas to diesel and other liquid fuels.

headline: Obama to Ask Wasserman Schultz to Stay On as D.N.C. Chief
text: President Obama will ask Representative Debbie Wasserman Schultz to serve another term as chairwoman of the Democratic National Committee and preside over the party as it heads into the next election cycle.

headline: ‘Chaplin’ to Close Next Month
text: “Chaplin: The Musical,” starring Rob McClure as the Little Tramp, will have its final Broadway performance on Jan. 6, the producers announced on Monday. When the show closes at the Ethel Barrymore Theater, it will have played 24 previews and 136 regular performances.

headline: Science Times Podcast
text: This week: the doctor versus the computer and your life after cancer.

headline: Image of the Day: Dec. 3
text: International Day of Persons with Disabilities observed in Hyderabad, Andhra Pradesh.

headline: Exploring Humanity’s Evolving ‘Global Brain’
text: Over the last several years, I’ve become familiar with the work of Thomas W. Malone and the Center for Collective Intelligence, the lab he directs at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. The center is studying, and trying to make the most of, the human species’ fast-growing capacity to think outside the box — with the box in this case being an individual’s skull and cerebral cortex.

headline: Street Style: Metallics
text: The best of readers’ photos from the week of Nov. 26.

headline: Twitter Has a New User: The Pope
text: VATICAN CITY — Now trending on Twitter: Pope Benedict XVI.

headline: Leading Off: For the Chiefs, a Day of Sorrow and Inspiration
text: From very far away, the Kansas City Chiefs’ win Sunday’s game over Carolina in the wake of the unthinkable murder-suicide perpetrated by Chiefs linebacker Jovan Belcher could have been tied up with a little sports bow. In football’s usual make-believe world, the kind often spun out of whole cloth by television types, the Chiefs rallied together, inspired one another, started to heal and move on and go ahead and fill in more of the clichés designed to make sports and athletes so heroic.

headline: For Rodriguez, First One Hip, Now the Other
text: 10:32 p.m. | Updated

headline: E.P.A. Updates a Decades-Old Water Quality Standard
text: Last week the  Environmental Protection Agency issued a new set of water quality guidelines for monitoring bacterial outbreaks in inland and coastal waters used frequently by recreational swimmers. The standard was last updated in 1986. The move was prompted by a federal court order and a requirement of the Beaches Environmental Assessment and Coastal Health Act of 2000.

headline: Don’t Rush the Critics Circle (People Have Tried)
text: The New York Film Critics Circle, one of the country’s pre-eminent critics’ groups, knows how to build anticipation: it’s releasing its choices for the year’s best cinema one by one on Twitter today, leaving the awards blogosphere alternately panting with me-firstness and grumbling with me-lastness.

headline: Close Encounters With the Lincoln Brand
text: Dip into most news outlets this week and it will be almost impossible not to encounter the Lincoln, Ford Motor Company’s luxury brand.

headline: Steven Strogatz and ‘The Joy of x,’ Part 2
text: This week we offer a second puzzle from  “The Joy of x,”  the recently-released book by mathematician Steven Strogatz based on his popular New York Times Opinionator Series “The Elements of Math.” If you happened to enjoy “The Elements of Math,” you’ll love “The Joy of x.”

headline: Copeland’s Strides Give Knicks a New, Improved Look
text: The most obvious difference between this Knicks’ season and any of the last dozen years are the high expectations. The Knicks are 12-4, second in the Eastern Conference and fifth overall. For the first time in more than a decade, the Knicks could be considered title contenders.

headline: Man Trying to Rescue Cat Dies in Fall From Tree
text: Updated, 5:45 p.m. | A 53-year-old man fell out of a tree and died while trying to rescue a cat in the Bronx late Sunday night or early Monday morning, the police said.

headline: The Rock Hall of Fame Names a New Frontman
text: The Rock and Roll Hall of Fame has a new frontman. Greg S. Harris, who before coming to the rock hall was a top official at the National Baseball Hall of Fame and Museum, will take over as the president and chief executive on Jan. 1, when the current chief executive, Terry Stewart, steps down.

headline: You Can Use the Slick Stuff to Clean Your Face
text: Tight, dull and parched skin can be a nagging problem come winter. Oil-based cleansers are frequently touted as powerful hydrators suitable for all skin types, including oily complexions. Below are some of the newest.

headline: College Freshmen Home for Winter Break: Independence vs. House Rules?
text: Are you a college freshman who will be heading home for winter break? My colleague Jan Hoffman would like to write about your first homecoming:

headline: Removing ‘Sacrifice’ From ‘Gluten-Free’
text: I WAS gluten-free before it was cool to be. In 2000, a doctor told me I was allergic to wheat, barley and rye, and said that avoiding gluten was the only way to end my stomach pains and chronic lethargy. So I had to give up tagliatelle, Belgian-style ale, granola and — I feared — cooking for friends.

headline: Lawyer Says Trader Did Not Manipulate Market
text: A lawyer for a high-profile trader under investigation over his trading in Treasury futures said his client did not engage in any manipulative activity.

headline: Everything’s Great in China
text: HONG KONG—Some two weeks after China’s once-in-a-decade leadership change brought intense scrutiny from the rest of the world, mainland government officials and sundry representatives vetted to speak with American journalists are fiercely, defensively optimistic: Everything’s swell, the country’s on the up and up, and any problems are really just glitches, easily surmountable.

headline: Monday Motorsports: Keselowski Collects $5 Million as Nascar Champion
text: LAS VEGAS — Brad Keselowski was officially crowned Sprint Cup champion on Friday at Nascar’s annual awards banquet here. Keselowski, a first-time winner, accepted a trophy, a diamond-studded champion’s ring from the Nascar president, Brian France, and a check for more than $5 million.

headline: Sex, Drugs, Rock ‘n’ Roll and More Sex?
text: For our most recent Ask the Expert feature, we invited readers to send us questions about female sexuality and aging. There was such a strong response that our expert, Susan Kellogg, a professor of obstetrics and gynecology, will be answering a second round of questions on Wednesday.

headline: The Get | Chris Benz’s Rhoda Dress for Anthropologie
text: Welcome Anthropologie’s latest Made in Kind designer partner: New York’s Chris Benz. “It’s a little something fun to spice up ladies’ wardrobes before the holidays,” says Benz of the capsule collection, which goes on sale today. Casual separates, like oversize tees, blouses with big off-the-shoulder bows, and floor-sweeping mermaid skirts, complement the collection’s dresses: ruffled, printed and peplumed, all perfect for a party. “Our intent was to bring unique pieces that embody my aesthetic — rich in color and print,” Benz says. Standing out is the print, which appears here on the knot-neck Rhoda dress ($348) and which Benz says, “incorporates the idea of a cameo but almost resembles a piece of precious jewelry.”

headline: Tax Battle in the Northeast
text: Bettina Damiani of Good Jobs New York, and Jonathan Gouveia of the N.Y.C. Economic Development Corporation, discuss the issue of pro-business tax incentives in New York and New Jersey.

headline: Don’t Encourage Students to Skip College
text: Kobe Bryant and LeBron James didn’t go to college at all. Carmelo Anthony attended Syracuse University, but for only a year. All three are now superstars in the N.B.A., earning tens of millions of dollars. So does this mean that we should encourage our 14-year-old hoops-loving son to take a shot at a similar path and see if he can make it as a professional basketball player?

headline: Stevie Wonder Drops Out of Benefit for Israeli Soldiers
text: Stevie Wonder has pulled out of a concert in Los Angeles benefiting Friends of the Israel Defense Forces, citing the current tensions in the Middle East.

headline: Most New Yorkers Think Climate Change Caused Hurricane, Poll Finds
text: New York State voters overwhelmingly say they believe that Hurricane Sandy demonstrated the effects of climate change, according to a poll released Monday by Siena College.

headline: New Faces at the N.H.L. Negotiating Table

headline: 5 European Nations Summon Envoys of Israel
text: JERUSALEM — Britain, France, Spain, Sweden and Denmark summoned the Israeli ambassadors to their countries on Monday to protest Israel’s plans for increased settlement construction, an unusually sharp diplomatic step that reflected the growing frustration abroad with Israel’s policies on the Palestinian issue.

headline: Have an N.F.L. Question? Judy Battista Has Answers
text: How (and when) will the Eagles soap opera end? How good (or not) are the Bears right now? How will the Niners resolve their quarterback situation? And the Jets? Judy Battista, the N.F.L. reporter for The New York Times, will answer questions from readers this week. Use the comment field below for your questions. Answers will appear Friday on The Fifth Down.

headline: Spate of Harsh Weather in New England Shifts Sentiment on Trees
text: WILBRAHAM, Mass. — First came the tornado, which felled five big trees and sent them crashing down on half their house, forcing Heather Mercier and Ellie Tobiasz to move into a mobile home on their property while the house was being repaired.

headline: It’s Health Care Costs, Stupid
text: Busy day, so not much blogging. But a further thought on budget issues.

headline: More Goodbyes (and One Good Riddance) for Philip Roth
text: Philip Roth’s recent announcement that he was retiring from fiction prompted headlines around the world. It has also prompted a chorus of envy, skepticism and at least one “finally!” from three dozen writers recently canvassed by Flavorwire.com.

headline: Cuomo Travels to Washington to Press for Disaster Aid
text: WASHINGTON — It was an unusual role for a politician who is accustomed to being in complete charge.

headline: After Re-election, Missouri Republican Decides to Leave Congress
text: The longest-serving member of Missouri’s Congressional delegation is leaving the Capitol and is headed to K Street.

text: Stuart Elliott, the advertising columnist, answers questions from readers each week. Questions can be sent to stuarte@nytimes.com.

headline: Accounts and People of Note in the Advertising Industry
text: Barrie Berg, chief executive for the Americas at What If Innovation, New York, was named to a new post, global chief executive. She succeeds Sal Pajwani, who will take a post that involves working with what the agency described as “its largest and most global clients.”

headline: Man Pushed to Death on Subway Tracks
text: Updated, 9:47 p.m. | A 58-year-old subway passenger was killed on Monday after he was pushed onto the tracks of an onrushing train in Manhattan by a man who had been mumbling to himself as he walked along the platform, the police said.

headline: Telling the Story of PHL (Also Known as Philadelphia)
text: An agency that promotes the City of Brotherly Love would love to share its assets, the better to raise the profile of Philadelphia around the world as a place to do business, visit, hold meetings and attend college.

headline: For Planes, a Climate Antidote: Bypass the Arctic
text: This year Arctic sea ice reached a historic low, breaking a record set in 2007 by a whopping 18 percent.  Researchers suggest that the ice could disappear entirely in as little as two or three decades. That would accelerate the warming of the planet, given that dark solar-energy-absorbing ocean water would replace a surface of bright white ice, which reflects sunlight back into space.

headline: String of Insider Trading Cases Shows Prosecutors Casting a Wider Net
text: The end of November included a veritable rush of insider trading prosecutions, belying the notion that the government goes on hiatus at the end of the year.

headline: For Second Opinion, Consult a Computer?
text: SAN FRANCISCO — The man on stage had his audience of 600 mesmerized. Over the course of 45 minutes, the tension grew. Finally, the moment of truth arrived, and the room was silent with anticipation.

headline: Tom Cruise, On Screen and in Person
text: For those who feel the need for speed and others who are looking to be completed, the Film Society of Lincoln Center will present a retrospective of the work of Tom Cruise this month, as well as a live talk with the star.

headline: A Rise in Injuries on Inflatable Bouncers
text: A new study has found that in the past two decades more than 64,000 children under 17 have been injured using inflatable bouncers at home or at public recreation facilities.

headline: Aspirin Tied to Reduced Risk of Liver Cancer
text: In a large prospective study, researchers have found an association between aspirin use and a reduced risk of liver cancer.

headline: Tree Power
text: Q. My family owns a 40-acre woodlot of relatively mature deciduous trees. How many pounds of carbon dioxide does such a forest absorb in a typical year? And how many pounds of oxygen are emitted?
