headline: Look of The Moment | Cold Weather Coral
text: Coral, a color once relegated to spring/summer collections and clothes for warmer climes, has been venturing out into colder evenings recently. Applied to heavier fabrics, the happy hue makes a festive holiday statement. The model Alek Wek’s Kenzo mini proved that coral can play a supporting role to darker, more wintry colors like navy; Keira Knightley wore a Richard Nicoll jacquard dress to the after-party for her film “Anna Karenina”; and the model Miranda Kerr added a layer of black — and a sweetheart neckline — to a long Giulietta dress.

headline: Dave Brubeck, Whose Distinctive Sound Gave Jazz New Pop, Dies at 91
text: Dave Brubeck, the pianist and composer who helped make jazz popular again in the 1950s and ’60s with recordings like “Time Out,” the first jazz album to sell a million copies, and “Take Five,” the still instantly recognizable hit single that was that album’s centerpiece, died on Wednesday in Norwalk, Conn. He would have turned 92 on Thursday.

headline: Elisabeth Murdoch, Matriarch of a Journalism Family, Dies at 103
text: Dame Elisabeth Murdoch, the 103-year-old mother of the media tycoon Rupert Murdoch, the widow of an Australian newspaper baron and one of her nation’s most noted philanthropists, died on Wednesday at her estate near Melbourne.

headline: Grand Bargain Express
text: David Brooks: Gail, I’m out in Los Angeles. Did you know that the celebrity set has moved beyond nerd glasses, and now Simpson-Bowles-style bipartisan budget plans are all the rage? Ke$ha and Kobe have been showing theirs off at parties, relying heavily on means testing Medicare and preserving the negative income tax. Snoop Dogg and Kendrick Lamar have come together for one raising an immense amount of money on a Bugatti tax. Taylor Swift and Chuck Norris have one, but I hear they didn’t write it themselves.

headline: In Mexico, a New Champion and More
text: Last Sunday, Tijuana won its first Mexican league title, triumphing at a listless Toluca , 2-0 on goals by Richard Ruiz and Duvier Reascos, to capture the championship, 4-1 on aggregate. Then, two days after the conclusion of the Apertura season, Mexican soccer was rocked by the death of the former Pachuca goalkeeper Miguel Calero, 41.

headline: New Chinese Leader Meets Military Nuclear Officers
text: BEIJING — The new Chinese leader, Xi Jinping, met Wednesday with officers of the military unit that oversees the land-based ballistic and cruise missiles of China’s nuclear force, the state-run news agency Xinhua said, in the latest indication that Mr. Xi is moving quickly to solidify his control of the armed forces.

headline: Obama Appeals to Business for Support on Tax Plan

headline: How to Bypass Instagram’s Twitter Barrier
text: As I reported earlier on Wednesday, Instagram will block Instagram photos from appearing on Twitter’s Web site. This means that when people post a photo from Instagram to Twitter, only a link will be displayed rather than the actual image. To see an Instagram picture in its filtered glory, people will have to leave Twitter and go to Instagram’s Web site.

headline: The Fate of an American City: Mark Binelli Talks About Detroit
text: Detroit has become the most visibly distressed symbol of our hard economic times. In his new book, “Detroit City Is the Place to Be: The Afterlife of an American Metropolis,” Mark Binelli traces the long history of racial and financial struggles there, documents the current crisis, and investigates the many ways — innovative, desperate and otherwise — that residents are trying to turn things around. In a recent e-mail interview, Mr. Binelli discussed the rise of urban agriculture in Detroit, apportioning blame for the city’s problems and more. Below are edited excerpts from the conversation:

headline: Beating the Frumpiness Out of You, but Gently
text: WHEN I told people I was going to meet Stacy London, the fashion stylist and host of the TLC show “What Not to Wear,” whose new book, “The Truth About Style,” was published this fall, the reaction was universal: What are you going to wear?

headline: The Whale in a Tank
text: Count Adam Gurowski cut a striking figure as he stormed about Washington in a broad-brimmed hat, flowing overcoat and colored spectacles. The Polish exile, who had lived in Berlin, St. Petersburg and Paris before coming to the United States in 1849, was the author of 1854’s “Russia As It Is,” a work praised as “original and striking.” The son of Count Wladyslaw Gurowski, who fought alongside Tadeusz Kosciuszko in the failed attempt to free Poland of Russian influence in 1794, Adam, according to his obituary in The New York Times, “imbibed the revolutionary spirit possessed by his father, and carried his patriotism to such an extent as to render himself obnoxious to the ruling powers.” When war broke out, Gurowski took a minor position in the State Department.

headline: Pressure Builds on Syrian Opposition Coalition; Fears of Chemical Weapons Rise
text: Pressure is building on a new Syrian opposition coalition to choose leaders and transform itself into a political force that could earn formal recognition from the United States and other countries as a viable alternative to the Syrian government.

headline: MoCA Los Angeles May Partner With U.S.C.

headline: Heat, Lacking Urgency, Are Stung by Wizards
text: WASHINGTON — Miami Heat Coach Erik Spoelstra did not want to say it outright, but the thought was clearly on his mind: Miami coasted for most of Tuesday’s game against the overmatched Washington Wizards. The Heat fell behind early and could not get going until it was too late. The result was an embarrassing 105-101 loss to a terrible team that doubled its victory total for the season from one to two.

headline: Ben Brantley Answers Readers’ Questions

headline: Fate’s Cruel Hand Nearly Ices a Heart
text: Hattie Shepherd, the title character of Ayana Mathis’s piercing debut novel, is at once a tragic heroine with mythic dimensions and an entirely recognizable mother and wife trying to make ends meet. Her story, set in 20th-century Philadelphia, is one of terrible loss and grief and survival, a story of endurance in the face of disappointment, heartbreak and harrowing adversity.

headline: Suddenly, Optimistic Signs Abound in N.H.L. Talks
text: Amid growing optimism that a settlement to save the N.H.L. season was within reach, the owners and the players union exchanged proposals as negotiations accelerated Wednesday night.

headline: More Information for Used-Car Buyers May Soon Be Required

headline: Stalled Farm Bill Is Pushed for Its Savings
text: WASHINGTON — As President Obama and Republican leaders try to avoid automatic spending cuts and tax increases beginning in the new year, several lawmakers say a stalled farm bill that reshapes nutrition and agriculture programs could contribute billions of dollars in savings.

headline: 36 Hours in Steamboat Springs, Colo.
text: STEAMBOAT SPRINGS evokes an era when cattle ranchers roamed its streets and locals preferred Stetsons to ski vests. But in recent years, Steamboat has sought to shed a bit of its family-friendly image as a cowboy theme park and embrace its inner Breckenridge. The town, nestled along the Yampa River in northwest Colorado, has installed an array of new après-ski bars, haute cuisine restaurants and late-night haunts, as well as upscale lodgings, like One Steamboat Place, that can rival anything at Vail or Aspen. The centerpiece of Steamboat’s face-lift, which coincides with the resort’s 50th anniversary, is a redeveloped promenade at the base of its gondola, with a heated walkway, a musical stage and a three-tiered ice castle. Families still flock to Steamboat for its dude ranches and hot springs. But after the children are put to bed, its downtown comes alive with an impressive night life and innovative culinary scene. “It’s still a cowboy ski town,” said Gerry Verdoner, bar manager of Sweetwater Grill. “But now there’s more balance.”

headline: Steamboat Springs, Colo.

headline: Report Bolsters the Case for Large U.S. Natural Gas Exports

headline: Maybe a Bathroom With a Nice Shower?

The contest began Wednesday at facebook.com/BatesMotelAETV and runs through Jan. 3.

headline: Describing the View From the Sidelines
text: FRANKLIN FOER’S latest book is a giant game of Jewish geography. An almost indecent number of the 50 writers he and his co-editor, Marc Tracy, recruited to write profiles for “Jewish Jocks: An Unorthodox Hall of Fame” are friends and sometime colleagues. And the panel discussion held recently at the Union Square Barnes & Noble, just a few hundred feet from where Emma Goldman once roused crowds in Yiddish, felt kind of like a bar mitzvah.

headline: For Greece, Oligarchs Are Obstacle to Recovery
text: ATHENS — A dynamic entrepreneur, Lavrentis Lavrentiadis seemed to represent a promising new era for Greece. He dazzled the country’s traditionally insular business world by spinning together a multibillion-dollar empire just a few years after inheriting a small family firm at 18. Seeking acceptance in elite circles, he gave lavishly to charities and cultivated ties to the leading political parties.

headline: Fighting the ‘Resource Curse’
text: About a  year ago, in the aftermath of the revolution that drove Muammar el-Qaddafi from power in Libya, journalists crowded into a press conference called by the transitional government’s Oil Ministry. Among the reporters was a small contingent of Libyan journalists. Yet it was only the foreigners who peppered a government minister with questions about when production would resume and other issues; the Libyans remained silent.

headline: Gossip Girl
text: HAS there ever been a celebrity more suited for Twitterati stardom than Lindsay Lohan? From her brawls to her arrests to her bad career choices and busted romances, LiLo is the gift that keeps on giving. Her arrest on Nov. 29, following the altercation she reportedly got into with another woman at a Manhattan night club over the boy band heartthrob Max George (The Wanted), and her widely panned role as Elizabeth Taylor in the Lifetime movie “Liz & Dick,” had people posting comments on Twitter at the rate of nearly one every 8 seconds. Below, a sampling.

headline: The Design Team Roman & Williams Gets Around
text: Black-pipe flanges, filament bulbs and vintage turntables — these industrial-chic tropes have come to signify good taste today, and much of it can be traced to Stephen Alesch and Robin Standefer.

headline: They Get Around
text: IF one was wondering at whose feet to lay the blame for the cannibalization of the nation’s old barns and derelict schoolhouses to meet the voracious appetite for reclaimed wood by trendy cocktail dens and restaurants, Stephen Alesch and Robin Standefer are a good place to start.

headline: Raphael Drawing Fetches Nearly $50 Million

headline: 10 Composers to Celebrate One Topic
text: The problems with “Women,” a new program performed by the New York Festival of Song on Tuesday evening at Merkin Concert Hall, began with the note in the playbill. In it, Steven Blier, the festival’s artistic director and main piano accompanist, wrote that after the success of “Manning the Canon,” an evening of songs by and about gay men, he felt the need “to balance the account with an evening celebrating women.”

headline: You Can Dance to It: Roots of Tradition With Improvisational Freedom
text: Dance rhythms teased throughout the concert at Carnegie Hall on Tuesday night: a summit of Latin jazz pianists with Chucho Valdés and Gonzalo Rubalcaba from Cuba, Danilo Pérez from Panama and Egberto Gismonti from Brazil.

headline: Six Performers Moving Through a Labyrinth of Perceptions
text: Miguel Gutierrez’s “And lose the name of action” seeks to demonstrate facets of a mind that has come apart. The title phrase concludes the “To be, or not to be” soliloquy in “Hamlet”; a long program note by Mr. Gutierrez begins with that speech’s final five lines and tells us of neurological problems afflicting his father, which in turn led Mr. Gutierrez to investigate the connections of body and mind. His note also variously addresses neurology, philosophy and somatics, and examines the role perception plays in reality. Mr. Gutierrez goes on to hope that his work may be a bridge connecting these various fields of inquiry.

text: There’s nothing wrong with some sparkle in your seasonal get-up. But there’s a fine line between arriving in festive glitter and looking like a Grammy Awards nominee.

headline: Newspaper Born of a Fire Is Back in Ink After a Storm
text: Never has the name of The Wave, the weekly newspaper of the Rockaways, seemed so apt.

headline: A Soul Singer Following in the Family Tradition
text: “If Only for One Night,” Brenda Russell’s seething pop-soul ballad of longing and desire, is probably best remembered by Luther Vandross’s ornate rendition on his 1985 album, “The Night I Fell in Love.” On Tuesday evening at 54 Below it was resurrected by Darius de Haas in a fiery, unabashedly abject interpretation whose desperate passion eclipsed even that of Mr. Vandross, the so-called “Pavarotti of pop,” who died seven years ago.

headline: Transcript of David Leonhardt’s Reddit Chat
text: David Leonhardt, The Times’s Washington bureau chief, took questions Wednesday on the popular social news site Reddit. What follows is an edited transcript.

headline: In Bed With the Flu, and Lots of Information About It
text: I wasn’t my usual self earlier this week. Some nasty flu bug had beaten me, reducing your usual quirky, chipper columnist to a feverish, bedridden shadow. It’s never fun being ill, and I’ve never been a good patient because all the sensible advice to stay warm, hydrated and in bed leads to boredom.

headline: Tracking a Body-Rattling Saxophone Storm
text: The biggest brace-yourself moment in Donny McCaslin’s first set at the Jazz Standard on Tuesday night came at the last possible moment, near the end of the encore, when he uncorked an impromptu tenor saxophone coda that seemed to rattle through his body like a heavy wind. The gathering force of his projection gave every indication of physical abandon, but the speed and complexity of his phrasing stressed otherwise. It was a pretty serious couple of minutes.

headline: Champions League: Matchday 6(B)
text: With games on Matchday 6(B) of the group stage of the UEFA Champions League on Wednesday, we continue a featurette in which we hope to bring Goal readers video of the best (and most important) goals of the day, courtesy of Fox Soccer.

headline: New York City Opera to Hold Online Auction
text: New York City Opera, seeking to shed decades’ worth of old sets, costumes and props, has decided to auction off most of the material next month, the company’s general manager and artistic director, George Steel, said on Wednesday. An online auction will begin in mid-January and run through Jan. 24.

headline: Bet Your Camomile Tea, Peter, You’re a TV Star Now
text: In Beatrix Potter’s first version of “The Tale of Peter Rabbit,” a menacing Mrs. McGregor leans over a kitchen table and presented a steaming-hot pie to Mr. McGregor, who holds a knife and fork at the ready. The pie, of course, is stuffed with the remains of Peter’s father.

headline: The iPad as a Hand-Held Darkroom
text: Over the years, I’ve been in and out of relationships with dozens of film cameras, Pentax, Canon, Nikon, Minolta and others, as a result of my passion for photography.

headline: Fall North American Championships
text: SAN FRANCISCO — On Sunday, the last day of the Fall North American Championships, the Reisinger Board-a-Match Teams was won by Pierre Zimmermann, Franck Multon, Fulvio Fantoni, Claudio Nunes, Geir Helgemo and Tor Helness, who play for Monaco. They finished 3.41 boards ahead of Sabine Auken from Denmark; Roy Welland of New York City; Bart Bramley of Dallas; and Lew Stansby of Dublin, Calif. Third were Bob Blanchard, Shane Blanchard (Bob’s son), John Hurd and Joel Wooldridge, all of New York City; Bob Hamman of Dallas; and Justin Lall of Las Vegas.

headline: Designing the 21st-Century Synagogue
text: Landau Zinder, a new architecture firm in Princeton, N.J., specializing in synagogues, is a partnership of two architects: Michael Landau, 70, whose four-decade career included a stint with Marcel Breuer, and Joshua Zinder, 44, who worked for Michael Graves, among others, before starting his own firm five years ago. The men, who still have individual practices, met about 10 years at the Princeton Jewish Center, where both are members. They spoke to a reporter about designing the 21st-century synagogue, which like many contemporary homes, involves concerns of technology, green strategies and aging occupants.

headline: So Your Flight’s Delayed? Relax.
text: Louis Vuitton didn’t become a successful purveyor of travel goods by sitting on its thumbs. Over the years, the company, which was founded in 1854, has invented steamer trunks that convert into beds and a padlock that it challenged Houdini to pick. Vuitton is recalling the adventurous spirit of those designs with Objets Nomades, a collection that was presented in the Miami Design District on Tuesday and will remain on view through Sunday.

headline: Alaska: Future Swing State?
text: The state where President Obama most improved his performance from 2008 was Alaska. He lost it by “only” 14 percentage points this year, considerably less than his 22-point margin of defeat in 2008.

headline: Raising a Paddle for the Gio Pontis
text: On Dec. 13, Wright in Chicago will hold an auction of 20th-century Italian masterworks, with almost half of the pieces by Gio Ponti. “He is the overarching figure of Italian design,” said Richard Wright, the auction house owner, tracing that arc from the 1920s, when Ponti began his career as an architect, industrial designer and editor in Milan (he founded the Italian magazines Domus and Stile), to the 1970s, the last decade of his life.

headline: The Sun Rises Again on Café Royal
text: In 1865, a nearly penniless Frenchman fleeing his debts opened Café Royal in London. The club’s heyday lasted more than a century, as celebrities swirled through its sumptuous precincts. (Max Beerbohm described “fumes of tobacco ever rising to the painted and pagan ceiling” of the Domino Room.) But in 2008, the building was sold, and its lavish appointments — cut-glass chandeliers, heavily varnished oil paintings, even a boxing ring — were auctioned off.

headline: Buddy-Buddy: Seasoned Actor and Young Director
text: Michael Caine was doing the eye thing. It’s a trick of his, developed over years of film performances and close-ups: Let your gaze rest on your scene partner, but only with one eye. The other eye, the one closest to the camera, can connect with the lens. The camera “will not miss anything,” he said, “including the bad. So you have to watch it.”

headline: Eva Zeisel’s Designs Shine On
text: Leucos is producing two glass lamps by Eva Zeisel, who died last year at 105. She first created versions five years ago for a friend of her granddaughter who was designing a coffee shop. “Eva was adamant about keeping the shape exactly the way it was” said Josie Anthony, Leucos USA’s president. “And she only wanted to do it in white.” (Leucos had to persuade her to make a honey-colored model.) The lamps — Summer (single curve, shown); Spring (double) — display her signature undulations. Available starting Friday at Gracious Home, from $345 for a Spring sconce to $735 for a Summer suspension lamp: (800) 338-7809 or gracioushome.com.

headline: Sales at Daniel Levy, Niche Modern and Others
text: From Thursday to Sunday, Daniel Levy porcelain tabletop overstock, seconds and discontinued patterns are up to 95 percent off (a Quadrille buffet plate, usually $275, is $25); 155 West 29th Street, Suite 3N, (212) 268-0878, daniellevyporcelain.com.

headline: Street Battles Erupt in Cairo
text: Street battles erupted in Cairo on Wednesday night, after Islamist supporters of President Mohamed Morsi attacked protesters camped outside the gates of the presidential palace.

headline: Blood Is Shed as Egyptian President’s Backers and Rivals Battle in Cairo
text: CAIRO — Angry mobs of Islamists battled secular protesters with fists, rocks and firebombs in the streets around the presidential palace for hours Wednesday night in the first major outbreak of violence between political factions here since the revolt against then-President Hosni Mubarak began nearly two years ago.

headline: Zona Style
text: At home with Franci Sagar, the woman behind the home store, Zona, and her daughter Sophie.

headline: An ’80s Hit Preps for a Comeback
text: IT is a bit of a flashback to walk into Franci Sagar’s Wooster Street loft. First, it is an unreconstructed ’80s-era habitat, with a huge bed at its center and little islands of activity, collections and furniture bobbing about. Then there’s the olfactory whomp of the place — toasty, spicy, cedar-inflected — that brings a whiff of Ms. Sagar’s hit machine, the home store known as Zona.

headline: Lions and Tigers and Bears, Oh My
text: In a TriBeCa loft, a menagerie under glass.

headline: For PC Virus Victims, Pay or Else
text: CULVER CITY, Calif. — Kidnappers used to make ransom notes with letters cut out of magazines. Now, notes simply pop up on your computer screen, except the hostage is your PC.

headline: Driver in Fatal Parade Crash Has Not Yet Been Questioned
text: HOUSTON — Three weeks after a truck carrying wounded veterans was struck by a train at a parade in Midland, Tex., federal investigators say they have been unable to interview the driver of the vehicle.

headline: How Upstart Played Its Way Into B.C.S. Club

headline: ‘Forgotten in Iraq’
text: As an American, as a journalist and simply as a person who tries to maintain some moral clarity in my life, I felt compelled in this Op-Doc video to tell the story of the workers in Iraq whose lives have been endangered or destroyed because of their loyalty to the United States.

headline: State May Oversee Detroit’s Finances
text: The City of Detroit, straining to manage its debts and meet its payroll, may be nearing circumstances dire enough to require a state-appointed emergency financial manager, Michigan officials cautioned city leaders this week.

text: Since he came to the United States from Haiti 23 years ago, Fritz Salomon has spent most of his time hospitalized for a disease he barely understands.

headline: Santorum Strikes Again
text: Lately, you’ve probably been asking: “What ever happened to Rick Santorum? The guy who ran for president in the sweater vest? The one who compared homosexuality to bestiality and did 50 push-ups every morning?” It’s certainly been on my mind.

headline: South Dakota: Tribes Raise Money for Sacred Land
text: Indian tribes that consider a high mountain prairie in the Black Hills of South Dakota to be sacred have raised enough money to purchase the land so that it can be preserved for religious ceremonies, the tribes announced. Three Sioux tribes — the Rosebud and Crow Creek in South Dakota and the Shakopee Mdewakanton in Minnesota — made contributions toward the $9 million cost of the 1.942-acre parcel, which is known as Pe’ Sla. The Sioux believe that Pe’ Sla was the scene of an ancient fight in which evil was vanquished.

headline: Mississippi: Fourth Guilty Plea in Hate Crime
text: A fourth white man pleaded guilty to hate crime charges on Tuesday in the killing of a black man who was robbed, beaten and run over by a pickup in Jackson. Three others have already pleaded guilty and await sentencing in the death of James C. Anderson, who was assaulted in June 2011. William Montgomery, 23, confessed in Federal District Court in Jackson on Tuesday to assaulting Mr. Anderson but said he did not participate in running him over. Another suspect, Jonathan Gaskamp, 20, also pleaded guilty to hate crimes charges in assaults against other blacks.

headline: Recognizing the Opposition in Syria
text: Should the United States officially recognize the opposition in Syria, or should Obama continue to use caution?

headline: Bad News on Capitol Hill for Last Coal-Fired Ferry
text: The Badger, the last coal-fired ferry in the United States, will have to sink or sail on its own. A provision in a little-noticed Coast Guard bill in the House would have allowed the ship to continue plying Lake Michigan — and dumping tons of coal ash into the lake each year. But the provision was taken out of the bill this week in negotiations with the Senate. It passed by voice vote in the House on Wednesday and was sent to the Senate. The Badger’s owners will have to hope that the Environmental Protection Agency gives the ferry a reprieve before its permit expires on Dec. 19. Otherwise, they will have to put the ferry into dry dock or switch to some other power source at considerable cost.

headline: A Legendary Modernist
text: Oscar Niemeyer, the Brazilian architect who created flowing designs, infused Modernism with a new sensuality and inspired of generations of architects worldwide, died Wednesday. He was 104.

headline: Oscar Niemeyer, Architect Who Gave Brasília Its Flair, Dies at 104
text: Oscar Niemeyer, the celebrated Brazilian architect whose flowing designs infused Modernism with a new sensuality and captured the imaginations of generations of architects around the world, died on Wednesday in Rio de Janeiro. He was 104.

headline: In Fine Print of Fiscal Debate, Charities Unite to Defend Deductions
text: WASHINGTON — Proposals to cap or otherwise limit deductions in order to raise tax revenue from the wealthy are gaining bipartisan support in Washington — and making charities and nonprofits very worried.

headline: Clipboard Chairman in Focus for Jets
text: Even in today’s high-tech N.F.L. — with its aerial cameras and triaxial knee braces — there’s still room for the humblest of technologies. You Jets fans know what I’m talking about. I’m talking about Greg McElroy’s clipboard.

headline: A Check on Bad Eyewitness Identifications
text: The Oregon Supreme Court in a unanimous decision last week upended how eyewitness identification is to be used in criminal trials. The landmark ruling shifts the burden of proof to prosecutors to show that such identification is sufficiently reliable to be admissible as evidence at trial. Misidentification is the country’s leading cause of wrongful convictions. By altering the legal standard, Oregon has set an example that other states and the federal courts would be wise to follow.

headline: Race to the Bottom
text: Competition among states and cities to lure businesses in hopes of creating jobs is not new, but it has become more fierce in recent years. An investigation by The Times found that state and local governments are giving out $80 billion a year in tax breaks and other subsidies in a foolhardy, shortsighted race to attract companies. That money could go a long way to improving education, transportation and other public services that would have a far better shot at promoting real economic growth.

headline: Njoy Commercial
text: Ads for Njoy King carry the theme “Cigarettes, you’ve met your match.”

headline: Campaigns for E-Cigarettes Borrow From Tobacco’s Heyday
text: IT has been decades since American consumers could watch cigarette commercials, which once filled the airwaves with pitches for brands like Camel, Chesterfield, Kool, Lucky Strike, Pall Mall, Viceroy and Winston. Now, they can watch cigarette spots again, to an extent: the smokes being advertised are electronic rather than made from tobacco.

headline: Win a Trip in 2013!
text: My latest column announces my next win-a-trip contest, an annual event in which I take a university student with me on a reporting trip to Africa. The aim is to generate some interest in global poverty issues both with the contest and with the blogging and videos that the winner will contribute to the New York Times website. I started the contest in 2006 and we’ve had some great trips over the years. For some of the winners, it has been life-changing, and HBO did a documentary called “Reporter” based on my 2007 trip; it’s on Amazon if you want to see what you’re getting yourself in for.

headline: Gifts That Change Lives
text: Looking for an unusual holiday gift? How about a $60 trio of rabbits to a family in Haiti in the name of someone special? Bunnies raise a farming family’s income because they, well, reproduce like rabbits — six litters a year! Heifer International arranges the gift on its Web site (heifer.org).

headline: Bay May Join Another Mets Castoff in Seattle
text: NASHVILLE — The Seattle Mariners on Wednesday were closing in on a formal agreement with Jason Bay, whose disastrous career with the Mets came to an abrupt end last month.

headline: Storm Writes a New Script in Campaigns for New York Mayor
text: This is when the New York City mayor’s race goes off script.

headline: Inspector of Day Care Centers Gets 2½ Years in Bribetaking Case
text: A former New York Fire Department employee who supervised safety inspections at day care centers was sentenced on Wednesday to two and a half years in prison for accepting thousands of dollars in bribes from center operators in return for overlooking violations and not performing inspections.

headline: Conflicting Views on How to Navigate a River of Cash
text: NASHVILLE

headline: An N.F.L. Team at the Rose Bowl? Not if Some Neighbors Have Their Way
text: PASADENA, Calif. — For nearly two years, the battle over bringing the National Football League to Los Angeles has been fought between two business titans competing to build a stadium in either downtown Los Angeles or the nearby City of Industry. No ground has been broken. The N.F.L. has not signaled whether it would approve a new franchise. There is not even a team clamoring to come.

headline: An Abduction Shines Light on Ukraine Asylum Policy and on Kremlin Methods
text: KIEV, Ukraine — For two and a half days in October, Leonid Razvozzhayev, a little-known leader of the Russian political opposition, moved furtively from one part of Kiev to another, meeting with political allies and human rights experts about seeking asylum in the West. At times, he was sure he was being followed. He was right.

headline: Theme of This Puzzle
text: THURSDAY’S PUZZLE — You know what I like more than anything on a Thursday? I like being fooled. It’s not because I enjoy feeling foolish, although God knows that’s easy enough. It’s because it’s proof that I’m alive and still have things to learn. That puts a smile on my face and, when it happens to you, I truly hope it puts a smile on your face, too.

headline: Young Immigrants Want ‘Dream Warrior’ Army
text: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — The movement of young immigrants in the country without legal papers, who call themselves Dreamers, is held together by more than a commitment to push Congress for a pathway to citizenship.

headline: In Changing Harlem, a Mosque Struggles to Pay Rent
text: Following the sun’s path over the sky, cabdrivers double-parked outside the mosque for Jumu’ah, or Friday prayer, in this part of central Harlem known as Little Africa. The worshipers steadily dripped in, men through one entrance, women through another.

headline: British Newspapers Agree to Regulator
text: LONDON — The editors of Britain’s principal national newspapers met Wednesday under pressure from Prime Minister David Cameron and agreed to the establishment of an independent newspaper regulator with far greater powers than those available to the existing watchdog.

headline: Trail to a Hedge Fund, From a Cluster of Cases
text: In April 2009, an F.B.I. agent visited the Silicon Valley home of Richard Choo-Beng Lee, a hedge fund manager with deep contacts inside technology companies. The government, the agent said, had overwhelming proof that Mr. Lee had engaged in insider trading. Within weeks, Mr. Lee confessed and began cooperating.

headline: Peace Process Pulls at Germany-Israel Ties
text: BERLIN — Growing up as a teenager in Germany, Jonathan Logan’s opinion of the Middle East conflict was black and white. “The Israelis were the good ones, and the Palestinians very clearly the bad ones,” he recalled Wednesday, as Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel arrived here for previously scheduled and suddenly rather tense consultations with Chancellor Angela Merkel.

headline: Art Basel Miami Beach Kicks Off
text: On Tuesday night, before the Art Basel Miami Beach fair opened for big collectors and V.I.P.s, the big event was the opening of the exhibition “Bill Viola: Liber Insularum” at the Museum of Contemporary Art, North Miami.

headline: Warm-Up Game Forces Knicks to Sweat
text: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — The Knicks had a stopover in Charlotte on Wednesday night on their way to an Eastern Conference showdown with the Heat in Miami on Thursday.

headline: Boehner Gains Strong Backing From House Republicans
text: WASHINGTON — With a daunting fiscal crisis looming and conservatives outside the House torching him at every turn, Speaker John A. Boehner might be assumed to have a shaky hold on his gavel. Instead, it appears he is enjoying the broadest support of his tumultuous two-year speakership from House Republicans.

headline: Behind a Flop, a Play(wright) Within a Play
text: A stroll down West 45th Street in the theater district is all it takes to understand the contradictory fortunes facing David Mamet, for years the heavyweight of bare-knuckled American playwrights, as well as the producers who believe that loyalty to the writer makes good business sense.

headline: Typhoon Bopha: Hurricane Sandy Times Two
text: HONG KONG — The official death toll from Typhoon Bopha climbed to 325 by Thursday afternoon, and with nearly 400 Filipinos still unaccounted for, the typhoon appeared as if it would be twice as deadly as Hurricane Sandy, the storm that thrashed the Caribbean and the eastern United States six weeks ago.

headline: After Fleeing Belize, Software Pioneer Seeks Asylum  in Guatemala
text: John McAfee, the software antivirus pioneer who disappeared from his home in Belize last month after the police there called him a “person of interest” in their investigation into the murder of his neighbor, has resurfaced in Guatemala City. He has hired a former attorney general and prominent defense lawyer, Telésforo Guerra, to seek political asylum in Guatemala. Mr. Guerra told local reporters that Mr. McAfee, 67, above, is being persecuted because he has refused to give the authorities in Belize any more money. Mr. McAfee had been blogging and sending Twitter messages while on the run, saying he fled because he feared for his life. Prime Minister Dean Barrow of Belize has called Mr. McAfee “bonkers.”

headline: Hasidic Man Denies Abuse of Young Girl He Counseled
text: Nechemya Weberman, the unlicensed ultra-Orthodox Jewish counselor charged with repeatedly sexually abusing a young girl in his care, testified in a Brooklyn courtroom on Wednesday that he had “never, ever” touched her inappropriately.

headline: When Best Still Isn’t Good Enough
text: In just over a decade of existence, the Florida International football program has struggled through the growing pains of being a fledging program, moved from Division I-AA to the Football Bowl Subdivision, taken part in the frenzy of conference realignment, had victories vacated by the N.C.A.A. and made two bowl games.

headline: 3 Charged With Plotting to Export Sensitive Materials to Iran and China
text: Three people have been charged with conspiring to illegally export to Iran and China a superstrong material called carbon fiber that can be used to make machines that can enrich uranium, federal prosecutors in Manhattan said on Wednesday.

headline: Lottery Numbers
In Louisiana, Growing Rice to Trade on Some Creatures That Eat It
text: GUEYDAN, La. — Donald Benoit’s rice fields are pristine enough for a picture postcard. Long, straight rows of bright green grain protrude from crystal clear water, with not a weed in sight. But one thing looks out of place.

headline: Options at Third Base Shrinking for Yankees
text: NASHVILLE — The Yankees’ options, however unappealing they might be, are dwindling.

headline: Giants, on Their Turf, Will Try to Slow the Saints’ Fast-Paced Offense

headline: A Patient’s Goal: Get Him to the Church on Time

headline: States Cut Antismoking Outlays Despite Record Tobacco Revenue
text: Faced with tight budgets, states have spent less on tobacco prevention over the past two years than in any period since the national tobacco settlement in 1998, despite record high revenues from the settlement and tobacco taxes, according to a report to be released on Thursday.

headline: Felton Sheds His Bandages and Helps Topple the Bobcats
text: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — Raymond Felton saw the pass coming, let his instincts take over and soon felt excruciating pain in his left thumb. On only the second play of Wednesday’s game against the Charlotte Bobcats, Felton deflected a pass from Kemba Walker out of bounds — and he realized his plan was flawed.

headline: A Chat With Michael Caine
text: The cinema fixture Michael Caine gives Melena Ryzik an interview and an acting lesson.

headline: What’s On Thursday
text: 9 P.M. (HBO) IN VOGUE: THE EDITOR’S EYE (2012) In honor of its 120th anniversary, Vogue magazine pays tribute to some of its most talked-about fashion layouts and the editors who created them — Grace Coddington, Tonne Goodman, Polly Allen Mellen, Camilla Nickerson, Phyllis Posnick and Babs Simpson — all women, whom Anna Wintour, the editor in chief, calls “our secret weapon.” This documentary, directed by Fenton Bailey and Randy Barbato and coinciding with the publication of “Vogue: The Editor’s Eye,” also features interviews with women who have graced the magazine’s cover and pages, like Nicole Kidman and Sarah Jessica Parker, and with the designers Alber Elbaz, Nicolas Ghesquière, Marc Jacobs and Vera Wang, herself a former Vogue fashion editor. (Above, a model wearing Christian Dior Haute Couleur Lipstick in Dazzling Orange.)

headline: 20 Years Ago: Riots Sweep India After Babri Mosque Destruction
text: “India’s towns and cities were swept by rioting between Muslims and Hindus on Monday, leaving more than 200 people dead and hundreds more injured a day after militant Hindus destroyed a 16th-century mosque in the northern town of Ayodhya,” Edward A. Gargan wrote in an article in The New York Times published Dec. 8, 1992.

headline: News Quiz | December 6, 2012
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper. Good luck!

headline: IHT Quick Read: Dec. 6
text: NEWS Rescuers sought to reach isolated villages Wednesday after a typhoon struck the Philippines, killing at least 325 people and leaving thousands homeless. Floyd Whaley reports from Manila.

headline: Stalemate and Rancor Stage Rally in N.H.L.
text: Donald Fehr, the executive director of the players union, had just finished a news conference Thursday in which he described the union’s latest offer to end the N.H.L. lockout, and how he believed it provided a “clear outline” for ending the dispute. Players like Sidney Crosby and Brad Richards were expressing guarded optimism to reporters about returning to the ice.

headline: Morsi Defends Wide Authority as Turmoil Rises in Egypt
text: CAIRO — Egypt descended deeper into political turmoil on Thursday as the embattled president, Mohamed Morsi, blamed an outbreak of violence on a “fifth column” and vowed to proceed with a referendum on an Islamist-backed constitution that has prompted deadly street battles between his supporters and their opponents.

headline: Minorities Report
text: LONDON — On Monday, a dozen masked gunmen said to be affiliated with the ­Taliban and Lashkar-e-Taiba broke into a graveyard in an elite neighborhood of Lahore, the historic capital of Punjab Province. They tied up the guard, a caretaker and about 20 visitors, and then vandalized 120 gravestones.

headline: Barclays Increases Stake in Absa Group in $2.1 Billion Deal
text: LONDON – The British bank Barclays agreed on Thursday to increase its stake in its South African subsidiary, the Absa Group, as it moved to consolidate its operations across Africa.

headline: Standard Chartered to Pay $330 Million to Settle Iran Money Transfer Claims
text: HONG KONG – The British bank Standard Chartered said on Thursday that it expected to pay $330 million to settle claims by United States government agencies that it had moved hundreds of billions of dollars on behalf of Iran.

headline: U.N. Envoy Is Seeking a Deal to Oust Assad From Syria
text: DUBLIN — With the support of the United States, the United Nations special envoy on Syria is mounting a diplomatic push for a brokered agreement that would lead to the ouster of the country’s president, Bashar al-Assad, and the installation of a transitional government.

headline: In Gujarat’s Gir Forest, India’s Most Privileged Voter
text: BANEJ, Gujarat — Nestled in the heart of Gir forest, home to the rare Asiatic lion, in Gujarat (where the Hindu nationalist Bharatiya Janata Party rules), is a hamlet called Banej.

headline: Art Basel Miami Beach: Pregame Events
text: “Few events at Art Basel Miami Beach start before 11 a.m., so that everyone can recover from the previous evening’s partying,” Patricia Cohen reports from the fair on our sister blog ArtsBeat.

text: In “When My Friend Ellen Grossman Met Jay-Z,” Tanzina Vega writes about the woman in the video posted above.

headline: Lynchings in the West, Erased From History and Photos
text: At first, “Disguised Bandit” — a life-size reproduction of a century-old postcard by Ken Gonzales-Day — does not suggest anything out of the ordinary. A sparse tree cuts the center of the photograph. A group of white American soldiers flanks the tree. One man grins. The others stare passively into the camera.

headline: The Real Fiscal Risks in the United States
text: Simon Johnson is the Ronald A. Kurtz Professor of Entrepreneurship at the M.I.T. Sloan School of Management.

headline: Is It Wrong for a Newspaper to Publish a Front-Page Photo of a Man About to Die?
text: Note: This Student Opinion question refers to a photograph that teachers may or may not wish to show to students. We have purposely not republished the photograph here, although we are providing a link to The Times City Room column, which published a photo of the New York Post front page and asked its readers a similar question.

headline: Week 14 N.F.L. Game Probabilities: The Sanchez Mistake
text: With Mark Sanchez’s benching last Sunday, it’s time to see how his 2012 production compares with his previous seasons. To be fair, Sanchez is not surrounded with as much talent as he has been in previous years. However, the nature of the quarterback position is such that truly skilled quarterbacks are able to transcend the limitations of the players around them. Just this season, we’ve seen rookies like Russell Wilson, Robert Griffin III and Andrew Luck instantly and significantly improve their offenses despite having about the same or less supporting talent than their teams had a year before.

headline: Tip of the Week: Bookmarks on the Home Screen
text: Google’s Android operating system and Apple’s iOS software both include a Web browser that lets you save bookmarks. For sites you visit frequently, however, it is often faster to get to your favorite page with the mobile equivalent of a desktop shortcut — an icon on the phone’s home screen — instead of fiddling around with the browser’s bookmark menu.

headline: Hong Kong’s Leader Seeks to Ease Concerns About Mainland China’s Influence
text: HONG KONG — Seeking to address a local backlash against mainland Chinese control, the chief executive of Hong Kong called Thursday for closer relations with the mainland but also emphasized his willingness to impose limits on mainland visitors and investors.

headline: Part 4: College Students Answer Reader Questions on Admissions and Campus Life
text: The Choice has invited two of our former student bloggers of “The Envelope, Please” series to stop by our virtual Guidance Office and answer reader questions about the admissions process and what college life is like after you’ve made your choice.

headline: Five Americans Who Could Leave M.L.S. and Head Abroad This Winter
text: The Major League Soccer season is over, and December has already seen several players move from one M.L.S. team to another.

headline: The Early Word: Togetherness
text: In Today’s Times:

headline: Enhancing Classics With Old-Car Style and Modern Mechanicals
text: Once shunned by purists, older collector cars and lookalikes fitted with modern engines, transmissions, brakes, electronic controls and sound systems are gaining new respect. Broadly known as restomods, cars that have been updated under the skin are as easy to drive, and often as safe and reliable, as a new model. And after modernization, these sought-after vehicles are unlikely to be garage queens, gathering dust.

headline: New eBay Product Aims to Harness User Data to Aid Auto Marketers
text: EBay is joining the growing hordes of companies that are offering even more data to advertisers to help them better reach intended customers, in this instance companies that sell cars, trucks, motorcycles and R.V.’s and run digital ads on ebay.com.

headline: A Conversation With: Author William Dalrymple
text: The Scottish historian and travel writer William Dalrymple’s new book “Return of a King: The Battle for Afghanistan 1839-1842” is an eloquent, animated account of the first Anglo-Afghan war, long regarded as Britain’s most disastrous imperial adventure. He spoke with India Ink about writing narrative history; the parallels between the first Anglo-Afghan war and the war on terror; and what the West could learn from his book.

headline: Aid Group Hit by Car Bomb in Damascus
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — As fighting raged in the Damascus suburbs, a car bomb exploded in the southern Zahraa district on Thursday, killing one person and damaging the headquarters of the Syrian Arab Red Crescent relief organization, state news media reported.

headline: How the ‘Death With Dignity’ Initiative Failed in Massachusetts
text: On election night, Jim Carberry and others who had worked to put a “Death With Dignity” law on the Massachusetts ballot gathered in the back room of a Waltham restaurant and watched their effort go down to narrow defeat.

headline: Shipping Horses Is Risky, but Hong Kong Race Is Enticing
text: Horses from around the world, and the people who own and look after them, have been traveling over the past week to take part in the Hong Kong International Races, four Group 1 contests at Sha Tin Racecourse on Sunday. Once they land, they get red-carpet treatment that the owners and trainers will probably be talking about for years.

headline: Billionaire Sells Stake in Topshop for $805 Million
text: The British billionaire Philip Green sold a 25 percent stake in the Topshop retail chain to the American private equity firm Leonard Green & Partners, which co-owns the J. Crew brand, for about $805 million.

headline: Daimler Sells Half Its Stake in EADS for $2.2 Billion
text: LONDON – The German carmaker Daimler sold half of its stake in the aerospace giant European Aeronautic Defense and Space on Thursday in deal worth 1.7 billion euros ($2.2 billion).

headline: Eggnog the Hard Way
text: Around this time last year, I advocated forgoing eggnog in favor of glogg, the Scandinavian mulled wine. I’m not here to issue a mea culpa, but I’m also not proud when it comes to holiday drinks and certainly not above a little backpedaling.

headline: How to Tame a Wild Pork Chop
text: Here, then, were two young people climbing through a canyon in morning half-light, Central Texas, stalking hogs. They were private chefs enjoying a morning free of clients, smelling faintly of the Angora sweater one of the chefs wore and also of last night’s red wine. They were headachy, and trying not to stumble in the scree that tumbled off the canyon’s walls as pigs above them rooted amid low oak and thickets of juniper. They had one rifle between them, and they walked slowly, heel to toe, so as not to make noise.

headline: A Social Business Strikes a Deal With Big Tobacco
text: A few months ago I wrote a blog post about TerraCycle’s intention to create a national recycling program for all waste, even including cigarette butts. As our programs have grown, we have had frequent internal debates about what kinds of companies we want to partner with to help them make their waste recyclable (which in turn makes their products greener).

headline: Afghan Spy Chief Is Wounded in Attack, Officials Say
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — A Taliban suicide bomber tried to assassinate the influential new chief of Afghanistan’s intelligence service at an agency guesthouse in Kabul on Thursday, officials said, in a brazen attack that left him seriously wounded and underscored the insurgency’s ability to go after those at the highest levels of the government.

headline: Morsi and the Balance of Power
text: Egypt erupted in violent clashes after President Morsi seized temporary powers beyond the review of any court.

headline: View From Boston on Sanchez: Thanks, Rex
text: Perhaps it’s the holiday spirit, but Patriots fans and Jets management seem to be in rare agreement these days.  Any rancor in an intense rivalry has been replaced by thanks, deep thanks. The Jets want Mark Sanchez to be the starting quarterback. And so, it turns out, do Patriots fans.

headline: Deutsche Bank Says Report That It Hid Losses Lacks Merit
text: PARIS – The big German lender Deutsche Bank on Thursday denied a report that it had hidden $12 billion in losses during the financial crisis. The bank said charges made by whistle-blowers had been investigated previously and found to be without merit.

headline: Thai Ex-Premier Charged With Murder Over Crackdown in 2010
text: HONG KONG — The former prime minister of Thailand, Abhisit Vejjajiva, was charged with murder on Thursday in connection with his role in a military crackdown on antigovernment protesters in Bangkok two and a half years ago.

headline: Congo Peace Talks Set to Open in Uganda
text: KAMPALA, Uganda — Congolese rebels and government officials prepared on Thursday for direct peace talks in the Ugandan capital, Kampala, their first face-to-face encounter since the rebels relinquished Goma, one of the Democratic Republic of Congo’s principal cities, after capturing it last month.

text: Alex Pareene gets it:

text: LONDON — Spare a thought for wealthy tax cheats.

headline: European Central Bank Cuts Growth Forecast
text: FRANKFURT — Acknowledging that the economy is likely to remain weak well into next year, the European Central Bank sharply reduced its growth forecast for the euro zone Thursday, and left its main interest rate unchanged at a record low of 0.75 percent.

headline: Kissing Cousins: One Is President
text: Peering into famous bedrooms is a pastime of biographers and filmmakers alike, and this season offers several opportunities for the nosily inclined. Alfred Hitchcock, as well as Elizabeth Taylor and Richard Burton, have all recently received the keyhole treatment; even Abraham Lincoln helps loosen Mary’s corset in the otherwise buttoned-up “Lincoln.” And in “Hyde Park on Hudson,” filmgoers can watch some presidential pleasuring, courtesy of Franklin Delano Roosevelt (Bill Murray) and his obliging cousin, Daisy Suckley (Laura Linney).

headline: Week 13 Film Review, Horror Edition
text: Andy Benoit takes a closer look at some Week 13 matchups, with the benefit of film analysis.

headline: In Shift of Jobs, Apple Will Make Some Macs in U.S.
text: Apple plans to join a small but growing number of companies that are bringing some manufacturing jobs back to the United States, drawn by the growing economic and political advantages of producing in their home market.

headline: Notes on Current Research
text: Busy today, so just quick notes on two recent working papers.

headline: Thursday Reading: Avoiding Too Much Stuff at the Holidays

headline: Recurring Name in Insider Trading Inquiry: SAC
text: In the government’s long-running investigation into insider trading, one hedge fund has continued to surface: SAC Capital Advisors, the $14 billion firm run by Steven A. Cohen. With federal prosecutors now going after a former SAC portfolio manager, DealBook’s Peter Lattman reports that the trail to SAC “has emerged out of a cluster of cases, many of them connected to the prosecution of the fallen titan Raj Rajaratnam. Investigators heard SAC traders on incriminating wiretaps; in other instances, cooperators and informants accused the fund of misconduct.”

headline: Toronto-Dominion to Buy Epoch for $668 Million
text: The Canadian lender Toronto-Dominion Bank agreed on Thursday to buy the parent company of Epoch Investment Partners for $668 million, as it moved to bolster its asset management operations in the United States.

headline: Diamondback to Close After Investors Withdraw $520 Million
text: Diamondback Capital Management, one of several hedge funds ensnared in the government’s insider-trading investigations, will close down after investors asked to withdraw $520 million in capital, the firm wrote in a letter to investors on Thursday.

headline: Daily Report: Apple to Bring Some Manufacturing to U.S.
text: For the first time in years, Apple will manufacture computers in the United States, the chief executive of Apple, Timothy D. Cook, said in interviews with NBC and Bloomberg Businessweek.

headline: A Note for the Transit Chief: Beware the Endorsement From Giuliani
text: If the mass-transit chief, Joseph J. Lhota, is serious about running for mayor next year, he ought to start worrying about the enthusiastic support he is getting from former Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani. As Mr. Lhota surely knows — he was Mr. Giuliani’s deputy at City Hall, after all — a blessing from his old boss is a political version of the kiss of death.

headline: The Brotherhood of Combat
text: Marine Corps boot camp inundated us with footage from Iwo Jima, images from Chosin Reservoir and stories of Khe Sanh. As I deployed to Iraq and Afghanistan I pondered what it is during the horrors of combat that drives us on, and if the experiences of war are the same across generations.

headline: Viva la Villa | Vampires in Volterra
text: Adventures in house-hunting: a writer chronicles her attempt to find the perfect home in Italy.

headline: General Atlantic Takes Stake in Brazilian Firm
text: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — The American private equity firm General Atlantic has agreed to invest $200 million for a minority stake in the Brazilian financial services firm XP Investimentos.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: British Newspapers’ Regulation Plan; and Brubeck, Jazz Popularizer
text: Britain’s main national newspapers on Wednesday agreed to the establishment of an independent newspaper regulator with far greater powers than the current, much-criticized regulation system, John F. Burns reports. The agreement came after pressure from Prime Minister David Cameron, who has agreed with the publishers that any change in regulation should be voluntary, and not be written into law, as was recommended by the Leveson inquiry, which investigated press abuses in Britain. Mr. Burns writes:

headline: Trust Women Conference: A Delegate’s Reflections
text: LONDON — The first Trust Women conference, hosted by Thomson Reuters Foundation and the International Herald Tribune in London this week, boasted an impressive line up of speakers — from Melanne Verveer, the U.S. ambassador-at-large for global women’s issues to Christy Turlington Burns of Every Mother Counts to Queen Noor of Jordan, to name a few.

text: Jason and Justin Sablich will provide fantasy football advice and analysis throughout the season on this blog and on Twitter @5thDownFantasy.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: NPR: The dairy cliff: milk producers, who have no safety net, would be hit hard if Congress does not pass a new farm bill. — Maria Newman

headline: Sorry, ‘Lincoln,’ That Wasn’t Your Day
text: The National Board of Review had its say on Wednesday, and it was a good day for everyone except the more than 100 actors (not to mention the hundreds of crew members, dozens of producers and one very important writer and celebrated director) in “Lincoln.”

headline: Starbucks Offers to Pay More British Tax Than Required
text: PARIS — Starbucks offered on Wednesday to pay about £10 million ($16.05 million) a year in corporate taxes in Britain — or £10 million more than it paid last year — in an effort to defuse protests against its lack of contributions to public coffers at a time when ordinary taxpayers are feeling the effects of government spending cuts.

headline: A Fresh Look at the Not-So-Dark Side of Earth
text: Fresh imagery showing the increasingly illuminated night side of Earth has been produced by NASA and the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration. This is one of the clearest visible signs of the Anthropocene — an era in which one species, us, is becoming a planet-scale influence. The imagery also shows big dark gaps in populous places — reflecting the reality that some 1.3 billion people still lack access to electricity.

headline: Searching for Latinos in Children’s Literature: A Reading List
text: Where are all the Latinos? That’s the question raised in an article published Wednesday in The Times that focused on the dearth of books with Latino characters that are aimed at school-age children. (No disrespect meant to the hugely popular Dora the Explorer or her cousin Diego, who started as cartoons.) This is an especially relevant issue given the increasing number of the country’s public school seats occupied by Latinos.

headline: An Age-Old Question: Readers Debate Science and Theology
text: Last week’s essay, “Between Rock of Ages and a Hard Place,” by Nicholas Wade, on a comment by Senator Marco Rubio of Florida that the age of the earth was “one of the great mysteries,” prompted dozens of letters. Here are some of them, followed by a response from Mr. Wade.

text: From the editorial page

headline: Partners’ Stake in Goldman Sachs Rises
text: The number of partners at Goldman Sachs has remained steady. But the elite group’s ownership in the Wall Street firm is rising.

headline: A Money Saving Phone Service Is Revived
text: In past years I have advised people looking to lower their phone bills to try the Web site Validas. It let them electronically enter their phone bills, which it analyzed, then suggested lower-priced plans that still gave them the same service or better.

headline: Mayor Pledges to Rebuild and Fortify Coast
text: New York City, still reeling from the impact of Hurricane Sandy, will expand its evacuation zones, tighten building codes and look for ways to fortify critical infrastructure like transportation and electrical networks from future natural disasters, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said Thursday.

headline: Carnegie Hall Dream Comes True for Medgar Evers’s Widow
text: Myrlie Evers-Williams, the widow of the slain civil rights leader Medgar Evers, has long shared the dream of many an aspiring musician: playing Carnegie Hall. Now, at age 79, Ms. Evers-Williams will get that chance, thanks to the persuasive power of the pop orchestra Pink Martini.

headline: Up in the Air
text: BERLIN — It’s the city’s biggest construction project since the Berlin Wall. But 20 years after it was first conceived and almost $4 billion dollars later, Berlin’s new airport is a hulking empty terminal with no planes and no passengers.

headline: Ian McEwan: By the Book
text: The author of “Atonement” and, most recently, “Sweet Tooth,” believes the greatest reading pleasure has “an element of self-annihilation.”

text: NEW HAVEN

headline: Yale University Art Gallery
text: Images of renovations at the museum.

headline: Ben Brantley Answers Readers’ Questions, Part 2
text: Yesterday Ben Brantley, the chief theater critic of The New York Times, answered readers’ questions about new scores, populist theater and other topics. Following is the final installment of his responses.

headline: Feeling For | Woodcut Notecards
text: Beautiful and strangely emotive, “Woodcut” was easily one of 2012’s best coffee table books. It collected the artist Bryan Nash Gill’s dramatic relief prints of tree-trunk cross sections in his native Connecticut. Ahead of the holiday giving season, Princeton Architectural Press has turned Gill’s images into a lovely set of 12 notecards and envelopes. $16; papress.com.

headline: Tea Party Hero Is Leaving the Senate for a New Pulpit
text: WASHINGTON — With a disappointing election in his rear view mirror and a budget compromise he could never swallow on the horizon, Senator Jim DeMint, the conservative Republican from South Carolina who helped ignite the Tea Party movement, is leaving the Senate to become president of the Heritage Foundation, a conservative research group.

headline: Keeping Score: Early Contenders for Most Improved Player
text: With the first full month of the 2012-13 N.B.A. season in the books, many pundits have pegged Jrue Holiday, who leads the Philadelphia 76ers in scoring and is second in the league in assists (but also leads the league in turnovers), as their early choice for most improved player.

headline: How Should New York Rebuild?
text: On Wednesday night, New York University’s Institute for Public Knowledge sponsored a public forum on the recent superstorm‘s implications for New York City, where many low-lying areas face a long and painful recovery — if full recovery is indeed the goal. Moderated by Chelsea Clinton, now a special correspondent for NBC News, the forum included four panelists from the fields of earth science, climate science, philosophy and sociology who reflected on how the likelihood of more frequent storm surges might be woven into the city’s urban planning.

headline: Blocks From Art Basel, Artists with More Modest Hopes
text: MIAMI BEACH — As dealers in the main fair at Art Basel Miami Beach were counting up six- and seven-figure sales from Wednesday’s V.I.P. preview, participants in SELECT, one of the numerous nearby satellite fairs here, were welcoming guests at the Catalina Hotel. The hopeful artists and gallery owners who paid $4,000 to $5,000 to transform one of the hotel’s 64 rooms into a mini gallery, installation space or performance site had different expectations than their brethren a few blocks away.

headline: Image of the Day: Dec. 6
text: India commemorates the anniversary of the death of B. R. Ambedkar.

headline: Video: Van Catches Fire Outside St. Patrick’s
text: File this one under common occurrence in uncommon location: a van caught fire and burned for an hour Wednesday night on Fifth Avenue and 50th Street, in front of St. Patrick’s Cathedral and across from Rockefeller Center. No one was injured in the fire, which was reported around 6:50 p.m. and put out by 7:48, the Fire Department said.

headline: Michael Caine, Scene Partner
text: In the annals of things the Bagger never expected to do – a long list including but not limited to hugging R2-D2; playing paintball with the star of an Oscar-winning film; and dressing up like a demented ballet demon – acting opposite Michael Caine ranked pretty high.

headline: Elizabeth Warren Still Carrying Campaign Debt
text: BOSTON — A final fund-raising haul of more than $42 million was not enough to keep Elizabeth Warren’s Senate campaign out of debt.

headline: BMW Recalling 30,000 X5 Sport Utilities
text: BMW is recalling almost 30,000 of its diesel-powered 2009-12 X5 sport utilities because the power-assist for the steering may fail, according to a report from the automaker posted on the Web site of the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration.

headline: Hollywood’s Year of Heroine Worship
text: Ordinarily, the unemployment of a film critic would be the very definition of a dog-bites-man story, but the circumstances that separated Michael Calleri from his job at The Niagara Falls Reporter, a small weekly newspaper in upstate New York, were sufficiently peculiar — and also sufficiently resonant — to go a bit viral, stirring up a minor storm on the Internet and attracting the attention of a network morning-news show. This was a man-bites-man story that also turned out to be a man-freaks-out-about-women story. In a long narrative uploaded in November by Roger Ebert on The Chicago Sun-Times’s Web site, Calleri quoted an e-mail from his boss, Frank Parlato (curiously unnamed in the article), who had recently taken over as editor and publisher of The Reporter. Parlato was not, to put it mildly, a fan of Calleri’s movie reviews, but his real problem was with the movies themselves. “I don’t want to publish reviews of films where women are alpha and men are beta,” he wrote. “Where women are heroes and villains and men are just lesser versions or shadows of females.”

headline: Netanyahu, in Visit to Germany, Defends Settlement Plans

headline: Ideas for English Language Learners | Celebrate the Holidays
text: This month’s edition of Ideas for E.L.L’s celebrates the holidays — Christmas, Hanukkah, Kwanzaa, New Year’s, even winter break — but, of course, just as you can pick, choose and adapt ideas from previous posts in this series, much of what we suggest below can be taught any time of year.

text: From the annals of Research Studies We Appreciate, Even Though We Aren’t Quite Sure What to Do With the Information, via The Atlantic: being a parent means you’re less likely to die before your time.

headline: Yankees Offer Youkilis One-Year Deal to Play Third
text: NASHVILLE — The Yankees took a step toward filling their hole at third base Thursday by making a one-year, $12 million offer to the free agent Kevin Youkilis.

headline: Not a Member of the Kathryn Bigelow Fan Club
text: As she has made Oscar history as the first woman to win an Academy Award for directing, Kathryn Bigelow, the filmmaker behind “The Hurt Locker” and the forthcoming “Zero Dark Thirty,” has remained gracious and graceful about her place in the cinematic canon. Not so Bret Easton Ellis, who took to Twitter to deliver his opinion on her films, her gender and her looks:

headline: Soccer’s Celluoid Antihero: ‘Heleno’
text: Heleno de Freitas tortured defenders to distraction and himself to death.

headline: Why Does My Food Have Less Flavor?
text: They are a ghastly orange color when they tumble out of their crinkly package with its flamelike logo, and salt mines and chemical plants may come to mind when you eat the first one, but, man, those tortilla chips are tasty. Or maybe it’s just that you can actually taste them. Because sorry, Charlie: as we get older, there may come a time when we find ourselves drawn not to food with good taste or food that tastes good but simply to food that has any flavor at all.

headline: Open Source Science Fair Video
text: Did you miss our Open Source Science Fair last month? Or are you just ready to relive all the fun of it? Either way, you’ll want to watch the videos of the event. Thanks to NYT developer David Seguin for his excellent camera work. Enjoy!

headline: U.S. Military to Monitor for Rocket
text: WASHINGTON — The commander of American military forces in the Pacific region said Thursday that warships equipped with advanced radar and other ballistic-missile defense systems were being relocated to monitor a potential rocket launching by North Korea.

headline: Rabbis Apologize for Tone of E-Mail on U.N. Vote
text: Facing outrage from some of their members, the rabbis who lead Congregation B’nai Jeshurun, a prominent synagogue in Manhattan, expressed regret Thursday at the tone of an e-mail that they sent last week celebrating the controversial vote by the United Nations to upgrade Palestine to observer-state status.

headline: Love Unleashed on the London Stage
text: LONDON—Love may or may not make the world go round, but it’s certainly doing its bit for the London theater. On stages large and small, across new plays and revivals and musicals, too, the vagaries of passion are fueling one show after another. “Cantiamo D’Amore” – “we sing of love” – or so announces a number in “Kiss Me, Kate,” the Cole Porter musical that has been newly revived in a Trevor Nunn-directed production at the Old Vic that, truth be told, is a mixed bag.

headline: Does Apple’s Tim Cook Want an Apple Television?
text: Apple customers have been yearning for it for years. And now, it seems, the chief executive of Apple, Timothy D. Cook, wants one too: an Apple-made television.

text: Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton praised Susan E. Rice, the United Nations ambassador and a leading contender to be the next secretary of state, during a news conference in Dublin on Thursday.

headline: Crusading New Orleans Prosecutor to Quit, Facing Staff Misconduct
text: NEW ORLEANS — Once again, as he has for over a decade, Jim Letten, the chief federal prosecutor here, appeared before reporters, just as he regularly has to announce that some suspiciously well-connected city contractor was facing a lengthy spell behind bars. But this time was different.

headline: Why Breaking Up H.P. Makes Sense
text: David Packard and William Hewlett may be Silicon Valley’s answer to Romulus and Remus in Rome’s founding story, but the era of their brainchild, Hewlett-Packard, as an everything-to-everyone conglomerate is coming to an end. Its chief executive, Meg Whitman, and its board, not to mention investors, won’t stick around for an arduous and risky five-year turnaround project. Breaking the company into good bits and selling bad ones must be on the agenda for 2013.

headline: Doing the Shareholder Sidestep
text: It may be an ego-bruising realization, but sometimes in a deal public shareholders just don’t matter.

headline: Best Bets for Finding the Snow
text: Forget racing down the slopes. The sport skiers have had to master in recent years has been chasing the snow.

headline: Creating Winter for Cross-Country Skiers
text: THEY came by the dozens, drawn to a white oasis in a land of green and brown. A high school teacher and eight students drove halfway across Vermont. A lawyer made the trip from his home, an hour away. Three vans pulled into the dirt parking lot at noon and disgorged 22 Bates College students, bleary-eyed after the four-hour drive from Maine.

headline: Jazz Impresario to Present Shows at Iridium
text: One of the most celebrated jazz impresarios in the country is starting over, booking a new series of concerts at Iridium in Midtown Manhattan after stepping down from his longtime post at Jazz at Lincoln Center.
