headline: Barclays Center
text: Inside the new home of the Brooklyn Nets, where a variety of Brooklyn vendors sell treats both savory and sweet.

headline: As the Year Draws to a Close, Deciding How to Slice Your Charitable Pie
text: Each year at this time, out of some combination of generosity and procrastination, millions of Americans rush to make donations to the causes and institutions important to them.

headline: A.I.G. in Talks to Sell Control of Its Aircraft Leasing Unit
text: The American International Group said on Friday that it was in talks to sell a majority stake in its big aircraft leasing unit to a group led by several Chinese institutions. It would be another major asset sale by the bailed-out insurer, which is still paying off billions it received from the federal government.

headline: A Son Lost, a Mother Found
text: My friend Yvonne was already at the front door when I woke, so at first I didn’t realize that my mother was missing.

headline: Brooklyn’s Home-Court Advantage
text: “Do you know what the Brooklyn dog is?” the woman behind the Nathan’s counter says sternly. “It is not a regular dog.”

headline: Poking Fun at Nuns Onstage, With Big Returns
text: CHICAGO — When did nuns become funny?

headline: Video: Post-Hurricane Politics in New York City
text: The response to Hurricane Sandy may have played a role in last month’s presidential election, and now New York City’s mayoral race, a year away, is being transformed by the storm and its effect on the city.

headline: Updates on Protests in Egypt
text: The Lede is following the political crisis in Egypt, where supporters and opponents of President Mohamed Morsi rallied on Friday.

headline: Dispatches From Your Dinner-Table Charity Discussions
text: In this weekend’s Your Money column, I urge readers to come up with an asset allocation for their charitable dollars, just as many people do for their investment portfolios. And in figuring out the right mix of global versus national versus local giving, or choosing among organizations within those categories, it makes sense to reckon with the argument that the most ethical approach is to give to organizations that can save lives for very little money half a world away.

headline: Goldman to Pay $1.5 Million for Failing to Supervise Trader
text: Goldman Sachs has agreed to pay $1.5 million to settle federal accusations that it failed to supervise a trader who fabricated “huge” positions at the bank, a modest deal that divided the government regulators who brought the case.

headline: Wide-Awake
text: A video gallery of dreams and transformations, featuring 13 actresses whose performances defined the year in film.

headline: Blend Your Vegetables
text: Your mother told you to eat your vegetables. Now the Recipes for Health columnist Martha Rose Shulman suggests blending them. She writes:

headline: Carried Away on a Cinematic Tsunami
text: WHAT begins as a leisurely family vacation in Thailand turns into destruction and despair in “The Impossible,” one of a few films this year in which characters respond to, and struggle to overcome, a natural disaster. But in this case it shares elements with horror films.

headline: Big Ticket | Sold for $33.5 Million
text: A large and lavish duplex penthouse that dominates one of the asymmetrical towers at the Park Laurel, a luxury condominium residence built in 2000 and anchored by the historic McBurney School, sold for $33.5 million and was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.

headline: When $250,000 Isn’t Actually $250,000
text: Binyamin Appelbaum and I have an article in Friday’s paper about President Obama’s proposal to raise marginal income tax rates for married couples earning “more than $250,000.”

headline: Quirks of the Game: The Roster Challenge
text: When a baseball team loses a player to a midseason injury it fills that roster spot by calling up someone from the minor leagues, someone who has been playing regularly and coached by someone in the organization. But for N.F.L. teams the replacement is someone from the practice squad, who has probably not played a game all year, or someone sitting on his couch at home hoping for such a phone call.

headline: Dismayed at Google’s Privacy Policy, European Group Is Weighing Censure
text: European data protection officials are drafting plans to censure Google over its online privacy policy if the company does not meet the demands of regulators to revise it.

headline: Banks Agree to Sell Back Some Greek Bonds
text: LONDON — Greece moved a step closer to completing a complex debt-reduction deal on Friday when the country’s largest banks said they had agreed to sell their discounted bonds back to the government.

headline: It’s Beginning to Feel a Lot Like . . . the End of the World
text: It’s getting to be that time of year again — the Mayan long year, I mean. The 13th and current baktun comes to an end in a matter of weeks, on the winter solstice. (Those 144,000 days just flew by, didn’t they.) Maybe you have kids of a certain age (or apocalyptic bent) who’ve brought it up? They seem to be joking about it in school lately. Or maybe you recall a passing mention in the magazine last month. (“The Vivos Group, which sells luxury bunkers, until recently had a clock on its Web site that was ticking down to Dec. 21, 2012 — a date that, thanks to the Mayan calendar, some believe will usher in the end times.”)

headline: Pompidou Center Reaches Across Atlantic for a Curator
text: French museums like the Louvre and the Pompidou Center seem to like all things American. The Louvre commissioned Cy Twombly to create a 3,750-square-foot ceiling for its Salle des Bronzes, which was unveiled two years ago next door to a ceiling triptych created more than half a century before by Georges Braque.

headline: Freeport Deals Too Cozy for Comfort
text: Freeport-McMoRan Copper and Gold’s foray into energy keeps getting cozier for the top executives involved. The mining company’s market value has plunged by $6 billion following news of its planned purchase of Plains Exploration and Production and McMoRan Exploration. Yet Jim Bob Moffett, Freeport’s chairman, and James Flores, chief executive of Plains, will come out ahead.

headline: On Our Radar: A Plant Stress Index
text: Government satellites’ measurements of “plant stress” anticipated the arrival of this year’s severe drought in the United States a month before the nation’s drought monitor did. [The Atlantic]

headline: A Party Swirling Nonstop, Safely
text: The grants, gigs, residencies and commissions have been coming fast and furious for the 35-year-old choreographer Kyle Abraham.

headline: Buzzed
text: Designers began showing collections for prefall 2013 this week in New York, and the looks were strong enough to give you a little buzz. While the season’s preview collections will go on through January, there is already a hint of the look to come, with a focus on sleek leather coats at Michael Kors and Alexander Wang, for example. And one coincidence that came up was the appearance of shearling that had been shaved so close to the skin in the collections of both Francisco Costa at Calvin Klein and Reed Krakoff that it looked like velvet.

headline: Advice for Avoiding Bad Investment Decisions
text: Paul Sullivan, in his Wealth Matters column this week, uses the fourth anniversary of the collapse of a string of investor frauds (including the biggest, the one involving Bernard L. Madoff) to offer some advice on avoiding similar frauds.

headline: Justices to Hear Two Challenges on Gay Marriage
text: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court announced on Friday that it would enter the national debate over same-sex marriage, agreeing to hear a pair of cases challenging state and federal laws that define marriage to include only unions of a man and a woman.

headline: Scene City: Art Basel as a Celebrity Magnet
text: Bruce Weber feted his new book, and Aby Rosen held his annual A-list dinner and after party.

headline: How to Be a Jew at Christmas
text: My social butterfly of a son waved at the woman standing in line at a local Starbucks. Simon was intrigued that the 20-something woman wore Army fatigues. She was curious about my 4-year-old’s holiday plans.

headline: Land of Light Taxes and Heavy Shopping
text: EAST HANOVER wasn’t spared much misery when the hurricane struck in late October. Trees were downed and power was out as long as two weeks. Then, once lights and heating came back on, Lisa Beck recalled, an electrical surge almost immediately sparked a fire at her neighbor’s house.

headline: Parties Precede and Proceed
text: THURSDAY was the official opening of Art Basel Miami Beach, but the partying was well into its third night.

headline: Cellos Frame Sculptures in Stop-and-Go Motion
text: When a choreographer takes inspiration from a French master like Auguste Rodin, alarm bells go off. Doesn’t it sound like a school assignment? In “The Rodin Project,”  performed at the Joyce Theater on Wednesday evening, the effect is more aimless and impressionistic than didactic.

headline: Pay Wall Push: Why Newspapers Are Hopping Over the Picket Fence
text: When The Wall Street Journal broke the news that The Washington Post was likely to start charging for online content sometime next year, it should not have come as a surprise, but it did.

headline: An Appeal to President Obama’s Better Side
text: This is a blog post about excessive secrecy, unsanctioned killing and an administration that abuses power to block court actions aimed at imposing accountability and review on its policy making.

headline: Off the Charts: Is the Banking Crisis Over?
text: Since the European Central Bank took steps to assure the banks could borrow money, and it became clear that Germany was not willing to allow the euro zone to break up, euro zone bank stocks have been among the best investments around.

headline: Q & A
text: Rule, but No Law, on Carpeting Requirements

headline: Week in Review: Gatorade, Michael Jordan and Insider Trading
text: The S.E.C. didn’t like a Netflix post on Facebook. | Peter Lattman followed a trail of insider cases to SAC Capital Advisors. | Citigroup said it would cut 11,000 jobs. | Warren E. Buffett sat down for an interview with Andrew Ross Sorkin. | Five firms were charged over audits in China. | A trader at Morgan Stanley faces an inquiry on a possible manipulation. | UBS is reported to be near a deal on rate rigging.

headline: The Gift of Winter Comfort
text: Gift ideas include blankets, candleholders, fan heaters and towel warmers.

headline: Hollywood Issue | Wide-Awake
text: Ingénues, icons, action heroes, divas and the world’s next great comedy star: 13 actresses who gave the dreamiest performances of 2012.

headline: A Bypassed Bellini Gets Its Due
text: The impressive and busy Collegiate Chorale regularly provides New York opera buffs a service by presenting concert performances of rarities at Carnegie Hall. It did so again on Wednesday, when James Bagwell, the chorus’s music director, conducted Bellini’s seldom-heard “Beatrice di Tenda” with a strong cast and the American Symphony Orchestra.

headline: Graphic Books Best Sellers: ‘Fables’ Spinoff Starring Sleeping Beauty
text: The writer Bill Willingham and “Fables,” the series he created, are no strangers to our graphic books best-seller lists. Now the first volume of that book’s spinoff, “Fairest,” has joined in, landing at No. 5 on our paperback list this week. Featuring intricate artwork by Phil Jimenez, the story follows Sleeping Beauty after she is woken by Ali Baba, the prince of thieves, who does not have the purest of intentions for the heroine.

headline: Sweet or Savory, a Bite at a Time
text: IN my very first restaurant job, I learned to make pâte à choux, the classic French pastry that is used for cream puffs and éclairs. I had to learn in a hurry, too, because my boss had just decided to make me the pastry chef, a position for which I was not remotely qualified. Yes, I knew how to bake bread, and I had experimented with pies, but I had no clue about producing fancy pastries for a “Continental” restaurant. No problem, the chef said, as he handed me recipes for the desserts I would be required to make daily: cream puffs, floating island, baked alaska and cheesecake.

headline: Newly Delayed Bike Share Program Is Now to Begin in May
text: First it was the software. Now it is the surge.

headline: Campaign Postscript Offers a Peek at Debates on Security and Spending
text: LAWRENCE, Kan. – President Obama resisted the blue goose.

headline: Consumer Reports Questions Ford’s Fuel Economy Ratings
text: Consumer Reports said on Thursday that its tests showed the 2013 Ford Fusion Hybrid and C-Max Hybrid fall short of the estimated fuel economy numbers assigned by the Environmental Protection Agency.

headline: The Grooves That Have Pulsed Before
text: It’s not hard to pick up on historical echoes in the music of Reggie Quinerly. A conscientious jazz drummer with a nimble and approachable style, Mr. Quinerly can naturally call a handful of his precursors to mind, especially the steady-humming engines of hard bop’s heyday, like Art Taylor, Louis Hayes and Jimmy Cobb.

headline: European Banks Thriving as Investor Fears Ease
text: THE European bank crisis was one of the major worries of 2012. There were forecasts that the euro zone would break up, that various countries would default on their debts and that undercapitalized banks would fail because national governments could not afford to keep them alive.

headline: Romance, From Tristan and Isolde to Today
text: In its first moments, the composer David Lang’s new vocal work “love fail” establishes the subdued and mystical mood it will sustain for more than an hour.

headline: Techniques to Up Your Holiday Baking
text: The holiday party season approaches, bringing all manner of baked goods in its wake. Two of my favorite bite-sized treatsfrom the oven are classic cheese puffs and cream puffs, both featured in this week’s City Kitchen column. The dough, which in French is called pâte à choux, is pretty easy to put together, once you learn the technique.

headline: Aston Martin, With New Cash, Moves to Next Step
text: A high-stakes battle for the heart and soul, if not control, of the sports car maker Aston Martin has been settled in favor of the Italian private equity firm Investindustrial.

headline: Parlor Coffee: Espresso and a Cut
text: Parlor Coffee might be New York City’s smallest espresso bar. It opened recently in the back of the Persons of Interest barbershop in Williamsburg. Dillon Edwards, the barista, operates his one-group Speedster espresso machine in a tiny back room that he shares with a display of hair tonics and creams. Mr. Edwards worked for Stumptown Coffee Roasters and Blue Bottle Coffee before setting up shop, and he pulls shots of espresso with beans he roasts himself and sources from the noted importer Coffee Shrub.

headline: Facebook Likely to End Experiment With Democracy
text: A half-million Facebook users have told the social network they do not want the company to change its privacy policy. Sounds impressive, right? Well, the only way that crowd will get its way and the status quo remain intact is if an additional 300 million people vote thumbs down before Monday. Odds of that happening? About zero.

headline: Layoffs at the Oscar Factory
text: The Associated Press reports today that R.S. Owens & Company, which has manufactured the statuettes for the Oscars (and the Emmys) for three decades, will lay off 95 employees on Dec. 17, when the Chicago company is bought by St. Regis Crystal of Canada. According to the A.P., R.S. Owens employs 250 workers, and the president, Scott Siegel, said they could apply to be rehired, although he wasn’t sure how many would be accepted.

headline: Hot Ford No Longer Flies Under the Radar
text: TESTED 2013 Ford Taurus SHO

headline: 4 Cylinders in a Big Car: Sometimes Less Is More
text: Bethlehem, N.H.

headline: Big Car, Smaller Engine
text: With the 2013 Taurus, Ford hopes to provide full-size accommodations with something closer to pint-size fuel economy.

headline: A Pilot's Round Trip Back to Movies
text: IF you’ve ever wondered what airline pilots do while cruising at 37,000 feet, ask Travis Fine. After Sept. 11 Mr. Fine, mulling his existence, traded an acting résumé with roles in ABC’s “Young Riders” and James Mangold’s film “Girl, Interrupted” for that of a commercial pilot.

headline: Crown Roast of Pork
text: You need an excuse to make a crown roast of pork, because it’s expensive. But it is impressive. So what’s a better excuse than the holidays?

headline: The Week in New York Region Pictures, Dec. 7
text: Subjects include a support group for transgender Latinas; residents coming back to Kissam Avenue on Staten Island; and the return of a storm-battered newspaper.

headline: To Impress the Guest, a Beast of a Roast
text: IT’S that roast beast feast time of year, when it’s almost de rigueur to make a very large piece of meat the focal point of your meal (vegetarians excepted).

headline: The Week in Culture Pictures, Dec. 7
text: Events included performances by the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater and the Tallis Scholars.

headline: I’ll Drink to That
text: At least since the days of Carry Nation, we bartenders have sometimes been regarded as nothing more than helpmates of iniquity and accomplices to debauchery. I don’t let such judgments get to me. But I’m also aware that plenty of people in the liquor service world have hearts as big as a triple whiskey on the rocks and work to help people in need of much more than a good, stiff drink.

headline: Anthony’s Pick-and-Roll Scoring Is Effective but Infrequent
text: From just about any angle, Carmelo Anthony is having a superlative season as a scorer. Particularly easy to notice is that he’s winning one-on-one battles in the post and in isolations from his favorite spots just off the elbow. He’s having a career year as a shooter, which would suggest that the Knicks are using him correctly.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Egypt and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Egypt, Gaza, Syria and Jordan.

headline: Bettis Is Ready for Notre Dame-Alabama, and Maybe the Hall of Fame
text: Jerome Bettis retired from the N.F.L. nearly seven years ago after the Steelers won Super Bowl XL. It was his first, and only, championship, the culmination of 13 seasons with six Pro Bowl appearances, three All-Pro selections and a spot at No. 6 on the league’s list of all-time career rushers. On Nov. 30, the Pittsburgh favorite and proud Notre Dame alum was named a semifinalist for the Pro Football Hall of Fame’s class of 2013.

headline: Comparing Recessions and Recoveries
text: For the 26th straight month, the country added jobs: 146,000 nonfarm payroll jobs in November, to be more precise.

headline: ‘Clear Errors’ About the Death Penalty
text: When the United States Supreme Court reinstated capital punishment in 1976, it said that the penalty could never be mandatory. Even if a jury finds a defendant guilty of a brutal murder, it still must weigh evidence about how to sentence him. Aggravating evidence concerns why a jury should impose a death sentence. Mitigating, or moderating, evidence concerns why it should not. That is the law of the land.

headline: The Week in Culture Pictures, Dec. 7
text: More Photographs

headline: Obama Asking Congress for $60.4 Billion to Help States Recover From Storm
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama proposed a $60.4 billion emergency spending bill on Friday to finance recovery efforts in areas pummeled by Hurricane Sandy, a sum that White House officials called a “robust” investment in the region but that was far less than what the states had requested.

headline: Lumière | France’s Trouble With Money
text: Bernard Arnault, the richest man in France and one of the richest men in the world, is a master of emotional concealment. But there he was, in a television interview in 2007, pouring his heart out about feeling unappreciated in his own country. He boasted that his company, LVMH, is a “beautiful” enterprise dedicated to producing made-in-France luxury goods and to spreading French creativity and culture throughout the world. In other countries, he said, corporate heads are highly respected; in France, they are not. “France has a problem with a market economy,” he said. “The influence of Marxism still exists.”

headline: On The Market | Second Homes in Aspen, Colo.
text: A Red Mountain traditional, a downtown condo, a landmark Victorian, a contemporary compound and an East End European.

headline: On the Market in Scottsdale, Ariz.
text: Click the slide show to view the On the Market properties. The contemporary and traditional homes, all with southwestern flair, range from $729,000 to $6.975 million.

headline: A Crown Roast for Every Appetite
text: In this week’s video and column, I share a recipe for an herbed crown roast of pork scented with fennel, garlic, lemon, and rosemary. The combination of flavors isn’t random; I borrowed it from a classic Tuscan porchetta.

headline: Good Will to All? Not if the World Ends
text: On Monday Jon Stewart memorably skewered those who overuse the phrase “the war on Christmas.” But maybe he spoke too soon, because on Saturday night on Syfy, it’s Santa Claus who gets the skewering. A much more literal one.

headline: From Rio to Doha, ‘They Just Talk, Talk, Talk, Talk, Talk’
text: The sustained deadlock in efforts to curb greenhouse gas emissions through treaty negotiations — including the closing round in Doha, Qatar — may be aggravating, but at least the situation brings to mind some great music.

headline: Hamas Leader Makes First Visit to Gaza
text: Khaled Meshal, the Hamas political chief whom the Israelis tried to assassinate in 1997, entered via Egypt.

headline: With Some Help in Holding Up His Wings, an Angelic Singer Crosses Genres
text: In the popular board game Don’t Say It! players draw cards asking them to describe a given term without using the four words most commonly associated with it. If there were such a card for Andrea Bocelli the taboo words would be tenor, superstar, blind and — to judge from the chorus of fan comments on YouTube and Amazon — angelic.

headline: Not Quite Headed for the Coffee Table
text: There are some great books on the history of punk, like Jon Savage’s “England’s Dreaming,” but now there’s a history of Punk, the loudmouthed, comic-stripped magazine that helped define the scene in New York in the mid-1970s, when everything was fun and filthy and the city was trying to avoid bankruptcy. Debbie Harry and Chris Stein, in a foreword to “The Best of Punk Magazine,” write that they assumed Punk was a really obvious, junky name, “but no, it was a periodical.”

headline: I Hope This Isn’t True
text: Ezra Klein says that the shape of a fiscal cliff deal is clear: only a 37 percent rate on top incomes, and a rise in the Medicare eligibility age.

headline: Pogue’s 12 Days of Gadgets: The Zooka Bluetooth Speaker
text: Here we are — it’s Day Two of Pogue’s 12 Days of Gadgets! One offbeat tech gift idea a day, and nothing over $100! (Here’s Day One.)

headline: Sudden Movements and Lyrical Leaps
text: When the composer and dance composition teacher Louis Horst first suggested that Anna Sokolow choreograph a dance to Alban Berg’s “Lyric Suite,” she was against the idea. Eventually, he wore her down. On Thursday evening at the Theater at the 14th Street Y, the Sokolow Theater/Dance Ensemble, led by its artistic director Jim May, performed the 1953 dance in its entirety as part of its “Sounds of Sokolow” series.

headline: When Cheap Foreign Labor Gets Less Cheap
text: Nick Wingfield and I had an article in Friday’s paper about how some American companies are “re-shoring” manufacturing they had previously sent abroad. The scale of these efforts is still more anecdotal than widespread at this point. Still, it’s worth examining why the United States might be a more attractive place to locate your plant today than in the past.

headline: And the Winner Is . . .
text: It was a close race, but as of 5 p.m. today readers said they preferred Kim Severson’s menu of edible holiday gifts over Julia Moskin’s. We asked the two perennial rivals-slash-cooking buddies (they wrote a book together) to come up with a menu of gift-worthy treats, and asked readers to pick which one they preferred. Slightly more readers chose Ms. Severson’s Southern-inspired sweet spiced pecans, cheese straws and hot fudge sauce. When they appeared on the “Today” show on Wednesday, the host, Willie Geist, picked Ms. Moskin’s menu. “All I can say is that the readers of The New York Times are among the smartest people on earth,” Ms. Severson said upon hearing the news of her victory.

headline: Friday Night Music: Lumineers
text: OK, folks, I have a problem: YouTube has changed its embed code, and the software here won’t let me post it. I’ll be talking to the IT people about this, but for now here’s the link.

headline: Mighty Old Trees Are Perishing Fast, Study Warns
text: The death rate of many of the biggest and oldest trees around the world is increasing rapidly, scientists report in a new study in Friday’s issue of the journal Science. They warned that research to understand and stem the loss of the trees is urgently needed.

headline: Hollywood Heroines: Behind the Scenes
text: We’ve been publishing Hollywood portfolios for nearly a dozen years now and supplementing them with online videos for the last five. But this is just our third time out making mini-movies. In 2010, our performers riffed on film archetypes (the femme fatale, the man on the run); in 2011, they played villains (the mad scientist, the gun moll). This year, once we realized, in consultation with the paper’s movie critic, A.O. Scott, that 2012 was a “pretty good year for female heroism,” we greenlighted the concept of an all-female cast, with a super power for each. That’s how we ended up with a snake charmer, a rainmaker, a light-bringer, superheroes and transformers (the personal kind, not the Michael Bay, mechanical kind).

headline: Pictures From the Week in Business, Dec. 7
text: After hiding in Belize, the software pioneer John McAfee was detained in Guatemala. Greece offered to buy back up to 30 billion euros of its bonds. Mattel introduced Barbie the builder. Apple said it would produce some computers in the United States.

headline: 2012 Election Ended With Deluge of Donations and Spending
text: The most expensive general election in history ended with a bang, according to new reports filed with the Federal Election Commission, with both presidential campaigns raising and spending huge amounts in the final two weeks before Election Day and “super PACs” and other outside groups dropping tens of millions of dollars worth of presidential advertising.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: GIF History, and Samsung vs. Apple
text: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. See more here.

headline: Auto Archives Land in Safe Havens
text: AUTOMAKERS have not always been the best stewards of the history and heritage of their brands. Some have begun to appreciate fully the value of these assets only in recent decades, it seems.

headline: A Time to Turn Pages Instead of Corners
text: A GOOD read may be just the ticket for this holiday season, whether for yourself or as a gift. Some of these half-dozen recently published titles provide a good look as well, with profuse photographs. The subjects are wide-ranging: a look inside the garages of well-known rockers, Juan Manuel Fangio’s winning years with Mercedes-Benz, a celebration of the Corvette’s 60 years, a woman’s account of how the racetrack changed her life, true-or-false tests of some persistent automotive mysteries and new details about Porsche’s beginnings. Excerpts from the books are available at nytimes.com/autos.

headline: Mess With Her, or Not: You’ll Get an Earful
text: NEW HAVEN — Vulnerability is perhaps not the first quality we associate with Kathleen Turner — or the second, or third or fourth. Even in her Hollywood heyday, Ms. Turner was a seductress whose huskily whispered intimacies carried the suggestion that a shiv might be drawn should romance go wrong.

headline: Why Apple Got a ‘Made in U.S.A.’ Bug
text: Apple’s decision to make some of its computers in the United States may be a positive for American jobs. It is certainly a marker of where much of the global computer industry has gone.

headline: Alexander Wang at Balenciaga
text: Some see Mr. Wang’s appointment as symbolic of the triumph of youth; others see the demise of fashion.

headline: An American in Paris, Again
text: ALEXANDER WANG may be the savviest designer of his generation.

headline: With Game Awards Ceremony, Xbox Users to Direct the Show
text: It’s tough to find a television show, at least of the contest or reality show variety, that is content to let viewers just watch the thing the old-fashioned way. “American Idol,” “The Voice” and “Project Runway” are always begging their viewers to vote on contestants or wheedling them into tweeting about the shows with ready-made hashtags.

headline: After the Storm, New Questions Arise
text: To the Editor:

headline: Elections in New York: Time to Consider Reforms
Obama and Congress
text: To the Editor:

headline: Fannie and Freddie’s Fate
text: To the Editor:

headline: Wearing His Heart on His Handkerchief
text: It’s a rare artist who can make you feel as though you’d never paid attention to one of the world’s best-known songs. The song is “I Heard It Through the Grapevine”; the artist is the choreographer Doug Elkins. Kyle Marshall dances to it toward the end of Mr. Elkins’s “Mo(or)town/Redux,” which received its New York premiere at the Baryshnikov Arts Center on Wednesday.

headline: Spy Chief’s Attacker Hid Bomb in Groin, Afghanistan Says
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — The man who tried to kill Afghanistan’s intelligence chief this week by smuggling a bomb into a guesthouse in Kabul concealed the device “around his groin,” according to a statement released Friday by the government. The statement suggested that could have been one reason the bomb might not have been detected during a search.

headline: Bad News for Campaign Finance
text: Friday overflowed with news about the inexorable influence of money in politics, none of it good. Every aspect of the post-election financial reports showed how this year’s campaigns took an irreversible turn for the worse.

headline: Extreme Obstacle Course Races Forge a Bond in Mud and Guts
text: Though the muddy details vary, each challenge consists of a 3- to 12-mile course spiked with cheekily named obstacles like Arctic Enema.

headline: Forging a Bond in Mud and Guts
text: BY Monday morning, Michael Cugini would be back at his desk at a major Wall Street firm, another high-powered cog in the engine of finance. There would be men on his left, men on his right, all yelling into their phones and scanning the stock ticker.

headline: Benefit’s Producers Condemn Scalpers
text: After days of complaints from music fans, the producers behind the 12-12-12 benefit concert for Hurricane Sandy victims denounced scalpers on Friday for reselling tickets to the event on StubHub and other Web sites for many times their face value.

headline: The Week in Pictures for Dec. 7
text: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include a support group for transgender Latinas; residents coming back to Kissam Avenue on Staten Island; and the return of a storm-battered newspaper.

headline: The True Meaning of Hanukkah
text: Washington

headline: Ebony Looks to Its Past as It Moves Forward
text: CHICAGO

headline: San Francisco Fall Nationals
text: One of the arts of bridge is judging your opponents, not just in the bidding but also in the play. Can you trust their signals? Can you decide whether a signal is attitude, count, suit-preference or an attempt to mislead?

headline: His Guiding Light? Mom, of Course
Letter to Congress on Hurricane Sandy Funding
text: The deputy director at the Office of Management and Budget sent a letter to Speaker John Boehner and Senate majority leader Harry Reid with recommendations to Congress on how Hurricane Sandy recovery funds should be used.

headline: ‘Rockin’ Garages’
text: It’s been said that the exhaust sound emanating from a Ferrari V-12 racing engine driven at high rpms sounds like a tearing piece of canvas — a near ear-piercing, high-pitched shriek.

headline: ‘Fangio & Mercedes-Benz: Alliance of the Best’
text: Fangio was indisputably the leading racing personality of his time.  When Mercedes-Benz provided him with a brilliant and virtually indestructible vehicle for their spectacular postwar comeback, it proved an almost unbeatable combination.  But it also saw the coming together of two very different characters, and every now and then a little ripple would appear on the otherwise smooth surface of this partnership.

headline: ‘Porsche — Origin of the Species’
text: Through 1943 and the early months of 1944 Allied bombers roamed more and more freely above Germany’s industrial centers. The spring of 1943 marked sharp intensification of the bombing. The eleventh attack on Stuttgart came on September 6, 1943, when the U.S. Army Air Force made its first daytime bombing run over the industrial center, location of the Daimler-Benz aircraft-engine factory. Nevertheless the home base of the Porsche team remained at Stuttgart-Zuffenhausen — even though many other firms with important wartime missions had already been dispersed, either underground or to strategically less important regions.

headline: ‘History’s Greatest Automotive Mysteries, Myths and Rumors Revealed’
text: The more automobile design has changed, the more it has remained the same. A century after the Model T Ford debuted, the vast majority of the cars on the road still feature steel bodies, chassis suspended on four wheels and four-stroke internal combustion engines. Not that would-be revolutionaries haven’t tried to “improve” the automobile with a host of innovations: Bodies made of carbon-fiber. Bodies fitted with wings. Bodies that float on water. Three-wheelers. Six-wheelers. Steam engines. Jet turbines. For a while, there was even talk of nuclear power.

headline: ‘Fast Girl’
text: Enter the racetrack. It’s not exactly yoga, my friends, and it’s not a day at the spa. It’s very, very loud. It’s stinky. The gear is uncomfortable. The helmet is heavy and restrictive and looks stupid. The seat belts are uncomfortably tight. The gloves are hot. If I’m not sweating like a pig while marinating on the hot tarmac then I’m freezing my [expletive] off. And above all else, screaming down a straight at 135 miles per hour is not relaxing. Adrenaline is having a house party in my nervous system. My heart is thudding. My brain is calculating wildly as my sensory input approaches maximum overload. My palms are sweating. Every nerve in my body is thrumming with the effort of keeping up, and the lizard part of my brain is just repeating and repeating: You’re gonna die, you’re gonna die, you’re gonna die. And yet I find this mental activity to be so therapeutic, so beneficial, so seductively desirable that I go back again and again for the brain fix. Why?

headline: ‘Corvette Sixty Years’
text: Born in 1910 to Russian-Jewish parents, Zachary (Zora) Arkuss grew up in St. Petersburg, where he witnessed the February 1917 Bolshevik revolution. Eventually his parents divorced and Zora’s mother Rachel remarried a man named Josef Duntov. In the early 1920s, they relocated to Germany. Enthralled with cars, racing, and high performance, he became a friend of Alfred Neubauer, head of Mercedes- Benz racing.

headline: For Baby No. 2 or 3, No Shower but a Sprinkle
text: WHEN Tori Males was pregnant with her first child more than three years ago, friends and family helped her celebrate the impending arrival with three elaborate baby showers. So when Ms. Males, a 31-year-old loan administrator from Woodstock, Ill., was due again earlier this year, she didn’t want or expect another fete.

headline: A Big Business in Getting High
text: THE artwork for Rihanna’s hit single “Diamonds” features a black-and-white image of the singer’s manicured hands rolling a joint made of diamonds. For the song’s music video, she takes a bedazzled puff.

headline: Prank Call Seeking Royal Family Secrets Takes Horrifying Turn
text: LONDON — As pranks go, this one appeared outrageous and obnoxious rather than malicious: after convincing a hospital nurse who answered the phone this week that they were Queen Elizabeth and Prince Charles, two Australian radio hosts then tricked another nurse into disclosing medical information about the pregnant Duchess of Cambridge, who had been admitted with acute morning sickness.

headline: An Art World Gathering, Divided by Money
text: MIAMI — Mera Rubell was taking time out from greeting the hundreds of visitors at her family’s sprawling contemporary art center here to vent.

headline: College Boosters
text: To the Editor:

headline: Rice in Limbo as Nomination Remains Uncertain
text: WASHINGTON — It did not take long for Susan E. Rice and her champions at the White House to realize that the Republican furor over the Benghazi attack was not going away after the presidential campaign ended.

headline: Justices to Take Up Generic Drug Case
text: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court said on Friday that it would decide whether a pharmaceutical company should be allowed to pay a competitor millions of dollars to keep a generic copy of a best-selling drug off the market.

headline: ‘Joe’s Junk Yard’
text: When I was growing up in Southeastern Pennsylvania, my father ran an automotive junkyard, and my mother ran a series of small antique shops. I was surrounded by junk. My mom routinely dragged us out of bed at sunrise to go to the flea markets and yard sales, in search of treasure – a painting by a famous artist, a valuable piece of pottery, or an important document or cash stowed in the backing of a frame. My dad helped run the family business, and started a motorcycle department to tap into his other interest besides cars: Harley Davidsons. He built one of his bikes from the ground up, using parts he acquired in the business. I was shaped by the idea that one man’s trash is another man’s treasure.

headline: Automotive Diversions of the Non-Driving Kind
text: This weekend’s Automobiles section offers six brief reviews of recent books that readers may want to consider as holiday gifts or as additions to their own bookshelves. Covering a broad range of interests – pop culture, famous racers and marque histories are among the selections – they are evidence of a healthy ecosystem in the realm of automotive literature.

headline: A Lifetime of Work Destroyed at Westbeth
text: Al Cooke, 81, had a few hours on Friday to save what remained of his life’s work. A metal sculptor, he slowly carried heavy sheets of aluminum up to his studio’s loft. Walking back down the stairs, however, the pain shooting through his knees made him hesitate with every step.

headline: Storm Sirens’ Last Wail
text: TILLAMOOK, Ore. — The tsunami sirens of Tillamook County, posted along the rocky beachfront on this stretch of the earthquake-prone Pacific coast, are a reassuring presence to many residents and visitors. The 30-odd pole-mounted speakers, simple and dated in their 1960s technology of transistors and circuit boards, carry an echo of cold war civil defense, suggesting that people have a kind of handle on responding to the earth’s potential violence from a killer wave.

headline: Pacquiao, Like All Boxers, Is in Fight Against Time
text: LAS VEGAS — When Manny Pacquiao climbs inside the ring Saturday to face his longtime nemesis Juan Manuel Marquez for the fourth time, his every movement will be scrutinized, analyzed, picked apart for signs of decline. His legs. His reflexes. His willingness to attack.

headline: Whipping Up Confections, With Expert Help
text: LAWRENCEVILLE, N.J. — Jonell Copeland, one of the 16 students in a holiday cookie class at the Sur La Table store here last Sunday, had carefully considered reasons for spending two hours learning to make gingerbread and sugar cookies, lemon-thyme wreaths and other treats.

headline: Pornography Curbs Ordered
text: The Air Force has ordered inspections of its facilities for public displays of pornographic or misogynistic materials after complaints from female personnel. The order from the Air Force chief of staff, Gen. Mark Welsh, follows a report in The New York Times about the case of a technical sergeant, Jennifer Smith, who has served in the Air Force for 17 years. She filed a complaint with the service saying that she had been the victim of sexual assault and harassment, and that she had also been forced to endure a hostile work environment because of widespread and open displays of graphic materials that were demeaning toward women.

headline: All That Sparkles
text: When Louisa and Alex Hargrave pioneered the Hargrave Vineyard (now Castello di Borghese) in Cutchogue in 1973, they made only still wines. First-rate sparkling wines from East End producers lay years in the future.

headline: The Best Gift Ideas for the Best-Dressed Global Traveler
text: Times are harder than they used to be for pretty much everybody. But that doesn’t change the professional imperative to look good or the personal desire to travel well. Indeed, in tougher economic times standing taller than the rest can be even more crucial at the office. And that means looking good, as the I.H.T. explains in our fashion special report:

headline: Rebel Groups in Syria Make Framework for Military
text: ANTALYA, Turkey — Military commanders of the main Free Syrian Army units from all over Syria agreed Friday to a unified command structure, bowing to intense pressure from Qatar and Saudi Arabia, who the fighters said promised more advanced weapons once a central military council was in place.

headline: A Killer Ends Half-Told Tale of His Crimes With Suicide
text: ANCHORAGE — In a conversation with homicide investigators before his suicide in jail this week, Israel Keyes said he had lived much of his life thinking that people only pretended to be nice. But then, Mr. Keyes told one of the interrogators, he realized that perhaps it was only him.

headline: Safety Agency Proposing Mandatory Event Data Recorders
text: The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration said on Friday that it was proposing a new standard that would require light passenger vehicles built on or after Sept. 1, 2014, to have event data recorders, or E.D.R.’s, an earthbound and much less complex version of the “black boxes” long seen in airplanes. The rule will not apply to vehicles weighing more than 8,500 pounds.

headline: Corporate Money Allowed for Inaugural Donations
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama will accept unlimited donations from corporations — but no money from lobbyists or political action committees — to finance his 2013 inaugural festivities, a spokeswoman for his inaugural committee said Friday.

headline: Aiming Beyond the Diner Décor
text: It is safe to say no one is coming to Fancy Lee Asian Bistro ’n’ Sushi for the décor. The restaurant, which opened early last year in Babylon, resembles neither a sedate traditional-style Japanese restaurant nor an ornate Pan-Asian palace. Instead, it looks like the diner that the building once was.

headline: Japanese Quake Stirs On-Air Alarm, but No Damage to Nuclear Plants Is Reported
text: TOKYO — It was perhaps the surest sign that Japan remains unnerved by last year’s devastating earthquake and tsunami. After a large quake on Friday hit near the same area stricken last year, broadcasters on the public television network NHK threw aside their usual reserve to repeatedly issue worried warnings about tsunamis, with one host frantically urging people to “flee now to save your life!”

headline: Jobs Report Becomes Fodder in Fiscal Debate
text: WASHINGTON — Democrats and Republicans seized on November’s job numbers on Friday to press for a compromise on a deficit deal, as Speaker John A. Boehner opened the door slightly to tax rate increases as part of a broad fiscal package.

headline: Tacos Every Which Way, and Beer From the Can
text: The newest of three tequilacentric restaurants, offshoots of the popular Barcelona tapas bars based in Fairfield County, Bartaco occupies a prime slot in West Hartford Center. The place has a brash and sunny feel, with high ceilings, whitewashed barn-wood walls, gleaming oak booths and a central three-sided bar where silver citrus juicers stand sentinel at every corner. The walls display colossal photos of tropical beaches, bikini-clad goddesses and bearded outdoorsmen conquering Alpine peaks.

headline: Hoping to Wake Up Against Saints, Giants Revisit a Nightmare
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — The Giants’ season-long quest to return to the defensive heights that carried them to last season’s Super Bowl triumph may revolve around motivation drawn from watching one of the worst performances in their 88-year history.

headline: An Enemy of Brussels, and Not Afraid to Say So
text: STRASBOURG, France

headline: Bill Cunningham | Men First
text: On the Street: The male fashion peacock is out of the cage.

headline: A Pizza for Dessert? Naturally. With S’mores.
text: IT has been years since going to a restaurant in a hotel typically meant suffering through mediocre fare designed mainly for the convenience of those staying there. Still, I cringed a little upon entering the Hilton Westchester in Rye Brook to go to its new restaurant, Härth, despite an attractive renovation that has opened up the space and made it more inviting. I smelled the chlorine of the indoor pool, saw the hotel’s generic welcome desk and thought, this isn’t promising.

headline: Holiday Boxes on Stoops Bring Reports of Thefts
text: A pair of brown leather boots was snatched last week from a doorstep in the suburbs of Chicago. A computer disappeared from a front porch in Fort Worth last month, and an iPad case was stolen outside a Long Island home this week.

headline: Strapped District Plans to Add Online Classes
text: MANCHESTER, N.H. — Budget cuts have eliminated about 95 full-time teachers from the school district here over the past year, swelling class sizes and prompting parents to cry foul.

headline: Harlem to Say Goodbye to an Art Deco Haven of Jazz
text: The Lenox Lounge, where Billie Holiday had a table, Dizzy Gillespie played his trumpet, and James Baldwin soaked up the scene, where the burgundy leather couches, Art Deco light fixtures and zebra-print wallpaper stir up memories of other eras, and where, even now, everybody knows everybody, will close on Dec. 31.

headline: A True Story of Hate and Redemption
text: I buy the idea of “Driving Miss Daisy”: A grouchy Southern Jewish white widow and her soft-spoken black chauffeur defy tradition and become close friends as the civil rights movement changes the world around them. But a Ku Klux Klan leader and an African-American woman who become pals? In the 1970s?

headline: Twenty and Counting
text: You may have heard that there are going to be 20 women in the Senate next year. I’ve been trying to figure out what that means.

headline: Canada Clears $15 Billion Chinese Takeover of an Energy Company
text: MONTREAL — Canada on Friday allowed a Chinese state-run oil giant to move forward with $15 billion takeover of a domestic energy company, but the government indicated that such deals might not pass muster in the future.

headline: Cheaper Money
text: America’s money is too expensive. That’s essentially what the Government Accountability Office stressed last week to a House subcommittee examining possible changes in America’s currency. Paper dollar bills wear out after four or five years, and replacing them with a sturdier coin could save $4.4 billion over the next 30 years. Pennies were not mentioned, but they, too, should get some reconsideration, on cost grounds alone: a single penny costs the government two pennies to make.

headline: Some Thieves at City’s Jails Lurk Outside
text: From a thief’s point of view, the place had a lot of potential.

headline: Bid to Write New Rules for Funds Gains Ally
text: A type of mutual fund could lose its trademark stable value of $1 a share after a crucial government official voiced his support for controversial efforts to overhaul the $2.6 trillion money market fund industry.

headline: Mavericks Succeeding Without Their Coach
text: MANKATO, Minn. — Football practice ended early, in the twilight, at Minnesota State University on Wednesday. As has been the case since mid-August, the Mavericks crossed Stadium Road to their locker room, cleats clacking on the asphalt. As they have all season, they made the walk without their coach.

headline: In WikiLeaks Case, Defense Puts the Jailers on Trial
text: FORT MEADE, Md. — In a half-empty courtroom here, with a crew of fervent supporters in attendance, Pfc. Bradley Manning and his lawyer have spent the last two weeks turning the tables on the government.

headline: It’s Hard to Be a Hero
text: On a crisp January day in 2007, a 50-year-old construction worker named Wesley Autrey became a New York hero when he rescued a man who had fallen onto the subway tracks.

headline: Certified Safe, a Factory in Karachi Still Quickly Burned
text: KARACHI, Pakistan — The century-old Central Jail here, a gritty repository of criminals, jihadists and sectarian killers, has a reputation for overcrowding and prisoner riots. But for Arshad and Shahid Bhaila, the industrialist brothers whose factory burned to the ground in September, killing at least 262 workers, there are some comforts.

headline: Scrooge. The Grinch. Congress.
text: Hurricane Sandy didn’t suppress job growth in November by as much as economists had expected. But the jobs report, released on Friday, offers plenty of bad signs, and no reason to believe the picture will improve unless Congress starts dealing with high unemployment and the needs of those already out of work for months.

headline: Beyond the Fiscal Cliff
text: As Congress waits for negotiators to resolve the budget standoff, there is other worthy business that could be accomplished, particularly in political ethics.

headline: After Stroke, Living in a Home Filled With Bickering, and Love
text: A conversation between two roommates, Marianela Toro and Ana Ventura, on a recent afternoon consisted of disparaging comments soaked in sarcasm and exasperated sighs that were soon chased with laughter. There was even a weapon brandished: Ms. Ventura, 43, threatened Ms. Toro, 46, with a pillow.

headline: Next Civil Rights Landmark
text: Fifty-eight years after it banned discrimination in public education, the Supreme Court has set the stage for the defining civil rights decision of this era — agreeing to hear two cases challenging laws that define marriage to exclude couples of the same sex. To us, and a growing number of Americans, the right course seems clear: that the justices continue the march toward real equality.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Ytterbium’s Atomic Number
text: SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — SEVENTY. The answer is SEVENTY.

headline: Dinosaurs and Denial
text: Finally, Senator Marco Rubio of Florida — a Tea Party darling and possible 2016 presidential candidate — admits that dinosaurs and humans didn’t co-exist.

headline: Bill on Russia Trade Ties Sets Off New Acrimony
text: WASHINGTON — In theory, the action by Congress this week to make Russia a full trading partner — finally doing away with a 38-year ban that once punished the Soviet Union over its restrictive emigration rules — could have begun a new era of happier ties between former cold war rivals.

headline: Jon Kest, Advocate for Low-Wage Workers in New York, Dies at 57
text: Jon Kest, a founder of the Working Families Party and a longtime community advocate in New York, who organized the recent strike by the city’s fast-food workers, among many other initiatives, died on Wednesday at his home in Brooklyn. He was 57.

headline: Jets’ Focus Returns to Ground Game
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — All of the attention paid to Mark Sanchez this week overlooks a simple point: the quarterback is not supposed to be the focal point of the Jets’ offense.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, Dec. 8, 2012
text: If we see any rockets and missiles, it will probably be the ones fired at us.

headline: Subverting the Standard Survey
text: An impressive selection of 79 artworks dating from the 1700s to the present makes up “Artists in America: Highlights of the Collection From the New Britain Museum of American Art” at the Nassau County Museum of Art in Roslyn Harbor. But while the museum’s Web site says the exhibition “surveys 300 years of great American painting,” the show isn’t arranged as a historical survey at all. Instead, it reflects recent curatorial trends, which lean toward mash-up or collage aesthetics, with paintings hung in pairs or groupings that consciously disrupt the flow of linear history.

headline: Marty Reisman, 82, a Wizard of Table Tennis, Dies
text: Marty Reisman, a wizard at table tennis, the sport in which he captured national championships, won and lost fortunes on wagers and moved crowds to laughter — sometimes using a frying pan as a paddle — as an opening act for the Harlem Globetrotters, died Friday in Manhattan. He was 82.

headline: Point Guards Past and Present Send Nets to Third Straight Loss
text: As the Warriors’ bus pulled up to Barclays Center on Friday, Coach Mark Jackson imagined for a moment what effect the glittery new arena and the rebranded Nets franchise would have on young point guards in New York.

headline: Small-Scale Works That Surprise at Every Turn
text: Steel that bends like a palm frond. Porcelain that mimics paper. And paper that flows like a river. The famed British sculptor Anthony Caro, still at work at 88, is a kind of alchemist, transmuting a range of materials and playing with our perceptions. These tricks of his can be contemplated at intimate range in the strong, lively small-scale works — most from private collections — that make up “Caro: Close Up,” at the Yale Center for British Art.

headline: Russia: Prosecutors Investigate After Exhibition Draws Complaints
text: Prosecutors in St. Petersburg are investigating an exhibition at the State Hermitage Museum by the British artists Jake and Dinos Chapman for possible violations of a law on inciting religious hatred. The exhibition, which opened in October, is called “The End of Fun” and addresses themes of violence and fascism in a series of installations resembling a chamber of horrors. A statement posted Friday on the Web site of the St. Petersburg prosecutor’s office said that “numerous citizens” had complained that the exhibition “offends the feelings of Orthodox believers and contains actions directed at degrading the dignity of citizens who profess Christianity.” The installations include a figure of the McDonald’s clown mascot, Ronald McDonald. crucified on a cross. Mikhail Piotrovsky, the Hermitage’s director, said the investigation of the exhibition was a sign of “the cultural degradation of our society,” according to the Interfax news agency. Members of the band Pussy Riot were tried and convicted in a similar case this year.

headline: In This Show, the Abstract Is Here and Now
text: RYE, N.Y. — Abstraction is often defined as what it is not: it is not representational, not objective, not figurative, not realistic, not narrative. “From Where I Stand: 12 Contemporary Abstract Artists,” an exhibition of 40 paintings and prints at the Rye Arts Center, aims to enlighten gallerygoers about what abstract art is and to present an assortment of methods and aesthetics at play in the genre.

headline: Congo: Peace Talks Delayed
text: Peace talks between rebels and the government of the Democratic Republic of Congo in Uganda were delayed Friday as negotiators failed to arrive on schedule, Congolese and rebel officials said.

headline: Quinn Backs Expansion of Campaign Spending
text: Christine C. Quinn, the City Council speaker and an expected candidate for mayor next year, is supporting a change to New York City’s campaign finance rules that would significantly expand the ability of unions, corporations and advocacy groups to spend money on behalf of local candidates.

headline: Hot Chocolate Under Stuffed Moose
text: The big stuffed moose peers down in amusement at the midweek crowd gathered on the Hudson Hotel’s terrace, newly tented in for the winter. Other assorted taxidermy, twinkling lights, sleds, skis, wooden tables and couches draped in fur throw rugs create the full-on incongruity of an urban ski lodge on West 58th Street. In lieu of expensive lift tickets, customers at the Hudson Lodge open their wallets for spiked and steaming drinks and gooey foodstuffs like fondue, cookies and s’more grilled cheese sandwiches. Manufactured snow shoots into the air nightly after 8, drawing tequila-induced squeals and melting into soap suds on the pates of prematurely balding men in suits. As D.J. tunes bounce in the 1,500-square-foot tent, spillovers from holiday parties mingle with couples on second dates cozying on benches, enjoying the marshmallow ambience after a hard day on the office slopes.

headline: Convictions in ’95 Killing of Cabdriver to Be Vacated
text: The Bronx district attorney said Friday that the murder convictions of five people found guilty in the 1995 shooting of a livery-cab driver must be thrown out.

headline: Women on the Margins
text: Q. There used to be a group of institutions for pregnant girls called Florence Crittenton Homes. Who was Florence Crittenton?

headline: Corrections: December 8, 2012
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: In the Ashes in Karachi, Evidence of Oversight Failures
text: A fire at a factory that was certified as safe killed at least 262 workers, highlighting monitoring flaws.

headline: Daring to Take the Long Way Home
text: The point of a mapping app is to move you efficiently from one place to another. But Wanderous, a free iPhone app released this fall, turns that idea on its head. A user enters start and end points, and the app comes up with a meandering path to travel between them. Exploring the city has always been a popular subject for New York-based  apps,  and Wanderous is one of several that aim to make strolling around the city feel like a game.

headline: Uganda: Oil Industry Regulations Passed
text: Lawmakers passed legislation on Friday intended to regulate Uganda’s nascent oil industry, but critics say it gives too much authority over the industry to the nation’s energy minister.

headline: Knicks Are Bombarding Their Opponents With 3-Pointers
text: CHICAGO — Shooting 3-pointers successfully in the N.B.A. is a skill that needs to be practiced over and over again. During training camp and after practice, many members of the Knicks did not lift weights or head to the treadmill. Instead, they looked for a ball and the 3-point line.

headline: Dance Is Never Far From His Mind
text: Last year, Robert Battle became the third person to head the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater since the company was founded in 1958. During the troupe’s season in New York, which runs through Dec. 30 at City Center, Mr. Battle attends both the matinee and evening performances. At other times, the day is more relaxing (though he also can’t seem to stay away from Ailey’s Midtown studios). Mr. Battle, 40, has for the past 14 years shared his Upper West Side apartment with Nina Miller, a voice teacher, who he says has become “like family.”

headline: The Maestro of Flushing
text: “You’re eating up my energy,” roared Maurice Peress, 82, as he rushed around his Manhattan apartment on Wednesday evening. He was preparing for a rehearsal but kept getting sidetracked by questions about his 60 years as an orchestra conductor, the last 30 at the Queens College Aaron Copland School of Music.

headline: A Neighborhood Through Time
text: For many decades, Danny Stein has photographed the dwindling Orthodox Jewish community on the Lower East Side, from its people and celebrations to its rapidly gentrifying streets.

headline: Eyes of the Soccer World Turn to Manchester
text: With just one swish of his right foot, Sergio Aguero changed the landscape of English soccer forever. His stoppage-time goal against Queens Park Rangers on the final day of the Premier League season in May clinched Manchester City’s first league title in 44 years and confirmed Manchester United was no longer the only soccer superpower in the northwest of England.

headline: Are the Knicks This Good?
text: The Knicks stand atop the Eastern Conference with a 14-4 record and have already demolished the Miami Heat on two occasions, including a 112-92 rout Thursday night in which Carmelo Anthony, the Knicks’ best player, did not suit up. The Knicks were expected to be a competitive team this season, but no one can really say he saw this kind of basketball coming.

headline: No Fehr? No Deal, Say the N.H.L. Players
text: The lockout is in its 84th day, and there will be no resolution, according to the players, without the union head Donald Fehr being part of the negotiations.

headline: East Village Shrine to Riots and Radicals
text: FOUR days before the opening of the Museum of Reclaimed Urban Space on Avenue C, near 10th Street, Bill DiPaola told the volunteer staff about the suggestion box. Though the group was supposed to make all decisions collectively, on this he acted alone.

headline: What’s On Saturday
text: 8 P.M. (Showtime) WAR HORSE (2011) Steven Spielberg’s sweeping adaptation of the popular stage spectacle follows Joey, a fleet-footed headstrong half-thoroughbred who has formed an unbreakable bond with a strapping lad, Albert (Jeremy Irvine, above), on his parents’ tenant farm in England. Across the English Channel, on the battlefields and in the trenches of Flanders and France, Joey and Albert endure parallel experiences, including harrowing escapes, the loss of friends, terror and deprivation. Peter Mullan and Emily Watson play Albert’s parents, and David Thewlis is their landlord in this story written by Lee Hall and Richard Curtis, based on the novel by Michael Morpurgo. “Like most movies with an antiwar message, ‘War Horse’ cannot help but be enthralled by the epic scale and transformative power of military conflict,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. “  ‘The war has taken everything from everyone’ — the truth of this reckoning, uttered more than once by characters on screen, is self-evident, but it is complicated by the visceral charge and cathartic relief that an effective war movie gives to its audience.” Still, “The extreme violence of the slaughter in World War I is implied rather than graphically depicted,” he added. “Mr. Spielberg steps back from the bloody, chaotic naturalism of ‘Saving Private Ryan’ — this is an animal fable for children, after all, with echoes of ‘E. T.’ and Carroll Ballard’s ‘Black Stallion’ — but his ability to infuse action sequences with emotional gravity has hardly diminished.”

headline: Shooting Lessons
text: Few people criticize the quality of the training that New York City’s recruits and police officers receive, but some say the officers need more gun training in real-life scenarios.

headline: Ready, Aim, Ready?
text: Armed with cap guns and the usual apprehension, two recruits from the New York Police Academy knocked on the door of a set in the Bronx meant to resemble a down-at-the-heels apartment. They had just received a radio assignment from an instructor: 911 had taken a complaint about an “E.D.P.” — an emotionally disturbed person — in their sector. They were told to report to the location and advise.

headline: The Great Divide, Now in the Toy Aisle
text: Earlier this year, at the 109th Annual American International Toy Fair, held at the Javits Convention Center as one of the culture’s most convincing cases for childlessness, a former investment banker named Jill Todd displayed “The Tuneables,” an interactive DVD series she had created through her company, the Music Intelligence Project. The daughter of two musicologists, Ms. Todd developed the project in conjunction with her parents as an instructional system in melody, rhythm and tone — the fundamentals of music leveraged as a means to enhance cognitive function. Nearby, but easily obscured by the acres of primary-color plastic, was a booth for a company called Fat Brain Toys, whose games and puzzles in logic and sequencing came with an impressive lineage, some of them designed by the celebrated inventor Ivan Moscovich, a Holocaust survivor.

text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

text: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

headline: IHT Quick Read: Dec. 8
text: NEWS Germany’s economy is slowing and will probably stagnate in 2013, the country’s central bank said Friday, sharply cutting its forecast for growth. Considering “the difficult economic situation in some euro area countries and widespread uncertainty, economic growth will be lower than previously assumed,” said the Bundesbank, which now expects G.D.P. to expand by just 0.4 percent next year. David Jolly reports.

headline: A Case for Forgiving Tiki Barber
text: Greg Hanlon of CapitalNewYork.com knows it’s a hard sell.

headline: The Weekend Word: Marriage
text: Today’s Times

headline: Newswallah: Bharat Edition
text: Jammu and Kashmir: In the legislative council elections held this week for four seats under the quota for panchayats, or village councils — the first such polls in 38 years — the governing coalition of National Conference and Indian National Congress won, Kashmir Live reported. The voters comprised 33,540 elected village council members and heads from the Jammu region and Kashmir Valley, according to an IANS report on the IBNLive Web site.

headline: Backing Off Added Powers, Egypt’s Leader Presses Vote
text: CAIRO — Struggling to quell violent protests that have threatened to derail a referendum on an Islamist-backed draft constitution, President Mohamed Morsi of Egypt moved Saturday to appease his opponents with a package of concessions hours after state news media reported that he was moving toward imposing a form of martial law to secure the streets and allow the vote.

headline: Rise of the Robots
text: Catherine Rampell and Nick Wingfield write about the growing evidence for “reshoring” of manufacturing to the United States. They cite several reasons: rising wages in Asia; lower energy costs here; higher transportation costs. In a followup piece, however, Rampell cites another factor: robots.

headline: Romany Were European 500 Years Earlier Than Previously Thought
text: LONDON — The Romany people constitute Europe’s largest and, arguably, now its most persecuted minority.

headline: A Welcome Reality Checker Amid Appeals to Fear and Utopia
text: I thought it worth revisiting my 2009 Perimeter Institute conversation with Vaclav Smil, someone I consider a vital touchstone in a world of distorted risk assessments, after noticing some of his recent columns. Here’s my relevant Twitter note, followed by some links:

headline:
Leader Celebrates
Founding of Hamas
With Defiant Speech
text: GAZA CITY — Khaled Meshal, the political leader of Hamas, gave a defiant speech on Saturday, vowing to build an Islamic Palestinian state on all the land of Israel, the West Bank and the Gaza Strip.

headline: For Afghan Officials, Facing Prospect of Death Is in the Job Description
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — There are so many ways for an Afghan official to die: car bombs, suicide attacks, a volley of bullets or, in the case of one particularly enterprising assassin, a handgun hidden in the sole of a shoe.

headline: Helmet? Check. Shoulder Pads? Check. Cup? No Thanks.
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Protection is a perpetual buzzword in the N.F.L.

headline: Variety: Spiral
text: SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE — Spirals are a lot of fun, particularly if you subscribe to what I like to call the “Hokey Pokey” method of solving: You put an Inward answer in, you put an Outward answer in, you put another In, and then you … well, you get the idea.

headline: Climate Talks Yield Commitment to Ambitious, but Unclear, Actions
text: DOHA, Qatar — The annual United Nations climate change negotiations concluded here late Saturday after the customary all-night negotiating session and recriminations over who must bear the costs and burdens of a warming planet.

headline: Chris Corbould
text: Chris Corbould is a British special-effects expert known for his work on James Bond films, including the latest, “Skyfall.” He also oversaw the breathtaking blasts and crashes in “Inception” and the Batman films, most recently “The Dark Knight Rises.”

headline: For Corporate Donors, Inauguration Details
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama’s finance team is offering corporations and other institutions that contribute $1 million exclusive access to an array of inaugural festivities, including tickets to a “benefactors reception,” a children’s concert, a candlelight celebration at the National Building Museum, two reserved parade bleacher seats and four tickets to the president’s official inaugural ball.

headline: Sharp-Elbowed Rebounder Gives Nets an Edge
text: Consider Reggie Evans’s basketball career as a play in three acts, three intimate conversations staged against three distinct backdrops: an enormous arena in Seattle, a small gymnasium in Kansas, a county jail in Pensacola, Fla.

headline: Deck the Malls
text: A short impressionistic video captures the holiday shopping bustle at Macy’s flagship department store in New York.

headline: Haiti’s Silenced Victims
text: A TEXT MESSAGE was the first sign that something was wrong. In the week after Hurricane Sandy hit Haiti, our research team was assessing post-disaster crime, food security and service provision. The message came from a Haitian researcher in our group, an enthusiastic and talented graduate student whom we’ll call Wendy. She had been walking alone a few blocks from our hotel when she was forced into a house and brutally raped.

headline: Suffer. Spend. Repeat.
text: IN these final weeks before Christmas, it may strike you that retailers have gone out of their way to make holiday shopping as unpleasant an experience as possible. The odd truth is that they probably have. And there’s a reason for that: evidence suggests that the less comfortable you are during the seasonal shopping spree, the more money you’ll spend.

headline: The Full Israeli Experience
text: Tel Aviv

headline: A Tepid ‘Welcome Back’ for Spanish Jews

headline: An Empty Seat in the Courtroom
text: THE lawyer David Coombs rarely speaks publicly outside the courtroom. He says that his client, Bradley Manning, the Army private accused of leaking secret documents to WikiLeaks, prefers it that way.

headline: Presidential Inauguration Donor Packages
text: A list of inaugural events and giving levels for prospective donors.

headline: An Unexpected Journey: Hobbits in the Heartland
text: Thirty years and 300 leagues separate me from that wintry day and place, yet how well I remember. Wearing a blue goose-down jerkin over my doublet, and boots, I descended the stairs to a library chamber and beheld with my own eyes the grave and thrilling history of Middle-earth, in its earliest form — page after page of the words, runes and drawings of J. R. R. Tolkien, the original texts, with corrections and annotations in his own spidery hand. How long I tarried there I do not know, yet even a scant minute would have justified my long journey across barren prairies to the city of men beside the Great Lake where the precious hoard had come to rest.

headline: What Compassionate Release?
text: Federal sentencing law has been indefensibly harsh for a generation, but in theory it has contained a safety valve called compassionate release. The 1984 Sentencing Reform Act gives federal courts the power to reduce sentences of federal prisoners for “extraordinary and compelling reasons,” like a terminal illness.

headline: Karzai Implicates Pakistan in Suicide Bombing That Hurt Afghan Spy Chief
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — The suicide bomber who tried to assassinate Afghanistan’s powerful new intelligence chief came from Pakistan and the attack was organized with the help of a sophisticated foreign intelligence service, President Hamid Karzai said Saturday.

headline: After Two Contenders Rebuild, the Thunder Look Stronger
text: OKLAHOMA CITY — Entering their game Friday in Oklahoma City, it was the Los Angeles Lakers — not the still very-young Thunder — in search of a statement win. It was the Lakers — the 16-time N.B.A. champions — who were looking to weigh themselves against the Thunder, the class of the Western Conference.

headline: A Step Toward E-Mail Privacy
text: The growth of the Internet, social networking and mobile technologies has transformed how Americans communicate and exchange information, but Congress has lagged in updating federal privacy laws to safeguard digital communications from inappropriate prying. Late last month, the Senate Judiciary Committee made some serious progress in the right direction.

headline: Schoolhouse to Courthouse
text: KENNETH screwed up. The 11th grader made a crude joke about the police officers in his Bronx high school — and an officer overheard.

headline: Bin Laden, Torture and Hollywood
text: I’M betting that Dick Cheney will love the new movie “Zero Dark Thirty.”

headline: The Years of Senator DeMint
text: IN November 2008, just after John McCain was routed by Barack Obama, Jim DeMint addressed a Myrtle Beach conference on the future of the Republican Party. The first-term South Carolina senator was there to reassure his audience: Republicans might have lost an election, but conservatism hadn’t lost the country.

headline: Worry Tempers Joy Over Gay Marriage’s Moment in Court
text: LOS ANGELES — Within moments of the announcement on Friday that the Supreme Court would hear two cases relating to same-sex marriage, gay activists rejoiced, heralding the decision as a major advancement for their movement.

headline: N.H.L. Void Has Networks Scrambling
text: DETROIT — Usually at this time of year, hockey fans would plant themselves in front of their televisions and watch players like Sidney Crosby, Alexander Ovechkin and Marian Hossa command the ice.

headline: Those Crazy Indemnity Forms We All Sign
text: IN order for one of my boys to play indoor lacrosse this winter, I was asked to sign a release indemnifying the sports dome and a long list of its business associates, volunteers, advertisers and (presumably) their family pets against any possible claim filed on behalf of my son.

headline: The Joke’s on Whom?
text: I’ve pranked several thousand people, although I never favored that term. Much of my career was spent doing hidden-camera stunts on “Candid Camera,” following a path charted for decades by my father, Allen Funt. We always worried about what might go wrong, particularly involving the physical and emotional health of unsuspecting subjects. Our gags were relatively tame, and we sought to find greater social meaning in each sequence. Our track record was pretty good. Still, we had our share of critics.

headline: A Lost Civilization
text: WASHINGTON

headline: The Cracks in the Nation’s Foundation
text: Across the coasts of New York and New Jersey, hundreds of millions of gallons of raw and partially treated sewage are spilling into waterways and the ocean. The immediate cause is equipment damage from Hurricane Sandy, but as Michael Schwirtz recently reported in The Times, aging plants like one in Nassau County on Long Island were leaking long before the storm, flooding neighborhood streets with sewage during downpours.

headline: Seeking to Qualify but Also to Inspire
text: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla. — It was crunch time last Sunday in the last round of the L.P.G.A.’s final qualifying tournament, and history and milestones were not the top priority for two young golfers trying to earn playing status for the 2013 tour.

headline: Censoring Myself for Success
text: HERE is a story about fame. I heard it first as a fable in Somalia, before living it out in America.

headline: Epic Battle of Opposites: Irish vs. Tide in 1973
text: Protecting a 24-23 lead in the final minutes of the 1973 Sugar Bowl against Alabama, underdog Notre Dame faced a pivotal third-and-8 at its 3-yard line.

headline: A Bittersweet Reunion in Guatemala
text: Amy and Rob Carr of Reno, Nev., are among the 4,000 Americans who found themselves stuck in limbo when Guatemala shut down its international adoption program in 2008.

headline: A Simple Way to Create Suspense
text: How do you create suspense? I’m asked that question often, and it seems that every writers’ symposium has a class with that title. It’s an important technical issue, and not just for so-called suspense novels. Every novel needs a narrative engine, a reason for people to keep reading to the end, whatever the subject, style, genre or approach.

headline: Splash!
text: Arsenal’s Santi Cazorla drew a penalty on what certainly looked like a blatant dive Saturday against West Bromwich.

headline: A Good Mentor Never Tramples on Big Dreams
text: This interview with  Tony Tjan, chief executive of Cue Ball, a venture capital firm based in Boston, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

headline: After Radio Prank, Hospital Chairman Condemns Australian Network
text: Last Updated, 3:28 p.m. A day after a nurse at a London hospital was found dead after falling victim to a prank call seeking medical information about the pregnant Duchess of Cambridge, the hospital’s chairman issued a scathing indictment of the Australian network that broadcast the hoax.

headline: Chevron Aims at an Activist Shareholder
text: PUBLIC corporations routinely tell shareholders that their views matter. The Chevron Corporation, for example, said in its 2012 proxy statement: “Your board welcomes dialogue on the topics presented in the stockholder proposals on the following pages.” So it might seem odd that last month Chevron subpoenaed one of its investors, Trillium Asset Management, which has sponsored numerous shareholder proposals at Chevron over the years. The oil company demanded documents related to those proposals. The subpoena also asked for records of discussions Trillium had about these proposals with the media.

headline: Big Money Bets on a Housing Rebound
text: DAVID N. MILLER, a master of bailouts, steps to the dais and coolly explains how the financial world went crazy.

headline: Tebow Divided Hometown Without Even Taking a Snap
text: JACKSONVILLE, Fla. — This was the first night of the 2010 N.F.L. draft, the draft that contained the player who could deliver excitement and relevancy, if not necessarily victories, to Raef Godwin’s beloved Jacksonville Jaguars.
