text: To the Editor:

headline: Heritage, Chicago, and the Fiscal Cliff
text: Menzie Chinn has some fun pointing out that if the doctrine Heritage was pushing to oppose fiscal stimulus were true — namely, that government borrowing always crowds out an equal amount of private spending — then the fiscal cliff could not be a problem. Hey, the government is going to borrow less, which will automatically and necessarily lead to an equal rise in private borrowing, so total demand can’t be affected, right?

headline: Cuba’s Free-Market Farm Experiment Yields a Meager Crop
text: HAVANA — Cuba’s liveliest experiment with capitalism unfolds every night in a dirt lot on the edge of the capital, where Truman-era trucks lugging fresh produce meet up with hundreds of buyers on creaking bicycle carts clutching wads of cash.

headline: Cuban Agriculture Struggles Under Creaky Infrastructure
text: More Cubans are farming, but because of waste, poor management, policy constraints and other problems, many are actually seeing less food at new private markets.

headline: A Tumultuous Trip to Mobile App Transparency
text: MOBILE apps are the Trojan horses of our smartphones.

headline: Billion-Dollar Flop: Air Force Stumbles on Software Plan
text: IN policy circles, problems that are mind-bogglingly difficult or impossible to solve, like global warming, are formally termed “wicked.”

headline: No Longer Overlooked
text: Like a fallen leaf, the question lingered silently for decades near the doorstep of the Baseball Hall of Fame in Cooperstown, N.Y.

headline: Letters to the Editor
text: To the Sports Editor:

headline: In Talks, G.O.P. May Have to Just Say Yes
text: IN their book, “Getting to Yes,” Roger Fisher and William Ury introduce what may be the most important concept in the theory of negotiations: the best alternative to a negotiated agreement, or Batna. Knowing your true Batna — and your adversary’s — is critical in bargaining. A vivid example from the entertainment world illustrates the concept and offers some useful hints about how the current fiscal negotiations in Washington are likely to unfold.

headline: Tax Arithmetic Shows Top Rate Is Just a Starter
text: WASHINGTON — Despite hints in recent days that President Obama and House Speaker John A. Boehner might compromise on the tax rate to be paid by top earners, a host of other knotty tax questions could still derail a deal to avert a fiscal crisis in January.

headline: The Next Move for the Fed
text: TIME is running out for Operation Twist, the Federal Reserve stimulus program named for that hip-swiveling dance from the 1960s.

headline: 30 Seconds With Kenny Smith
text: Kenny Smith explains how to play NBA Baller Beats, a new Xbox 360 Kinect-controlled game.

headline: A Switch at Midlife, to Make a Difference
text: I CAN pinpoint the time in my career when I started to question what I was doing with my life.

headline: Hamas Leader Delivers Defiant Speech at Anniversary Celebration
text: Khaled Meshal delivered a fiery speech at a celebration for the 25th anniversary of Hamas in Gaza on Saturday.

headline: Out of Vietnam, and Back
text: MY father, Quang Lam, was a captain in the South Vietnamese Army. He was a helicopter pilot who had been trained in Texas. On April 30, 1975, when Saigon fell, he was able to escape Vietnam and reached the United States. But he was not able to let us know what had happened to him until a year later.

headline: Racetrack Drugs Put Europe Off U.S. Horse Meat
text: PARIS — For decades, American horses, many of them retired or damaged racehorses, have been shipped to Canada and Mexico, where it is legal to slaughter horses, and then processed and sold for consumption in Europe and beyond.

headline: A Fringe Politician Moves to Japan’s National Stage
text: TOKYO — Shintaro Ishihara has been a rare, flamboyant presence in Japan’s otherwise drab political world for four decades. A novelist turned right-wing firebrand, he has long held celebrity status on the political margins, where he was known for dramatic flourish. He once signed a pact in blood to oppose diplomatic ties with China because of its communist government, and he published a book at the height of Japan’s economic power that lectured his countrymen on the need to end what he considered its postwar servility to the United States.

headline: Celtics Take Long View on Draft Picks
text: When the Boston Celtics ended up with back-to-back picks in the first round of the 2012 N.B.A. draft, they had a rare opportunity to draft a player who was ready to contribute right away and one who was more of a project. They did exactly that, selecting Jared Sullinger with the 21st pick and Fab Melo with the 22nd, a pick they acquired in a trade in 2011.

headline: Variations on Obama’s Tax Plan
text: President Obama has offered a tax plan that would raise $1.4 trillion in revenue over 10 years by increasing taxes on top earners. How different variations on the plan could affect how much money is raised:

headline: Marijuana Legalization and States Rights
text: As the Obama administration weighs its response to the legalization of the recreational use of marijuana in Washington and Colorado, a new YouGov poll has found that a slim majority of adults believe the federal government should not enforce federal laws — under which marijuana use is still illegal — in those states.

headline: New Taxes to Take Effect to Fund Health Care Law
text: WASHINGTON — For more than a year, politicians have been fighting over whether to raise taxes on high-income people. They rarely mention that affluent Americans will soon be hit with new taxes adopted as part of the 2010 health care law.

headline: Matchup: Saints (5-7) at Giants (7-5)
text: 4:25 p.m. Eastern, Fox

headline: Rumblings for Change in Sudan’s Governing Party
text: KHARTOUM, Sudan — When the Sudanese government announced late last month that it had disrupted a “plot of sabotage” and had arrested 13 people, including senior members of the armed forces and the security services, it shed light on what was already an open secret: the growing discontent within its ranks.

headline: Matchup: Jets (5-7) at Jaguars (2-10)
text: 1 p.m. Eastern, CBS

headline: Russia Announces Barriers on Imports of U.S. Meat
text: MOSCOW — Russian health regulators announced formidable new barriers to the import of meat from the United States late on Friday, in a move some analysts saw as retaliation for American legislation punishing Russian officials linked to human rights violations.

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, Dec. 9
text: With all eyes on Washington as the fiscal deadline looms, the Sunday shows are focusing on the status of negotiations. Alan K. Simpson and Erskine B. Bowles, who served as co-chairmen of President Obama’s deficit reduction commission two years ago and are still promoting their proposal, will appear on CBS’s “Face the Nation” to weigh in.

headline: Last Name First
text: SUNDAY’S PUZZLE — The nice thing about the Sunday New York Times crossword puzzles is that they run with a title. According to some solvers, the not-so-nice thing about the Sunday New York Times crosswords is that they run with a title.

headline: Previewing the Fourth Quarter of the N.F.L. Season
text: Has your team clinched a playoff spot, leaving you wondering what to pay attention to with a month to go in the N.F.L. regular season? In an unusually top-heavy and familiar season — it is possible that only 2 of the 12 playoff teams will be different from last season — you have plenty of company. Three divisions have been settled and two more could be this weekend, but the playoff picture is still spectacularly scintillating. Colts-Broncos in the Peyton Bowl? Sign us up. But subplots — and no shortage of firings, benchings and questionable decisions — abound to tide us over until January. Put down the holiday catalogs and keep this guide handy.

headline: A Family, for a Few Days a Year
text: GUATEMALA CITY — The little boy flies like an airplane through the hotel, his arms outstretched. Then he leaps like a superhero, beaming as the red lights on his new sneakers flash and flicker, while the American couple he is with dissolve in laughter.

headline: Giving an Old Brewery a New Life, and Cuisine
text: Nearly 12 years ago, the Pearl Brewing Company in downtown San Antonio emptied its tanks and moved the production of its beer to Fort Worth. It left behind a historic but derelict 22-acre complex, anchored by a towering brew house. It looked like the property was destined to be razed.

headline: Contributions Blackout Serves Many Functions
text: Ladies and gentlemen, close your checkbooks. Sunday starts the blackout on campaign contributions to Texas state officeholders,   a period of pecuniary protection that will last until after the legislative session that begins in a month.

headline: Proposed Rules on Fracking Gain Cautious Praise
text: Hydraulic fracturing, or fracking, the controversial process of shooting water, sand and chemicals underground to retrieve oil or natural gas trapped in shale rock, has made plenty of headlines in recent years. But the drilling process involves many other steps beyond breaking up rock — and several opportunities for things to go wrong.

headline: Italy’s Prime Minister to Quit After Losing Party Support
text: ROME — Prime Minister Mario Monti said he intended to resign after losing the backing of former Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi’s party, according to a statement issued late Saturday by the president’s office.

headline: Syrian Rebels Tied to Al Qaeda Play Key Role in War
text: BAGHDAD — The lone Syrian rebel group with an explicit stamp of approval from Al Qaeda has become one of the uprising’s most effective fighting forces, posing a stark challenge to the United States and other countries that want to support the rebels but not Islamic extremists.

headline: Perry Helps Advisers Take a Big Next Step
text: “Career coach” is not listed on Gov. Rick Perry’s résumé, but it might as well be.

headline: Land Routes Blocked, Smuggling Rises Sharply on California Coast
text: LOS ANGELES — The small, open-hull fishing boats head north from Baja Mexico, traveling at night, their navigation lights off. It is an old smuggling route, popular with tequila runners during Prohibition in the 1920s and then little used for nearly a century.

headline: North Korea Cites Rocket Problems
text: HONG KONG — North Korea said Sunday that it might have to postpone a rocket launching it had previously said would take place as early as Monday, citing unspecified problems encountered by its technicians.

headline: ‘Famous’ Wolf Is Killed Outside Yellowstone
text: Yellowstone National Park’s best-known wolf, beloved by many tourists and valued by scientists who tracked its movements, was shot and killed on Thursday outside the park’s boundaries, Wyoming wildlife officials reported.

headline: Clinton’s Countless Choices Hinge on One: 2016
text: You’re one of the most famous women on earth, and you’re jobless for the first time in decades. You’d like to make money, but you don’t want to rule out running for president. So what do you do all day?

headline: New Art District in Miami
text: The newfound allure of Wynwood is the latest testament to how art can sprinkle its metaphysical magic and transform even the bleakest places.

headline: Breathing Life, and Art, Into a Downtrodden Neighborhood
text: MIAMI — Ski, a New York graffiti artist, swirled a can of spray paint, blasting a riot of neon in this once-forlorn slab of Miami called Wynwood. A few doors down, in a pop-up store, another artist, Asif Farooq, was selling an array of firearms — actually cardboard replicas for those who like everything about a gun except the shooting.

headline: Anthony Will Sit for a Second Straight Game
text: CHICAGO — Carmelo Anthony will miss his second consecutive game Saturday night, sitting out as the Knicks play the Chicago Bulls. Anthony, who sustained a deep cut on his left middle finger during Wednesday’s victory in Charlotte and received five stitches, had the final say to sit out.

headline: Duke Shows Krzyzewski a Quality He Values
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Year after year, Duke seems to manufacture championship-caliber basketball teams as if on an assembly line. Coach Mike Krzyzewski’s recipe for success is no secret. It starts with recruiting fundamentally sound players, preaching unselfish play and finding chemistry.

headline: Even the Best Can Bungle, and Then It Gets Exciting
text: The highest-ranked men are sometimes accused of shying away from risk in their game play. That was certainly not true last week, when there were several games filled with bold moves and mistakes. They were a lot of fun to watch.

headline: Army Batters Navy, but Bid to End Streak Slips From Its Grasp
text: PHILADELPHIA — The game was over, and the Army football team glumly walked up the sideline Saturday and turned to face seven sections filled with gray-coated members of the Corps of Cadets. Only a few players sang the United States Military Academy’s alma mater, and their classmates were not exactly in the mood to sing, either.

headline: From Street Hustler to Family Man Eager to Cook
text: James Glover was a product of a very different New York.

headline: Rally Protests Coalition in New York State Senate
text: Civil rights leaders and black lawmakers, worried that minority communities would be robbed of influence in Albany, on Saturday denounced a plan by Republicans and a group of dissident Democrats to join together to preside over the State Senate.

headline: Peter Johnson, Crusader Against Corruption, Dies at 91
text: Peter Johnson was 17 when his father, James, a longshoreman on the Manhattan docks, died. James was owed pay that the family needed for his burial. Peter had to beg the corrupt longshoremen’s union to get it.

headline: Manziel, in His First Season, Achieves a Heisman First
text: Johnny Manziel spent his 20th birthday Thursday, with what little time he had, playing nine holes of golf with his family. That night, he accepted the Davey O’Brien Award as the nation’s top quarterback. That left no time for birthday gifts.

headline: Robert Lescher, Editor and Literary Agent, Dies at 83
text: Robert Lescher, a literary agent and steward to the works of a wide array of distinguished 20th-century authors, including Robert Frost, Isaac Bashevis Singer and Alice B. Toklas, died on Nov. 28 in New Milford, Conn. He was 83.

headline: Fugue for Wrung-Out Tinhorns
text: The fight has gone out of the once-robust boys from “Glengarry Glen Ross,” David Mamet’s 1984 Pulitzer Prize-winning drama of sharks in a small pond. Sure, they still curse and rant and beat up on the furniture in the production that formally opened at the Gerald Schoenfeld Theater on Saturday night, after an indecently extended preview period.

headline: Corrections: December 9, 2012
text: NATIONAL

headline: Lottery Numbers
Adoption Limbo
text: American families are struggling with long adoption delays in Guatemala.

headline: A Maestro in Queens
text: Maurice Peress, a protege of Leonard Bernstein and former associate of Duke Ellington, leads the Queens College Orchestra like a big-time philharmonic.

headline: Chávez Says His Cancer Has Returned and Names His Successor
text: ORURO, Bolivia — President Hugo Chávez of Venezuela announced Saturday in Caracas that he would have to undergo another operation for cancer, and he designated his vice president, Nicolás Maduro, as his successor if he should prove unable to continue to lead the country.

headline: Knicks Fall Apart vs. Bulls’ Defense
text: CHICAGO — The pace was so slow, so tedious at times that the loudest noise inside United Center was often the bounce of the ball and the squeak of sneakers. Or it was the clang of the ball bouncing off the rim, which happened a lot in the Knicks’ game Saturday against the Bulls. Coaches Mike Woodson of the Knicks and Tom Thibodeau of the Bulls frequently raised their arms in bewilderment. Sure, the Knicks and the Bulls played solid defense, but they were inefficient on offense.

headline: Feeding the People in Cuba
text: Last year, President Raúl Castro legalized small agricultural businesses as part of an effort to revive the economy.

headline: Dodgers Are Said to Land Greinke
text: The Los Angeles Dodgers reached a record contract Saturday with starter Zack Greinke, agreeing to a six-year, $147 million deal. The $24.5 million average annual value is the highest ever for a pitcher on a multiyear contract, surpassing C. C. Sabathia’s $24.4 million average annual salary with the Yankees.

headline: Army vs. Navy Replay
text: A recovered fumble in the fourth quarter dashed any hope the Army had for ending Navy’s win streak.

headline: ‘Fragile’ Australian Radio Hosts Get Counseling After Nurse’s Death
text: HONG KONG — Anger and outrage continued to grow over the weekend after two Australian radio hosts made a prank call to the London hospital where the Duchess of Cambridge, Kate Middleton, was being treated for acute morning sickness.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, Dec. 9
text: There’s this hope in you that doesn’t want to die. In my heart, he’s my son.

headline: Meghan Kelly, Jason Gefaell
text: Meghan Boyle Kelly and Jason William Gefaell were married Saturday in Westerly, R.I. The Rev. James R. Bocchino performed the ceremony at Christ Episcopal Church, where he is the interim rector, with the Rev. Richard Ryscavage, a Roman Catholic priest, taking part.

headline: Stephanie Hacker, Jonathan Krieger
text: Stephanie Alexandra Hacker and Jonathan Brett Krieger are to be married Sunday, with Rabbi Gerald L. Zelizer officiating at Clarks Landing, a catering hall in Point Pleasant, N.J.

headline: Harlan Bratcher, Toby Usnik
text: Harlan Ray Bratcher and William Louis Usnik Jr. were married Thursday at the Manhattan Marriage Bureau. Damaris Acosta, a deputy city clerk at the New York City Clerk’s Office, officiated.

headline: Abigail Eustis, Geoffrey Sprague
text: Abigail Elisabeth Eustis, a daughter of Barbara Simmons Eustis and James R. Eustis Jr. of Bronxville, N.Y., was married Saturday evening to Geoffrey Owen Sprague, the son of Margaret Wunderlich Sprague and Stephen Owen Sprague of Boston. The Rev. Dr. Richard J. Lichti, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony at the Reformed Church of Bronxville.

headline: Lindsay Hymson, Jason Schechter
text: Lindsay Sarah Hymson and Jason Robert Schechter were married Saturday evening at Temple Israel in Lawrence, N.Y. Rabbi Ian J. Silverman officiated.

headline: Vanessa Kramer and Joseph Hallett III
text: Vanessa Brie Kramer and Joseph Jacob Hallett III were married Saturday in Brooklyn. Rabbi Benjamin J. Zeidman officiated at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden.

headline: Laura Fine, Benjamin Liebman
text: Laura Bailey Fine and Benjamin Isaac Liebman were married Saturday evening at Cook Commons, an event space in Baltimore. Rabbi Daniel Cotzin Burg officiated.

headline: Alexis Steil and Bradley Burwell
text: Alexis Ingham Steil, the daughter of Janice M. Steil and M. Peter Steil Jr. of New York, was married Saturday evening to Bradley William Burwell, a son of Judith A. Burwell of Vashon Island, Wash., and William E. Burwell of Aspen, Colo. The Rev. Lynn Sanders, an Episcopal priest, officiated at St. Bartholomew’s Church in New York.

headline: Alison Cool, Willing Davidson
text: Alison Collier Cool and Homer Willing Davidson were married Friday at the Manhattan Marriage Bureau. James Mitchell, an employee of the New York City Clerk’s Office, officiated.

headline: Jill Grabel, Andrew Kirby
text: Jill Patricia Grabel and Andrew Justin Kirby were married Saturday at the Raphael vineyard in Peconic, N.Y. The Rev. Marie April Gismondi, a minister of the Church of Ancient Ways, officiated.

headline: Catherine Dwyer, Adam Brinch
text: Catherine Elizabeth Dwyer and Adam Soren Brinch were married Saturday at the Second Congregational Meeting House Society on Nantucket Island in Massachusetts. The Rev. David M. Horst, a Unitarian Universalist minister, performed the ceremony.

headline: Mara Opperman, Scott Maness
text: Mara Rachel Opperman and Scott Russell Maness were married Saturday evening at the Pleasantdale Chateau, an event space in West Orange, N.J. Cantor Hal Rifkin officiated.

headline: Leigh Aidner and Micah Brill
text: Leigh Ryan Aidner, the daughter of Sandye Berger of New York and Donald A. Aidner of Los Angeles, was married Saturday evening to Micah Levy Brill, the son of Ralph Brill of North Adams, Mass., and the late Gail J. Koff, who lived in New York. Rabbi Jordan Millstein officiated at Cipriani 42nd Street, an event space in New York.

headline: Parisa Arash and Rudrabhishek Sahay
text: Parisa Arash and Rudrabhishek Sahay were married Saturday at the Acqualina Resort and Spa in Sunny Isles Beach, Fla. The Rev. Milan R. Kralik, a minister of the United Church of Christ, officiated.

headline: Erin Moughon and David Smith
text: Erin Nicole Moughon and David Paul Smith were married Saturday in New York. The Rev. Gary Wiley, an evangelical minister, performed the ceremony at the Park Avenue Christian Church.

headline: Kerry Nordling, David Mayurnik
text: Kerry Catherine Nordling and David Paul Mayurnik were married Saturday evening at Meadow Wood Manor, an event space in Randolph, N.J. The Rev. Carroll J. Mrowicki, a minister affiliated with CITI Ministries, performed the ceremony.

headline: Sonya Hebert and Jon-Bernard Schwartz
text: Sonya Natasha Hebert and Jon-Bernard Schwartz are to be married Sunday at the Carnegie Institute for Science in Washington. Rabbi Stan Levin is to officiate.

headline: Pacquiao Stunned in Sixth Round
text: LAS VEGAS — Manny Pacquiao never saw it coming. He never saw the punch that snapped his head back Saturday and dropped him to the canvas and left him sprawled there momentarily, face down, while his wife sobbed uncontrollably and the packed crowd at MGM’s Grand Garden Arena rose to its feet in shock.

headline: Newswallah: Long Reads Edition
text: An article in Open magazine titled “The Villain Nobody Knows” looks at the beginnings of the Babri Masjid controversy. “The idea that eventually changed the politics of India emerged for the first time among three friends,” write the authors, who trace its origins to Maharaja Pateshwari Prasad Singh, head of the princely state of Balrampur, Mahant Digvijai Nath, politician and religious leader, and KKK Nair, an Indian Civil Service officer, whose friendship was formed over a shared interest in Hindu communalism (and tennis).

headline: Like the Band They Follow, Stones Fans Are Grayer but Still Spry
text: After 50 years in the rock music business, the Rolling Stones have an average age of 68, higher than the average age of the justices on the United States Supreme Court. By all accounts, they are aging well, as have their songs.

headline: Reindeer Games in Hong Kong
text: HONG KONG — Hong Kong has one of the most expensive and crowded property markets in the world, and CBRE, the commercial real estate services firm with offices here, can be highly imaginative when illustrating that point.

headline: Well-Worn Sound, With Unrelenting Swagger
text: In a filmed montage of celebrity adoration before the start of the Rolling Stones show on Saturday night at the Barclays Center in Brooklyn, Iggy Pop had a good line. He was remembering seeing the band play in the late ’60s, and he said, approvingly, that hearing Keith Richards’s guitar sound back then felt like being hit with a dead mackerel.

headline: Ignoring Planetary Peril, a Profound ‘Disconnect’ Between Science and Doha
text: In one of the most poignant moments of the Doha climate talks, the Philippine climate change commissioner, Naderev M. Sano, appealed to his fellow negotiators at a session deciding the contours of the second commitment period of the Kyoto Protocol.

headline: Afghan and Coalition Forces Rescue American Doctor Who Was Kidnapped by Taliban
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — An American doctor kidnapped by the Taliban was rescued Sunday by Afghan and coalition forces in eastern Afghanistan, officials said. At least six people were killed, including a member of a U.S. special forces Navy SEAL team. Two Taliban leaders were arrested during the rescue.

headline: All He Wants for Hanukkah Are In-App Purchases
text: “In-app purchases,” my son said when I asked him what he wanted for Hanukkah. I was dismayed. He wanted to buy the $0.99 and up shortcuts that let him level up in his iPod games. It’s a cash cow for video game developers, a freemium business strategy that allows you to download apps for free but which hits you up for cash later in exchange for slogging through hours of gameplay and unlocking content fast.

headline: Stephanopoulizing
text: Whoops — forgot to post about this. My head talks on This Week this morning; posting from the Green Room now.

headline: Manchester Derby: City 2, United 3
text: Robin van Persie is unlikely to forget his first Manchester derby.

headline: Disruptions: How My Smartphone Emptied My Pockets
text: Growing up, I noticed that something happened to my father as he aged: his wallet expanded with each passing year.

headline: Tom Wolfe Would Hardly Recognize The Bronx Today
text: Two white people, one of them a young woman decked out in a royal-blue Avenue Foch jacket with shoulders out to here . . . enough matched luggage in the back seat for a trip to China . . . a $48,000 Mercedes roadster . . . in the middle of the South Bronx . . .Miraculous!

headline: Romanians Vote in Parliamentary Elections
text: PARIS — Romanians went to the polls on Sunday in parliamentary elections that have threatened to push the country further into political upheaval and acrimony.

headline: On Our Radar: The Doha Denouement
text: John M. Broder’s summary of the slim achievements at the United Nations climate change conference in Doha, Qatar. [The New York Times]

headline: Mortgage Crisis Presents a New Reckoning to Banks
text: The nation’s largest banks are facing a fresh torrent of lawsuits asserting that they sold shoddy mortgage securities that imploded during the financial crisis, potentially adding significantly to the tens of billions of dollars the banks have already paid to settle other cases.

headline: What’s on Sunday
text: 9 P.M. (ABC) CHRISTMAS WITH HOLLY (2012) Mark Nagle (Sean Faris) is the uncle and guardian, along with his two brothers, of 6-year-old Holly (Lucy and Josie Gallina), who hasn’t spoken a word since her mother died unexpectedly. He also owns a coffee shop in Friday Harbor, Wash., where Maggie Conway (Eloise Mumford, above with Mr. Faris) has moved after her fiancé left her at the altar. Maggie’s dream, quickly fulfilled: to open a toy store in this town, where she spent her summers as a girl. During the holiday retail crunch, she can’t help but be drawn to Holly each time she comes in. Alex Paxton-Beesley plays Mark’s girlfriend, who may or may not be what keeps Mark and Maggie from getting to know each other in this “Hallmark Hall of Fame” production.

headline: Telecoms Merger in Austria Could Open Door to Further Consolidation
text: BERLIN — For nearly a decade, financial analysts have expected a wave of mergers and acquisitions to sweep Europe’s fragmented telecommunications sector, consolidating the region’s 102 mobile operators and creating a more efficient market.

headline: James Bond Won’t Die at the Box Office Either
text: “Skyfall” climbed back to No. 1 at North American theaters over the weekend after more than a month in release — an extremely difficult box-office stunt to pull off, even for James Bond. “Skyfall” took in an estimated $11 million between Friday and Sunday, lifting its domestic total to $261.6 million and putting a $1 billion global gross within reach for Sony and Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer.

headline: Obama and Boehner Talk Deficits at the White House
text: WASHINGTON — With just three weeks left for lawmakers to avert a fiscal crisis, President Obama and Speaker John A. Boehner met privately at the White House on Sunday as a top Republican senator suggested that his party should perhaps accede to Mr. Obama’s demand to raise the top tax rates so that the attention can shift to making serious cuts in benefit programs like Medicare and Medicaid.

headline: What’s on Monday
text: 8 P.M. (ABC) EXTREME MAKEOVER: HOME EDITION While on patrol in Iraq in February 2007, Staff Sgt. Shilo Harris received burns to more than 40 percent of his body after an roadside bomb struck the truck that he was traveling in. But he refused medical treatment until he had been assured that his troops were safe. During the months of surgeries that followed, Mr. Harris and his wife, Kathreyn (above, with their children), found their calling: to help those undergoing the same anguished ordeal. Mr. Harris became a motivational speaker, and Ms. Harris started working for the Army Wounded Warrior Project. In this two-hour episode Ty Pennington and his crew renovate their home in Smithville, Tex., with the help of the actor J. R. Martinez and the country singer Lee Greenwood.

headline: U.S. Drone Strike Kills a Commander for Al Qaeda in Pakistan
text: PESHAWAR, Pakistan — A senior commander for Al Qaeda has been killed in an American drone strike in North Waziristan, the restive tribal area along the border with Afghanistan, Pakistani security officials said Sunday.

headline: A Day for the Reds in the Manchester Derby
text: Manchester’s derby, City versus United, has grown into a game for all nations. The players now come from all over the world, and Sunday’s version was broadcast live to 212 countries. It was a tumultuous affair, settled by a winning goal in stoppage time that gave United a 3-2 victory on City’s turf.

headline:
Fighting Drives an
Old Sense of Peace
From Damascus
text: DAMASCUS, Syria — Business has been terrible for Abu Tareq, a taxi driver, so last week, without telling his wife, he agreed to drive a man to the Damascus airport for 10 times the usual rate. But, he said later, he will not be doing that again.

headline: Technology or Monopoly Power?
text: More on robots and all that: first, here’s the chart from the BLS (pdf), which focused on nonfarm business:

headline: Broadway on the Elbe
text: HAMBURG, Germany — An eight-hour production of Goethe’s “Faust” may be the highbrow hit of the fall at the grand Thalia state theater here, but it is an altogether different blockbuster — the Disney musical “Tarzan” — that exemplifies why modern Hamburg has become that rare thing in the theater world: a reliable profit center for producers outside of their two biggest markets, New York and London.

headline: Nets’ Evans, Knowing Focus Is on Him, Tries to Stay on His Feet
text: Reggie Evans is a brawny, feisty rebounding machine who loves a good collision. It takes a lot to make him cringe. A brief exchange with Commissioner David Stern might have done it.

headline: Opponents of Egypt’s Leader Call for Boycott of Charter Vote
text: CAIRO — The political crisis over Egypt’s draft constitution hardened on both sides on Sunday, as President Mohamed Morsi prepared to deploy the army to safeguard balloting in a planned referendum on the new charter and his opponents called for more protests and a boycott to undermine the vote.

headline: Next Act in Italian Drama: Exit Monti the Technocrat, Enter Monti the Politician?
text: ROME — For months, he had flirted with the idea of staying out of politics, but in the end former Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi just could not resist. His statement on Saturday that he would seek office again out of a sense of “responsibility” for Italy effectively ended the mandate of Prime Minister Mario Monti, who said he would step down after Parliament passes a budget bill this month.

headline: Protest of Peace Prize for E.U. Turns Local
text: OSLO — After braving a blizzard of denunciation from China from afar over its decision two years ago to honor a jailed Chinese dissident, the Norwegian Nobel Committee faced anger in its own backyard Sunday on the eve of a ceremony awarding this year’s Nobel Peace Prize to the European Union.

headline: The Lure of the Writer’s Cabin
text: Much has been written about the writer’s cabin. Among the most notable recent books on the topic are “Heidegger’s Hut” by Adam Sharr and “A Place of My Own: The Architecture of Daydreams,” Michael Pollan’s account of  imagining and then actually constructing his own writing space. A standard Internet search can quickly yield images of the writing rooms (cabins, huts, sheds) of legendary scriveners: Dylan Thomas, Virginia Woolf, Ludwig Wittgenstein, Roald Dahl, Carl Jung, Henry Thoreau and — a writer of a markedly different sort —Ted Kaczynski, to name a few. And Jill Krementz’s 1999 collection of photographs “The Writer’s Desk” gives us tantalizing glimpses of writers sitting at their desks. But why the interest? Have these places somehow become secular sites of the sacred?

headline: As Jets Stand by Sanchez, They Run Past Jaguars
text: JACKSONVILLE, Fla. — It may not look like it sometimes, but the Jets want to win. Honest, they do. That desire to win consumes their lives, week after week after week, and guides their decisions — decisions like their call to start Mark Sanchez on Sunday against the Jacksonville Jaguars, a week after he was removed with a bruised ego.

headline: Channeling Bach, With Intensity and Dexterity as Tools

Without a glance at the audience he sat down at the piano, lightly hunched his shoulders and began to play the first notes of Bach’s French Suite No. 5 in G.

headline: Time Passes, but a Song’s Time Doesn’t

Developed by Telltale Games, this downloadable game was released in five parts, reflecting the episodic nature of the comic book and the television series. headline: Robots and Robber Barons

text: KESHOD, Gujarat —The prospects of the Indian National Congress party in the battleground state of Gujarat are dwindling by the day, analysts and potential voters say, a situation that could ultimately advance Gujarat chief minister Narendra Modi’s bid to become prime minister.

headline: Behind the Cover Story: A. O. Scott on Women, “Girls” and the Standout Female Performances of the Year
text: A.O. Scott, a chief film critic for The Times, wrote this week’s cover article about the state of women in movies and exceptional female performances in 2012. His essay accompanies a photo portfolio by Tierney Gearon.

headline: Fill-In | More Dads Buy the Toys, So Barbie, and Stores, Get Makeovers
text: Directions: Fill in the blanks in the first seven paragraphs of the article “More Dads Buy the Toys, So Barbie, and Stores, Get Makeovers” by Stephanie Clifford.

headline: Jets Need a Receiver; What About Braylon Edwards?
Opel Confirms End of Car Production at a Key German Plant
text: FRANKFURT — Opel, the unprofitable European unit of General Motors, confirmed Monday that it would stop producing cars at its plant in Bochum, Germany, in 2016, a sign that even the Continent’s most powerful economy cannot escape the effects of the euro zone crisis.

headline: What’s Going On in This Picture? | Dec. 10, 2012
text: Update: Dec. 12: Scroll to the bottom of this post to find the caption, related story and comments from the photographer.

headline: This Week in Small Business: The Pope’s on Twitter (Are You?)
text: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners this week.

headline: Subject Appears Anxious
text: Year: 2007

headline: Crowdsourcing Your Commute
text: THE HAGUE — In an article in our Smart Cities series, my colleague Choe Sang-Hun reported on how citizens of Seoul are able to connect to a city information system to receive real-time traffic information or mass transit updates.

headline: Training Needed for Home Care Is Lacking
text: “H” from Chicago, I heard you when you joined a lively discussion over hospice at home here a couple of weeks ago and asked, “where can family members get the training to do all the nursing tasks?”

headline: Mourning an Alpha Female
text: As I reported on Sunday in The Times, Yellowstone National Park’s best-known wolf was shot and killed last week outside the park’s borders. A large gray alpha female known as 832F, she had been fitted by researchers with a GPS collar that allowed them to track her movements.

headline: RIT Capital to Take Stake in British Financial Start-Up
text: LONDON – RIT Capital Partners, the investment firm chaired by Jacob Rothschild, said on Monday that it had acquired a stake in a British crowdfunding company, Zopa.

headline: And Now, Round 3 in the Medea Sing-Off
text: Paris—On Monday evening Cherubini’s “Médée” takes to the stage of the Théâtre des Champs-Élysées as the third and final work of a mini-festival this fall of operas about Greek mythology’s most famous woman spurned. On the podium, will be Christophe Rousset, whose sterling credentials as a harpsichordist and Baroque specialist might suggest he’d be more at home with Marc-Antoine Charpentier’s “Médée,” the first in the series (‘‘Medea’’ by the composer Pascal Dusapin was the second).

headline: The Math Bowl: Carolina’s Win Against Atlanta
text: The Atlanta-Carolina game was a mini-mathematics bowl for some in the statistical community.

headline: Study Predicts Future for U.S. as No. 2 Economy, but Energy Independent
text: WASHINGTON — A new intelligence assessment of global trends projects that China will outstrip the United States as the leading economic power before 2030, but that America will remain an indispensable world leader, bolstered in part by an era of energy independence.

headline: Q&A: Borrowing E-Books from the Library
text: Q.

headline: Monday Reading: Deep Powder, Without Deep Pockets
text: Deep powder without deep pockets, how my smartphone emptied my wallet, new taxes take effect to fund health law and other consumer-focused news from The New York Times.

headline: Opinion Report: Factory Fires
text: From the editorial page

headline: Getting His Goat
text: MOSCOW — Should the prime minister have referred to Russian detectives as “goats”? It can be a derogatory term in Russian, just like that word in English that can mean either donkey or derriere.

headline: Kickoffs Help Giants, but Future of Kickoffs Is Uncertain
text: The Giants needed kickoff returns by David Wilson to turn the momentum against the Saints on Sunday.

headline: Philosophy, or Plumbing: How Well Is Academia Preparing Students for the Real World?
text: A report being released Monday by the McKinsey Center for Government shows a big disconnect between new grads looking for work and the employers looking to hire them. Both sides have acknowledged that something is amiss: Only 42 percent of employers felt that new hires were adequately prepared by their education or formal training. Similarly, only 45 percent of graduates felt they were adequately prepared for even entry-level positions in their field.

headline: Banks’ Rising Legal Bills
text: The mortgage crisis continues to haunt banks, which face an onslaught of lawsuits, Jessica Silver-Greenberg writes in The New York Times. “Estimates of potential costs from these cases vary widely, but some in the banking industry fear they could reach $300 billion if the institutions lose all of the litigation. Depending on the final price tag, the costs could lower profits and slow the economic recovery by weakening the banks’ ability to lend just as the housing market is showing signs of life.” The banks are fighting prosecutors, regulators and investors. “We are at an all-time high for this mortgage litigation,” said Christopher J. Willis, a lawyer with Ballard Spahr, which handles securities and consumer litigation.

headline: Daily Report: The Browser Wars Are Back
text: Many consumers are not so sure what a Web browser is. But these programs have become a crucial business for tech companies like Google and Microsoft, Claire Cain Miller reports in Monday’s New York Times. That is because they are now the entry point not just to the Web but to everything stored online, like Web apps, documents and photos.

headline: Japanese Manufacturers Help Save Chip Maker Renesas
text: TOKYO — When a magnitude 9 earthquake knocked out a chip-making factory at Renesas Electronics, Toyota Motor and other manufacturers dispatched hundreds of workers to help get the plant in northeastern Japan running again.

headline: Vain Glorious | The ‘Shampage’ at Pierre Michel
text: To ease the stress of the impending holiday rush, the Pierre Michel salon has introduced a service called the “shampage” (shampoo plus massage). I was cynical, but it’s a winner: a 30-minute hair wash that also focuses on pressure points to release stress. Masseuse/stylists (let’s call them “masstylists”) apply gentle fingertip pressure on both sides of your nose to clear sinuses. Why every stylist doesn’t do this everywhere all year round is another story (they should!). The service at Pierre Michel does not cost extra, and it’s not required, either. A regular blow-out is $65 and includes the “shampage” if your schedule permits.

headline: Huawei to Open Research Center in Finland
text: PARIS — Huawei Technologies, a Chinese maker of telecommunications equipment, said on Monday that it planned to open a research and development center in Helsinki next year, accelerating its investments in Europe, where its business is expanding rapidly.

headline: Not Silenced, 33 Years After Her Own Subway Nightmare
text: On the second night of Hanukkah, Renee Katz lit the menorah candles Sunday evening at her home in Queens, using her right hand a bit tentatively. Hanukkah candles are slender. They are not easy for Ms. Katz to grasp with the right hand. “I don’t have great dexterity,” she said. “Anything that requires fine motor skills is hard.”

headline: Windows 8’s Clarity Problem
text: A modest suggestion to Microsoft: Next time, more verbs.

headline: Vast Land Deal Divides Detroit
text: John Hantz says he has a dream: to purchase 140 acres of derelict land in the heart of Detroit and turn it into the world’s “largest urban farm.”

headline: Chanel's Scottish Touch Warms Up the Scottish Highlands
text: EDINBURGH — The ghost of the doomed Mary, Queen of Scots, might have been swirling in the (fake) mist above the ruined castle where she was born five centuries ago; and the plaintive bagpipes could have been in honor of Gabrielle (Coco) Chanel, when the young French woman was in love with both the Duke of Westminster and the Highlands of Scotland.

headline: Family Treasures and the Secrets They Unlock
text: PARIS — Sometimes there are family treasures that unlock the dramas of generations, revealing stories far larger than ever imagined.

headline: Amgen to Acquire the Gene-Hunting Firm deCODE
text: In a bid to bolster its drug discovery efforts, the biotechnology giant Amgen said on Monday that it would pay $415 million to acquire deCODE Genetics, a gene-hunting business known for its headline-grabbing discoveries linking genetic variations to disease.

headline: Ask Alex Gansa and Howard Gordon About ‘Homeland’
text: Dec. 14 | Updated  Answers are published here.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Bloomberg and The Financial Times, and the First ‘Telecopter’
text: The stars are aligning, perhaps, for the purchase of The Financial Times by Bloomberg L.P., the media company whose shares are 90 percent controlled by New York’s mayor, Michael R. Bloomberg, Amy Chozick and Michael Barbaro write. The departure of two top executives at Pearson, the owner of The Financial Times, has made the sale of the newspaper seem a possibility. Bloomberg, which makes its money primarily from desktop terminals, would have to weigh the business advantages of going backward technologically to print; one advantage would be to gain a well-respected daily platform for Bloomberg content. (Thomson Reuters is also said to be likely to bid on the newspaper.)

headline: Critics’ Groups in Los Angeles, New York and Boston Get Serious
text: The films that, at year’s end, critics (and sometimes audiences) love are beginning to take shape and let’s call it, well, whatever form gravitas takes. The Los Angeles Film Critics Association announced its choices over the weekend, and it gave the top prize to Michael Haneke’s “Amour,” the story of an elderly French couple dealing with dementia and death.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: LA Weekly: Apples as art. — Jeff Gordinier

headline: Standard Chartered Agrees to Settle Iran Money Transfer Claims
text: The British bank Standard Chartered reached a deal with federal and state prosecutors on Monday over accusations that it had illegally funneled money for Iranian banks and corporations.

headline: Man Group’s Chief  to Step Down
text: LONDON — The Man Group, the world’s largest publicly traded hedge fund management firm, said on Monday that Peter Clarke would retire as chief executive at the end of February after almost 20 years with the firm.

headline: More Time For Investors To Sell Back Greek Debt
text: LONDON — Greece, on the verge of completing a crucial plan to reduce its debt burden, extended the deadline on Monday for foreign investors and Greek banks to sell their deeply discounted bonds back to the government.

headline: Moroccans Fear That Flickers of Democracy Are Fading
text: TANGIER, Morocco — Until recently, politics in Morocco involved red carpets and speeches in high Arabic that the average citizen could not understand. But on a campaign swing this fall through a working-class area of this port city, Prime Minister Abdelilah Benkirane stood on a makeshift podium in a muddy vacant lot.

headline: HSBC Names Head of Financial Crime Compliance
text: LONDON – The British bank HSBC on Monday appointed Robert W. Werner, a former United States Treasury official, to direct financial crime compliance, a newly established role.

headline: Something in My Last Post Didn’t Add Up
text: Well, commenters to my last post quickly revealed why I am not a wealthy and successful businessman.

headline: Apps for Children Fall Short on Disclosure to Parents, Report Says
text: Several hundred of the most popular educational and gaming mobile apps for children fail to give parents basic explanations about what kinds of personal information the apps collect from children, who can see that data and what they use it for, a new federal report says.

headline: A ‘Girls’ Soundtrack Album Is On the Way
text: Anyone who feels their approximation of the life of 20-something Brooklyn ladies is incomplete without a musical accompaniment can ready their headphones. The HBO series “Girls” will have an official soundtrack, released by the label Fueled by Ramen on Jan. 8, just before the second season’s premiere. Contributors include a who’s who of pop acts and the contemporary indie scene like Fun., Icona Pop, Fleet Foxes, Robyn (whose “Dancing on My Own” helped fuel a plot point in an early episode), and Sleigh Bells. A track by Santigold  called “Girls” is the lead single.

headline: Memo from Miami | Fun in the Sun
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: Where Neighborly Agreement Is Scarce, Finding Consensus on Art in the Lobby
text: The spaces are often teeny and the prices are generally enormous, but perhaps the most irritating feature of living in New York City condominiums and co-ops lies past the wallet and outside the apartment door: collective decision-making among dozens, even hundreds, of neighbors.

headline: U.S. Agricultural Research Is Faltering, Report Warns
text: A blue-ribbon panel of scientific and technology advisers to President Obama warns that the nation risks losing its longstanding supremacy in food production because research in agriculture has not kept up with new challenges like climate change, depleted land and water resources and emerging pests, pathogens and invasive plants.

headline: ‘Zero Dark Thirty’ Catches Even Cast Members by Surprise
text: 11:51 a.m. | Updated  With this season’s compressed schedule for Oscar voting comes a glut of screenings, Q&As and other appearances intended to endear movies and their stars and filmmakers to Academy voters. In New York that also means luncheons — often masterminded by the publicity maven Peggy Siegal — that are stocked with Academy members who don’t mind a free meal in exchange for a few hours in the company of colleagues and celebrities.

headline: Dueling Protests Continue in Cairo
text: The Times’s Cairo bureau chief, David Kirkpatrick, explains the ongoing political crisis over Egypt’s draft constitution.

headline: Everyone’s a Critic: Turkish Lawmaker Joins Prime Minister in Attack on Soap Opera
text: The culture clash between a steamy Turkish soap opera and the country’s conservative governing party shows little sign of abating.

headline: Street Style: Black and White
text: The best of readers’ photographs from the week of Dec. 3.

headline: Image of the Day: Dec.10
text: International Human Rights Day was observed by children of sex workers in West Bengal.

headline: Obama, With Blue-Collar Backdrop, Pushes for Higher Taxes on the Richest
text: REDFORD, Mich. — Using a German-owned truck factory as a grease-stained backdrop, President Obama on Monday pressed his case for higher tax rates for the richest Americans, declaring that his economic program would cut the deficit without crimping the job market.

headline: Alice in Math Wonderland
text: The Museum of Mathematics (MoMath) will open to the public on Saturday at 11 East 26th Street in Manhattan. The museum features innovative hands-on exhibits that emphasize the fun of mathematics. To celebrate the occasion, today’s Numberplay and the one next week will feature puzzles that are based on exhibits at the museum.

headline: Mourning a Banda Star
text: TimesCast: Mexican-American singer Jenni Rivera is feared to have died in a plane crash. | Cuba’s agricultural experiment with capitalism. | Egypt’s constitutional standoff continues.

headline: Feeling the Heat, Yoga Chain Bows to Bikram, Despite Federal Ruling
text: Updated, 4:25 p.m. | A popular New York-based chain of yoga studios accused by Bikram Yoga of copyright infringement has decided to let go, despite a Copyright Office ruling that supported its position.

headline: Jenni Rivera, Mexican-American Singer, Dies at 43
text: Jenni Rivera, the Mexican-American singer and reality television star known as “the Diva of Banda,” died early Sunday when the plane in which she was traveling crashed outside Monterrey, Mexico, after a performance there. She was 43.

headline: When Giving a Used Gift Is O.K.
text: Would you give someone a “pre-owned” gift for the holidays or a birthday?

headline: An Adoptive Parent Won’t Take the Blame
text: I’m the adoptive mother to a daughter and a son, ages 10 and 8, both born in Guatemala. Three years after my daughter came home, in November 2006, The New York Times ran an article blasting Guatemala’s adoption system, calling the country a “virtual baby farm.”

headline: Did the Mainstream Press Really Bungle the Campaign’s  ‘Single Biggest Story’?
text: In one of the most fascinating media-related pieces I’ve read in a while, Dan Froomkin interviews Thomas Mann and Norman Ornstein, two longtime Washington observers who wrote a book together and soon after, they say, found themselves near pariahs in a city that didn’t want to hear what they had to say.

headline: Single Rides and Monthly Passes to Cost More in M.T.A. Plan
text: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority’s board appears poised to consider a proposal that would increase base fares on subways and buses by a quarter, to $2.50, and raise the cost of a 30-day pass by $8, to $112.

headline: Amid Highlights, Grief Returns to N.F.L. Sideline
text: Death was again a presence on an N.F.L. sideline on Sunday. A week after Jovan Belcher of the Kansas City Chiefs committed suicide in front of Coach Romeo Crennel and General Manager Scott Pioli after murdering his girlfriend Kasandra Perkins, the Dallas Cowboys paid tribute to Jerry Brown, who died after a car in which he was a passenger spun out of control on Saturday. The driver was a teammate, Josh Brent, who was jailed and charged with intoxication manslaughter.

headline: The Connection Between Europe’s Nobel and Afghanistan
text: The European Union received the Nobel Peace Prize on Monday in recognition of the bloc’s commitment to peace and human rights.

headline: Springsteen, Lady Gaga and the Black Keys to Join the Stones
text: Bruce Springsteen, Lady Gaga and the Black Keys will be guest artists when the Rolling Stones play on Saturday at the Prudential Center in Newark, the last scheduled concert in a mini-tour to celebrate the band’s 50th anniversary.

headline: 7 Score and 7 Years Ago, a Similar Albany
text: New York’s capital city can’t seem to catch a break. A string of corruption and sex scandals and byzantine power struggles have frustrated would-be reformers; the State Senate is so divided that Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo said last week that “I expect the leadership situation to be fluid and subject to influence for some time.”

headline: Baryshnikov Arts Center Announces 2013 Season
text: The Baryshnikov Arts Center has announced its spring 2013 season lineup, a schedule of performance and dance that will focus on new works by choreographers relatively new to the New York scene.

headline: Masta Killa on ‘The Master’
text: The Los Angeles Film Critics Association fell hard for “The Master,” awarding Paul Thomas Anderson best director and also smiling on Joaquin Phoenix and Amy Adams for their performances. They’re professionals and all, but few of them – as far as we know – actually take the title “Master.”

headline: Look of The Moment | Pharrell Williams
text: The Look: Army Grade. Black tie on top with street-sport shorts on the bottom and an allover military camo is a perfect fashion mash-up.

headline: Charles Rosen, Scholar-Musician Who Untangled Classical Works, Dies at 85
text: Charles Rosen, the pianist, polymath and author whose National Book Award-winning volume “The Classical Style” illuminated the enduring language of Haydn, Mozart and Beethoven, died on Sunday in Manhattan. He was 85.

headline: A New Twist on a Hanukkah Staple
text: I’m glad that nutritionists have changed their view of fats. The data tells them that when it comes to negative health outcomes like deaths from diabetes and heart disease, fats, at least of the polyunsaturated and monounsaturated variety, are not the big bad culprits. Simple carbohydrates appear to play a much more pernicious role.

headline: Changes at The Wine Advocate Signal a Shift in the Market
text: For many wine lovers, the news that Robert M. Parker Jr. is planning to sell a portion of his influential newsletter, The Wine Advocate, to a group of Asian investors and step down as editor in chief does not so much signal an end of an era as acknowledges changes that have been under way for a decade.

headline: Video Shows Man Mugging 85-Year-Old Woman in Elevator
text: The police are looking for a man who was captured on video knocking down an 85-year-old woman in the elevator of her West Village apartment building and stealing her bag. The man is at least six feet tall and weighs at least 200 pounds, the police said.

headline: Sweet Potato and Apple Latkes With Ginger and Sweet Spices
text: I found that the best way to make these so they cook through without burning is to make small latkes, using about 2 tablespoons of the mixture for each one. You can also finish them in the oven.

headline: Homer R. Warner, a Pioneer of Using Computers in Patient Care, Dies at 90
text: Homer R. Warner, a physiologist whose research fusing engineering and medicine helped introduce computer analysis to diagnosing illnesses, died on Nov. 30 in Salt Lake City. He was 90.

headline: Accounts and People of Note in the Advertising Industry
text: Bottlerocket Marketing Group, New York and Foxborough, Mass., was acquired by Brand Connections, New York. Financial terms were not disclosed. The acquisition is the second in a month for Brand Connections, coming after a deal to acquire Pie Advertising, New York.

headline: Q. and A. With Stuart Elliott
text: Stuart Elliott, the advertising columnist, answers questions from readers each week. Questions can be sent to stuarte@nytimes.com.

headline: Environment: Mapping Hot Spots of Lead Contamination Could Safeguard Children in Mining Towns
text: Using a hand-held scanner to map hot spots where the soil is full of lead could protect children in mining towns against brain damage, scientists at Columbia University concluded in a new study.

headline: Playing the ‘Talk About Giving’ Game With Your Family
text: In this past weekend’s Your Money column, I mentioned the “Talk About Giving” game. It’s a $13 offering (including shipping and handling) from the Central Carolina Community Foundation, and you pick cards from a deck and use the questions as a way to begin a family discussion about values and philanthropy.

headline: ‘In the Heights’ Coming to the Heights
text: “In the Heights” will finally be coming to the Heights. The rap-salsa-pop musical by Lin-Manuel Miranda, which won the 2008 best musical Tony for its jaunty exploration of the lives of Dominican-American characters living in Washington Heights, will be restaged in the form of a one-night-only concert Feb. 11 at the United Palace of Cultural Arts at 175th Street and Broadway.

headline: A Rising Tide of Noise Is Now Easy to See
text: When a hurricane forced the Nautilus to dive in Jules Verne’s “Twenty Thousand Leagues Under the Sea,” Captain Nemo took the submarine down to a depth of 25 fathoms, or 150 feet. There, to the amazement of the novel’s protagonist, Prof. Pierre Aronnax, no whisper of the howling turmoil could be heard.

headline: The Mayor Menino Blues
text: A blues tune recorded by the mayor of Boston, Thomas M. Menino, is featured on the Samaritans’ suicide prevention Web site.

headline: David Ortiz Sings the Blues
text: A blues tune recorded by David Ortiz of the Boston Red Sox can be found on the Samaritans’ suicide prevention Web site.

headline: Effort to Fight Suicide Focuses on ‘the Help and the Hope’
text: There has been quite a vogue in recent years for what are called random acts of kindness. A new campaign is adding some planning to the mix.

headline: Cuomo Rejects Criticism for Avoiding Senate Leadership Dispute
text: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, criticized by black lawmakers for not objecting to a proposed governing coalition in the State Senate between Republicans and a group of dissident Democrats, insisted on Monday that it was not his place to get involved in what he called “a schism within the Democrats” in the chamber.

headline: Your ‘Modern Family’ Questions Answered
text: Steven Levitan and Christopher Lloyd, the co-creators of the hit ABC comedy “Modern Family,” answered questions posed by Times readers. (Alex Gansa and Howard Gordon, the creators of Showtime’s “Homeland,” are taking queries now.)

headline: For the Baseball Classic, the Fan Cave Will Be International
text: The M.L.B.’s popular Fan Cave is taking a road trip, sort of.

headline: Technology and Wages, the Analytics (Wonkish)
text: Obviously I’m getting a lot of reaction to my stuff on robots and all that. (My copy editor, last night: “Thank God, it’s not about the fiscal cliff!”) My sense is, however, that a lot of the reaction, both positive and negative, involves misunderstanding the economic logic, with some readers believing that technological progress can never hurt workers, others believing that rapid productivity growth always hurts workers; neither is true. So here’s an attempt to explain what’s going on in the theory; cognoscenti will recognize it as nothing more than an exposition of J.R, Hicks’s analysis of the whole thing in his 1932 Theory of Wages (pdf).

headline: Westgarth Says Pension Plan Would Be a ‘Gain’
text: Below, excerpts from an hourlong conversation over the weekend with Los Angeles forward Kevin Westgarth, a member of the N.H.L. Players’ Association negotiating committee. (You can read a profile here.) In that conversation, he discusses what was achieved by last week’s talks in New York, why the owners seem to be dodging mediation, why they dislike Donald Fehr, what really happened in the reported shouting match between Jeremy Jacobs and Ryan Miller, and where the two sides stand on key issues as new talks loom in the 12-week-old N.H.L. lockout.

headline: Want to Live Longer? Breathe Clean Air
text: Continuing declines in air pollution are linked to increasing life expectancy, a national study has found.

headline: Gmail Goes Down, Frustrating Office Workers
text: Some Gmail users had trouble starting the work week on Monday.

headline: Really? On a Cloudy Day, Your Eyes Can Be Sunburned
text: THE FACTS

headline: Fried Shallots
text: Mark Bittman prepares a simple garnish with a mandoline.

headline: A Winter’s Cornucopia in Wales
text: THE predicament I found myself in was also an opportunity, and not unlike the puzzle that faces C.S.A. participants each week: I had a pile of vegetables and I had to figure out what to do with it. (A C.S.A. — for community supported agriculture — is a scheme in which participants share in a farmer’s risk and bounty, putting money down upfront and getting a periodic share of the crop in exchange.)

headline: Campaign Finance API: We’re Deprecating Individual Donor Search
text: One of the earliest features of our Campaign Finance API allows users to search individual contributions to presidential candidates from 2008 and 2012 by name and/or ZIP code. But this data is offered in many other places, several of which have better search interfaces and also include contributions to other campaigns. (The individual search responses are also among the least requested by users of our Campaign Finance API.)

headline: Man Fatally Shot on Midtown Street
text: Updated, Tuesday, 6:51 a.m. | Gunfire cut through the bustling noise of Monday afternoon in Midtown Manhattan, a sound instantly recognizable to passers-by on a packed corner a block from Central Park.

headline: TimesOpen 2012 Hack Day Wrap-Up
text: 10:12 a.m. | Updated Added Tumblist Times to the list of hacks (we were waiting for permission to post the details).

headline: A Brief Note on Mary Matalin
text: The briefer the better, I’d say. But anyway, yesterday on “This Week” she attacked me for being a “polemicist”; what’s interesting is the context. I was trying to correct a claim she was making that was factually wrong. She threw out a number — $1.7 trillion from capping deductions — as evidence that the G.O.P. claim that it can raise lots of revenue from high-income Americans without raising tax rates is true.

headline: Egyptian President Tries to Clarify Military Order
text: CAIRO — A day after President Mohamed Morsi formally directed the military to help keep public order and authorized soldiers to arrest civilians, a spokesman on Monday sought to draw distinctions between the order and the forms of martial law that the Egyptian Army had previously imposed.

headline: European Officials Accept Union’s Nobel Peace Prize
text: OSLO — Besieged by economic woes and insistent questions about its future, the European Union accepted the Nobel Peace Prize on Monday with calls for further integration and a plea to remember the words of Abraham Lincoln as he addressed a divided nation at Gettysburg.

headline: At Home on Mars
text: Q. Could Mars be made suitable for human life by raising plants to produce oxygen?

headline: Facing a Defining Sunday After a Deflating One
text: Days like last Sunday happen occasionally in the N.F.L. — usually at least once a season — and when they do, it feels as if a shift has taken place. Next Sunday’s schedule is loaded with critical matchups and will be perhaps the best viewing day of the season, with at least eight games freighted with postseason implications.

headline: The Next Big Thing in Motorcycles: Going Small
text: LONG BEACH, Calif. — Boomers who were long the motorcycle industry’s primary focus could be less important to product planners if the new, smaller bikes presented last weekend at the Progressive International Motorcycle Show are indeed the future.

headline: Concussion Liability Costs May Rise, and Not Just for N.F.L.
text: As the N.F.L. confronts a raft of lawsuits brought by thousands of former players who accuse the league of hiding information about the dangers of concussions, a less visible battle that may have a more widespread effect in the sport is unfolding between the league and 32 of its current and former insurers.

headline: Ford Fixing Leak Problem With Software Upgrade
text: Ford says that next week it will send dealers a software upgrade that will solve a fire concern that required the recall of 65,000 2013 Escapes and almost 15,800 2013 Ford Fusions in the United States.

headline: Concern Over Apps for Kids
text: TimesCast Media+Tech: An update in the battle over children’s privacy online. | Deb Perelman of Smitten Kitchen. | Bloomberg weighs bidding on Financial Times.

headline: Britain’s Departing Central Banker Is Troubled by Trade Imbalance
text: Mervyn A. King, the outgoing governor of the Bank of England, expressed confidence in his successor and discussed economic challenges facing Britain and the United States in their approaches to monetary policy and financial regulation in a speech Monday at the Economic Club of New York.

headline: N.H.L. Drops Games Through Dec. 30
text: In a move expected after last week’s failed labor talks, the N.H.L. canceled another 16 days of games Monday. The move extended the cancellations from Dec. 15 through Dec. 30, bringing the total number of regular-season games lost in the lockout to 526, or 42.8 percent of the schedule.

headline: Mapping Ocean Noise
text: A project to document and map man-made noise in the ocean estimated average annual underwater noise across a range of frequencies.

headline: The Budding Health Care Costs of Climate Change
text: Images of physical damage have been prominent in the news coverage of Hurricane Sandy – the charred frames of houses in Breezy Point, Queens, for example, or a roller coaster submerged in the Atlantic City breakers. Far less conspicuous are long-term health effects, from increased rates of tetanus and respiratory disease to post-traumatic stress disorder.

headline: Hotel Worker Settles Claim Strauss-Kahn Forced Sex
text: The former French politician Dominique Strauss-Kahn and the hotel housekeeper who accused him of sexually assaulting her last year have agreed to settle her lawsuit stemming from their encounter, a judge said on Monday.

headline: Abuse Verdict Topples a Hasidic Wall of Secrecy
text: Sexual abuse in the ultra-Orthodox Jewish community has long been hidden. Victims who came forward were intimidated into silence; their families were shunned; cases were dropped for a lack of cooperation.

headline: Week Ahead in Fiscal Talks
text: The Times’s Annie Lowrey reports on how some Republicans are considering concessions on taxes in order to shift the debate to entitlements.

headline: The Fine Line Between Legal, and Illegal, Insider Trading
text: The steady drumbeat of insider trading cases brought by the government has continued, and corporate officers have not avoided scrutiny.

headline: Batman, Not Bond, and Other Film Institute Notes
text: 1:35 p.m. | Updated  It was good news for fans of one British series, and bad news for diehards of another today, as the American Film Institute announced its picks for the year’s best films. “The Dark Knight Rises” – helmed by a British director, Christopher Nolan, with stars, like Christian Bale and Michael Caine, from all over the United Kingdom – was on the list; “Skyfall” was not. (Sorry to disappoint, Bond aficionados and Bagger readers!) Robert Zemeckis’s “Flight,” still an Oscar contender for Denzel Washington’s performance, was also not chosen as one of the cream of the crop; latecomer “Django Unchained” was.

headline: Holiday Shopping on the Fly
text: Airport shopping used to be mainly for the desperate or bored. But as airports seek to generate more revenue, they have been expanding their offerings of stores and other services, and some time-constrained business travelers now say they find gift-worthy items before their flights.

text: This week: cacophony in the ocean deep, parasites and zombies, and building empathy in children.

text: Researchers may have discovered the earliest dinosaur yet, or at least its closest relative.

headline: Scene City: Last Stop at Art Basel Miami Beach
text: A roundup of some Art Basel Miami Beach parties held over the weekend, including a party held at the former Versace mansion and Moncler’s 60th anniversary.

headline: South Street Seaport Museum to Reopen Friday
text: The waterlogged South Street Seaport Museum has dried out and is coming back to life. Having been closed by Hurricane Sandy, the museum will reopen on Friday, officials announced Monday.

headline: Walkabout — 12/10: What Berlin’s Delayed Airport Means, and Our Travel Section’s Cameo on “The Simpsons”
text: Up in the Air Willy Brandt International Airport was supposed to be Berlin’s gateway to the world, but has turned into a symbol of its provincialism. (International Herald Tribune)

headline: In China, New Leadership and New Style
text: Xi Jinping visited Shenzhen over the weekend in a move seen by some as a sign of his commitment to further economic reforms. The choice of this city as the destination for his first domestic trip as general secretary is seen as a strong signal that Mr. Xi is hitching himself to Deng Xiaoping’s legacy and style and is serious about reinvigorating reforms.

headline: The Giving Spree | Liu Wen
text: Who: The Chinese model Liu Wen, who appeared on the cover of T’s spring travel issue. Her journey from Hunan province, where she was born, to the New York runways is documented in Christina Larson’s “The Liu Wen Express.”

headline: A Tense Compromise on Defining Disorders
text: They plotted a revolution, fell to debating among themselves, and in the end overturned very little except their own expectations.

headline: Notable Opinion Art from 2012
text: A selection of illustrations that reflects on the issues of 2012 using exemplary wit, incisiveness, beauty and provocation.

headline: Republican Party Looks to Learn From 2012 Electoral Losses
text: The Republican National Committee is studying how to improve the party’s image, expand its appeal to voters and improve how campaigns are conducted, a move that signals a direct acknowledgment that party leaders are intent on trying to heed lessons from the 2012 election cycle.

headline: China Detains Two Tibetans in Self-Immolation Protests
text: BEIJING — Chinese police officials have detained a Tibetan monk and his nephew and accused them of playing a role in a series of self-immolations, according to Xinhua, the state news agency. The move appeared to be part of a campaign to prosecute Tibetans who are accused of aiding others who set fire to themselves in protest of Chinese rule.

headline: Opportunity, a Mars Rover Past Its Best-By Date, Keeps Going
text: SAN FRANCISCO — While many obsessed over speculation that NASA’s newest Mars rover, Curiosity, had dug up signs of life — it had not — it is the agency’s older, smaller jalopy, Opportunity, that has been exploring a more intriguing plot of Martian real estate.

headline: Jettisoning the Aircraft Leasing Business
text: Robert H. Benmosche is making American International Group more aerodynamic — at a price.

headline: When Hiding Their Food, Eurasian Jays Keep Quiet
text: The Eurasian jay, a member of the crow family, hides acorns and other food in several thousand locations every year, to be retrieved when food is scarce.

headline: Life After Escaping an Indian Brothel
text: Minati, 19, was never meant to be rescued from a brothel here in the red light district of Kolkata, India. When Nick Kristof accompanied the International Justice Mission and the police on a raid in a brothel in the Songachi district last year, they were looking for a girl much younger than Minati.

headline: Fearing a Mile-High Punk’d Prank
text: NEVER in a million years did I think that I was going to be the guy who hops on a plane and gets to go and do something he enjoys so much — being “the Subway guy.” I’m a good flier, but I’m also lucky that most of my flights have been pretty uneventful.

headline: S.C. Governor Rules Out a ‘Placeholder’ Appointment to Replace DeMint
text: South Carolina Gov. Nikki Haley said Monday that she would not appoint a “placeholder” to fill temporarily the Senate seat made vacant by the retirement of Senator Jim DeMint.

headline: Coating on Aspirin Sets Off a Debate
text: Millions of Americans take low-dose aspirin every day to prevent heart attacks and strokes. But a study published last week challenges some cherished beliefs about the familiar remedy, leaving some consumers to wonder if they should throw out their coated pills and others concerned that they unnecessarily may be taking expensive substitutes.

headline: Recalling Lives Altered, in Ways Vivid and Untidy
text: Alice Munro, one of the foremost short-story writers of her generation, creates tales that have the scope and amplitude of novels: whole lives are condensed into a handful of pages, the progress of love is charted over the years as passion gives way to restlessness or deeper commitment or something more ambiguous.

headline: A Dark and Stormy Fall Season for Broadway
text: The fall theater season on Broadway has been one of the weakest in recent memory, to judge by box office receipts and critics’ reviews, with only a handful of potential hits among the new shows. Indeed, the two best-reviewed shows of the fall have emerged as two of the worst sellers on Broadway.

headline: Gridlock Reform
text: With Harry Reid apparently determined to alter Senate filibuster rules, Republicans John McCain, Lamar Alexander, Jon Kyl and Lindsey Graham have commenced “back-channel talks” with Democrats.

headline: Efficacy of Tobacco Taxes Tied to Gene Type
text: Tobacco use has declined sharply since the 1960s, but for the past 20 years about 20 percent of the population has continued to smoke. The imposition of steep tobacco taxes in many states has not lowered the smoking rate.

headline: Lower Bone Density for Girls Who Smoke
text: Smoking in teenage girls is associated with slower development of bone mineral density, a new study reports.

headline: Fighting the ‘Resource Curse,’ Part 2
text: The World Bank has announced efforts to create a $50 million trust fund for use by African countries negotiating mineral, oil and gas contracts. The money would be spent on securing advice from lawyers and from technical advisers like engineers and chemists during negotiations with energy and kining companies.

headline: Genomic Study Traces Roma to Northern India
text: The Roma people of Europe, often called Gypsies, are long thought to have originated in India because of similarities between Roma and Indian languages. But historical records are scanty.

headline: Afghan Women’s Affairs Aide Shot Months After Killing of Predecessor
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — The acting head of women’s affairs in Laghman Province in eastern Afghanistan was shot to death in daylight on Monday as she was traveling to work.

headline: Understanding How Children Develop Empathy
text: The mother was trying to hold the baby still, and I was pulling gently on the ear, angling for a better look at the infant’s eardrum. The wriggling baby didn’t like any of it, and her whimpering quickly turned to full-fledged wails.

text: “Have you seen but a bright lily grow,” a Ben Jonson poem asks, “before rude hands had touch’d it?”
