headline: North Korea Launches Rocket
text: The Times's David E. Sanger discusses Pyongyang's apparently successful attempt to put a satellite into orbit, the timing of which caught the United States by surprise.

headline: Obama to Recognize Syrian Rebels
text: The Times's Michael R. Gordon on President Obama's announcement that the United States will formally recognize a coalition of Syrian opposition groups as the country's legitimate representatives.

headline: Court Convicts a Bosnian Serb General of Genocide
text: PARIS — A former senior commander of the Bosnian Serb Army, Zdravko Tolimir, was convicted of genocide on Wednesday and sentenced to life in prison for his role in the killings of thousands of prisoners near the Bosnian town of Srebrenica in July 1995.

headline: Airbnb Adds ‘Experience’ As a Rental Filter Choice
text: Airbnb, which started as a vacation rental site, has sought to expand its mission with add-ons like meetups, activities meant to broaden its appeal to an audience just as interested in a curated travel experience as they are in bargain accommodations.

headline: Political Predictions, Holiday Edition
text: Gail Collins: Happy holidays, David! I can tell we’re in the Christmas season because the tree sellers have returned from Quebec and set up shop on my corner. I always enjoy getting off the subway and walking through what seems to be a small forest populated by people speaking French and brandishing hatchets.

headline: Claims of Looting Shadow Expert in Khmer Art
text: BANGKOK — For decades Douglas A. J. Latchford, an 81-year-old British art collector, has built a reputation as one of the world’s great experts in Khmer antiquities, one whose generous return of treasures to Cambodia garnered him knighthood there in 2008.

headline: The Knicks Have a New Number: 3
text: The New York Knicks’ final, game-winning shot against the Brooklyn Nets Tuesday night was, appropriately, a Jason Kidd 3-pointer. The Knicks, who lead the Eastern Conference, are averaging 29.4 3-point shots per game, which puts them on pace to shoot more 3-pointers than any team in N.B.A. history.

headline: Knicks-Lakers: Compare and Contrast
text: Carmelo Anthony of the Knicks had a season-high 45 points. Thirty-nine-year-old Jason Kidd hit the game-winning 3-pointer. The Nets had an early lead of 17 points, and led by 10 in the third quarter. The Knicks won, 100-97, evening the season series at a game apiece.

headline: In Performance: Michael Learned
text: The actress in a scene from Bruce Graham’s family drama “The Outgoing Tide.”

headline: A Warm-and-Fuzzy Look That Leaves You Cold
text: YOU see them all the time lately, grown women who look as if they dressed for work and then walked out of the house and forgot their shoes. On the A train at 42nd Street, a woman in a business suit stood reading the business reports on her iPad, on her feet fur slippers as big as plates.

headline: Why Not in My Backyard?
text: Photographing Quvenzhané Wallis in Brooklyn.

headline: Deadline Nears for Free Holiday Shipping
text: If you’re planning on shipping holiday gifts at no charge, it’s time to start paying attention — that is, if you want them to arrive before Christmas Day. Time is running out for free shipping.

headline: In London, a Sanctum for Single Malts
text: Signature cocktails need to go. And no one seems to feel this sentiment as acutely as the whiskey aficionados and connoisseurs who belong to London’s new Soho Whisky Club. Besides its fabulous whiskey, the club’s finest quality is its semisecret location in a lofty annex above one of London’s oldest and finest single-malt retailers, the Vintage House on Old Compton Street. This downstairs shop carries over 1,800 pours and is the envy of single-malt collectors, offering hard-to-find tipples like a 70-year-old Mortlach (just $30,400). The attitude of the upstairs whiskey club seems to be along the lines of: Why read a description of our whiskies when you can have them in a glass? And for a $320 annual membership fee, members enjoy privacy, free monthly tastings and a choice from over 300 single malts, from the delightfully drinkable to the rare reserves. Among the special 2012 bottles the club currently recommends are the Port Ellen 32 year old ($956), a peppery pour with an almost muddy coal finish, and Auchroisk 30 year ($367), which tastes of banana, charred fruitcake and orange peel.

headline: Homes for $2.9 Million
text: Properties in Ballard, Calif., Golden, Colo., and Chicago.

headline: What You Get for ... $2.9 Million
text: BALLARD, CALIF.

headline: How Boulder Grew Into a Hub for Start-Ups
text: After selling his Boston start-up in 1995, Brad Feld, then 29, moved to Colorado with his wife, Amy.

headline: Below the Line: Designing the Costumes for ‘Magic Mike’
text: This  summer, when Christopher Peterson would meet people and tell them he designed the costumes for Steven Soderbergh’s stripper drama “Magic Mike,” he would often hear the same question: “What costumes were there?”

headline: A Three-Bedroom House in an Old Sugar Mill on Nevis
text: Vervain Mill, converted in 1980 and renovated in the 1990s, is on the market for $1.95 million.

headline: House Hunting in ... Nevis
text: A THREE-BEDROOM HOME IN A CONVERTED SUGAR MILL ON NEVIS

headline: Book Titles With That Indie-Rock Feel
text: When Douglas Coupland, born in 1961, called a novel “Girlfriend in a Coma,” after the song by the Smiths, it made perfect generational sense. The song was released when Mr. Coupland was 25. But certain bands — the Smiths, R.E.M., the Cure — continue to hold a special place for bookish listeners of new generations, and to influence writers looking for titles.

headline: The Hottest Tickets of the Year
text: WHO’S AFRAID OF VIRGINIA WOOLF? Half a century after it exploded onto the American cultural scene, Edward Albee’s biting examination of marriage as a grueling emotional battleground was revitalized yet again, making for the year’s best show on Broadway. The Steppenwolf Theater production, directed by Pam MacKinnon, stars a revelatory Tracy Letts as the most commanding George I’ve seen, and Amy Morton as the most woundingly human Martha. Fight the fight for good theater on Broadway by making a visit to “Virginia Woolf” a priority. Trust me, you’ve never seen it like this before.

headline: Charles Isherwood’s Best of 2012
text: Photos of “The Piano Lesson,” “Detroit” and other shows.

headline: Russia’s History Should Guide Its Future, Putin Says
text: MOSCOW — In his first major speech since returning to the presidency, Vladimir V. Putin on Wednesday called on Russians “not to lose ourselves as a nation,” urging them to look for guidance in Russia’s historic and traditional values — and not in Western political models — as it charts its post-Soviet development.

headline: Stress Less: Understanding How Your Mind and Body Respond to Anxiety
text: Overview | What is stress? How do the body and brain respond to it? Why is it important to understand the effects of stress? In this lesson, students learn about the physiological stress response, and then choose from a number of activities to explore various aspects of anxiety.

headline: Dealbook Conference
text: Aha. Forgot to post this; it’s on today, with live blog and webcast here. I’m on at 4:45. But first, off to Zabar’s to pick up some supplies to take home to NJ.

headline: Starter: Atera Opens a Reservation-Only Lounge
text: Starter, an occasional column, takes a look at newly opened restaurants and bars.

headline: Taylor Swift Is Back on Top of the Charts
text: On the music charts this week, Taylor Swift returns to No. 1 after a brief exile in second place, outselling new releases by Wiz Khalifa and Kesha as well as a blizzard of holiday-themed albums.

headline: Four Blocks Away
text: When David and Jen Gordon heard the Nets were moving to Brooklyn, four blocks from where they live, David signed up four years in advance, placing at 186th on the waiting list for season tickets.

headline: Self-Taught Cook, Best-Selling Cookbook
text: Deb Perelman was working as an art therapist in 2003 when she decided that she wanted to tell stories about her life in New York, mostly about the bad dates she was going on. She started a blog and called it Smitten.

headline: Behold the 12/12/12 12:12 Baby
text: This baby is so fresh she doesn’t even have a name yet, but she definitely has a number. Baby-girl Patterson entered the world at 12 minutes after noon today at NewYork-Presbyterian/Weill Cornell hospital. (The clock-looking thing on the right in the photo above is a timer, not a clock.)

headline: Pogue’s 12 Days of Gadgets: PowerTrip Charger
text: Oh come, all ye faithful — today is Day 5 in Pogue’s 12 Days of Gadgets! One gift idea every day that you probably weren’t thinking about — and nothing over $100.

headline: To Save a Coral Reef Enabler
text: Luiz Rocha, the curator of ichthyology at the California Academy of Sciences, writes from Belize, where he conducts research on one of the world’s most endangered fish.

headline: McAfee’s Ride With the Press Is Still as Bumpy as Ever
text: The tumultuous relationship between the technology entrepreneur John McAfee and the reporters who have covered his flight from Belize took another turn on Tuesday, when McAfee announced on his blog that he would no longer cooperate with Vice, the publication that revealed his location when it posted an image embedded with information about where it had been taken.

headline: Lisa Della Casa, Soprano, Dies at 93
text: Lisa Della Casa, the Swiss soprano who combined an outstanding voice, stunning beauty and exceptional stage presence to become one of the foremost interpreters of Richard Strauss, died on Monday in Münsterlingen, Switzerland. She was 93.

headline: Official Joy on North Korea’s Airwaves
text: The success of North Korea’s rocket launching on Wednesday, which appeared to propel a satellite into orbit, was greeted with officially sanctioned displays of glee from reporters and citizens on state television. Martyn Williams, who runs the blog North Korea Tech, posted video of a state television anchor announcing the launching.

headline: Bill Seeks to Make Resale of Tickets for Benefit Concerts Illegal
text: As public outrage continues to simmer over scalpers’ profiting from the resale of tickets to the “12-12-12″ benefit concert for hurricane victims at Madison Square Garden, a state senator submitted a bill on Wednesday in Albany that would make it illegal to resell tickets to charitable events for more than their face value.

headline: City May Test Smartphone Apps in Hailing Yellow Taxis
text: With some board members still skeptical about authorizing smartphone apps to hail yellow cabs, the New York City Taxi and Limousine Commission’s chairman said Wednesday that the panel was instead likely to consider a pilot program to allow the products for a trial period.

headline: Another Portrait of Imminent Death, but One Worthy of Publishing
text: Last week, there was a Web’s worth of debate about the decision of The New York Post to publish a salaciously headlined photo of a man just before he was struck and killed by a subway train in New York.

headline: Shakespeare Theater Company in Washington Avoids Eviction
text: The Shakespeare Theater Company in Washington, which won this year’s Tony Award for best regional theater, won another victory on Tuesday – this time in court – and staved off the threat of eviction from its 7th Street home in the Lansburgh building.

headline: German Lawmakers Vote to Protect Right to Circumcision
text: BERLIN — German lawmakers on Wednesday passed legislation ensuring parents the right to have their boys circumcised, bringing a close to months of legal uncertainty set off by a regional court’s ruling that equated the practice with bodily harm.

headline: 10 Arrested in Theft of Web Data
text: International authorities, with some help from Facebook, have arrested 10 people accused of operating a network of infected computers that stole personal information from millions of victims.

headline: One is the Loneliest Number
text: In the latest issue of the New Republic, Judith Shulevitz offers a fascinating and fairly personal meditation on the consequences of delayed childbearing and older parenting for American society. At heart, the essay is about public health, and the ways in which older parenting — especially older male parenting, the latest research on sperm quality suggests — and fertility treatments seem to be associated with increasing risks of birth defects, genetic disorders, schizophrenia, and possibly autism as well. But there’s a long section on the social consequences of postponing parenting, which intertwines in interesting ways with some of the birthrate-related issues I’ve been writing about lately. Here’s an extended quote from Shulevitz on the world that delayed childbearing is making:

headline: Court Seizes Assets of Greek Oligarch
text: An Athens court on Wednesday ordered the seizure of assets belonging to Lavrentis Lavrentiadis, a Greek oligarch whom the authorities have charged with fraud and embezzlement, and 29 of his former associates, the latest legal maneuver in a case that has underscored concerns over corruption and crony capitalism in Greece.

headline: It's Game On for Super Bowl Ads
text: The Times’s Stuart Elliott talks about how Super Bowl advertisers, spurred by the marketing opportunities created by social media, are starting their campaigns earlier than ever before.

headline: The Best Tablets for Children
text: TimesCast Media+Tech: Super Bowl marketing gets an early start. | Warren Buckleitner reviews children’s tablets.

headline: TimesCast Media+Tech: The Best Tablets for Children
text: Super Bowl marketing gets an early start. Warren Buckleitner reviews children’s tablets.

headline: The Giving Spree | Stephen Burks
text: Who: The Readymade Projects designer Stephen Burks, who appeared with the poufs he made out of Manila rope and Dedar fabric trimmings in T’s Design and Living issue.

headline: A Filmmaker Comes to Terms With a Modern Medea
text: What is it about Belgian filmmakers and their fascination with children in peril? The Dardenne brothers have built an entire career out of sympathetic portrayals of them, most recently with “The Kid With a Bike,” and last year Michael Roskam won a nomination for the Academy Award for best foreign-language film for “Bullhead,” a portrait of a severely damaged little boy who grows into a fearsome beast of a man.

headline: Scene City: Celebs Pile Up at “Django Unchained”
text: Quentin Tarantino fetes his latest movie at a star-filled screening.

headline: When Wall Street Investors Favor Performance Over Ethics
text: To have one employee tied to insider trading may be regarded as a misfortune. But, with apologies to Oscar Wilde, to have six looks like carelessness.

headline: Father and Son Drive 423 Miles on One Charge in Tesla Model S
text: Last spring, Tesla Motors speculated in a blog post that “it could even be possible” to drive a Model S more than 400 miles on a single charge and offered an unspecified prize for the first person to do so. Last weekend, the challenge was met by a father-and-son team in Florida.

headline: Keeping Score: For Warriors, Defense Is the Difference
text: Economist Arthur Okun invented the misery index in the 1960s as a quick and dirty way to measure the economic climate for a given economy, with higher scores being associated with more “miserable” economies.

headline: Eric Schmidt: How We Outrace the Robots
text: At the DealBook conference today in Manhattan, I asked the executive chairman of Google, Eric Schmidt, where in the world the jobs for a great many people will be. His advice: We have to learn how to “outrace the robots.”

headline: European Officials Agree to Central Oversight of Banks
text: BRUSSELS — Finance ministers agreed early on Thursday to place banks in the euro area under a single supervisor, a step enabling European Union leaders to deliver a show of unity at their year-end summit that starts later in the day.

headline: Photo Replay: December 12
text: A view of the day in sports, including club soccer and a man-versus-horse race.

headline: Earlier Kickoff for Super Bowl Advertising Campaigns
text: Stuart Elliott, the advertising columnist of The New York Times, discusses with David Gillen, a deputy business editor, a recent change in thinking among Super Bowl advertisers. Once, the content of the ads was a closely guarded secret, often first shown during the game itself; this year, many companies are teasing what is in their ads, hoping to stoke interest on social media.

headline: Be Wary of Video Games’ Educational Promises
text: With electronic toys from Leap Pads to Wii U consoles topping many a holiday gift list, one way many parents justify the purchases, particularly with younger children, is to focus on their educational possibilities. Every platform offers games and apps that come with promises about everything from promoting social or spatial abilities to developing literacy.

headline: A Son Comes Out, Needing More Than His Family
text: Joseph Schwartz has sophisticated, loving parents. When they noticed their son’s aversion to sports and attraction to dolls, they didn’t assume Joseph was gay; they just knew he was different. When Joseph referred to Saladin, the well-dressed 12th-century Sultan of Egypt and Syria, as “the fabulous Muslim leader,” they simply embraced their son’s panache. When his father, John, discovered pictures of naked men in Joseph’s Internet history — well, at that point Joseph’s parents did assume he was gay. Still, John Schwartz and his wife, Jeanne Mixon, wisely waited for their son to come out on his own terms, which he eventually did, at the age of 12.

headline: In Brooklyn, Minus the Buzz
text: Here came the Patriots of Lafayette Educational Campus, crossing Benson Avenue in front of their school, on the way to another road game and traveling, as usual, with train fare, not fanfare.

headline: Fancy Pants
text: “IT’S feminine without being obvious,” said Phillip Lim, explaining why he is attracted to the notion of a woman in evening pants. Frocks may still be the go-to choice for holiday celebrations, but this season’s chic new party pants can hold their own, sleek eye-catchers in a room otherwise crowded with conventional cocktail dresses and trailing gowns. Irreverent but considered, these scene-stealers — cigarette-slim and shown in extravagant brocades, cool jacquards and slippery jewel-tone silk blends — seem destined to be the life of the party.

headline: For Knicks and Lakers, a Reunion and a Rivalry
text: The Knicks and the Los Angeles Lakers, trending in opposite directions, will cross paths for the first time this season Thursday night at Madison Square Garden. In what is usually a marquee game for the league, the Knicks will see a familiar face at the Garden in Lakers Coach Mike D’Antoni.

headline: Latino Groups Warn Congress to Fix Immigration, or Else
text: WASHINGTON — The nation’s largest Latino organizations warned Congress on Wednesday that they will keep a report card during the immigration debate next year, with plans to mobilize their voters against lawmakers who do not support a comprehensive immigration bill.

headline: Hunt for Midtown Killer Focuses on Queens After Getaway Car, a Rental, Is Found
text: The search for the gunman who carried out the brazen murder of a man in Midtown Manhattan has intensified in Queens, where investigators found the getaway car, Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly said Wednesday.

headline: This Tarantino Premiere Killed
text: AH, Christmas. Movies are rushed out this time of year, either as Oscar contenders or for the holiday box office.

headline: Rick Snyder on ‘Right to Work’
text: Michigan Gov. Rick Snyder explained on Morning Joe today that his state’s new “right to work” law is actually good for workers and unions; it makes unions stronger by requiring them to “present a good value proposition” to workers that will inspire them to join up.

headline: Caro on Johnson Tops Historians’ Poll, but Seward Book Is Close Behind
text: To perhaps no one’s surprise, “The Passage of Power,” the latest installment of Robert Caro’s acclaimed biography of Lyndon B. Johnson, has topped the History News Network’s online poll to choose the best history book of 2012.

headline: Warren Is Nominated for Senate Banking Committee
text: Elizabeth Warren, the Harvard professor who won a Senate seat in November, is officially on track to join the Senate Banking Committee, after the Democratic Steering Committee approved her assignment on Wednesday. The appointment is subject to approval by the full Democratic caucus and a resolution by the full Senate after it convenes in January.

headline: The New York Times Names a New Business Editor
text: Dean E. Murphy, a reporter and editor with The New York Times for the last 12 years, has been named the next editor of the business section of The Times. The announcement was made on Wednesday afternoon in a memo from Jill Abramson, the executive editor.

headline: Israeli Minister Vents Anger at Europe
text: JERUSALEM — Israel’s blunt-talking foreign minister, Avigdor Lieberman, gave vent on Wednesday to the government’s anger over recent diplomatic gains by the Palestinians paired with international rebukes for Israel, comparing Israel’s situation to that of Czechoslovakia in 1938 before the Nazi invasion.

headline: Christie Tells Barbara Walters He Isn’t Too Heavy to Be President
text: Gov. Chris Christie said it was “ridiculous” for people to question whether he was too heavy to be president of the United States during a television interview scheduled to be broadcast on Wednesday night.

headline: Ground Rules for a Shopper
text: Many things may be within your price range if you know how to scout for a deal. In the piece, Follow the Bargain Hounds, fashion insiders tell us how to search for a good bargain. Here are some of their tips:

headline: On 12-12-12, Songs in Reply to a Storm
text: Jon Pareles live blogged the 12-12-12 benefit concert for victims of Hurricane Sandy from Madison Square Garden. Read his complete review here. A slide show of images from the concert by Damon Winter is here.

headline: Follow the Bargain Hounds
text: IT takes a cool head and a keen fashion compass to navigate the winter sales. But Tammy Eckenswiller, a style executive for an Internet fashion retailer, has scoped that terrain long enough to know that patience pays. Even now, weeks deep into the discount season, she has unearthed deals, among them a handful of items she sighted when they first bowed on the runways last spring.

headline: In a Farewell Speech, Lieberman Reflects on His Political Journey
text: WASHINGTON — For nearly a quarter-century, Senator Joseph I. Lieberman has been an unmistakable presence in a legislative body filled with colorful personalities and large egos.

headline: 2012 Hack Day Coverage
text: Here’s a quick roundup of articles and tweets about the TimesOpen Hack Day we held this past weekend:

headline: Wheelies: The Here, There, Everywhere Edition
text: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

headline: Google’s Coolest Project? Broadband
text: According to Eric Schmidt, Google‘s executive chairman, the most interesting project going on at the search giant is its high-speed broadband trials in Kansas City. (Missouri and Kansas versions)

headline: A Quirky Little Bookshop in Cyberspace
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: Guilty Plea for One of Julian Robertson’s ‘Tiger Cub’ Funds
text: Bill Hwang was once a star at Tiger Management, the gilded hedge fund empire run by the billionaire investor Julian Robertson.

headline: Characters Who Take Up More Than Their Share of Room in the Family
text: Diabetic and more than 300 pounds, Edie Middlestein, the feisty matriarch in Jami Attenberg’s new novel, “The Middlesteins,” is facing surgery and a family in disarray. At 600 pounds, Charlie, the housebound writing teacher in Samuel D. Hunter’s play “The Whale” (at Playwrights Horizons through Saturday) has congestive heart failure and a daughter he hasn’t seen in years. We asked Ms. Attenberg and Mr. Hunter to take in each other’s works and discuss what led them, coincidentally, to characters who are literally larger than life. These are excerpts from their e-mail exchange.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Syria and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Syria, Egypt, Greece and North Korea.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Foxconn’s Robot Troubles, and Google’s Broadband
text: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. See more here.

headline: No Celebrity-Filled Concert on the Mall for Obama’s 2nd Inaugural
text: There will be no big star-studded concert on the National Mall to celebrate President Obama’s second inauguration next month, several of his inaugural planners said Wednesday.

headline: A Story of AIDS, From the Beginning
text: LAST Wednesday night, David France, the director of the documentary “How to Survive a Plague,” made his way to the Open Society Institute in Columbus Circle for a question-and-answer session and a screening of his film, which is about the early years of the AIDS epidemic. Afterward, he was mobbed by well-wishers and advice-seekers.

headline: L’Wren Scott, The Sweet Smell
text: The fashion designer and romantic partner of Mick Jagger has introduced a fragrance.

headline: L’Wren Scott: Fashion, Mick Jagger and Now a Fragrance
text: BEFORE she was a fashion designer whose clothes can be found in the closets of Nicole Kidman and Michelle Obama, and before she was famous for a decade-plus romance with Mick Jagger, L’Wren Scott was one of the most successful stylists working in Los Angeles. One of her assignments, in the early 1990s, was an advertising campaign for Elizabeth Taylor’s White Diamonds, which would become the best-selling celebrity fragrance in the world.

headline: Suspect in Patz Murder Pleads Not Guilty
text: The man indicted in the killing of Etan Patz in 1979 loudly pleaded “not guilty” Wednesday to murdering the 6-year-old boy.

headline: Russell Libby, Organic Farming Advocate, Dies at 56
text: Russell Libby, one of the nation’s leading advocates for organic farming, died on Sunday at his farm in Mount Vernon, Me. He was 56.

headline: To Extend a Device’s Battery Life, Get to Know It Better
text: As you jet off on a winter vacation or a holiday season trip to see family, chances are you’ll face a 21st-century problem: mobile device battery angst. It’s a never-ending itch at the back of your thoughts. Though we all love to use our smartphones to stave off boredom, or to navigate a new city, every moment of use eats precious battery time. And, particularly during a journey, you never know when you will find power next.

headline: Steps, Back and Forth, Into a New Comfort Zone
text: For the collaboration “Cross Bridge” the choreographer Molissa Fenley and her colleagues ventured outside their comfort zones in approaching one another. Dancers spoke. An actress danced. But the work, which had its debut last weekend at the Club at La MaMa, began and ended with proven strengths.

headline: Kevin Arpino Plays to a Silent Audience
text: TALL and tan with a wrist full of jangly silver bracelets, Kevin Arpino shouted into his cellphone in a room full of fashion models.

headline: Spirituality Follows Its Cycles to ‘Grace’
text: When Robert Battle became artistic director of Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater last year, he gave up a dance company named after himself and his works, and his principal job changed from making his own art to tending a repertory filled with the creations of others. Finding the right place for his choreography in his new home loomed as a challenge.

headline: Woman Declares Louis Armstrong Was Her Father
text: On Saturday a batch of letters that Louis Armstrong wrote to a girlfriend will go on sale at an auction house in Los Angeles. That in itself is not surprising: Armstrong wrote thousands of letters in his lifetime, and he was known to be a lothario.

headline: Senator Demands F.A.A. Relax Electronics Rules
text: The Federal Aviation Administration could be on the receiving end of legislation if it does not change its stance on the use of electronics during takeoff and landing.

headline: Scouting Report
text: POP-UPS

headline: Q Train, 11:05 A.M.
text: N.Y. See: A honeymoon begins on the Q train.

headline: Tooker Alley
text: IN an unmistakable sign that Prospect Heights has arrived on the Brooklyn scene, the neighborhood now claims not one, but at least two artisanal cocktail bars. The latest even has a retro-sounding name, Tooker Alley, which, it turns out, is named after the Chicago street that led to the Dil Pickle Club, a famed freethinker’s hangout.

headline: News Roundup: In Afghanistan, Reporting on Progress and Recalling the Soviet Invasion
text: Defense Secretary Leon E. Panetta made an unannounced visit to Afghanistan on Wednesday to push forward proposals for future troop levels, Thom Shanker reports.

headline: Young Venezuelans Exude Confidence to Go With Their Passion
text: It is typical for orchestras of well-trained young musicians to convey exuberance. The players of the Simón Bolívar Symphony Orchestra of Venezuela, under their charismatic music director Gustavo Dudamel, were afire with exuberance during two sold-out programs at Carnegie Hall on Monday and Tuesday nights.

headline: Energy Dept. to Underwrite 7 Wind Projects
text: The federal government is stepping up its efforts to kick-start the offshore wind industry by awarding $28 million in grants to seven projects that are developing varying kinds of power-generation technology.

headline: The Moods of Messiaen, Interpreted in 20 Ways
text: Messiaen would surely have been delighted at the setting for a concert featuring his “Vingt Regards sur l’Enfant-Jésus.” The piano was placed next to the crèche under the huge Christmas tree in the Medieval Sculpture Hall of the Metropolitan Museum of Art. En route to the space guests passed through a room featuring ornate Christian paintings and iconography.

headline: SolarCity Slashes I.P.O. Share Price
text: SolarCity, which installs solar panels for homeowners, has priced its initial public offering at $8 a share, well below its earlier estimates, a person briefed on the matter said on Wednesday.

headline: Holiday Reading, Some Homework Required
text: “BurdaStyle Sewing Vintage Modern: Mastering Iconic Looks from the 1920s to 1980s,” by Nora Abousteit with Jamie Lau. Potter Craft. 216 pp. $29.99

headline: George Bailey Touches a Few More Lives
text: The Irish Repertory Theater’s “It’s a Wonderful Life: The 1946 Live Radio Play” can’t help frustrating fans of Frank Capra’s 1946 holiday perennial about a small-town family man contemplating suicide who learns how worthwhile his life has been. After all, the conceit of the play — which condenses more than two hours into 70 brisk minutes, with 25 characters inhabited by 6 actors (and one sound-effects man) — requires the excision of treasured passages. But this feather-light show is a small triumph anyway.

headline: The Fed vs. the Fiscal Cuts: Not a Fair Fight
text: Since the financial crisis began, the Federal Reserve has taken the lead on stimulating the economy. It starting easing long before the Recovery Act was even a twinkle in Congress’s eye, and it has continued its stimulus efforts in the last couple of years to counteract fiscal tightening while the Recovery Act was petering out. As Mervyn A. King, the governor of the Bank of England, explained this week, central banks around the world have pursued monetary easing to offset fiscal tightening.

headline: A Crowded Red Carpet for Women After Oscar
text: Keira Knightley was in the unlovely upper lobby of a Chelsea movie theater, chewing gum, waiting to discuss “Anna Karenina.” She was on a tight schedule promoting her star turn in the director Joe Wright’s film adaptation of that Tolstoy novel, and there was little time to waste. Spoiler: We started with the death.

headline: Flickr Has the Opportunity to Become the Next Flickr
text: It’s quite amazing to think that Flickr, once one of the best photocentric social sites, was purchased by Yahoo in 2005 for, wait for this, around $30 million. (No, that’s not a typo, people used to buy start-ups for million of dollars, not billions.)

headline: A Trove of Tablets for Young Hands
text: Parents take note. For approximately the price of a child’s bicycle — about $200 — you can purchase what may be the 21st-century equivalent: a tablet computer.

headline: Gold Cup Semifinals and Final in England
text: The premier event on the British bridge calendar is the Gold Cup. The semifinals and final, played at the West Midlands Bridge Club in Solihull, England, last weekend, featured two close matches.

headline: Perchance to Make You Look Rested
text: BAGS. Puffiness. Dark shadows. Circles.

headline: Consignment Shopping, With Confidence, on the Web
text: RUMMAGE through your closet. Amass your no-longer-desirable designer clothes. Carry them to a consignment store or upload jpegs to eBay and wait for someone to deem your castoffs worthy of purchase. Or if you are on the buying end: pray the designer pieces you bought online are genuine.

headline: During the Regency’s Renovations, the Power Breakfast Takes a Pause
text: When the next history book about New York City is written, the chapter on people and power will almost certainly require a section covering something that began in 1975 and ended on Wednesday: The modern Manhattan power breakfast.

headline: At Interfaith Luncheon, an Appeal for a Miracle
text: Hanukkah is the Jewish holiday of miracles, commemorating how one day’s worth of oil left in a Jerusalem candelabra more than 2,000 years ago somehow lasted for eight days. Imam Souleimane Konate, the head of Masjid Aqsa, a mosque in Harlem, is hoping that bodes well for his cause.

headline: Trying on a Look? You Can Ask an App for Help
text: CAN an iPhone make you more beautiful?

headline: Antiwar ‘Grannies’ Briefly Make Toys ‘R’ Us Store Their Battlefield
text: Clamors for peace inside the mammoth Toys “R” Us emporium in Times Square might not be unusual coming from parents and directed at their toddlers demanding yet another Barbie doll or another ride on the store’s Ferris wheel.

headline: Art Meets Design
text: Limited-edition furniture at Design Miami.

headline: After the Boom, a Better Kind of Art
text: MIAMI BEACH

headline: The Newfangled Corkscrew: It Comes With a Twist
text: THE holiday season is traditionally a time of joy, but not for the home bartender or the fancier of fine wines. For them, and almost anyone else who entertains at home, it’s a festival of unwanted gifts, of gizmos and gadgets whose pointless ingenuity makes “thank you” the most difficult phrase to pronounce in the English language.

headline: Living Large in 400 Square Feet
text: Drawing on his skills as a carpenter and an artist, Mike Fontana employed all sorts of perspective tricks so that his tiny apartment feels a lot larger than its actual dimensions.

headline: The Prince of St. Marks Place
text: MIKE FONTANA is proof that you can live large, in inverse proportion to the square footage of your environment, and that the heart can take wing in the tiniest of spaces.

headline: Getting the Walls Out of the Way
text: Reconfiguring an Upper West Side apartment to let in the light.

headline: Where There’s a Wall, There’s a Way
text: MAKING a home in Manhattan can be daunting, and co-op prices are a horror story unto themselves. The $1.5 million that Dr. Noga Harizman, 43, and her husband, Zwika Pres, 44, had budgeted for an apartment for themselves and their three children would have gotten them a lovely home in short order almost anywhere else in the country. But in New York, it took Dr. Harizman, an eye specialist, and Mr. Pres, who recently started a chain of organic Mediterranean restaurants called Nanoosh, two years to find a home.

headline: Cuomo Puts Campaign Finance on 2013 Agenda
text: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo said on Tuesday that he would seek legislation to significantly expand New York’s regulation of political spending by corporations, individuals and tax-exempt groups during his third year in office.

headline: Shopping for Men’s Wear-Inspired Furnishings
text: Scott Sanders, an interior designer in Manhattan, shops for men’s-wear-inspired fabric, which lends a “wonderful, warm feeling” to the home.

headline: Men’s Wear-Inspired Furnishings
text: PLAID, flannel, tweed, herringbone, Fair Isle: almost any men’s-wear-inspired fabric can make a home feel more welcoming, said Scott Sanders, an interior designer in Manhattan.

headline: Market Ready
text: Q. Our dining room is painted dark gray, but I’ve read that light neutral colors are better when you’re selling your home. Should we repaint it?

headline: An Artist’s Obscure Object of Desire
text: If you’d like to spice up your cultural life, you might want to visit the “KAMA, Sex and Design” show, which opened this month at the Triennale Design Museum in Milan. There are some 300 exhibits, from historic to contemporary, including “Unknown Shell,” an installation by Nacho Carbonell, a 32-year-old Spanish-born artist in the Netherlands, who does free-form fantasy furnishings and whose work has been collected by celebrities like Brad Pitt.

headline: Seating That Demands Your Best Behavior
text: Scott Newkirk started his design career in the visual display department at Barneys three decades ago. He went on to a career as a fashion stylist, with a few years spent as the proprietor of a now-defunct shop called Kudzu in Sullivan County. Now he’s a furniture designer. Last month, he introduced the Newkirk collection, which consists of a bench, a desk and two versions of an oversize chair, all made of solid oak and inspired by the church seating of his Mississippi youth. He said his daybed design is like a modernist pew, while his oversize, seemingly Donald Judd-inspired chairs (called Sculpted Seating No. 1 and No. 2) were conceived as mismatched twin sofas. “The black one wraps around you and is mysterious and sensual, while the white one is soothing in a different way. Sitting in the white one seems to clear your mind.” Prices from $7,500 to $15,000. Information: newkirkny.com.

headline: A Work of Art Where You Can Rest in Peace
text: The Seattle-based architect Tom Kundig designs houses that fit serenely into the landscape, often with generous quantities of concrete and steel and splashes of mechanical wizardry (roofs and wall-size shutters may crank open with a hand-turned wheel). Recently, Greg Lundgren, an artist and impresario who founded Lundgren Monuments, a Seattle company that produces memorials, approached Mr. Kundig to design a funerary urn as handsome as those homes.

headline: ‘The Collier Campbell Archive: 50 Years of Passion in Pattern’
text: For half a century, Sarah Campbell and her older sister, Susan Collier, created textile patterns that found their way onto wallpaper, bedding, furnishings, clothing, even the carpets in Gatwick Airport. The British design team’s colorful body of work has been collected in “The Collier Campbell Archive: 50 Years of Passion in Pattern” ($75; Ilex), a brick of a book that contains seemingly everything they ever produced.

headline: Storage That Mimics the Skyline
text: It felt like a million-to-one-shot, but Victor Vasilev tried anyway. Mr. Vasilev, the Milan-based architect, sent the design of a shelf he wanted to produce to the Italian company Boffi — via a general e-mail address listed on the Web site. “It’s like sending a drawing to Chanel and expecting them to call back,” he said. “But they called me after two hours.”

headline: Sales at Coral & Tusk, Judy Ross and Others
text: On Saturday, from 10 a.m. to 8 p.m., Coral & Tusk will discount many items up to 40 percent, with free gift wrapping (the Owl portrait pillow, regularly $74, will be about $67); 109 South Fifth Street (Berry Street), Room 401, Brooklyn, (718) 388-4188, coralandtusk.com.

headline: Colleen Walker, Nine-Time Winner on L.P.G.A. Tour, Dies at 56
text: Colleen Walker, a nine-time winner on the L.P.G.A. Tour who captured the 1997 du Maurier Classic 10 months after giving birth, died Tuesday in Valrico, Fla. She was 56.

headline: Of Many Woes, One Man’s Illness Threatens Venezuela’s Revolution
text: CARACAS, Venezuela — The bottlenecks at a major port were so bad this year that Christmas trees from Canada were delayed for weeks, and when they did show up they cost hundreds of dollars. A government-run ice cream factory opened with great fanfare, only to shut down a day later because of a shortage of basic ingredients. Foreign currency is so hard to come by that automakers cannot get parts and new cars are almost impossible to buy.

headline: Internet Use in Adoptions Cuts 2 Ways, Report Says
text: WASHINGTON — The Internet has fundamentally changed the adoption process. It has allowed adoptees and their birth parents to reunite, and adopting parents can find a range of support from families around the world struggling with similar problems.

headline: In a Victory for Regulators, Judge Dismisses a Mutual Fund Lawsuit
text: Wall Street suffered a rare courtroom loss on Wednesday after a federal judge sided with regulators who wanted to keep a closer eye on freewheeling derivatives trading.

headline: Examining the Support for Same-Sex Marriage
text: Updated | 11:15 a.m.

headline: Selective Editing by Fox News Contributor Revealed by Fox News
text: Last Updated, Friday, 12:51 a.m. As my colleague Jennifer Preston reported, there were scuffles between union activists and supporters of Michigan’s Republican-dominated Legislature outside the state Capitol in Lansing on Tuesday, as the lawmakers approved sweeping changes to the way unions will be financed.

headline: In Response to Criticism, Officials to Remove Quote From Memorial to King
text: WASHINGTON — An inscription on the memorial honoring the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. that set off a controversy will be removed.

headline: Joe Allbritton, TV and Banking Titan, Dies at 87
text: Joe L. Allbritton, a Texas financier who at age 50 became a television and newspaper baron in Washington, then climbed the city’s social hierarchy as he transformed himself into the foremost banker to Embassy Row, died on Wednesday in Houston. He was 87.

headline: Study Shows a Pattern of Risky Loans by F.H.A.
text: A new and extensive analysis of 2.4 million loans insured by the Federal Housing Administration in recent years shows a pattern of risky lending that could generate $20 billion in losses and harm thousands of the nation’s most vulnerable borrowers. By ignoring risks in loans it insured in 2009 and 2010, the study concludes, the F.H.A. is imperiling both borrowers and taxpayers who stand behind the agency.

headline: Census Officials, Citing Increasing Diversity, Say U.S. Will Be a ‘Plurality Nation’
text: The term “minority,” at least as used to describe racial and ethnic groups in the United States, may need to be retired or rethought soon: by the end of this decade, according to Census Bureau projections released Wednesday, no single racial or ethnic group will constitute a majority of children under 18. And in about three decades, no single group will constitute a majority of the country as a whole.

headline: Investors Stay Calm, if Cautious, as Stalemate Simmers
text: Washington wonders what will happen. Wall Street thinks it already knows.

headline: California: Governor Being Treated for Prostate Cancer
text: Gov. Jerry Brown of California is undergoing treatment for localized prostate cancer caught in its early stages, his office announced on Wednesday. Dr. Eric Small, Mr. Brown’s oncologist, said that the cancer would be treated with a short course of conventional radiotherapy. “The prognosis is excellent, and there are not expected to be any significant side effects,” he said in a statement released by Mr. Brown’s office. The treatment is expected to be completed by the first week of next year, the statement said. Mr. Brown’s office said the governor, who is 74, would continue to work a full schedule.

headline: D’Antoni Still Struggling to Find the Right Fit
text: When the time came at last to pack up his practice-day polo shirts and his seven-seconds-or-less playbook, Mike D’Antoni moved as far from Madison Square Garden as he could get — not really so much by design but by happenstance. When the Lakers call, there is only one right answer.

headline: Millions in Ransoms Fuel Militants’ Clout in West Africa
text: BAMAKO, Mali — Oumar Ould Hamaha, a notorious Islamist commander in the deserts of western Africa, has nothing but disdain for the international powers he opposes or the hapless Westerners he and other militants subject to extreme deprivation, hunger, thirst and proselytizing for months on end.

headline: Massachusetts: Mistrial in Treasurer’s Corruption Case
text: The corruption trial of a former Massachusetts treasurer, Timothy P. Cahill, ended in a mistrial on Wednesday, after the jury announced a deadlock. In April, the state’s attorney general, Martha Coakley, charged Mr. Cahill with public corruption, fraud and conspiracy. Ms. Coakley alleged that Mr. Cahill ran TV and radio advertisements in support of the state lottery, which, as the state treasurer, he oversaw, to bolster his independent run for governor in 2010. The jury acquitted his co-defendant, Scott Campbell, on Tuesday.

headline: A Vital Disability Benefit for Children
Hints at Steeper Road to Victory for Perceived Front-Runner in Mayor’s Race
text: No one ever said being a front-runner would be easy.

headline: Sanctions on Eritrea
text: To the Editor:

headline: Voters and Web Privacy
text: To the Editor:

headline: Things I Saw — No. 47
text: Suggestions for what you’d like Jason to see and draw may be sent to thingsisaw@nytimes.com.

headline: Hailing a Yellow Cab With an App
text: The New York City Taxi and Limousine Commission will vote Thursday on new rules that would allow e-hailing and smartphone payment for yellow taxi rides. The changes would be a groundbreaking improvement for the city’s taxi industry, putting it in line with London, Chicago, Toronto and other world cities. The entrenched interests of the livery and black car business, however, could end up thwarting this progress.

headline: Solar Panels for Every Home
text: WE don’t think much about pitch pine poles until storms like Hurricane Sandy litter our landscape with their splintered corpses and arcing power lines. Crews from as far away as California and Quebec have worked feverishly to repair or replace those poles as utility companies rebuild their distribution systems the way they were before.

headline: Standing and Delivering
text: Is it heretical of me, or merely quirky, to find myself nearly as fascinated by the procedural game the Supreme Court is playing in the same-sex marriage cases as I am by the underlying merits of the two appeals the court has agreed to decide?

headline: Tagliabue’s Ruling Offers Criticism, and Closure
text: By Wednesday morning, Roger Goodell was in Dallas for an owners meeting, examining the latest technology on hip and thigh pads, a timely reminder that the issue of player safety hangs over almost every major decision the N.F.L. makes about its on-field product.

headline: To Tell Its Story, Red Cross Goes to Those It Helped
text: THE American Red Cross has commissioned a new public service advertising campaign to raise money in the holiday season by showing how the organization helps people facing problems other than major disasters like Hurricane Sandy.

headline: Top State Dept. Lawyer Is Leaving
text: Harold Koh, the top lawyer in the State Department, will step down early next year and return to teaching at Yale Law School, a department official said on Wednesday. His impending departure is part of a major overhaul in the Obama administration’s national security legal policy team, including the announcement last week that the Pentagon general counsel, Jeh C. Johnson, is resigning.

headline: Tibet Is Burning
text: Beijing

headline: Canada Reviews Plans to Buy F-35 Fighter Jets
text: Canada said Wednesday that it would reconsider plans to buy 65 F-35 fighter jets after an independent audit found that the sophisticated stealth planes would cost substantially more than the government had promised.

headline: The Meaning of Minority
text: America’s white majority just bought itself another year.

headline: Nursing Homes Told to Reinstate Workers
text: A federal judge in Hartford has ordered a Connecticut nursing home chain to reinstate nearly 600 workers who have been on strike since July 3, and to rescind the pension and health care cuts it had imposed.

headline: Fishmonger Charged in Bleach Attack on a Rabbi
text: A Brooklyn fishmonger was charged by the police on Wednesday with throwing bleach in the face of a rabbi who is an outspoken advocate for victims of sexual abuse in the borough’s ultra-Orthodox Jewish community.

headline: Another Boom Year
text: It appears that a lot of people believe the world will come to an end next Friday, possibly during a zombie apocalypse.

headline: Fascination With a New Yankee’s Jewish Roots
text: It has been a game of sorts over the years — marveling when ballplayers turn out to be Jewish and straining to expand the parameters of the religion so that as many players as possible can be included.

headline: Tax Increases Across the Board
text: Taxpayers at all levels would be affected by scheduled tax increases if lawmakers fail to come to an agreement.

headline: Members of Assad’s Sect Blamed in Syria Killings
text: Scores of Syrian civilians belonging to President Bashar al-Assad’s minority Alawite sect were killed Tuesday in the first known Alawite massacre since the Syrian conflict began. But the killings, in the village of Aqrab, happened under circumstances that remain unclear.

headline: Lawmakers Chastise Union for Not Moving Forward on H.G.H. Testing
text: WASHINGTON — A bipartisan group of lawmakers vented its frustration on Wednesday at the N.F.L. players union for not yet agreeing to put into effect a test for human growth hormone nearly two seasons after promising to do so.

headline: A Brooklyn Protester Pleads Guilty After His Twitter Posts Sink His Case
text: In the end, the tweets told the tale.

headline: Charity Begins at Home
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Five-Month Season Boils Down to One
text: In recent weeks, as another college football regular season concluded in dramatic fashion and universities once again began to switch conference affiliations, the college basketball season started. The general sports fan could be forgiven for not noticing.

headline: Fighting Corruption, One Handyman at a Time
text: MOSCOW — Not since Joe the Plumber have contractors taken on such political overtones.

headline: ‘Daily Show’ Is Policy Forum for Newark’s Mayor
text: While many mayors suffer in relatively anonymity, there is a good chance that you have heard of Cory A. Booker of Newark. If you, say, turn on a television, or are on Twitter, you have probably heard that he spent the last week eating burned sweet potatoes while on his food-stamps diet, that he pulled a woman from a burning building, that during snowstorms he shovels out perhaps every snowbound car in his beleaguered New Jersey city.

headline: Global Internet Diplomacy
text: Representatives of 193 countries are meeting in Dubai to update a treaty known as the International Telecommunication Regulations that was last negotiated in 1988 and governs the exchange of telephone traffic between countries.

headline: North Korea’s Latest Provocation
text: Even though it cannot feed its people, North Korea has joined the ranks of countries with the money and expertise to build and launch a long-range rocket and put a satellite into space.

headline: Denied Insurance, Then Facing a Spiral of Depression
text: After working for more than a decade as a home health aide, Tolentino Gonzalez faced a derailment in his livelihood and self-worth last May.

headline: Judges Needed for Federal Courts
text: There has been a severe breakdown in the process for appointing federal judges. At the start of the Reagan years, it took, on average, a month for candidates for appellate and trial courts to go from nomination to confirmation. In the first Obama term, it has taken, on average, more than seven months.

headline: It’s a Smart, Smart, Smart World
text: Before I get to the dreary budget debates in Washington, here’s a bright spot of good news: We’re getting smarter.

headline: Kim Jong-un Earns Cachet With Rocket’s Success
text: SEOUL, South Korea — For North Korea’s inexperienced young leader, Kim Jong-un, the largely successful launching on Wednesday of a long-range rocket could not have come too soon.

headline: For New York Fans Accustomed to Letdowns, a New Reason to Kvell
text: Thomas Hobbes was born long before Major League Baseball, but when he wrote that life during anarchy was “solitary, poor, nasty, brutish and short,” he could have been talking about the Jews who have played professional baseball in New York.

headline: It’s Hard to Get a Reaction
text: THURSDAY’S PUZZLE — If you are not a diehard solver, this one might need some explaining. It’s not hard to get, but it might be hard to see at first.

headline: Wrapped Up in the Comfort of Defeat
text: The sad souls in Melissa James Gibson’s new play, “What Rhymes With America,” wear their dissatisfaction in different styles. For the divorced dad trying to strengthen his bond with his teenage daughter, it’s like a drab overcoat he cannot manage to shrug off. For the 40-something virgin whose father has just died, shrouding herself in singlehood has almost become a comfort, like a big puffy coat. The would-be actress stuck working as an extra in an opera puts on a braver front: wielding her anger as a Valkyrie does her armor.

headline: The Human Cost of Cheap Clothing
text: Where does the responsibility lie when it comes to improving safety standards in factories that produce affordable clothing, and what can be done about it?

headline: Corrections: December 13, 2012
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Socialists Denounce Gérard Depardieu for Leaving France
text: PARIS — Gérard Depardieu, one of France’s best-known actors, has been accused by the country’s Socialist government of lacking patriotism after he moved to Belgium apparently in a bid to avoid the taxes for which France is also renowned.

headline: Far From the Cheers
text: At the lower end of the basketball food chain in Brooklyn, high school players like the Lafayette Pirates often play road games where attendance is limited because of security reasons.

headline: Income Malaise of Middle Class Complicates Democrats’ Stance in Talks
text: WASHINGTON — The income stagnation that has hit the middle class in the last decade is complicating the Democrats’ position in the fiscal talks, making it more difficult for them to advocate across-the-board tax increases if a deal falls through.

headline: Another Editor Steps Down in Phone Hacking Scandal
text: News Corporation’s British newspaper unit, embroiled in the aftermath of a phone hacking scandal, lost another high-ranking executive on Wednesday when the editor of The Times of London announced he would step down.

headline: Text of the Federal Reserve’s Policy Statement
text: Below is the statement the Federal Reserve released Wednesday after the central bank’s two-day policy meeting:

headline: Boehner Tries to Contain Defections on Fiscal Unity
text: WASHINGTON — Speaker John A. Boehner moved Wednesday to maintain Republican unity on deficit reduction talks as lawmakers on the far right openly chafed at his leadership and some pragmatists pressed for quick accommodation on tax rate increases on the rich.

headline: Giants Seek a More Grounded Celebration
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — The list of freakish sports injuries sustained by athletes over the years can be both amusing and horrifying. Simple tasks can turn painful (pitcher Adam Eaton stabbed himself with a paring knife while trying to open a plastic-wrapped DVD case). Seemingly safe activities, like playing Guitar Hero, can have serious ramifications (pitcher Joel Zumaya injured his elbow while playing the game in 2006).

headline: Hal Schaefer, Jazz Pianist and Marilyn Monroe Friend, Dies at 87
text: On Nov. 5, 1954, not long after Marilyn Monroe filed for divorce from Joe DiMaggio, DiMaggio was having dinner with Frank Sinatra when he heard, probably from a private investigator, that if he went to a certain apartment house on Waring Avenue in West Hollywood, he’d find her in the arms of another man.

headline: Drink Ingredient Gets a Look
text: Sarah Kavanagh and her little brother were looking forward to the bottles of Gatorade they had put in the refrigerator after playing outdoors one hot, humid afternoon last month in Hattiesburg, Miss.

headline: Nets End Losing Skid, but It’s Not Easy
text: A 12-day run of disappointment and exasperation finally ended for the Nets on Wednesday night, but not without another few moments of needless anxiety.

headline: Failings Found in Trial of Ukrainian Ex-Premier
text: MOSCOW — In a report commissioned by the government of Ukraine, a team of American lawyers has concluded that important legal rights of the jailed former prime minister, Yulia V. Tymoshenko, were violated during her trial last year on charges of abusing her official power, and that she was wrongly imprisoned even before her conviction and sentencing.

headline: British Premier Apologizes in Killing of I.R.A. Lawyer
text: LONDON — Nearly a quarter of a century after one of the most brazen killings in Northern Ireland’s decades of sectarian violence, Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain said Wednesday that there had been “a shocking level of state collusion” and offered an apology to the family of the slain man.

headline: Russian Documentary Series Halted After Director’s Home Raided
text: The creators of a documentary film series on Russia’s opposition leaders announced Wednesday that they would halt the project after the police raided the home of the film’s director. The films, collectively known as “The Term,” are regularly posted online and trace Russia’s protest movement, beginning with Vladimir V. Putin’s return to the presidency in May. A note on the latest episode said that investigators’ pressure on the director had violated “the main principle of a documentary of high quality: the author should not be a participant of the events.”

headline: South Africa: Mandela Responding to Treatment for Lung Infection
text: Nelson Mandela, South Africa’s ailing former president, was responding to treatment for a lung infection, government officials said Wednesday as he prepared to spend a fifth night in a Pretoria hospital. “Doctors attending to former President Mandela have reported that he has made progress during the past 24 hours, and they are satisfied with the way he is responding to treatment,” President Jacob Zuma said in a statement.

headline: Portrayal of C.I.A. Torture in Bin Laden Film Reopens a Debate
text: WASHINGTON — Even before its official release, “Zero Dark Thirty,” the new movie about the hunt for Osama bin Laden, has become a national Rorschach test on the divisive subject of torture.

headline: Berlusconi Says Return Hinges on Incumbent
text: ROME — Will he or won’t he? Just days after he startled financial markets by saying he would run for office, former Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi said Wednesday that he would consider withdrawing if Prime Minister Mario Monti ran as the leader of a center-right coalition. But Mr. Monti has given no indication that he plans to take Mr. Berlusconi up on his offer.

headline: 2 Bills Before City Council Would Limit Deportations
text: Two bills that members of the New York City Council plan to propose on Thursday would place further limits on the city’s cooperation with federal authorities seeking to detain and deport immigrants.

headline: N.Y.U. Head Faces Prelude to a No-Confidence Vote
text: Professors at New York University’s largest school are planning to meet Thursday to contemplate a bold undertaking: holding a no-confidence vote about the university’s president, John Sexton.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Filmmakers Halt Work on Russian Opposition Documentaries After Raid
text: MOSCOW — The creators of a documentary film series on Russia’s opposition leaders announced Wednesday that they would halt the project after police investigators raided the home of the film’s director.

headline: N. Joseph Woodland, Inventor of the Bar Code, Dies at 91
text: It was born on a beach six decades ago, the product of a pressing need, an intellectual spark and the sweep of a young man’s fingers through the sand.

headline: While Apple Regroups, Google Offers a Maps App
text: The return of a Google-powered maps application to the iPhone may make it easier for Apple’s customers to find their way. But it will not relieve Apple of the pressure to bring its own maps service up to snuff.

headline: Maps App for iPhone Steers Right
text: It was one of the biggest tech headlines of the year: in September, Apple dropped its contract with Google, which had always supplied the data for the iPhone’s Maps app. For various strategic reasons, Apple preferred to write a new app, based on a new database of the world that Apple intended to assemble itself.

headline: 60 Seconds With Pogue: Google’s Map App
text: David Pogue reviews Google’s newly released map app for the iPhone.

headline: A Halfway House Built on Exaggerated Claims
text: Seeking an operator for a major halfway house in Brooklyn, the federal government awarded a $29 million contract to a nonprofit group with a promising name, Community First Services, and impressive credentials.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, Dec. 13, 2012
text: Lots of Western countries are paying enormous sums to the jihadists. The source of our financing is the Western countries. They are paying for jihad.

headline: Prison Term in Guns Case Tied to Agent’s Killing
text: PHOENIX — A man who bought two weapons found at the scene of a Border Patrol agent’s killing and subsequently linked to the botched gun-trafficking investigation known as Operation Fast and Furious was sentenced here on Wednesday to 57 months in federal prison, closing another chapter in a case that ignited a political firestorm.

headline: An All-Star Concert in Reply to a Storm
text: There were the Rolling Stones. There were Bruce Springsteen, Billy Joel and Bon Jovi. There were the Who and Eric Clapton. The two surviving members of Nirvana reunited to sing with Paul McCartney. And there, too, amid all the aging rockers, were Kanye West and Alicia Keys.

headline: Illinois: Online Gun Site Is Sued
text: The Brady Center to Prevent Gun Violence filed a wrongful-death lawsuit against a firearm classifieds Web site on Wednesday, apparently the first time legal action was taken against online gun sales. The lawsuit, in Chicago against Armslist.com, contends that the Web site facilitated the illegal purchase of a handgun used to kill Jitka Vesel in Illinois last year. “It should be harder to buy a semiautomatic handgun than a used sofa on Craigslist,” said Jonathan E. Lowy, director of the legal action project at the Brady Center. Richard A. Pearson, executive director of the Illinois State Rifle Association, called the lawsuit “ridiculous” because the site requires users to agree not to use its listings for unlawful purposes.

headline: Concert to Benefit Sandy Victims
text: Musicians performed at the 12-12-12 benefit concert for victims of Hurricane Sandy at Madison Square Garden in New York City.

headline: Life, Interrupted: My Mother’s Cooking
text: For many of us, the holiday season triggers memories of food and family. That’s certainly the case for me. I can always tell when my mother, an artist who grew up in Switzerland, starts to feel nostalgic for home. It is the smell of the crispy apple tarts, the ginger cookies, and the creamy muesli full of nuts and fresh berries. The scent alone delivers a rush of childhood memories for me.

headline: Test Yourself | English, Dec. 13, 2012
text: The question was written by Shannon Doyne. It comes from the article “A Hunger for Tales of Life in the American Cul-de-Sac.”

headline: Word of the Day | sensual
text: sensual •\ˈsen(t)-sh(ə-)wəl, -shəl\• adjective

headline: U.N. Nuclear Weapons Inspectors Visit Iran
text: Nuclear inspectors visited Iran for their first meeting since August, but they appeared to be no closer to resolving a dispute over their repeated requests to examine Parchin, a military site that the inspectors suspect was used for atomic weapons trigger tests. The head of the inspector delegation, Herman Nackaerts, deputy director of the International Atomic Energy Agency, based in Vienna, told reporters as the group left for Tehran that the purpose of the visit was to devise a way to satisfy the agency’s concerns over the Iranian program’s “possible military dimensions.” He also said his delegation still hoped the Iranians would allow a visit to Parchin. Some members of his group were seen carrying equipment that could be used for testing at Parchin.

headline: What’s On Thursday
text: 8 P.M. (13) THE RICHARD TUCKER OPERA GALA The lyric soprano Ailyn Pérez — the 2012 winner of the Richard Tucker Award and the first Latina to receive the prize — performs alongside the baritones Dmitri Hvorostovsky and Gerald Finley; the mezzo-soprano Olga Borodina; the tenors Marcello Giordani, Giuseppe Filianoti and Stephen Costello (Ms. Pérez’s husband); the bass Ildar Abdrazakov; and the bass-baritone Erwin Schrott in arias and ensembles by Verdi, Rossini, Donizetti, Massenet, Mascagni, Handel and Wagner. Patrick Summers (above right, with Ms. Pérez and Mr. Costello) conducts members of the Metropolitan Opera Orchestra in this “Live From Lincoln Center” presentation, hosted by Audra McDonald and taped Nov. 11 at Avery Fisher Hall. “Her voice has a distinctive timbre, with plaintive richness blended into its youthful bloom,” Anthony Tommasini wrote in The New York Times when he reviewed this performance. “Ms. Pérez, a beautiful woman who commands the stage, has the makings of a major soprano.”

headline: Cuban Foreign Minister Named to Top Party Body
text: Cuba has elevated its foreign minister, Bruno Rodríguez, to the Communist Party’s Political Bureau, where he will join a handful of other senior leaders who are a generation younger than Fidel and Raúl Castro. Mr. Rodríguez, 54, is a former military officer, law professor and ambassador to the United Nations. He became the foreign minister in 2009. Known for his command of English and his loyalty to the Castros, he delivered a speech last month to the United Nations criticizing President Obama for failing to advance United States-Cuba relations despite the president’s promise to “launch a new chapter of engagement.”

headline: In Rajasthan, Guar Farmers Wait for a Return to Boom Times
text: NEW DELHI – A year ago, farmers of the modest guar bean in Rajasthan were enjoying boom times, but this year they’re still waiting for a windfall.

headline: News Quiz | December 13, 2012
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper. Good luck!

headline: IHT Quick Read: Dec. 13
text: NEWS President Bashar al-Assad’s forces have resorted to firing ballistic missiles at rebel fighters inside Syria, Obama administration officials said Wednesday, escalating a nearly two-year-old civil war as the government struggles to slow the momentum of a gaining insurgency. Michael R. Gordon and Eric Schmitt report.

headline: Mercedes-Benz Offers E-Class Sneak Preview
text: Mercedes-Benz plans the official world premiere of its extensively revamped E-Class lineup at the North American International Auto Show in Detroit on Jan. 14, but a sneak preview of the new sedans and station wagon was revealed Thursday.

headline: So Asian Kids Are Good at Math. What Does That Mean?
text: HONG KONG— There were two conflicting reactions to international exam results this week.

headline: Guns N’ Roses Plays in India After Twenty Year Wait
text: The legendary American rock band Guns N’ Roses made the outsourcing boomtown of Gurgaon the last stop on their debut tour of India Wednesday night, a tour 20 years in the making.

headline: Climate Change Forces Ski Areas to Face an Uncertain Future

headline: When Should You Compromise?

Many worry that if politicians fail to act, the United States could fall back into a recession. President Obama and House Speaker John A. Boehner have been negotiating, but so far they have been unable to reach a compromise on how to reduce the budget deficit.

headline: Why Is Hair  Growing Out of There?
text: You’re in the barber’s chair, secure in the knowledge, at least if you are male, that another haircut is drawing to a close as you hear the familiar buzz of the electric clippers flipping on and then feel them gliding up and down on the back of your neck. But what’s this? Has your barber taken a wrong turn? What are those clippers doing so close to your ear? What?! They’re actually in your ear. That can mean only one thing: you are now officially old, and you have the ear hair to prove it. It cannot get any worse than this, you think. And then the clippers make another turn and head . . . for your nose.

headline: How the Sale of a Business Can Go Terribly Wrong

headline: What’s a Store For?
text: The elevator door opened in the Sutton Place penthouse of Richard Perry, the hedge-fund manager, and there he stood in the white foyer wearing a black knit suit whose slumping shoulders made him look like a bony country parson. Perry is a man of meticulous habit, a super-athlete who prides himself on his sophisticated sense of style. He has a closetful of suits by Thom Browne and Lanvin that don’t have shoulders that slant like a roof. This one was a blip of misjudgment. But Perry, no doubt out of devotion to his wife, Lisa, a fashion designer who made the suit in the same double knit she uses for her mod dresses, decided to wear it that night. And it was an evening of some importance, for the Perrys were off to a party at Barneys — their first since Richard bought the renowned specialty store.

headline: A Soap Opera on the High Seas
text: A lesser-known consequence of the collapse of the real estate market in 2007 was the sudden unemployment of a 40-year-old carpenter from Kalamazoo, Mich., named Scott Meisterheim. Meisterheim first went to Las Vegas, then north to an oil-drilling camp in the Alaskan Arctic, and, one divorce later, to Nome, Alaska, a town of about 3,500 people huddled on the coast of the Bering Sea, in search of that last hope among last hopes: gold.

His day trip to Kandahar on Thursday was not publicized in advance and garnered little news media attention. Mr. Panetta never left the well-fortified base.

headline: Acropolis Now
text: Say what you will about the state of the Greek economy, but Athens remains a triumph. As politicians left and right try to hammer out a plan to keep the country afloat, the Parthenon still crowns the Acropolis like, in the words of an ancient Turkish traveler, “some impregnable fortress not made by human agency.” And if there is more commotion in Syntagma Square than usual, overall Athens is noisily going about being Athens — cafes are full, night life is roaring and at a recent concert by the singer Anna Vissi fans were flinging 10-euro trays of carnations at the star by the hundreds. Best of all, those undeterred by fiscal follies can probably get more value for their euro here than in any other big European city right now. Consider that a room at the posh New Hotel, by Syntagma Square, is going for slightly more than 100 euros a night, and includes the kind of gourmet breakfast that draws local dealmakers and diplomats alike. That kind of value, along with refreshingly drama-free winter weather, turns the idea of visiting into an imperative.

headline: Assessing the Financial Burden of Being an M.T.A Rider

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Debating Torture in ‘Zero Dark Thirty,’ and a Food Blogger Breaks Out
text: “Zero Dark Thirty,” about the hunt for Osama bin Laden, won’t open in movie theaters until Wednesday, but it is already dividing screening audiences for its depiction of torture by the United States, and its suggestion that brutal treatment may have produced useful early clues to catching Bin Laden, Scott Shane reports. A new Senate report on C.I.A. interrogations, which has been criticized by the Republican minority, has found that brutal treatment was not “a central component” in finding Bin Laden; the film’s screenwriter, Mark Boal, explained that he was “to compress a program that lasted for years into a few short scenes.” Those scenes, he said, attempted “to reflect a very complex debate about torture that is still going on” and showed that brutal treatment produced both true and false information.

text: Harvey Weinstein and Quentin Tarantino are doing whatever passes for a victory dance in their quarters – a less intense shouting match? – since they scored big with Golden Globe nominations this morning. The Hollywood Foreign Press Association saw fit to grant Mr. Tarantino’s “Django Unchained” five nominations, just shy of the pack leader, “Lincoln,” which had seven, and tying with “Argo.” “Django,” Mr. Tarantino’s bloody take on a western as a slavery revenge fantasy, picked up finalist spots for best picture, drama; best supporting actor (for Leonardo DiCaprio and Christoph Waltz); best screenplay; and, crucially, best director.

headline: 36 Hours in Sarasota, Fla.
text: WHERE else can one spend the morning reveling in the beauty of works by Peter Paul Rubens, Frans Hals and Botticelli and the afternoon lolling on a powdery white sand beach? That is the lure of Sarasota, the city perched on the Gulf of Mexico where John and Mable Ringling, the circus impresario and his wife, set the stage for a vibrant cultural life after buying land there in 1911. Not only did John Ringling create the old-master-filled John and Mable Ringling Museum of Art, but he brought the Ringling Brothers and Barnum & Bailey Circus to winter in Sarasota. His elephants even hauled timber for the John Ringling Causeway, which links the mainland to Lido Key. Nature, which initially attracted the Ringlings and other wealthy Midwesterners, provides its own set of pleasures beyond the beaches: whether it’s fishing, watching manatees and sea turtles or strolling past orchids and mangroves in an expansive botanical garden. For more civilized diversions, there is a plethora of restaurants and shops, and even an opera and orchestra.

headline: Ringling, Rubens and More in Sarasota, Fla.

headline: Big East May Go Small

In fact, you could go take another lap or two of Mars and it is likely that we will still be talking about the same things when you get back, that being the Saints’ bounty scandal and college conference realignment — specifically, the way the Big East is making the biggest hash of it.

headline: Bonnie the Mannequin’s Wild New York Adventure
text: While looking into the history of Barneys for my article in Sunday’s magazine, I came across the amazing windows that the artist Lynn Hershman Leeson did for Bonwit Teller in the fall of 1976. Bonwit’s was located on Fifth Avenue at 56th Street, where Trump Tower is today. After two years of negotiation with store management, Hershman Leeson brought her art and social commentary to 25 windows. “I wanted to put art in the context of everyday life,” Hershman Leeson, whose work includes photography, video, film and installations, said this week. She had already done a project in a prison. “I thought, Well, if I’m going to do something in New York City, I should do stores.”

headline: Letter From Berlin | Paper & Tea
text: Forget boxes of chamomile, or even English teapots. A new specialty tea company in Berlin’s affluent district Charlottenburg offers a different route to high-end ginger, lavender and Moroccan mint teas. Paper & Tea, which opened its doors on Dec. 1, is a far cry from your typical over-the-counter — almost pharmaceutical — approach to tea shops.

headline: N.F.I.B. Suffers the Post-Election Blues
text: The news from the National Federation of Independent Business on Tuesday was grim, very grim indeed. Confidence among small-business owners — or, more precisely, among a certain subset of small-business owners — dropped precipitously in November, as gauged by the organization’s Small Business Optimism Index. And the reason for the pessimism, said the N.F.I.B.’s chief economist, Bill Dunkelberg, was clear: President Obama won re-election.

headline: Battle Brews Over a Small, Vital Fish
text: The fate of a nondescript fish called the menhaden will be the focus of debate on Friday when the Atlantic States Marine Fisheries Commission meets in Baltimore to consider whether a catch limit should be imposed to end what many groups see as the outright exploitation of the species. So far, environmental groups, recreational and commercial fishermen, birders and others have generated over 100,000 comments in favor of protecting the fish.

headline: Cinder Block City

Up to that moment, I could see from my fourth floor window all of central Park Slope, the apex of which was the steeple of the Old First Reformed Church on Carroll Street, where I went to nursery school. For the six years I’d lived in the Brooklyn neighborhood of Gowanus, I had done the dishes, chopped vegetables and served guests wine across my kitchen island while looking up through that window at the church’s steeple, visible between the new high-rises on Fourth Avenue.

headline: One Man, 10 Favorites, Guvnor
text: WHEN is a cliché not a cliché? The question is relevant to all art, which is of necessity devoted to reinventing and re-energizing the familiar. But it seemed more pertinent than ever to New York theater during 2012. This was a year in which Broadway did its usual business of patching up and recycling old musical scores (“Nice Work if You Can Get It”) and movie scripts (“Newsies”) while serving up an unprecedented surfeit of revivals of plays we felt as if we had seen only yesterday (“A Streetcar Named Desire,” “Cyrano de Bergerac,” “Death of a Salesman,” “Who’s Afraid of Virginia Woolf?,” “The Heiress,” “Glengarry Glen Ross”).
