headline: Art Fairs, Full of Bling if Not Fire
text: THIS year the expansion of the art world beyond its traditional boundaries reached new extremes. On many fronts it seemed that the global was winning out over the local, what with the continued proliferation of art fairs, the spread of auctions and the franchising of art galleries, on the Gagosian model, around the globe. And this year it often seemed as if the effects of all this — a combined draining of energy and further stratification of the art world into haves and have-nots — were registering most powerfully in New York, which still has the biggest gallery scene in the world.

headline: Another Lakers Headache: Missed Foul Shots by Howard

headline: Neighbors From the Far East, Getting Along Just Fine

You are sipping water from a Mason jar under bare dangling bulbs, as if at some rustic hipster bar. But Chinatown-shopkeeper abacuses line the walls, brass lion’s-head door knockers snarl from the backs of chairs, and a kaleidoscope of petaled lampshades has turned half the ceiling into a lotus pond.

headline: Simplifying the Fiscal Cliff Debate
text: There are a lot of potential moving parts in the fiscal cliff negotiations, and thus a lot of potential ways that matters could be negotiated and settled, postponed or left half-resolved. But sometimes simplification helps, and the best place to start when thinking about how things are likely to play out is with the following brute fact: No matter what Congressional Republicans offer the president and what they’re willing to concede, taxes on the wealthiest Americans are going to rise by at least $800 billion over the next decade. This is not a possibility, not a likely scenario, not a maybe or a might be; it’s just reality, conceded even by the notorious RINO Jim DeMint. Which means that it’s useful for analytic purposes to treat that $800 billion as a baseline, rather than as a live point of give and take in the negotiations, and recognize that any bigger deal John Boehner and Barack Obama are able to cut should be judged as much on how it balances spending cuts and tax increases beyond that baseline as on what it looks like overall.

Pero el aumento súbito en la población de las ciudades en la jungla actualmente subvierte esa visión rural y provoca alarma entre los científicos, a medida que una gama de nuevos proyectos industriales transforma la Amazonía en la región de más rápido crecimiento de Brasil.

headline: Film Forum
text: Seen in fast forward, the career of David Thomson — the avid, idiosyncratic movie critic — looks more like a klatch session than a formal lesson in the history of film. Where many writers’ work suggests a dutiful progression, Thomson chases his subjects with free-associative license: Nicole Kidman to Alfred Hitchcock (with a hefty reference work in between), the big picture to the picayune. And where a lot of critics aim for impartial assessment, he has unapologetically privileged his private passions. Today, Thomson is best known for his “New Biographical Dictionary of Film,” but his strength is less taxonomy than transition, the almost cinematic way his mind cuts among its intellectual frames.

headline: The Senate Does Something Right
text: Disabled veterans won a big, unexpected victory today: the Senate passed Senator Patty Murray’s bill to expand fertility services, including in-vitro fertilization, at the Veterans Affairs Department. Ms. Murray, the Washington Democrat and chairwoman of the Veterans’ Affairs Committee, sponsored the bill, S.3313, to help service members whose war wounds have left them unable to have children. She said infertility was a particular problem for service members coming home from Iraq and Afghanistan, where improvised bombs frequently cause severe pelvic injuries.

headline: Israeli Foreign Minister Faces Indictment on Lesser Charges

headline: Borders and Epochs, Dissolving at His Keyboard
text: EARLY in his career, beginning in the 1950s, the pianist and bandleader Eddie Palmieri used to play mambo shows at the Palladium Ballroom, on Broadway at 53rd Street. The Ed Sullivan Theater was just across the street but seemed to belong to a different, distant world: while Sullivan’s popular Sunday night TV show was happy to book the likes of Señor Wences, the Spanish ventriloquist, the frenetically danceable Latin music that Mr. Palmieri played was thought to lack mainstream appeal.

headline: Ahead of Their Times, but Resolved to Love
text: When Alan Cumming turns on his beaming grin in “Any Day Now,” Travis Fine’s militant tear-jerker, he conveys such intense, unguarded emotion you almost want to avert your eyes. That smile, and the blazing performance it distills, conveys so ferocious a mixture of desire, hurt, defiance, courage, neediness and reckless abandon that it makes everyone else seem cowardly. You consider the real meaning of the Jerry Herman anthem, “I Am What I Am,” from “La Cage aux Folles,” as it is lived out in extremis by one flamboyantly gay man.

headline: Down the Shore, the Lost and the Found
text: ASBURY PARK, N.J. — I’m riding down Kingsley, looking for a place to park. With the crowds at Convention Hall, the Stone Pony and the Wonder Bar, there are no spots left on this oceanfront stretch. I’m here to see the roller-derby championship, three weeks after Hurricane Sandy ripped through and devoured the boardwalk. It’s night, and a waxing moon barely lights the culprit — the churning Atlantic, which both gives this place its life and threatens its existence.

headline: The Drinks Are Expensive but the View Is Priceless
text: The bar at Má Pêche in the Chambers Hotel was closed for a private party, so it would be a night without seven-spice sours and steamed pork buns. The King Cole Bar at the St. Regis was so packed with souls — almost all of them merry, fittingly enough — that there wasn’t even room to stand.

headline: Russian State Role Seen in Death of Poisoned Spy

Litvinenko, offering “prima facie” evidence of Russian state involvement and indicating that he had been a paid agent of the British Secret Intelligence Service, MI6, lawyers at a preliminary inquest hearing said.

headline: Where Opposites Attract
text: NEW HAVEN — In a museum era dominated by the vying forces of bad economics and compulsive building, it’s a miracle when something comes out right, which makes the opening of the splendidly renovated and expanded Yale University Art Gallery here a happy event. The angels of art, design and budgetary planning were on duty. Everything worked. The country’s oldest university art museum has arrived at a kind of institutional ideal of opposites in balance.

headline: Bodies in Motion
text: Netta Yerushalmy, a lifelong dancer who first performed at just 3 years old, will present a new work, “Devouring Devouring,” tonight at the storied Off Off Broadway theater La Mama. The title may conjure images of gluttony, and Yerushalmy doesn’t shy away from the food metaphor, describing the piece she has choreographed as a “feast” of offerings for the audience’s eyes and minds.

headline: Top Sichuan Official Removed in Corruption Inquiry
text: BEIJING — A high-ranking Communist Party leader who was the second most powerful official in China’s southwest Sichuan Province was removed from his posts on Thursday amid corruption allegations that may hint of a wider crackdown on graft.

headline: Spare Times for Dec. 14-20
text: Around Town

headline: Leak of Climate Panel Drafts Speaks to Need for New Process
text: Dec. 14, 11:00 a.m. | Updates below |A WikiLeaks-style Web dump of drafts of the 2013 report from the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change provides fresh evidence that the organization’s policies and procedures are a terrible fit for an era in which transparency will increasingly be enforced on organizations working on consequential energy and environmental issues.

headline: Opening the Doors to the Life of Pi
text: For those of us who have been intoxicated by the powers and possibilities of mathematics, the mystery isn’t why that fascination developed but why it isn’t universal. How can students not be entranced? So profound are the effects of math for those who have felt them, that you never really become a former mathematician (or ex-mathematics student) but one who has “lapsed,” as if it were an apostasy.

headline: In Gangster State of Mind: Aging? Fuhgeddaboutit
text: The three geezers who run riot in “Stand Up Guys” aren’t just grumpy old men acting up. They’re veteran gangsters whose final rampage before they surrender to the dying of the light is a triumphant affirmation of vitality that the movie milks for two parts comedy to one part pathos.

headline: Few Echoes in a Voice With Mettle
text: At the end of her show at the Bowery Ballroom on Tuesday night, Solange was in the crowd, dancing, one reveler of many, set apart only by the fact that she had just been onstage, that it was her song moving the room, that her sister is Beyoncé — but really, by none of that.

headline: Spare Times for Children for Dec. 14-20
text: ALL ABOARD: HISTORIC TRAINS AND TOYS WEEKEND

headline: Audience Participates; Kneepads Recommended
text: Imagine for the purposes of this review that you have a ticket for Yvonne Meier’s dance-theater work “The Shining.” Not many do; only 12 people may attend each performance. First, in the foyer of New York Live Arts, you must sign a liability waiver. Then a naked woman greets you, sings to you and ushers you into a van that transports you to a location outside Manhattan. (Though its Web site announces that performances of “The Shining” are happening there, I’ll preserve its mystery, as requested.)

headline: Prompting Discussion on Torture
text: The new film “Zero Dark Thirty” and a recent Senate report reignite the debate over the United States government’s policy on torture.

headline: Fans Jeer D’Antoni, but Sting Is in Defeat
text: Mike D’Antoni got the warm embrace he hoped for upon returning to New York.

headline: Damien Hirst Leaves Gagosian
text: Less than a year after the Gagosian Gallery gave Damien Hirst all 11 of its spaces around the world to show his spot paintings, word comes that the bad-boy British artist will no longer be represented by Gagosian, where he has shown on and off for 17 years.

headline: No Reading Between the Lines
text: What does it say about a biography when the author’s description of her working methods is more revealing than her text is. That’s the situation with “Saul Steinberg,” a studious, bone-dry book that is packed with information yet utterly inert. Its author, Deirdre Bair, has done far better work before, including her book on Simone de Beauvoir and her National Book Award-winning biography of Samuel Beckett. But when it comes to Steinberg she is hopelessly constrained by the circumstances in which she did her research and writing.

headline: Where an Attaché Comes With the Room
text: AS a certified butler from the Taj Hotels training program in New Delhi, Anupam Guha says he has waited on all manner of esteemed personages, including the former British prime minister Tony Blair (“a dignified man, ” he said, “with a very soft human heart”) and Aga Khan IV (a fan of sweets, to whom Mr. Guha served sugarcoated strawberries).

headline: Don’t Think About Santa as a Meal
text: With the avalanche of made-for-television holiday movies this year, practically any constituency you can think of has been served.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Gaza and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Gaza Strip, Syria, India and Spain.

headline: The Beatles’ Seat-of-the-Pants Movie
text: For many people the Beatles have ascended to a could-do-no-wrong status: Everything they ever did was great, brilliant, as good as it has ever been. That’s not true, of course. Even the best albums had some filler, and none of the movies are likely to be mistaken for “Citizen Kane.”

headline: After North Korea’s Missile Launch
text: “No one can ignore us from now.”

headline: Android Malware Creeps Into Cellphone Bills
text: Smartphones are meant to be headache-free compared with old-school computers. But malicious software written for Android devices can be even sneakier than the malware that invaded PCs.

headline: Revenue Rises, Deficit Falls: Fiscal Cliff Gets Credit
text: Let us pause to give credit where credit is due.

headline: Comptroller Is Expected to Try to Upset Deal for New Taxis
text: City Comptroller John C. Liu is expected to announce on Friday that he will not sign off on the Bloomberg administration’s contract with Nissan to provide New York City’s next generation of taxis, according to people with knowledge of the matter.

headline: A Daughter Stumbling in Her Father’s Footsteps
text: It takes a stupid crime and an avoidable tragedy to realize that the title of the American independent movie “The Girl” refers to two people. The first is Ashley (Abbie Cornish), a solitary, thorny rose of Texas who lives in a trailer park and punches a clock at a dead-end job. Her manager favors the Latina workers, or so she believes; worse, her young son, Georgie (Austin Wayne West), has been taken away from her. She visits him soon after the story opens, dropping by the foster home where he lives and that, with its tidy lawn and swing set, looks pretty as a picture. It’s a snapshot of the American dream that seems out of her reach and that will bring her and the second girl trouble.

headline: Dancing by Night
text: Lessons in Haitian dance in East Flatbush, Brooklyn, offer fast-paced beats that recall their ultimate West African origins even as they announce their own distinctive intensity.

headline: If College Admissions Were Like Tetris, Everything Would Fall in Line
text: Sush Krishnamoorthy, from New Delhi, is part of a “Choice” class that includes student-bloggers from Nairobi, Kenya; Topeka, Kan.; Seattle; Rogers, Ark.; Las Vegas; New York City; and Hunting Valley, Ohio. Her fourth post is below. — Tanya Abrams

headline: Neighborhood Joint: Haitian Dance at La Difference Auto School
text: Where by day students learn the rules of the road, by night they can learn the art of djembes, conga drums and the distinct intensity of a country’s footwork.

headline: Art and Real Estate Tango in Miami
text: MIAMI

headline: Despite Risks, China Stays at North Korea’s Side to Keep the U.S. at Bay
text: BEIJING — Even though North Korea ignored China’s appeal not to test its new longer-range missile, the new leadership here appears intent on remaining a steadfast supporter of its wayward neighbor because it considers the North a necessary buffer against the United States and its allies.

headline: GTT ★
text: Our quirky, discerning picks for the most interesting things to do around the state this week.

headline: For Images of Impending Death, Context Is Crucial
text: Our post Wednesday seeking your thoughts on the differences between two widely seen — and differently perceived — photographs of men moments away from death drew an outpouring of responses, both in the comments and on Twitter.

headline: Mickey Boardman’s Obsessions
text: A look inside the editorial director of Paper Magazine’s apartment.

headline: From a Murder to Madness
text: “My summer has stayed with me all my life,” muses the narrator of the melodrama “Saving Grace B. Jones.” “If you saw that summer in a movie, you’d never believe it really happened.” True enough.

headline: Workers’ Paradise Lost
text: Philadelphia

headline: Haitian Rhythms You Can Hear From the Street
text: BY day, La Difference Auto School offers lessons in turn signals and rights of way in English, French, Creole and Spanish from a ramshackle but brightly painted storefront in East Flatbush, Brooklyn. It hardly stands out among the car mechanics, polyglot bookstores, Trinidadian roti shops and Jamaican seafood markets in this busy Caribbean neighborhood. But on Sunday nights, Haitian rhythms spill onto Rogers Avenue from the school’s back room, where drummers from La Troupe Makandal and dancers from La Troupe Zetwal organize lessons in traditional Haitian drumming and dance.

headline: The Natural History Museum of Mickey
text: AS the editorial director of Paper Magazine, it is Mickey Boardman’s job to discover and point out the sorts of things people ordinarily overlook and discard.

headline: Iran: U.S. Expands Anti-Nuclear Sanctions
text: The United States expanded anti-nuclear sanctions against Iran on Thursday, blacklisting seven Iranian companies and five individuals including Fereydoon Abbasi, Iran’s top nuclear official and the target of a failed assassination attempt in Tehran two years ago, which Iran said was the work of Israeli operatives. The Treasury Department said the sanctions were intended to deter the procurement operations of the Atomic Energy Organization of Iran, which is led by Dr. Abbasi; the Iran Centrifuge Technology Company; and Iran’s uranium enrichment program. Companies and people on the blacklist cannot do business with any American businesses or citizens, and any assets they may have in the United States will be frozen. The new sanctions, which came as a team of inspectors from the International Atomic Energy Agency was visiting Iran, were likely to anger Iranian officials, who have repeatedly rejected Western and Israeli accusations that their nuclear program is a cover to develop the ability to make atomic weapons.

headline: Hark! The Herald Angels Didn’t Sing
text: Stanford, Calif.

headline: Something Borrowed, but Not Something Blue
text: FOR her formal wedding in September, Faye Juaniza Colon wore a strapless satin gown with tiny buttons down the back. It was a classic elegant ensemble, and the apple-size shoulder tattoo just didn’t work.

headline: Weighing Options for Expanding School Choice
text: In debates over school choice, like the one brewing as the 83rd legislative session draws closer, traditional public school districts are often cast as stubborn defenders of the status quo.

headline: U.S. to Send 2 Missile Units to Turkey to Deter Syrians
text: WASHINGTON — The United States plans to send two Patriot missile batteries and about 400 military personnel to Turkey to defend against a possible Syrian missile attack, two allied officials said Thursday.

headline: When It Comes to Race for House Speaker, Secretiveness Rules
text: ​Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a column for The Tribune.

headline: Putin Backs Penalizing U.S. Judges in Adoptions
text: MOSCOW — President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia voiced support on Thursday for sanctions on American judges and others accused of having violated the rights of adopted Russian children in the United States. Such legislation is being proposed here in retaliation for a bill passed by Congress last week to punish people from Russia accused of violating human rights.

headline: In Ignorance We Trust
text: A packet of letters arrived the other day from the honors English class at St. Lawrence School in Brasher Falls, N.Y. Snail mail, from high school sophomores? Yes, and honest, witty and insightful snail mail at that. They had been forced to read a book of mine.

headline: Back When Americans Were the ‘Illegals’
text: The illegal immigrants had crossed the river in defiance of the law, then escaped capture by sneaking past armed patrols in the dark. They did not have the required paperwork and were ordered to leave, but the authorities suspected the immigrants would probably defy them.

headline: Shopping Doesn’t Have to Mean Suffering
text: To the Editor:

text: To the Editor:

text: To the Editor:

text: To the Editor:

text: To the Editor:

headline: From Madison Square Garden to Madison Avenue
text: IT is not surprising that someone who works in advertising once interned at Vogue and has the fashion sense, and looks, to model occasionally. Similarly, it is not unusual to find ex-athletes at agencies. Nor is it out of the ordinary that someone in the industry is also an owner of a bar. Or active in causes like marriage equality and helping the victims of Hurricane Sandy. Or turns up, from time to time, in the gossip columns.

headline: Manhattan’s Print Dealers
text: For a completely Zen shopping experience then, or if you insist, soon, few things are more relaxing than going through the old stock of Manhattan’s print dealers.

headline: Holiday Foot-Dragging and Its Rewards
text: PERSONALLY, I like shopping on Christmas Eve. If you are not gripped by getting the perfect present in the perfect wrapping for the perfect person, it’s fun to go through a few stores at the end of the day as Midtown is emptying out, and buy whatever strikes your fancy. And for a completely Zen shopping experience then, or if you insist, soon, few things are more relaxing than going through the old stock of Manhattan’s print dealers.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 2,147 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American recently:

headline: 7 Colleges Seem Ready to Bolt From Big East
text: After looking on as realignment diluted and marginalized the Big East Conference, the seven universities in the league that are not part of the Football Bowl Subdivision are expected to depart in the coming days and form a league revolving around basketball.

headline: Holidays Without God
text: Can you really celebrate Christmas and Hanukkah without paying tribute to God?

headline: Rutgers Suspends Coach for Three Games, Citing Behavior
text: Rutgers suspended its men’s basketball coach, Mike Rice, for three games and fined him $50,000 for a violation of athletic department policy, the university announced Thursday.

headline: A Fed Focused on the Value of Clarity
text: WASHINGTON

headline: A Mixed-Race Girl in a Mixed-Up World
text: Sweetness O’Hara, the quiet teenager at the center of the American independent movie “Yelling to the Sky,” lives in a small house that seems even smaller when her father is raging through it. As played by the young actress Zoë Kravitz, Sweetness moves through life like a leaf in the wind. She drifts and scatters and at times gets caught underfoot, including by a gang of local bullies. Every so often, though, she faces down a more frightening, confusing antagonist, her father, Gordon (Jason Clarke), a violent drunk whose menace overruns his erratic charm.

headline: The Credit Union Alternative
text: THIS year for the first time in their century-old history, credit unions are on track to surpass $100 billion in mortgage loan originations.

headline: A Campus Art Museum, Renewed
text: A sign near the main entrance to the Yale University Art Gallery says, “You may carefully touch.” It’s an invitation to set in motion a sculpture made of fragments of cast iron, broken porcelain and stainless steel by the contemporary American artist Robert Hudson. A modest push and the piece slowly revolves, its blue, rust and chrome chasing each other as if on a miniature carousel.

headline: The Cost of Solitary Confinement
text: The New York Legislature greatly improved the treatment of mentally ill inmates in 2008, when it required the prison system to place seriously mentally ill inmates who violate rules into a treatment program instead of solitary confinement, where they were more likely to harm themselves or commit suicide.

headline: As a Premier Prepares to Depart, the Talk Is of Lost Opportunities
text: ROME — As Prime Minister Mario Monti prepares to exit the stage, he has burnished Italy’s image — and his own — abroad, but he is less beloved at home. Italians are irate about higher taxes, while critics say that Mr. Monti failed to carry out the basic structural changes he said were needed, leaving a legacy more of austerity than growth.

headline: To Gain From Rising Sales, G.M. Redesigns Pickups
text: PONTIAC, Mich. — Signs of recovery in the housing and construction industries have given a much-needed lift to the market for full-size pickup trucks, which took a beating during the recession.

headline: Leader of Atlanta Turnaround Is Above All a Teacher
text: FLOWERY BRANCH, Ga. — Mike Smith had just finished his second season coaching in the N.F.L., but he was already preparing for his retirement. It was late February 2001, and Smith was on his knees at a dusty playground in a village outside Cancún, Mexico, teaching a boy about 9 years old the technique of tackling.

headline: The Mother-in-Law Gift Gap
text: My mother-in-law gives me significantly more-modest Christmas gifts than she gives my husband — even though I am the main breadwinner and my hard-earned dollars buy the extravagant presents we give her. Her gifts to me are in the $25 range and help with housework. Last year, she gave my husband a $5,000 present. I don’t need anything from her, but our gift exchanges feel like a slap in the face. Are there rules for in-law gifts? Anonymous

headline: Elevating Champagne’s ‘Unacknowledged Grape’
text: PITY the poor pinot meunier grape. It’s the third member of the Champagne trinity, yet given the proud superstar status of the other two — chardonnay and pinot noir — pinot meunier is often a humble afterthought, if it’s given any thought at all.

headline: The G.O.P.’s Existential Crisis
text: We are not having a debt crisis.

headline: Failure to Commit in a World Where Romance Rules
text: What’s eating Sarah (Lizzy Caplan), the failure-to-commit heroine of the mopey comedy “Save the Date”? Sensitive men — the lead singer in a band (Wolfbird, no less), a gently awkward marine biologist — love her. She’s cute and droll and draws cute pictures. But should a man dare to say he loves her, or worse, propose marriage, she shuts off.

headline: Pain Behind the Budget Cuts
text: You might never spot an air marshal on your flight, but it’s reassuring to know one might be there. In a few weeks, though, many of them are likely to get pink slips — along with food safety inspectors, border patrol agents and countless other government employees who play a crucial if hidden role in everyone’s lives.

headline: Gloom and Doom for the Planet
text: “This is appalling,” says the actor Jeremy Irons, surveying a reeking mountain of consumer waste fouling a once glorious beach in Lebanon.

headline: Merchant Ends Run on HBO
text: Larry Merchant, 81, the boxing commentator and International Boxing Hall of Fame inductee, will work his final regularly scheduled bout for HBO on Saturday when Nonito Donaire and Jorge Arce square off in Houston. It will be the end of a 35-year run for Merchant at HBO. Merchant covered every notable boxer in the previous three decades. Last year, he all but challenged Floyd Mayweather to a fight after a contentious in-ring interview. “I wish I was 50 years younger,” Merchant said.

headline: Egypt’s Flawed Constitutional Vote
text: On Saturday, voters will begin casting their ballots in Egypt on their new constitution. But the process managed by President Mohamed Morsi has been so corrupted by power plays, division and violent protests that it is hard to see how the referendum can result in the consensus needed to lay a foundation for enduring democratic change. Mr. Morsi should have postponed the referendum, reconvened a constitutional assembly that was less dominated by his Muslim Brotherhood allies and charged its members with writing an amended charter that would respond to the concerns that his more liberal, secular opponents have with the current draft.

headline: Report of ’80s Sexual Abuse Rattles Yeshiva Campus
text: A tall, imposing rabbi with a black goatee who served as assistant principal and principal during his 27 years at Yeshiva University High School for Boys, George B. Finkelstein was the face of authority to Mordechai Twersky, who graduated in 1981.

headline: Perseverance Reigns When Incurable Disease Strikes
text: “Jason Becker: Not Dead Yet” is really only partly about Mr. Becker, a guitar wizard whose promising career was derailed by one of the most unforgiving afflictions there is, amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, or Lou Gehrig’s disease. This heartfelt documentary is also, more subtly, a tribute to the squadron of caregivers that has enabled Mr. Becker not only to survive for an extraordinarily long time but also to continue to compose music, using virtually the only part of him that still moves, his eyes.

headline: Fighting the Power Across the Globe and Time
text: Infinitely less than the sum of its parts, Antonino D’Ambrosio’s “Let Fury Have the Hour” crams 50 thoughtful artists into a disappointingly muddled film.

headline: High-Tech Factories Built to Be Engines of Innovation
text: SCHENECTADY, N.Y. — The Obama administration has long heralded the potential of American factories to offer good, stable middle-class jobs in an economy that desperately needs them. But experts say there might be another advantage to expanding manufacturing in the United States: a more innovative economy.

headline: This Week’s Movies | Dec. 14, 2012
text: The New York Times critics on “The Hobbit,” “Any Day Now” and “The Girl.”

headline: Paper Links Nerve Agents in ’91 Gulf War and Ailments
text: Reviving a 20-year debate over illnesses of veterans of the 1991 Persian Gulf war, a new scientific paper presents evidence that nerve agents released by the bombing of Iraqi chemical weapons depots just before the ground war began could have carried downwind and fallen on American troops staged in Saudi Arabia.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Quotation of the Day for Friday, Dec. 14, 2012
text: We borrowed a lot of money, but we had no choice. I wasn’t going to watch the buildings fall down.

headline: Prosecutor Says Morsi Aides Interfered in Inquiry
text: CAIRO — A prosecutor in Cairo is accusing aides to President Mohamed Morsi of applying political pressure to an investigation into the bloody clashes here last week, in order to corroborate Islamists’ claims about a conspiracy against the president involving thugs paid to foment violence.

headline: In Cairo Crisis, the Poor Find Dashed Hopes
text: CAIRO — A faded poster of Hosni Mubarak hangs on a wall in a crumbling neighborhood here, reminding residents of an empty pledge to find jobs for young people. Down the street, a campaign banner for his successor, Mohamed Morsi, hangs across the road, a reminder of more recent promises unkept.

headline: Promise vs. Reality in Newark on Mayor’s Watch
text: NEWARK — When snow blanketed this city two Christmases ago, Mayor Cory A. Booker was celebrated around the nation for personally shoveling out residents who had appealed for help on Twitter. But here, his administration was scorned as streets remained impassable for days because the city had no contract for snow removal.

headline: Returning Home by Leaving Big East
text: It has been almost four years since Lou Carnesecca sat cross-legged in Madison Square Garden and diplomatically chose a word to describe the contemporary Big East as a basketball league. “Unwieldy,” the old coach said as he watched his beloved St. John’s play Georgetown on one of those March tournament afternoons when one could not help but measure the fine line between handsomely bigger and harmfully bloated.

headline: Building a Showcase Campus, Using an I.O.U.
text: Some call it the Edifice Complex. Others have named it the Law of More, or the Taj Mahal syndrome.

headline: Wake Up and Smell the Coffee
text: FRIDAY’S PUZZLE — There’s a certain amount of good-natured hazing that takes place when you go to work at The New York Times, and that’s to be expected. It’s not easy to get a large newspaper out every day, and having a little fun with the newbies is a good way to blow off steam.

headline: Corrections: December 14, 2012
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Recent Critic of Jets Settles In as Their New Receiver
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — Braylon Edwards took a spot in front of his locker after the Jets’ practice Thursday and within five minutes was attempting to run a nifty curl route around his recent Twitter message that the “idiots calling shots” were ruining the Jets.

headline: Causes of Death
text: With more children around the world surviving to adulthood, more people are now dying of noncommunicable diseases like cancer or heart disease.

headline: Hurricane Sandy’s Effects Leave Some Municipal Workers as Refugees, Too
text: City welfare workers with flashlights strapped to their heads are trudging up as many as 25 flights of stairs to dark, chilly offices to retrieve computers, Medicaid checks and, if time allows, a child’s art project.

headline: Hamas Gains Allure in Gaza, but Money Is a Problem
text: GAZA CITY — Hamas has been riding high of late, after its professed victory in the recent conflict with Israel and the overthrow last year of Egypt’s president, Hosni Mubarak, an avowed enemy.

headline: Controversial Group Plans More Ads in Subway Stations
text: The group behind a recent spate of inflammatory advertisements throughout the transit system said this week that it planned to make its biggest purchase yet: the space beside each of the roughly 220 clocks hanging in New York City’s subway stations.

headline: Fields and Picnic Area Open in Brooklyn Park
text: Brooklyn Bridge Park, an 85-acre work-in-progress that stretches along the East River waterfront, took a significant step toward completion on Thursday with the opening of three new athletic fields, two playgrounds and a picnic area on Pier 5.

headline: Confession Only Adds to Mystery in Patz Case
text: “There are no secrets in this case,” the lawyer Harvey Fishbein wrote in papers he filed in court Wednesday.

headline: As the Mets Sit Quietly, Trade Speculation Swirls
text: A month and a half has passed since the conclusion of the baseball season, and the Mets have made no player acquisitions of any significance. Instead, it has been a winter defined by departures.

headline: Moody’s Downgrade Deepens Puerto Rico’s Economic Problems
text: Moody’s Investors Service downgraded the debt of Puerto Rico to just above junk status on Thursday, putting pressure on the governor-elect, Alejandro García-Padilla, to show credible plans for staving off a crisis.

headline: Dempster Is Set to Join Red Sox
text: The Boston Red Sox reached an agreement on a two-year, $26.5 million contract with the right-hander Ryan Dempster, adding a veteran starter to a thin rotation. The agreement was confirmed by a baseball official. The deal will not be announced until Dempster, 35, passes a physical. He was 12-8 with a 3.34 earned run average last season for the Chicago Cubs and the Texas Rangers. Dempster is the fifth player, but the first pitcher, to reach a two- or three-year contract agreement with the Red Sox this off-season. Burned in past years by long-term commitments, the Red Sox have been thriftier this time, signing Dempster, Jonny Gomes, Mike Napoli, David Ross and Shane Victorino to short-term deals. Napoli’s contract has not been finalized.

headline: Hoping for a Senate Seat, the Friendliest of Rivals
text: WASHINGTON — Representatives Trey Gowdy and Tim Scott, first-term Republicans from South Carolina, are both in the running to replace Senator Jim DeMint when the conservative leaves office next month. But they say they know the best man for the job: the other guy.

headline: Senate Panel Approves Findings Critical of Detainee Interrogations
text: WASHINGTON — The Senate Intelligence Committee on Thursday approved a highly critical, classified report on the Central Intelligence Agency’s detention and interrogation program, the most comprehensive review of the brutal treatment of Qaeda prisoners in the years after the Sept. 11, 2001, terrorist attacks.

headline: Hope of a Better Future Fades in Boulaq
text: Everywhere, people tell stories about the Egyptian government’s failures, suggesting that the new leaders had turned out no better than the old ones.

headline: Rice’s Blunt Style Endeared Her to President, but Not All
text: WASHINGTON — For President Obama, the decision to forgo the fight to make Susan E. Rice his secretary of state was a deeply painful one. It required publicly abandoning one of his most loyal aides, who had broken with the Democratic foreign policy establishment early to side with his improbable candidacy, and whose blunt-speaking style — which helped cost her the job — had always been, for Mr. Obama, a part of her appeal.

headline: Judge in North Carolina Voids 3 Death Sentences
text: A judge in North Carolina on Thursday ruled that race had played a significant role in the sentencing of three convicted murderers to death, and changed their sentences to life in prison without possibility of parole. It was the second such decision under the state’s Racial Justice Act and the first since the act was amended by the state legislature.

headline: Outcry Brings Down Murals in Atlanta Art Project
text: ATLANTA — Two murals intended to spruce up blighted neighborhoods in Atlanta have been painted over after some residents complained that they were confusing at best, demonic at worst.

headline: Church Opens Arms to Muslim Group, and Is Taken to Task
text: When the Muslim Public Affairs Council arranged to hold its annual convention at All Saints Church in Pasadena, Calif., this Saturday, leaders of both organizations believed it would be a bold demonstration of progress in interfaith relations.

headline: After Fast Start, Anthony Limps Off and Knicks Hold On
text: Carmelo Anthony looked up at the shot clock, put his head down and drove the lane. Mike D’Antoni, his former coach, stood a few feet away as Anthony was fouled hard by Dwight Howard. Anthony’s left knee and ankle were caught under his body when he hit the court in a violent crash.

headline: The End of 'Ebb' and 'Flow'
text: An animation released by NASA shows the proposed crash landing of two lunar-orbiting spacecraft, called Ebb and Flow, into the moon's surface.

headline: Two Space Probes to Crash, Intentionally, on Dark Side of Moon
text: NASA’s latest Moon mission will end on Monday — not with a whimper, but a splat.

headline: Word of the Day | filibuster
text: filibuster •\ˈfi-lə-ˌbəs-tər\• noun and verb

headline: As State Budgets Rebound, Federal Cuts Could Pose Danger
text: After years of budget cuts and sluggish recovery, states expect to see their revenues climb back to prerecession levels this year for the first time since the financial crisis hit. But even as some states hope to restore some of the deep spending cuts they have made, they face a new threat.

headline: National Governors Association Fiscal Survey of States
text: States collected more taxes this year than in 2008, the last fiscal year before the recession. But the news is not as good as it initially appears.

headline: A Mother Fought to End a Destructive Path and Reunite Her Family
text: Getting through to troubled teenagers should not be difficult, says Julie Rodriguez, who aspires to be a counselor after surviving some tough decades of violence and drug abuse.

headline: Bryant’s Frustration Grows as Free Fall Continues
text: Kobe Bryant tried making the most of his off day in New York City on Wednesday.

headline: What’s On Friday
text: 9 P.M. (Sundance) RESTLESS In the conclusion of this two-part drama written by William Boyd, Ruth Gilmartin (Michelle Dockery), a Cambridge graduate student in 1970s England, continues to uncover the past of her mother, Sally (Charlotte Rampling, above), who she has recently discovered is actually Eva Delectorskaya (Hayley Atwell plays the young Eva), a Russian exile who worked as a British spy during World War II. Now the former spy thinks someone is out to kill her, which is why she’s buying a rifle and ammunition strong enough to take down a charging elephant. “We all have secrets,” she admonishes her disbelieving daughter. “No one even knows half the truth about someone else.” Rufus Sewell and Michael Gambon share the role of Lucas Romer, a spymaster and Sally’s former lover, who may be the only one who can save her. “Devout fans of the British espionage thriller or the British cozy mystery may find themselves perfectly happy with ‘Restless,’ ” Mike Hale wrote in The New York Times. “Mr. Boyd’s understated script is free of hackneyed dialogue or florid emotion (no surprise), and there are niceties of language — strategically repeated phrases, Ruth’s wavering forms of address to her mother — that you don’t expect in a mini-series. And Ms. Dockery and Ms. Rampling, in their relatively short screen time together, have an astringent rapport that brings to life the complicated relationship of Ruth and Eva, as well as Mr. Boyd’s themes of the forging and cracking of identity under pressure, in a way that goes beyond words on a page.”

headline: News Quiz | December 14, 2012
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper. Good luck!

headline: At a Busy Gurgaon Call Center, Putting the Phones on Hold for ‘Family Day’
text: On a recent Friday, amid the corporate sprawl of modern Gurgaon, Genpact, one of India’s largest business process and technology outsourcing centers, transformed an otherwise nondescript conference room into a festive reception hall with bright balloons, waiters passing out candy and a stage set up for the occasion. Employees trickled in, some new to the company, others veterans with years of experience, to slowly fill the 100-odd chairs in the room. But this afternoon, instead of the notepads and pens they would bring to regular team meeting, these workers have got their families in tow.

headline: IHT Quick Read: Dec. 14
text: NEWS European leaders gathering on Thursday for their year-end summit meeting hailed an agreement to place euro zone banks under a single supervisor, calling it a concrete measure to maintain the viability of the currency as well as a step in laying the groundwork for a broader economic union. James Kanter reports from Brussels.

headline: Russia Steps Back From Envoy’s Comments on Syria
text: MOSCOW — The Russian Foreign Ministry distanced itself on Friday from comments by its Middle East envoy, who was widely quoted a day earlier as saying that rebels in Syria may defeat the forces of President Bashar al-Assad, and said Russia’s insistence on a political solution to the Syrian crisis will never change.

headline: Should You Care About the Health and Safety of Those Making Your Clothing?
text: Recent factory fires killed more than 400 workers in Bangladesh and Pakistan. Unsafe conditions, like locked exits and barred windows, made the death tolls much higher. In the United States, more than a century of activism and legislation has drastically improved factory safety at home, but so much of our clothing is now manufactured overseas where workers do not have the same protections. American consumers benefit from lower prices, but at what cost?

headline: Panetta Orders Deployment of U.S. Antimissile Units in Turkey
text: INCIRLIK AIR BASE, Turkey — Defense Secretary Leon E. Panetta signed an official deployment order on Friday to send 400 American military personnel and two Patriot air defense batteries to Turkey as its tensions intensify with neighboring Syria, where government forces have increasingly resorted to aerial attacks, including the use of ballistic missiles, to fight a spreading insurgency.

headline: Kirchner Stumbles Again
text: BUENOS AIRES — It wasn’t the celebration President Cristina Fernández de Kirchner had planned. For months, her government had billed Dec. 7 as the date in which the Clarín Group, the country´s largest media conglomerate, would finally be left with no choice but to dismantle in accordance with a 2009 media law that curtails how many broadcast licenses one company can own. For months, the government billed the date, which it christened as “7D” in copious state advertising, as the dawn of a new day in Argentina.

text: GUILTY PLEA EXPECTED FOR UBS UNIT IN RATE-RIGGING CASE  |  “UBS is in final negotiations with American, British and Swiss authorities to settle accusations that its employees reported false rates, a deal in which the bank’s Japanese unit is expected to plead guilty to a criminal charge,” DealBook reports. In addition, “UBS could face about $1 billion in fines and regulatory sanctions,” according to people briefed on the matter who spoke of private discussions on the condition of anonymity.

headline: Ending a Life, and a Part of Yourself, for the First Time
text: Two hundred meters was all that separated me from an insurgent carrying an AK-47. I sat in a dilapidated brown leather chair, recessed in the shadows of a second-story room in the government complex of Falluja, Iraq. My sights were perfectly centered as I perched my elbows on the desk in front of me. The clear tip traced the center of his chest. He crept around a corner of a mud wall and slowly moved toward our position. Fear built inside me. I hesitantly began to pull the trigger of my M-16.

headline: How Big Is the Budget Hole?
text: Something I’ve been meaning to write: get into a discussion of matters fiscal, especially with conservatives, and you’re bound to have somebody declaring that we have a ONE TRILLION DOLLAR deficit, which means that what Americans want from their government is far more than we can pay for, so we must slash the welfare state, etc.. Also, that the hole is so big that taxing the rich can’t possibly make any real difference (although somehow savaging the poor supposedly will).

To which the owners, not in possession of a deep fryer, could only reply, “No.”

But true to form, he writes, the awards from the Hollywood Foreign Press Association were spread about quite evenly, with “Argo” and “Django Unchained” close behind with five nominations apiece; “Zero Dark Thirty,” “Les Misérables” and “Silver Linings Playbook” each received four. The Globes will be handed out on Jan. 13, with Amy Poehler and Tina Fey as co-hosts of the telecast, a role recently filled by  Ricky Gervais.

headline: A Director Who Prefers Working With Kids (Well, One in Particular)
text: Early in her career, the Swiss-French director Ursula Meier, 41, worked as an assistant to Alain Tanner, whose directorial credits include acclaimed films like “The Salamander” and “Jonah Who Will Be 25 in the Year 2000.” Ms. Meier has so far made only two feature-length films on her own, but both, “Home” in 2008 and now “Sister,” ended up being submitted by Switzerland as that country’s candidate for the Oscar for best foreign-language film.

headline: Keeping Up With the Dodgers
text: If there is one thing the Angels owner Arte Moreno definitely has, it’s a sense of place. There is a reason they are the Los Angeles Angels now and not the bourgeois Anaheim ones. Moreno wanted in on Hollywood, wanted to own and operate a slice of show business. So, in Hollywood, when the Dodgers go flashy by signing Zack Greinke and trading for Adrian Gonzalez and Josh Beckett, the Angels have to throw $125 million at Josh Hamilton.

headline: Google Introduces a New Mobile Ad to Combat Fat Fingers
text: The “fat finger effect” — the theory that people accidentally click on mobile ads because cellphone screens are so small — is one reason mobile ads generally earn less money than ads shown on desktop computers.

headline: Miss Manners on the Best Holiday Visits
text: WITH the holidays upon us, families are crisscrossing the country to visit one another. The likelihood of all this family togetherness devolving into discord is so great it’s become a Hollywood trope. Judith Martin, the arbiter of etiquette known as Miss Manners, dispenses words of advice on how to avoid such scenarios. Below are edited excerpts from a conversation with her on how to be a gracious host and a well-mannered house guest.

headline: Chasing Anchovies on Turkey’s Black Sea Coast
text: “SO you’re here for anchovies,” said the bartender at Sehrazade, a shadowy spot in Unye, Turkey, a smile playing at the corners of his mouth.

headline: Skiing to a Remote Retreat in the Canadian Rockies
text: IN a secluded valley deep in the Canadian Rockies, miles from any road and even farther from the nearest chairlift, sits a luxurious cabin. Inside there’s a sauna, a crackling fire and two chefs laboring in a fully stocked kitchen; outside, trackless powder stretches to the glacier-capped horizons.

headline: Restaurant Report: Le Bec Fin in Philadelphia
text: In 1970, a Frenchman named Georges Perrier opened an opulent little jewel box of a restaurant just off Rittenhouse Square in Philadelphia and astutely named it Le Bec Fin, a French expression that literally translates as the Fine Beak, but that also means the Fine Palate. He quickly seduced the city’s frequently Francophile establishment, and, more important, tutored them in Gallic gastronomy like a stern but conditionally charming headmaster. For almost 40 years, Bec Fin was considered the best restaurant in Philadelphia, and one of the finest French tables in the United States.

headline: A Woman’s Final Wish, Denied by the Church That She Loved
text: Carmen Villegas’s last wish was to lie in repose for just one hour inside Our Lady Queen of Angels. The modest brick church on East 113th Street in East Harlem had been the center of her life since childhood.  When the Archdiocese of New York closed it in 2007, she led a group of the faithful in weekly services on the sidewalk, hoping their prayerful protest would persuade the hierarchy to reopen the sanctuary.

headline: European Leaders Back Common Banking Rules
text: BRUSSELS — European Union leaders pledged on Friday to take further steps to set up common banking rules for the bloc, but they delayed plans for a shared budget for the euro zone nations as pressure appeared to be easing on the single currency.

After all, they have a history  of doing the award shows’ best bits:

headline: At the Panel’s Edge
text: Ellen Forney’s greatest strength as a cartoonist is her gift for explanation — getting information across with vigor, wit and visual inventiveness. That inspiration may have come at an awful cost, she suggests in MARBLES: Mania, Depression, Michelangelo, and Me (Gotham, paper, $20), a memoir of her long tango, or wrestling match, with bipolar disorder. As she explains, her frantic, volatile high moods seemed to fuel her art; her crushing lows made it nearly impossible for her to make it, or do anything else; and the desperately inexact science of medication, she once feared, might rob her of the creativity she cherished. The bulk of “Marbles” documents her wobbly progress toward stability, with interpolated drawings from her journals and occasional side trips into the history of “crazy artists.” It’s not exactly focused, but it’s mostly delightful: Forney switches up the style and layout of her artwork every page or two, and she’s got enough perspective on herself to find some kind of comedy even in painful experiences.
