text: Beware of walking and texting, a look at the new T-Mobile pricing, a quest for smarter, speedier airport security and other consumer-focused news from The New York Times.

headline: Gunmen in Pakistan Kill Women Who Were Giving Children Polio Vaccines
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Gunmen shot dead five female health workers who were immunizing children against polio on Tuesday, causing the Pakistani government to suspend vaccinations in two cities and dealing a fresh setback to an eradication campaign dogged by Taliban resistance in a country that is one of the disease’s last global strongholds.

headline: A Bungalow, Destroyed by Sandy
text: Dear Diary:

headline: Energy Agency Sees Global Coal Boom Unabated, Europe’s Binge Temporary
text: The International Energy Agency’s Medium-Term Coal Market Report, issued today in Paris, is essential reading for anyone wishing to maintain a reality-based view of global trends in fuel use. While many energy forecasts end up wrong, on short time scales like this, that’s less true. [Dec. 19, 7:34 a.m. | Insert | Tom Zeller Jr. has written a useful analysis of the report for Huffington.]

headline: African National Congress Chooses Tycoon as the Party’s Deputy President
text: BLOEMFONTEIN, South Africa — In South Africa, a nation where the gap between the rich and poor yawns wider than just about anywhere in the world, Cyril Ramaphosa might seem an unlikely savior to a political party whose base is the poor. His fortune is estimated to top $500 million. He sits on the board of the mining company whose 34 workers were killed in a harsh police crackdown on an illegal strike protesting low pay and miserable living conditions.

headline: Feeling For | Sebastian Bergne’s Brussels Sprouts Wrap
text: The once-lowly Brussels sprout has become the darling of many a restaurant side-dish menu, but who would have expected it to be the inspiration for wrapping paper? Just in time for the holidays, the London designer Sebastian Bergne offers us the very tasty Brussels Sprouts Wrap, his ode to a vegetable that he thinks many people in the U.K. still “love to hate.” Like many born-again Brussels sprout fans, Bergne understands that it’s all about the cooking, and has printed his favorite recipe — which includes bacon and chestnuts — on the paper itself.

headline: Alex Smith Can Still Win Passer Rating Crown
text: Keep an eye on what San Francisco does with Alex Smith over the next two weeks.

headline: Reaction to Newtown Shootings Spreads to Corporate America
text: 4:43 p.m. | Updated

headline: A Growing List of Gun Victims, and the Mayor’s Demand for a Plan
text: On the same day as the school massacre in Newtown, Conn., another madman attacked little children outside a primary school many thousands of miles away.

headline: Rape Suspects Captured in Record Time, Delhi Police Say
text: Four men have been arrested in the rape of a woman and the beating of her male friend, after the police tracked down the bus in which the assaults took place, Delhi’s police chief said Tuesday.

headline: No Monkey Business: Woman Behind Botched Fresco Restoration Sells Painting on eBay
text: You may not appreciate the handiwork of Celia Giménez, the 80-year-old woman whose unauthorized restoration of a religious fresco turned the face of Jesus into something resembling, say, a monkey in a shearling coat. But like it or not, she is now a professional artist: The Associated Press reported that an original painting by Ms. Giménez, depicting only a rustic scene and no holy figures or primates, had been sold on eBay for about $1,400.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Nielsen Buys Arbitron, and Instagram’s New Ad-Friendly Rules
text: Nielsen Holdings announced Tuesday morning that it would be acquiring Arbitron, the radio ratings company, for $1.26 billion, Michael de la Merced reported. The acquisition price amounts to $48 a share in cash for each outstanding share of Arbitron, or a 26 percent premium to Arbitron’s closing price on Monday. The deal was described by Nielsen as part of its effort to track how people view and listen to media programs, which can be delivered in an increasing array of formats.

headline: The Deal Dilemma
text: First things first: cutting Social Security benefits is a cruel, stupid policy — just not nearly as cruel and stupid as raising the Medicare eligibility age. But sometimes you have to accept bad things in pursuit of a larger goal: health reform should have included a public option — heck, it should have gone straight to single-payer — but a flawed route to universal coverage was better than none at all.

headline: No Shortage of Contenders — for Next Oscar Season
text: Oscar voting began on Monday but with more than two months left in the season, you may already be tired of hearing about the debate over the torture in “Zero Dark Thirty” or the historical accuracy of “Lincoln.”

headline: N.F.L. Playoff Field Will Look Familiar
text: Chase Stuart writes about the historical and statistical side of football at his site, FootballPerspective.com

headline: What We’re Reading
text: Bright Cove: In this week’s video treat, Pascaline Lepeltier, sommelier at Rouge Tomate in New York and friend of the wine panel, demonstrates how to lop off the head of a Champagne bottle using no more than a spoon. — Eric Asimov

headline: Toyota to Pay Record $17.35 Million Fine for Delaying Recall
text: For the fourth time, Toyota has agreed to pay a fine to settle allegations by the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration that the automaker delayed a safety recall.

headline: On Our Radar: A Global Coal Boom
text: Coal will come close to surpassing oil as the world’s top energy source by 2017, the International Energy Agency predicts. Demand for coal will increase in every region of the world except the United States, where the fuel is being pushed out by natural gas, the agency says. [International Energy Agency]

headline: How to Read Like a Master of ‘Meh’
text: Samantha Henig is the magazine’s online editor and writes The Meh List section of The One-Page Magazine..

headline: Peter Kenen, R.I.P.
text: Oh, my — I just got word that my colleague and friend Peter Kenen has died. I’ll try to write more later, but I did write an essay for his festschrift, “The Practical Theorist”, a number of years back. Sad to say, I don’t have an electronic copy; but I can lift the opening from Google Books:

headline: For Potvin, and Rangers Fans, the Chant Endures
text: N.H.L. hockey at Madison Square Garden may seem like a far-off memory now, with more than six months gone since the last time it was played. But the fact remains: the chant is as much a part of the Garden hockey experience as anything.

headline: Musical Moments, Part 6
text: Anthony Tommasini performs favorite classical music moments sent in by readers.

headline: NBC Reporter Describes Captivity in Syria
text: Last Updated, 11:00 p.m. Richard Engel, the chief foreign correspondent for NBC News, and four colleagues were freed on Monday after five days in captivity in Syria, as my colleagues Brian Stelter and Bill Carter report.

headline: Love ’Em While You Can
text: It takes special people to run a bad sports franchise these days, people with superhuman powers of persuasion. During the season, these fine managers must convincingly beg fans: please love our players, invest your emotions — and large chunks of your paychecks — in those wonderful humans wearing our uniform. Please forget that our franchise has not won a championship since, oh, we forget when. Please shell out large sums for tickets and jerseys and the privilege of being associated with us.

headline: France Opens the Door to a Right to Die, but Not Now
text: LONDON — France may become the latest European country to grant a right to die to the terminally ill, after a government-commissioned report on Tuesday opened the door to legalizing assisted suicide.

headline: Obama and Biden to Attend National Prayer Service
text: President Obama and Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. will go to the Washington National Cathedral on Jan. 22, the day after their second inaugural ceremony, to participate in the National Prayer Service, held every four years to commemorate the inauguration of the president.

headline: In Shooting Aftermath, Axelrod Says Focus Should Also Be on Video Games
text: While much of Washington has focused on what to do about guns in the aftermath of the school shooting in Connecticut, at least one adviser to President Obama also wants the country to think about what to do about violent video games.

headline: Musical Moments, Part VI: ‘Clair de Lune’
text: What constitutes a “moment” in music? Some readers cited fairly long passages, even whole movements of pieces, as favorite moments. But BAM (to use the name readers gave for their posts), from Farmington, Conn., pointed to a precise moment toward the end of Debussy’s popular piano piece “Clair de Lune” when a single note is introduced to a chord, resulting in a “subtle change of harmony,” like “the instant of recognizing first love on a moonlit night.” In this video I discuss that moment.

headline: Wal-Mart's Aggressive Corruption
text: TimesCast: President Barack Obama offers a deal over fiscal crisis. | Young adults struggle with homelessness while jobless or underemployed. | David Barstow on how Wal-Mart used payoffs in Mexico.

headline: War of the Words
text: MADRID — A tart pun appeared on a protester’s sign along a Barcelona street last week: “Franco ha Werto.” The idea was that the former dictator General Francisco Franco, who died (“ha muerto”) in 1975, is being recast as Spain’s current education minister, José Ignacio Wert.

headline: Ang Lee’s 3-D Vision
text: With few bankable stars in his new film, the director Ang Lee has been doing many of the press rounds himself for “Life of Pi,” traversing the globe to promote his 3-D story of a boy, a boat and a tiger. We caught up with Mr. Lee recently at the Apple store in SoHo, where he was due for a Q. & A. He had been traveling with the film since its premiere at the New York Film Festival in September, when he admitted to some fatigue. “I thought I was going to get sick,” he said, “but I didn’t have time.”

headline: An Arrest in the Vandalism of Soldera Wine
text: A former employee of Case Basse di Soldera, the great Brunello di Montalcino estate, has been arrested on charges of destroying more than 60,000 liters of wine, the Italian daily Corriere della Sera reported.

headline: Web Sites Offer Free Credit Monitoring
text: Credit Sesame, a Web site that helps people manage their credit, has begun offering its users free credit monitoring, a service that big credit bureaus offer for a fee.

headline: Vice Purchases i-D, the British Style Magazine
text: Vice, the multimedia company known for its in-your-face journalistic style, is expanding into fashion coverage by buying the British style publication i-D magazine.

headline: Top 10 Movies for Grown-Ups, AARP Edition
text: Call me a dinosaur, but I still watch movies in theaters. When I walk into the theater I feel like a kid — because even at the age of 60, I’m the youngest person there. Part of that is, younger people don’t have the emotional ties to movie theaters that my generation does. They’re at home watching on Netflix, or in the case of my kids, on their laptops. And part is selection — I have yet to see a movie with a vampire in a leading role.

headline: The Ethics of Aesthetics
text: Suzy Menkes of the I.H.T. talks to Livia Firth about the Green Carpet Challenge and fashion’s impact on the environment and social justice.

headline: Jefferies Posts $71.6 Million Profit in 4th Quarter
text: The Jefferies Group is ending its life as an independent firm on a pleasant note: with a solid quarterly profit.

headline: Arbitron Deal Would Extend Nielsen’s Reach Into Consumer Habits
text: 7:54 p.m. | Updated Consumers today are gleaners of information, moving swiftly from cellphones to newspapers, tablets to radio and social media to television. The question for advertisers is how to reach them across a fragmented environment.

headline: Williams, Johnson Play Down Rift over Nets Offense
text: 4:49 p.m. | Updated For a few minutes at least, Deron Williams and Avery Johnson found common ground regarding the Nets’ playbook on Tuesday.

headline: Varied Snacks Nudge Children Toward Healthier Eating
text: Brian Wansink and his colleagues at the Food and Brand Lab at Cornell University are known for their targeted research into what nudges us to eat less food. (Wansink is the author of “Mindless Eating: Why We Eat More Than We Think” and the researcher who led the infamous “bottomless soup bowl” experiment.)

headline: For Young Disabled Athletes, a Chance to Glide, and Compete, on the Ice
text: The players arrived at Lasker Rink in Central Park on Saturday morning with the help of wheelchairs, walkers and crutches. Many had to be helped into their pads and then lifted into the bucket seats of narrow aluminum sleds with skate-blades on the bottom.

headline: Manhattan Theater Club and Ars Nova Announce Recipients of Inaugural Commissions
text: Two prominent New York theaters, Manhattan Theater Club and Ars Nova, announced on Tuesday that they have chosen five playwrights as the first recipients of their new Writer’s Room commissions. The commissions are worth between $5,000 and $10,000 a piece and are geared to developing works for possible Off Broadway productions at the theaters. The inaugural commissions will go to Thomas Bradshaw (“Job”), Samuel D. Hunter (“The Whale”), and Sharyn Rothstein (“The Invested”); a fourth commission will be shared by Adam Bock (“A Small Fire”) and Justin Levine (“Bonfire Night”), who are developing a new musical.

headline: Our Sons Are Not Future Killers
text: The Asperger’s stereotype before the shootings in Newtown, Conn., was relatively harmless if inaccurate – that of a quirky, brilliant male unable to read subtle social cues or navigate the world of non-autistic people. Think Sheldon on “The Big Bang Theory” or Abed on “Community.”

headline: Hospitals Fear They’ll Bear Brunt of Medicare Cuts
text: WASHINGTON — As President Obama and Congress try to thrash out a budget deal, the question is not whether they will squeeze money out of Medicare, but how much and who will bear the brunt of the cuts.

headline: Image of the Day: Dec. 18
text: Hindu pilgrims begin congregating at Allahabad, Uttar Pradesh, for the Kumbh Mela.

headline: Dec. 18 Updates on Connecticut Shooting Aftermath
text: Four days after the school shooting in Connecticut took the lives of 20 children and 6 staff members, classes resumed at most Newtown schools on Tuesday and the National Rifle Association broke its silence. “The N.R.A. is prepared to offer meaningful contributions to help make sure this never happens again,” it said in a statement. Also on Tuesday, at least two more funerals were held, and a New York Post editorial echoed Rupert Murdoch’s calls for tighter gun control.

headline: Melville’s About-Face
text: Early in 1864 Herman Melville was one of a number of Northern writers solicited to contribute works to “Autograph Leaves of Our Country’s Authors,” a volume of literary works intended to raise funds for the United States Sanitary Commission. Obligingly, Melville sent in a short poem, “Inscription for the Slain at Fredericksburgh.” But he soon regretted it.

headline: New Leader for Pearson Unit That Includes Financial Times
text: John Ridding will take over as chief executive of the FT Group, a subsidiary of Pearson that includes The Financial Times and half of The Economist, the company said Tuesday.

headline: Some Gun Retailers Make Changes After School Shootings
text: Retailers that sell guns are making some changes after the shooting in Newtown, Conn.

headline: Director of Louvre to Step Down
text: Just days after the Louvre opened its nearly $200-million outpost in the industrial town of Lens in northern France, Henri Loyrette, the Louvre’s longtime director who was a champion of the project, announced his resignation after having run the museum for 12 years.  He plans to leave in April.

headline: Frank Macchiarola, Called the ‘Standard’ for a New York Schools Chief, Dies at 71
text: Frank J. Macchiarola, who was widely regarded as one of the canniest and most effective New York City schools chancellors of the last half-century, died on Tuesday at his home in Downtown Brooklyn. He was 71.

headline: Russia Sends Warships Toward Syria for Possible Evacuation
text: MOSCOW — Russia sent warships to the eastern Mediterranean Sea on Tuesday, the Defense Ministry announced, in what appeared to be preparation for a possible evacuation of Russian citizens from Syria.

headline: Invitation to a Dialogue: Beyond Gun Control
text: To the Editor:

headline: Boehner Plan Addresses Taxes but Delays Fight Over Spending Cuts
text: WASHINGTON — House Republican leaders struggled on Tuesday night to rally their colleagues around a backup measure to ease the sting of a looming fiscal crisis by allowing tax rates to rise only on incomes over $1 million.

headline: Delta, Virgin Atlantic And the Stakes for Fliers
text: Delta Air Lines recently agreed to buy a 49 percent stake in Virgin Atlantic from Singapore Airlines for $360 million. The deal is a boon for both carriers, giving Delta greater access to Heathrow Airport, one of the world’s busiest hubs, and Virgin Atlantic greater capacity to send passengers to New York, one of the most popular international destinations.

headline: Holding All the (Business) Cards
text: A selection of chic cases that aptly balance form and function.

headline: On the Road, With Their Baggage
text: Contrary to what the title and casting might suggest, the Barbra Streisand-Seth Rogen comedy, “The Guilt Trip,” is not “The Shrew and the Cringing Meatball.” There are no screaming accusations, no threats or recriminations, no tearful apologies in this amiable mother-son road odyssey.

headline: The Taming of the Stomach
text: MOTION sickness, as many travelers know all too well, can strike on ships, trains, planes or in a car — whenever the balance center in the inner ear senses motion that the eyes do not. Those mixed signals, which are sent to the brain, can literally be sickening.

headline: Face Time | Cora Keegan
text: Cora Keegan is a fresh new face on the modeling scene, having moved to New York’s East Village not too long ago from her hometown of Las Vegas. Since then she’s done some wonderful work and walked in some big-name fashion shows (Narciso Rodriguez, Jason Wu and Mulberry, to name a few). Her complexion, which is naturally lovely, got the attention of Francesco Clark, the creator and president of the skin care line Clark’s Botanicals, who recently chose Cora to be its brand ambassador. On top of her looks, Keegan has incredible charisma and curiosity. Here, she tells T about her healthy eating habits and the beauty products she’s picked to keep her skin looking radiant.

headline: Brooklyn Ballers
text: New York City's biggest basketball stars have come mostly from Brooklyn.

headline: N.B.A. Pipeline Bypassing New York for New Jersey
text: Ron Naclerio, who decades ago gave his heart to New York City high school basketball, had it broken early this year.

headline: Amgen Agrees to Pay $762 Million for Marketing Anemia Drug for Off-Label Use
text: The biotechnology giant Amgen marketed its anemia drug Aranesp for unapproved uses even after the Food and Drug Administration explicitly ruled them out, federal prosecutors said on Tuesday.

headline: Supreme Court Gun Ruling Doesn’t Block Proposed Controls
text: WASHINGTON — Despite the sweeping language of a 2008 Supreme Court decision that struck down parts of the District of Columbia’s strict gun-control law, the decision appears perfectly consistent with many of the policy options being discussed after the shootings in Newtown, Conn.

headline: The President Negotiates With Himself
text: We have seen this so many times in the past four years that I certainly hope President Obama is not falling for it again.

headline: Cavs’ Varejao Is Invaluable and Tradeable
text: History will remember this era of Cleveland Cavaliers basketball as one of optimistic highs linked to one brief, spirit-crushing interlude — the departure of LeBron James in 2010.

headline: Dead Sea Scrolls Go Digital
text: The Dead Sea Scrolls were buried in caves for centuries, and then enmeshed in controversy over scholarly access since their discovery in the late 1940s. But as of today, some 5,000 high-resolution images of the scrolls are readily available online, thanks to a collaboration between the Israel Antiquities Authority and Google.

headline: How Local Tax Rates Affect High-Income Professionals
text: Jeremy Lin of the Houston Rockets returned on Monday night to Madison Square Garden, which used to be his home court in the days of Linsanity not so long ago. Mr. Lin thrived on the energy of the New York crowd, but one thing he probably doesn’t miss is the taxes.

headline: Two Video Views of Science as a ‘Girl Thing’
text: Some Dartmouth College doctoral candidates doing research in Greenland took offense at the European Commission’s attempt earlier this year at using viral video as a recruiting tool for exciting girls about careers in science. Herewith, “Science: It’s a Girl Thing” [Update, Sept. 9, 2015: The original was pulled; here’s a Young Turks report]:

headline: Samsung Ends Its Push for a European Sales Ban on Some Apple Products
text: Samsung said on Tuesday that it had dropped its request for a ban on sales of certain Apple phones and tablet computers in Europe, a sharp tactical turn in a patent war that the companies have been fighting on multiple fronts around the world.

headline: M.L.S. First Kick on March 2
text: A brief off-season will lead to the earliest start of Major League Soccer, which will begin its 18th season with six games on March 2.

headline: Columbia Gets $200 Million Pledge for Brain Institute
text: Mortimer B. Zuckerman, the real estate developer, owner of The Daily News and philanthropist, has pledged $200 million to endow an interdisciplinary Mind Brain Behavior Institute at Columbia University.

headline: Adam Lanza, Asperger’s and a Misleading Connection With Violence
text: 1. Did Adam Lanza, who authorities have identified as the gunman in Newtown, Conn., ever receive a diagnosis of Asperger’s syndrome?2. If so, would that be relevant?3. And has The Times been scrupulously responsible in the way it has reported on this aspect of Friday’s massacre at the Sandy Hook Elementary School?

headline: Lisa Loeb Explains Her Cameo on the ‘Gossip Girl’ Finale
text: Warning: this post contains spoilers about the series finale of “Gossip Girl.” XOXO.

headline: After Recession, More Young Adults Are Living on Street
text: SEATTLE — Duane Taylor was studying the humanities in community college and living in his own place when he lost his job in a round of layoffs. Then he found, and lost, a second job. And a third.

headline: City in Colorado Is Sued Over a Drilling Ban
text: DENVER — An industry group representing oil and gas companies has sued a city in Colorado that outlawed hydraulic fracturing, saying voters had no right to ban the drilling practice.

headline: Gun Control After Newtown
text: TimesCast Politics: The reaction spreads to corporate America. | Representative Carolyn McCarthy on legislative possibilities. | Is the N.R.A. still a potent political force?

headline: How to Make Those Bundles Neat
text: Making tamales isn’t difficult, but it will go more smoothly, especially for first-timers, with some guidance concerning technique.

headline: Wrapped in Tradition
text: PHOENIX

headline: Spoofing Celebrities in a Weekly ‘Time Machine’
text: A new celebrity-spoofing pop show, “Totally Tubular Time Machine,” will begin weekly performances on Saturday nights on Jan. 19 at New York’s Culture Club, the latest attempt by entertainment producers to develop musical parodies out of hit songs from the 1980s. Among the producers are Robert Watman, the chief executive of ’70s- and ’80s-themed nightclub chains Polly Esther’s and Culture Club, and Denise Fennell and Suzanna Melendez, two of the creators of “Birdy’s Bachelorette Party,” a pop-infused send-up in which real bachelorette parties blended with a fictional one. “Time Machine” will feature actors playing music idols like Madonna, Lady Gaga, Justin Bieber and Britney Spears, with audience members encouraged to ask questions about their personal lives and become celebrity gossipmongers themselves. Ms. Melendez will direct the show.

headline: A First Impression That Lasts
text: FOUR cups of water, a cup of polenta and a lump of butter. Boil over medium heat for 10 minutes as it bubbles like Satan’s private hot tub. Then bring down the flame as low as it goes. An hour later, stir in salt, a spoonful of olive oil and three-quarters of a cup of grated cheese.

headline: F.T.C. Opens an Inquiry Into Data Brokers
text: It’s getting tougher to be a data broker.

headline: U.S. Inquiry of Google Is Expected to Press On
text: WASHINGTON — The Federal Trade Commission is unlikely to finish until January its investigation into whether Google abused its power in the search market, people briefed on the investigation said on Tuesday.

headline: A Fit in New York; Growing Pains in Houston
text: The sense of momentum and excitement that characterized the thrilling rise of Jeremy Lin was evident again in Madison Square Garden on Monday night, but this time he was wearing Houston Rockets red. Lin, an undrafted point guard, came up with a dynamic performance in his new team’s 109-96 victory over the Knicks. His play contrasted sharply with that of Raymond Felton, who not only replaced Lin in New York but seemed to view Lin’s return as a personal challenge, and struggled as a result.

headline: Wheelies: The Money Edition
text: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

headline: Already Criticized, Freeport Deals Raise Questions of Conflicts
text: The brouhaha over Freeport-McMoran Copper and Gold’s recent acquisitions illustrates the sometimes unsatisfying way that corporate law deals with conflicts of interest.

headline: Yanks Abroad: Working for 1860 Munich
text: After more than a year recovering from a knee injury, the American forward Bobby Wood is beginning to hit his stride in a remarkable comeback at 1860 Munich.

headline: Woman in Petraeus Case Won’t Be Charged With Cyberstalking
text: WASHINGTON — Federal prosecutors have informed Paula Broadwell, whose affair with David H. Petraeus led to his resignation as director of the C.I.A., that she will not be charged with cyberstalking.

headline: The Giving Spree | Bobbi Brown
text: Who: The makeup artist and businesswoman Bobbi Brown, who was profiled in “The Mogul Next Door” in T’s spring women’s issue.

headline: It’s Not Just a Job; It’s a Musical
text: In addition to having been recorded by James Taylor, its composer, “Millwork,” a haunting slice of blue-collar melancholia, has been covered by artists from Emmylou Harris to Eddie Vedder, Bruce Springsteen to Bette Midler. But as performed with a gorgeous sorrowful twang by Marie-France Arcilla in “Working: A Musical,” at 59E59 Theaters, this evocative ballad belongs unequivocally to the woman standing before us, a mother of three who toils as an assembly-line steam-press operator in a luggage factory, reflecting on her “wasted” life.

headline: Jefferies’s Exceptionalism
text: Full-year earnings from Jefferies put Wall Street’s dilemma in a nutshell.

headline: United Is Latest Airline to Block Rewards Web Site
text: United Airlines has joined some of its competitors in blocking a third-party Web site that helps consumers track their frequent-flier miles from multiple airlines.

headline: Obama Talks to Pro-Gun Senator; White House Sketches Policy Shift
text: President Obama consulted on Tuesday with a pro-gun Democratic senator who has expressed support for new regulations on firearms as the White House sought to shape a comprehensive response to the massacre of schoolchildren last week in Connecticut.

headline: Photo Replay: December 18
text: A view of the day in sports, including a German Cup soccer match in Gelsenkirchen and perhaps the final day of horse racing at Folkestone in Kent, England.

headline: L’Apicio
text: The team behind Dell’anima and Anfora opens a new spot in the East Village.

headline: The Impact of the  Latest Insider Trading Convictions
text: The convictions of Anthony Chiasson and Todd Newman in a lucrative insider trading case may well send a message to Mathew Martoma, the former SAC Capital portfolio manager, about the risks he runs if he fights similar charges filed against him.

headline: If You Like Ravi Shankar. . .
text: Each week, Val Haller, the founder of the music Web site Valslist.com, matches music from her baby boom generation to music of her 20-something sons’ generation.

headline: Director Named for New Children’s Museum in Harlem
text: The Sugar Hill Children’s Museum of Art & Storytelling, part of a new Harlem development due to open in 2014 that includes affordable housing, has named a director.

headline: Special News Quiz | Farewell, 2012
text: The Year in Rap, from Flocabulary.

headline: ‘The Hobbit,’ Gangster-Style
text: Whenever there’s a lull in Oscarland, the Bagger turns to our pals over at Nextmovie for the latest installment of their series “Rappers Review Movies.”

headline: Aspirin Use Tied to Rare Eye Disorder
text: Regularly taking aspirin may slightly raise the likelihood of developing a degenerative eye condition, a new study found.

headline: No Clear Link Between Cancer and 9/11 Debris, Study Finds
text: Six months after the federal government added cancer to the list of sicknesses covered by the $4.3 billion World Trade Center fund, a New York City health department study has found no clear link between cancer and the dust, debris and fumes released by the burning wreckage of the twin towers.

headline: Anger at Changes on Instagram
text: Instagram, the popular photo-sharing service, was met with anger after changing its terms of service on Monday. The changes will let advertisers in Facebook’s ad network use data and information that users have shared on Instagram, and will also give Instagram and Facebook the right to use its users’ photographs and identity in advertisements. The changes are to go into effect Jan. 16.

headline: Controversial Israeli Embassy Facebook Page Taken Down ‘for Maintenance’
text: The Israeli Embassy in Ireland has temporarily removed its entire Facebook page from the Web, after a controversial Christmas message stating that Jesus would “probably end up being lynched in Bethlehem by hostile Palestinians” if he lived today was posted and then deleted from the account on Monday.

headline: Embracing the Pain, for Science
text: Luiz Rocha, the curator of ichthyology at the California Academy of Sciences, writes from Belize, where he conducts research on one of the world’s most endangered fish, social wrasse.

headline: Indianapolis Orchestra Scores Donations From Team Owners
text: Basketballs and bassoons, goalposts and Gustav Holst, brutal human collisions on grass and intertwining melodies on stage, twirling batons and time-beating batons – none of these things seem to go together. But they do for the sake of Indianapolis. The city’s orchestra said the owners of the local professional football and basketball teams had each promised to donate $750,000 to help the financially ailing orchestra survive.

headline: The Weapons Continuum
text: In the wake of the school massacre in Newtown, Conn., and the resulting renewed debate on gun control in the United States, The Stone will publish a series of essays this week that examine the ethical, social and humanitarian implications of the use, possession and regulation of weapons. Other articles in the series can be found here.

headline: Congolese Rebel Leader Is Acquitted of War Crimes
text: PARIS — The International Criminal Court in The Hague said Tuesday that it found testimony against a former rebel leader “too contradictory and too hazy” to convict him of a gruesome 2003 attack on a village in the Democratic Republic of Congo in which some 200 people were hacked to death and female survivors were raped and held in camps as sex slaves.

headline: PATH Service to Return to Hoboken Wednesday
text: Seven weeks after Hurricane Sandy dumped an estimated 500 million gallons of water in Hoboken, crippling its transportation network and leaving tens of thousands of commuters casting about for alternative modes of travel, officials said Tuesday that PATH train service was at last set to resume.

headline: Joseph Stettinius Jr.
text: Mr. Stettinius, 50, is the new chief executive of Cassidy Turley, a commercial real estate services firm based in Washington, succeeding Mark Burkhart in early October. Mr. Stettinius, who is also the president, helped to establish the company, which was created in 2008 through the merger of four former Colliers firms. Since then, more than 10 additional firms have joined the company.

headline: Building Sales Surge in SoHo, Especially on the Side Streets
text: The ornate cast iron SoHo building known as the King of Greene Street traded hands last week for $41.5 million. The deal was a 47 percent increase in value from when the property at 72-76 Green Street, designed by Isaac F. Duckworth, last sold five years ago. It is also the latest in a torrent of building sales that have taken hold this year in SoHo.

headline: Debating the Power of the N.R.A.
text: The Times’s Nicholas Confessore talks about whether the National Rifle Association is still a potent political force.

headline: A Fond Last Look at  “Gossip Girl”
text: The CW series “Gossip Girl” was not great TV. Far from it. And as it said goodbye this week, this cult show deserved to be remembered not only for the previously unknown young actors it turned into stars, but for its knowing embrace of the fashion world over its six seasons. Where else but on “Gossip Girl” would designers like Suno, Zuhair Murad, and Rag & Bone be regularly name-checked, or teenage girls be found fretting over whether to wear Oscar de la Renta or Marchesa to a garden party? On Monday, the show’s last episode, in which “Gossip Girl” was revealed as Dan Humphrey (played by Penn Badgley), prompted its fans — and some of its stars — to take to Twitter, a few with theories about the significance of the finale’s date and many with their own alternate endings.

headline: Gun-Focused Reality TV Shows Get New Scrutiny After Newtown Killings
text: The topics of guns and gun use continue to resonate across the media landscape in the days after the elementary school massacre in Newtown, Conn. One show that may be affected is the popular reality show “Sons of Guns,” which is shown on the Discovery Channel.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Crime Maps and Internet Radio Trouble
text: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. See more here.

headline: The Will to Compromise
text: Last week, I wrote a post expressing a certain pessimism about a major fiscal cliff deal, arguing that that because the baseline for negotiations includes a large tax increase no matter what, any deal beyond that all-but-guaranteed tax hike would give partisans on both sides a plausible reason to feel like losers: Republicans because the tax number required to make a deal would look so huge (upwards of $1 trillion and all that), and Democrats because any entitlement cuts at all would seem like a concession too far given the relative strength of their negotiating position.

headline: An Interview With Rep. Carolyn McCarthy
text: Representative Carolyn McCarthy of New York talks about gun control legislation.

headline: When Trade Shows Were Both Grand and Central
text: In the preservation debate over Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s rezoning plan for east Midtown, one of the most conspicuous landmarks is a building that hasn’t existed for almost half a century, yet still exerts a strong influence over the neighborhood.

headline: Pogue’s 12 Days of Gadgets: The Leash Camera Strap
text: The first Noël, the angels did sing — but that was a long time ago. Today, the angels might note instead that it’s Day 9 of Pogue’s 12 Days of sub-$100 Gadgets for the holidays.

headline: Obama's New Offer in Fiscal Talks
text: The Times's Jeremy W. Peters discusses President Obama's latest offer in ongoing fiscal negotiations with Speaker John A. Boehner.

headline: Arts as Antidote for Academic Ills
text: Stationed in front of one of his large self-portraits, the artist Chuck Close raised his customized wheelchair to balance on two wheels, seeming to defy the laws of gravity.

headline: TimesCast Politics: Gun Control After Newtown
text: Chip Somodevilla/Getty Images

headline: McElroy, Not Tebow, Replaces Sanchez
text: For nearly four seasons, the Jets have begun each week with one constant in their starting lineup: through thick and thin, Mark Sanchez has been the quarterback.

headline: I Couldn't Breathe
Scans of Mummy Show Pharaoh’s Slit Throat
text: The pharaoh Ramses III, who ruled Egypt in the 12th century B.C., had a scheming wife who was intent on murdering him to bring their son to the throne. The plot is documented in an ancient papyrus, but the exact circumstances of Ramses’ death have been unclear.

headline: Cerberus to Sell Top Gunmaker
text: In the wake of the Newtown, Conn., killings, the investment firm Cerberus Capital Management said it would sell its stake in Freedom Group, the country's largest gunmaker.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Pakistan and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Pakistan, Syria, Ukraine and Afghanistan.

headline: The Unfolding Story of Maps: Dragon Warnings to Smartphone Screens
text: Simon Garfield’s past work includes a whole book about the color mauve and last year’s delightful “Just My Type,” an ebullient survey of facts about fonts and typography. Now he turns his attention to a somewhat mustier subject: the history of cartography. He is most engaging on the most checkered parts of that history.

headline: The Gentleman Action-Hero From Hawaii
text: It was odd but gratifying to see the way Senator Daniel Inouye, who died yesterday in Washington at age 88 after serving Hawaii in Congress for more than 50 years, was praised in multiple dimensions today.  The New York Times obituary stressed his “quiet,” “courtly,” “soft-spoken” nature, painting a portrait of a deferential man plucked from obscurity now and then for various important jobs (like the Watergate and Iran-Contra hearings). Awestruck bloggers and commenters at sites like Reddit, meanwhile, focused more on the senator as an action hero, someone out of a Quentin Tarantino movie.  Many of them had apparently just found out what Mr. Inouye did in World War II—an amazing story that was in all the obits and on his Medal of Honor citation, and is now in Badass Digest, under the headline “The Time Daniel Inouye Pried a Grenade From His Severed Arm.”

headline: Preparing for Spontaneous Travel
text: WHEN Sam Shank began HotelTonight, a last-minute hotel booking app, two years ago, he thought its typical user would be a business traveler in need of a place to lay her head.

headline: Facebook Responds to Anger Over Proposed Instagram Changes
text: Jeremy Pinnix, an app developer in Spring Hill, Tenn., has been a regular user of the photo-sharing service Instagram since it was introduced in 2010, posting pictures of his family, local scenery and favorite moments.

headline: An American-Made Business Model Has Less Success Overseas
text: For years, the titans of finance have held out the promise that they could export their business model overseas and mint billions in the process. Yet, there are increasing signs that global deal-making was always a myth.

headline: U.N. Presents Grim Prognosis on the World Economy
text: World economic growth has weakened substantially this year and faces the confluence of a triple threat — the so-called fiscal cliff in the United States, the European debt crisis and a sharp slowdown in China, the United Nations said in a report released on Tuesday. The worst case, the report said, could be a new global recession that mires many countries in a cycle of austerity and unemployment for years.

headline: Étude on Aging, Its Graces, Its Indignities
text: A masterpiece about life, death and everything in between, Michael Haneke’s “Amour” takes a long, hard, tender look at an elderly French couple, Georges and Anne — played by two titans of French cinema, Jean-Louis Trintignant and Emmanuelle Riva — in their final days. Set in contemporary Paris, it begins with the couple’s front door being breached by a group of firemen. One moves through the rooms, delicately raising a hand to his nose before throwing open several large windows. He may be trying to erase the smell that probably brought the firemen there in the first place and which has transformed this light, graceful, enviable apartment into a crypt.

headline: Without Any Fanfare, Jennifer Egan Switches Publishers
text: The Pulitzer Prize-winning novelist Jennifer Egan quietly switched publishers this summer, joining Scribner, a division of Simon & Schuster, from Alfred A. Knopf, a division of Random House.

headline: A Trio of Hot Chile Extracts
text: A stocking stuffer with a warning label? “Use one drop at a time” is what it says on the little bottles of fiery chile extracts made by the Henry Family Farm in the Shenandoah Valley of Virginia. There are three varieties: yellow fatali African habañero delivers fruity notes with the heat; green Jamaican lime chile is tart; and the orange naga jolokia ghost chile of India is rich, and the hottest of the trio. They are easier to use in this liquid form (think cocktails) than as a ground spice.

headline: A Bakery Reaches to West Village
text: Zachary Golper and Kate Wheatcroft, above, who opened their bakery, Bien Cuit, a year and a half ago in Boerum Hill, Brooklyn, are already adding a Manhattan satellite. The new bakery in the West Village is more rustic than the original, and has space for cafe tables and chairs. Differences also emerge in the menu, for Mr. Golper, the baker, is featuring several items not sold in Brooklyn. A sleek bûche de Noël, lacquered in dark chocolate and buttoned up with tiny macarons, is filled with insanely rich chocolate mousse. Though scarcely eight inches long, it would satisfy six people. Potpies filled with artichokes, potatoes, olives and cheese, or, more typically, with chicken, sport flaky peek-a-boo lattice tops. The galette des rois, or kings’ cake for Epiphany, is classically done, with a lush almond filling. There are sandwiches on Bien Cuit breads and salads, too.

headline: Kenneth Chenault’s Crisis Years
text: It is sure to come up: What did Kenneth I. Chenault do during the bailouts?

headline: Improvisation, With Prompting to Set the Mood
text: On a recent rainy afternoon, I was sitting at an old-fashioned desk in a bare concrete loft in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, listening intently to the members of So Percussion, joined by Grey McMurray on electric guitar, rehearse a composition called “Toothbrush.” The piece will form part of their show “Where (we) Live,” which opens on Wednesday at the Brooklyn Academy of Music Harvey Theater.

headline: At Grand Central, Produce by Eli Zabar
text: The produce stands at both ends of the Grand Central Market are now in the hands of Eli Zabar, who has turned each one into a garden of delights. Lavish displays of vegetables, fruit and flowers practically overflow their open shelves. The produce is more abundant near the street entrance, while at the stand near the inner station door you’ll find olives, nuts and dried fruits; packaged precut vegetables to grab and go; and soups, juices, dips and dressings. The prices are lower than in all of his other stores, Mr. Zabar said. An example? Mangoes are $2.99 instead of $3.99 to $4.99, and peeled and sliced they are $6.99 a pound, compared with $8.99 uptown.

headline: A Do-Your-Own Quick Bite From Spain
text: The pintxo, a quick bite (pronounced PEEN-cho), is the Basque country’s contribution to the tapas bar. Now San Sebastián Food, a company based in Spain that sells food products and arranges culinary tours of the Basque region, has introduced a kit for preparing and serving them. You get two slate serving boards, ceramic bowls and glasses; four ceramic spoons; and a bunch of wooden skewers, all designed for various tidbits like garlic shrimp, potato tortilla and anchovies skewered with olives and peppers. There is also a recipe booklet, an apron and a small skillet.

headline: After the Deluge, an Outpouring of Support From Afar
text: CHICAGO — Business was brisk on Sunday afternoon at the Empty Bottle, a homey bar and a celebrated alternative-music nightclub in the Ukrainian Village neighborhood here. As 1 p.m. approached, patrons lined the bar and milled around throughout the club space, cradling beers and coffees. Above the bar an ancient rivalry was unfolding: the Green Bay Packers were overpowering the Chicago Bears.

headline: Senate Democrats Press House for Broader Domestic Violence Bill
text: House Republicans are expected to bring a new version of the Violence Against Women Act to the House floor sometime before the end of the year. But Democrats warned on Tuesday that if the bill passed in the House, it would not stand a chance in the Senate.

headline: Off the Menu
text: Opening

headline: Cranberry Conserve: Tart Option to the Can
text: CRANBERRY sauce can be so divisive. Guests at your Christmas table might be surprised to see it homemade because they are so accustomed to the canned version: that tubular, semi-opaque gelatin with a flavor far from the taste of fresh cranberries.

headline: Calendar
text: Christmas and Seafood

headline: School Officials Look Again at Security Measures Once Dismissed
text: In 1999, the year of the shootings at Columbine High School in Colorado, Heath E. Morrison was a middle school principal in Maryland, shocked by what he and his colleagues saw as a terrible but unique episode. “There was this intense desire not to overreact,” said Mr. Morrison, who is now superintendent of the Charlotte-Mecklenburg school district in North Carolina.

headline: Goodbye, Government, Under Either Fiscal Plan
text: As President Obama and Speaker John Boehner negotiate to resolve the looming fiscal crisis, Americans might be forgiven for believing that the nation’s problems would be solved if they could only agree on whether to raise $1.2 trillion or $1 trillion in new taxes over the next 10 years, or whether they should cut $850 billion rather than $1.2 trillion more in government spending.

headline: Excerpt: 'The Great God Pan'
text: Keith Nobbs, left, and Jeremy Strong in a scene from Amy Herzog’s drama at Playwrights Horizons.

headline: Awaiting Merger With Random House, Penguin Settles E-Book Case
text: 10:53 a.m. | Updated Penguin, trying to ensure a clean slate before its planned merger with Random House, announced on Tuesday that it was settling a lawsuit brought by the Justice Department over the pricing of e-books.

headline: Obama Inaugural Committee Announces Some Parade Participants
text: Two dozen musical bands and other organizations – including the Kamehameha Schools Warrior Marching Band from President Obama’s native Hawaii, the Lesbian and Gay Band Association from St. Louis, and the Boston Crusades Drum and Bugle Corps – have agreed so far to march in the nation’s 57th inaugural parade on Jan. 21, Mr. Obama and his inaugural planners said Tuesday.

headline: Racing Pulses Before and After ‘Zero Dark Thirty' Screening
text: WITH a truncated schedule for this year’s Oscars nominations and an unusually high number of late-arriving films, even the most celebrified of industry insiders have yet to see all the big awards hopefuls.

headline: M.T.A. Chief Will Resign as He Looks at Mayoral Bid
text: Joseph J. Lhota, the chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, has informed the Cuomo administration that he is stepping down from his position, according to four people with direct knowledge of his plans. He is expected to resign on Friday, allowing him to pursue a candidacy for New York City mayor as a Republican.

headline: Coming Back: Making Slow Progress
text: In a second installment, Kissam Avenue residents on Staten Island are trying to piece their lives back together seven weeks after Hurricane Sandy. Some are making more progress than others.

headline: Victories Are Small, but So Are the Setbacks
text: Marisa and Claudio Finco stood in what was once the living room of their two-bedroom house on Kissam Avenue on Staten Island, taking stock of progress since Hurricane Sandy ravaged their neighborhood.

headline: Bronx Judge Is Censured by Judicial Commission
text: The Bronx surrogate judge was censured by the State Commission on Judicial Conduct for failing to take appropriate action after learning that one of his appointees had collected unauthorized and excessive fees, the commission announced on Tuesday.

headline: Court Limits Questioning of Motorists by the Police
text: Police officers in New York may not ask drivers or passengers during a routine traffic stop whether they have a gun or any other weapon unless the officers have a “founded suspicion” of some criminal behavior, the state’s highest court said in a decision released on Tuesday.

headline: Building Body Parts With Software
text: Good news: Maybe people are not so different from machines after all.

headline: A Suburban Wasteland in Virginia Gets a Modern Urban Feel
text: MERRIFIELD, Va. — To see Merrifield, Va., today, with its sleek white Target, its narrow 1920s-style streetscape of specialty food shops along Glass Alley and the rest of the $542 million mixed-use Mosaic District is to nearly forget this unincorporated area’s former life as an uninviting industrial suburban crossroads.

headline: Hedge Fund in Middle of Argentine Debt Battle
text: Gramercy Funds Management is not exactly a household name in the investing world. But in recent weeks it has emerged as a major player in Argentina’s long-running battle against creditors.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 2,151 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans recently:

headline: Details Are Revealed in Brothers’ Terror Case
text: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla. — One of two brothers accused of conspiring to use weapons of mass destruction traveled to New York City last month to scout targets for his plan to set off a bomb, a federal prosecutor said in court on Tuesday.

headline: Debacle Is Just Another Drop in Jets’ Bucket
text: For a franchise that had already given the N.F.L. an owner who implored his players to show the world they were “not a bunch of horses’ asses,” a man so desperate to get away he resigned as “HC of the NYJ” moments before he was about to be introduced as the head coach, and, a mere three weeks ago, an entirely new category of ineptitude — the butt-fumble — it might be difficult to recognize rock bottom.

headline: The Fight for Aleppo
text: A sustained and pitched battle between rebel fighters and government forces has left Aleppo in ruins.

headline: Rubble and Despair of War Redefine Syria Jewel
text: ALEPPO, Syria — Inside the classrooms where they once studied, the boys darted like a pack. Their banging and clanking could be heard for a city block.

headline: Syria’s Largest City, Reshaped by Scarcity and Violence
text: Winter is descending on Aleppo, where an urban battle is being waged between rebels and the military of President Bashar al-Assad.

headline: Obama’s Weakness on Treaties
text: Washington

headline: The Puzzle of Black Republicans
text: Philadelphia

headline: Dietary Seat Belts
text: Here’s some good news: Seat belts save lives[1] . So do vaccinations. The world’s population is living longer. The childhood obesity rate has declined[2] in parts of the United States.

headline: North Carolina: Brigadier General Faces Court-Martial
text: Brig. Gen. Jeffrey A. Sinclair, a former deputy commanding general for the 82nd Airborne Division, will face a court-martial early next year on sexual misconduct charges, including forcible sodomy involving a subordinate, officials at Fort Bragg announced on Tuesday. The nine charges against General Sinclair also include having sex with a captain in Afghanistan, threatening the officer if she ended their affair and misusing travel funds. Supporters of General Sinclair, including his wife of 27 years, have acknowledged that he had an affair, but they say the relationship was consensual and did not involve coerced sex. General Sinclair is scheduled for arraignment on Jan. 22.

headline: For Dickey, Warm Memories, if Not of Final Days
text: The long and multilayered drama between R. A. Dickey and the Mets, having consumed much of the team’s winter preoccupations, seemed at last to find a sort of closure Tuesday afternoon.

headline: The Emperor of All Identities
text: Washington

headline: After Three Strokes, Keeping a Clear Focus
text: It was February 2003, and Fabienne Kirk was waiting for a friend at a restaurant on West 23rd Street in Manhattan.

headline: Comments on Israel by Top Contender for Defense Secretary Are Scrutinized
text: WASHINGTON — With Chuck Hagel, a former senator from Nebraska, emerging as a front-runner to be President Obama’s next secretary of defense, critics are taking aim at his record on Israel as well as remarks he made about pro-Israel lobbying groups in Washington.

headline: Monks Lose Relevance as Thailand Grows Richer
text: BAAN PA CHI, Thailand — The monks of this northern Thai village no longer perform one of the defining rituals of Buddhism, the early-morning walk through the community to collect food. Instead, the temple’s abbot dials a local restaurant and has takeout delivered.

headline: For Modernizing Thais, Monastic Life Loses Allure
text: Buddhist temples are growing lonely in rural Thailand as consumer culture rises.

headline: Knicks Closer to Getting Stars on Court Together
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — The Knicks do not lead the N.B.A. in candor or availability, and as a result, insight into injuries is often hard to come by. When Jason Kidd had back spasms earlier this season and missed four games, he was never around to talk about his ailment until he returned in a victory over the Charlotte Bobcats.

headline: Law Firms Are Accused of Aiding Chinese Immigrants’ False Asylum Claims
text: They invented woeful tales of persecution for their Chinese clients. Prepped them on how to lie about having had a forced abortion. Even tutored them on religion.

headline: Killer’s Mother Was Shot 4 Times, Official Says
text: Inside Adam Lanza’s family home in Newtown, Conn., his path of devastation seemed coldly calculated, from his mother’s bedroom, where she lay in bed with four bullets to her head, to the badly damaged computer hard drive.

headline: Pussy Riot, Tupac and Putin
text: Moscow

headline: Experts Warn of Budget Ills for the State, Lasting Years
text: New York State faces long-term budget problems that are compounded by the teetering finances of its local governments, an aging infrastructure and the possibility of severe cuts in federal funding, a panel of fiscal experts said Tuesday.

headline: Panel Assails Role of State Department in Benghazi Attack
text: WASHINGTON — An independent inquiry into the attack on the United States diplomatic mission in Libya that killed four Americans on Sept. 11 sharply criticized the State Department for a lack of seasoned security personnel and for relying on untested local militias to safeguard the compound, according to a report by the panel made public on Tuesday night.

headline: The Yawning Loophole in the Gun Laws
text: Pressures from unexpected quarters continued to build on Congress to strengthen the country’s porous gun laws. Pro-gun legislators expressed support for stronger rules. A prominent private equity firm announced that it was divesting itself of the company that makes the Bushmaster rifle, which was used in the mass shooting of 20 children and seven adults in Connecticut on Friday.

headline: A Basketball Star and His ‘Twin’ Sell Insurance
text: LOS ANGELES CLIPPERS player Chris Paul has an impressive record for assists, or passing the ball to a teammate who scores, including leading the N.B.A. in assists for two consecutive seasons beginning with the 2007-8 season. Now State Farm is introducing an advertising campaign featuring Paul that promotes its agents as being willing to assist, too.

headline: Why We Need Sandy Relief Now
text: Within days after Hurricane Katrina devastated the Gulf Coast in 2005, Congress approved more than $62 billion in emergency relief. It is now more than seven weeks since Hurricane Sandy hit the Northeast, and Congress is just beginning to consider President Obama’s request for $60 billion to restore damaged areas of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut. As with Katrina, Congress should now move swiftly to provide the full package of relief to help the region recover.

headline: Lin, Playing for Houston, Remains Son of New York
text: During his astonishingly rapid rise early this year, Jeremy Lin became the nation’s favorite underdog and a hero to many ethnic Chinese, including some who had never watched basketball. The cheers for Lin were perhaps loudest three miles south of Madison Square Garden in Chinatown, where his newfound fans packed restaurants and bars to watch him turn the also-ran Knicks into prime-time fodder.

headline: President Obama Offers a Deal
text: No sooner did President Obama offer Speaker John Boehner a more-than-generous budget deal to avoid the so-called fiscal cliff than Mr. Boehner invoked what he called “Plan B.” After arguing, absurdly, that the president’s plan was unbalanced, Mr. Boehner offered an even cushier alternative for high-income taxpayers that would raise the threshold for higher tax rates to $1 million and preserve expiring tax cuts for the heirs of multimillion-dollar estates.

headline: Prison Could Be Productive
text: How can incarceration change so that people are improved by the experience, rather than harmed and hardened?

headline: Decline in Child Obesity
text: To the Editor:

headline: Theories of Intelligence
text: To the Editor:

headline: Agricultural Research
text: To the Editor:

headline: Taking Steps to Avert Mass Shootings
text: To the Editor:

headline: Irish Government Set to Allow Abortion in Rare Cases
text: DUBLIN — The Irish government said Tuesday that it was preparing to allow abortion under limited circumstances in an effort to comply with demands by the European Court of Human Rights to clarify the country’s legal position on the issue.

headline: In Russia, Calls for a Halt to Adoptions by Americans
text: MOSCOW — Some Russian lawmakers are calling for a ban on adoptions of Russian children by American citizens, in a bid to toughen their response to a new United States law that seeks to punish people from Russia who are accused of violating human rights.

headline: Russian Soccer Fans Marching Backward to Intolerance
text: A year in which racism and xenophobia have marred European soccer has brought another brazen act of intolerance. The largest fan club of Zenit St. Petersburg, the two-time defending Russian champion, has demanded that the team include no black or gay players.

headline: Obama Facing Critical Choice After Shooting
text: WASHINGTON — For President Obama, the massacre of schoolchildren in Connecticut has upended standard political calculations and has presented a choice that goes to the heart of his approach to governance, not just on guns but also on issues like climate change, immigration and even taxes.

headline: Broad Gun Control Efforts Introduced in Wake of Shooting
text: The first concrete responses to the massacre in Newtown, Conn., began emerging on Tuesday, as state leaders proposed measures to curb gun violence, corporations distanced themselves from an event that has traumatized the nation and the White House pointed to gun control measures that President Obama would champion in the months ahead.

headline: Once Proudly Web Only, Shopping Sites Hang Out Real Shingles
text: Andy Dunn was fierce about the Internet-only model of his apparel company, Bonobos, after helping to found it in 2007. He gave a speech, “The End of Apparel as We Know It,” arguing that stores were a bad economic decision. As he told a news channel in 2009: “We keep men out of retail stores when we know that men fundamentally don’t enjoy shopping.”

headline: Facing the Unendurable, Families Lay to Rest Two Children, Both 6
text: NEWTOWN, Conn. — They were so young that their lives were defined by small, fleeting enthusiasms.

headline: Sometimes, Memories Play Tricks on You
text: “I don’t remember that.”

headline: One of a Deadly Seven
text: Administrivial Good Deed Fundraising Alert! Have you ever wanted to participate in one of those nifty puzzle hunts, like the MIT Mystery Hunt, but live too far away? Puzzazz, a puzzle app development company would like to make puzzle hunts available to one and all, and they’re running a Kickstarter campaign to help fund it. Pledge a little (even as little as $1.00 pledge gets you swag!) or a lot to help get this project off the ground and you too might be able to enjoy the creative puzzles made by some of the best talent in the business. During the meanwhile, watch the video at the top of the project’s page for more information, as well as to see a meta puzzle starring some familiar faces.

headline: Corrections: December 19, 2012
text: INTERNATIONAL

headline: Sanchez’s Fall Is Clear; His Future Isn’t
text: Every interception Mark Sanchez threw, every terrible decision that he made Monday night, doubled as a challenge to the Jets’ front office. Cut me, Sanchez almost seemed to be daring them.

headline: Spy Suit Against Army Workers Is Cleared
text: Several activists from Washington State can continue with a lawsuit accusing two civilian employees of the United States Army of spying on organizers of protests against the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan, a federal appeals court ruled on Monday.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Congressional Negotiators Drop Ban on Indefinite Detention of Citizens, Aides Say
text: WASHINGTON — Lawmakers charged with merging the House and Senate versions of the National Defense Authorization Act decided on Tuesday to drop a provision that would have explicitly barred the military from holding American citizens and permanent residents in indefinite detention without trial as terrorism suspects, according to Congressional staff members familiar with the negotiations.

headline: The Instagram Muddle
text: Our story so far: Instagram, the filter-and-share photo app that was recently bought by Facebook for $1 billion, changed its privacy policy on Monday. The new one says:

headline: Deaf Officers Step in Where Police Work Counts on Eyes More Than Ears
text: OAXACA, Mexico — When the police officer spotted the man acting suspiciously, pacing erratically with an odd look on his face, he immediately called for backup. That is, he spun around in his chair at the police command center here and rapidly motioned to a colleague in sign language.

headline: Nets’ Williams Continues to Be Haunted by Team That Traded Him
text: It was not the Nets’ playbook that lost Tuesday night, or the apparent philosophical difference between their head coach and their leading star. But the Nets did lose again, a result that can only heighten whatever tensions may linger.

headline: Mets Closer Francisco Has Elbow Surgery
text: The Mets announced Tuesday night that closer Frank Francisco had surgery to remove a bone spur from his right elbow. Francisco should be able to begin throwing in six weeks, and the Mets said they expected him to be ready for opening day.

headline: Alex Moulton, Creator of Quirky Small-Wheeled Bike, Dies at 92
text: Alex Moulton, a British automotive engineer who created a small-wheeled bicycle that fired a trend in the 1960s and became the forerunner of the collapsible, portable bikes of today, died on Dec. 9 in Bath, England. He was 92.

headline: China: A Rising Party Leader Is Elevated Yet Again
text: A Communist Party star, Hu Chunhua, has been appointed party chief of Guangdong Province, which is central to China’s export economy and has been a laboratory for more open economic policies since 1979, Xinhua, the state news agency, reported Tuesday. Mr. Hu, 49, was party chief of Inner Mongolia and was given one of 25 Politburo seats during the leadership transition in November. Party insiders had said Mr. Hu — a protégé of Hu Jintao, the former general secretary of the party, who is not related — would most likely be appointed to Guangdong to give him experience in a coastal economic powerhouse before he ascends further. He has a chance of being appointed to the Politburo’s elite Standing Committee in 2017. His closest rival, Sun Zhengcai, was posted in November to Chongqing, the booming southwest municipality once run by Bo Xilai, the disgraced party aristocrat.

headline: Congo: Two Rebel Leaders Hit With Financial Sanctions
text: The United States blacklisted two senior leaders of the M23 movement, a Congolese rebel military force, accusing them of recruiting child soldiers and obstructing peaceful resolution of the chronic conflict in the Democratic Republic of Congo. Under sanctions imposed by the Treasury Department, any property held by the two, Col. Baudoin Ngaruye and Col. Innocent Kaina, that is within jurisdiction of the United States government is frozen, and no Americans can conduct transactions with them. The Treasury’s action reflects increased international pressure on the M23 group and its leadership, which has been implicated in widespread rights abuses by investigators at the United Nations. And according to Reuters, the United Nations reported that the Lord’s Resistance Army, commanded by Joseph Kony, was responsible for more than 180 attacks and that rebels had committed some 126 rapes in an eastern town.

headline: A Methodical Governor Is Tested by a Heart-Wrenching Ordeal
text: HARTFORD — The panicked and desperate family members had waited for hours at the firehouse with the Christmas tree sale. It looked as if they would be there through the night when Gov. Dannel P. Malloy huddled in the parking lot with the director of the Connecticut State Police, Col. Danny Stebbins.

headline: Venezuela: Chávez Develops Infection After Surgery
text: President Hugo Chávez has come down with a respiratory infection as he seeks to recover from a complicated procedure for cancer, a government official in Caracas said Tuesday. The official, Ernesto Villegas, the information minister, said doctors detected the infection on Monday and “proceeded immediately” to treat it. “It has been controlled,” he said. He added that Mr. Chávez was in stable condition. The president is in a hospital in Havana, where he had the operation last week. Officials have said that he may be too sick to return to Venezuela to begin a new six-year term on Jan. 10.

headline: Kenya: Somali Refugees Are the Target of a Roundup
text: The Kenyan government posted a notice in newspapers on Tuesday asking all Somali refugees in the country to report to camps along the Kenya-Somalia border. “The government of Kenya has decided to stop reception, registration and close down all registration centers in the urban areas,” the notice said. Kenyan security forces have blamed ethnic Somalis for a recent spate of fatal grenade attacks and attacks on churches. The attacks began after Kenya sent troops into Somalia last year in the most extensive military operation in Kenya’s history. Hundreds of thousands of Somali refugees live in Kenya, many of them concentrated in forlorn camps along the border, but thousands also live in the capital, Nairobi.

headline: Accounts of a Siege in Syria Differ on Rebel YouTube Channels and British Television
text: As my colleagues Liam Stack and Hania Mourtada reported, Syrian activists said last week that members of a pro-government militia known as the shabiha had massacred dozens of civilians this month in the village of Aqrab, northwest of the city of Homs, just outside the town of Houla.

headline: Canada: Three Arrested in Syrup Warehouse Theft
text: The police in Quebec arrested three men on Tuesday in the theft of about six million pounds of maple syrup from an unguarded warehouse in St.-Louis-de-Blandford, southwest of Quebec City. The warehouse is operated by the Federation of Quebec Maple Syrup Producers, a marketing agency, as part of its “global strategic maple syrup reserve.” The thefts, which had begun a year earlier, ended in July. The investigation recovered about two-thirds of the stolen syrup in other parts of Canada and in the Northeastern United States, the authorities said. The police were searching for five other men who are suspects.

headline: Cancer Among 9/11 Workers
text: Cancer rates among rescue and recovery workers were not statistically higher than those in the general populaiton.

headline: Lawyer Says Ritual Circumcision Is Protected Activity
text: A lawyer for Orthodox Jewish groups asked a federal judge on Tuesday to throw out a New York City regulation requiring parents to sign a consent form before their infant sons undergo a form of Jewish ritual circumcision in which the circumciser uses his mouth to remove blood from the incision.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, Dec. 19, 2012
text: We left everything to get our dignity. This is the price we have to pay, and it is a cheap price to get our freedom from the tyrant.

headline: Unclassified Version of the Accountability Review Board Report
text: Findings from an independent inquiry into the attack on the United States diplomatic mission in Libya that killed four Americans, including Ambassador J. Christopher Stevens.

headline: Word of the Day | generate
text: generate •\ˈje-nə-ˌrat\• verb

headline: Live as Long as an Olympian
text: Olympic athletes are not like the rest of us. Most of them live longer, for one thing, as two revealing new studies found. But not all Olympians enjoy that bonus. Certain sports, the studies suggest, may be better than others when it comes to extending lifespan, a finding that has broad implications for those of us who have no expectations of ever being an Olympian.

headline: After Criticism, Public Library Offers Peek at Renovation Plans
text: In the 10 months since the New York Public Library announced plans for a $300 million renovation of its Fifth Avenue flagship building, scholars and writers have accused the library of abandoning its commitment to research and questioned how the circulating library across the street could be shoehorned into a treasured landmark.

headline: How the N.R.A. Rates Lawmakers
text: The National Rifle Association gives members of Congress a grade ranging from A to F.

headline: To Japan-China Row, Add One Potential Provocateur
text: HONG KONG — The idea that armed conflict could break out in the Pacific over a handful of godforsaken islands is almost unthinkable, not only for the violence involved but also for the potentially calamitous economic and political repercussions. Political leaders, military officials and security analysts can barely utter the W-word out loud for fear they might be unbottling the genie.

headline: What’s On Wednesday
text: 9 P.M. (BBC America) THE HOUR Bel (Romola Garai) and Freddie (Ben Whishaw, above) try to persuade Randall (Peter Capaldi) to shelve a story on anti-nuclear policy in favor of one that would reveal the secret behind the hold of Cilenti (Vincent Riotta) over the most influential men in London. But the offer of an exclusive interview forces Hector (Dominic West) to choose between running the piece or protecting the man who saved his life. Meanwhile, Bel’s relationship with Bill (Tom Burke) deepens, irritating Freddie, whose marriage to Camille (Lizzie Brocheré) is suffering. Hector and Marnie (Oona Chaplin) find a moment of long-overdue honesty. And the bond between Randall and Lix (Anna Chancellor) deepens as new information about their past surfaces.

headline: BBC’s Leaders Faulted as Lax in Handling Sex Abuse Crisis
text: LONDON — Lax leadership hampered by “rigid management chains” left the British Broadcasting Corporation “completely incapable” of dealing with the sexual abuse crisis that has shaken the network, in the words of an exhaustive report released Wednesday.

headline: Brutal Punctuation
text: THEY pop up all the time in Quentin Tarantino’s movies as a kind of visual punctuation for his elaborate plots: scenes of startling, outlandish violence, often grotesquely amusing but often so graphic you want to turn away. “Sometimes it’s meant to be fun, sometimes it’s meant to be horrifying,” he said, speaking days before the Newtown killings and the subsequent cancellation of the Los Angeles premiere of"Django Unchained.” “It just depends on the moment and the mood.”

headline: News Quiz | December 19, 2012
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper. Good luck!

headline: IHT Quick Read: Dec. 19
text: Aleppo, Syria’s largest city and the bloodied stage for a battle now running into its sixth month, is slipping into disaster. C.J. Chivers reports from Aleppo, Syria.

headline: Ex-Dictator’s Daughter Elected President as South Korea Rejects Sharp Change
text: SEOUL, South Korea — With the election of Park Geun-hye as president on Wednesday, South Korea extended the tenure of its staunchly pro-American governing party and handed power to the daughter of South Korea’s longest-ruling dictator, the first woman to win the post in a deeply patriarchal part of Asia.

headline: ‘Breakfast at Tiffany’s’ and ‘The Matrix’ Among Movies Added to National Film Registry
text: Holly Golightly, Billie Dawn, “Dirty” Harry Callahan and Neo are all guaranteed a piece of cinematic immortality: the movies that committed those classic characters to celluloid, along with motion pictures like “3:10 to Yuma,” and “Anatomy of a Murder” have been selected for inclusion in the National Film Registry, the Library of Congress is to announce on Wednesday. Among the 25 films that the congressional librarian, James H. Billington, said in a statement were chosen “as works of enduring importance to American culture,” are “Breakfast at Tiffany’s,” the Blake Edwards romantic comedy; “Born Yesterday,” the George Cukor screwball farce; “Dirty Harry,” the Don Siegel thriller starring Clint Eastwood; and “The Matrix,” the first entry in the Wachowskis’ futuristic action-adventure.

headline: Test Yourself | Math, Dec. 19, 2012
text: Test your math skills with this question created by Pete Diamantis at Math for America from the article “Holiday Boxes on Stoops Bring Reports of Thefts.”

headline: Exploring the Possibilities of Math in a New Museum
text: In “Opening the Doors to the Life of Pi: Museum of Mathematics at Madison Square Park,” Edward Rothstein reviews the newly opened Museum of Mathematics.

headline: God Save the British Economy
text: Entering the Bank of England is like walking back in time to the old British Empire. Its brass door is attended by the Pinks, men in black hats and pink tailcoats. Vast meeting rooms are decorated with richly colored carpets, high ceilings with gold filigree and ornate furniture. Between rooms, the marble floors bear monetary-themed mosaics. One depicts the development of the British pound. Elsewhere, the mosaics take the form of constellations — a reminder that the empire and its economy once dominated everywhere you could see the stars at night.

headline: What Will You Remember Most From 2012?
text: What national, international, cultural and personal events in 2012 stand out most for you? Why?

headline: 2 Former Porsche Executives Charged With Market Manipulation

headline: Older People Become What They Think, Study Shows
text: All of us have beliefs — many of them subconscious, dating back to childhood — about what it means to get older. Psychologists call these “age stereotypes.” And, it turns out, they can have an important effect on seniors’ health.

headline: Fifty Shades of Santa
text: I know I am about to shock and disappoint you, but I can live with my secret no longer: For many years I had an affair with a married man from out of town. I knew it was wrong, but I was a single woman, lonely, and it was the holiday season.

headline: When Your Broker Doesn’t Really Represent Your Interests

The second time around she decided to hire a seasoned company that specializes in selling small financial services businesses. This broker had great public relations and a history of having sold many businesses.

headline: Turkey’s Nagging Whodunit
text: ISTANBUL — I’ve long suspected that governments cling to conspiracy theories like some children cultivate imaginary friends. It’s a way of coping with events outside their control. If only reality were as dramatic or as clear-cut or even as fun as the fantasy.

headline: UBS’s Record Settlement Over Rate Rigging
text: UBS PAYS $1.5 BILLION FINE OVER RATE RIGGING AS UNIT PLEADS GUILTY  |  The Swiss bank UBS announced a record settlement with global authorities on Wednesday over its role in a scheme to manipulate interest rates. The bank is paying a combined $1.5 billion in fines, and its Japanese subsidiary is pleading guilty. “The UBS subsidiary, which agreed to plead to a single count of wire fraud, is the first unit of a big bank to agree to criminal charges in more than a decade,” DealBook reports.

headline: Quentin’s World
text: THE road of excess leads to the palace of wisdom, Blake wrote, and for the last few decades no one in Hollywood has followed that road more assiduously than Quentin Tarantino. His movies are famous for their violence and bloodshed; their blaring soundtracks; their offbeat, Pinteresque dialogue; their startling performances from actors you had almost forgotten about; and their encyclopedic range of references to other movies, especially schlocky ones. He spent his formative years — the period when everyone else was in film school — working as a clerk in a video store, and it shows. His films are apt to allude to Godard in one frame and a movie like “Candy Stripe Nurses” or “Dead Women in Lingerie” in the next.

headline: Exploring the Mekong’s Uncertain Future
text: Picture a river that has catfish the size of bears. With a giant freshwater stingray that could blanket a king-size bed and weighs as much as a buffalo.

text: Knight Capital, the stock market-making firm that nearly collapsed last summer after a $440 million trading glitch, has reached an agreement to merge with Getco, the Chicago-based high-speed trading firm.
