headline: Rallying Around Tebow, as Jets Run From Him
text: If Tebow had been given the chance to do something — anything — all the fans and pundits and talking heads would have been screaming for a change at the slightest hint of success. So, while Tebow raised a ruckus merely by stripping off his shirt to jog off the field on a rainy day at training camp, Sanchez remained the undisputed starter. He held on as captain of the Titanic right to the bitter end, the Jets resisting any urge to save themselves by jumping in a lifeboat piloted by Tebow. Paul Newberry, The Associated Press

headline: Haggling Over Hagel
text: JERUSALEM — For the last seven years I’ve been running a feature called The Israel Factor as part of my blog. It is a monthly survey of Israeli experts on U.S.-Israeli relations. When relevant, these experts have been asked to rank prospective candidates for the U.S. presidency as “good” or “bad” for Israel.

headline: Newtown Massacre Changes Plans at Movie and TV Studios
text: LOS ANGELES — When news broke about the massacre in Newtown, Conn., on Friday, the USA cable channel jumped into action. Using key words like “shooting,” “school” and “children,” executives reviewed scripts and identified problematic episodes of shows like “Law & Order: Special Victims Unit” and “NCIS” that were about to run.

headline: The Colors of Travel 2012
text: Explore the places we visited last year, from Maine to Russia, through the colors they revealed.

headline: Putin Under Fire From International Rights Groups
text: LONDON — An alliance of international human rights and citizen action groups has accused Vladimir V. Putin of cracking down on Russia’s civil society since he returned to office as president in May.

headline: Finding a Long Shot in Mexico
text: Arriving on assignment in San Juan Teotihuacan, Mexico, I expected to see the ancient Pyramid of the Sun — the largest structure in the area — dominating every vista.

headline: One Night in Bethlehem
text: Christmas offers an almost delirious range of subjects for children’s books, from the obvious Santa Claus and reindeer to the decoration of trees, the singing of carols and the proliferation of battery-operated presents. But telling stories about the origins and meaning of the holiday for very young children is a bit more daunting.

headline: A Writer’s Crash Course in Films (and Casting)
text: Lucy Alibar, a playwright who wrote the screenplay for the indie contender “Beasts of the Southern Wild” with the film’s director, Benh Zeitlin, is from a small rural town in the panhandle of Florida. How small and rural?

text: Anthony Tommasini performs favorite classical music moments sent in by readers.

headline: Iraqi President to Get Care in Germany
text: BAGHDAD — Jalal Talabani, the president of Iraq, will be flown to Germany for medical treatment for a stroke suffered this week, officials said on Wednesday. The president, 79, was said to be in “stable” condition, and the decision was announced after medical specialists from abroad were dispatched to the hospital to assess the possibility of sending him out of the country for further treatment.

headline: Counting Those Who Matter
text: OF all the hefty fashion tomes that land with a thump in bookstores at this time of year, the vanity monographs and the oh-please-not-another-one biographies of Coco Chanel and Diana Vreeland have nothing on a good survey of designers who matter.

headline: On Our Radar: The Train to Nowhere
text: The head of a Toronto company explains why it had a train haul biodiesel back and forth over the United States border in 2010 without unloading it: to make several million dollars generating renewable energy credits under the Environmental Protection Agency’s green fuels program. [CBC]

headline: A Conservative Whose Supreme Court Bid Set the Senate Afire
text: Robert H. Bork, a former solicitor general, federal judge and conservative legal theorist whose 1987 nomination to the United States Supreme Court was rejected by the Senate in a historic political battle whose impact is still being felt, died on Wednesday in Arlington, Va. He was 85.

headline: Kodak to Sell Digital Imaging Patents for $525 Million
text: Eastman Kodak once described the sale of 1,100 digital imaging patents as a windfall that could prop up and even save the beleaguered company.

headline: Jackson Blames Cast Member for His ‘Saturday Night Live’ Expletives
text: Given the panoply of colorful language that Samuel L. Jackson has used in his film career it would not seem to require much effort to get him to enunciate another expressive word of the 4-, 8- or 12-letter variety. But after two (or possibly one and a half) vulgarities slipped past his lips on “Saturday Night Live” over the weekend, Mr. Jackson suggested in an interview Tuesday night that they were the fault of an “S.N.L.” cast member who may have missed his cues.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: LA Weekly: Southern California is fixated on healthy eating, you say? Maybe. But the place also happens to have a golden abundance of fried chicken. — Jeff Gordinier

headline: Obama Chosen as Time Magazine’s Person of the Year
text: In a choice likely to surprise few, Time magazine has named the newly re-elected President Obama as its Person of the Year for building through his winning coalition a presidency that “spells the end of the Reagan realignment that had defined American politics for 30 years.”

headline: Scientists See Big Impacts on U.S. Ecosystems from Global Warming
text: A new analysis by dozens of scientists provides a useful update on measured and anticipated impacts of human-driven climate change on ecosystems from western forests to coastal waters. The report, “Impacts of Climate Change on Biodiversity, Ecosystems, and Ecosystem Services,” is one of a suite of studies feeding into what will be the third National Climate Assessment, an overarching analysis of impacts on everything from transportation systems to public health. (Periodic assessments were requested by Congress in 1990; the previous two are here.) The previous two reports were the subject of political and legal tussles.

headline: What’s Your Favorite Holiday Christmas Book?
text: Gretchen: Each year, my mother gives my daughters a Christmas picture book, so we have a large collection. A friend asked which book was my favorite, and I had a lot of trouble deciding.

headline: E-Commerce, With Bricks and Mortar, Too
text: After years of eschewing bricks-and-mortar locations as old-fashioned, suddenly e-commerce zealots are finding out something simple: customers really, really like to try on clothes.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Hollywood Meets Real Violence and Anger at Instagram
text: What was once unthinkable is now almost routine for studio and network executives as they prepare contingency plans for programming after tragedies like the massacre in Newtown, Conn., write Brooks Barnes and Bill Carter. At USA Network, executives used keywords to search for terms like “children” and “killing” to find and postpone sensitive episodes. The incident has also sparked a discussion about hypocrisy within the entertainment business, which is seen as largely liberal and supportive of gun control but makes its bread and butter on violent images.

headline: Russia Vote Favors Ban on Adoptions by Americans
text: MOSCOW — The Russian Parliament on Wednesday overwhelmingly voted in support of a bill that would prohibit the adoption of Russian children by American citizens, though it was unclear if President Vladimir V. Putin would allow the ban to go forward.

headline: Increase in Base Subway Fare and 30-Day Pass Is Approved
text: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority voted unanimously on Wednesday to raise the base fare on subways and buses by a quarter, to $2.50, and to increase the cost of a 30-day MetroCard by $8, to $112.

headline: Dec. 19 Updates on Connecticut Shooting Aftermath
text: Funerals and wakes were held on Wednesday for at least six victims of Friday’s school shooting in Newtown, Conn. Detectives continued to search for a possible motive. In Washington, President Obama  ordered  Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. to develop a multifaceted response. The president also said he would submit broad new gun control proposals to Congress no later than January.

headline: Musical Moments, Part VII: Brahms
text: Brahms prefaces his Intermezzo in E-flat (Op. 117, No. 1) with a quote from a short poem, a sad Scottish lullaby, sung by a mother who is comforting a weeping child. And this intermezzo begins like a gentle lullaby. But a reader from Beachwood, Calif., loves the moment in this piece, a short transitional phrase, when the music turns mysterious and troubling. I agree, and I discuss it in this video.

headline: 12-12-12 Producers Say Concert Brought In $50 Million
text: The 12-12-12 benefit concert at Madison Square Garden last week has raised about $50 million for people affected by Hurricane Sandy, the producers announced on Tuesday night. They said that they expected more money to flow in over the coming weeks from the sales of albums, merchandise and more donations, and that the first $50 million in aid would be distributed immediately.

headline: From Selling T-Shirts to Collecting Awards
text: Lucy Alibar, the co-writer of “Beasts of the Southern Wild,” has explained how casting Quvenzhané Wallis, who was 6 at the time of filming even though the part of Hushpuppy initially called for an 11-year-old, changed the whole tenor of the script. As Ms. Alibar and her co-writer, the director Benh Zeitlin, discovered, it’s one thing to say, as Hushpuppy’s father does, “I’m worried about you because you’re so stupid,” to a preteen; quite another when she’s a tiny girl.

headline: A Bloody Price in Syria

headline: Piers Morgan Shows Disgust While Interviewing Gun Owners’ Advocate
text: Anybody who has been watching “Piers Morgan Tonight” on CNN since the shootings at the Sandy Hook elementary school could discern he is no fan of guns, but on Tuesday night he made it clear that he doesn’t much like the people who own them either.

headline: U.N. Seeks New Aid for Syria Crisis and Predicts 1 Million Refugees by Mid-2013
text: GENEVA — The United Nations appealed on Wednesday for $1.5 billion in new aid to handle the humanitarian crisis created by mounting violence in Syria, and it predicted that the number of refugees would double to more than one million in the next six months.

headline: Look of The Moment | Ladies in Red

Here, Anne Hathaway is coming up roses in a vintage velvet Mafalda sheath; Rihanna cozies up in a cardinal feathered fur, enhanced with a sexy red lip; and Beyoncé Knowles wears a trompe l’oeil bustier dress by Markus Lupfer in Miami.

headline: A Wave of Start-Ups Helps Small Companies Outsource Their Tasks
text: Small-business owners are like Swiss Army knives: expected to handle dozens of specialized tasks without falling apart. But even the sharpest entrepreneurs have it tough this time of year — inevitably, some will outsource part of their workload to other enterprising people.

headline: Michael Haneke Finds His Brando
text: In the competition for the Oscar for best foreign-language film, the early favorite is the Austrian submission, Michael Haneke’s “Amour,” and not just because it won the top prize at the Cannes Film Festival last spring and nearly swept the European Film Awards this month. The story of a Parisian couple, retired music teachers in their 80s, confronting their own decline also features powerfully affecting performances by Jean-Louis Trintingant and Emmanuelle Riva.

headline: Exploring a Proposed Carbon Diet for American Power Plants
text: Earlier this week, Daniel Lashof of the Natural Resources Defense Council blogged about the group’s new proposal for cutting carbon dioxide emissions from American power plants — not just at the plant itself but by creating incentives for end users to conserve electricity. That means you, me and the businesses that we rely on. Here’s the opener, a link to the rest and a short Q&A I did with Dan to dig in on a couple of questions:

headline: How Small Businesses Use Fiverr, TaskRabbit and Other Services

headline: Capturing America, Fact by Fact

More households have dogs as pets than cats, but cat lovers are more likely to have multiple pets. And more foreigners visited New York (9.3 million) than any other American city (Los Angeles was a distant second with 3.7 million).

text: Some of the year’s best book covers, chosen by people in and around the world of graphic design.

headline: Obama Vows Fast Action in New Push for Gun Control
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama declared on Wednesday that he would make gun control a “central issue” as he opens his second term, promising to submit broad new firearm proposals to Congress no later than January and to employ the full power of his office to overcome deep-seated political resistance.

headline: Image of the Day: Dec. 19
text: A winter morning on the banks of Yamuna River, in Delhi.

headline: Designers on Their Favorite Book Covers of 2012
text: We recently asked people in and around the world of graphic design to name one of their favorite book covers from 2012 and briefly describe its appeal. We didn’t allow for repetition of choices, but several of those polled mentioned the cover chosen by the designer Jon Gray, who writes:

headline: Hundreds of Political Parties Are India’s Pressure Valve Against Unrest
text: NEW DELHI — It is hard to say something nice about any Indian political party, especially within 900 words, but in my latest “Letter From India” column I argue that an important factor in maintaining a largely peaceful India is that there are so many political parties. The 2009 general elections were contested by 364 parties, many of them representing in very specific ways the concerns, biases and hopes of various communities. As the power of older, larger parties erodes, the many smaller parties are gaining influence because the major parties need them in order to assemble a governing coalition.

headline: A Look at Fine and Dandy
text: At Fine and Dandy, a men’s wear store in midtown, it’s not quite all vintage — only the ideas.

headline: House Democrats Call on Boehner to Take Up Gun-Control Issue
text: House Democrats, coming out in force in the wake of the Newtown, Conn., shooting massacre, called on House Speaker John A. Boehner to bring a ban on high-capacity ammunition magazines to a vote by Saturday as a first step in a broader effort to rein in guns next year.

headline: Forget In-Flight Movies; Preflight Is the Way to Go
text: Imagine that before you leave for the airport to board a flight, you receive an e-mail with a video embedded that greets you by name and supplies details on the departure and boarding time and gate, and arrival time and gate, as well as information on mileage-boosting offers and upgrade costs for the route.

headline: Why Gun ‘Control’ Is Not Enough
text: In the wake of the school massacre in Newtown, Conn., and the resulting renewed debate on gun control in the United States, The Stone will publish a series of essays this week that examine the ethical, social and humanitarian implications of the use, possession and regulation of weapons. Other articles in the series can be found here.

headline: Obama Speaks on Gun Control
text: In the aftermath of a deadly shooting at Sandy Hook Elementary in Newtown, Conn., President Obama addresses the nation on gun control and also talks about ongoing fiscal negotiations.

headline: Anti-Casual Friday Headquarters
text: ONE recent afternoon, two men were sitting in facing chairs in the small below-grade space that serves as the storefront of Fine and Dandy, a shop specializing in the accouterments of the well-dressed life.

headline: Musical Moments, Part 8
text: Anthony Tommasini performs favorite classical music moments sent in by readers.

headline: Ballet Opening Night at La Scala Is Canceled as Chorus Members Go on Strike
text: Chorus members at La Scala theater in Milan, protesting having to wear costumes and make gestures without extra pay during a dance performance, have gone on strike. The strike forced the cancellation on Wednesday of opening night of Berlioz’s “Roméo et Juliette,” with choreography by Sasha Waltz. The choristers said the extra duties violate their contract, but management argued they were no more than normally called for, according to Italian new reports. James Conlon, the American conductor and the music director of the Los Angeles Opera, was to have led the performance. Strikes or the threat of labor action at La Scala cause frequent disruptions, usually in opera productions.

headline: The Newtown Aftermath
text: David Brooks: Gail, since the shootings in Newtown, Conn., the debate has gone off on two tracks, the gun control track favored mostly by liberals and the mental health track favored mostly by conservatives. If you don’t buy my distinction, just compare the editorials and op-eds that have appeared respectively on our own fine pages and the comparable pages of The Wall Street Journal.

headline: Is the Second Amendment Absolute?
text: Opponents of gun control—of even the most reasonable, basic safeguards like background checks or limits on the size of ammunition clips—were silent directly after the Newtown shooting. But they are starting to emerge from hiding, and most of what they’ve had to say suggests they’ve learned little, if anything, from the killings.

headline: Musical Moments, Part 9
text: Anthony Tommasini performs favorite classical music moments sent in by readers.

headline: Army Seeking Death Penalty in Massacre of 16 Afghans
text: SEATTLE — The United States Army will seek the death penalty against Staff Sgt. Robert Bales, who is accused of killing 16 civilians in Afghanistan, officials said on Wednesday.

headline: Below the Line: Bringing Light to ‘Lincoln’
text: When charged with the task of determining how to frame and light a president he saw as “iconic,” the cinematographer of “Lincoln” often decided on one way: iconically.

headline: New Label Alert | Roomeur
text: Best friends since studying fashion design together in Israel, Hagit Kassif and Omer Pozner had always planned on starting a label together. Different paths brought them to New York — Diane von Furstenberg for Kassif, Elie Tahari for Pozner — then separated them again when Kassif headed to London to start a master’s degree at the Royal College of Art. But six months into her program, she called Pozner and told him it was time to stop dreaming and get to work. “I said, ‘Quit your job, this is it,'” she remembers. Reunited in New York and designing under the name Roomeur, the pair have just shown their first collection for prefall. Inspired by photographs of Frida Kahlo as well as by her artwork, it imagines the feminist icon transplanted to modern-day Gotham and in possession of, among other things, a brocade shorts suit and a draped black silk frock with a vibrant botanical print and a wrapped waist. “We were thinking of the two sides of Frida’s character,” Pozner says. “The hard and the soft.”

headline: At News Conference, Reporters Skip Past Gun Control and Face Instant Criticism
text: 3:34 p.m. | Updated The harshest judges of those in news media are often others in the news media, and, with the benefit of Twitter, that intrajournalistic watchdog role can be performed simultaneously with the journalism being criticized.

headline: The Kitten Makes Way for the Cat
text: SCARLETT JOHANSSON doesn’t like making pat statements about herself. She tends to pepper her insights with swear words, self-deprecation or a short, raspy laugh. But during a 90-minute interview recently there was one truth that she acknowledged simply: She did a lot of growing up in the three years between her Broadway debut, at the age of 25 in “A View From the Bridge,” and her return this month as Maggie in another American classic, Tennessee Williams’s “Cat on a Hot Tin Roof.”

headline: Test Run: Addappt, a Connected Address Book for iPhones
text: You’ve probably heard this story before: A friend loses his cellphone, buys a new one and then invites hundreds of people on Facebook to join a group called “Lost my phone. Post your numbers please.”

headline: Morgan Stanley Makes Donation After Sandy Hook Massacre
text: Morgan Stanley, where three employees lost family members in the Sandy Hook Elementary School shootings, has donated $150,000 to charities honoring the victims.

headline: Family Sentenced to Prison in England Over Forced Labor
text: DUBLIN — Five members of an Irish family who enjoyed lavish lifestyles from the proceeds of forced labor were jailed in England on Wednesday after a three-month trial.

headline: 4 Are Out at State Dept. After Scathing Report on Benghazi Attack
text: WASHINGTON — Four State Department officials were removed from their posts on Wednesday after an independent panel criticized the “grossly inadequate” security at a diplomatic compound in Benghazi, Libya, that was attacked on Sept. 11, leading to the deaths of Ambassador J. Christopher Stevens and three other Americans.

headline: Former Wisconsin Coach Climbs Back Into Hot Seat
text: MADISON, Wis. — Two squares of sticky tape remained where Bret Bielema’s nameplate had been. Barry Alvarez moved back into the head football coach’s office overlooking Camp Randall Stadium at the University of Wisconsin this month for convenience, but he has no plans to settle in. Alvarez took only one significant thing from his athletic director’s office with him: a glass candy jar filled with gumballs of assorted colors.

headline: Remembering the Passion of a Teacher Who Died Protecting Students
text: STRATFORD, Conn. — She has come to be known for her instinctive heroism in saving the lives of many of her young students, but at her funeral on Wednesday, Victoria Soto, a first-grade teacher at Sandy Hook Elementary School in Newtown, was remembered in a way that only those closest to her would have known.

headline: General Grant’s Infamous Order
text: “I, a peaceable, law abiding citizen, pursuing my legitimate business at Paducah, Kentucky, where I have been a resident for nearly four years, have been driven from my home, my business, and all that is dear to me, at the short notice of twenty-four hours; not for any crime committed, but simply because I was born of Jewish parents,” said a young merchant named Cesar Kaskel to reporters in late December 1862. The accompanying headline disclosed why Kaskel was so abruptly ordered out. It read: “Expulsion of Jews from General Grant’s Department.”

text: To the Editor:

headline: Surge of Sales for Jenni Rivera; Swift Remains No. 1
text: Taylor Swift has topped the Billboard album chart once again, with her album “Red” (Big Machine) holding at No. 1 for a fifth week with 208,000 sales, according to Nielsen SoundScan. The new album by Bruno Mars, “Unorthodox Jukebox” (Atlantic), also did well, opening at No. 2 with 192,000.

text: PARIS — François Hollande began his campaign for the French presidency in January with the declaration that he and his Socialist party were prepared to break from policies that they said had contributed to the financial crisis, notably promising a separation of investment banking from consumer banks.

text: Last Updated, Thursday, 2:20 p.m. NBC News announced on Wednesday that an employee who had been kidnapped in Syria last week along with the correspondent Richard Engel arrived safely in Turkey, as more details of the hostage drama were released by opposition media activists.

headline: ‘Messiah,’ Informed by History
text: December is a decidedly gluttonous month for “Messiah” fans in New York, who can feast on myriad versions offered by ensembles across the city. The New York Philharmonic wades energetically into the “Messiah” fray each season with five consecutive performances, a testament (not that any proof is needed) to this oratorio’s enduring popularity.

text: Oh, holy night — you’ve forgotten your phone!

headline: Buying a Gift Card, and Checking It Twice
text: Although they may lack the drama of a brightly wrapped package, gift cards remain popular holiday presents for finicky or otherwise hard-to-buy-for recipients. The National Retail Federation deems them the “season’s hottest gift.”

headline: Shopping Snapshots: Dec. 20
text: Hot pink isn’t waiting until spring to show off; for Barneys New York, pajamas in bulldog, fox, leopard and anchor print; basic pieces by Daryl K will now be carried by Steven Alan stores; and for nails, try silver glitter.

headline: Europe Proposes New Tobacco Rules
text: BRUSSELS — Health warnings should cover 75 percent of cigarette packs but governments should also have leeway to require plain packaging, the European Commission said Wednesday.

headline: Israel Defies Allies in Move to Bolster Settlements
text: JERUSALEM — Israel pushed ahead with aggressive new settlement building on Wednesday, brushing aside a growing chorus of international opposition, including criticism by its Western allies, that the move threatened to destroy the peace process with the Palestinians.

headline: Don’t Worry: Donkey Cheese Is Still Available
text: Donkey cheese is irresistible, or at least articles about it are. A week ago, several British newspapers, notably The Daily Telegraph and The Daily Mail, reported that Novak Djokovic, the top-ranked men’s tennis player, had bought the entire world supply of pule, a Serbian donkey cheese, for his restaurants.

headline: New Online Privacy Rules for Children
text: In a move intended to give parents greater control over data collected about their children online, federal regulators on Wednesday broadened longstanding privacy safeguards covering children’s mobile apps and Web sites. Members of the Federal Trade Commission said they updated the rules to keep pace with the growing use of mobile phones and tablets by children.

headline: Wedding Q. and A.

headline: Has Fiction Lost Its Faith?
text: A seminary student has an affair with an insurance adjuster he met in an office building near Riverside Church; then they go their separate ways — and that’s the whole story.

headline: Bork and Liberalism
text: The death of Robert Bork at the age of 85 has naturally turned attention back to the famous hinge moment in his long career — the confirmation hearings that transformed him from “Robert Bork, illustrious conservative legal scholar” into “Robert Bork, icon of the culture wars,” and made his last name a synonym for the demagogic, by-any-means-necessary takedown of a judicial nominee. How much of a turning point the hearings really represented in our progress toward polarization can be debated, but they certainly changed the way law and politics intersect: Everything from the shape of confirmation hearings to the career choices of would-be jurists to the trajectory of the modern conservative legal movement has been stamped by Bork’s defeat at the hands of Ted Kennedy, Joe Biden, and a united front of liberal interest groups.

headline: Challenging France to Do Business Differently
text: PARIS — Louis Gallois, one of France’s most influential industrialists, knew he was about to make waves for the country’s Socialist president.

headline: An Undersea Grotto to Soothe Restless Children
text: It’s a struggle faced by many bleary-eyed parents: getting their children to sleep at night. The Tranquil Turtle from Cloud B is here to lend a helping flipper by combining three sleep aids in one: a plush toy, a night light and a music box.

headline: Polymers Make These Gloves Hot
text: Electrically heated gloves can save your fingers in extreme cold, but there are two challenges in making them. One is getting the heat evenly distributed. The other is preserving battery power so they stay hot as long you need.

headline: Aleppo’s History Under Threat
text: Last Updated, Thursday, 9:59 a.m. As my colleagues Chris Chivers, Tyler Hicks and Ben Solomon report in text, photographs and video, civilians are suffering from shortages of food and medicine, among other hardships, in Aleppo, Syria’s largest city, which is being torn apart in urban warfare between rebels and forces loyal to President Bashar al-Assad.

headline: 2 Former UBS Traders Exposed in Rate-Rigging Case
text: As the Justice Department announced its case against UBS, prosecutors also took aim at two former UBS trader at the center of the rate-rigging scheme, the first criminal action against individuals tied to the broad investigation.

headline: Obama and Boehner Diverge Sharply on Fiscal Plan
text: WASHINGTON — Hopes for a broad deficit-reduction agreement faded on Wednesday as President Obama insisted he had offered Republicans “a fair deal” while Speaker John A. Boehner moved for a House vote as early as Thursday on a scaled-down plan to limit tax increases to yearly incomes of $1 million and up, despite Senate opposition and Mr. Obama’s veto threat.

headline: Ally Repays Last of Debt Borrowed Under F.D.I.C. Guarantee
text: Ally Financial, the former G.M.A.C., said Wednesday that it had repaid the last of the debt it had borrowed in response to the financial crisis under a Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation program.

headline: Turner Steps Out of Awkward Pre-Firing Tap Dance
text: The end of an N.F.L. season is always awkward for coaches who know they will be fired shortly after the final whistle. Most choose to deal with it by not dealing with it, deflecting all questions and refusing to acknowledge the pink-slip-clad elephant in the room.

headline: F.D.A. and States Discuss Regulation of Drug Compounders
text: SILVER SPRING, Md. – The Food and Drug Administration conferred with public health officials from 50 states on Wednesday about how best to strengthen rules governing compounding pharmacies in the wake of a national meningitis outbreak caused by a tainted pain medication produced by a Massachusetts pharmacy.

text: Got a bunch of duplicate entries in the address book of your Web-based mail service, especially for people who use more than one e-mail address? Gmail, Yahoo Mail and Hotmail all include tools that let you weed out or merge the dupes.

text: Q.

headline: Karmazin Leaves Sirius XM Earlier Than Expected
text: Sirius XM Radio has appointed James E. Meyer as its interim chief executive officer, the company announced on Wednesday, as Mel Karmazin steps down from the top spot earlier than expected.

headline: In Most Rich Countries, Women Work More Than Men
text: In most of the developed world, women spend more time working each day than men do, if you include unpaid work.

headline: Man Fatally Beats Grandmother With Tusk, Police Say
text: Updated, Thursday | The police said on Wednesday that an emotionally disturbed man in Hamilton Heights fatally bludgeoned his grandmother and, as officers attempted to arrest him, struck a police officer in the head with a plastic elephant tusk, injuring him.

headline: Commercial Buddhism in Thailand
text: Buddhism has been a way of life in Thailand for centuries, but inside the most popular temples is a trend that critics call “fast-food Buddhism.”

headline: Beauty Gift Guide: Saving Santa’s Back
text: Is your loved one’s stocking stuffed with a few too many oranges? Try these pint-size, prettifying gifts instead.

headline: I.R.S. Leader Says Inaction on Tax Will Affect Returns of Millions
text: The acting commissioner of the Internal Revenue Service said Wednesday that if Congress fails to act this year to prevent the alternative minimum tax from expanding, as many as 100 million households — of the 150 million total taxpayers — will be unable to file their taxes on time as the I.R.S. scrambles to reprogram its computers. Some 30 million tax-filers will see an unexpected tax hit.

headline: On the Path of a Next Rising Star
text: THE invitation to HBO’s “In Vogue: The Editor’s Eye” party had arrived, but Kilo Kish was lacking adequate formal wear. There was a time when she might have gone in her street clothes — say, a vintage tank top with an image of Marvin Gaye, stonewashed jeans and socks patterned with marijuana leaves.

headline: Smile, and Say ‘Android’
text: “Android camera.” Wow, that has a weird ring, doesn’t it? You just don’t think of a camera as having an operating system. It’s like saying “Windows toaster” or “Unix jump rope.”

headline: In Wake of Deadly Riot, Egyptian Team Plays On
text: NAGOYA, Japan — Ahmed Fathi, a defensive midfielder, ran for his life when he saw thousands of Egyptian opposition supporters streaming toward him on the field. His team, Al Ahly of Cairo, had just lost a local league game in February to Al Masry in the city of Port Said.

headline: Obama Talks Tough
text: In the course of just a few hours, President Obama warned House Speaker John Boehner that he would veto his so-called Plan B for the so-called fiscal cliff. And he appointed Vice President Joe Biden to lead a task force on guns. That’s not terrible for a guy who makes even his most ardent supporters wonder if he’s willing to fight for tough causes.

headline: Near Cape Town, a 300-Year-Old Farm
text: The manor house on this 300-year-old property in South Africa’s Western Cape dates to 1692. The property, encompassing two other houses, is on the market for $3.4 million (30 million rand).

headline: Prefall Collections
text: A look at prefall collections, including Oscar de la Renta, Proenza Schouler and Jason Wu.

headline: Last Day of Fall? On the Calendar Only
text: WHETHER or not the clothes the designers are showing in their early fall collections are new, their images have changed a lot this season. Jack McCollough and Lazaro Hernandez of Proenza Schouler pointed out the difference in their prefall snaps — well, they’re snappier, looser and definitely not those robotic images that we’re used to on digital look books.

headline: The World Through a Flurry of Snow
text: THE holiday windows of the flagship Saks Fifth Avenue in New York always prompt sidewalk pileups. But this year the window with the largest crowd snapping cellphone pictures is the one containing 150 snow globes.

headline: Harvesting Fragments From a Chilean Master
text: If Roberto Bolaño’s “Woes of the True Policeman” were a pop music CD — rather than a posthumous novel from this Chilean writer who, since his death at 50 in 2003, has emerged as the most significant Latin American literary voice of his generation — it would undoubtedly be described as a collection of outtakes, alternate versions and demos. Any assessment, as a consequence, would have to come with an advisory that its primary appeal is to completists only.

headline: The Legacy of Suzanne Belperron, Jeweler
text: Her designs are so singular that they tend to strip away one’s assumptions about jewelry in the latter half of the 20th century.

headline: Harmonies, New and Old, for Charming Madonnas
text: In the Medieval Sculpture Hall of the Metropolitan Museum of Art there are no drama queens. The Madonnas who dot the great vaulted room have been perfecting their calm, inward poise for centuries, exuding a graceful stillness that nevertheless pulsates with life through the artfully curved folds of a robe or the attentive slant of a head.

headline: Modern, Before the World Was
text: THE Paris jeweler Suzanne Belperron began working in 1919 at age 19, and continued without stopping for the next 56 years. She died in 1983. Her life and career spanned the modern movement in the arts, feminism and the emergence of fashion as a big business. Yet anyone looking at the work of this remarkable woman can’t help but feel she was interested only in her own ideas.

headline: Create and Track Your Gift List, or Send a Silly Holiday Card
text: It’s the holiday season, and I’m so jam-packed with cheer that it doesn’t matter that I’ll be spending the holidays on a beach in a country where the chances of a white Christmas — weather I always hope for — are small.

headline: Sleight of Hand and Illusions of the Theater
text: LOS ANGELES — Whether it’s seducing the audience into suspending disbelief as seemingly normal folk burst into song, or, more basically, convincing us that what appears before us has some meaningful reality, theater is on some fundamental level a feat of make-believe.

headline: Homes for $2.4 Million
text: Properties in Key Biscayne, Seattle and Hawaii.

headline: What You Get for ... $2.4 Million

headline: All Across the City, Coming Together to Make Joyful Noise
text: A crowd of hundreds assembled under the Washington Arch early Saturday evening. Most were fiddling with their iPhones. A few dazed revelers in full Santa dress looked on, outliers of the drunken Santacon hordes. Tourists craning their necks to make out what was at the center of the crush of bodies were puzzled to find a man in horn-rimmed glasses handing out cassettes and black retro boomboxes.

headline: Camaro Production Returning to the United States
text: The next Chevrolet Camaro will be built in the United States at the Lansing Grand River Assembly Plant in Lansing, Mich., General Motors announced on Wednesday.

headline: Arthur C. Clarke E-Books for Sale in U.S.
text: Thirty-five titles by the celebrated science fiction writer Arthur C. Clarke, the author of “2001: A Space Odyssey,” among other classics, will be released in digital form for the first time in the United States, the independent e-book publisher RosettaBooks said on Wednesday.

headline: A Gender-Bender Parody, ‘Gangnam Style’ Included
text: The question about Les Ballets Trockadero de Monte Carlo has long been: how seriously should we take the dancing? This male ballet troupe, affectionately known as the Trocks, is certainly comic, but these men in point shoes are also good enough — technically, stylistically — that you want them to be better.

headline: Where a Thousand Words Paint a Picture
text: PERHAPS one place to start when trying to account for the singular, layered power of Peter Sacks’s paintings — the way they suggest a meticulous, almost penitential attention to detail even as they convey a larger visual narrative — is with the walks he took growing up in South Africa during the 1950s and ’60s. It was on these walks around the Drakensberg Mountains that Mr. Sacks, the son of liberal white parents (his father, a renowned doctor, taught in a black medical school), encountered ancient cave paintings made by the original South African bushmen.

headline: The Holidays After a Tragedy
text: As we have anguished in recent days over how to talk to our children about the Newtown, Conn., shootings, there has been an another, unspoken question beneath the surface: how do we talk to ourselves?

headline: Hands Off My Clothes, Mommy
text: TRADITIONAL rules of retailing hold that popular adult brands, like the Gap and J. Crew, will inevitably create a children’s line (Gap Kids, Crewcuts). Even designer labels like Fendi and Marc Jacobs have joined in, with coral tulle baby dresses and $150 bootees for those who cannot yet walk.

headline: A Seasonal Meal With a Warm Heart and Tasty Comedy (Who Needs Chestnuts?)
text: The singer Maureen McGovern radiated the comfort, joy and good humor of a benign Christmas angel at Tuesday’s opening-night performance of her holiday show at 54 Below.

headline: A Life of Its Own
text: Anyone fascinated by automates will enjoy Max Byrd’s new thriller. In fact, to enjoy this book, you probably have to be fascinated by the windup robots that were all the rage in 18th-­century Europe. Byrd certainly is. And he has done his research to prove it, notably into Jacques de Vaucanson, the eccentric Frenchman who garnered great fame and considerable fortune by building, wait for it, a defecating duck.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Pakistan and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Pakistan, Connecticut, South Korea and Greece.

headline: A Cold Heart, but Hints at Warmth
text: Exactly one rap star has an Instagram account wholly devoted to affectionate, intimate, cute pictures of his child: Chief Keef. This is the same Chief Keef who had another of his Instagram accounts suspended in September for posting a photo of himself receiving oral sex. The same person who spent a significant portion of 2012 under house arrest in connection with gun charges. The same one whose music is in part a catalog of gang-related boasts and threats. Chief Keef is 17, and appears happy for the most part to be seen as a problem child.

headline: The Music Is Timeless, but About the Rockers ...
text: THERE was Roger Daltrey, 68, with his open shirt revealing a Palm Beach perma-tan, and abs so snare-tight that they immediately raised suspicion. (“Implants!” charged a few skeptical members of the Twittersphere.)

headline: 60 Seconds With Pogue: Android Cameras
text: David Pogue reviews the Nikon Coolpix S800C and the Samsung Galaxy Camera.

headline: WikiLeaks, Hollywood’s Next Muse
text: LOS ANGELES — At the end of Alex Gibney’s not-quite-finished documentary “We Steal Secrets” — about Julian Assange and WikiLeaks — is a screen crawl describing the fate of Pfc. Bradley Manning, the Army intelligence analyst who now faces trial for the release of confidential military and diplomatic documents.

headline: Betsey Johnson, Back in the Pink
text: DESPITE repeated pleas, Betsey Johnson would not sit still.

headline: Supporting Actor Category Is Thick With Hopefuls
text: Few directors would have the temerity to throw lines at Robert De Niro. Then there’s David O. Russell. Mr. Russell, the writer and director of “Silver Linings Playbook,” which stars Mr. De Niro as an obsessive but caring father, had a loose interpretation of following the script: he shouted bits of dialogue for his actors to repeat as the cameras were rolling.

headline: Up Front
text: Paul Elie’s essay in this week’s issue, about Christianity’s waning presence in contemporary American fiction, is in some ways a counterpoint and a natural follow-up to his first book, “The Life You Save May Be Your Own” (2003). In that book, Elie offered a group biography of four midcentury Catholic writers who took faith as a central theme: Thomas Merton, Dorothy Day, Flannery O’Connor and Walker Percy.

headline: Angels, Santas and Carrots
text: The ornament collection of Bonnie Mackay.

text: MALDEN BRIDGE, N.Y.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Tech Leaders for Gun Safety, and Every Last Tweet
text: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. See more here.

headline: Giving Gardens a Hand
text: A NOTABLE no-fire zone in the garden war is Santa Monica, Calif., where residents are encouraged to uproot grass lawns in favor of more sustainable landscaping. In 2008, the city started a garden-sharing program to pair homeowners who have land with gardeners looking for fertile ground. “We act as the matchmaking service,” said Wendy Pietrzak, the city employee who runs the program. “The homeowners work out the arrangements.”

headline: The Battlefront in the Front Yard
text: JASON HELVENSTON was at work on his second crop, spreading compost to fertilize the carrots, bok choy, kale and dozens of other vegetables he grows organically on his property in Orlando, Fla., when the trouble began.

headline: Be Ready for the End of the World, or an Emergency of a Lesser Sort
text: We may have only a few hours to live. On Friday, the Mayan calendar will come to an end, leading some to predict that the world will spiral into chaos. It could be the end of days. Locusts could swarm the earth, destroying crops. Tornadoes the size of Florida could shred Europe. Thousand-foot waves could crash over Idaho. Zombies! Flesh-eating viruses, human sacrifice, dogs and cats living together.

headline: The N.R.A. Protection Racket

headline: N.Y.S.E. Is in Talks for Merger

headline: In Texas, a Showroom for Artful Furniture
text: For nearly a decade, Jamey Garza, 48, has made custom furniture in Marfa, Tex., eventually introducing his own designs. But until last week, he didn’t have a proper showroom in which to display his pieces as well as those made by his wife, Constance Holt-Garza, 47. The couple spent six months renovating two commercial buildings on a corner lot they bought three years ago, across the street from their home. “We’d pull pieces out, and they’d be hot and dusty,” Ms. Holt-Garza said. “We decided we needed a nice clean space to show the furniture.” The 900-square-foot showroom is now filled with Mr. Garza’s saddle leather, wood and powder-coated steel furniture; Ms. Garza’s table linens and throw pillows; and works on paper by the local artists Leslie Wilkes and Meghan Gerety. Prices range from $24 for a linen tea towel to $3,050 for a 48-inch round cafe table: (432) 729-1946, garzamarfa.com.

headline: Chatter of Doomsday Makes Beijing Nervous

headline: An Updated Chair for a Restored Masterwork
text: Returning the Mies van der Rohe masterwork Villa Tugendhat, an outstanding example of early modernism, to its former glory was a huge undertaking. The house, built in 1930 in Brno, Czechoslovakia, with an innovative iron frame, had been neglected after the Tugendhat family fled the Nazis in 1938. Vladimir Ambroz, the head designer of A.M.O.S Design in what is now the Czech Republic, oversaw much of the recently completed two-year project, including the restoration of all the Mies-designed furniture. Mr. Ambroz thought that the original Brno chair, an endlessly copied classic, needed a companion piece that would be softer and more comfortable. This low lounge seat pays homage to the original — the tubular steel, for example, is the same — but the chair is wider and deeper for contemporary users. The chair, in Spinneybeck leather, is $1,365: 011-420-542-212-898 or amosdesign.cz.

headline: Cayman Islands: Premier Is Named to Replace Ousted Predecessor
text: The governor of the Cayman Islands on Wednesday appointed Juliana O’Connor-Connolly as the new premier of the British territory. The former premier, W. McKeeva Bush, was ousted Tuesday by the Legislative Assembly, a week after his arrest in a corruption investigation.  Ms. O’Connor-Connolly, a former teacher and lawyer, became the first female minister of the Caymans in 1997, heading the Ministry of Community Affairs, Sports, Women, Youth and Culture.

headline: Apps to Regulate Apps
text: NOBODY ever said that big cities make for easy living. The apps of the moment, Uber and Airbnb, try to mitigate matters by letting you book a car ride or rent someone’s apartment using your smartphone or computer. They are beloved by those contemplating scarce taxis or $500 hotel rooms. But they’re considerably less popular among city regulators, whose reactions recall Ned Ludd’s response to the automated loom.

headline: Mexico: A Guzmán Is Deported
text: A woman believed to be the daughter of the most-wanted drug trafficker in the world, Joaquín Guzmán Loera of Mexico, has been deported to Mexico after two months in custody in California, her lawyers and American law enforcement officials said Wednesday. The woman, Alejandrina Gisselle Guzmán Salazar, 31, pleaded guilty in federal court on Monday to carrying a fake visa as she tried to enter the United States at the San Ysidro border crossing in October. She was sentenced to time served and returned by immigration authorities to Mexico on Tuesday. A law enforcement source said that officials were “pretty confident” that Mr. Guzmán is her father, but her lawyer said that played no role in her case.

headline: Poignant Endorsements in Weight-Loss Campaign

headline: U.S. Office Rejects 2nd Apple Patent

headline: Spain: Separatist Parties in Accord
text: The two main separatist parties in Catalonia signed an agreement on Wednesday to form a government, as well as allow the 7.5 million citizens of what is Spain’s most powerful economic region to vote in 2014 on whether to secede. That puts the Catalan president, Artur Mas, on a collision course with Spain’s prime minister, Mariano Rajoy, who sees any independence referendum as a violation of the country’s Constitution. In last month’s regional elections in Catalonia, separatist parties won 74 of the 135 seats in the Catalan Parliament. Yet the vote turned out to be a setback for Mr. Mas himself, because his party lost 12 seats.

headline: Mr. Abe’s Second Chance

A few short years ago, many were counting out Mr. Abe and his party as relics of an exhausted postwar political order. Now both are back, handed a huge parliamentary majority and a new chance to shape the future of a country with the world’s third-largest economy behind the United States and China.

headline: It’s the Guns
text: President Obama on Wednesday gave Vice President Joe Biden Jr. a month to complete a job that he could have finished that afternoon. It is time to come up with, as Mr. Obama put it, “a set of concrete proposals” to make the nation safer from guns. The ways to do this are well-known because the nation has grappled with gun massacres many times before. It is Congress that hasn’t.

headline: Some Answers on Benghazi

It offers this country a better chance of understanding what went wrong and what correctives are needed than the reckless Republican mudslinging that for weeks dominated public discourse in the aftermath of the calamity.

headline: A Helium Shortage Leads to Fewer Balloons in the Sky

A gated community on Lake Erie in Ohio that had handed out balloons to children at a Fourth of July parade for decades did not give out a single balloon this year. And a longtime tradition at University of Nebraska home football games — releasing up to 5,000 red balloons after the Huskers score their first touchdown — was downsized this season to a modest 2,000.

headline: Frustrating Game, Week and Month

headline: Struggling to Go On After a Son’s Death

Not far from the doorway is a table adorned with dozens of photos that preserve Shytik Bowman, killed last year, as he will always be remembered: a charismatic young man a few weeks shy of 18 with more than a passing resemblance to the singer Chris Brown.

headline: What’s On Thursday
text: 8 P.M. (NBC) A WHITE HOUSE CHRISTMAS: FIRST FAMILIES REMEMBER First ladies present and past — Michelle Obama, Laura Bush, Hillary Rodham Clinton, Barbara Bush and Rosalynn Carter — reminisce with Meredith Vieira about their Christmases in the White House. The former first children Barbara Bush, Jenna Bush Hager, Chelsea Clinton, Dorothy Bush Koch, Michael Reagan, Amy Carter, Susan Ford Bales, Tricia Nixon Cox, Julie Nixon Eisenhower, Lynda Johnson Robb and Luci Baines Johnson share their holiday memories as well. Ms. Vieira also trails along with staff members and volunteers, above, at the White House as they plan the décor around this year’s theme, “Joy to All,” with more than 50 trees and elaborate gingerbread creations.

headline: Iraqi President Is Flown to Germany for Treatment After Stroke
text: BERLIN — Jalal Talabani, the president of Iraq, was flown to Germany on Thursday for medical treatment for a stroke suffered this week, his spokesman said. The president, 79, was said to be in “stable” condition, and the decision to move him was announced after medical specialists from abroad were dispatched to Iraq to assess the possibility of sending him out of the country for further treatment.

headline: South Korean President-Elect Calls for Reconciliation After Tight Race
