headline: Putin Evasive on Banning Adoptions by Americans
text: MOSCOW — He seemed to wince a bit as he sauntered on stage — a twinge no doubt from a lingering back injury — but as he took his seat before scores of cameras in a hall packed with more than 1,000 journalists on Thursday, President Vladimir V. Putin was clearly in his element: under the bright lights, jaunty and confident, arriving to theme music befitting an action hero.

headline: Putin Defends Stand on Syria and Chastises U.S. on Libya Outcome
text: MOSCOW — President Vladimir V. Putin on Thursday strongly defended Russia’s implacable opposition to military intervention in Syria and sharply chastised the United States for its role in toppling Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi of Libya, describing that outcome as a mistake that created chaos and ultimately led to the death of Ambassador J. Christopher Stevens in Benghazi.

headline: Chinese Companies Head for the Exit
text: HONG KONG–Fed up with slumping share prices, prickly regulators and aggressive short sellers, Chinese companies listed on American stock exchanges are increasingly heading for the exits.

headline: The Early Word: Gun Violence
text: In Today’s Times:

headline: After Storm, ‘Friends’ Rescue a Caregiver
text: Tales of Hurricane Sandy survival will likely emerge for years — particularly about the sick and elderly who were trapped in their homes or forced to evacuate under harrowing circumstances. Many of those stories have happy endings, like this one of social media and neighborliness I recently heard.

headline: In London for the Holidays? Theatrical Gifts for Everyone on Your List
text: So who needs more possessions? The holidays afford the chance to give the gift of theatergoing, the kind of present that will be remembered (one hopes) throughout the year. With that in mind, what follows is a handful of London theater suggestions for the festive season.Enjoy, and curtain up!

headline: Guns N’ Poses
text: LONDON — My father once owned a rifle, a little .22, with which he occasionally shot rabbits. He had inherited it from my grandfather, who in turn had inherited it from my great-great-uncle. It was in a small way a family heirloom and might have one day come to me. Except it didn’t.

headline: Ericsson Writes Down a Chip-Making Venture
text: BERLIN — Ericsson, the world’s biggest maker of mobile network equipment, said on Thursday that it would take a sizable charge against earnings to write down the value of ST-Ericsson, an unprofitable venture that makes cellphone components.

headline: Scenes From Rajkot, Gujarat on Election Day
text: It seemed as if the people of Rajkot, a large and politically charged city in western Gujarat, were all talking about the same thing on Thursday morning: the Bharatiya Janata Party’s near-certain victory in the state elections.

headline: Week 16 N.F.L. Game Probabilities: The Case for Carolina
text: There are some great matchups this week to write about, but I’m going to choose to feature perhaps the least important one. The Raiders visit the Panthers, a forgettable game in almost all respects. Both teams have losing records and have been eliminated from the playoffs. There are no records to be broken or rivalry to be fought. But there is one quirk.

headline: Giving Lamb Legs
text: The gleaming, massive lamb shank on these pages, impressive though it may be, is not the most effective way to serve what amounts to the shin and ankle of a lamb.

headline: Jerry Seinfeld Intends to Die Standing Up
text: Jerry Seinfeld began his commute after dinner, in no particular hurry. Around quarter to 8 on a drizzly Tuesday, he left his Manhattan home — a palatial duplex apartment with picture windows and a broad terrace overlooking Central Park — and made for a nearby garage. Due to tell jokes at a comedy club downtown, he decided to drive what he calls his “city car”: a 1998 Porsche 911 Carrera 4S. Stepping into the garage, he tugged a thick fabric cover from the car. The interior was a pristine matte black, and the paint job was a startlingly luminous azure. “It’s called Mexico blue — a very traditional Porsche color,” Seinfeld said. “In the ’70s it looked normal, but now it looks insane.”

headline: The End of the World
text: According to some interpretations of the Mayan calendar, the world is scheduled to end on December 21.

headline: A Merrier Christmas
text: KYOTO — Spend any time in Japan these days, and you can’t help but notice: This country may be less than 1 percent Christian, but it’s 100 percent Christmas. Hearing the carols blaring from sidewalk loudspeakers in this overwhelmingly Buddhist and Shinto country, you wonder, how did Japan buy into such a foreign tradition?

headline: Jerry Seinfeld: How to Write a Joke
text: The comedian describes the anatomy of his Pop-Tart joke, still a work in progress, and shows his longhand writing process.

headline: On Our Radar: ‘Twelve Quaggas Clogging’
text: An expert on invasive species adjusts the “Twelve Days of Christmas” lyrics to educate people about threats and prevention in the Great Lakes. [The Journal Sentinel]

headline: Might Makes Him Mr. Right
text: “Who are you, Mister?” a young woman asks Jack Reacher (Tom Cruise), and it’s a question that recurs, not always quite so politely, throughout the movie that bears Reacher’s name. He may be an elusive individual with a sketchy background — ex-military, no fixed address, a single shirt to his name — but as an archetype he is easy enough to recognize. He is a cousin of Shane and Caine (from the old “Kung Fu” television series) and Clint Eastwood’s Man With No Name: a paladin without portfolio who travels from town to town, dispensing righteous violence and hard-boiled aphorisms.

headline: Snapshots of the Instagram Debate, Through the Lens of Professionals
text: “During Hurricane Sandy, I was on assignment in Arizona. At the hotel where I was staying, they had really bad cable. The best way I could follow what was going on with the storm was by seeing the photos being posted to Instagram. It was amazing.”

headline: Opinion Report: Ending Gun Violence
text: From the editorial page

headline: The Deal for N.Y.S.E.
text: N.Y.S.E IN MERGER TALKS  |  The owner of the New York Stock Exchange is in talks to be acquired by the IntercontinentalExchange, an upstart commodities and derivatives trading platform, in an $8 billion deal, people briefed on the matter tell DealBook’s Michael J. de la Merced. IntercontinentalExchange, known as ICE, is expected to offer about $33 a share, with two-thirds of that in stock, according to one of these people. That would be a 37 percent premium to NYSE Euronext’s closing price on Wednesday.

headline: Thursday Reading: Where Donated Cars May End Up
text: Where donated cars may end up, filling blank walls on a budget, fun smartphone apps for the holidays and other consumer-focused news from The New York Times.

headline: Bus Company Involved in Recent Rape Banned From Delhi’s Roads
text: Yadav Travels, the company that owned the bus in which a woman was raped Sunday evening in Delhi, has been banned from operating in India’s capital region, transportation officials have told India Ink.

headline: Upstart Market Operator Clinches $8.2 Billion Deal for N.Y.S.E.
text: 8:39 a.m. | Updated

headline: Champions League Draw
text: It is the dream matchup: Cristiano Ronaldo vs. Wayne Rooney. Alex Ferguson vs. José Mourinho. Manchester United vs. Real Madrid.

headline: Ristretto | Scaling Up for the Holidays
text: I’ve been good this year, which must be why I already have the V60 Drip Scale from Hario. A slim device with the footprint of an iPad Mini, it’s a step up for coffee scales. Actually, as far as I know it’s the only digital scale designed expressly for coffee. The engineers at Hario not only put a timer next to the readout screen, but added a couple of hidden features that address the specific needs of brewing coffee.

headline: John Goodman in the Crescent City
text: On a balcony overlooking his New Orleans neighborhood, John Goodman discusses movies with Melena Ryzik.

headline: It May Not Be the End of the World, but It’s Bad News for Transit Riders
text: Optimism being our default position, let’s begin with the good news:

headline: At Benghazi Hearing, State Dept. Concedes Errors
text: WASHINGTON — State Department officials promised on Thursday to carry out quickly the recommendations of a review board to beef up security for the foreign service and urged Congress to provide more money to protect American diplomats.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Senators Criticize ‘Zero Dark Thirty,’ and Filming Assange
text: Three prominent United States senators on Wednesday joined critics of the film “Zero Dark Thirty” over its depiction of C.I.A. interrogations in the ultimately successful hunt for Osama bin Laden, Scott Shane writes. In a letter to Michael Lynton, chairman and chief executive of Sony Pictures Entertainment, which is releasing the film, the senators called the film “grossly inaccurate and misleading in its suggestion that torture resulted in information that led to the location” of Bin Laden. The three — Dianne Feinstein, Democrat of California; Carl Levin, Democrat of Michigan; and John McCain, Republican of Arizona — called on Sony to “consider correcting the impression that the C.I.A.’s use of coercive interrogation techniques led to the operation” against Bin Laden, but they do not explain exactly how that could be done.

headline: An Apology for the Oxford English Dictionary’s Ill-Timed Word of the Day
text: Oxford University Press, the publisher of the Oxford English Dictionary, has apologized for what it called “a coincidence of the worst kind” after the dictionary’s Web site named “bloodbath” as its word of the day on Tuesday, after last week’s deadly shootings in Newtown, Conn.

headline: High-Speed Trade Giants to Merge
text: The merger of two computer-driven trading firms is set to create a new company that market analysts say would most likely be the single largest player in the trading of American stocks, and a dominant force in several other markets.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: Momofuku Long Play: An early-’80s-tinged video of the influential London chef Marco Pierre White. Mario Batali worked as his sous-chef, and his unrepentant memoir, “White Heat,” was Bourdain before Bourdain. — Julia Moskin

headline: Daily Report: F.T.C. Broadens Rules on Children’s Online Privacy
text: In a move intended to give parents greater control over data collected about their children online, federal regulators on Wednesday broadened longstanding privacy safeguards covering children’s mobile apps and Web sites, Natasha Singer reports in Thursday’s New York Times. Members of the Federal Trade Commission said they updated the rules to keep pace with the growing use of mobile phones and tablets by children.

headline: Dec. 20 Updates on Connecticut Shooting Aftermath
text: Funerals or wakes were to be held on Thursday for at least six victims of Friday’s school shooting in Newtown, Conn., as Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. prepared to visit Newtown in the afternoon to meet with investigators and first responders. In Washington, Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. is meeting with law enforcement officials to discuss gun restrictions after President Obama asked him to lead the administration’s response.

headline: Video: John Goodman in the Crescent City
text: In his 30-year career, John Goodman has never been nominated for an Oscar, and though he was up seven times for an Emmy for his work in the sitcom “Roseanne,” he never won for that show either. He did finally win the TV honor for a guest performance on “Studio 60 on the Sunset Strip,” but as he tells the Bagger in the video above, “I’m used to losing.”

headline: Camry Gets Rating of ‘Poor’ in a New Crash Test
text: The Toyota Camry, the best-selling car in the United States, did not do well in the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety’s new frontal crash test of 18 moderately priced cars.

headline: Q&A: Customizing Word Keyboard Shortcuts
text: Q.

headline: Marathon Organizers Offer Refund or Future Race
text: Nearly two months after it canceled the New York City Marathon in the days after Hurricane Sandy, New York Road Runners announced Thursday that runners who registered for the 2012 race could get either a full refund or entry into the race in one of the next three years.

headline: The Ultimate Threat
text: Dear Diary:

headline: Female Vaccination Workers, Essential in Pakistan, Become Prey
text: LAHORE, Pakistan — The front-line heroes of Pakistan’s war on polio are its volunteers: young women who tread fearlessly from door to door, in slums and highland villages, administering precious drops of vaccine to children in places where their immunization campaign is often viewed with suspicion.

headline: As Dogs Waste Away, Owners Seek Answers
text: A few years ago, Michele Daniels’s puppy, Jackie, suddenly became sick with constant, messy stomach problems. As Jackie, a 9-month-old German shepherd, rapidly lost 20 pounds, Ms. Daniels, who lives in Point Pleasant, N.J., spent many sleepless nights caring for her dog and worrying.

headline: Joke About Child Murder Remains in ‘This Is 40’
text: Judd Apatow’s child-murder joke will remain in “This Is 40” when the film arrives in theaters on Friday.

headline: The Eighteenth Brumaire of Barack Obama
text: These days, political events occur, as it were, twice — the first time as near-tragedy, the second time as farce*.

headline: Lee Child: By the Book
text: The author, whose lead character makes his film debut this weekend in “Jack Reacher,” would like to ask Shakespeare, “Why did you make ‘Richard III’ so damn long?”

headline: Being French Means Never Having to Say…
text: LONDON — President François Hollande on Thursday acknowledged the sufferings inflicted on Algeria during more than a century of French colonial rule in a statement that fell short of an apology.

headline: Health Workers in the Cross Hairs
text: TimesCast: The campaign against polio faces fear and violence in Pakistan. | Buddhism in Thailand becomes increasingly commercial. | At UBS, a rare admission of fraud from a major bank.

headline: On Not Seeing the Forest for the Equations
text: So, Noah Smith weighs in on the state of macro and argues that there really isn’t that much disagreement in the field, because both saltwater and freshwater macro use the same set of techniques. (For newbies: saltwater is the kind of macro practiced at MIT, some of Harvard, Princeton, etc., macro that still finds Keynesian ideas useful and argues that monetary and fiscal policy can be effective; freshwater is Chicago, Minnesota, etc. insisting that business cycles are optimal responses to real shocks).

headline: Big Moments, Not Always in the Script
text: WOULD “Rebecca” have been unforgettable? We may never know, though the drama surrounding the season’s ill-fated Broadway production certainly was. The revelation that the show’s last-minute investor didn’t exist was among the theater year’s most galvanizing moments. Here are others, on stages big and small:

headline: The Year’s Most Galvanizing Moments
text: A look at scenes on stages big and small.

headline: Limited Blogging for A Bit
text: Travel day tomorrow, and I have to do a lot of preparation today (oh, and write a column for tomorrow’s paper). I might weigh in if something important happens AND I find myself in a place with internet access; otherwise, a bit of a break coming.

headline: For Supporting Actor, Who Would Get Your Vote?
text: This season’s supporting-actor hopefuls are a mix of cinema legends and newcomers, performers stretching and playing just beyond their comfort spots. It’s a tight race, which we examine in depth here.

headline: Musical Moments, Part VIII: Mozart
text: Several readers wrote in to say that one of their favorite moments in music comes near the end of the fourth and final act of Mozart’s “Marriage of Figaro,” when the philandering Count Almaviva, having been caught and humiliated, asks his wife for forgiveness. But that melody is hinted at in Act III, during the count’s seductive duet with Susanna, his wife’s maid, as I point out in this video.

headline: The Giving Spree | Will Self
text: Who: The writer Will Self, who profiled Emma Watson for T’s fall women’s fashion issue, and who more recently wrote about London’s cabbie shelters in “Fare Grounds.”

headline: Caribou and Oil Companies to Share Alaska Petroleum Reserve
text: An Interior Department plan for the National Petroleum Reserve – Alaska calls for half of its 23 million acres to be set aside for wildlife conservation, wilderness and recreation and for the rest to be opened to potential oil and gas development.

headline: Booker Studies Bid for Senate, Not Governor
text: Despite pressure from party leaders, Mayor Cory A. Booker of Newark will not challenge Gov. Chris Christie for re-election next year in New Jersey, deciding instead to focus on making a bid for a Senate seat in two years.

headline: Fewer Americans Say Their Actions Can Slow Climate Change
text: Americans may be buying more compact fluorescent light bulbs these days, but they are less likely to set their thermostats low during the winter than they were four years ago and have less confidence that their actions will help to curb global warming, according to a new survey.

headline: The Christmas Frog
text: Last winter, on Christmas Eve, I found a frog in my lettuce. The lettuce was not even organic, and I was sure it came from Mexico. I had purchased it at the Pathmark grocery store under the Manhattan Bridge, and it had been in the fridge for days. The frog hopped out of the bag and perched on a plate, looking uncannily like a food-related item.

headline: A Tough Season to Be a Nets or Jets Fan
text: You are not alone if today’s sports news starts to feel a lot like your last-minute Christmas shopping. You start out with such high hopes (playoffs, baby!), everything looked so much nicer in the ads (or pregame shows) and you suddenly find yourself staring at some of the weird men’s gifts of the season and wondering where everything went so wrong. I mean, when did those ballyhooed, whoopee-we’re-big-in-Brooklyn Nets turn into the N.B.A. equivalent of ice-scraper mittens?

headline: The N.R.A.’s Blockade on Science
text: In the wake of the school massacre in Newtown, Conn., and the resulting renewed debate on gun control in the United States, The Stone will publish a series of essays this week that examine the ethical, social and humanitarian implications of the use, possession and regulation of weapons. Other articles in the series can be found here.

headline: In Performance: Tracee Chimo of ‘Bad Jews’
text: In Joshua Harmon’s comedy “Bad Jews,” Tracee Chimo plays Daphna Feygenbaum, a Vassar senior who is less than thrilled to be staying with relatives on the Upper West Side when in town for her grandfather’s funeral. In this scene Daphna complains to her cousin about another cousin who ate a cookie during Passover. The show runs through Dec. 30 at the Roundabout Underground’s Black Box Theater.

headline: Hiding in Plain Sight, a Japanese Pub
text: From the street, you’d never know it was there. Walking toward the elevator and staircase, both at the end of a narrow hallway in what passes for a lobby, you’re not entirely sure you have the correct address.

headline: ‘Moonrise Kingdom’s’ Magical, Nerve-Racking Moment
text: When Wes Anderson started working on the script that eventually became “Moonrise Kingdom,” he had a direction in mind, a few ideas, 11 or so pages of notes and a feeling – “the memory of a fantasy,” as he put it.

headline: The 12.9.12 Issue
text: HOLLYWOOD’S YEAR OF HEROINE WORSHIP

headline: Poetry Pairing | ‘The Oxen’
text: In anticipation of Christmas, this week’s Poetry Pairing matches “The Oxen” by Thomas Hardy with two articles: “The Christmas ‘Maniac,’” and from 2011, “A Lively Nativity Scene With Roots in Italy.”

headline: A Top Deal Maker at Sony Will Join Warner Music
text: Robert S. Wiesenthal, a top deal maker at Sony for the last decade, is leaving the company to become chief operating officer of the Warner Music Group, the company announced on Thursday. The move could help Warner expand through acquisitions and compete more handily against the music world’s two corporate giants, Universal and Sony.

headline: Modi Victory Speech Comes With Apology
text: Addressing a large crowd of cheering supporters Thursday evening after the Bharatiya Janata Party won a decisive victory in the state elections in Gujarat, its polarizing leader Narendra Modi thanked the state’s voters for coming out in large numbers, even as he appeared to reach out to Indians all over the country.

headline: Preposterous Explanations for Newtown
text: Beyond the abstraction of evil, we may never know why Adam Lanza shot and killed 20 children, six school officials and then himself in Newtown last Friday. And there can never be a satisfactory answer to the question “how could this happen?” (Although all-too-easy access to guns is certainly part of the answer. As Mayor Bloomberg put it, “It’s so unbelievable and it only happens in America. And it happens again and again.”).

headline: Image of the Day: Dec. 20
text: The two-day India-ASEAN summit began in New Delhi on Thursday.

headline: Long After War, Moral Questions Linger
text: It’s hard for a New York team to maintain fan loyalty when it is playing erratic football. But the front office deserves a lot of credit when the green and white colors are displayed alongside members of the military at the opening ceremonies of every game.

headline: Syria Fires More Scud Missiles at Rebels, U.S. Says
text: WASHINGTON — Forces loyal to President Bashar al-Assad of Syria have resumed firing Scud ballistic missiles against rebel positions in recent days, American officials said on Thursday.

headline: Living With Cancer: Dancing With N.E.D.
text: The vocalist begins her song with people shocked by a diagnosis they cannot accept, women not yet ready to admit they have cancer.

headline: ‘Charlie Rose’ Show Agrees to Pay Up to $250,000 to Settle Interns’ Lawsuit
text: 9:09 p.m. | Updated  Charlie Rose and his production company have agreed to pay as much as $250,000 to settle a class-action lawsuit brought by a former unpaid intern who claimed minimum-wage violations.

headline: Merck Says Niacin Drug Has Failed Large Trial
text: The drug maker Merck announced on Thursday that a combination of niacin and another medicine failed to protect against heart attacks and strokes in a large clinical trial, and that the company would no longer pursue approval of the combination drug in the United States.

headline: Frank Beardsley, 97, Storied Father of 20
text: Stacks of discount-price children’s shoes lined the walls of a large closet at the Beardsley home in Carmel, Calif., in the 1960s and ’70s — size after size in three types: oxfords for school, patent-leather dress-ups for church and tennis shoes for play.

headline: A Holiday Built on Presence, Not Presents
text: MY three vegetarian, activist, urban, multi-degreed, agnostic, adult children have rejected Christmas as a consumerist sham of a holiday, one in which they will not be participating. Oh, they’ll take the day off and drink organic wine, but they won’t be buying presents, putting up a tree, baking cookies, lighting candles or decking any halls. There will be no taking of a family picture for their card and no sending of that card or any other.

headline: Culture and Cuisine in Queens
text: A jazz legend’s home, a museum that honors the moving image and tastes from around the world are all part of the Queens experience.

headline: 36 Hours in Queens, N.Y.
text: REMEMBER old New York, where immigrants strived, cultures collided, grit outshined glamour and ethnic restaurants were filled with ethnic crowds, not Instagramming foodies? Before Manhattan commerce was diluted with H&M and Starbucks, and Brooklyn became half hipster playground, half suburb substitute? That city lives on in Queens, where the forces of gentrification have barely nipped at the edges of the city’s most expansive borough, home to 2.2 million people, from (it seems) 2.2 million backgrounds. Though its coastal areas have only just begun to recover from the destruction of Hurricane Sandy, most of the borough’s vast territory was untouched by the storm, and is full of sights and sounds unlike anything you’ll find a short subway ride away in “The City.”

headline: A Hit Parade of Small Labels and Upstarts
text: Fiscal cliffs are nothing new in the classical record industry. As became increasingly apparent when the classical music critics of The New York Times set about the annual ritual of choosing records of the year, the larger economy could perhaps learn a thing or two from certain classical cliff dwellers who have managed to tailor supply to demand while maintaining a zest for innovation and continuing to lead and expand taste.

headline: 36 Hours? In Queens, Enough Frugal Options for a Week
text: This week, the New York Times Travel section is publishing its first ever 36 Hours itinerary for Queens, N.Y. As a Queens resident, I heartily endorse the weekend romp through its unique museums, wildly eclectic restaurants, energetic night life and extraordinarily affordable foot massages. As the article’s author, I must add that my feet have never felt more relaxed.

headline: Reading (and Composing) ‘Wanderlists’ With an App
text: Browsing through Afar.com, the user-generated online travel guide, is like chatting with a group of well-traveled friends. Users post such passionate descriptions and beautiful photos of destinations that you want to follow in their footsteps.

headline: For a Big Exchange Merger, Platoons of Advisers
text: Putting two of the biggest market operators in the world together requires a fair amount of work. In the case of the IntercontinentalExchange‘s $8.2 billion takeover of NYSE Euronext, that fell on 18 — yes, 18 — advisers. (To be fair, NYSE Euronext’s failed tie-up with Deutsche Börse relied on an even bigger group of 20 firms.)

headline: Empathy as a Path to Climate (and Energy) Progress
text: Dec. 21, 8:33 a.m. | Updated below |David Roberts at Grist yesterday posted a deeply moving essay about using empathy as a means to take on tough issues. He built the piece around President Obama’s heartfelt reaction and response to the Connecticut elementary school massacre and, followed by Joe Romm, noted the lack of any such response from the president or society on the greenhouse buildup despite the risk posed by human-driven climate change. (Current and past greenhouse-gas emissions will affect the climate for generations, actually millenniums, to come).

headline: Princelings
text: A series that looks at how relatives of top Chinese officials have amassed vast wealth through businesses closely entwined with the state.

headline: Carrie Nation at the New Yorker
text: Here’s Adam Gopnik’s thought experiment on guns:

headline: Last-Second Gift Suggestion From the Magazine (and Jerry Seinfeld, Sort Of)
text: It’s Dec. 20. You have five days before Christmas, and we can assure you that for the entirety of that time, navigating any stores that sell anything vaguely gifty is going to be disastrously unpleasant. Have no fear. If the person you need a last-second gift for is a New Yorker, an aspiring writer, a fan of comedy and/or an observer of pop-culture phenomena, then we have a gift idea for you!

headline: Common Core Practice | Serendipitous Discovery
text: “We’re never quite certain where The Times will take us when we walk through our classroom door,” write Sarah Gross and Jonathan Olsen, the teachers with whom we’ve been collaborating for our Friday Common Core Practice postings.

headline: Polio Campaign Crisis in Pakistan
text: Times health reporter Donald G. McNeil Jr. speaks about the killing of polio vaccine workers.

headline: In Defense of the $100 Christmas Tree
text: In our household, the fake versus live Christmas tree debate was long ago resolved in my favor. I prefer live trees because that’s what I grew up with, and I think they’re ultimately better for the environment. And they just plain smell nice.

headline: Happy Birthday, You Miserable Achievers
text: What’s going on with Pete and Debbie? First of all: You remember Pete and Debbie, don’t you? They were the designated grown-ups played by Paul Rudd and Leslie Mann in “Knocked Up,” a movie about the accidental conception and hilarious gestation of their niece. If you want an update on that child, who would be in kindergarten by now, you won’t find it in “This Is 40,” Judd Apatow’s “sort-of sequel” to the earlier movie and the fourth feature film he has directed. (The baby’s parents were played by Katherine Heigl and Seth Rogen, who have moved on to other things.)

headline: E-Reader Market Shrinks Faster Than Many Predicted
text: Nearly three years after the first iPad was introduced, the tablet has come a long way. Now there are plenty of smaller, cheaper tablets that are pretty powerful. So why buy a more primitive e-book reader?

headline: Obama, Fan of ‘Lincoln’ (and ‘Beasts,’ Too)
text: When Time magazine announced Barack Obama as its person of the year, bet you didn’t think it would include a dive into his movie tastes. But granted an audience with the president, the magazine’s managing editor, Richard Stengel, asked him about watching “Lincoln.”

headline: ‘Newsies’ Recoups Initial Investment
text: The Broadway musical “Newsies,” a David-vs.-Goliath story about the 1899 strike of New York City newsboys, has recouped its $5 million capitalization, becoming the fastest of any Disney musical on Broadway to turn a profit, the show’s producers said on Thursday.

headline: UBS Settlement Minimizes Impact of Guilty Plea
text: The Swiss banking giant UBS paid a fairly stiff price to settle the rate-rigging case. In addition to approximately $1.5 billion in penalties and disgorgement, the bank’s Japanese securities subsidiary pleaded guilty to a charge of felony wire fraud.

headline: Questions Remain About New Plan on ‘Too Big to Fail’
text: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation and the Bank of England recently put out a new paper on how they might work together to aid a major financial institution that gets into trouble.

headline: Insurance Institute Announces Its New Top Safety Pick+ Award
text: Now that the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety has added a new frontal crash test to its portfolio, it announced on Thursday that it will add a new safety award to recognize vehicles that do even better than those that receive its Top Safety Pick award.

headline: Asked & Answered | Pascal Barbot
text: The arrival of a new cookbook dedicated to a hotshot chef and his destination restaurant is usually met with the realization that the volume is more advanced than our brains can fathom, although it will look lovely on a coffee table or impressive on a shelf. You might expect more of the same from “Astrance: A Cook’s Book” (Éditions du Chêne, $95), the new tome from the 12-year-old, 25-seat Michelin-starred Parisian restaurant that was recently ranked 18th in the world. Astrance’s chef Pascal Barbot is a master, after all. But Astrance, which was written by Chihiro Masui and Barbot’s business partner Christophe Rohat, who is responsible for everything that goes on in the front of house, is an entirely unorthodox, or as Masui might say, “unnatural,” cookbook. In it, what Barbot calls “spoken recipes” reveal more about the chef’s process and approach than the traditional combination of head notes and directions do.

headline: Media Baubles: A Just-in-the-Click-of-Time Gift Guide
text: Not that long ago, someone here, we won’t say who, came up with the bright idea of doing a media-centric gift guide. There was a fair amount of skepticism, but when the list was produced, it settled everything. Some of the best editorial minds in the hemisphere — well, actually, the dark overlords of the media kingdom at The New York Times — judged it to be ill-considered, dumb, awkwardly executed and full of log-rolling.

headline: Ackman Outlines Bet Against Herbalife
text: From the perspective of Herbalife‘s executives, the company is built on a sound model that benefits its participants.

headline: Recommended Reading: Journo-Code Commit Messages
text: New York Times interactive news developer Tyson Evans wrote this fantastic article that’s sure to fill you with holiday cheer: “Updated horse parser”: The year in journo-code commit messages at NiemanLab.org.

headline: Boehner Cancels Tax Vote in Face of G.O.P. Revolt
text: WASHINGTON — Speaker John A. Boehner’s effort to pass fallback legislation to avert a fiscal crisis in less than two weeks collapsed Thursday night in an embarrassing defeat after conservative Republicans refused to support legislation that would allow taxes to rise on the most affluent households in the country.

headline: Shorter Stairway to Heaven: Rock Stars Die Younger, Study Finds
text: A new study confirms what music fans have long suspected: rock and pop musicians die prematurely more often than the general population.

headline: A Brief History of the New York Stock Exchange
text: The New York Stock Exchange, with its opening bell and floor traders, has been the public image of a stock market for two centuries

headline: Why Renters Use More Electricity
text: Why do people buy inefficient refrigerators and clothes washers when spending a little more for an efficient one would save them money over time through lower electricity or water bills? There are a variety of reasons, but one that is persistently cited is that people are not necessarily buying these appliances for themselves. Often the buyer is a landlord, and the user is a tenant who does not make the choice but faces the consequences because he receives the energy bill.

headline: She’ll Be Thankful for the Memory
text: FLASH memory drives come in many odd forms — disguised as plastic sushi pieces, Swiss Army knives and Hello Kitty figures. Now, a contender for the oddest: a vibrator.

headline: Russian Ban on U.S. Adoptions Moves Forward
text: A law that would prohibit adoptions of Russian children by United States citizens passed Russia’s lower house of Parliament on Wednesday. The bill (in retaliation for a new United States law that seeks to punish Russian citizens who are accused of violating human rights) still faces two more legislative votes, and President Vladimir V. Putin has evaded the question of whether or not he would sign it.

headline: The View from Notre Dame: Russell’s Twist of Fate
text: In December 2011, KeiVarae Russell traded in his childhood dream of suiting up for Southern California for a new one of playing for Notre Dame. One year later,  Russell, a  freshman cornerback, can realize the biggest dream of all: a national championship.

headline: Bistro SK in City Island
text: At night, City Island is left to its residents, who have welcomed Bistro SK as if positively starved for coq au vin and bavette, hanger steak with red wine-shallot sauce.

headline: Making It Easier to Estimate Libor Losses
text: The potential victims of the Libor scandal are starting to estimate the costs to their bottom lines.

headline: A Bistro in the Bronx With a Warm Welcome
text: FOR all the restaurants in New York City claiming the name “bistro,” it is rare to find one with the most crucial ingredient. It’s not duck confit; it’s a dining room where everyone is welcomed and waited on by the owner, who may also be (or be married to) the chef.

headline: Q&A: Easing the Pain of Computing
text: Q.

headline: Forget the East-West Divide; It’s Berlin vs. Munich
text: For the German director Christian Petzold, the subject of his latest film, “Barbara” — a character study of an East German doctor torn between her sense of professional responsibility and a desire to escape to the West with her lover — is one that hits close to home. He was born in West Germany to parents who had fled together from East Germany, but as a child and adolescent, he would return with them to East Germany each summer, to enjoy the warmth and affection of the many relatives who had remained behind while also experiencing what he now describes as an “atmosphere that was very, very mistrustful” in the larger society.

headline: Nearly 30,000 Jobs Lost Because of Hurricane Sandy
text: Hurricane Sandy wiped out nearly 30,000 jobs in and around New York City last month, the New York State Labor Department said on Thursday.

headline: Hoping for a Silent Night
text: My wife and I raised our boys (twins, 6, and their brother, 1) to believe in Santa. My sister decided against it with her little ones (6, 4, 2 and 1). We will be together for a day around Christmas, and she wrote that if Santa comes up, her oldest will spill the beans, causing confusion and possibly heartbreak. She suggested we tell our children not to mention Santa, and asked what I thought. What do you think?

headline: $1,200 a Pound, Truffles Suffer in the Heat
text: PARIS — Just about everything in Eduardo Manzanares’s shop, Truffes Folies, is made with truffles. Sausage, cheese, spaghetti — even popcorn.

headline: NYSE Euronext’s Decent Deal for Its Suffering Shareholders
text: At least Duncan Niederauer, the NYSE Euronext chief executive, isn’t blind to the inevitable. He has agreed to sell the Big Board to IntercontinentalExchange for $8.2 billion.

headline: Cash and Debit Prevail This Holiday Season
text: The holiday season is one time when my credit card gets a heavy workout, and this year is no different. But I’m apparently an outlier, according to a survey of holiday consumer spending.

headline: Cardinal Finds a Biblical Parallel in a School Aide’s Selfless Life and Death
text: KATONAH, N.Y. — To those who know what aides do for the disabled children in their care, it was no surprise that after a gunman invaded the Sandy Hook Elementary School in Newtown, Conn., the body of Anne Marie Murphy was found slumped protectively over at least one of her charges, a 6-year-old boy named Dylan Hockley.

headline: Who’s to Blame for the Fiscal Cliff Impasse?
text: Republicans are trying to blame the apparent impasse in fiscal cliff negotiations on President Obama and the Democrats.

headline: Sale of Wright House Assures Its Preservation
text: PHOENIX — A house designed by Frank Lloyd Wright here for his son was sold on Thursday, guaranteeing its preservation after it had been threatened for months with demolition by its owners, who had planned to replace it with new homes.

headline: Internet Meme Goes Analog
text: The viral 8-bit meme Nyan Cat has inspired a pop-up store in New York City.

headline: Syrian Television Journalist Announces Defection
text: In a telephone interview shown on Thursday by the Saudi news channel Al Arabiya, a man who identified himself as Ahmad Fakhouri, a prominent Syrian state television anchor, announced his defection.

headline: Should Felton Be Shooting So Much?
text: Because the Knicks’ offense has been so strong under the direction of Raymond Felton, there is a sense that his passing has led to the eye-popping production. After all, part of the thinking behind letting Jeremy Lin leave was that the Knicks, with Carmelo Anthony as the team’s centerpiece, needed a more traditional point guard at the controls.

headline: Snow Fall: The Avalanche at Tunnel Creek
text: The snow burst through the trees with no warning but a last-second whoosh of sound, a two-story wall of white and Chris Rudolph’s piercing cry: “Avalanche! Elyse!”

headline: Milan Fashion House to Join the Diesel Empire
text: LONDON — Renzo Rosso, the Italian executive who has turned cool style into big bucks, is expanding his empire.

headline: The Avalanche at Tunnel Creek
text: Fresh powder beckoned 16 expert skiers and snowboarders into the backcountry. Then a slab of snow cracked and swept violently down the mountain. No one knew how many were caught.

headline: UBS Unit Admits Guilt in Rate Case
text: Peter Eavis and David Gillen of The New York Times discuss UBS, which became the first big global bank in more than two decades to have a subsidiary plead guilty to fraud.

headline: Former Top Banker Testifies in Spain Behind Closed Doors
text: MADRID — Rodrigo Rato, a former top banking official in Spain and a former managing director of the International Monetary Fund, on Thursday became the most prominent banker to appear in a Spanish court since the start of the country’s financial crisis.

headline: Pogue’s 12 Days of Gadgets: The Touchfire iPad Keyboard
text: Thumpity thump-thump — that’s the sound your fingers make on an iPad screen when they try to type. It’s not an efficient process. You sort of have to keep looking down at the glass to see where your fingers are. In short, typing is not, ahem, the iPad’s shining moment.

headline: Brian McGrory Rises From Boston Globe Paperboy to Become the Paper’s Next Editor
text: 8:44 p.m. | Updated The Boston Globe announced on Thursday that Brian McGrory, a columnist and former metro editor at the newspaper and a Boston native with deep roots in the area, would be its next editor. The appointment is effective immediately.

headline: Web Service Raises $7 Million to Automate Your Life
text: IFTTT, the nifty Web service that offers a way to automate tasks online, just got a nice holiday present: a significant chunk of change from the venture capital firms Andreessen Horowitz, NEA and Lerer Ventures.

headline: ‘Inventing Abstraction’
text: A look at the new exhibition at the Museum of Modern Art.

headline: For All His Flaws, an Influential Ceramist
text: The British ceramist Michael Cardew carefully recorded his anxieties and failures. From his 1920s apprenticeships until his death in 1983, he traveled worldwide, proselytizing for traditional, handmade ceramics and writing confessional diary entries and letters to his family. He detailed his nightmares about misfortunes befalling his wife and three sons during his long absences, and his frustrating efforts to set up self-sufficient potteries in Ghana and Nigeria.

headline: When the Future Became Now
text: In the second decade of the 20th century, abstraction became the holy grail of modern art. It was pursued with feverish intent by all kinds of creative types in Europe, Russia and elsewhere, responding to assorted spurs: Cubism and other deviations from old-fashioned realism, the beautiful whiteness of the blank page, communion with nature, spiritual aspirations, modern machines and everyday noise.

headline: Two Inaugural Balls to Honor Obama Guests and Military Families
text: President Obama will hold just two official inaugural balls – one for guests of his choosing, with some limited tickets for the public, and the other to honor military families – after he takes the oath of office to begin his second term, inaugural planners said Thursday.

headline: Egypt’s Chief Prosecutor Retracts His Resignation
text: CAIRO — Egypt’s chief prosecutor withdrew his resignation on Thursday, just days after submitting it. The move was the latest bizarre turn in a complicated three-way struggle among the new Islamist president, the institutions of the old government and the president’s opposition in the streets.

headline: The Push for Gun Control
text: TimesCast Politics: The history and future of gun-control legislation. | The upcoming challenges for the Democratic Party. | The sharp divide on the fiscal talks.

headline: Hollande Uses Softer Tone on Delicate Visit to Algeria
text: PARIS — On a delicate and closely watched visit to Algeria, President François Hollande of France on Thursday acknowledged the “profoundly unjust and brutal” nature of France’s colonial rule, a statement seen in both countries as heralding a change of tone. But Mr. Hollande did not make an apology for France’s conduct, although Algeria has long pressed for one.

headline: The Giving Spree | Tiina Laakkonen
text: Who: The fashion stylist and new store owner Tiina Laakkonen, whose Amagansett home was featured in T’s Design and Living issue.

headline: Boomers and Millennials Feel a Need to Care for One Another
text: Last summer there was a media frenzy about a supposed war between greedy baby boomers who are sucking up the nation’s resources, and young adults, the millennials, doomed to a bleak financial future. “Are Millennials the Screwed Generation?” asked the Daily Beast, which never lets itself get bogged down by nuances.

headline: A Tokyo Ramen Innovator Eyes the Lower East Side
text: There has been a lot of buzz about Ivan Orkin, the American chef who took the Frank Sinatra route — “his way” — with ramen in Tokyo. He is now in New York and plans to open a version of his popular ramen restaurants on the Lower East Side.

headline: ‘Iron Curtain’ Exhibition at Hebrew Home
text: A perk of living in a city brimming with artists and art lovers is that there tends be a lot of stuff around. Having a surplus means that terrific work can end up in unexpected places. Many of those places are fun to seek out.

headline: Pushed and Pulled, a Doctor Wants a Way Out
text: “Barbara” is a film about the old Germany from one of the best directors working in the new: Christian Petzold. For more than a decade Mr. Petzold has been making his mark on the international cinema scene with smart, tense films that resemble psychological thrillers, but are distinguished by their strange story turns, moral thorns, visual beauty and filmmaking intelligence. His latest to open in the United States, “Barbara,” begins in 1980 with an East German doctor from Berlin (Nina Hoss) who, after an unspecified offense, has been recently banished to the boonies. There, in between hospital rounds and harassment from the secret police, she waits and she burns.

headline: Applicants Continue to Flock to Early Admission Programs
text: One theme that emerges is that many binding early decision and nonbinding early action programs continue to record double-digit increases in applicants when compared with the previous year.

headline: The Caucus: Paying Final Respects
text: Sen. Daniel Inouye of Hawaii, who died Monday at 88, laid in state in the Capitol rotunda on Thursday.

headline: A Bronzino Portrait Heads to Auction
text: Agnolo Bronzino was the go-to guy for power portraits in 16th-century Florence. “They were generally commissioned by wealthy people to convey a certain swagger and confidence,” said Nicholas Hall, head of Christie’s international department of old master paintings.

headline: In Japan, a Test of Inflation Targets
text: “Under a paper-money system, a determined government can always generate higher spending and, hence, positive inflation.”

headline: Bloomberg, Incensed by Shooting, Vows Stiffer Fight to Rework Gun Laws

headline: Fewer First-Time Buyers
text: TWO recent national surveys of real estate agents suggest that first-time buyers are on the decline, their access to the housing market blocked by tight credit and eager investors.

headline: Memorials, Along With Some Mischief
text: The New York solo debut of the Berlin-based artist and writer Hito Steyerl at e-flux is one of the best gallery shows of the season. Ms. Steyerl works primarily in video, but defines the medium broadly to include documentary, staged history, what look like found film images and the near-equivalent of home movies.

headline: The Nervous Leading the Blind to the End
text: Praising the virtues of the radio dramas from his childhood, Stephen King once noted that the perfect monster is the one you make in your mind.

headline: White House Asks Police for Help in Shaping Gun Control Policy
text: The White House recruited national law enforcement leaders on Thursday to help shape a response to last week’s school shootings in Connecticut, hoping to use the credibility of America’s police officers to build support for measures curbing the spread of assault weapons.

headline: An Interview With Patrick Gaspard
text: The Times’s Jeff Zeleny interviews Patrick Gaspard, the executive director of the Democratic National Committee, about some upcoming challenges his party faces.

headline: Awaiting the End in a Small Turkish Town
text: ISTANBUL — Despite assurances from leading Islamic and Christian clerics and the global skepticism based on scientific facts, as many as 10,000 people are expected to descend on a small Turkish town in the Aegean region in hopes of being among the few to survive the Dec. 21, 2012, doomsday supposedly predicted by the Mayan calendar.

text: THE wine panel generally explores a particular region, genre or vintage in all its manifestations. We might examine the 2007 Barolos, for example, or survey recent Mosel kabinett rieslings or Mendocino pinot noirs. Our tasting coordinator, Bernard Kirsch, always shops retail and puts together a representative sampling.

headline: Ladies, Gentlemen and Kids, Start Your Engines!
text: Drivers in New York have two choices: slow bumper-to-bumper traffic and fast bumper-to-bumper traffic. Everyone knows Option 1. It is an existential condition in the city.

headline: ‘Why Does Everyone Have a Grandma and Grandpa Except Me?’
text: “Why does everyone have a grandma and grandpa except me?” my 4-year-old daughter asked me a couple of weeks ago as we snuggled on the couch. I answered her the way I have answered my 8-year-old son over the past five years: “Grandma and Grandpa are in heaven, so even though you can’t see them, they are watching you all the time.”

headline: City’s Incarceration Rate Plummets as Nation’s Climbs
text: Even as the prison population across the country continues to grow, New York City officials said on Thursday that they had recorded a large drop in the city’s rate of incarceration.

headline: Vain Glorious | Dr. Philippe Allouche on the Bio-Lift Facial
text: A facial massage that feels more like an annual checkup — assessing hydration, elasticity and epidermal water loss — is an intriguing way to start a spa treatment. Dr. Philippe Allouche of the French skin care line Biologique Recherche has been practicing medical beauty since the early 1990s. His clinical, holistic “Bio-Lift” facial at the Peninsula Spa in New York professes to reshape the face. T spoke to Dr. Allouche about the virtues of electrical currents, the healing power of the hand and his golden rule: never, ever do steam extractions.

headline: Venison and Zinfandel Wines
text: The weather and the wine demanded a plate of robust food. Our zinfandels had class, so I chose venison, sophisticated and festive. And when I discovered that D’Artagnan, the meat and luxury food purveyor, offered venison osso buco, I decided that was the ticket. Venison is leaner than veal, but braising made it rich and tender. (Boneless venison stew meat could be used instead.) Cranberries, red wine, sweet parsnips and a heady whiff of allspice rounded out the dish. Broad noodles or grits alongside would welcome a pool of the abundant sauce. And remember to provide small forks for the lagniappe, the bone marrow. FLORENCE FABRICANT

headline: When the Auto Moved In
text: IN the no-holds-barred luxury residential market, it’s a constant battle to find something to offer picky millionaires. Among the most unusual lures are the super-handy parking spaces in the 19-story Sky Garage at 11th Avenue and 24th Street, where sales began in 2007 and ended this year. The architect Annabelle Selldorf gave 14 apartments there separate elevators so that residents could park their cars within 10 feet of their living rooms. This amenity is not without a precedent: the town-house garage of the early 1900s.

headline: Transcript of The Choice Blog’s College Application Help Line
text: On Wednesday, The Choice hosted a live, hourlong College Application Help Line on Facebook, in an effort to help high school seniors and their families navigate this pivotal period of the admissions process with confidence.

headline: The Good News in the Fare Increases, Relatively Speaking
text: There was one relatively good piece of good news arising from the subway and bus fare increase announced Wednesday, “relatively” being the key word. Under the new fare structure, the “break-even point” for a 30-day unlimited MetroCard – that is, the point at which the unlimited card becomes a better deal than the pay-per-ride card – comes sooner, at 48 rides instead of 50.

headline: Once Banished, Never Silenced
text: Outstanding artworks in the Vietnam-era department of my personal mental museum include: James Rosenquist’s “F-111”; Peter Saul’s hallucinatory paintings of rape and carnage in Vietnam; Claes Oldenburg’s monumental sculpture of a giant lipstick standing vertically on military tank tracks; and Judith Bernstein’s mural-scale, charcoal drawings of enormous phallic screws. All of these have in common a more or less explicit metaphorical conflation of war and sexual violence.

text: FOR more than a dozen years, ever since his divorce, Richard Carbone had rented a two-bedroom apartment in Suffolk County on Long Island. It was near his business, Tech Steel and Materials, a seller of specialty metals. His rent was around $2,000 a month.

headline: A Continent’s Art on a Long American Journey
text: It’s easy to take for granted just how quickly art travels today, whether by JPEG or shipping crate. For a sense of how slow things were just a century ago, and how much could get lost en route from one continent to another, visit “African Art, New York, and the Avant-Garde,” a small but highly compelling show at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. It’s one of several exhibitions timed to the centennial of the Armory Show of 1913, where many New Yorkers caught their first glimpse of Modern art from Europe (much of it influenced by African sculpture).

headline: Thrill-Seeking Beats Take the Scenic Route
text: First the good news: America the Beautiful has rarely looked more ripe for exploration than it does in “On the Road,” a noble attempt by the Brazilian director Walter Salles (“The Motorcycle Diaries,” “Central Station”) to capture literary lightning in a bottle. With spacious skies stretching endlessly over open, uncongested roads bordered by amber waves of grain, and purple mountains beckoning in the distance, the movie resurrects a perennial frontier dream and invites you to barrel into the unknown with its Beat Generation legends.

headline: Hints of Mischief Waft in Spirit of the Season
text: Wonder and innocence, gaudiness and cheer: can it be any surprise that the jazz drummer Matt Wilson thrives around the holidays? His Christmas Tree-O, which released a scrappy and endearing album on Palmetto two years ago, does more or less what you’d expect, batting around holiday standards with a mischievous but sentimental air.

headline: A Bunch of Drummers and Friends, Thinking About Home and John Cage
text: If you have followed the exploits of So Percussion, you will probably recognize that “Where (we) Live,” the new show that the group has mounted at the Brooklyn Academy of Music’s Harvey Theater, is a project its members have been working toward for some time now. If not, you will probably be perplexed, if pleasantly so. You may even wonder what the goings-on have to do with contemporary classical music, the sphere from which So Percussion emerged.

headline: A Debut With a Proustian Touch
text: The violinist Paul Huang’s Francophile New York recital debut on Tuesday evening at Merkin Concert Hall had an unlikely literary connection.

headline: Gil Friesen, Entertainment Executive, Dies at 75
text: Gil Friesen, who achieved success in films and television but was best known for helping to establish A&M Records as an artists’ haven for an eclectic stable of performers that included Carole King, the Police, Barry White and the Carpenters, died on Dec. 13 at his home in Los Angeles. He was 75.

headline: A Mad Dash to Avoid a Bigger Tax Bite
text: NOT that anybody needs more stress during the holiday season, but sellers and their brokers and lawyers across the country have been scrambling to close deals and avoid January tax increases that will eat into their profits.

headline: Super Bowl, Tebow, Saints: Answers to Readers’ Questions
text: Judy Battista, the N.F.L. reporter for The Times, answers questions from readers.

headline: The Formidable Co-op Approval Process
text: NO matter how wealthy you are, or how much money you spend on a co-op apartment in New York City, what you have to go through to get approved by the building’s board of directors is a level of scrutiny that no one is spared.

headline: German Health Care Attracts Foreign Patients
text: BERLIN — When Jalal Talabani, the president of Iraq, needed advanced medical care for a stroke suffered this week, he flew not to the United States or Britain but to Germany, for treatment here in the capital.

headline: Assange Addresses Dozens in London
text: As my colleague Michael Cieply reports, six months after Julian Assange stepped into the small Ecuadorean Embassy in London, seeking political asylum, several Hollywood filmmakers are at work on dramatic treatments of the WikiLeaks story.

headline: Police Dept. to Use Internet to Try to Stop Mass Shootings
text: Top intelligence officials in the New York Police Department met on Thursday to examine ways to search the Internet to identify potential “deranged” gunmen before they strike, Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly said.

headline: Talking Turkey About Real Estate
text: WHEN it comes to playing the real estate game, the period between Thanksgiving and New Year’s Day is traditionally a dead zone, thanks to unpredictable weather, relentless family obligations and brimming to-do lists. But this time of year, seeds are often planted that propel housing decisions down the line.

headline: Wall St. Downsizes Holiday Parties
text: In the year of Hurricane Sandy, looming fiscal austerity and global scrutiny of banks, Wall Street is just not in a celebratory mood.

headline: Playing With the Band When the Music Meant Everything
text: There is plenty of hope but little glory in “Not Fade Away,” David Chase’s sympathetic, acutely drawn portrait of a young Italian-American musician in New Jersey chasing 1960s rock ’n’ roll dreams. That character, Douglas Damiano (the perfectly cast John Magaro), is not a baby Bruce Springsteen or Jon Bon Jovi surrogate ascending to the pantheon while the whole world cheers. Near the beginning of the movie, a voice-over narrator, Douglas’s younger sister Evelyn (Meg Guzulescu), remarks, “Like most bands, you’ve never heard of them.”
