text: In Today’s Times:

headline: A Plea From the Admissions Office to Go for the ‘Dangerous’ Essay
text: Daniel Grayson is the associate director of undergraduate admissions at Tufts University in Medford, Mass.

headline: Home for the Holidays, or Not: Minnesota, Land of Pink Tinsel  and Doodads
text: Have you had a memorable holiday away from home? Tell us your stories in the comment space here. We’ll post our favorites on IHT Rendezvous during these last weeks of 2012.

headline: North Korea Says It Detained American Over ‘Hostile Acts’
text: SEOUL, South Korea — North Korea said on Friday that it had charged an American citizen detained there with committing “hostile acts against the republic,” a crime punishable by years in prison, at a time when the United States is pushing for new sanctions against the reclusive country for a recent rocket launching.

headline: Obama Asks Supporters to Push Congress on Gun Control
text: President Obama sought on Friday to enlist supporters to mount a public lobbying campaign on behalf of gun control in the wake of the mass killings in Newtown, Conn., suggesting that Congress would listen only if forced to by a populist backlash to gun violence.

headline: Georgian Soldier Disappears in Afghanistan
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — A soldier from Georgia belonging to the NATO-led mission in Afghanistan has been missing since Wednesday in the southwest of the country, the coalition said on Friday.

headline: How Was Your Doomsday?
text: LONDON — One of the most alarming things to have emerged from the hullabaloo over the so-called Mayan doomsday prophecy is how many people in the world actually believed it.

headline: Is the Cure for Cancer Inside You?
text: Claudia Steinman saw her husband’s BlackBerry blinking in the dark. It had gone untouched for several days, in a bowl beside his keys, the last thing on anybody’s mind. But about an hour before sunrise, she got up to get a glass of water and, while padding toward the kitchen, found an e-mail time-stamped early that morning — “Sent: Monday, Oct. 3, 2011, 5:23 a.m. Subject: Nobel Prize. Message: Dear Dr. Steinman, I have good news for you. The Nobel Assembly has today decided to award you the Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine for 2011.” Before she finished reading, Claudia was hollering at her daughter to wake up. “Dad got the Nobel!” she cried. Alexis, still half-asleep, told her she was crazy. Her father had been dead for three days.

headline: In a Lime Plaster Job, a Leonardo Moment
text: What do the Sistine Chapel, the Brooklyn Bridge, the Appian Way and the outside of the straw bale house we’ve been building have in common?

headline: Week 16 in Fantasy Football: Favorable and Unfavorable Matchups
text: Jason and Justin Sablich provide fantasy football advice and analysis throughout the season on this blog and on Twitter @5thDownFantasy.

headline: Happy Holidays
text: What are you doing over the holidays?

headline: A Man of Many Parts Wants More
text: FOR T. I., the rapper, actor, novelist, reality-television star and former resident of the Forrest City Federal Correctional Complex in Arkansas, existential accountings are routine and often occur in the oddest of places. So he seemed unfazed to find himself, on a recent Wednesday afternoon in Hell’s Kitchen on the set of Current TV’s “Joy Behar: Say Anything!,” amiably fielding questions about federal weapons charges, the emotional veracity of his family’s VH1 show, “T. I. & Tiny: The Family Hustle,” and the long-term romantic prospects of his fellow pop stars Chris Brown and Rihanna.

headline: General Electric to Buy Avio for $4.3 Billion
text: LONDON – General Electric agreed on Friday to buy the Italian aerospace company Avio for $4.3 billion, acquiring a long-time partner in its jet engine business.

headline: Girl Shot by Taliban Asks That College Not Bear Her Name
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — The Pakistani teenager who was shot in the head by a Taliban gunman in October has asked a provincial government to reverse its decision to name a college after her, an official said on Friday. But her request was not immediately granted.

headline: The Japan-China Bout
text: Preparing for the next round in the Japan-China bout.

headline: Changing Face of Finance
text: CHANGING FACE OF FINANCE  |  The $8.2 billion deal for the New York Stock Exchange showed how the power base in finance has shifted. Once seen as the cradle of American capitalism, the stock exchange has suffered from declining trading volumes and razor-thin margins. Meanwhile, its acquirer, the Atlanta-based IntercontinentalExchange, or ICE, has bolstered its position as “trading in commodities and derivatives has become much more lucrative than trading in the shares of companies,” DealBook’s Ben Protess and Nathaniel Popper write.

headline: Opinion Report: Gun Money
text: From the editorial page

headline: Friday Reading: Frugal Travel Options in Queens
text: A week of frugal options in Queens, easing the pain of computing, milk prices may soar and other consumer-focused news from The New York Times.

headline: British Commission Says Bank Reforms Don’t Go Far Enough
text: LONDON — Regulators in Britain should have the power to completely split up banks, a government-commissioned report concluded Friday, adding that changes being currently proposed do not go far enough to prevent a future crisis.

headline: A Song for the Girl in the White Jacket
text: Dear Diary:

headline: Updates on Connecticut Shooting Aftermath
text: A week after the school shooting  in Newtown, Conn., people around the world observed a moment of silence at 9:30 a.m. Church bells rang 26 times for each of the victims who died inside Sandy Hook Elementary School. At least five more victims from the shooting, including three children, were buried on Friday. After a weeklong silence, the National Rifle Association made a case this morning for armed police officers to be stationed at every school. Click to read Thursday’s updates.

headline: The Civilian Toll of Cluster Munitions
text: C. J. Chivers reports from Marea, Syria, on the government’s use of cluster munitions in 2012 against civilians in what appears to be collective punishment.

headline: App Smart Extra: More Holiday Apps
text: As befits the date, this week’s App Smart column was about Christmas-related apps. We talked about a variety of them, like photo effects or storytelling ones.

headline: The Boardwalk of Lagos
text: LAGOS — For the first time, Monopoly, the American board game, has been customized for Lagos, Nigeria’s commercial capital. The counsel on the box: “Stay sharp — because there’s only room at the top for one. For everyone else, there’s bankruptcy.”

headline: Pinnacle to Buy Ameristar Casinos for $869 Million
text: Pinnacle Entertainment agreed on Friday to buy Ameristar Casinos for $869 million in cash, in a deal that would more than double its size.

headline: Daily Report: A Million Users Desert BlackBerry, and Revenue Falls 48%
text: Research in Motion said on Thursday that it lost a million BlackBerry owners worldwide during the company’s last financial quarter, the first such decline in the device’s history, Ian Austen reported on Friday in The New York Times.

headline: The Giving Spree | Edward Barber and Jay Osgerby
text: Who: Edward Barber and Jay Osgerby, the British designers responsible for 2012’s Olympic torch, for which they earned a spot in T’s “Twelve for ’12.”

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Instagram in Retreat, and ‘Jersey Shore’ Signs Off
text: The photo-sharing app Instagram on Thursday completed a full retreat from its proposed new terms of service that led to instant outcry from users, Nicole Perlroth and Jenna Wortham reported. The question, however, was whether the move came too late from Instagram, which was acquired this year by Facebook and is under the same pressure as its parent company to generate advertising revenue. The proposed changes included a clause that suggested Instagram would share users’ data — like their favorite places, bands, restaurants and hobbies — with Facebook and its advertisers to direct ads more precisely. In the interim, other services, including Flickr, which coincidentally has just introduced a new app, appeared to be gaining followers.

headline: Debt Ceiling Rises Again as Threat for the U.S.
text: The three major ratings agencies shrugged off this week’s breakdown in talks aimed at ending the fiscal impasse in Washington by Jan. 1, saying their outlook for America’s sovereign debt was already negative and would not immediately change.

headline: Passing the Bar: Ireland to Get Its Own Version of ‘Cheers’
text: Sometimes you want to go where everybody knows your name, and other times you want to go where your name is pronounced with a rich Irish brogue. Ireland, a nation which we understand has its own longstanding tradition of people gathering together in establishments that serve alcohol, will be getting a remade version of the NBC sitcom “Cheers” that transports its familiar cast of characters from a Boston bar to a rural Irish pub.

headline: Apollo Unit to Buy Aviva’s U.S. Unit for $1.8 Billion
text: A unit of Apollo Global Management agreed on Friday to buy the American operations of Aviva, the British insurer, for about $1.8 billion in cash.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: BBC: Well, they should have plenty of leftovers. Survivalists, calling themselves “preppers,” have been storing food for Friday’s apocalypse, which may or may not have been predicted by the ancient Mayans. – Glenn Collins

headline: Obama Presses Stripped-Down Plan to Limit Tax Increase
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama, conceding that a “grand bargain” for deficit reduction with Speaker John A. Boehner is unlikely, called Friday for Congress to approve a stripped-down measure by year’s end to prevent a tax increase for all but the richest taxpayers and to extend aid for two million unemployed Americans.

headline: Interpretive Freedom
text: In “America’s Unwritten Constitution,” Akhil Reed Amar, a commendably unorthodox and, in some ways, iconoclastic constitutional scholar at Yale Law School, bucks dominant opinions on both sides of the political spectrum. He contends that the written Constitution points to an unwritten one, and he argues that we can interpret with both intellectual honesty and analytical rigor. Aware that the idea of an unwritten constitution has been abused by judges and scholars on both the left and right, Amar insists that the idea itself is sound — indeed indispensable to the cause of constitutional fidelity — and needs rescuing from its abusers.

headline: When You Need a Stand-in for Champagne
text: PARIS—In a recent column, my colleague at The New York Times, Eric Asimov, looked at holiday alternatives to Champagne. Some people in Champagne would argue, with some justification, that there is no such thing, but there are certainly a lot of other wines with bubbles.

headline: Kerry Named for the Role of a Lifetime
text: WASHINGTON — With a patrician bearing, nearly three decades of service on the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, a highly decorated combat career in the Vietnam War, even a father who was a diplomat, John Kerry is the very picture of a secretary of state.

headline: Happy Birthday, Larry Eisenberg
text: The name Larry Eisenberg should sound familiar to Times readers. Mr. Eisenberg is among the more active members of our online community, and perhaps the most distinctive. For whenever he comments, he does so in verse. Specifically, in limerick form. He’s the closest thing this paper has to a poet in residence.

headline: Kesha Reverses Herself on ‘Die Young’ Lyrics
text: The massacre of school children in Newtown, Conn., has had reverberations in the radio world, as lyrics that seemed within the bounds of good taste two weeks ago suddenly seem to hit a sour note.

headline: ‘Amour’ Leads Foreign-Language Oscar Shortlist
text: The Academy winnowed down 71 films to a shortlist of 9 today that is heavy on European entries. The films vying for five spots on the ballot are:

headline: Book Review Podcast
text: This week, Robert P. George discusses “America’s Unwritten Constitution”; Leslie Kaufman has notes from the field; Jonathan Mahler talks about the fate of Detroit; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host.

headline: The Art of Getting Bloomberg ‘Super PAC’ Money
text: Are you a politician looking for a bit of cash from Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s “super PAC”?

headline: Hanging Around
text: Synchronized spins in Toronto’s skies.

headline: Who Made That Champagne Cork?
text: According to legend, a French monk named Dom Pérignon realized that a cork could seal in the fizz and flavor of Champagne after he saw Spanish travelers using tree bark to plug their water gourds. But George Taber, author of “To Cork or Not to Cork,” and other historians dispute this story. Taber cites evidence of Champagne corks on the Duke of Bedford’s household inventory list from 1665 — several years before Dom Pérignon took charge of the vineyards at the abbey of Hautvillers. Still, Pérignon and his name remain indelibly associated with Champagne.

headline: Laptop Prop?
text: I’m alternately amused and annoyed by the proximity of laptop computers on anchors’ desks during televised news broadcasts and other public-affairs programming. While I’d like to believe it’s there for the news reader’s reference as she tracks breaking news, or to look up momentarily forgotten facts like the capital of Estonia, I am more disposed to believe they are just props situated to convey the impression of a (phony) “up to the minute” information capacity. Does a news program have an ethical responsibility to avoid misrepresenting how current its reporters’ information is likely to be? What’s more, isn’t positioning the laptop to continuously display its manufacturer’s logo a form of advertising inappropriate for a news organization? JACK KENNY, BUFFALO

headline: Our Family Christmas, Rescinded
text: Several years ago, my mother announced that she was spending Christmas in Egypt with friends. I flew home anyway, alone, and spent two days making homemade pierogies and sauerkraut and bread for the traditional Carpatho-Rusyn meal we always have on Christmas Eve. At 10 p.m., my sister had an hour off from her rounds at the hospital. She came home and we ate. Then she left, and I did the dishes.

headline: This Week’s Movies: Dec. 21
text: This week, Times critics look at the Kathryn Bigelow drama “Zero Dark Thirty,” the Michael Haneke film “Amour,” and Seth Rogen and Barbra Streisand in “The Guilt Trip.” See all of this week’s reviews here.

headline: Snack Time
text: It’s hard not to snack at holiday time, but this week Martha Rose Shulman offers some healthful — and economical — alternatives to assuage the guilt.

headline: Plains of Blood
text: The “Iliad” is the goriest of ancient poems. Homer doesn’t sugarcoat the death of a hero, or even that of some insignificant Myrmidon. He’s an anatomist of death, a forensic pathologist of the bronze spear and the bronze sword. The Greek and Trojan warriors meet their fates in ways violent, bloody and graphic — had Greek battlefield surgeons existed, they could have used the “Iliad” as a textbook. Hollywood’s violence is merely a weak imitation of what the Greeks recited for centuries.

headline: Boehner Again Finds the Speaker’s Chair Can be Lonely
text: WASHINGTON — Less than 24 hours after failing to advance his plan to avert a fiscal crisis and telling his Republican colleagues to head home for the holidays, Speaker John A. Boehner walked silently into a news conference Friday on Capitol Hill, where reporters then pressured him to explain how he would manage to keep his job.

headline: Metaphors, Take Flight
text: Literary critics occasionally practice an aphoristic little art form without a name, one that captures in vivid analogies the distinctive architecture or choreography of a writer’s sentences. Sometimes critics (or reviewers) celebrate the author’s distinctive style, sometimes they mimic it, sometimes they skewer it. Whatever the case, these figurative sketches are always illuminating, and they provide a small literary pleasure of their own along the way.

headline: Back From Madness
text: In the vast and growing literature of ­affliction there is essentially one ­story: how the writer and her loved ones made it through. From a literary point of view, everything depends on the sensibility of the narrator, her comportment both as the teller and as the main character in her own tale. The reader’s resistance to these stories can be strong. Severe illness, by its nature, narrows the focus; the palette of experience both intensifies and shrinks; we crawl into the bush, figuratively speaking, and wait out our fate, fighting to survive. There is little suspense: the existence of the memoir is testament to the fact that the author has lived to tell the tale. But what hard-won nugget of wisdom has she brought back from her brief descent into a hell that most of us, for now, have been lucky enough to avoid? Can she give her ordeal meaning beyond the brute fact of the thing itself?

headline: Why Am I a Safer Driver?
text: You may not be a shrunken figure perched behind the steering wheel with a homburg on your head and a Gen Y’er gritting his teeth in the car behind as you lumber along in the passing lane (at least, not yet) but the fact is you probably don’t drive the way you used to.

headline: ‘We Shall Go On to the End’
text: The second volume of William Manchester’s best-selling life of Winston Churchill, published in 1988, left the newly appointed British prime minister in May 1940 standing on the verge of his “finest hour.” Manchester began work on the third and final volume, but the project was halted in 1998 when he suffered two strokes. “Language for me came as easily as breathing for 50 years,” he said, “and I can’t do it anymore.”

headline: Fraternity of Men
text: The intricate challenge that brothers pose for each other, aptly characterized by the playwright Athol Fugard as a “blood knot,” is right up there with the most intense, frustrating, rewarding and self-defining of social bonds. If I speak from experience, having one brother, think how much more is George Howe Colt, with three — an older, Harry, and two younger, Ned and Mark — authorized to expatiate on the subject. Anyone who’s had the pleasure of reading Colt’s previous, National Book Award-­nominated work, “The Big House” (2003), will know his delicate, detailed, ironically self-­mocking way with prose, and his lucid, affectionate fair-­mindedness. That book dealt mainly with the generational fortunes of his Boston/Cape Cod WASP clan; the present one, “Brothers,” is more a meditation on himself and his contemporaries, seen through the fraternal lens.

headline: Where Credit Is Due
text: Mothers and daughters. Let’s consider them — not because we’re intrigued by the eccentricities of women like Big and Little Edie Beale of “Grey Gardens” or the connection between Mary Wollstonecraft and Mary Shelley, but because fathers and daughters have taken up so much space. A case in point is Louisa May Alcott and her several dads, as Eve LaPlante reasonably argues. Was Louisa really descended solely from the legendary likes of Emerson, Hawthorne and Thoreau, never mind the transcendentally feckless Bronson Alcott? Didn’t she have a mother?

headline: 40 Days and 40 Nights
text: Antoine Wilson’s first novel, “The Interloper” (2007), had a brilliant conceit. Seeking vengeance against the man who murdered his wife’s brother — a crime that has crippled her with depression — Owen Patterson decides to write the killer in jail using a female pseudonym. The convict, Owen muses, “would fall in love with his correspondent and then, when she had wholly gained his affection . . . break his heart.”

headline: Bearing Arms
text: Despite the movie theater massacre in Aurora, Colo., in July — to say nothing of “smaller” mass shootings elsewhere in the United States this year — the issue of gun control was conspicuously absent from the 2012 presidential campaign. It wasn’t until mid-October that Barack Obama and Mitt Romney felt compelled to address the problem of gun violence — and then only because an undecided voter asked them about it at the town-hall presidential debate. As Stephen Colbert joked afterward: “Now is not the time to discuss gun control. We haven’t had a mass shooting in almost 49 days.” A mere four days after Colbert’s quip, another mass shooting left three people dead and four injured at a Wisconsin day spa. Which, of course, did nothing to inject the issue of gun control into the presidential race.

headline: Element of Surprise
text: “Subtle” is an inadequate word for Ruth Rendell. So are “crafty,” “cunning,” “clever” and “sly.” Although these are accurate descriptions of her confounding technique, a better word would be “surprising.” Whatever it is you might think Rendell is up to, especially when she’s writing as Barbara Vine — that’s not it.

headline: Fiction Chronicle
text: MY BRILLIANT FRIEND  Book One: Childhood, Adolescence.  By Elena Ferrante.  Europa Editions, paper, $17.

headline: A Man and an Island
text: This gleaming novel tells the story of a Ceylonese Odysseus born poor in 1899. Through his protagonist’s long and eventful life, Randy Boyagoda explores themes of shifting identity, of the diamond-hard determination to evade one’s destiny and of the inner landscapes of an island that itself undergoes a dramatic transformation. Boyagoda’s hero lives a long century, accruing wealth and sophistication, but his village is always there, as home always is, and the juxtaposition between “the stinking piled-up old ways” and the turning world beyond gives “Beggar’s Feast” much of its narrative tension.

headline: Remains to Be Seen
text: Back in 2009, when the American auto industry was in free-fall, Mark Binelli joined the great migration of newspaper reporters and magazine writers — myself among them — heading to Detroit. We were all looking for a fresh angle on what was essentially the same ­story: What happens to the city that they’ve been (barely) supporting when the Big Three, like the wobbly legs of a rickety old stool, finally give way?

headline: Paperback Row
text: A MAN OF PARTS,  by David Lodge. (Penguin, $17.) Once called “the man who invented tomorrow,” H. G. Wells (1866-1946) wrote in a range of forms and genres: from science fiction to gritty working-class realism and Wikipedia-like history. (An autodidact of deep intellectual curiosity, he also immersed himself in socialist politics and free love.) Lodge’s smart novel reimagines Wells’s life and his many tormented relationships with women, including Rebecca West.

headline: Editors’ Choice
text: THE ENTERTAINER: Movies, Magic, and My Father’s Twentieth Century,  by Margaret Talbot. (Riverhead, $28.95.) Talbot shrewdly examines the career of her father, the actor Lyle Talbot, which illuminates the first 60 years of the last century.

headline: Inside the List
text: CATS AND DOGGEREL: Serious poetry almost never shows up on the best-seller lists, but the unserious kind does make an occasional appearance. Witness for instance Calvin Trillin’s “Dogfight,” a collection of satirical verse about the 2012 presidential campaign, still bouncing around the extended hardcover nonfiction list after climbing as high as No. 12 last week. (Sample lines: “Reveal himself? No, Mitt would not be forced; / The humanizing had to be outsourced.”) Meanwhile, Francesco Marciuliano has spent six weeks on the hardcover advice, how-to and miscellaneous list with “I Could Pee on This: And Other Poems by Cats,” currently at No. 13 on the extended list. In a recent phone interview, Marciuliano told me he wrote the book while mourning his two cats, Boris and Natasha (“named after the characters in ‘Rocky and Bullwinkle,’ ” he clarified, “not ‘War and Peace’ ”), who had lived with him for some 17 years. “When you spend any real time with cats,” he said, “you eventually try to figure out what on earth is going on in their brains. Dogs wear everything on their sleeves — or flanks? — but cats are very poised and reserved, very serious about the job of being a cat.”

headline: Book Review Podcast: ‘America’s Unwritten Constitution’
text: This week in The New York Times Book Review, Robert P. George reviews “America’s Unwritten Constitution.” Mr. George writes:

headline: Musical Moments, Part IX: Strauss
text: A few readers also agreed about another overwhelming moment in music, the passage toward the end of Strauss’s opera “Der Rosenkavalier” when the Marschallin sings a resigned “Ja, Ja” as she walks out of the life of her much younger lover, Octavian, and out of the opera. Here is my take on it.

headline: On Our Radar: Bigger Marine Sanctuaries
text: In a move that would permanently ban oil drilling along more than 50 miles of rugged coastline, the Obama administration plans to significantly expand two marine sanctuaries in Northern California. [The Santa Cruz Sentinel]

headline: Leading Off: Were the Mayans Just Predicting the End of the N.H.L.?
text: We have finally made sense of the N.H.L. lockout. After a season of staring at this sorry spectacle and concluding that N.H.L. owners are the adult equivalent of children who light things on fire just because they like to watch them burn, there is a glimmer of reason in all of this.

headline: Candy Cane Scrooge
text: I’m considering getting the windows on my family S.U.V. tinted.

headline: G.M. Recalling 119,000 Pickups for Missing Hood Latch
text: General Motors is recalling almost 119,000 of its 2010-12 Chevrolet Colorado and GMC Canyon pickups because the hoods may fly open, the automaker has informed the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration.

headline: Volunteers Helped to Tell an Asteroid’s Story
text: On April 22, a fast-moving fireball flew through the sky over Nevada and California and exploded. Some people witnessed the event, others snapped photos, and a security camera near Lake Tahoe caught it on video.

headline: The ‘More Guns’ Argument
text: Of the many specious arguments against gun control, perhaps the most ridiculous is that what we really need is the opposite: more guns, in the hands of more people, in more places. If people were packing heat in the movies, at workplaces, in shopping malls and in schools, they could just pop up and shoot the assailant.

headline: Feeling For | Gargyle’s New Bags
text: Gargyle, the multibrand boutique that started online and turned brick-and-mortar with a New York City outpost in 2010, has just released a debut collection of women’s handbags. “We wanted to start with familiar shapes but then add frill and details and stuff that would be instantly recognizable as a Gargyle bag,” says Nhung Nguyan, who founded the shop with her husband, Don Vu. Made of dark textured leather, the made-in-New York collection is a trio of beloved styles — the circle (called the Elwood, shown here), the bucket (Omaha) and the satchel (Smarty Jones) — finished with subtle but effective embellishments, like zigzag trimming and custom hardware. “They’re really sort of masculine looking,” Nguyen says. “Masculine but in feminine shapes.”

headline: A Magical Day at Disney
text: Having visited Walt Disney World more than two dozen times, I’ve learned how to make my own magic. Here’s my idea of a perfect day.

headline: Inside Disney’s New Fantasyland
text: “YOU have a great gig,” I said to the mermaid as I sat down beside her in the giant clamshell. “You don’t have to schlep around.”

headline: Manifest Fantasy
text: Take a spin around Disney’s New Fantasyland, the largest expansion in the history of the Magic Kingdom.

headline: Your Disney Questions
text: For the Dec. 23 issue of the Travel section, I wrote about the grand opening of New Fantasyland at Walt Disney World Resort in Florida. Yet it was hardly unfamiliar territory. I’ve visited Walt Disney World more than two dozen times (and counting), which makes me something of an expert.

headline: N.R.A. Envisions ‘a Good Guy With a Gun’ in Every School
text: WASHINGTON — After a weeklong silence, the National Rifle Association announced Friday that it wants to arm security officers at every school in the country. It pointed the finger at violent video games, the news media and lax law enforcement — not guns — as culprits in the recent rash of mass shootings.

headline: For Quick Success, Be Flexible
text: THE members of Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater aren’t interchangeable, but some rise to the top faster than others. The elegant Jacqueline Green is everywhere this season, dancing lead roles in Kyle Abraham’s “Another Night” and Jiri Kylian’s “Petite Mort” as well as — and even she can hardly believe this — carrying the umbrella in the “Wade in the Water” section of Ailey’s 1960 masterpiece “Revelations.”

headline: New Spaces for the Revolution
text: JUDSON DANCE THEATER, a group of experimental artists who masterminded a series of performances from 1962 to 1964, altered the course of dance history. This wave of choreographers, inspired by composition workshops taught by Robert Ellis Dunn at Merce Cunningham’s studio, approached Judson Memorial Church as a space to show the pieces developed in the class after being turned down by the 92nd Street Y.

headline: Breakup Fees in NYSE’s Deal With ICE Show Lessons From Past
text: After its attempted merger with Deutsche Börse collapsed, NYSE Euronext‘s board grew a little wary of jumping into another major deal that could fall apart on antitrust grounds.

headline: Colorblind Casting Widens Opera’s Options
text: COLORBLIND casting has become commonplace in opera. In most instances to mention a singer’s race in a review would be not just irrelevant but in questionable taste. If a white Italian baritone portraying the title role of Verdi’s “Rigoletto” were to be greeted onstage by a black American soprano as Rigoletto’s daughter Gilda, that they are of different races would be a nonissue. What would matter is what always matters: the singing, the acting, the overall effectiveness of the performance and the production.

headline: With Kerry’s Exit Expected, Hopefuls Wait in the Wings
text: President Obama’s decision to pluck John Kerry of Massachusetts from the Senate to be his new secretary of state sets the stage for a comeback by the departing Senator Scott P. Brown, a Republican, even before he leaves office early next month.

headline: With Nomination, Kerry Has Chance to Reshape Résumé
text: Senator John Kerry’s nomination to be secretary of state makes him something of a throwback. He is an unsuccessful nominee for president who appears set to ascend to a major new political position following his loss.

headline: In Toledo, Layers of Spanish History
text: THE rain and morning fog had left the cobblestones of the old bridge too slippery to jog on. I had to get to the other side of the Tagus River to get a real view. I turned and looked.

headline: ‘Behind the Veil of the Forest’ in India
text: THE rutted road, part paved, part dirt, was a border between two worlds. To the left, a patchwork of villages, farms and fields covered the fertile plains between the Ganges and Yamuna Rivers. To the right rose the rugged, forested wilderness of the Shivalik Hills. Dehradun, the bustling capital of the northern state of Uttarakhand, was just 20 miles away, but felt much, much farther.

headline: Restaurant Report: Ammo in Hong Kong
text: Not far from the ceaseless thrum of Hong Kong’s busy Admiralty district, down a narrow footpath and through a thicket of lush greenery and wizened banyan trees, you’ll find a shimmering glass box. Peer in and you’ll see a well-heeled clientele perched in plush banquettes, hoisting glasses and passing around small plates.

headline: Letters to the Editor
text: Where the Slopes Are

headline: The Right Time to Say Goodbye
text: IN this season’s opening episodes of “Gossip Girl” the gang was once again on the trail of a missing Serena. (She’s disappeared before.) She was keeping secret the fact that she had slept with a boyfriend of Blair’s (not the first time); the two women weren’t on speaking terms (as usual). Dan was writing a tell-all (again). And Rufus was making waffles. (It’s what he does.) If it seems as if the show had visited this territory before, it had.

headline: Traveling Paths of Their Making
text: Melissa Aldana

headline: Off the Charts: Germany Perks Up
text: German job and export growth are slowing and industrial production is declining. But business sentiment has turned up and stocks have been strong.

headline: Struggling Red Hook Businesses Feed a Cookbook
text: In used bookstores and flea markets, I can never resist flipping through community cookbooks put together by churches, ladies’ clubs and such. You’ve seen them — they’re typically typewritten, with hand-drawn paper covers, and they’re bound with a wire spiral or a curled plastic comb.

headline: Simon de Pury Steps Down from Helm of Phillips de Pury
text: Just as the art world is disappearing for the holidays, Phillips de Pury & Company, the struggling boutique auction house, released an announcement that Simon de Pury — its chairman, principal auctioneer and the face of the company for the last 12 years — is stepping down. In a separate e-mail his wife, Michaela, who has been a senior director there, announced her departure too.

headline: 40 Years Without a Word
text: While my inner grump tried to scoff at “Mummenschanz,” my inner kid seldom stopped grinning. Sure, this Swiss mime troupe, which goes by the same name as its production, has been producing similar shows for 40 years. But its longevity is well earned, and in an age of ceaseless special effects, its low-tech feel is unexpectedly energizing.

headline: Dec. 23 — 29
text: IT’S that time of the year again: jam-band convergence, when New York City’s rock halls fill with bands playing marathon sets, settling in on their way to New Year’s Eve.

headline: A Hip-Hop Rant, With Epiphanies and Caricatures Included
text: “Ingenious Nature,” a theatrical mixtape now at SoHo Playhouse, is the white Canadian rapper Baba Brinkman’s latest foray into educational hip-hop theater.

headline: Two London Councils Battle Over Henry Moore Sculpture
text: Who really owns Old Flo?

headline: Weekend Fare
text: Known for its over-the-top weekend brunches, Beaumarchais, 409 West 13th Street, in the meatpacking district, brings its penchant for parties with an “End of the World” soiree Friday night. The French restaurant will be in a festive mood with Mayan décor, costumes, a special menu and music. For reservations, e-mail reservations@beaumarchais.com or call (212) 675-2400.

headline: A Legislative Revolt
text: TimesCast: Speaker John A. Boehner faces dissension in the ranks over fiscal deal. | Syria uses cluster bombs against civilians. | Tearing down after Sandy. | A hockey anomaly.

headline: ‘Argo’ and the Workaday C.I.A. Officer
text: John Goodman may not have done much research for his part in “Argo” but his castmate and director, Ben Affleck, sure did, from meeting with the real-life C.I.A. operative he plays, Tony Mendez, to scouring old news footage.

headline: Q&A: Setting AutoSave Times In Microsoft Office
text: Q.

headline: France Suspects Islamists in a Kidnapping
text: PARIS — The men responsible for the kidnapping Wednesday of a French citizen in northern Nigeria are believed to be linked to Al Qaeda’s North African affiliate or other radical Islamist groups in northern Mali, French officials said Friday.

headline: Anatomy of a Scene: ‘Django Unchained’
text: Quentin Tarantino, the writer and director of “Django Unchained,” narrates a scene from his movie.

headline: Beyond Wizards and Vampires, to Sex
text: Vampire and wizard fans are apparently ready for characters who shed their robes and show a little more skin.

headline: A Crowd Service Gives Tips on Cloud Service
text: If you are looking for a cloud service, 50,000 friends would like to help you out.

headline: House Speaker on Canceled Vote
text: House Speaker John A. Boehner failed to win support for his latest proposal to avert the fiscal cliff, and said he would still be willing to negotiate with President Obama.

headline: Outside the Box: Eight No-Wrap Gift Ideas
text: Consume, consume, consume. That message is about as easy to ignore this time of year as the sight of a plump, red-suited man tromping over a crest of new-fallen snow.

headline: Making an Argument for a Narrower Focus In Charitable Donations
text: THIS is a time of year when solicitations for donations are coming at you from every direction, and for good reason: the end of the year is when people make most of their gifts to charity.

headline: Text of the N.R.A. Speech
text: The prepared remarks delivered by Wayne LaPierre, executive vice president of the National Rifle Association, on Friday.

headline: Vain Glorious | Barber & Supply Comes to Williamsburg
text: After having colonized downtown Manhattan, the boys behind F.S.C. Barber have finally opened their first outpost in Williamsburg to cater to Brooklyn’s hirsute hipster class. Barber & Supply, the new salon that opens tomorrow, features old-school Belmont barber chairs (with custom built-in ash trays), oak and nickel cabinetry, and a pop-up apothecary, which will rotate every three months, showcasing different purveyors. (Malin+Goetz is first up.) Since the Brooklyn shop allowed for more space, the founder Sam Buffa decided to build a large, Grand Central Terminal-style communal bench so clients can hang around in a more gentlemanly fashion. Now if they only they did shoeshines.

headline: ‘Walking Dead’ Gains a New Season But Its Show Runner Becomes Latest Casualty
text: “The Walking Dead,” AMC’s hit drama series about the survivors of a zombie apocalypse, will continue for another season, but not all the members of its creative team will continue on to fight the undead hordes: the cable channel said on Friday that its show runner, Glen Mazzara, was leaving the series.

headline: The Ultimate Amenity: Grandparents
text: THE unlikely new custodians of the nuclear family are young, urban and inextricably caught up in their careers: Do not expect them to flee the city for the suburban lawns and balms of their wonder years. They don’t want to go home again, not even if or when their lives start to be accessorized by cradles, strollers, pacifiers, pediatrician appointments and nannies. They prefer to customize the complexities of the city to fit their needs, not escape the city for simpler climes.

headline: Russia Moves a Step Closer to Banning Adoptions by U.S. Citizens
text: MOSCOW — The lower house of Parliament gave its final approval on Friday to a proposed ban on the adoption of Russian children by American citizens, drawing a sharp response from the United States, which urged officials not to play politics with the lives of orphans.

headline: The Sweet Spot | Pondering ‘Lincoln’
text: David Carr and A. O. Scott talk about Steven Spielberg’s latest offering, and whether moviegoers prefer rollicking tales or history lessons.

headline: Each Wed in 1980, Three Sisters and Their Spouses Look Back
text: BACK in 1980, three sisters — Susan, Carol and Beth Driscoll — were married in three separate ceremonies. Thirty-two years later, they are all still married. Susan, the eldest of the three, married John Devlin on June 14; now both 59, they live in Oxford, Md., where she is executive director of a nonprofit and he is a management consultant. Carol, 57, married James Kagdis, 55, on Aug. 2; they live in Fairfield, Conn., where she is a medical director and he a business acquisitions manager for an aircraft company. Last in line was Beth, who married Samuel Kinney on Oct. 4. Beth, 55, is a director of community services; Samuel, 57, is an insurance broker and they live Summit, N.J.

headline: After His Home Was Flooded and His Music Lost, the Maestro Returns
text: Irwin Meyer was never afraid of the sea. He joined the Navy and was on a combat-crippled destroyer off Omaha Beach on D-Day for the invasion of Normandy, and on three subsequent invasions in Europe.

headline: On Television, Holiday Specials Draw Plenty of Eyeballs
text: In keeping with a long-standing holiday tradition, the television networks filled the airwaves with Christmas-themed specials and movies this year. While some classics, like “It’s a Wonderful Life” and “A Christmas Story” will not be broadcast until Monday, viewers have had plenty of holiday programming to choose from throughout the month.

headline: Weighing the Consequences of a Money Fund Overhaul
text: Anyone know what to do with $2.6 trillion?

headline: Even in Disarray, G.O.P. Has Power to Constrain Obama
text: WASHINGTON — It’s been 45 days since voters reaffirmed their faith in President Obama and heartily endorsed his policy agenda for the next four years.

headline: No Lip-Syncing for the Wretched of Paris
text: London

headline: N.R.A. Calls for Armed Guards in Schools
text: Wayne LaPierre of the National Rifle Association announces the creation of the National School Shield Program and calls on government to put armed security officers in every school in the nation.

headline: Anatomy of a Scene: ‘Django Unchained’
text: In the middle of “Django Unchained,” Quentin Tarantino’s energetic mashup of spaghetti westerns and blacksploitation movies, comes a quiet and important scene. It’s a moment involving Django’s wife, the slave Broomhilda, played by Kerry Washington. The scene finds Django (Jamie Foxx) and his partner, Dr. King Schultz (Christoph Waltz), on a mission to rescue Broomhilda from a plantation. In the video above, Mr. Tarantino narrates a closer look at the scene, discussing his choice of Ennio Morricone music, the delicate lighting and the subtle ways the actors play the moment.

headline: Re-emerging BMG Buys Rights to ’80s Hits From Culture Club and the Like
text: 2:51 p.m. | Updated BMG Rights Management, which in just four years has become a major music-publishing company, has expanded once again with a $90 million deal for some 30,000 songs, including a slew of 1980s hits by Culture Club, Tears for Fears and the Human League.

headline: Kremlin Statements Move Farther Away From Syria’s Leader
text: MOSCOW — President Vladimir V. Putin said Friday that Russia’s main goal in the Syrian conflict was to avoid chaos, the latest in a series of remarks that have served to distance Moscow from the government of President Bashar al-Assad and shift the focus to a controlled political transition.

headline: A Trove of Tablets for Young Hands
text: The Times's Children's tech critic reviews 21 tablets for children.

headline: Hagel Apologizes About Remarks Against Gay Diplomat
text: Chuck Hagel, a candidate for secretary of defense whose record on gay-rights issues has come under fire in recent days, apologized on Friday for remarks he made as a senator that an openly gay man nominated for a diplomatic post should not represent the United States.

headline: Mexico Frees American in Case That Drew Criticism
text: MEXICO CITY — An American Marine veteran who spent the past four months in a Mexican prison for crossing the border with a shotgun was released on Friday, according to his family and lawmakers who came to his aid, ending an ordeal that had raised tensions between the two governments.

headline: Fiscal Cliff Looms
text: The Times’s Binyamin Appelbaum and Peter Lattman talk about the G.O.P. revolt following Speaker John A. Boehner’s effort at a compromise during fiscal cliff negotiations with President Obama.

headline: In Filing, News Corp. Says Publishing Business Showed $2.1 Billion Loss
text: Potential investors got a glimpse of the financial challenges that Rupert Murdoch’s soon-to-be spun-off publishing company could face. In a regulatory filing, News Corporation said its publishing businesses lost $2.1 billion in the fiscal year that ended June 30.

headline: Graphic Books Best Sellers: Pogo Possum and Friends
text: Volume two of “Pogo,” by Walt Kelly, which continues the deluxe reprinting of the newspaper strip starring Pogo Possum and set in the Okefenokee Swamp, is at No. 4 on the graphic books hardcover best-seller list this week. This volume introduces some cool characters: Tammanany the Tiger, Uncle Antler the bull moose, and three bats named Bewitched, Bothered and Bemildred. Carolyn Kelly, the cartoonist’s daughter, designed and edited the book, as well as restoring some of the strips. This volume also features annotations and commentary by the comic historians R.C. Harvey and Mark Evanier.

headline: Voting From the Heart (Once the Online Snags Were Solved)
text: 11:42 a.m. | Updated  Oscar voting has been live online for a week, and almost from the first, there were problems.

headline: The Sweet Spot: Dec. 21
text: David Carr and A. O. Scott talk about Steven Spielberg’s latest offering, and whether moviegoers prefer rollicking tales or history lessons.

headline: Liberating Pleats
text: SMALL costume exhibits are finding a home at the Queen Sofía Spanish Institute. The cultural center, on Park Avenue near 68th Street, was host to an impressive Balenciaga exhibition in 2010 and now one devoted to the Venetian textile maven Mariano Fortuny. The exhibition spaces are not generous, and they are on separate floors, but on a weekday morning a visitor might find the place to herself, and that’s pretty rare. Also, for “Fortuny: An Artistic Legacy,” the set designer Stefan Beckman (he does Marc Jacobs’s shows, among other presentations) has created a spare but powerful design that helps illuminate the multiple talents and paradoxical nature of Mariano Fortuny y Madrazo.

headline: 12 Days of Gadgets: Necomimi Brain-Powered Cat Ears
text: On the 12th day of Christmas, my true love gave to me…the last gift idea for gadget lovers who don’t really merit spending over $100 on.

headline: Explosion of Brands and Erosion of Soul
text: Now that the college football bowl season has kicked off — four games down, a mere 31 to go — we should all pause, put down our Bud Lights and reflect on what this annual ritual reveals about our nation’s soul.

headline: The Flip Is Dead. Long Live the Touchdown Celebration.
text: To flip or not to flip, that was one of the biggest questions leading up to the Giants’ game against Atlanta on Sunday.

headline: E.P.A. Issues Standards on Air Pollution for Boilers
text: WASHINGTON — The Environmental Protection Agency on Friday issued long-delayed new air pollution standards for industrial boilers, incinerators and cement kilns. The rules provide significant concessions to industry and allow several additional years for full compliance in an effort to minimize job and economic impacts, officials said.

headline: Engineered Fish Moves a Step Closer to Approval
text: Government regulators moved a big step closer on Friday to allowing the first genetically engineered animal — a fast-growing salmon — to enter the nation’s food supply.

headline: Knicks Lose Their Taste for Turnovers
text: Though the grind of the N.B.A. season makes them rare, Knicks practices this year have begun with an amusing refrain: the coaching staff, including Mike Woodson, runs baseline-to-baseline laps, one for each turnover under 13 the Knicks committed in the last game.

headline: In Varied Housing Size, Diversity Insurance
text: IN 1974, Nora and Al Galland, their two young sons in tow, packed up their belongings and traded in a cramped one-bedroom apartment in Brooklyn Heights for a five-bedroom colonial in Hastings-on-Hudson, in southern Westchester.

headline: Living In | Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y.
text: A village in southern Westchester has a diverse housing stock that includes Tudors, colonials, contemporaries and apartments, in many price ranges.

headline: Image of the Day: Dec. 21
text: A demonstration in Mumbai against Swiss drug manufacturer Novartis’s attempt to get its cancer drug patented in India.

headline: Revisiting Apple, NBC and Gay Marriage
text: After Apple introduced its iPhone 5 in China last week, Apple’s chief executive, Tim Cook, hailed the rollout as the company’s most successful ever, with two million handsets sold the first weekend. It’s the kind of news that in the past has sent Apple stock soaring.

headline: For the Holidays, a Nostalgia Trip on a Bus Like Ralph Kramden’s
text: “I’m in a time machine right now,” John Davies said from his seat beside a window that, like the people on the bus in the nursery-school lyric, went up and down. A “drop-style window,” to those in the know.

headline: Rachael Kun and Tim Morehouse
text: THERE is no instruction manual for how two people should get to know each other and fall in love. But for Rachael Kun, that book does exist. And little did she know that Cupid’s arrow was actually a sword.

headline: Popcast: Best Songs of 2012
text: This week, in part two of our year-end music discussions — last week we covered the best albums of 2012 — the Times pop critics Jon Pareles, Jon Caramanica, Nate Chinen and Ben Ratliff discuss the best songs of 2012.

headline: New Label Alert | Friends & Associates
text: Over the course of his career as a fashion editor and stylist Matthew Edelstein has had plenty of opportunity to form opinions about American fashion — and now, with his new clothing line, he’s decided to do something about them. “In the past few years it’s become all about heritage,” he says. “I want to pull away the heritage, strip away the nostalgia and do modern sportswear. I love the idea of taking back that easy, modern spirit that designers like Claire McCardell and Geoffrey Beene and Perry Ellis had.” Friends & Associates, named for what Edelstein considers the collaborative spirit of creative ventures, does just that, focusing on bright, polished pieces that make getting dressed in the morning a breeze. The resort collection, which is available beginning today on the Friends & Associates Web site, features lots of crisp cottons and an oversize polka dot print in what Edelstein calls “candy store” colors; spring offerings, pictured here, are a continuation of the same athletic-inspired theme with a buffalo check thrown into the mix.

headline: Signing Off Until (Nearly) Next Year
text: Nothing like a deflated end-of-the-world prophecy to underscore a brief goodbye. The Bagger will be taking a short and much-needed break next week, stocking up on screener time like so many Academy members and others avoiding harsh realities. Enjoy the holiday and see you on almost-2013.

headline: A Biodiversity Map, Version 2.0
text: Tigers and pandas live in Asia, kangaroos and koalas in Australia and polar bears and snowy owls in the Arctic. The world can be divided into regions based upon the unique types of animals that live there. Or so the thinking went when Alfred Russel Wallace published the scientific world’s first global biodiversity map in 1876.

headline: Dreaming of Haiti
text: Prince Loveridge, a free black Northerner, taught at a segregated school on Staten Island during the Civil War. Shortly after the war began, he published a letter in the short-lived abolitionist paper The Pine and Palm, asking why more of his students hadn’t heard about the emigration plan to Haiti. For blacks like Loveridge, who were free but hardly treated equal, it seemed to be on everyone’s mind.

headline: Big Ticket | Sold for $39,000,018
text: The stealth sale of a duplex penthouse at 730 Park Avenue coveted by an elite assemblage of suitors — people with the requisite liquidity to part with nearly $40 million in cash in a heartbeat and a backup portfolio capable of impressing the building’s extraordinarily selective board — was the biggest sale of the week, according to city records.

headline: How Focused Is Your Charitable Giving?
text: In this weekend’s Wealth Matters column, Paul Sullivan tells the story of Leonard A. Lauder’s commitment to breast cancer research and uses it to make the case for focusing your philanthropy on just a few causes.

headline: The Year in Style
text: Many of the most memorable style moments of 2012 are symptomatic of an industry in which the players are struggling to retain their relevancy and their shares of the pie.

headline: How to Guard Kevin Durant
text: Kevin Durant is a basketball player of unique physical dimensions and capabilities. No one that tall has been so quick and skilled. He sheds the players tall enough to bother his jump shot with his whip of a crossover and has become strong enough to shuck the smaller defenders who grab and hold in a desperate attempt to deny him breathing room.

headline: ‘Silence,’ ‘Tribes’ and ‘Fuerza Bruta’ Aren’t Closing Just Yet
text: Three long-running Off Broadway shows that were slated to close have extended their runs due to audience demand, the producers of each have announced.

headline: Italian Quits Post, but Can’t Be Counted Out

headline: It’s the End of the World and I Feel Fine
text: SOME choose to marry on a numerically auspicious date (12/12/2012; 11/11/2011 to name two). Others are more focused on the proximity of the sun — as in “will I be warm, but not too warm in my expensive wedding gown?” Still others find that to wed on doomsday is a perfectly romantic notion.

headline: Retailers Try to Adapt to Device-Hopping Shoppers
text: Ryan O’Neil, a Connecticut government employee, was in the market to buy a digital weather station this month. His wife researched options on their iPad, but even though she found the lowest-price option there, Mr. O’Neil made the purchase on his laptop.

text: “IT’S the moment every actor actually fears,” Matt Damon said, looking around a suite at the Waldorf-Astoria in mock terror.

headline: Germans Are Upbeat Even Though News Is Not
text: FOR much of the last half of this year, the German economy appeared to be losing steam, in no small part because of the growing problems in the rest of the euro zone.

headline: Symphony of Compositions From Decomposition
text: THE cinema may or may not be dead, but film almost certainly is. Celluloid-based entertainment will become either a dim memory or a boutique specialty within the next few years, as the major studios continue to phase out bulky, old-fashioned (but oh so beautiful) 35-millimeter prints in favor of Digital Cinema Packages (DCPs, for short) delivered to theaters on hard drives or through high-speed Internet connections.

headline: The Images of 2012: New York
text: For many in New York and elsewhere, 2012 will forever be connected to a pair of devastating disasters: the widespread damage caused by Hurricane Sandy and the wrenching massacre of 26 people, including 20 children, at Sandy Hook Elementary School in Newtown, Conn.

headline: The N.R.A. Crawls From Its Hidey Hole
text: Wayne LaPierre, the executive vice president of the National Rifle Association, would have been better advised to remain wherever he had been hiding after the Newtown, Conn., massacre, rather than appear at a news conference on Friday. No one seriously believed the N.R.A. when it said it would contribute something “meaningful” to the discussion about gun violence. The organization’s very existence is predicated on the nation being torn in half over guns. Still, we were stunned by Mr. LaPierre’s mendacious, delusional, almost deranged rant.

headline: City Rejects Proposal to End Fight Over Bike Lane
text: The group behind a lengthy campaign against a bike lane on Prospect Park West said this week that it had laid the framework for its clash with the city to end.

headline: A Cheeky Take on a Holiday Classic
text: In “Nut/Cracked,” David Parker’s bare-bones rendition of the perennial holiday ballet, you’ll see a Santa with a shaving-cream beard, a Sugar Plum solo performed in the dark by a man armed with a flashlight, and a Chinese variation in which another male dancer gulps a single noodle from a takeout carton. What you won’t come across is a tutu, a wand or a nutcracker. The dancers, who wear black sweats and white T-shirts, are masters of loose, barefoot tap.

headline: Celebrations Around the World of Another Day on Earth
text: People marked the end of a 5,125-year cycle known as the Long Count in the Mayan calendar, while others braced for what they thought was the end of the world on Dec. 21.

headline: As Doomsday Flops, Rites in Ruins of Mayan Empire
text: TULUM, Mexico — Midway through the supposed end of the world here, searing solar rays blasted a group of people lying on the beach. One of them turned to a visitor and with no trace of apocalyptic agony reported on what was obvious.

headline: This Bach Suite Is Making All Local Stops
text: Slowly, surely, it began dawning on the G train passengers Friday afternoon. These were not ordinary subway buskers. This was no accident. Something was going on.

headline: Batting Their Lashes Won’t Do It All; They’ve Got Big Tutus to Fill
text: Les Ballets Trockadero de Monte Carlo serve largely as a critique — however loving — of the conventions and traditions of ballet, many of which can look awfully musty to modern-day eyes: the tiaras, the fairy tales, the hierarchies that flourish onstage and off.

headline: Kerry on Global Issues
text: Long before he was nominated to serve as secretary of state on Friday, Senator John Kerry has been one of the Democrats’ top voices on foreign policy, whether as chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee since 2009, the party’s presidential nominee in 2004, or as a Vietnam veteran testifying about America’s role there in 1971. Here are some of his recent statements on issues he is likely to confront during his term.

headline: Arrest of a Sunni Minister’s Bodyguards Prompts Protests in Iraq
text: BAGHDAD — Protests erupted Friday in Sunni-dominated areas of Iraq after 10 bodyguards to Rafe al-Essawi, the finance minister and a top Sunni politician, were arrested on terrorism charges in an episode that further deepened a political crisis that first flared a year ago, after the American military departed.

headline: Before the Clock Strikes 12, a Time to Indulge
text: THE holidays present a number of opportunities to splurge, and New Year’s Eve is the ultimate night for it. Though it may seem a cliché, the classic combination of blini and caviar is the perfect example — indulgent, elegant and delectable to the extreme. If you are hosting a small crowd for drinks (preferably Champagne or vodka with these), it’s all you need to serve, though it also can be a sit-down first course. Preparation is simple: the blini are topped with a dab of crème fraîche, a spoonful of caviar and a drizzle of butter.

headline: Choosing Your Caviar (but Don’t Expect a Bargain)
text: There’s a little decadence at hand in this week’s City Kitchen column, but worry not — that’s what New Year’s resolutions are for. Blini and caviar may sound cliché, but it’s a festive treat to go with that Champagne or vodka you’re sipping, and that’s what the holidays are for. Or at least that’s how I feel this year.

headline: The Lhotas, Loyal Republicans, Gave to Democrats, Too
text: If Joseph J. Lhota had his druthers, A. Gifford Miller would be serving out his second term as mayor, and David S. Yassky would be entering his fifth term as a Brooklyn congressman.

headline: Outbursts of Full-Bodied Joy
text: Lovers of Handel’s “Messiah” who look forward to taking in a holiday performance each year have lots of choices in New York. Whether you prefer the piece played by a period-instrument ensemble or a modern orchestra; sung by a chorus of hundreds or a chamber choir; presented in a large church, an intimate chapel or a concert hall, you can usually find what you desire.

headline: Tasting Freedom, at Last, in Black, White and Sepia
text: First, there was the big question, which Deborah Willis and Barbara Krauthamer had been talking about for years: What does freedom look like? Then there was the small, somber face of Dolly, whose photograph the two women, both academics, had come across separately in their research and wondered about ever since. It was affixed to a handwritten wanted notice from 1863, under a headline offering a “$50 Reward!!” for the return of Dolly to her owner in Augusta, Ga.

headline: Champagne’s Fancy Tricks
text: HOW to toast the new year? Perhaps some Champagne. Or maybe a cocktail. Then again, why choose when you can have them both in one glass?

headline: Make Way for Kilowatts: A Growing-Up Year for Plug-Ins
text: FOR those who advocate the electrification of the automobile, it has been a good year. No fewer than eight significant plug-in models came to market in the United States in 2012.

headline: The Scourge of Guns, 1866 Edition
text: Lest you think that the gun-control debate is a modern-day phenomenon, the following editorial appeared a mere 53,437 days ago, on page 4 of The New-York Times of April 30, 1866, under the headline “Carrying Firearms.”

headline: A Progress Report on Fracking and Water Safety
text: The federal Environmental Protection Agency released a progress report on Friday about its national study of the potential impacts of hydraulic fracturing on drinking water supplies. In nearly 200 pages, the agency lays out data, case studies and a summary of research into issues like spills and the treatment and disposal of wastewater.

headline: In Knicks, Echoes of 76ers of 2000-01

headline: From Stravinsky and Rossini, an Evening of Madcap Adventures
text: On Wednesday evening the Mannes Opera presented a double bill of one-act comedies at the Kaye Playhouse at Hunter College: Stravinsky’s “Mavra” and Rossini’s “Scala di Seta” (“Silk Ladder”). That both works are so rarely performed is a shame, not only because they brim with comic verve and musical invention, but also because they seem to feed a contemporary appetite for brisk situational comedy served with a side of snark. “Mavra,” especially, with a running time of under 30 minutes and a score like a laugh track, felt like a TV sitcom in Laura Alley’s fresh and entertaining production.
