headline: The False Promise of Energy Independence
text: The International Energy Agency recently confirmed what market watchers have been saying for a year: oil and gas production in the United States is surging and is expected to continue to rise. This trend has led a parade of analysts and even the government’s National Intelligence Council to predict that, after four decades of failed attempts, America might soon become energy independent. This view, if taken too far, is not only wrong, it is dangerous. The United States would remain entangled with the global oil market indefinitely even if it were to import no oil. Political leaders lulled into a false sense of security by rising domestic oil and gas output run the risk of making big mistakes.

headline: Tesla Begins East Coast Fast-Charging Corridor
text: Tesla Motors officially opened on Friday the first 480-volt Supercharger stations on the East Coast, effectively making possible a Boston-to-Washington trip in the company’s Model S sedan, which the Environmental Protection Agency has rated at 265 miles of range with the larger 85-kilowatt-hour battery pack.

headline: Beltway Stop in the Oscar Race
text: LOS ANGELES — This month Senator Al Franken, Democrat of Minnesota, got a laugh from the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences when he rose to present an honorary Oscar. Filmmakers, he said, should be flattered to know that powerful lawmakers — like him — talk movies in the Senate cloakroom.

headline: Bahrain Welcomes European Delegation, Not Delegates’ Calls to Free Dissidents
text: Last Updated, Saturday, 10:34 a.m. As The Lede reported on Wednesday, a delegation from the European Parliament visited Bahrain this week to discuss human rights, just as the kingdom jailed a rights advocate for documenting a protest on Twitter.

headline: The Week in Pictures for Dec. 21
text: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include the shootings in Newtown, Conn.; the plight of an apartment complex after Hurricane Sandy; and a program that matches nurses with low-income mothers.

headline: Critics’ Picks: Great Performances Without the Guilt
text: ENGINES are getting smaller, with V-6s replacing V-8s in many car and truck lines, and 4-cylinder power plants showing up even in large luxury sedans. But while fuel economy is rising, as automakers prepare for strict mileage standards that take effect over the next 12 years, enthusiasts’ fears have proved unfounded: exciting, fun-to-drive cars hardly seem endangered.

headline: Lawrence Ulrich’s Top 10 0f 2012
text: The FR-S and BRZ twins are No. 1, and another duo, from Audi, are among the year’s best cars. The Honda Accord comes in fifth.

headline: Second Avenue and East 19th Street, 4:58 P.M.
text: N.Y. See: There is still time to buy a tree.

headline: A Year of Few Dull Moments
text: IN a year full of comebacks (and a few setbacks), memorable anecdotes were plentiful. Here are some automotive highlights of 2012.

headline: Lincoln Strategy: We’ll Try Anything
text: ON Dec. 3, Lincoln formally rebranded itself the Lincoln Motor Company, kicking off a marketing barrage for Ford’s sole remaining luxury division. A Facebook post announcing the brand’s name change attracted nearly 2,000 comments.

headline: A Spot for Thai Curry, Washed Down With Tea
text: To be frank, I wasn’t thrilled with the tom kha that I ordered at Wild Ginger, a Thai restaurant that opened in July of 2011. A traditional soup made with lemon grass and coconut milk, it was thin and dull. And although I liked the Thai chicken dumplings, they didn’t rival any on my “best dumplings” list.

headline: Police Strategies for Dealing With School Shootings Changed After Columbine
text: The police officers were inside an elementary school in Queens, guns drawn. They moved quickly down the halls, clearing classroom after classroom until they arrived outside the one they were looking for. The one with the gunman inside.

headline: Guiding Gay Evangelicals Out of the Campus Closet
text: In the DC Comics universe, Kate Kane is a lesbian who dons a mask to fight crime as Batwoman. In the real universe, Kate Kane is the pseudonym of a bisexual woman in her 20s who this year helped found QueerPHC, a blog for gay, lesbian and otherwise unstraight students and alumni of a conservative Christian college.

headline: SportAccord Mind Sports Games
text: The difference between winning and losing at the bridge table can be the play of one card in 69 boards.

headline: An English Pub From Doorway to Mash
text: The Good Life, an English pub in Massapequa Park, will win fans on the basis of its beer selection alone: 24 on draft and 70 more in bottles. But the place also has a spirited atmosphere, speedy service, 16 television sets, and food that most often satisfies.

headline: Confessions of a Man in a Fedora
text: During his concert at the Barclays Center on Thursday night, Leonard Cohen spent a lot of time in an unusual pose for a rock star: on his knees, like a supplicant or a suitor. Those are just two of the roles he takes in his songs. He’s also a lover, a cad, a penitent, a believer, a cynic, a comedian, a kindly codger and a prophet of catastrophe.

headline: Hurricane Relief Bill Clears Hurdle in the Senate
text: WASHINGTON — A $60.4 billion bill to pay for recovery efforts in states pummeled by Hurricane Sandy took a major step toward passage in the Senate on Friday.

headline: Meals With a Twist, Starting With Popcorn
text: Watertown has its share of pizza parlors, diners, Chinese takeout and run-of-the-mill tavern food. Since spring 2012, it also has the Main Street Grill, which strives toward a more refined cuisine.

headline: Alabama to End Isolation of Inmates With H.I.V.
text: A federal judge on Friday ordered Alabama to stop isolating prisoners with H.I.V.

headline: A Night for Indulgence
text: What inspires revelers to cram into Times Square on New Year’s Eve, sporting goofy eyewear and clapping mittens to keep warm? Well, something of that same spirit — a desire for camaraderie — has people making last-minute dinner reservations, wanting emphatically not to be alone in the hours leading up to midnight on Dec. 31.

headline: Justice Dept. and Puerto Rico Agree to Overhaul the Island’s Troubled Police Force
text: WASHINGTON — The Justice Department’s Civil Rights Division and the government of Puerto Rico agreed Friday to sweeping changes to the commonwealth’s large and troubled Police Department intended to help overcome a history of discrimination, violence and corruption.

headline: An Accidental Comedian of the People
text: BERLIN

headline: Mole Makes His Way to an Enchanted Place
text: Mr. Toad is really not a bad guy. A little conceited, yes. A little carried away with the joy of possessions, like his fast cars and all the beautiful things in his grand home, Toad Hall. But considering that he is the richest creature in town, he is surprisingly lovable. And as played with enormous presence and easy style by Tituss Burgess, he is the comic center of “A Wind in the Willows Christmas,” the sweet, expertly staged holiday offering at the Two River Theater Company in Red Bank.

headline: Acting C.I.A. Director Disputes Depiction of Torture in ‘Zero Dark Thirty’
text: “I would not normally comment on a Hollywood film,” reads the first line of a statement released Friday afternoon by Michael Morell, the Central Intelligence Agency’s acting director, directed at employees but posted on the agency’s Web site, “but I think it important to put ‘Zero Dark Thirty,’ which deals with one of the most significant achievements in our history, into some context.”

headline: Study Finds Flaws in Pipeline Leak Detection Systems
text: A forthcoming federal report on pipeline safety has found that members of the general public are more likely to identify oil and gas spills than the pipeline companies’ own leak detection systems.

headline: Medicare’s Influential Chief Actuary to Retire
text: WASHINGTON — Richard S. Foster, who as chief actuary of the Medicare program for the last 18 years nettled presidents of both parties with his projections of rapid growth in federal health care spending, will retire next month, the Obama administration said Friday.

headline: In Syria, Cluster Munitions Takes Its Toll
text: In an article on Friday, C.J. Chivers examines the effect of cluster bombs on the Syrian civilian population. He writes:

headline: China: Report Links Former Police Chief to Murder
text: A Chinese news organization, Southern Metropolis Weekly, has reported that Wang Lijun, a former police chief in Chongqing, played a direct role in organizing the murder of Neil Heywood, a British businessman found dead in a hotel room in November 2011. The publication reported this week that it had obtained documents that said one or more witnesses had told officials that Mr. Wang had examined a container of cyanide with Gu Kailai, the wife of Bo Xilai, the former party chief of Chongqing, on Nov. 12, 2011. Ms. Gu had thought up a plot to kill Mr. Heywood by poisoning him, and Mr. Wang encouraged her on Nov. 13 to meet Mr. Heywood for dinner and then poison him, the report said. During this year’s trial of Ms. Gu, witnesses said she tried to think of ways to kill Mr. Heywood with Mr. Wang, but the statements did not indicate Mr. Wang had played a direct role in the poisoning plot, according to one lawyer at the trial. Ms. Gu was convicted of Mr. Heywood’s murder and was given a commuted death sentence; she could be imprisoned for life. Mr. Wang was later given a 15-year sentence after being convicted on various charges.

headline: A Christmas Show Within a Show
text: Can true love triumph over squabbles and misunderstandings? Will the inn be saved from bankruptcy? Can the kindly retired general find peace and purpose as a civilian? Is it really a good idea to count your blessings instead of sheep?

headline: Nice-Guy Ryan Gets in the Way of Coach Ryan
text: In 2001, I was a member of a Denver Broncos defense that was, in all honesty, a mess. The defensive coordinator at the time was Greg Robinson, whose favorite saying was, “Guys, it’s never as bad or as good as you think it is.” And in most instances he was right. Sometimes a little perspective is needed. But in the case of the Jets and Rex Ryan, that perspective does not exist.

headline: Cuba: National Assembly President to Leave His Post
text: Ricardo Alarcón will leave his post as president of Cuba’s National Assembly in February after two decades on the job, furthering a gradual generational transition that President Raúl Castro has recently begun to prioritize. The government recently elevated its foreign minister, Bruno Rodríguez, to the Communist Party’s political bureau, and with the departure of Mr. Alarcón, 75, analysts said the groundwork was being laid for a time when neither the Castros nor their contemporaries governed. He served for years as Cuba’s main point man on relations with the United States, and he has often been described as Cuba’s third-most powerful official. But Mr. Alarcón was also seen as a loyalist of Fidel more than Raúl, and speculation about his fate has been swirling since last summer, when the police arrested one of his top aides on suspicion of corruption and spying.

headline: Three Men Appear in Court in Mysterious Terror Case
text: Three men appeared in Federal District Court in Brooklyn on Friday on charges that they had trained to be suicide bombers with a Somali terrorist group.

headline: Giants Offensive Line Hopes to Be Intact for Ravens, Despite Injuries
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — One of the many disturbing elements of the Giants’ 34-0 manhandling by the Falcons in Atlanta on Sunday occurred when Chris Snee, a three-time Pro Bowl guard, missed part of the second quarter with a hip injury.

headline: A Tiffany Gem, Restored to Glory
text: IRVINGTON, N.Y. — Painted in gold leaf, the words “Knowledge is Power” adorn the entrance to the reading room in the Town Hall of Irvington. The lettering is elaborate, the phrase itself like an incantation. As a child, I read it nearly every day as I entered the library. The words seemed to promise something the room did not deliver, something more than institutional lighting and faded encyclopedias.

headline: If You’re Trying to Stretch a Budget, Forgo the Fowl
text: Some festive, if quirky, expressions of true love hit a record this year.

headline: Playing the Odds for a Scott Brown Senate Comeback
text: Massachusetts voters do not just know Senator Scott P. Brown. They also like him.

headline: Van Dorn’s Wild Ride
text: On Dec. 20, 1862, the cold, clear morning air in the Union-occupied north Mississippi town of Holly Springs rang with shots, the clang of sabers and rebel yells. The streets filled with cheering Southern civilians, surrendering Northern soldiers and wheeling Confederate cavalrymen, who had charged so hard into the town, one trooper recalled, that their horses were “hot and smoking.” Gen. Ulysses S. Grant’s efforts to take Vicksburg would go up in the flames of the supplies that the rebels were preparing to burn. All this was happening at the hand of a disgraced, and often disgraceful, man: Maj. Gen. Earl Van Dorn.

headline: To Save Syria, We Need Russia
text: Washington

headline: Tunisian Dictator’s Possessions to Be Sold at Public Auction
text: TUNIS — It could be the Middle East’s most opulent yard sale.

headline: ‘Good Wishes From Robert Frost’
text: In 1929, lines from Robert Frost’s “Christmas Trees” — the poem that begins, “The city had withdrawn into itself/And left at last the country to the country” — enticed Joseph Blumenthal, who ran a fine letterpress, to print it in a holiday card. The trouble was, he did not have Frost’s permission. As Mr. Blumenthal recalled, Frost saw the card by chance, and far from being angry, asked Mr. Blumenthal for copies and suggested they meet. “My sympathies have been enlisted on the side of small presses and hand setting,” he wrote. “My heart will be with you in your work.”

headline: In Rush for Record, Peterson Faces Tough Odds Again
text: Anything written about Adrian Peterson’s astonishing season should probably begin with “Once upon a time,” as it seems more rooted in fable than fact.

headline: A Vast Collection that Predates MoMA
text: Founded in 1920 by Katherine Dreier, Marcel Duchamp and Man Ray as an “experimental museum” and satirically incorporated society, Société Anonyme’s more serious aim was to promote modern art in America. The group formed at a pivotal moment: less than a decade after the 1913 Armory Show and after Alfred Stieglitz closed his modern-focused 291 Gallery in 1917.

headline: Shop Owners Report Rise in Firearm Sales as Buyers Fear Possible New Laws
text: Rainier Arms, a gun dealer in Auburn, Wash., receives great Yelp reviews for its responsiveness. But a call to the dealer on Friday led to a full voice mail box, and an e-mail to its sales team drew this automatic response: “Thank you for contacting Rainier Arms for your AR-15 needs.  Due to an overwhelming response to the latest political climate, we are experiencing longer-than-normal response times.”

headline: Potential Backlash for the Muslim Brotherhood
text: The Muslim Brotherhood has disillusioned residents in a onetime stronghold.

headline: Guns and Their Makers
text: “It takes a lot of men to make a gun,” wrote Stephen Sondheim in his 1990 musical “Assassins.”

headline: After Newtown Massacre, N.R.A. Proposes ‘Absolute Protection’
text: Hope that the massacre of 20 5- and 6-year-old children might shirt the terms of the gun-control debate in the United States seemed to recede Friday after the National Rifle Association, the powerful gun-rights lobbying group, came out forcefully for measures other than gun control as a way to prevent future bloodshed in America.

headline: Instagram Reversal Doesn’t Appease Everyone
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Facebook may have quelled a full-scale rebellion by quickly dumping the contentious new terms of use for Instagram, its photo-sharing service. But even as the social network furiously backpedaled, some users said Friday they were carrying through on plans to leave.

headline: Pictures From the Week in Business
text: Cerberus Capital Management said it would sell the gun maker Freedom Group, the government is exiting its investment in General Motors and Peter Madoff was sentenced to prison for his role in his brother’s Ponzi scheme.

headline: Support for Egypt’s Muslim Brotherhood Erodes in an Islamist Bastion
text: AL TALBEYA, Egypt — Mohamed Salamah used to vote with the Muslim Brotherhood. But in Saturday’s referendum on the Islamist-backed constitution, Mr. Salamah says he is voting against it, mainly because he no longer trusts the movement.

headline: Football, and It’s Not Political
text: MIAMI GARDENS, Fla. — You can learn a lot about a politician by watching him watch football. Or can you?

headline: U.S. Acts With Europe to Strengthen Iran Penalties
text: The United States and Europe announced strengthened sanctions against Iran on Friday, increasing the number of blacklisted companies and individuals linked to the Iranian nuclear program, in coordinated actions that underscored the failure to resolve one of the most intractable international disputes.

headline: Man, 52, Is Convicted as a Juvenile in a 1976 Murder, Creating a Legal Tangle
text: ELIZABETH, N.J. — By all other measures it would be a routine case of the “C.S.I.” age: a detective working a cold case alights on a stray clue, and running a DNA sample, finds a man he believes is the killer. Thirty-six years after the crime, the man is brought to trial and convicted of murder.

headline: Wish You a Gun-Free Christmas
text: Well, the Mayans were sort of right.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, Dec. 22, 2012.
text: The only thing that stops a bad guy with a gun is a good guy with a gun.

headline: In Taxes, Guns and Cabinet, Gridlock Grips the Capital
text: WASHINGTON — If Friday’s memorial service for one of this country’s long-serving senators was a somber recollection of a bipartisan era that once was, the rest of the day was a frenetic reminder of the political gridlock that now grips the capital.

headline: School Bus Drivers’ Union Threatens to Strike in January
text: For the second consecutive year, a showdown between New York City’s largest union for school bus drivers and City Hall is threatening to strip 150,000 public school students of transportation just after the holidays.

headline: Russian Orphans as Political Pawns
text: Russian legislators looking to retaliate against a new American human rights law have settled on an exceptionally vulnerable target: Russian orphans. The proposal would bar American citizens from adopting them. This is a cynical and cruel response. The American law, called the Magnitsky Act, was signed by President Obama last week and seeks to punish Russian citizens accused of violating human rights by denying them visas to visit the United States and the right to own real estate in this country.

headline: Former Friend Is Convicted Over Kerik’s Home Renovations
text: A Bronx jury on Friday convicted one of two brothers who, prosecutors said, lied to a grand jury about paying for renovations to the apartment of Bernard B. Kerik, the former police commissioner of New York, when he was a city official.

headline: Vernice D. Ferguson, Leader and Advocate of Nurses, Dies at 84
text: Vernice D. Ferguson, who fought for greater opportunities, higher wages and more respect for nurses as a longtime chief nursing officer for the Veterans Administration, died on Dec. 8 at her home in Washington. She was 84.

headline: After Audubon, an Artist of the Park
text: To survive on the street, Lee Rogers has developed a niche that is a far cry from the typical panhandling or bottle redemption.

headline: The Hague: Congolese Ex-Militia Leader Is Released
text: A former Congolese militia leader was released from prison on Friday, hours after judges turned down a bid from the prosecution to keep him behind bars pending appeal. This week, judges at the International Criminal Court in The Hague acquitted the former militia leader, Mathieu Ngudjolo, 42, of crimes against humanity and war crimes. They found that prosecutors had failed to prove his commanding role during a 2003 attack on the village of Bogoro, where militia fighters raped many and killed 200 villagers. Mr. Ngudjolo must now wait in the Netherlands until the United Nations formally lifts his travel ban. He has served almost five years in the court’s prison.

headline: Larry L. King, Texan Author and Playwright, Dies at 83
text: Larry L. King, a journalist, essayist and playwright with a swaggering prose style and a rollicking personal one, who left Texas as a young man but never abandoned it in his work — turning out profiles of politicians, articles on the flaws and foibles of American culture, searching autobiographical essays and, most famously, the book for the Broadway musical “The Best Little Whorehouse in Texas” — died on Thursday in Washington. He was 83.

headline: In House of Representatives, an Arithmetic Problem
text: Markets were down sharply on Friday after Speaker John A. Boehner’s tax plan failed to reach a vote in the House on Thursday evening. No Democrats were prepared to support the bill, and Mr. Boehner told reporters that his plan also lacked sufficient votes among Republicans.

headline: Corrections: December 22, 2012
text: NATIONAL

headline: Mourning a Boy Who Flapped His Wings, and 25 Other Lives in Newtown
text: BETHEL, Conn. — Six white balloons and 19 purple balloons floated into the gray sky, up to the wisp of blue that peaked out above the steeple. Then 8-year-old Jake Hockley released the last purple balloon, the favorite color of his younger brother, Dylan, and it too lifted into the unknown.

headline: Inez Andrews, Gospel Singer, Dies at 83
text: Inez Andrews, whose soaring, wide-ranging voice — from contralto croon to soul-wrenching wail — made her a pillar of gospel music, died on Wednesday at her home in Chicago. She was 83.

headline: Wanted: Transit Wizard
text: The nation’s largest public transportation system is looking for a new leader, again. After 14 months as chairman and chief executive of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, Joseph Lhota announced plans this week to resign at the end of the year. He is considering a run for mayor next year. For the 15 million people who live in the New York City area served by the transit authority, the big question will be who replaces Mr. Lhota in this crucial and difficult job.

headline: Jets Try to Find Relevance With Nothing to Play For
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — Since his hiring as coach of the Jets in 2009, Rex Ryan has never had a week like this. There is really nothing on the line.

headline: Taking a Day of Rest From the Kettle and the Bell
text: From the week before Thanksgiving until Christmas Eve, Oliver Canmore Barrow rings a bell beside a kettle to raise money for the Salvation Army, as he has done since 1986; in recent years he has been stationed outside St. Patrick’s Cathedral. Technically, he is a volunteer, but he says, “I’m more than a volunteer — I’m a member of the Salvation Army.” He credits the organization with helping him turn his life around after a long struggle with drugs and alcohol that began in the 1970s. Born in Belize, Mr. Barrow, 77, lives in East Harlem; divorced, he has two children and three grandchildren. Sundays are for prayer, both at home and at the army’s Manhattan Citadel on East 125th Street, and for visiting his sister in a nursing home in Brooklyn.

headline: Less Likely to Crack
Healthy Meals After an Illness
text: Everything changed for Marla Gutman in December 2008, when she got sick with what she thought was a stomach virus. When she reached the doctor’s office she was slurring her words, her blood pressure had plunged, and then she passed out. She was rushed to Montefiore Medical Center, where she was found to have pneumonia that had turned into sepsis, leading to multiple-organ failure.

headline: For the Mets, Is There Anybody Out There?
text: Wanted: Able-bodied candidates for a professional baseball team in Queens. The ideal candidate has experience working in a big-league outfield. The starting salary is modest, though there will be ample opportunity and room for growth. The position is seasonal. Lefties need not apply.

headline: Christmas in the City, Beyond Rockefeller Center
text: APP NYC Holiday GuidePLATFORM iPhone and other iOS devicesPRICE $2.99

headline: A Daughter Tries to Help but Ends Up Swindled
text: Sitting side by side on their living room sofa, Patricia Morales and her daughter, Katherine, could be any mother-daughter duo. Both have dark hair, dark eyes and welcoming, infectious smiles.

headline: Tea for Three (and Doll, and Doll’s Pet)
text: The American Girl Cafe on the third floor of American Girl Place on Fifth Avenue at 49th Street — the global center for the commodification of girlhood — is a very pink place. At the holidays, it is filled with droves of dressed-up girls sitting under pine wreaths with their mothers, their aunts and their look-alike, and extremely expensive, dolls. The cafe serves brunch, lunch, an afternoon tea and dinner — to as many as 900 people a day — all accompanied by highchairs for the nonhuman diners and a box of what are known as table talkers: a collection of conversation-inspiring questions for those adults rendered speechless by the rosy, girl-friendly décor. At tea the other day, the table talkers were largely left untouched by a happily chatty mother-and-daughter team visiting from Northern California with the mother’s sister-in-law.

headline: Guard Says Nets Aren’t Following Schemes; Coach Cites Trust
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — The Nets returned to their practice court here Friday for the first time since Hurricane Sandy, but the topic of conversation was not about being back home so much as it was about a struggling team in need of fixing.

headline: Answers to Questions About New York
text: The First Actors Home

headline: Ex-Model Gets 25 Years for Killing His Companion
text: A former fashion model who was convicted of murdering and mutilating his journalist companion in a Times Square hotel barely fluctuated his soft voice on Friday as he tried to describe what drove him to incredible violence.

headline: Cluster Bombs in Syria
text: The Times's Michael Slackman speaks with Peter Lattman about recent cluster bomb attacks in Syria.

headline: Dangerous Abscesses Add to Tainted Drug’s Threat
text: YPSILANTI, Mich. — Dr. David Vandenberg admitted three patients to St. Joseph Mercy Ann Arbor hospital on Tuesday, and called a fourth with news that left her in tears: She had a large abscess deep inside her back, near her spine, and would need surgery as soon as possible.

headline: Guns, Smoke and Mirrors
text: What was that?

headline: Anatomy of a Scene: 'Les Misérables'
text: Tom Hooper, the director of “Les Misérables,” narrates a scene from the film.

headline: With a Click, a Meal and a Story
text: She had never worked in a restaurant or gone to culinary school, but there she was on a recent Thursday night, buzzing up to a stranger’s apartment in Astoria, Queens, carrying equipment and fresh groceries from Chinatown. She took command of her host’s small kitchen: cleaning bok choy and pea shoots, cutting sirloin, peeling prawns.

headline: A Question of Whether to Rebuild
text: In coastline areas of New York City, property owners are dealing with varying degrees of damage to their homes and businesses. Some have already decided to rebuild, and others are still deciding how to proceed.

headline: On Ravaged Coastline, It’s Rebuild Deliberately vs. Rebuild Now
text: As moldy drywall thudded to the curb in a depressing drumbeat throughout Breezy Point, Queens, Thomas Ryan’s reciprocating saw stood out like a growling declaration of impatience.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Ugly Game at the Garden Looks Beautiful to the Bulls
text: Rarely in Carmelo Anthony’s career has he heard the roar of the crowd during a game from a seat in the locker room. But on Friday night against the Chicago Bulls that was what Anthony experienced after he was ejected in the fourth quarter of a wild game that included 50 personal fouls, 9 technicals and 4 ejections.

headline: Intense Alienation Can Be an Incubator for Violence
text: Nearly 20 years ago, on Dec. 7, 1993, Colin Ferguson, an unstably irascible man of 35, transplanted to Brooklyn from privileged West Indian beginnings, boarded the Long Island Rail Road’s 5:33 train from Penn Station and killed six people, injuring 19 others. As explanation, he cited various grievances on notepaper, among them: “racism by Caucasians and Uncle Tom Negroes” and “sloppy running of the #2 train.” The crime, committed with a rapid-fire 9-millimeter pistol, carries a horrific familiarity now, and yet it remains distinctive for having occurred against the backdrop of a major American metropolis.

headline: Events in Westchester
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

headline: Events in Connecticut
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

headline: Holiday Tuesday (Christmas)
text: NEW YORKGOVERNMENT OFFICES  Closed.

headline: Events on Long Island
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

headline: Events in New Jersey
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

headline: What’s On Saturday
text: 9 P.M. (Starz) THE PIRATES! BAND OF MISFITS (2012) A continually thwarted pirate captain (above, voiced by Hugh Grant) pursues his dream of winning an award for best pirate of the year in this stop-motion tale of high-seas silliness from Aardman Animations, the company behind “Wallace & Gromit.” But the pirate has competition, notably Black Bellamy (Jeremy Piven) and Queen Victoria (Imelda Staunton). “Exquisitely detailed — from its ocean breakers to the wavelike curlicues on a pirate’s luxurious beard — the movie is a curiosity cabinet of visual pleasures but so breezy and lightly funny that you may not realize at first how good it is,” Manohla Dargis, who made it a critics’ pick, wrote in The New York Times. “(You’re too busy grinning.)”

headline: IHT Quick Read: Dec. 22
text: NEWS In its first extended comment since the primary-school massacre in Connecticut last week, the United States’ powerful gun lobby, the National Rifle Association, called on Friday for American schools to be patrolled by armed guards. “The only thing that stops a bad guy with a gun is a good guy with a gun,” said Wayne LaPierre, the N.R.A. vice president. Eric Lichtblau and Motoko Rich report from Washington.

headline: Newswallah: Bharat Edition
text: Jammu and Kashmir: A period of harsh winter weather, known locally as Chillai Kalan and expected to last 40 days, began in Kashmir on Friday, Kashmir Live reported. Low temperatures were recorded across the Kashmir Valley, but bright, sunny skies marked the first day of Chillai Kalan instead of the expected snowfall, the newspaper reported.

headline: The Weekend Word: N.R.A.
text: Today’s Times

headline: Philippines Enacts Strong Penalties for Abductions by Security Forces
text: MANILA — The Philippines has enacted a law aimed at stopping the military and police officers from abducting people suspected of antigovernment activity, one of the ugly legacies of the country’s years of dictatorship.

headline: This Week in the Global Arts Guide
text: “Awakening the Night: Art From Romanticism to the Present” at the Belvedere Museum in Vienna includes 300 works interpreting the night — as the realm of darkness, a safe haven or a reflection of oneself, from Romanticism to 21st-century art. The Romantic era was a period when, in literature and visual arts, the perception of the night was redefined under the influence of sciences like astronomy and psychology. On display are paintings, prints, drawings, photographs, films, sculptures and objects by Friedrich, Waldmüller, Nolde, Kirchner, Magritte, Delvaux and Ansel Adams. Through Feb. 17.

headline: Strapped Spanish Put Hopes in Lottery
text: LONDON — Spain was gripped by its annual lottery fever on Saturday as millions who were battered by another year of economic gloom looked forward to a share of a $3.3 billion Christmas payout.

headline: YouTube’s Field-Goal Kicker and the Jets
text: It has almost become a sports cliche. An athlete tries a series of trick shots, sometimes needing dozens and perhaps hundreds of attempts before making them, then uses the successful clips in a video that spreads on the Web.

headline: Pakistani Politician Killed in Suicide Bomb Attack
text: PESHAWAR, Pakistan — The Pakistani Taliban claimed responsibility on Saturday for a suicide bomb attack that killed a senior politician in northwest Pakistan in one of the most high-profile assassinations of a political leader in months.

headline: Boston Priest to Lead Oversight of Sexual Abuse Claims at Vatican
text: Pope Benedict XVI on Saturday appointed as the Vatican’s new sexual crimes prosecutor a priest who handled clergy sexual abuse cases in the Roman Catholic Church in Boston at the height of the scandal and for years afterward.

headline: Sitcom Kabuki (Trivial)
text: OK, so I’ve just spent a number of hours on domestic flights, the kind that show sitcoms on screens down the middle of the aisle. (Which is why I was too tired for Friday Night Music — next week). I didn’t listen to any of the dialogue – I was reading – but I did find myself watching some of the acting. And with the sound off, you can really see just how artificial the conventions of sitcom acting are: the telegraphed double-takes, the faux-angry declarations of the men, the perkiness of the women, etc., etc. – none of it resembling at all the way real people behave. It’s an art form, if you like, that’s as deeply stylized and full of conventional signifiers as Kabuki theater or Chinese opera; the actors might as well be wearing ritual masks representing their alleged characters and emotions.

headline: Maya and the Vigilantes
text: For some reason, this seems to be Maya MacGuineas week, with profiles by both Suzy Khimm and Noam Scheiber. MacGuineas is the queen of the deficit scolds, having run the Committee for a Responsible Federal Budget, perhaps the most prominent of the many Pete Peterson-backed organizations trying to scare us about the deficit, and now the moving force behind Fix the Debt, a group associated with corporate and Wall Street interests who, of course, care only about the good of the nation.

headline: Getting It First or Getting It Right?
text: THE media critic Jack Shafer wrote recently that, in the age of Twitter, the public had better get used to a new fact of life: News stories, especially the early reports of breaking news events, are very likely to be inaccurate.

headline: The War Against Too Much of Everything
text: IF you haven’t finished your holiday shopping yet, don’t bother.

headline: Acting C.I.A. Chief Critical of Film ‘Zero Dark Thirty’
text: The acting director of the C.I.A., Michael J. Morell, has criticized a new movie about the hunt for Osama bin Laden, saying it exaggerates the role of coercive interrogations in producing clues to the whereabouts of the leader of Al Qaeda.

headline: Kobe and Messi at 32,000 Feet
text: It’s good to be the king … the king of goals and the king of the Lakers.

headline: Waiting to See if a ‘Yes Man’ Picked to Succeed Chávez Might Say Something Else
text: CARACAS, Venezuela — Nicolás Maduro, the handpicked successor of Venezuela’s ailing president, Hugo Chávez, stood on a stage this month and gave a barnburner of a speech in classic Chávez style. He shouted until his voice gave out, swore an oath of loyalty to the revolution and blasted its opponents. But when the crowd started to chant his name, he quickly cut them off, shouting into the microphone: “Chávez! Chávez! Chávez!”

headline: From Behind, Knicks Chase Refs
text: Complaining to the referees has not gotten the Knicks far this season. Friday’s 110-106 loss to the Chicago Bulls was the best and most recent example of how a frustrated Knicks team can lose its composure and then struggle for the rest of the game.

headline: Variety: A Gridless Diagramless Puzzle, Redundantly
text: VARIETY PUZZLE — You might not have noticed this, but the English language is a strange beast.

headline: In Ravaged Syria, Beach Town May Be Loyalists’ Last Resort
text: TARTUS, Syria — Loyalists who support the government of President Bashar al-Assad are flocking to the Mediterranean port of Tartus, creating an overflowing boomtown far removed from the tangled, scorched rubble that now mars most Syrian cities.

headline: Being Considered the Next Serena Is a Compliment and a Detriment
text: PLANTATION, Fla. — The tennis coach Kathy Rinaldi settled into her folding beach chair near the court, out of the sun’s range but close enough for her encouragement to be heard by her teenage pupil, Taylor Townsend. A few feet away, a woman, dressed from visor to sneakers in tennis whites, was speaking on her phone: “I’m getting ready to watch Taylor Townsend. She’s the girl who looks like Serena.”

headline: As Charter Nears Passage, Egyptians Face New Fights
Giants’ Poor Run Defense Slows Pass Rush to a Stumble
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.

headline: A Father’s Journey
text: FOR a long while, my father’s way of coping was to walk quietly from the room. He doesn’t remember this. I do. I can still see it, still feel the pinch in my chest when the word “gay” came up — perhaps in reference to some event in the news, or perhaps in reference to me — and he’d wordlessly take his leave of whatever conversation my mother and my siblings and I were having. He’d drift away, not in disgust but in discomfort, not in a huff but in a whisper. I saw a lot of his back.

headline: An Improvable Feast
text: LONG ago the Roman Catholic Church decreed Christmas Eve a vigil during which the faithful should solemnly await Christ’s arrival and his deliverance of a better world.

headline: Cats at Hemingway Museum Draw Tourists, and a Legal Battle
text: KEY WEST, Fla. — As any visitor to Ernest Hemingway’s house knows, the grounds here boast more than just Papa’s typewriter, his white iron-framed bed and the oft-used urinal he brought home from Sloppy Joe’s bar.

headline: MF Global Overseers Reach Accord Over Claims
text: 5:15 p.m. | Updated

headline: Ancient Buddhas, Modern Peril
text: WHEN the Taliban blasted the famous Bamiyan Buddhas with artillery and dynamite in March 2001, leaders of many faiths and countries denounced the destruction as an act of cultural terrorism. But today, with the encouragement of the American government, Chinese engineers are preparing a similar act of desecration in Afghanistan: the demolition of a vast complex of richly decorated ancient Buddhist monasteries.

headline: Chinese-American Faces Trial in China
text: BEIJING — As his family tells it, Vincent Wu is an industrious Chinese-American immigrant who sold his family’s suburban Los Angeles home to finance the construction of a shopping center in China he thought would allow him to retire early. To the police in Huizhou, a city in the southern province of Guangdong, Mr. Wu, 54, is a Mafia kingpin and illegal casino operator who dispatched his enemies through kidnapping, extortion and violence.

headline: Anatomy of a Murder-Suicide
text: SUICIDE is not as newsworthy as homicide. A person’s disaffection with his own life is less threatening than his rage to destroy others. So it makes sense that since the carnage in Newtown, Conn., the press has focused on the victims — the heartbreaking, senseless deaths of children, and the terrible pain that their parents and all the rest of us have to bear. Appropriately, we mourn Adam Lanza’s annihilation of others more than his self-annihilation.

headline: Paul Is Cornerstone of Clippers’ Revival, and Not Just on Court
text: LOS ANGELES — In Clippers lore, which is no longer a comedy routine, much of the credit for this season’s rise to No. 2 in the West — eight games ahead of the Lakers entering Saturday — goes to a makeshift committee of Coach Vinny Del Negro; the team president, Andy Roeser; and the assistant personnel director, Gary Sacks, who jumped in after their vice president for basketball operations bolted on the eve of last summer’s N.B.A. free-agent signing period. On their own, they acquired Jamal Crawford, Lamar Odom, Matt Barnes and Grant Hill.

headline: Amid Success and Unrest, Goodell Remains Resolute
text: Roger Goodell’s year began with a rich contract extension in January, a reward from N.F.L. owners for the 10-year collective bargaining agreement he helped complete and for the blockbuster business that followed.

headline: Russia Says It Won’t Play Role in Ousting Syria’s Leader
text: MOSCOW — The foreign minister of Russia, which is among Syria’s most reliable allies, said Saturday that several countries were offering asylum to President Bashar al-Assad to get him to leave Syria, but that Moscow would not mediate on their behalf, according to Russian news services.

headline: Flacco Under Fire Though Ravens Again Reach Playoffs
text: OWINGS MILLS, Md. — The Baltimore Ravens were positioned to slice into Denver’s 10-0 lead shortly before halftime last Sunday when they advanced to first-and-goal at the Broncos’ 4-yard line. But everything changed when quarterback Joe Flacco made a pass that he regretted the instant the ball left his hand.

headline: One Nation Under God?
text: THIS week millions of “Chreasters” — Americans who attend church only on Christmas and Easter — will crowd into pews to sing carols and renew their vague relationship with the Christian God. This year, there may be fewer Chreasters than ever. A growing number of “nones” live in our midst: those who say they have no religious affiliation at all. An October Pew Research Center poll revealed that they now account for 20 percent of the population, up from 16 percent in 2008.

headline: Bloomberg, LaPierre and the Void
text: FOR a week after the Newtown shooting, the conversation was dominated by the self-righteous certainties of the American center-left. In print and on the airwaves, the chorus was nearly universal: the only possible response to Adam Lanza’s rampage was an immediate crusade for gun control, the necessary firearm restrictions were all self-evident, and anyone who doubted their efficacy had the blood of children on his hands.

headline: When Bahrain Said: Get Lost
text: Bahrain International Airport

headline: Melissa Hamilton
text: Melissa Hamilton is an Irish ballerina who is currently dancing the role of the Sugar Plum Fairy in The Royal Ballet’s production of “The Nutcracker” in London.

headline: From Apocalypse to Dystopia
text: WASHINGTON

headline: Sunday Dialogue: Violence in America
text: Readers debate the best response to the surge in mass killings.

headline: Clashes Break Out in India at a Protest Over a Rape Case
text: NEW DELHI — Thousands of protesters streamed into the heart of New Delhi on Saturday to demand justice and better policing in the wake of the brutal rape of a 23-year-old medical student.

headline: Send in the Clowns
text: WHEN thinking about the state of the Republican Party, I defer to a point that the Democratic consultant James Carville made the other day: “When I hear people talking about the troubled state of today’s Republican Party, it calls to mind something Lester Maddox said one time back when he was governor of Georgia. He said the problem with Georgia prisons was ‘the quality of the inmates.’ The problem with the Republican Party is the quality of the people who vote in their primaries and caucuses. Everybody says they need a better candidate, or they need a better message but — in my opinion — the Republicans have an inmate problem.” The political obsessions of the Republican base — from denying global warming to defending assault weapons to opposing any tax increases under any conditions, to resisting any immigration reform — are making it impossible to be a Republican moderate, said Carville. And without more Republican moderates, there is no way to strike the kind of centrist bargains that have been at the heart of American progress — that got us where we are and are essential for where we need to go.

headline: Bye-Bye to the Big Board?
text: If the mergers announced last week go through, NYSE Euronext, the owner of the New York Stock Exchange, will be acquired for $8.2 billion by IntercontinentalExchange, or ICE, an electronic operator of markets for derivatives and commodities, while Knight Capital Group, an electronic trading firm, will be sold for $1.4 billion to Getco, a privately held firm that has been a leader in high-frequency trading.

headline: In India, a Dangerous and Divisive Technocrat
text: Last week, Narendra Modi, a deeply polarizing Indian politician, led his party to a third consecutive election victory in the western state of Gujarat, which he has led for more than a decade. Though regional contests in the country are usually of little interest to outsiders, Mr. Modi’s win is significant because it sets him up as a presumptive front-runner in the race to become India’s next prime minister in elections scheduled for 2014 and casts a spotlight on his controversial rise to power.

headline: Wounded Warrior Pose
text: MEN are famous for ignoring aches and pains. It’s macho. Men get physical exams less often than women. They tend to remain silent if worried about their health. When hurt, their impulse is to shun doctors and rely on home remedies, like avoiding heavy lifting to ease backaches. Male athletes play through injuries. It’s all about virility and manliness.

headline: Holiday Games for Fans, Not for Players
text: The Knicks are not associated with Christmas in New York in the same way as the Rockettes or Macy’s, but that is not for a lack of effort. Having played more Christmas Day games than any other N.B.A. franchise — 47 entering this season — the Knicks will be trading presents, slippers and family dinners for a chance at beating the Lakers on national television.

headline: Cynics, Step Down. Let Hef Love.
text: Hugh Hefner, 86, is engaged to marry Crystal Harris, a lovely woman six decades his junior, on New Year’s Eve. If your reaction is skepticism — he just wants publicity, she’s only in it for the money — then you’re part of a rampant trend of cynicism that must cease. Why, you sneer? Because our culture is falling under the destructive sway of snarky observers whose raison d’être is to mirthfully degrade anything and everything, including a warm, loving relationship that should be held up as an inspirational example in today’s dispassionate society.

headline: Pardons for the Wilmington 10
text: Before leaving office next month, Gov. Bev Perdue of North Carolina should finally pardon the Wilmington 10, a group of civil rights activists who were falsely convicted and imprisoned in connection with a racial disturbance in the city of Wilmington more than 40 years ago. The convictions, based on flimsy evidence and perjured testimony, were overturned by a federal court in 1980. But by then, the lives of the convicted had been broken on the wheel of Jim Crow justice.

headline: Has Lego Sold Out?
text: FOR generations of American children and their parents, Legos were the ultimate do-it-yourself plaything. Little plastic bricks, with scant instructions, just add imagination.

headline: Across the Field From Sanchez, Another Quarterback Struggles as Well
text: Mark Sanchez will be in uniform for the Jets on Sunday, but only as a figurehead quarterback, stripped of his essential duties, left to chart plays on a clipboard and ponder where his career took its sharpest detour.

headline: Values Validate a First-Ballot Good Guy
text: Dale Murphy is trailing by 10 runs with two out and the bases empty in the bottom of the ninth inning. He is not going to win, but there is honor in fighting till the end.

headline: Words of 2012
text: ALL due credit to petroleum and technology, social media and memes, and the humbling power of the weather, for their ability to generate and sustain new words. And the 2012 elections also made for a bountiful harvest of new political expressions. So let’s close the year by taking a look at some of its lexical highlights.

headline: A 2013 Guide to Better Behavior in Business
text: AS the new year draws near, I’ve been thinking about what might make it a happy one for investors, taxpayers, home buyers and consumers. Herewith, a short wish list:

headline: A Self-Defeating Adventure in Self-Rating
text: My best tennis days are behind me, and they were never glorious. I was a middling player for a good Division III program in the mid-1990s, and my most memorable collegiate tennis moment happened off the court. (I once smoked marijuana with a professional player.) My last sanctioned match was several years ago, when I, like thousands of other dreamers, signed up for the nationwide tournament for a single spot in the United States Open qualifiers. I lost in the second round to a high school student.

headline: The Scourge of Concealed Weapons
text: As the nation’s leaders devise new gun control strategies following the Connecticut shooting, they should look for ways to strengthen state laws that govern the possession and use of firearms. In too many states, these laws are weak and, in some cases, seem almost designed to encourage violence.

headline: Guess Who Still Believes in Invisible Vigilantes
text: Lots of chatter about the WSJ’s account of how the deficit negotiations broke down, although — a few fun quotes aside — most of it is what we already pretty much knew. But here’s a passage that bothered me:

headline: The Six-Toed Denizens of Key West
text: For generations, the cats at the Ernest Hemingway Home and Museum have stretched out on Hemingway’s couch, curled up on his pillow and mugged for the Papa-razzi.

headline: Games and More Games on Day After Christmas
text: After the confinement and tiring etiquette of Christmas Day, the prospect of soccer on Wednesday offers something of a refuge for Britons. An opportunity to escape the family, the simmering tensions and the dinner table strife, and breathe a sigh of relief, Boxing Day games are a tradition that Britain holds dear.

headline: Drugs Aim to Make Several Types of Cancer Self-Destruct
text: For the first time ever, three pharmaceutical companies are poised to test whether new drugs can work against a wide range of cancers independently of where they originated — breast, prostate, liver, lung. The drugs go after an aberration involving a cancer gene fundamental to tumor growth. Many scientists see this as the beginning of a new genetic age in cancer research.

headline: Locations in ‘The Hobbit’
text: Images and sketches of the otherworldly sets in Peter Jackson’s latest film.

headline: What He Learned From the Boss Who Left at 5:30
text: This interview with  Robert J. Murray, global chief executive of iProspect, a digital marketing agency, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

headline: Out With the Old Anxiety
text: Middle age arrives not with a birthday, with 48 candles on an angel food cake, but with a sudden unbidden insight in the middle of a sleepless night. You roll over and eye the clock and see all at once that the phrase “anything is possible” is not true. That is, it is no longer true for you, if it ever was. You are not going to become a doctor, or run a marathon or have a baby or sail around the world on a solo voyage documented by National Geographic. You simply haven’t the time, the feet, the eggs, or possibly even the desire required to mount such elaborate dream sequences.

headline: Pest Control in the Sky, Courtesy of a Raptor
text: THREE days a week, a pair of hawks named Mowgli and Melvin are stationed by the edge of an artificial pond at the Water Garden, an office park in Santa Monica, Calif.

headline: Stories of Hardship, Even Before the Storm
text: When Hurricane Sandy hit the New York region on Oct. 29, it delivered a painful blow to thousands of residents, devastating not only those on the coastline, but also people already facing financial hardship. More than 300,000 housing units in New York State were reported damaged or destroyed.

headline: After Losing Job in ’09, Woman Is Impeded Again After Trying to Rebuild
text: Water rushed into Annmarie Nicholson’s basement apartment through the creases of her closed windows. Although the torrent did not shatter the glass, its power was enough to force the front door shut and transform the home into a cistern in just 15 minutes.

headline: Letters to the Editor
text: To the Sports Editor:

headline: The Learning Curve of Smart Parking
text: PLACE “smart” in front of a noun and you immediately have something that somehow sounds improved.

headline: Fighting Anxiety, Sludge and Ruin
text: Things were finally starting to look up for Kim Benson.

headline: Losses Mount for a Family Struggling to Keep Afloat
text: Outside George and Patricia Smyth’s home in Gerritsen Beach, Brooklyn, the street was awash with floating debris. Among the more notable items that Hurricane Sandy had flushed from their flooded basement were hundreds of ice cream cones and jars full of toppings, inventory from the business they were forced to close last year.

headline: Battle of the Somm
text: Sommeliers are on the front line of customer service and profit generation in first-class restaurants where the price of a bottle of wine can easily dwarf any sum spent on food. Below is the secret language of some of New York’s finest “Somms.”

headline: Chastened Temple Stops Syracuse and Boeheim
text: Syracuse Coach Jim Boeheim received the loudest ovation from the fans at Madison Square Garden on Saturday, some of whom arrived with signs and shirts celebrating his latest career accomplishment.

headline: In the Fiscal Debate, a Little Symbolism Can Go a Long Way
text: “GRANT me chastity and continence, but not yet.” That line from St. Augustine could describe the undercurrent of the fiscal negotiations in Washington. We must decide whether to pursue a relatively loose and stimulative policy, and to trust in our later discipline, or to slam on the brakes now.

headline: Ready, Again, for the Moving Van
text: ON New Year’s Day, the company I work for, Four Seasons Hotels and Resorts, will move me from Washington to Paris, where I will become a regional vice president of the company and general manager of the Hotel George V, which it manages.

headline: 30 Seconds With Daniele De Rossi
text: Daniele De Rossi is among a vanishing breed of athletes — one who has spent his entire professional career with one club, Roma of Italy’s Serie A in his hometown. De Rossi, whose father, Alberto, also played for Roma, has appeared in nearly 300 games for the team.

headline: A Career Turn, Not on the Map
text: I WAS born prematurely with hyaline membrane disease, also called infant respiratory distress syndrome. The doctors kept my mother from seeing me while they waited a day or two to see how I’d do. She wasn’t happy about it, and climbed out on a window ledge to force the issue. Police cars converged, as the officers didn’t know she was just trying to make a point. A female doctor worked with my mom to resolve the situation, and then my dad brought me to my mom. My parents named me for that doctor.

headline: Our Oppressive Ally, Bahrain
text: My Sunday column looks at oppression by a close American ally, Bahrain There are nastier countries around the world, but among close American allies Bahrain pretty much takes the cake for hostility to democracy and human rights. And it seems to me that if we’re going to complain about human rights violations by Iran or Syria (as we should) then we also have to speak up about torture and extra-judicial killings by an ally like Bahrain. The Obama administration has tried a policy of quiet diplomacy, but that has manifestly failed: The situation in Bahrain is getting worse, and both sides are becoming more violent and extreme.

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, Dec. 23
text: Just over a week since a massacre at a Connecticut elementary school left 26 dead, the debate over how to prevent future shootings continues. Following the National Rifle Association’s announcement Friday of a new initiative to put an armed guard in every school, N.R.A. officials will join the Sunday shows to talk about the proposal.

headline: Rorschach in Hebron: Grainy Footage Fails to End Arguments Over Fatal Shooting
text: Updated | Thursday, Dec. 27 When the Israel Defense Forces released 49 seconds of grainy, black-and-white video this week, showing some of what happened at a checkpoint in the West Bank city of Hebron before the fatal shooting of a Palestinian teenager by an Israeli officer, a military spokesman expressed confidence that the security-camera footage proved that the killing was justified.

headline: Man Exonerated in Central Park Rape Is Charged With Assault
text: One of the five young men who were wrongly convicted more than 20 years ago of raping and beating a woman in Central Park was arrested earlier this week and charged with menacing and assault stemming from an encounter in October at the park’s northeast corner, the authorities said.

headline: N.R.A. Call to Guard Schools Is Criticized as Too Simplistic
text: The National Rifle Association’s blunt call on Friday to train and place armed guards in every school in the nation as a way to “protect our children right now” has brought a divergence of opinion from school officials, teachers, parents and police officials.

headline: A Fascination of Wall St., and Investigators
text: YOU want the headquarters of Steven A. Cohen, one of the most successful financial speculators of our time, to look like Dr. Evil’s secret lair. But it is just another office-park building, a low-slung affair of tinted glass and red brick, on the southern fringes of Stamford, Conn.

headline: Russia’s Move to Block U.S. Adoptions Sets Off a Wave of Worry
text: As word spread last week that a house of the Russian Parliament had voted to prohibit adoptions of Russian children by American parents, Russian adoptees in the United States made appeals to President Vladimir V. Putin, asking Russia not to hold needy children hostage to international politics.

headline: Giving Mom’s Book Five Stars? Amazon May Cull Your Review
text: Giving raves to family members is no longer acceptable. Neither is writers’ reviewing other writers. But showering five stars on a book you admittedly have not read is fine.

headline: Bywords
text: “I weep for ADONAIS — he is dead!Oh, weep for ADONAIS! though our tearsThaw not the frost which binds so dear a head!” — Percy Bysshe Shelley

headline: Sharing the Bounty of California
text: The Farm to Family program, run by the California Association of Food Banks, taps surplus produce from growers and packers and channels it to food pantries.

headline: Taliban Hint at Softer Line in Talks With Afghan Leaders
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — After years of deriding Afghanistan’s government and army as corrupt tools of Western occupiers, the Taliban have begun publicly airing a softer vision for the country’s future, with senior insurgent leaders saying the militants are willing to govern alongside other Afghan factions and even to adopt the current American-financed army as their own.

headline: Affluent Students Have an Advantage and the Gap Is Widening
text: Low-income students with above-average scores on eighth grade tests have a college graduation rate of 26 percent — lower than more affluent students with worse test scores.

headline: For Poor, Leap to College Often Ends in a Hard Fall
text: GALVESTON, Tex. — Angelica Gonzales marched through high school in Goth armor — black boots, chains and cargo pants — but undermined her pose of alienation with a place on the honor roll. She nicknamed herself after a metal band and vowed to become the first in her family to earn a college degree.

headline: A Bleak Procession of Funerals for Shooting Victims Ends in Newtown
text: NEWTOWN, Conn. — This community laid to rest on Saturday the last of the children killed in a schoolhouse massacre.

headline: Express Train Derails on Upper West Side
text: The last car of a southbound train on the A express line jumped the tracks while passing through the Upper West Side of Manhattan on Saturday morning, transit officials said. No one was hurt, but hundreds of passengers were temporarily stranded.

headline: Thieves Target Volunteers Aiding Staten Island
text: Days after powerful waves created by Hurricane Sandy washed over parts of Staten Island and left devastation behind, a group of people from other states arrived in New York City saying they wanted to help.

headline: How Party of Budget Restraint Shifted to ‘No New Taxes,’ Ever
text: WASHINGTON — On a Saturday afternoon in October 1990, Senator Pete V. Domenici turned from a conversation on the Senate floor, caught the eye of a clerk by raising his right hand and voted in favor of a huge and contentious bill to reduce federal deficits. Then he put his hand back into his pocket and returned to the conversation.

headline: ‘Big Rich Texas’ Becomes an Unlikely Reality-TV Hit
text: In a cosmetic surgeon’s office in the Uptown neighborhood of Dallas, a mother sat in on a consultation with her 16-year-old daughter. Her explanation for their visit?

headline: Latina Liberals Vie for Senate Seat Left by Gallegos’s Death
text: The recent death of a veteran state legislator from Houston has set the stage for an unexpected election that includes two members of a growing demographic in Texas, the progressive Latina woman.

headline: Turning to Outsiders to Finance Water Deals
text: Developers say the site for the proposed Lake Columbia reservoir in East Texas is not much to look at right now.

headline: The Diploma Divide
text: Angelica Gonzales graduated at the top of her high school class and headed off to one of the nation’s top universities. Four years later she is back home, without a degree.

headline: School Lawsuits Serve a Purpose, as Easy Outs
text: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a column for The Tribune.

headline: At a Sacred Site, a Fight Over Women and Prayer
text: JERUSALEM — The face-off at the security gate outside the Western Wall one Friday this month was familiar: for more than two decades, women have been making a monthly pilgrimage to pray at one of Judaism’s holiest sites in a manner traditionally preserved for men, and the police have stopped them in the name of maintaining public order.

headline: Lee Dorman, Bass Guitarist, Dies at 70
text: Lee Dorman, a bass guitarist for the psychedelic rock band Iron Butterfly, who played on one of the genre’s most recognizable songs, “In-a-Gadda-da-Vida,” died on Friday in Laguna Niguel, Calif. He was 70.

headline: Midge Turk Richardson, Ex-Nun and Editor, Dies at 82
text: Midge Turk Richardson, who spent 18 years as a nun before spending 18 years as the editor of Seventeen magazine, a redoubt of worldly concerns like clothes, makeup and dating, died last weekend at her home in Manhattan. She was 82.

headline: Jimmy McCracklin, R&B Singer and Songwriter, Dies at 91
text: Jimmy McCracklin, a blues singer and pianist who by his count composed nearly a thousand songs and recorded hundreds, including the 1950s hit “The Walk,” died on Thursday in San Pablo, Calif. He was 91.

headline: When Games Can Take Years to Complete
text: Ron Langeveld of the Netherlands did not receive a lot of attention when he won the World Correspondence Chess Championship in October. Computers have removed much of the title’s luster.

headline: Women at the Western Wall
text: Jodi Rudoren, The Times’s Jerusalem bureau chief, reports on Jewish women fighting Orthodox restrictions on how and where they can pray at the Western Wall in Jerusalem.

headline: Corrections: December 23, 2012
text: INTERNATIONAL

headline: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, Dec. 23
text: It’s becoming increasingly unlikely that a low-income student, no matter how intrinsically bright, moves up the socioeconomic ladder. What we’re talking about is a threat to the American dream.

headline: Amanda Steren, Marc Garfinkle
text: Amanda Jean Steren and Marc Evan Garfinkle were married Saturday evening at Old Oaks Country Club in Purchase, N.Y. Rabbi Seth M. Limmer officiated.

headline: Kathleen O’Connell, Stephen Marsh
text: Kathleen Cook O’Connell and Stephen Ingram Marsh were married Saturday at a private home in Malibu, Calif., that was rented for the occasion. Jennifer Robinson, a friend of the couple who was temporarily appointed a deputy commissioner of civil marriages by Los Angeles County, officiated.

headline: James Mulkin Jr. and Michael Robertson II
text: James Edward Mulkin Jr. and Michael Eugene Robertson II were married Wednesday at the Manhattan Marriage Bureau. James Mitchell, an assistant administrator in the City Clerk’s office, officiated.

headline: Marcela Schaefer, Jeffrey Weber
text: Marcela Elizabeth Schaefer and Jeffrey Robert Weber were married Tuesday. James Mitchell, an assistant administrator in the City Clerk’s office, officiated at the Manhattan Marriage Bureau.

headline: Alona Simon, Gabriel Erbst
text: Alona Judith Simon, the daughter of Nadine S. Simon and Zvi A. Simon of Westbury, N.Y., was married Saturday evening to Gabriel Alexander Erbst, a son of Jeannette R. Erbst and Les Erbst of Long Branch, N.J. Rabbi Laurence A. Sebert officiated at the Liberty Warehouse in Brooklyn.

headline: Joyce De Leon and Joshua Stein
text: Joyce De Leon and Joshua Michelangelo Stein were married Saturday. The Rev. Angel Castro performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Cathedral of Our Lady of the Angels in Los Angeles.

headline: Claire Friedman and Maximillian Feldman
text: Claire Gillian Friedman and Maximillian Louis Feldman were married Saturday night at the Metropolitan Club in New York. Rabbi Jill Hausman officiated.

headline: Mercedeh Namei, John Back Jr.
text: Mercedeh Namei and John Edward Back Jr. were married Saturday at Memorial Hall, an event space in Cincinnati. The Rev. Al Hirt, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

headline: Nicole Parent and Philip Haughey Jr.
text: Nicole Marie Parent and Philip Carberry Haughey Jr. were married Saturday in Cambridge, Mass. The Rev. David J. Cavanagh performed the ceremony at St. Paul Roman Catholic Church, with the Rev. Michael E. Drea, another Roman Catholic priest and the pastor of the church, taking part.

headline: Jordan Kraemer and Channing Moore
text: Jordan Harriet Kraemer and Richard Channing Moore III were married Monday at City Hall in San Francisco. Robin Wirthlin, a deputy marriage commissioner of San Francisco County, officiated.

headline: Windsong Hollis and Ronald Gottlieb
text: Dr. Windsong Emily Hollis was married Saturday to Ronald Joseph Gottlieb in Washington. Judge Delissa A. Ridgway of the United States Court of International Trade in Manhattan officiated at the Cosmos Club. The Rev. John P. Goodloe Sr., a Pentecostal minister, offered a blessing.

headline: Police Crackdown in Delhi Sunday After Protests Over Rape
text: A week of growing anger about a recent rape in Delhi ended in violence Saturday after police and protestors clashed near the India Gate monument.

headline: Adding More Bricks to the Great Firewall of China
text: HONG KONG — China appears to have reinforced its Internet firewall in recent days, blocking some of the leading services that allow people on the mainland to access forbidden sites like Twitter, Facebook and YouTube.

headline: Newswallah: Long Reads Edition
text: Gujarat’s divisive chief minister Narendra Modi surprised no one when he won a resounding victory in the recent state elections, inching closer, some say, to fulfilling his ambitions of becoming a national leader, perhaps even prime minister. But what remains surprising and even inscrutable to some is the fervent support the right-wing politician enjoys on his home turf and elsewhere.

headline: Home for the Holidays, or Not: An Expat Christmas in New York
text: NEW YORK — I am American and I live abroad right here in New York. I know it doesn’t seem to make sense but it is true. Well that’s because I am French-American to be precise. I’ve lived and worked in New York for almost twenty years and I call it home — except at Christmas time.

headline: Egypt Opposition Gears Up After Constitution Passes
text: CAIRO — Egyptians approved an Islamist-backed constitution, state news media said Sunday, and the headlines made clear that the political brawl about it has only begun.

headline: A 50-50 Game and Season for the Giants

headline: North Korean Missile Said to Have Military Purpose
text: SEOUL, South Korea — South Korean technicians scrutinizing the debris of the North Korean rocket launched this month have found evidence suggesting the rocket’s military purposes and the North’s technological ties with Iran in its efforts to develop an intercontinental ballistic missile, South Korean officials said Sunday.

headline: Protests Over Rape Turn Violent in Delhi
text: NEW DELHI— Protests over a recent gang rape quickly gained force over the weekend, tapping into longstanding fury against entrenched corruption and lopsided justice, and leading to clashes with the police.

headline: From Corn Dogs to Bûche de Noël, and Onward

They changed the way they ate and cooked and thought about food, and my mother started making “bûche de Noël.” — translated into English, that means “Christmas log cake.” (Proving that everything sounds better in French.)

headline: Syrian Airstrike Is Said to Kill Dozens in a Bread Line

text: West Antarctica has warmed much more than scientists had thought over the last half century, new research suggests, an ominous finding given that the huge ice sheet there may be vulnerable to long-term collapse, with potentially drastic effects on sea levels.

headline: N.R.A. Leaders Stand Firm Against Gun Restrictions
text: Leaders of the National Rifle Association said Sunday that they would fight any new gun restrictions introduced in Congress, and they made clear that they were not interested in working with President Obama to help develop a broad response to the Connecticut school massacre.

headline: ‘The Hobbit’ Stays No. 1 at the Box Office
text: The weekend before Christmas is typically a weird one for Hollywood. It is one of the only periods all year when a movie’s performance over its first three days does not necessarily signal how good (or bad) total ticket sales will be; ticket buyers may still materialize in significant numbers over the holiday week.

headline: Stoudemire Not Quite Ready to Return

headline: Italian Premier Won’t Run in New Elections but Keeps Options Open
text: ROME — After weeks of speculation, Italy’s caretaker prime minister, Mario Monti, said Sunday that he would not run as a candidate in national elections that are expected in February, but was open to leading the government if parties that endorsed his pro-Europe, pro-reform agenda asked.

headline: Why Is This Museum Shaped Like a Tub?
text: AMSTERDAM — Offhand I can’t recall seeing a more ridiculous looking building than the new Stedelijk Museum, which recently opened here. Shaped like a bathtub, of all things, it arrives years behind schedule at the tail end of the money-fueled, headline-hungry, erratically ingenious era of indulgent museum design that began to peter out with the global economy. Compared with no-frills, cost-effective, almost penitential, post-meltdown designs like Herzog & de Meuron’s stylish Parrish Art Museum in the Hamptons, it’s a throwback.

headline: For the Holidays, Hong Kong Decks Its Skyscrapers in Lights
text: HONG KONG — For the past few weeks, Santa Claus, looking cheerful and surrounded by twinkling stars and ornaments, has been dancing on the sides of skyscrapers.
