headline: Jets Try Something New but End Up With a Similar Result
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — With nothing at stake in the Jets’ game Sunday against the San Diego Chargers, it had an experimental feeling at the start. Out of the playoffs, the Jets loosened the restraints on their playbook a bit.

headline: Surmounting Struggles in Life and Onstage
text: NEWARK — Fred Hammond walked onstage after a technical delay: a big man in jeans, a dark blazer and rectangular glasses moving uncharismatically, stiffly, maybe wearily.

headline: No Sales Pop for a New Version of Windows
text: BELLEVUE, Wash. — It used to be that a new version of the Windows operating system was enough to get people excited about buying a new computer, giving sales a nice pop.

headline: SportAccord World Mind Games in Beijing
text: At the second SportAccord World Mind Games in Beijing this month the United States open team (Curtis Cheek, Joe Grue, John Hurd, Joel Wooldridge, Ralph Katz and Howard Weinstein) played against Sweden (Peter Bertheau, Per-Ola Cullin, Fredrik Nystrom, Johan Upmark, Johan Sylvan and Frederic Wrang) in the battle for third place. The first four Swedes, along with Krister Ahlesved and Jonas Petersson, won the World Mind Sports Games open team title in Lille, France, last August.

headline: The Freedom of Faith: A Christmas Sermon
text: In an essay in The Times’ Sunday Book Review this week the writer Paul Elie asks the intriguing question: Has fiction lost its faith? As we are gathered here today, let us consider one of the most oddly faithful of all fiction writers, Fyodor Dostoevsky. More specifically, I’d like focus pretty intensely on what some consider to be the key moment in his greatest novel — arguably one of the greatest of all time — “The Brothers Karamazov.” (Elie himself notes the 1880 masterpiece as an example of the truly faith-engaged fiction of yore.) I speak in particular of the “Grand Inquisitor” scene, a sort of fiction within a fiction that draws on something powerful from the New Testament — Jesus’s refusal of Satan’s three temptations — and in doing so digs at the meaning of faith, freedom, happiness and the diabolic satisfaction of our desires.

headline: Topics to Make Brazil Squirm
text: Francisco Buarque de Hollanda, known professionally as Chico Buarque, has had a curiously bifurcated artistic career. In his homeland, Brazil, he is considered the greatest songwriter of the past 50 years, a kind of Cole Porter crossed with Bob Dylan whose elegant compositions, written alone or with partners like Antônio Carlos Jobim, Vinicius de Moraes and Caetano Veloso, have become standards in the Great Brazilian Songbook.

headline: ‘Four Seasons’ Gets New Spin
text: Reconstructing staples of the classical repertory through a contemporary prism has long tempted artists of wide-ranging aesthetics. The music of Bach has proved particularly irresistible, luring jazz performers like Uri Caine, Jacques Loussier and Dave Brubeck. The rapper Ludacris poached the “Dies irae” of Mozart’s Requiem for his song “Coming 2 America.”

headline: Two Cast Changes For Metropolitan Opera
text: The Metropolitan Opera announced on Saturday two casting changes for coming performances. The first will be on Wednesday, when the tenor Bryan Hymel is scheduled to make his Met debut in Berlioz’s “Troyens.” Mr. Hymel will step in for the tenor Marcello Giordani as Aeneas for the final four performances of “Les Troyens,” including the “Live in HD” global transmission on Jan. 5. The second change is for the production of Rossini’s “Comte Ory,” which will now feature the debut of Pretty Yende, the South African soprano who won first prize in Plácido Domingo’s Operalia competition in 2011. She will play Countess Adèle. “Le Comte Ory” is scheduled to open on Jan. 17.

headline: ‘How I Met Your Mother’ Nears an Extension
text: Television viewers who have been waiting seven-and-a-half years to learn the identity of the titular mother in the CBS comedy “How I Met Your Mother” may have to wait a little longer. CBS is close to finishing new contracts with the show’s creators and cast to extend the series and bring it back for a ninth season, according to Entertainment Weekly’s Web site. Jason Segel, who has built an impressive film résumé while also starring in “How I Met Your Mother,” was reported to be reluctant to return but is said to have signed on. The show has been a solid ratings performer in recent years, reaching a series high in total viewers last season, with an average of 9.7 million. It has been averaging 8.2 million viewers during its eighth season.

headline: A Kesha Reversal On ‘Die Young’ Lyrics
text: The Newtown, Conn., school shootings have had reverberations in the radio world, as lyrics that seemed within the bounds of good taste two weeks ago are suddenly hitting a flat note. A case in point is Kesha’s recent hit “Die Young,” a lightweight party tune about living for the moment. Though the theme of the song is carpe diem, it contains the chorus: “Let’s make the most of the night like we’re gonna die young/We’re gonna die young/We’re gonna die young.” Program directors at pop stations in Connecticut and around the country took the song out of their rotations in the days after the Dec. 14 shootings. Another song receiving very few spins these days is “Pumped Up Kicks,” last year’s Foster the People hit, which tells the story of a student shooting his classmates. The airplay for Kesha’s song dropped 19 percent on the Billboard Radio Songs chart this week, and the song has dipped to No. 4 from No. 3 on the Hot 100 single chart. Several program directors said the drop-off in airplay would be temporary, Billboard reported. In a string of Twitter posts last week, Kesha, below, apologized and asserted that she had objected to the lyrics but was “forced” to sing them. “I did NOT want to sing those lyrics and I was FORCED TO,” she wrote, in a post that was later taken down. She later posted a message on her Web site trying to clarify: “After such a tragic event I was feeling a lot of emotion and sadness when I said I was forced to sing some of the lyrics to ‘Die Young.’ Forced is not the right word. I did have some concerns about the phrase ‘die young’ in the chorus when we were writing the lyrics especially because so many of my fans are young and that’s one reason why I wrote so many versions of this song. But the point of the song is the importance of living every day to the fullest and staying young at heart, and these are things I truly believe.” Kesha is one of several songwriters on “Die Young.” The list includes Lukasz Gottwald (known as Dr. Luke), Benny Blanco, Cirkut and the group Fun.’s frontman, Nate Ruess.

headline: Just a Little Off the Top for Rossini’s Old ‘Barber’
text: It was illuminating, at intermission during the Metropolitan Opera’s opening-night presentation of Rossini’s “Barber of Seville” on Tuesday, to scroll through comments about the performance posted on Twitter. The staging, by Bartlett Sher, was the busy, buzzy, slightly daffy one that has mostly earned approval since its 2006 debut. The cast was filled with promising up-and-comers and reliable company players.

headline: The Illustrious and Twisted Paths to Secretary of State
text: WASHINGTON — My latest Letter From Washington details why Senator John Kerry of Massachusetts is an excellent choice to be secretary of state.

headline: On a Solstice, Music Can Pop Up Anywhere
text: New York became an outdoor concert hall on Friday, when Make Music Winter organized events in public spaces in the city for the winter solstice.  The next event?  The next solstice: June 21, 2013.

headline: Present-Tense Movement, With Memory
text: PHILADELPHIA — The dances choreographed by Merce Cunningham abound in solos. Because these solos deal purely with steps and movements, with no evident characterization or narrative gesture, it’s easy to miss the ways in which they operate as drama. Alone, a Cunningham dancer investigates movement, space and time with a quality of contemplation that often turns dance into a stream-of-consciousness soliloquy. A dancer may return to a step like a default position or a habit of thought; may suddenly — and frequently — change direction and tempo as if changing the subject; may change position in midair as if meeting a challenge. The focus of the eyes plays a crucial role.

headline: Coveting a Children’s Garden of Z’s
text: Few preschoolers who watch the Sprout channel’s brilliant “Snooze-a-Thon” on Christmas Eve are likely to appreciate its startling genius as a piece of filmmaking. This is neo-neo-neorealism at its finest, boldly pushing the envelope to places where even radical iconoclasts rarely go.

text: “Abe would have liked this book,” the Fox News television host Bill O’Reilly said confidently of his blockbuster best-seller “Killing Lincoln: The Shocking Assassination That Changed America Forever.” Even the ending?

But Périgord black truffles, the Rolls Royce of truffles, seem to be suffering from a climatic trend toward hotter and drier summers in their native habitats of southwestern France and Spain.

headline: Upper West Side Store Is Hurt by Staten Island Flooding
text: 1:48 p.m. Monday | Updated On first hearing, it simply did not make sense. How could Stationery and Toy, a cherished, packed daughter-and-pop store at 125 West 72nd Street, have lost almost all of its inventory during Hurricane Sandy? After all, the Upper West Side was barely discommoded by the storm. Most residents suffered from nothing much more serious than survivor’s guilt.

headline: In a Land of Austerity, Christmas Is Reinvented as a Season of Thrift
text: MADRID — This is the season when barren stone plazas and broad sidewalks here fill with Christmas markets peddling sweets, candles, holiday decorations and crafts. But alongside the festive stalls this year, another kind of market has sprung up in response to Spain’s hard times.

headline: Albert Hirschman, Optimistic Economist, Dies at 97
text: Albert O. Hirschman, who in his youth helped rescue thousands of artists and intellectuals from Nazi-occupied France and went on to become an influential economist known for his optimism, died on Dec. 10 in Ewing Township, N.J. He was 97.

headline: A TV Voice Rang True in Clamor of Shooting

headline: China Takes Chilling Look at Security in Its Schools

She gets up, but stumbles again inside the gates as the man slashes at her with a meat cleaver. Two minutes later, dozens of students race out of the gates as the man rampages through the school, eventually wounding 23 children.

headline: When Prophecy Fails
text: Back in the 1950s three social psychologists joined a cult that was predicting the imminent end of the world. Their purpose was to observe the cultists’ response when the world did not, in fact, end on schedule. What they discovered, and described in their classic book, “When Prophecy Fails,” is that the irrefutable failure of a prophecy does not cause true believers — people who have committed themselves to a belief both emotionally and by their life choices — to reconsider. On the contrary, they become even more fervent, and proselytize even harder.

headline: Another Rout, and Giants’ Playoff Hopes Are Teetering
text: BALTIMORE — The emotional spectrum was wide in the Giants’ locker room late Sunday as a humbled group of men snatched at oversize suits and half-knotted ties before stalking toward the door. Many seemed to be moving quicker than they had all day, and their haste made it appear as if they were, understandably, trying to run from their humiliation as fast as possible.

headline: Sneaky Apps That Track Cellphones
text: A perversion of smartphone technology called “stalking apps” — precise, secretive trackings of the movements of cellphone users — is increasingly a matter of national concern, particularly for domestic abuse victims. No less threatening is the routine monitoring of children’s locales and phone habits for commercial purposes while parents are kept in the dark. Stealth apps even stoop to cyber-leering through the now notorious app called Girls Around Me, which allows men to search out women, unbeknown to them, by cross-matching GPS technology with information and photo sites like Facebook.

headline: Could A.I.G. Happen Again?
text: The United States government recently sold the last of its shares in the American International Group, more than four years after it bailed out the insurance giant with a package of assistance that eventually totaled $180 billion. In announcing the sale, the Treasury Department also said that the government had a “positive return” of $22.7 billion — a sum that fails to take into account tax breaks A.I.G. received as a ward of the state. But whether the government profited from the bailout is not important. The truly vital issue is this: Could this happen again? Unfortunately, the troubling answer is yes.

headline: On School Stage, Learning Harlem’s Past and Narrowing a Generational Gulf
text: Inside a stuffy classroom in Harlem, the subject was a matter of local history; the teaching device was known as tableau, an acting exercise. The fifth-grade class of 17 students spent the morning acting out various emotions listed on the blackboard, some doing so with partners of far more advanced age.

headline: Running a Fast Break From Brooklyn to the Garden

In Brooklyn, Deron Williams was starting to salvage another disappointing personal performance by draining a 3-pointer from the wing, staking the Nets to an 89-82 lead over the Philadelphia 76ers with 62 seconds left in their game.

headline: Staying Independent in Old Age, With a Little Help
text: My 92-year-old aunt, who is cognitively impaired and requires a walker or wheelchair to get around, still lives in her own apartment, where round-the-clock home health aides help her get to and from the bathroom, bathe, dress and undress, and go outside each day for some fresh air. The aides shop, prepare and serve meals, do light housekeeping and make sure she takes her medications on time.

headline: Woman Is Killed and Boy Is Critically Injured in Newark Stabbings
text: A young woman was killed and a 9-year-old boy was in critical condition in stabbings in Newark over the weekend that the authorities were investigating as related crimes, the police and prosecutors said on Sunday.

text: HONG KONG — The nomination of Senator John Kerry as the new U.S. secretary of state has been warmly received by China, but the state-run news media on the mainland has sharply attacked the passage of a new military spending bill that is awaiting President Obama’s signature.

headline: In Gold’s Own Country
text: Lord Padmanabha, the presiding deity of Thiruvananthapuram, also known as Trivandrum, the capital of Kerala, who is depicted as reclining on a gigantic snake, Anantha, suddenly went up in the estimation of his devotees recently, when it was discovered that he has an inestimable treasure of gold in his custody.

headline: Prime Minister Manmohan Singh Appeals for ‘Peace and Calm’
text: On Monday morning Prime Minister Manmohan Singh addressed the nation and appealed for peace and calm in the wake of the protests that broke out in New Delhi following the gang rape of a 23-year old woman last Sunday. He spoke for the first time on national television after the incident, and assured that perpetrators of the crime would be punished and measures would be taken to ensure safety of women across India.

text: KABUL, Afghanistan — A police sergeant shot and killed an American civilian adviser at police headquarters in Kabul on Monday, Afghan police officials said, breaking a relative lull in the so-called insider killings that have strained the relationship between Americans and Afghans here.

text: Paris — With the season of  exuberant gift giving, joyful excess and artificial Christmas trees at hand, activists, academics and filmmakers are warning of growing landfills and environmental pollution fed by our unsustainable consumption cycle.

text: The high-rises of Chongqing, in western China, are built on hills; it is a city of steep ups and downs.

text: MOSCOW — Last week was a terrible week to be a Russian and a great week to be a journalist. From my point of view as a journalist, there was drama, suspense and even a bit of comedy. From my point of view as a Russian, there was nothing but tragedy and shame.

headline: Fudging the Facts, for Peace of Mind
text: Lou, my beloved grandfather, lived almost 101 years and obsessively worried every single day of his adult life — probably because his adult life began before it should have. As a child in Russia, he watched helplessly as his mother and sister were killed during a vicious pogrom in their village.

headline: Protected Tigers, Burning Bright
text: Tigers have delivered a bit of holiday cheer: populations are on the upswing, it turns out, in some protected areas in India and Thailand. In a field often dominated by news of felled forests and population declines, wildlife conservationists have taken heart from this development, while noting that tigers have a long, long way to go if they are to claw their way off the endangered species list.

text: Here are some end-of-year thoughts on ways to fit human aspirations on a finite planet, expressed during a recent short interview taped while I was participating in this years Business for Social Responsibility (aka BSR) conference (more interviews and talks are here). headline: Daily Report: Making Everything in Life a Game
text: Many businesses are using games to try to get people hooked on their products and services — and it is working, thanks to smartphones and the Internet, reports Nick Wingfield on Monday in The New York Times.

headline: An E-Book Price War Is Slow in Coming
text: Right about now, just as millions of e-readers and tablets are being slipped under Christmas trees, there is supposed to be a ferocious price war over e-books, reports David Streitfeld on Monday in The New York Times. But it has not happened quite like that.

headline: Windows 8 Sales Disappoint in Shaky PC Market
text: It used to be that a new version of the Windows operating system was enough to get people excited about buying a new computer, giving sales a nice pop, reports Nick Wingfield on Monday in Thew New York Times. Not this time.

headline: Urs Fischer Hits the Beach
text: Call it domestic spectacle: the way the Swiss artist Urs Fischer blends statuary, household furniture and a Photoshopped mishmash of Americana. In what is sure to be one of the last gallery openings of 2012, his show “Tables, Heads and Arms” will make its debut three days after Christmas at Eden Rock on the island of St. Barts. For a 2011 show at Gavin Brown’s Enterprise, Fischer made 300 tabletops, only two-thirds of which were ever displayed in New York. Twenty-one from the remaining lot will go on view in St. Barts, along with an assortment of found objects (chairs, vases, lamps), a new sculpture cast from Fischer’s forearms and several hand-painted figurines. The pop culture references here run the gamut from Tom Hanks in “Da Vinci Code” mode to E.P.A. warning signs to Big Bird, who rather solemnly graces the announcement card. But before reading political subtext into the Sesame Street character’s appearance, it’s worth remembering that Fischer titled a 2010 exhibition “Oscar the Grouch” and that he has a 3-year-old daughter, Lotti, with the artist Cassandra MacLeod. All three are expected to attend his year-end Caribbean vernissage.

headline: A Tuesday Like Any Other Day, a Holiday, for an Exonerated Woman
text: Letter by letter, Cathy Watkins removed her name from a roster it should never have been on. This was a list of two dozen prison inmates, their names entered on a board maintained by Centurion Ministries in Princeton, N.J. Centurion advocates on behalf of men and women like those on that board, people it believes were locked up for crimes they did not commit. People like Cathy Watkins.

headline: ‘Game of Thrones’ Is Named Year’s Most Pirated Show
text: Some fans of the HBO series “Game of Thrones” may not be willing to pay a premium-cable subscription fee to watch it, but short of besieging a fleet of ships with a magical explosive chemical they’ll do just about anything else to get their hands on it. “Game of Thrones,” the HBO fantasy drama adapted from George R. R. Martin’s “Song of Ice and Fire” novels, was the year’s most pirated show, according to the Web site TorrentFreak. TorrentFreak said that an individual episode of “Game of Thrones” had been illegally downloaded some 4.28 million times according to data compiled from BitTorrent peer-to-peer file-sharing services and other sources (the particular episode that drew this many downloads was not specified).

headline: Intersection:Dandies in the West Village
text: We hear Kai Shaw explain how men’s wear is shaping fashion, while other West Village locals gave us tips on holiday dressing.

headline: A Gaming Laptop That’s Quick and Costly
text: The word “extreme” may be overused in describing male-dominated activities like the X Games or the cinnamon challenge, but it fits the bill when it comes to the Razer Blade gaming laptop.

headline: Holiday Greens: Spinach for Christmas
text: When I lived in Paris I used to eat Christmas Eve dinner every year at a brasserie.  I would always order salmon and a side of spinach, which they cooked very simply and served up in copious amounts. There must have been one low-level guy on the kitchen brigade who did nothing but wash, stem and blanch spinach all day, so much of it did the popular side dishes require. (For every cup of cooked spinach you need 3 pounds of bunch spinach or 1 1/2 pounds of baby spinach.) That is a lot of beta keratin, vitamin K, iron, vitamins A and C, manganese, folate, magnesium, calcium, potassium, vitamins B2 and B6, tryptophan and dietary fiber for Christmas.

headline: Penne With Mushroom Ragout and Spinach
text: ​​Mushrooms and spinach together is always a match made in heaven. I use a mix of wild and regular white or cremini mushrooms for this, but don’t hesitate to make it if regular mushrooms are all that is available.

headline: Garlic Soup With Spinach
text: I made a lot of turkey stock after Thanksgiving and pulled some out for this spinach-packed, very quick and easy soup. A vegetarian version made simply with water and garlic is equally delicious.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: The Austin Chronicle: Some barbecue masters in Texas lost their lease. So now they’re serving their grub out of their own trailer. Perfect brisket and magnificent Hill Country sunsets? Count us in. — Jeff Gordinier

headline: Coughlin’s Remarks on ‘Flat-Lining’ Giants
text: The Giants finished a nothing-special 9-7 last season but won their division and earned a home game in their playoff opener on their way to a championship.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Hollywood’s 2012 Comeback, and Reviewing Amazon’s Reviews
text: Movie attendance was up 5.6 percent, despite a weak summer, punctuated by mass killings at a screening in Aurora, Colo., of the latest Batman feature, Brooks Barnes writes. Ticket revenue at North American theaters is projected to jump by 6 percent, to $10.8 billion, according to an analysis by Hollywood.com. In 2012, industry executives say, the increase from foreign sales was even more critical, salvaging the prospects of movies that were mild disappointments in the United States like “Ice Age: Continental Drift,” from 20th Century Fox, which made $68 million in China alone.

text: LONDON — The London Stock Exchange Group said on Monday that it had revised the terms of its takeover proposal for LCH.Clearnet, citing the changing regulatory environment.

text: New projections by researchers indicate that dry spells will get progressively worse in coming decades in California, Nevada, the Colorado River headwaters region and Texas, putting greater stress on agriculture, ecosystems and a growing population. [Nature Climate Change]

headline: Bond Vigilantes and the Power of Three
text: Matthew Yglesias picks up on a point I’ve tried to make at some length recently: the popular story about how an attack by bond vigilantes can cause an interest rate spike and turn America into Greece, Greece I tell you, is incoherent. (Here’s a 2010 example from Alan Greenspan — the piece in which he declares it “regrettable” that the vigilantes haven’t yet attacked, but grudgingly concedes that low rates might persist “well into next year”, that is, into 2011. So what has he learned from the failure of his prophecy? Nothing, of course). It’s not just that there have so far been no signs of the bond vigilantes; it’s that even if for some reason the vigilantes did attack, it’s very hard to see how they could cause a recession in a country that retains its own currency and doesn’t have large amounts of debt denominated in foreign currency.

headline: Case Pits Adoptive Parents Against Tribal Rights
text: WASHINGTON — “What has been the toughest decision for you?” Charlie Rose asked Justice Antonin Scalia in a television interview a few weeks ago. He meant the most personally wrenching.

headline: Because You Watched Live Theater: ‘The Netflix Plays’ Coming to Ars Nova
text: To date, a Netflix subscription may not have done much more than killed valuable hours of your free time, caught you up on missed episodes of “Futurama” and turned you on to the suggestions of its enigmatic recommendation engine. (Enjoyed vintage reruns of “Sesame Street”? Why not try “The Taking of Pelham 1-2-3″?) But now that video service has inspired its own dramatic series, “The Netflix Plays,” which will be presented at Ars Nova, the nonprofit Manhattan theater, by its Play Group, from Jan. 30 through Feb. 9, its press representatives said on Monday.

headline: The Twelve Days of Christmas Puzzle
text: On the twelfth day of Christmas, my true love gave to me: twelve Drummers Drumming, Eleven Pipers Piping, ten Lords-a-Leaping, nine Ladies Dancing, eight Maids-a-Milking, seven Swans-a-Swimming, six Geese-a-Laying, five Gold Rings, four Colly Birds, three French Hens, two Turtle Doves and a Partridge in a Pear Tree.

headline: How Much Milk Should Children Drink?
text: Cow’s milk is the primary source of vitamin D for children, but dairy products can interfere with the absorption of iron. Pediatricians have never known how much milk a child should drink. Now researchers have established that for most children, two cups a day achieves the right balance.

text: The best of readers’ photos from the week of Dec. 17.

headline: Warhol’s Mao Portraits Banned From a Show in China
text: Even though Mao’s face can be found in work by many Chinese artists, government officials in China have nonetheless vetoed the inclusion of Andy Warhol’s famous rendition of the Great Leader in a retrospective of his work traveling there, Bloomberg reported. Eric Shiner, director of the Andy Warhol Museum in Pittsburgh, said that when he heard last month that officials in China’s Ministry of Culture objected to displaying 10 Mao portraits, he asked them to reconsider.

headline: What’s On Monday
text: 7:30 P.M. (Cinemax) LOVE ACTUALLY (2003) Hugh Grant, above, portrays a British prime minister and twinkly bachelor who fancies a member of his household staff (Martine McCutcheon) at 10 Downing Street — and nearly causes an international crisis when he protects her virtue from the president of the United States (Billy Bob Thornton) — in this ensemble comedy written and directed by Richard Curtis, who also wrote “Bridget Jones’s Diary,” “Notting Hill” and “Four Weddings and Funeral.” The cast is rounded out by Emma Thompson as the prime minister’s sister, a middle-aged housewife whose husband (Alan Rickman) is besotted with his secretary (Heike Makatsh); Liam Neeson as a widower and single stepfather wallowing in grief; Colin Firth as a writer cuckolded by his own brother who is smitten with his Portuguese housekeeper; and Martin Freeman and Joanna Page as actors who fall in love while working as body doubles in a sex scene on a movie set, only to end their first date with a chaste kiss on the cheek. A. O. Scott, writing in The New York Times, called the movie an “indigestible Christmas pudding.” He added that a “genuine comic spark comes from Bill Nighy, playing a washed-up, dissolute rock star named Billy Mack, who is trying for a comeback with a treacly Christmas record.”

headline: From the Battlefields of Iraq to a Fight in Congo’s National Parks
text: William Coppeler’s journey to the 7th World Ranger Conference in Tanzania in November began two years ago, not long after the Iraq veteran had left the Army’s 25th Infantry Division for life back home in Port Clinton, Ohio.

headline: Pedestrian Accidents More Deadly in Men
text: More than twice as many men as women die in pedestrian-vehicle accidents. Now researchers have partly determined why.

headline: Our Top 10 Photo Books of 2012
text: “What is a book?” Believe it or not, the question was asked more than once in the photo department’s informal but very serious deliberations over the best books of 2012. There was much agonizing and jockeying for favorites as we tried to reduce an array of more than 500 books to just 10 favorites. Ultimately, the most important question, the one that ruled the day, was “Which books do you most want to have on your shelf?” Here are the answers, in no particular order.

text: A stop-motion Christmas wish from the Lego minifigs of Motherlode.

text: A photo of my friend Peter’s dog pops up on my phone for three seconds, then disappears. I respond with a picture of an enormous pile of nachos I’m working on at a Brooklyn bar.

headline: Gaza Cease-Fire Helps Fishermen, but Risks Remain
text: GAZA CITY — Khader Bakr, a 19-year-old fisherman, was thrilled to hear that he could now fish up to six nautical miles from the coast, up from the three-mile limit Israel had had in place since 2009. The change was part of the cease-fire deal that halted last month’s fighting in Gaza between Israel and Hamas.

headline: California Law Tests Company Responses to Carbon Costs
text: LOS BANOS, Calif. — The Morning Star Company’s three plants in California emit roughly 200,000 metric tons of carbon dioxide into the atmosphere each year — about the same amount as the Pacific Island nation of Palau — as they turn tomatoes into ketchup, spaghetti sauce and juice used by millions of consumers around the world.

headline: Celebrities Selling Homes Scrub Off the Star Dust
text: On a fan Web site devoted to Julian Casablancas, the lead singer of the band the Strokes, and his wife, Juliet, there are pictures of the happy-looking couple in all sorts of settings: at a football game, walking a red carpet and crossing the street holding hands. There are also photographs of an apartment they own and are hoping to sell — here, some nice arched doorways, there, a guitar hanging on the wall — along with the date and time of an open house and a link to the address.

headline: Seeking Answers in Genome of Gunman
text: In a move likely to renew a longstanding ethical controversy, geneticists are quietly making plans to study the DNA of Adam Lanza, 20, who killed 20 children and seven adults in Newtown, Conn. Their work will be an effort to discover biological clues to extreme violence.

headline: Game Theory: Caring About Make-Believe Body Counts
text: Dear Chris, Kirk and the rest,

headline: Food vs. Fuel in 2013
text: In coming days, the Environmental Protection Agency’s to-do list will include setting a standard for the amount of advanced biofuels that refiners will be required to blend into gasoline and diesel supplies in 2013. The question is tricky because production in one category, cellulosic fuel from nonfood sources like corn cobs, stalks, wood chips and garbage, has not met the target set by Congress. The E.P.A. has the authority to adjust the quotas as needed, but the issue is complicated.

headline: A New Focus on the ‘Post’ in Post-Traumatic Stress
text: Psychological trauma dims tens of millions of lives around the world and helps create costs of at least $42 billion a year in the United States alone. But what is trauma, exactly?

headline: B.M.I. Can Predict Health Risks
text: Some scientists believe that body mass index, a calculation involving the ratio of height to weight, is an inaccurate measure of obesity-related risks because it does not account for body shape, fat mass and lean mass. But a new study finds that B.M.I. works at least as well as other body measurements, and better than some, to predict certain health problems.

headline: Is Paying to Message Strangers a New Texting Business?
text: Cellphone carriers are making less money from text messages thanks to free messaging services offered by Facebook, Apple and other tech companies. But now Facebook is running a test to see if it can make some money by charging people to send messages to strangers.

headline: Walkabout — 12/24: Airports Gird for Storm, and Vegas Gets an Airline
text: Storm on Santa’s Heels After dumping six feet of snow in California, a major storm headed east today, likely to add chaos to the usual holiday travel slog. (NBC)

headline: Wright’s Law: A Teacher’s Unique Lesson
text: In 2012, The Times profiled Jeffrey Wright, who uses wacky experiments to teach children about the universe, but it is his own personal story that teaches them the true meaning of life.

headline: The Black, the White and the Angry
text: “It’s better than ‘Lincoln,’ ” my teenage daughter said, as the end credits rolled at a screening of Quentin Tarantino’s “Django Unchained.” She was teasing me — it’s a sad fact of my life that some of the people I’m fondest of do not seem to share my fondness for Steven Spielberg’s latest movie — but also suggesting an interesting point of comparison.

headline: Protesters Disrupt Egyptian Blogger’s Speech in Israel
text: Last Updated, 7:01 p.m. Palestinian students disrupted a dissident Egyptian blogger’s address at the Hebrew University of Jerusalem on Sunday.

headline: From Bang to Whimper: A Heart Drug’s Story
text: On June 23, 2005, American medicine managed to take a small step forward and a giant step backward at precisely the same time, with government approval of the first medication to be earmarked for a specific racial group. It was BiDil, a drug designed to treat heart failure in blacks.

headline: With a Parent Off Again at War, a Holiday of Pride and Isolation
text: FORT CAMPBELL, Ky. — Signs of the season have been everywhere at Fort Campbell High School over the last couple of weeks: a student soloist sang the Carpenters’ “Merry Christmas, Darling” at the annual holiday concert, a big tree sparkled in the cafeteria under the Screaming Eagle emblem of the 101st Airborne Division, and thousands of parents were deployed yet again in Afghanistan.

headline: The Fed and Interest Rates
text: In response to today’s column, I’m getting a lot of the usual: namely, the claim that low interest rates don’t prove anything, because the Fed has been buying up all the federal government’s debt issue. This is always said with an air of great wisdom; in fact, it’s remarkably foolish, managing to be wrong in three distinct ways.

headline: Obstacles to Financing for Retired Chimpanzees
text: As the National Institutes of Health reduces its use of chimpanzees in invasive biomedical research, it is moving more chimps to retirement homes. But the agency could face a problem in paying for their continuing support, officials say.

Bond imagined that his/her self-described freakishness was caused by a traumatized mother’s suddenly curdled breast milk when her favorite soap opera was interrupted by Walter Cronkite’s announcing President John F. Kennedy’s assassination.

headline: Andy Ricker to Open Whiskey Soda Lounge in Brooklyn
text: If you were not convinced that Brooklyn was an East Coast version of Portland, Ore., the chef Andy Ricker, who owns Pok Pok Ny in Brooklyn, keeps adding to the case. In the spring, he plans to open a Whiskey Soda Lounge, like the one he has in Portland, just a few doors down from Pok Pok Ny. This branch, in a small space, will serve drinks and Thai-style “drinking food” snacks that Mr. Ricker described as “spicy-salty-sour.” He sees it as a holding pen for customers waiting for tables at the restaurant. And he plans to serve Ike’s Vietnamese Fish Sauce Wings, a cult favorite.

text: Mosasaurs were large, ancient relatives of monitor lizards. They were common during the Late Cretaceous period, 66 million to 100 million years ago, and were found near shallow marine areas in salt water.

headline: A Happy Ending, Sort of, Comes With No Closure
text: “West of Memphis,” a work of fierce documentary advocacy directed by Amy Berg (“Deliver Us From Evil”), follows the successful crusade to free three men convicted of murder 18 years ago in a sloppy, hysterical rush to justice.

headline: An Oratorio Gets Its Day
text: It has been a season of relief for those New York Bach fans perpetually disappointed that their master’s “Christmas Oratorio” is not a holiday perennial on the order of Handel’s “Messiah.”

headline: Thousands of Children Are at Risk in Central Africa, Aid Agency Warns
text: A large measles epidemic is spreading in Central Africa, endangering the lives of thousands of children, the medical charity Doctors Without Borders warned last week.

headline: Big Money and Mischief in Reagan-Era Hollywood
text: William Stadiem’s specialty has been collaborating on gossipy tell-alls with minor celebrities. Very minor celebrities, but well-positioned ones. Mr. Stadiem’s books include “Mr. S: My Life With Frank Sinatra,” with George Jacobs, Sinatra’s keenly observant valet, and “Marilyn Monroe Confidential: An Intimate Personal Account,” with Lena Pepitone, who worked for Monroe as a maid. According to reader feedback on the Goodreads site, the Monroe book is a better written treatment of National Enquirer-type material. If you read it by a pool and dropped it in the water, a reader says, you wouldn’t be all that sorry.

headline: Making a Sandwich by the Book
text: Do you really need a cookbook to make a sandwich? Not for PB&J, perhaps, but what if you are tempted by soft scrambled eggs and ricotta on fresh focaccia, or sardines with pickled eggs and salsa verde? That’s when you should open the Saltie cookbook, based on the menu at this compact sandwich shop in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. Besides recipes for sandwiches and their components, it has desserts, soups, eggs and salads. An easily assembled cock-a-leekie makes a delicious cold-weather supper. The method is unusual: bring a whole chicken to a boil, then let it cool in the liquid for an hour, after which the chicken is done and you have your broth. Prunes add color and a touch of sweet richness.

headline: Smoked Fish From Long Island
text: Phil Karlin, a commercial fisherman based in Cutchogue, N.Y., has started making and selling various smoked fish products under the name North Fork Smoked Fish. His line includes smoked blue fish fillets and a creamy smoked blue fish pâté, a slightly spicier Caribbean pâté made with smoked swordfish, a mixed smoked-fish dip, and hot-smoked Norwegian salmon pâté (below) and fillets, all tailor-made for easy entertaining. The pâtés and dips are appetite-whetters. The succulent fish fillets can be served alongside a salad, in a sandwich or broken up into a chowder.

headline: As Forests Disappear, Examining the Mechanisms of Their Death
text: LOS ALAMOS, N.M. — Everywhere, trees are dying.

headline: Turkish Breads Seek a Niche in the Bagel Capital
text: In Eastern Mediterranean regions, Balkan countries and the Arab world there is a popular snack that looks like a large bagel and comes beaded with sesame seeds. It has various names, but in Turkey it’s called simit, and it is the star attraction at a new shop in Manhattan called Simit & Smith. The Smith is fictitious; the Turkish entrepreneurs behind the enterprise added it to make the name more American-sounding, said Burak Atay, the managing partner. They opened on the Upper West Side last week and already have a bakery and store in Cliffside Park, N.J. Two spots are planned for the financial district in early 2013.

headline: The Wretched Lift Their Voices
text: In the first long act of “Les Misérables,” Anne Hathaway opens her mouth, and the agony, passion and violence that have decorously idled in the background of this all-singing, all-suffering pop opera pour out. It’s a gusher! She’s playing Fantine, the factory worker turned prostitute turned martyr, and singing the showstopping “I Dreamed a Dream,” her gaunt face splotched red and brown. The artful grunge layered onto the cast can be a distraction, as you imagine assistant dirt wranglers anxiously hovering off camera. Ms. Hathaway, though, holds you rapt with raw, trembling emotion. She devours the song, the scene, the movie, and turns her astonishing, cavernous mouth into a vision of the void.

headline: For the Home Mixologist, One Tool for 10 Tasks
text: A Swiss Army knife for the bar? Why not, especially in a small apartment. This gadget, the Bar10der, combines everything you need, except the shaker and alcohol, to make a drink. The muddler at one end doubles as a reamer. A strainer, knife, zester, channel knife, stirrer, bottle opener and corkscrew all pull out of the handle for use. There is a double jigger, for an ounce and a half-ounce. The cushioned rubber-clad handle is easy to grip, and you have a choice of colors: azure, purple, lime or orange.

headline: 12 Restaurant Triumphs of 2012
text: AT the end of my first year in the restaurant critic’s chair, the New York dining landscape still looks like a wonderland to me.

headline: The Year’s Farewells
text: A few of the notable restaurants that closed in 2012.

headline: The Dishes of 2012 That Dazzled on Their Own
text: Many restaurants that didn’t make the top 12 of the year still served memorable dishes. Pete Wells lists eight of the best.

headline: The Top 12 Restaurants of 2012
text: Pete Wells shares his list of the year’s best restaurants.

headline: A New Calf Has Arrived in Brooklyn
text: Updated, Dec. 26 | Brooklyn’s bovine population has grown by one: a calf was born at the Prospect Park Zoo, officials announced Monday.

headline: The Trocks Tackle ‘Laurencia’
text: The all-male drag company Les Ballets Trockadero de Monte Carlo is currently staging the Soviet-era ballet “Laurencia” at the Joyce Theater.

headline: Going to Sleep While We Wait for Santa
text: We’re not sure if Santa Claus will leave a luxury car with a giant bow in the driveway, a motorcycle in the garage or a Matchbox car in the stocking, but we do know he won’t leave anything if we’re awake. So Wheels is taking a not-so-long winter’s nap tonight and tomorrow. But rest assured we’ll be back on Wednesday. Merry Christmas to all!

headline: In Performance: Alice Ripley of ‘A Civil War Christmas’
text: “A Civil War Christmas,” Paula Vogel’s play with music, is set during the grim holiday season of 1864. Alice Ripley, who plays Mary Todd Lincoln and other characters, sings a medley of “Yellow Rose of Texas” and “Ain’t That a Rockin’ All Night.” The show runs through Dec. 30 at New York Theater Workshop.

headline: Buried Treasure That Is Filled With Mystery
text: IF you have never bought truffles because, frankly, you do not know how to begin and you are afraid you will get skunked, well, you are not alone. Serious home cooks and even food pros are bamboozled all the time. It’s actually pretty difficult and always expensive to attain good-quality truffles, especially for retail customers. In fact, acquiring truffles is so fraught with potential fraud that you might wonder whether the dining experience is worth the financial risk.

headline: The Chemistry Sets of Yesteryear
text: From “Chemcraft” to the “Midgetlab,”  chemistry sets flourished from the early through the mid-20th century, featuring everything from gender-specific kits to tabletop labs complete with “Atomic Energy.”

headline: A Science Toy Spectacular
text: This week we take up a history of science toys. And if you’ve ever wondered what toys the reporters and editors at the Science Times adored as children, well, we got that too.

headline: Columbus Circle, 2:38 P.M.
text: N.Y. See: A violinist on the uptown No. 1 train platform at the 59th Street-Columbus Circle subway station.

headline: Practical to Career-Oriented to Just Plain Fun
text: Harry Potter fans will appreciate the origin of the chemistry set: In 18th century England, university students were given supply lists and sent to shops in London that assembled kits for each course of study, from geology to mineralogy and chemistry.

headline: A Haunting Tale, Perfect for Christmas
text: At holiday time, the Metropolitan Museum of Art draws countless visitors to its Medieval Sculpture Garden to see the splendid Christmas tree and 18th-century Neapolitan crèche. The garden has also been a special site for holiday concerts. The museum has put much thought over the years into choosing appropriate seasonal music, especially early music.

headline: Gifts That Keep Giving (if Not Exploding)
text: Ask scientists of a certain age about their childhood memories, and odds are they’ll start yarning about the stink bombs and gunpowder they concocted with their chemistry sets. Dangerous? Yes, but fun.

headline: What’s Your Best Meal of 2012?
text: Pete Wells has listed his best new restaurants of the year, along with some of the best dishes he tasted. Now we look to you. Share your best restaurant meals of the year by tweeting us at @nytdining, using the hashtag #bestmeal2012. Your pick doesn’t have to be from a new restaurant, or even a place in New York City; it simply has to be something delicious, intriguing, stimulating or just so good you couldn’t stop thinking about it.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Syria and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Syria, India, Afghanistan and West Bank.

headline: Russian Prosecutor Seeks Acquittal in Lawyer’s Death
text: MOSCOW — A prosecutor unexpectedly pressed Monday for the acquittal of the only official to be tried in the case of Sergei L. Magnitsky, a lawyer whose death in prison three years ago generated an international furor over Russian human rights abuses.

headline: No Requiem for Earth, Only Celebration
text: The world did not end on Friday as the ancient Maya calendar foretold. But if any apocalyptic forces were kicking around the planet that day, they were combated by a performance that evening at Carnegie Hall of “The Creation,” Haydn’s astonishing oratorio that depicts God’s making of the world, presented by the New York Virtuoso Singers, the Orchestra of St. Luke’s and a roster of vocal soloists, conducted by Harold Rosenbaum.

headline: Dining Calendar
text: Free Beer

headline: Not Even the Russians Can Do This ‘Laurencia’
text: Tory Dobrin, the artistic director of the all-male drag company Les Ballets Trockadero de Monte Carlo, affectionately known as the Trocks, first saw a clip of the Soviet-era ballet  “Laurencia”  on television in the early ’80s, and it stayed with him. The ballet shows its choreographer, Vakhtang Chabukiani, dancing in a ripped shirt, with a bare midriff and torn pants, surrounded by women in peasant skirts and blouses.

headline: What He Does for Love
text: For the last couple of months, VH1 has been showing the reality show “Marrying the Game,” which chronicled the wedding preparations of the Game, the abrasive, derivative rapper, and his longtime girlfriend, Tiffney Cambridge. By the end of the season, though, the two were at loggerheads, and the wedding was off, at least partly because of the Game’s heavy focus on completing work on “Jesus Piece,” his fifth album.

headline: ‘No Means No,’ and More From Wise Grandparents
text: “Parental Guidance,” a new comedy with Billy Crystal, is about a minor-league baseball announcer who, after he’s canned for being an old shtick in the mud (he doesn’t tweet), develops a new relationship with his daughter and grandkids. Actually, he teaches everyone a lot of lessons — it’s revenge of the geezer — allowing him to have his curmudgeonly cake and eat it too. Mostly, though, “Parental Guidance” is what families who are desperate to get out of the house over the holidays and need to bridge the generational divide will see after they’ve seen “Les Misérables.”

headline: In Performance: Alice Ripley
text: The actress sings “Yellow Rose of Texas” from “A Civil War Christmas.”

headline: Qatar 2022: Nine Years Can Go By Fast
text: Every four years, soccer fans around the world revel in what has been called the biggest sporting event on the planet — the World Cup.

headline: More on a Man Who Flew More Than a Million Miles
text: AS the end of the year approaches, many business travelers anxiously do the mileage math. That is, how many miles did I fly this year on a given airline? Was it enough to hit the mark for whichever elite-status level I’m pursuing for next year?

headline: Harmonizing Two Holidays
text: Marc Kudisch and Jeffry Denman rely too much on well-worn themes to make “The Holiday Guys: Happy Merry Hanu-Mas!,” their new seasonal stage show, a must-see addition to the December crush. But it’s moderately diverting, nonthreatening and nontaxing, which seem to be the main theatrical criteria at this time of year. And when the two men put aside the predictable banter and just sing, it’s downright pleasant.

headline: That’s No Mouse King in the Trailer
text: Reality television viewers familiar with Chris March from his stint as a “Project Runway” contestant or his endearingly wacky Bravo spinoff, “Mad Fashion,” will know this designer and sometime drag artist as an outsize personality with a cuddly exuberance to match his girth. But that personality is largely AWOL from his holiday dansical, “Chris March’s The Butt-Cracker Suite!,” playing at Here.

text: Jonathan Bales breaks down a big play each week of the season.

headline: Getting Polio Campaigns Back on Track
text: How in the world did something as innocuous as the sugary pink polio vaccine turn into a flash point between Islamic militants and Western “crusaders,” flaring into a confrontation so ugly that teenage girls — whose only “offense” is that they are protecting children — are gunned down in the streets?

text: To the Editor:

headline: City’s Law Tracking Energy Use Yields Some Surprises
text: In courting tenants over the last six years, 7 World Trade Center has trumpeted its gold LEED rating, an emblem of sound environmental citizenship.

headline: Jack Klugman, Actor of Everyman Integrity, Dies at 90
text: Jack Klugman, the rubber-mugged character actor who leapt to television stardom in the 1970s as the slovenly sportswriter Oscar Madison on “The Odd Couple” and as the crusading forensic pathologist of “Quincy, M.E.,” died on Monday at his home in the Woodland Hills section of Los Angeles. He was 90.

headline: Markets Quiet, Awaiting Move on Impasse
text: It was supposed to be an easy week.

headline: Endless Emotions Over N.F.L.’s Longest Game
text: Ed Podolak loves this time of year. Invariably, he is asked about his momentous game on Dec. 25, 1971, when he amassed 350 total yards, still a postseason record, even though his Kansas City Chiefs lost in double overtime to the Miami Dolphins, 27-24, in the longest contest in N.F.L. history.

headline: Aid for Children, Facilitated by Wings
text: I’M the president of the United States Fund for Unicef, and I travel for a lot of reasons. First and foremost, I go places so I can see firsthand the work that Unicef is doing on the ground.

headline: Future of Corporate Tower May Hinge on a New Use
text: The AT&T Building, a lavish $200 million headquarters with a seven-story arch at 550 Madison Avenue, was a symbol of a resurgent New York when it opened in 1983 after a decade of municipal woes and corporate flight.

headline: Dressing Up for Success
text: In September, a pedestrian walking on Central Park South in Manhattan might have noticed the name Jumeirah being stripped from the marquee of the Essex House, a luxury hotel. The property became a JW Marriott. Earlier, it was a Westin.

text: ROME — Pope Benedict XVI, delivering his annual Christmas Eve message in a voice that sometimes seemed to waver, called on the faithful to make room for God in their thoughts and busy, technology-filled lives.

headline: Mexico Finds Unlikely Allies in Trade Fight
text: As tomato growers in Florida and some other states fight a 16-year-old agreement that they contend allows farmers in Mexico to export tomatoes at a price below their costs, the Mexican farmers are finding allies in the United States.

headline: 7-Eleven Shifts Focus to Healthier Food Options

headline: The 2012 Sidney Awards I
text: At the start of the 1980s, about 5 percent of Harvard students were Asian-American. But the number of qualified Asian-American applicants rose so that by 1993 roughly 20 percent of Harvard students had Asian heritage.

headline: Officials Push to Postpone Swearing-In of Chávez
text: CARACAS, Venezuela — Top officials in the government of President Hugo Chávez, who is recuperating from cancer surgery in Cuba, say they will postpone his inauguration, now set for Jan. 10, if he is too ill to return to Venezuela to begin his new term.

headline: Deployed Yet Again
text: Students at Fort Campbell High School live with the emotions of parents who carry the burdens of war.

headline: Unpacking Christmas
text: Almost everyone who keeps Christmas seriously and loves this season for reasons secular or sacred cherishes the ritual of going through the decorations that have gathered over time. Each year, the Christmas archive is unpacked again. Here are the oldest ornaments for the tree — hand-me-downs over several generations, terribly fragile, their color faded but no less powerful in memory for that.

headline: Jack Klugman, Character Actor, Dies
text: Jack Klugman, the character actor who leapt to television stardom in the 1970s as the slovenly sportswriter Oscar Madison on “The Odd Couple,” died on Monday.

headline: A Pleasant Surprise Amid the Sure Things
text: The N.F.L. has never seen a rookie class make a larger impact than this year’s group. Now, with the playoff field nearly set, the extraordinary nature of these rookies is coming into focus.

headline: F.B.I. Counterterrorism Agents Monitored Occupy Movement, Records Show
text: WASHINGTON — The Federal Bureau of Investigation used counterterrorism agents to investigate the Occupy Wall Street movement, including its communications and planning, according to newly disclosed agency records.

headline: Indiana: No Bond for 3 in Fatal Arson
text: Three people charged with murder and arson for causing an Indianapolis house explosion were jailed without bond after a court hearing on Monday. A Marion County judge entered not guilty pleas for the defendants — Monserrate Shirley; her boyfriend, Mark Leonard; and his brother Bob Leonard — who were arrested on Friday. They were accused of tampering with Ms. Shirley’s gas fireplace to fill her residence with gas and using the microwave to spark the Nov. 10 blast, which killed two neighbors and damaged surrounding homes. Investigators believe the three were trying to collect insurance money on the house.

headline: Another Try at Nuclear Negotiations
text: After a six-month hiatus, the United States and other major powers are trying to resume negotiations with Iran over its nuclear program. Iran has been enriching uranium in defiance of United Nations Security Council resolutions for six years, and Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel has threatened military strikes if these activities are not halted by next spring or early summer. It is imperative that all sides make every effort to reach a diplomatic solution. War, of course, would be disastrous. But so would an Iran with a nuclear weapon.

headline: Where Streets Are Darkest, Christmas Still Comes
text: Residents of neighborhoods devastated by Hurricane Sandy celebrate the holidays.

headline: Troops in Afghanistan Find Cheer With a Yule Logon
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Marine Cpl. Brett Bass will do what a lot of American service members hope to this Christmas Day: “I’m going to give myself a gift of not turning on my alarm clock,” he said.

headline: The Power of a Mom’s Love
text: It’s Christmas. The fiscal cliff is still approaching, guns remain a huge problem and the political paralysis in Washington isn’t abating. But, in the spirit of the season, let’s put aside our national troubles for this one day and talk about something a little more inspiring. Let’s talk about what a mother’s love can accomplish.

headline: Approaching Illness as a Team
text: The Cleveland Clinic, long considered a premier medical system, is gaining new renown for innovation in improving the quality of care while holding down costs.

headline: After Looking East to the Knicks, Nash Cut West to the Lakers
text: LOS ANGELES — In the beginning, it was hard for Steve Nash to picture himself wearing the purple-and-gold uniform of the Lakers, his archrival for eight years when he played for the Phoenix Suns.

headline: Real and Virtual Firearms Nurture a Marketing Link
text: As Electronic Arts prepared to market Medal of Honor Warfighter, the latest version of its top-selling video game released in October, it created a Web site that promoted the manufacturers of the guns, knives and combat-style gear depicted in the game.

headline: No Easy Route if Assad Opts to Go, or to Stay, in Syria
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — President Bashar al-Assad of Syria sits in his mountaintop palace as the tide of war licks at the cliffs below.

headline: Caring for a Toddler Who Rules the House
text: Jose Valentin is the head of a four-person household. Technically.

headline: Hackers of Football Team’s Web Site Demand Apology in Rape Case
text: Computer hackers hijacked the Web site of a prominent Ohio high school football team late Sunday, threatening to release the personal data of school officials, coaches and every player on the team if those involved in a suspected rape did not publicly apologize to the girl and her family.

headline: Key West Looks at Identity as It Plots Tourism Future
text: KEY WEST, Fla. — There is no better motto for this raucous southernmost point on the American map than “One Human Family.”

headline: A Republican Mayoral Possibility Unsettles Democrats
text: I served as City Hall bureau chief during the temple-throbbing Age of Giuliani. Almost alone among the men who vowed daily loyalty to Rudolph W. Giuliani — and the mayoral inner circle often was a male preserve — Joe Lhota qualified as media-friendly.

headline: Religious Exemptions and the Liberal State: A Christmas Column
text: On Sunday in these pages, Molly Worthen reported on the decline of “the Protestant civil religion that has undergirded our common life for so long “(One Nation Under God?).” That might come as a surprise to the millions of TV viewers who watched the memorial service held in Newtown, Conn., a little more than a week ago. Despite a few gestures in the direction of Catholics and religious minorities (and no gestures at all in the direction of non-believing atheists and agnostics), the tenor of the service was deeply Protestant, as were the remarks of President Obama (that famous Muslim!) who seemed more preacher than chief executive as he repeatedly struck biblical chords and ended by recalling Jesus’s call to send the little children to him.

headline: In Their Hours of Need
text: Can the Giants still make the playoffs? Yes, but it will require four specific results and a long day of waiting. Here’s a potential timeline of events for Sunday that could end with the Giants slipping into the postseason.

headline: Tebow’s Inactivity Speaks Volumes on Jets
text: If the perfect microcosm of the Jets’ season was modeled after one game, Sunday’s 27-17 loss to the San Diego Chargers would be an apt candidate.

headline: Fire and Flooding in Breezy Point
text: The fires that enveloped the community of Breezy Point, Queens, on the night that Hurricane Sandy hit, left a hole in the heart of this genial shore community.

headline: Frenzy Over Teaching Test Is Symptom of Italy’s Myriad Woes
text: ROME — Luisa Ribolzi, an expert on education in Italy, likened a teaching job at a public school when the economy is bad to “a ship to jump on for everyone who is swimming in the sea.”

headline: Clinging to Now, but Looking to Future Changes
text: One day after a deflating blowout loss that kind of, sort of, maybe felt like the end of the season (but actually wasn’t), it was difficult to know which way to look with the Giants.

headline: Gaza: Rights Group Accuses Militants of Unlawful Rocket Attacks on Israel
text: Human Rights Watch said Monday that armed Palestinian groups in Gaza had violated the laws of war by firing hundreds of rockets toward population centers in Israel during eight days of fighting in November. Three Israeli civilians, a soldier and a civilian contractor at a military base were killed by the rocket fire. The group said that two Palestinians were killed, apparently by rockets that fell short, and that the militants endangered Gaza civilians by firing from densely populated areas. More than 150 Palestinians were killed by Israel airstrikes and shelling. A spokesman for Hamas, the Islamic militant group that controls Gaza, rejected the report as biased, telling Reuters that the Palestinians were defending themselves. Human Rights Watch, a nongovernmental group based in New York, has criticized Israel for what it called unlawful attacks on a house that killed 12 people, and on Palestinian journalists during the conflict. Israel has insisted that it fired on legitimate targets.

headline: Antigovernment Graffiti Restored, Courtesy of Government
text: SAN FRANCISCO — For decades, visitors to Alcatraz Island had trouble deciphering the faded red graffiti on the old prison’s rusted water tower.

headline: China: 89 Abducted Children Rescued
text: The police have broken up nine child trafficking rings, rescuing 89 children and arresting 355 suspects, the Ministry of Public Security announced Monday. According to the official Xinhua news service, the gangs abducted children in several provinces in the south and then sold them elsewhere in China. The raid was part of a nationwide crackdown on kidnappers, who often seize boys. Most of the stolen children are sold to families who want a male heir but face limitations imposed by China’s strict family-planning policies. The Chinese government says that 10,000 children are kidnapped each year, but some experts suggest the number may be as high as 70,000.

headline: Russia: More Trouble for an Activist
text: Federal authorities on Monday announced another criminal case against Aleksei Navalny, the anticorruption advocate and political opposition leader — the fourth over all and the second one this month. Mr. Navalny, left, has denied all of the allegations, describing them as politically motivated retribution for his activities. The federal Investigative Committee on Monday accused Mr. Navalny of stealing more than $3 million from the Union of Right Forces, a liberal party that is now defunct, in 2007. The authorities have also accused Mr. Navalny and his brother of conspiring to steal money in business deals. In addition, Mr. Navalny has been questioned in connection with a protest last May and has been accused of defrauding a timber company. Mr. Navalny, responding on Twitter to the latest charges, posted, “Enough.”

headline: Battered Seaside Haven Recalls Its Trial by Fire
text: They expected the sea to come, though not like this. Tim Dufficy, 26, one of the volunteer firefighters, had relocated his two cars to the rooftop lot of a Brooklyn mall so they would be up high. Of potential risks, fire did not rouse much concern. They began the evening contemplating turkey.

headline: A Start-Up Sees a Gold Rush Among the Stars
text: BELLEVUE, Wash. — The job description and title, “Chief Asteroid Miner,” are not what you are likely to come across on a job-search Web site. Besides, the position is taken. Chris Lewicki, the president of Planetary Resources, a company based in this city just east of Seattle, has it on his business cards.

headline: Historic Boston Church’s Decision to Sell Rare Psalmbook Divides Congregation
text: BOSTON — When the leadership at Old South Church decided it was time to fix up their home, they turned to a fund-raising option most likely available only to a Colonial-era institution like this one, founded in this city’s primordial hinterlands: selling a copy of a rare psalmbook, printed across the river in Cambridge in 1640, that could fetch up to $20 million at auction.

text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.

text: NEW YORK

headline: Richard Adams, Same-Sex Spouse Who Sued U.S., Dies at 65
text: Richard Adams, who nearly four decades ago legally married his male partner in Colorado and, in the first lawsuit of its kind, tried unsuccessfully to have their marriage recognized by the federal government, died on Dec. 17 at his home in Los Angeles. He was 65.

headline: Friend of Former Commissioner Is Acquitted of Lying in Inquiry
text: A Bronx jury acquitted a friend of Bernard B. Kerik, the former New York police commissioner, on Monday of a charge involving perjury to a grand jury in 2006 over renovation work to Mr. Kerik’s apartment.

headline: Corrections: December 25, 2012
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: What Kept China’s Search Engines Busy in 2012
text: HONG KONG — With an estimated 600 million Chinese now having access to the Internet, it seems both instructive and important to find out about their end of the global online conversation. What have they been reading and searching for this year? What has them worried, or optimistic? What have they been blogging and blathering about?

headline: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, Dec. 25, 2012.
text: No one really cares. Your father goes, gets deployed. War — it’s normal. It’s not like a big deal that we’re still at war.

headline: ‘Warfighter’ Video Game Is Linked to Gun Makers
text: It has not yet been two weeks since Adam Lanza used two handguns and an assault rifle to kill 20 first-graders and six adults at Sandy Hook Elementary in Newtown, Connecticut.

headline: What’s On Tuesday
text: 9 P.M. (BBC America) DOCTOR WHO: THE SNOWMEN In this annual holiday episode, a Scrooge-like Doctor (Matt Smith), mourning the loss of Amy and Rory to the Weeping Angels, takes on a new companion, Clara (Jenna-Louise Coleman, above with Mr. Smith). Now it’s up to her to persuade him to board the Tardis and save Christmas from the villainous Doctor Simeon (Richard E. Grant) and his army of snowmen.

headline: Merry Christmas!
text: India celebrates Christmas.

headline: Adding Indian Spice to Christmas
text: For those who celebrate Christmas, the meal eaten to mark the holiday can be as important as the ritual of exchanging gifts or decorating a green tree.

headline: Charles Durning, Prolific Character Actor, Dies at 89
text: Charles Durning, who overcame poverty, battlefield trauma and nagging self-doubt to become an acclaimed character actor, whether on stage as Big Daddy in “Cat on a Hot Tin Roof” or in film as the lonely widower smitten with a cross-dressing Dustin Hoffman in “Tootsie,” died on Monday at his home in Manhattan. He was 89.

headline: Forget the Sleigh, Bring On Air Force One
text: Of all the first lady’s official duties, the Christmas Eve phone calls to young children eagerly anticipating news of Santa’s arrival must rank among the least prone to complication.

headline: Hark! The Herald of Christmas Past
text: One hundred years ago, in celebration of the holiday season, The New York Herald Tribune European edition (a forerunner of today’s IHT) published its annual Christmas supplement. The richly illustrated pages contained original artwork and articles on a variety of topics.

headline: Record-Breaking Weekend in the N.F.L.
text: Chase Stuart writes about the historical and statistical side of football at his site, FootballPerspective.com.

headline: A Conservative Case for the Welfare State
text: Bruce Bartlett held senior policy roles in the Reagan and George H.W. Bush administrations and served on the staffs of Representatives Jack Kemp and Ron Paul. He is the author of “The Benefit and the Burden: Tax Reform – Why We Need It and What It Will Take.”

headline: Safety Agency Blasts Grinches Who Use ‘Safety’ to Spoil Christmas Fun
text: LONDON — Britain’s health and safety watchdog has come out with a timely indictment of petty officialdom for using the excuse of supposedly protecting the public in order to spoil everyone’s Christmas fun.

headline: Chinese and Syrians Are in Prayers of the Pope
text: ROME — Speaking from the balcony of St. Peter’s Basilica, Pope Benedict XVI called on Tuesday for religious freedom in China and peace for the “defenseless” in Syria in his Christmas message.

headline: Chinese Driver Runs Down Students
text: HONG KONG — A man angry over a court ruling in the case of his daughter’s murder used his car to run down a group of high school students in northern China, causing 13 to be hospitalized with injuries, the local government and the state news media reported on Tuesday. It was the second major attack on students in China in less than two weeks.

headline: Pass the Hat, Save the Arts?
text: PARIS — In the early rush to turn crowd-funding online into a new source of public revenue to buy everything from medieval ivory statues in France to a gallery for dinosaur bones in Canada, there’s a cautionary tale: It doesn’t always work.

headline: Tuesday Reading: Unpacking Christmas Memories
text: Unpacking Christmas memories, how much milk should children drink, finding a simplified smartphone and other consumer-focused news from The New York Times.

headline: Q&A: Selling Your Own iBooks
text: If I use the iBooks Author program to create my own e-book, do I have to sell it through Apple’s online bookstore?

headline: Navigating Retail Holiday Return Policies
text: Now that the holiday shopping frenzy is over, it’s time for the traditional Returning of the Gifts.

headline: The Best in Culture
text: A collection of the year’s best in art, music and film. See interactive feature >>

headline: Israel to Review Curbs on Women’s Prayer at Western Wall
text: JERUSALEM — Amid outrage across the Jewish diaspora over a flurry of recent arrests of women seeking to pray at the Western Wall with ritual garments in defiance of Israeli law, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has asked Natan Sharansky, the chairman of the Jewish Agency, to study the issue and suggest ways to make the site more accommodating to all Jews.

headline: Mandela Is Looking Better, President Says After Visit
text: JOHANNESBURG — President Jacob Zuma of South Africa gave a largely upbeat assessment on Tuesday of the health of Nelson Mandela, the nation’s first black president and anti-apartheid icon, who has spent more than two weeks in the hospital for a lung infection and gallstones.

headline: TV Watch: India's 'Child Bride'
text:
One of the top-rated shows in India, "Child Bride," is about Anandi, an underage girl
who was forced into an arranged marriage by her parents.

headline: ‘Don’t Come To This Land, My Daughter’
text: This is a soap opera about female infanticide in India.

headline: Is That Christmas Tree Kosher?
text: JERUSALEM — More than two decades ago, the Israeli belly dancer Ilana Raskin won a Supreme Court case against the Israeli rabbinate. It had withheld a license for serving kosher food in the hotel where she was to perform because it found such acts immodest and immoral. She prevailed in court, on the argument that the rabbinate, which is the only Israeli institution permitted to issue kosher-food licenses, should do so only on grounds pertaining to the preparation and serving of food.

headline: TV Watch:  ‘I Do’
text: This is a new soap opera about Zoya, an Indian girl who returns home from New York and has to adjust to her traditional Muslim community. The romances are predictable but the setting isn't.

headline: Pick Your All-Time New York City N.B.A. Team
text: New York City high schools have produced at least 211 N.B.A. and A.B.A. players, including 12 Hall of Famers. Choose and share a team of your own.

headline: Game Theory: Making Room for the Women
text: Women. You must have heard of them. They’re like real gamers, only with little hands and silly, squeaky voices and constant gripes about being marginalized and hypersexualized and threatened with rape in online multiplayer settings.

headline: A Onetime Drug Dealer, Now Working to Combat a Plague of Gun Violence
text: Rudy Suggs, 48, has already lived one life, and now he is on his second. The first was as a gun-toting drug dealer in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, a few blocks from where he grew up. The second is as an anti-gun-violence activist, working the same streets he used to roam late into the night to prevent gunshots before they happen.

headline: Gaming Workplace Workouts
text: The company Nextjump splits its employees into workout teams and rewards them for going to the gym.

headline: Spike Lee Goes After ‘Django Unchained’
text: He may not have seen it, but the film director Spike Lee already has an opinion about “Django Unchained.” In a recent interview with Vibe, he said he would not watch Quentin Tarantino’s latest film, set in the antebellum South, which opened in theaters on Tuesday. “I can’t speak on it ’cause I’m not gonna see it,” he said. “The only thing I can say is it’s disrespectful to my ancestors, to see that film.”

headline: Q. and A. With Michael Bradley
text: Before his 20th birthday, Michael Bradley fulfilled a dream when he signed a contract to play for Heerenveen in the Netherlands. Since then, Bradley, 25, has played in Germany (Borussia Mönchengladbach), in England (on loan to Aston Villa) and in Italy (first for Chievo Verona and now for Roma).

headline: Former Official Stole Millions in Real Estate, Russia Says
text: MOSCOW — The police said Tuesday that they had arrested a former official of a federal agency that manages state enterprises on charges of stealing $330 million in property, a theft noteworthy even by the standards of Russian public corruption.

headline: Ben Affleck Says No to a Senate Run
text: Any Massachusetts residents dreaming of having an Oscar winner who publicly rubbed up J. Lo as their Washington envoy are due for disappointment. Ben Affleck declared that he would not compete for John Kerry’s Senate seat if Mr. Kerry is confirmed as secretary of state. “I love Massachusetts and our political process, but I am not running for office,” Mr. Affleck wrote on his Facebook page.

headline: The View from Notre Dame: Tickets to Ride
text: SOUTH BEND, Ind. — The players had not left the Los Angeles Coliseum after Notre Dame defeated Southern California on Nov. 24 when the Fighting Irish senior Danny Kinasz secured his seat for the plane ride to Miami for the Bowl Championship Series title game on Jan. 7.

headline: Clout Diminished, Tea Party Turns to Narrower Issues
text: The Tea Party might not be over, but it is increasingly clear that the election last month significantly weakened the once-surging movement, which nearly captured control of the Republican Party through a potent combination of populism and fury.

headline: Mine, All Mine: Ski Areas Rent Whole Mountains
text: Having a private ski mountain seems the stuff of ski-bum fantasy. But for little more than the price of a daily lift ticket (if overall cost is divided equally), a few ski areas offer the chance for skiers to act like king (or queen) of the mountain for the day.

headline: What to Play on Boxing Day
text: It was fun putting together the Christmas Dozen Playlist that accompanied my eggnog column. And I couldn’t have done it without my friend Sean, an M.T.A. subway motorman, whose holiday gift to his friends is a painstakingly compiled, wonderfully idiosyncratic music mix; he introduced me to three of the numbers I included on my playlist: Toots and the Maytals’ “Christmas Feeling Ska”; BeauSoleil’s “Papa St. Nick”; and William Bell’s “Everyday Will Be Like a Holiday.” (I did not consult with Questlove, but he has some tips for holiday-party playlist-making, too.)

headline: Gunman Who Killed 2 Firefighters Left Chilling Note
text: WEBSTER, N.Y. — On Monday morning when darkness was still raw, William Spengler Jr. armed himself with a rifle, a revolver and a shotgun. He had killed before. Harboring a deep-seated hatred of his sister, who lived with him, and a desire to harm his neighbors on a beachfront strip off Lake Ontario, Mr. Spengler composed a rough, typewritten plan that foretold of the destruction to come.

headline: Design Unveiled for Haiti Stadium
text: It has been nearly three years since an earthquake devastated Haiti.

headline: Motive Unclear in Killing by Woman in Afghan Force
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Sergeant Nargis went to work Monday with murder on her mind.

headline: Game Theory: Challenging the Industry
text: Helen,

headline: Russian Says Ban on U.S. Adoption Flouts Treaties
text: MOSCOW — Russia’s deputy prime minister for social affairs has warned President Vladimir V. Putin that a proposed ban on adoptions of Russian children by American citizens would violate several international treaties as well as an agreement on adoptions ratified this year between the Russian government and the United States.

headline: The Triumphs and Failures of Deal Makers in 2012
text: It is time to award the Deal Professor A’s, the grade for the best deals and deal makers of 2012. Unfortunately, there were also a large number of F’s this year. Here is the top and bottom of the class, in alphabetical order:

headline: Celtics Subdue Nets in Christmas Day Opener
text: The scoreboard is inanimate, reflecting only cold results and momentary fate, but it can occasionally serve as an emotional and spiritual marker, reflecting the brilliant highs and the most wrenching lows of the N.B.A. calendar.

headline: Now in 3-D, Christmas With the Queen
text: For the first time, Queen Elizabeth II marked Christmas in a third dimension. Speaking from London, the queen videotaped her traditional holiday address to the British public in 3-D, and even donned 3-D glasses to watch it from Buckingham Palace. In the annual remarks, which she writes herself, the queen paid tribute to servicemen and women whose “sense of duty takes them away from family and friends” over the holidays, and highlighted a year that included the 60th anniversary of her reign and the London Olympic Games, The Associated Press reported.

headline: A Mass Holiday Homecoming Saddles a Rural Irish Town
text: RATHKEALE, Ireland — Christmas in Ireland is a time of homecomings, with joyous family reunions at airports and ferry piers. But the largest single gathering of all briefly turns this little town into the only place in Ireland where armed police officers patrol the streets 24 hours a day to deter internecine feuds and other disorderly conduct.

headline: In Hopes of Healthier Chickens, Farms Turn to Oregano
text: FREDERICKSBURG, Pa. — The smell of oregano wafting from Scott Sechler’s office is so strong that anyone visiting Bell & Evans these days could be forgiven for wondering whether Mr. Sechler has forsaken the production of chicken and gone into pizza.
