headline: From the 17th Century, Gleeful Jinks Aplenty, More Low Than High
text: How do you hold an audience of the young and hip captive, let alone keep them laughing, wolf-whistling and hooting with delight through a three-and-a-half-hour evening fashioned from the dusty bones of 17th-century popular theater? Ed Sylvanus Iskander’s raucous production of Amy Freed’s anachronism-flaunting “Restoration Comedy” at the Flea Theater answers that question.

headline: It’s Not Just a Job; It’s a Musical
text: The song “Millwork,” a haunting slice of blue-collar melancholia, has been recorded by its composer, James Taylor, and covered by artists from Emmylou Harris to Eddie Vedder, Bruce Springsteen to Bette Midler. But as performed with a gorgeous sorrowful twang by Marie-France Arcilla in “Working: A Musical,” at 59E59 Theaters, this evocative ballad belongs unequivocally to the woman standing before us: a mother of three who toils as an assembly-line steam-press operator in a luggage factory, reflecting on her “wasted” life.

headline: Heart Disease in Military Shows Steep Drop Since Korean War
text: A new study shows that the rate of American service members with signs of coronary artery disease has declined sharply in the last half century, falling to roughly 1 in 10 military personnel today from about 8 in 10 during the Korean War.

headline: Ever Independent, Lieberman Moves On, Calling Partisan Fighting a ‘Cancer’
text: WASHINGTON — There was Joseph I. Lieberman, in the midst of his extended farewell tour of interviews, speeches and personal appearances (“This feels like the Last Waltz of the Band,” he said), talking about how much people have hated him.

headline: Google Apps Challenging Microsoft in Business
text: SAN FRANCISCO — It has taken years, but Google seems to be cutting into Microsoft’s stronghold — businesses.

headline: Modern Dance Groups to Get Hurricane Sandy Aid
text: Among the huge outpouring of relief for damages from Hurricane Sandy nearly two months after it hit, a modest effort is on the horizon for the shoestring but vibrant world of modern dance in New York City. Starting in early January checks from $1,000 to $5,000 will go out to companies, choreographers and theaters knocked back on their heels by the destruction and flooding.

headline: Pats on the Back, and a Nod to Artistic Versatility
text: The annual Kennedy Center Honors are always a heartening reminder that amid the din of day-to-day pop culture, real and enduring artistic achievement is taking place, even if we forget to notice. But the 35th installment of the awards, which will be broadcast Wednesday night on CBS, is particularly satisfying, a delicious mix of highbrow and not so highbrow, beginning with a man who memorably dressed as a woman and ending with a rock ’n’ roll symphony.

headline: Extraordinary Actors Ennobling the Ordinary
text: You’ve heard and probably used the phrase “perfectly ordinary” in various contexts. Today consider it in a new one: as an excellent description of what Jack Klugman and Charles Durning did so very, very well.

headline: After Storm, Moving to Update a Mall at the South Street Seaport
text: Nearly two months after Hurricane Sandy devastated the South Street Seaport on the East River in Lower Manhattan, Dumpsters still line its cobblestone streets and nearly all of the stores west of Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive remain closed.

headline: Nick J. Romito
text: Mr. Romito, 30, is the founder and chief executive of View the Space, a new real estate technology business that creates online video tours, primarily of office space, and provides data-tracking services to commercial real estate companies, among them SL Green Realty, Vornado Realty Trust and Silverstein Properties.

headline: Voice of Calm in Debate on Guns
text: In “Living With Guns” Craig R. Whitney, a former correspondent and editor for The New York Times, writes that he is motivated by the belief that “Americans on both sides of the debate about guns can and must find common ground.” He hopes to defuse the prevailing “hysteria” by establishing that both sides are correct in at least one fundamental assertion.

headline: Iran Suggests Attacks on Computer Systems Came From the U.S. and Israel
text: Iran reported a number of new cyberattacks on Tuesday, saying foreign enemy hackers tried in recent months to disrupt computer systems at a power plant and other industries in a strategically important southern coastal province as well as at a Culture Ministry information center.

headline: The View from Alabama: Saban Delivers Again
text: TUSCALOOSA, Ala. — The University of Alabama’s football program reached a fork in the road after the 2006 season.

headline: Concerns About the Safety of Drilling
text: To the Editor:

headline: After the Airport Closes
text: Developments on the sites of decommissioned airports are being closely watched, as growing demand for air travel puts pressure on other urban airports with little space to grow.

headline: Idled City Airports Are Finding a Second Life as Housing
text: DENVER — When excavators digging on the land that was formerly Denver’s Stapleton Airport unearthed an old Cessna, J. W. Duff, the 86-year-old owner of the J. W. Duff Aircraft Company was not surprised. “Lots of planes” were disposed of by burial when the airport was still in operation, Mr. Duff said. Finding something unexpected is just one of the many challenges of turning idled airports into something else.

headline: Hotel Review: Andaz Shanghai
text: UPSHOT

headline: In Toronto, a Locavore’s Life Made Easy
text: FOR some, the term locavore has gone from revolutionary to groan-worthy, conjuring images of holier-than-thou elites with the means to worry about not just where, but by whom, their cheese is made. And yet, as easy as it might be to dismiss eating from harvests no more than 100 miles from home as a lark of the privileged, the movement is still gaining converts.

headline: Sometimes the Instruments Upstage the Instrumentalists
text: Even people barely aware of classical music have heard of Strads. The stringed instruments made by Antonio Stradivari and his family, part of a trailblazing group of 17th- and 18th-century Italian luthiers, are more famous than most of the works played on them.

headline: The True Meaning of an N.B.A. Feast
text: Eighteen grueling years as a professional basketball player and Jerry Stackhouse was slipping into uniform, color-coordinated sneakers included, for the first time on Christmas Day. A benefit of having never held down a roster spot on one of the chosen holiday elite has been quality family time at home, nestled comfortably in front of expanding television screens.

headline: Fiscal Cutoff Would Pinch at First, Then Get Steadily Worse
text: Quick action by President Obama and Congress could still help the economy escape the full impact of hundreds of billions in tax increases and automatic spending cuts set to take effect shortly after the last minutes of 2012 tick away next week. But if the deadlock in Washington persists much longer than a few weeks, the consequences will quickly mount, economists warn.

headline: In Race Around World, Boat Relies on the Power of Wind, Water and Sun
text: Bernard Moitessier of France surprised the sailing world by peeling away from the first solo, nonstop, around-the-world race when he was on the cusp of finishing in 1969. He said in his reports to passing ships that he had found enlightenment on the high seas. He continued to go two-thirds of the way around the globe before landing in the South Pacific because he could.

headline: Downtown, Before the Gentry Moved In
text: For some of us it’s still a bit of a shock to encounter a Whole Foods on the corner of Bowery and Houston Street with a sign outside that reads, “Bowery Self-Serve Cookie Bar: Because It’s Been That Kind of Day.” For more than a century, after all, and until very recently, the Bowery was known for trafficking in substances considerably stronger than cookies.

headline: No Shushes Amid Joy And Pride In the Youth
text: “The modern shunning of applause between movements is one of the more tired and unnatural conventions of the classical music world,” Vivien Schweitzer rightly observed in a recent concert review in The New York Times.

headline: The TV Watch Abroad
text: Alessandra Stanley, the chief television critic of The New York Times, is going abroad to watch foreign television this year.

headline: On Indian TV, ‘I Do’ Means to Honor and Obey the Mother-in-Law
text: MUMBAI, India — Mothers-in-law are not a joke on Indian TV.

headline: To Reach Younger Buyers, Vintners Think Outside the Bottle
text: PERSUADING consumers to drink anything other than bottled wine is an uphill climb. Glass bottles are the gold standard, so newer brands are turning to sleek, eco-friendly containers and promoting them through social media to reach younger wine drinkers.

headline: Remembrance of Passions (and Follies) Lost
text: The word melancholy occurs several times in “Tabu,” Miguel Gomes’s odd and sometimes entrancing new film, memorably at the beginning, where it is used (in a voice-over) to describe a Portuguese explorer making his wistful way through the wilds of Africa, haunted by ghosts and threatened by crocodiles. This poor, intrepid soul is a character in a movie that is watched by Pilar (Teresa Madruga), a middle-aged single woman living in modern Lisbon. Her unadventurous, middle-class euro zone existence is melancholy in its own way. Like the explorer, Pilar is filmed in narrow-screen black-and-white, which casts a glow of nostalgic mystery over her everyday dealings with friends and neighbors.

headline: Why, God?
text: WASHINGTON

headline: Japan’s Population
text: To the Editor:

headline: How Can We Best Measure College Success?
text: To the Editor:

headline: Credit Range
text: FICO provides the credit scores of roughly 200 million Americans.

headline: Giving Siblings an Edge
text: To the Editor:

headline: Media Coverage of Killings
text: To the Editor:

headline: Lincoln Center, 1:31 P.M.
text: The Big Apple Circus performed at Lincoln Center on Christmas.

headline: Bahrain, a Brutal Ally
text: Isa Town, Bahrain

headline: Our Failed Approach to Schizophrenia
text: Washington

headline: Fraud in Preschool Special Education
text: Over the last several months, the New York State comptroller’s office has painted a damning portrait of fraud and malfeasance in the program that spends $2 billion a year on special education for preschool children with learning, developmental and other disabilities. The comptroller’s latest audit points squarely at the state’s Education Department, which clearly needs to do a better job of overseeing this troubled program. But the Legislature, too, has a role to play in rooting out fraud.

headline: Asleep at the Wheel: Bad Luck, or a Crime?
text: Should drowsy driving be prosecuted like drunken driving, or is nodding off at the wheel simply an accident – like hitting a patch of ice?

headline: Intentional Bias in North Carolina
text: A North Carolina trial judge recently resentenced three death-row inmates to life without parole under the state’s Racial Justice Act, which allows inmates to have their sentences reduced if it can be shown they were tainted by racial bias. In the trials of two blacks and one Lumbee Indian, the judge found “powerful evidence”of such bias.

headline: Give Chuck a Chance
text: In case you haven’t heard, President Obama is considering appointing Chuck Hagel, a former United States senator from Nebraska and a Purple Heart winner, as the next secretary of defense — and this has triggered a minifirefight among Hagel critics and supporters. I am a Hagel supporter. I think he would make a fine secretary of defense — precisely because some of his views are not “mainstream.” I find the opposition to him falling into two baskets: the disgusting and the philosophical. It is vital to look at both to appreciate why Hagel would be a good fit for Defense at this time.

headline: Stop Subsidizing Obesity
text: Not long ago few doctors – not even pediatricians – concerned themselves much with nutrition. This has changed, and dramatically: As childhood obesity gains recognition as a true health crisis, more and more doctors are publicly expressing alarm at the impact the standard American diet is having on health.

headline: Russia’s Desire for Cars Grows, and Foreign Makers Take Notice
text: NIZHNY NOVGOROD, Russia — Sleek and glistening, the General Motors sedans creep off the assembly line here. They are as new as cars can get. And so is the assembly line, where the first test cars emerged this month.

headline: Nowadays, ‘Odd Couple’ Would Have to Be Rich Couple, Too
text: “The Odd Couple,” a beloved sitcom that ran for five years beginning in 1970, just lost its other half. Jack Klugman, the cleanliness-challenged sportswriter Oscar Madison, died at age 90 on Monday, never again to infuriate his fictional and anal-retentive roommate, a photographer named Felix Unger, played by Tony Randall, who died in 2004.

headline: Obama to Leave Hawaiian Vacation Early to Work on Fiscal Deal
text: KAILUA, Hawaii — President Obama is planning to cut his Christmas vacation short and return to Washington to make a last-ditch push for a compromise on a tax and spending dispute that remains stubbornly unresolved.

headline: One Illness After Another, and an Eviction Looming
text: As the water surged through the basement apartment of a Coney Island town house during Hurricane Sandy, Jeffrey Cowen, a cherubic and chatty sort, tried to calm down the two tenants who had remained with him in the building.

headline: Transactions
text: ¶ Recent Sale

headline: Updating Mann’s Status From Stuffy to Chatty
text: LÜBECK, Germany — The latest sensation from the literary lion Thomas Mann is more than a century old and runs over 500 characters, not pages, long.

headline: Colonel Wilder’s Lightning Brigade
text: Newly promoted rebel brigadier general John Hunt Morgan set out on a cavalry raid into Kentucky on Dec. 22, 1862. His objective: the railroad between Nashville and Cincinnati, the primary supply line for Gen. William Rosecrans’s Army of the Cumberland. Rosecrans was getting ready to move his 44,000 men against the 38,000 soldiers under Gen. Braxton Bragg, based in Murfreesboro, just 26 miles from Nashville. The Federal general didn’t have enough cavalry to simultaneously support a movement on Bragg and a hunt for Morgan’s 3,000 raiders, but he could ill afford to let supply disruptions threaten his attack plans: President Lincoln was growing impatient for results.

headline: The Dawning of Domestic Drones
text: The drones are coming to a neighborhood near you.

headline: Immigration and Policing
text: The Obama administration on Friday announced a policy change that — if it works — should lead to smarter enforcement of the immigration laws, with greater effort spent on deporting dangerous felons and less on minor offenders who pose no threat.

headline: First Fighting Islamists, Now the Free Market
text: CAIRO — Hamdeen Sabahi was the most popular leader in the fight against Egypt’s new Islamist-backed constitution. Now he is preparing for his next battle: against Islamist leaders’ plans for Western-style free-market reforms.

headline: Perfect 10? Never Mind That. Ask Her for Her Credit Score.
text: As she nibbled on strawberry shortcake, Jessica LaShawn, a flight attendant from Chicago, tried not to get ahead of herself and imagine this first date turning into another and another, and maybe, at some point, a glimmering diamond ring and happily ever after.

headline: City in North Is Captured, Syrian Rebels Announce
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Rebel fighters in Syria said they had taken control of a strategic town on the Turkish border on Tuesday, and the international envoy to Syria said in Damascus that he had yet to receive any response from President Bashar al-Assad to proposals he delivered to halt the country’s deepening war.

headline: Coming Back: Under New Management
text: L+M Development Partners has its work cut out for it as it starts renovations on Ocean Village, a long-neglected low-income housing development on the Rockaway Peninsula.

headline: A New Owner and, Many Hope, a New Lease on Life
text: There is a sparkling view of the now-docile Atlantic Ocean from the window of an apartment on the 19th floor of Building 2 of Ocean Village, an eyesore of a low-income housing complex in the Arverne section of the Rockaway Peninsula. Turn around, and the view is far less lovely. The apartment is empty, one of about 350 vacant units in the disheveled towers, its kitchen uprooted and walls smudged with grime.

headline: A German Resurgence, Feet First
text: GELSENKIRCHEN, Germany — The resurgence of German soccer began, like the country’s economic comeback, after a long slide toward stagnation amid dire prophecies of impending irrelevance.

headline: Chinese Officials Find Misbehavior Now Carries Cost
text: BEIJING — The Chinese have become largely inured to tales of voracious officials stockpiling luxury apartments, $30,000 Swiss watches or enough stolen cash to buy their mistress a Porsche.

headline: Charles Durning, Versatile Actor, Dies
text: Charles Durning, who was an acclaimed character actor in “Cat on a Hot Tin Roof” and “Tootsie,” died on Dec. 24.

headline: Nash Helps Lakers Get Back at Knicks
text: LOS ANGELES — All the Lakers have wanted for weeks was their team back, and here it was, just in time for Tuesday’s high-profile rematch against the Knicks.

headline: Corrections: December 26, 2012
text: Corrections appearing in print on December 26, 2012.

headline: Catholic Schools Open Doors to Storm-Tossed Students
text: The scene at St. Patrick School in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, seemed no different from that at any other parochial school: Students stood bright-eyed and fidgety in choirlike rows around the auditorium stage, rehearsing carols for an annual Christmas pageant.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, Dec. 26, 2012
text: I just figured, the oil field is here and I’d make the money while I could. I didn’t want to waste the money and go to school when I could make just as much.

headline: Legal Curbs Said to Hamper A.T.F. in Gun Inquiries
text: MARTINSBURG, W.Va. — The Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives has been without a permanent director for six years, as President Obama recently noted. But even if someone were to be confirmed for the job, the agency’s ability to thwart gun violence is hamstrung by legislative restrictions and by loopholes in federal gun laws, many law enforcement officials and advocates of tighter gun regulations say.

headline: Egocentric Person’s Mantra
text: WEDNESDAY’S PUZZLE — Writers in general tend to be a self-involved bunch, but Dan Schoenholz takes the cake. His puzzle is all about himself. Or rather, ME. No, not me ME. Him ME. Stay with me on this.

headline: A Finals Reunion Comes Out the Same
text: MIAMI — A decade and a half has passed since the N.B.A. finals have featured the same matchup for two straight years.

headline: Richard Baum, 72, Dies; Connected China Watchers on the Web
text: Richard Baum, who presided over Chinapol, an online discussion group about China that has become an essential forum for many experts, diplomats and journalists, died Dec. 14 at his home in Los Angeles. He was 72.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Pay in Oil Fields Is Luring Youths in Montana
text: SIDNEY, Mont. — For most high school seniors, a college degree is the surest path to a decent job and a stable future. But here in oil country, some teenagers are choosing the oil fields over universities, forgoing higher education for jobs with salaries that can start at $50,000 a year.

headline: Los Angeles Weighs Law Banning Elephant Shows
text: LOS ANGELES — The Ringling Brothers and Barnum & Bailey Circus train has been bringing four-ton Asian elephants to this city since 1919.

headline: Fired, but Firing Back, Over Dealings in Washington
text: WASHINGTON — Eric W. Payne’s world has shrunk. The man who oversaw millions of dollars in city contracts today watches every dime in his family budget. He has not worked full time since 2009. He and his family were evicted last summer, and now their lives spill from boxes in a cramped town house in suburban Virginia.

headline: Study Finds Modest Declines in Obesity Rates Among Young Children From Poor Families
text: A new national study has found modest declines in obesity among 2- to 4-year-olds from poor families, a dip that researchers say may indicate that the obesity epidemic has passed its peak among this group.

headline: For Akaka, a Senate Role as No. 1 on the Roll
text: WASHINGTON — It is a name that has echoed prominently through the Senate for years, even though most Americans know very little about the person himself.

headline: Facade of Manhattan Luxury Building Collapses
text: Any holiday celebrating in the luxury apartments in the O’Neill Building in Manhattan came to an abrupt end on Tuesday night when the building’s facade collapsed and it was evacuated, Fire Department officials said.

headline: N.B.A. Replay: Dec. 25
text: The Celtics pounded the Nets, the Lakers stopped the Knicks and the Heat survived the Thunder.

headline: Japan’s Premier Resigns, Making Way for a Predecessor
text: TOKYO — Prime Minister Yoshihiko Noda resigned Wednesday ahead of a vote in Parliament to return former Prime Minister Shinzo Abe to power, ending the country’s three-year break from decades of near-constant rule by the conservative Liberal Democratic Party.

headline: Exercise and the Ever-Smarter Human Brain
text: Anyone whose resolve to exercise in 2013 is a bit shaky might want to consider an emerging scientific view of human evolution. It suggests that we are clever today in part because a million years ago, we could outrun and outwalk most other mammals over long distances. Our brains were shaped and sharpened by movement, the idea goes, and we continue to require regular physical activity in order for our brains to function optimally.

headline: Buy, Sell, Adopt: Child Trafficking in China
text: HONG KONG — In announcing the rescue of 89 abducted Chinese children on Christmas Eve, a senior police official said baby boys could now be purchased in China’s interior for less than $5,000 — and then resold for three times that amount in the wealthier coastal provinces.

headline: A German Resurgence, Feet First
text: Nicholas Kulish writes in Wednesday’s Times about the revival of German soccer, both on the field and on the balance sheet, in recent years, and about what the changes might mean for the country’s prospects in the game in the future.

headline: Suicide Bomber Kills 3 Afghans by U.S. Base
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — A suicide bomber killed three Afghans on Wednesday in an unsuccessful attempt to enter an American military base in eastern Afghanistan, American and Afghan officials said.

headline: Ex-Premier Is Chosen to Govern Japan Again
text: TOKYO — Parliament formally elected Shinzo Abe as prime minister on Wednesday, ending a three-year break from decades of near-constant rule by his conservative Liberal Democratic Party.

headline: IHT Quick Read: Dec. 26
text: NEWS The Tea Party might not be over, but it’s increasingly clear that the U.S. election last month significantly weakened the movement, which had nearly captured control of the Republican Party through a potent combination of populism and fury. Trip Gabriel reports.

headline: China Opens Longest High-Speed Rail Line
text: HONG KONG — China began service Wednesday morning on the world’s longest high-speed rail line, covering a distance in eight hours that is about equal to that from New York to Key West, Fla., or from London across Europe to Belgrade, Serbia.

headline: Sachin Was Us, and We Were Sachin
text: If love is defined by that which gives without expecting anything in return, then I guess we love our cricketers.

headline: The Images of 2012: Sports
text: The year started triumphantly for New York sports fans as the Giants won Super Bowl XLVI with a narrow last-minute victory over the New England Patriots. In addition, the Nets moved to Brooklyn and returned major professional sports to the land the Dodgers had forsaken.

headline: A Budget for Regulation
text: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago. He is the author of “The Redistribution Recession: How Labor Market Distortions Contracted the Economy.”

headline: Week 17 N.F.L. Game Probabilities and Motivations
text: Week 17 can be a tough one for predicting N.F.L. games. Some teams have playoff futures on the line, or at least a significant seeding advantage, and they may face teams with nothing to play for. This can create mismatched motivation levels and personnel decisions for which a purely mathematical model cannot account.

headline: The Gypsies’ Dance
text: MADRID — The Seville-born Spanish choreographer and dancer Israel Galván looks unprepossessing: trim and lithe, his beard flecked with gray. Yet his style is explosively eclectic. From taut whirls and arching leaps he snaps into angular poses and syncopated glides.

headline: From a Tiny Projector, a Big Picture
text: As consumers switch from laptops to tablets and smartphones, the makers of projectors are adapting.

headline: Russian Measure Banning Adoptions by American Citizens Is Sent to Putin
text: MOSCOW — The upper chamber of Parliament on Wednesday unanimously approved a bill to ban adoptions of Russian children by United States citizens, sending the measure to President Vladimir V. Putin, who has expressed support but not yet said if he will sign it.

headline: A Vote for Pete Carroll as Coach of the Year
text: Morning links for your consideration:

headline: Tip of the Week: Start Menu Alternatives for Windows 8
text: The new interface of Microsoft’s Windows 8 operating system may be disorienting at first for those who have spent years automatically heading toward the Start menu. While the new Windows 8 Start screen is a colorful alternative for displaying frequently used programs, widgets and apps, it may not appeal as much to people who favor things in lists, or who are not using a touch-screen computer.

headline: Dance the Smartphone Tango Without Me
text: I haven’t got a smartphone. I don’t even have a cellphone.

headline: Love, Ages Apart
text: GOOD and great directing can appear self-evident. You know it when you see it even if it can be hard to explain what exactly you’re seeing. As Andrew Sarris wrote in “The American Cinema,” his magnificent, sublimely eccentric taxonomy of good, bad and fringe directors, “direction is a relatively mysterious, not to say mystical, concept of creation.” He dedicated the next few hundred pages of his landmark book to help unravel that mystery.

headline: Spielbergian, on a Budget
text: MY two favorite American movies of 2012 were “Lincoln” and “Beasts of the Southern Wild,” a big shiny Hollywood apple and a sweet little Sundance orange, with, at least at first glance, nothing much in common. If you were so inclined, you could plot these two films at opposite ends of the spectrum that currently defines American cinema, where the very big movies cluster at one end, the very small at another, with less and less in the middle.

headline: Welcome to the Friars Club
text: Dear Diary:

headline: Game Theory: A Playwright on the Art of Video Games
text: So it’s the end of 2012, and it feels like gaming is pushing through its creative adolescence. There are glimpses of what it might become. Thus, for games to take their rightful place among other creative works it’s important to ask what they do that other forms cannot.

headline: Getting the Dirt on Hurricane Sandy
text: On Oct. 29, waters from Hurricane Sandy’s 13-foot surge dredged up sediment from the city’s waterways and sent it barreling through the streets and into basements and backyards. As the floods receded, residents of neighborhoods with toxic Superfund canals worried that waterborne chemicals had contaminated their homes, streets and parks, rendering them unsafe.

headline: Daily Report: Google Moves Onto Microsoft’s Turf in Business Software
text: It has taken years, but Google seems to be cutting into Microsoft’s stronghold — businesses, reports Quentin Hardy in Wednesday’s New York Times.

headline: Wednesday Reading: Renting Your Own Private Ski Resort
text: Renting your own private ski resort, when your date wants to know your credit score, selling your own iBooks and other consumer-focused news from The New York Times.

headline: This Year in Small Business: Not Impressed!
text: Another year of The Dashboard is behind us, and it’s time to look back at our favorite comments, blogs, opinions and videos of 2012, the ones that had the biggest impact on small-business owners. Enjoy.

headline: Capital-biased Technological Progress: An Example (Wonkish)
text: Ever since I posted about robots and the distribution of income, I’ve had queries from readers about what capital-biased technological change – the kind of change that could make society richer but workers poorer –really means. And it occurred to me that it might be useful to offer a simple conceptual example – the kind of thing easily turned into a numerical example as well – to clarify the possibility. So here goes.

headline: The Best in Men’s
text: The roundup of our favorite stories of 2012 in men’s fashion. See interactive feature >>

headline: Dan Stevens Has Something to Say About ‘Downton Abbey’
text: Be forewarned that this post deals with developments on “Downton Abbey” that British viewers are now aware of, but which have not yet occurred in the American broadcast of that series. In other words, major spoilers ahead.

headline: Christmas After Sandy
text: In Red Hook, Brooklyn, congregants attended Christmas Mass at Visitation Church, which has experienced a resurgence since Hurricane Sandy.

headline: Leading Off: The Great Christmas Dilemma
text: To walk around New York, or any city, on Christmas is to understand the joy of a little quiet. The consumerism-run-amok atmosphere of the buying season takes a well-earned pause, all but a few stores resting in their iron gate cocoons. People wander around just walking; not shopping, just walking. O.K., that part may be unique to New York.

headline: Dennis Lehane Offers Literary Reward for Missing Dog
text: When a character goes missing in a Dennis Lehane novel, usually nothing good results. But Mr. Lehane, the author of best-selling novels like “Mystic River” and “Gone Baby Gone,” is trying to make the best of the disappearance of a beloved dog, and is offering an unusual reward to the person who helps return her: he said he would name a character after that person in a coming novel.

headline: Protecting Freedom(Works)
text: OK, the story of the fight at FreedomWorks — which ended with Dick Armey being sent away with a $8 million severance package — is getting even more bizarre. From the WaPo:

headline: Grace Notes, Far From Hollywood
text: Bestiaire

headline: Is Growth Over?
text: It’s taken me a while to get around to Bob Gordon’s stimulating essay suggesting that the great days of economic growth are behind us. It’s not that different from things he’s been saying before, and I have in the past had a lot of sympathy for that view. I now believe, however, that his technological pessimism is wrong — or if you prefer, it’s the wrong kind of pessimism. But this is definitely a discussion worth having.

headline: In the Company of Captain Cook
text: A young boy conscripted aboard a ship of seasoned sailors. A journey to faraway lands in an uncharted world. A tale of cannibals and exotic creatures and devastating illness. This could be the makings of the latest young adult action thriller. Instead it’s a strikingly illustrated picture book for older readers, piquantly evocative of centuries-old historical events.

headline: An Early Tale of the Internet
text: Last Friday I interviewed Peter E. Hart, an electrical engineer who was an early artificial intelligence researcher, about one of the first robots, a machine named Shakey that was designed at SRI International beginning in 1966. SRI was one of the laboratories from which many personal computing and networking technologies were first developed.

headline: In Speaker Dock, a Minimalist Home for the iPhone 5
text: Capitalizing on the sudden need for iPhone 5 docking stations, Harman has released the JBL OnBeat Micro speaker dock that features the must-have Apple Lightning connector.

headline: Consequences of a Political Deadlock
text: TimesCast: Fiscal impasse adds to economic anxiety. | At Jerusalem’s Western Wall, women fight against ultra-Orthodox beliefs. | Christmas after Hurricane Sandy in Red Hook, Brooklyn.

headline: These Worlds Take a Lot of Work
text: A CREW of hundreds came together to create the locations for Peter Jackson’s “Hobbit” trio of prequels to his “Lord of the Rings” movies. Some of the artists who brought their expertise to “Rings” are back. Dan Hennah, who won an Oscar for set decoration in “Return of the King,” served as the production designer on the new films. And Joe Letteri, whose work at Weta Digital gave form and texture to the character Gollum, has returned to Middle-earth, now with a more advanced set of technological tools at his disposal.

headline: The End of Spider-Man (at Least for Now)
text: Comic book fans who pick up Issue No. 700 of “The Amazing Spider-Man,” which arrived in stores on Wednesday, will see what Marvel Comics is promising as the final fight between Spider-Man and his longtime nemesis Dr. Octopus. The end result has the villain taking over the hero’s mind, body, costume and mission. Dr. Octopus, who is convinced he can do a better job than Peter Parker’s alter ego, begins his adventures as the wall-crawling hero in “The Superior Spider-Man,” the first issue of which will be available Jan. 9.

headline: Reminder: Campaign Finance Donor Search Will Be Deprecated
text: If you’re a regular user of the presidential donor information returned by our Campaign Finance API, don’t forget: that request type will be deprecated this Friday, Dec. 28. We won’t be creating a new version; we’re removing the data from our servers completely. Please update your code, and leave a comment if you have questions or concerns.

headline: Storm Weakened a Fragile System for Mental Care
text: When a young woman in the grip of paranoid delusions threatened a neighbor with a meat cleaver one Saturday last month, the police took her by ambulance to the nearest psychiatric emergency room. Or rather, they took her to Beth Israel Medical Center, the only comprehensive psychiatric E.R. functioning in Lower Manhattan since Hurricane Sandy shrank and strained New York’s mental health resources.

headline: Even in a Lockout Year, Rangers Raise a Banner
text: The N.H.L. lockout has derailed a lot of plans, like teams celebrating last season’s accomplishments at their home openers.

headline: ‘Crowdfunding’ Rules Are Unlikely to Meet Deadline
text: When the Jobs Act became law in April, supporters proclaimed a new era for small businesses seeking to raise money.

headline: Image of the Day: Dec. 26
text: Narendra Modi sworn in as Gujarat’s chief minister for the fourth time.

headline: RocketHub Ponders Its Future in Crowdfunding
text: We have published a story about why the Securities and Exchange Commission has struggled to write the rules that will carry out equity crowdfunding for small businesses. One company that has been at the forefront of the effort to influence those rules is RocketHub, a donation- and rewards-based crowdfunding site based in New York. Itself a small business, RocketHub debuted in 2010 and now has about 10 employees, including its four founders — but is still viewed as one of the largest American crowdfunding platforms.

headline: Your Best Meal of 2012, New York Edition
text: We asked you to tweet your favorite meal of the year using the hashtag #bestmeal2012, and received so many responses that we’ve split the highlights into two categories to feature here on Diner’s Journal. First up are New York City places, some of which you’ll also find on Pete Wells’s list of the best new restaurants of the year. Restaurants that are further afield will be gathering in a post this afternoon. Tell us your #bestmeal2012 by tweeting us at @nytdining.

headline: Video: A Red Hook Church Rebounds After Hurricane
text: In Red Hook, Brooklyn, people attended Christmas Mass at Visitation Church, which has experienced a resurgence since Hurricane Sandy.

headline: Syrian General Whose Task Was Halting Defections Flees
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Syria’s government suffered an embarrassing new setback as the top general responsible for preventing defections within the military became a defector himself, making what insurgents described on Wednesday as a daring back-roads escape by motorcycle across the border into Turkey.

headline: Exploring the Roots of an Emerging Planet-Spanning ‘Mind’
text: I’m grateful to Krista Tippett, the host of the captivating public radio program “On Being,” for including me in an exploration of the present-day resonance of “noosphere,” the concept of an emerging global intelligence shaped in the early 20th century by Pierre Teilhard de Chardin, a French Jesuit priest, philosopher and paleontologist (with others). You can read two of Teilhard’s most influential books touching on this concept — “The Phenomenon of Man” and “The Future of Man” — online.

headline: Every Bird Counts, but Some Make the Heart Beat Faster
text: Binoculars at the ready, a small group of birders fanned out through the field, searching for a brown-and-gray bird that was stubbornly refusing to show itself.

headline: Senator Daniel K. Akaka in the Roll Call
text: Senator Daniel K. Akaka's name can be heard in the roll call vote for the Affordable Care Act.

headline: Senator Daniel K. Akaka
text: Senator Daniel K. Akaka’s name can be heard in the roll call for a vote to authorize the use of United States military force against Iraq in October 2002.

headline: Nine Ski Apps to Make the Most of the Mountain
text: Headed to the mountains for the holidays? Here are nine ski-friendly apps that will help you make the most of your trip.

headline: Only Known Leo Motorcycle to Be Auctioned
text: LAS VEGAS — The recent discovery of the only known example of a Leo motorcycle, which is scheduled to be auctioned here Jan. 10 by Bonhams, raises more questions than answers.

headline: Grim Prognosis for a 60-Ton Whale Stranded on a Beach in Queens
text: Updated, 12:56 p.m. Thursday | The whale has died. See latest post.

headline: When Going Solo Is Not the Goal
text: A NEWSPAPER. Gum. A bottle of water.

headline: Author of Twitter Account Isn’t Philip Roth
text: 12:33 p.m. | Updated

headline: Catching the Sights, Not the Bugs
text: Friends and family so often asked Dr. Charles E. Davis, a specialist in microbiology and infectious disease, how to avoid getting sick when they travel abroad, he decided to put all of his advice in one place. The result is “The International Traveler’s Guide to Avoiding Infections,” released this year by Johns Hopkins University Press. Below are edited excerpts with Dr. Davis in a discussion about precautions international travelers should take before and after trips to far-flung destinations.

headline: In Soccer as in Life, Will a Resurgent Germany Dominate a Weakened Europe?
text: Our colleague Nicholas Kulish has written a year-end sports piece sure to get folks thinking. “The resurgence of German soccer began, like the country’s economic comeback, after a long slide toward stagnation amid dire prophecies of impending irrelevance,” Nick writes.

headline: What’s On Wednesday
text: 4 P.M. (AMC) CASINO (1995) Martin Scorsese directs this crime drama based on the nonfiction book by Nicholas Pileggi that follows Ace Rothstein (Robert De Niro), a gambling savant hired by the Mafia to run a casino in Las Vegas in the 1970s and to ensure that the bosses back home always receive a piece of the profits. His muscle is Nicky Santoro (Joe Pesci), whose criminal activities and proclivity for violence spiral out of control. “Mr. Pileggi, Mr. De Niro and Mr. Pesci, all ‘Goodfellas’ alumni, are back in familiar capacities, joining Mr. Scorsese to do what they do best,” Janet Maslin wrote in The New York Times. “But,” she added, “ ‘Casino’ also has a new ingredient in Sharon Stone,” above with Mr. De Niro, “who will be nobody’s idea of Hollywood fluff after this spectacular, emblematic performance. As Ginger McKenna, a gorgeous hustler who falls from the ranks of Vegas’s royalty to its lowest depths, she represents the full range of this film’s stark extremes.” Ms. Stone, above with Mr. De Niro, received an Oscar nomination.

headline: Senator Lieberman's Farewell
text: On the eve of his retirement, Senator Joseph Lieberman reflects on his political career and the proper role of bipartisanship.

headline: Worried About Taxes, Some Consumers Cut Back
text: As time ticks away for a resolution to the so-called fiscal cliff mess, some consumers aren’t taking any chances.

headline: Game Theory: Considering Video Games as Ballet
text: Like Lucy, when I write and think about video games, I try to focus on what the medium can do that the canonical arts — books, movies, theater, dance, music, television, painting, sculpture, comics, whatever — cannot. But I think it’s also worth emphasizing how video games resemble the culturally accepted arts. They’re more alike than different.  In 2012, I started reading a couple of books — one new, the other newish — about the history of other art forms, and their infancies would be very familiar to gamers.

headline: Business Travelers in Haiti Will Have a New Marriott
text: Digicel, the telecommunications giant, and Marriott International recently broke ground on a $45 million hotel in Port-au-Prince, Haiti, that is to open in early 2015.

headline: Sneaking Back, From Out of Nowhere
text: JEAN-LOUIS TRINTIGNANT has been, for better than half a century, one of the great stealth actors of the movies. He knows how to catch an audience unaware.

headline: Fire Hits World Trade Center Construction Trailers
text: A fire at the World Trade Center construction site damaged three construction trailers on Wednesday but did not affect any buildings and injured no one, the authorities said.

headline: Outcry Over Newspaper’s Map of Handgun Permit Holders
text: 8:45 p.m. | Updated In the days after the Connecticut school killings, a newspaper in nearby Westchester County, N.Y., decided to respond by publishing the names and addresses of handgun permit holders in its readership area. The newspaper, The Journal News, said that informing people about legal weapons in their neighborhoods was a public service.

headline: No Questions on N.R.A. Plan, but Plenty of Comments
text: The National Rifle Association didn’t take any questions at its news conference last Friday, announcing its National School Shield program to have armed guards in every school. But there were plenty of harsh words on Twitter, many from celebrities — even those not included in the “Demand a Plan” video that has gotten millions of YouTube views.

headline: How to Read Like a Staff Writer Who Writes About Everything
text: Susan Dominus recently wrote for the magazine about dieting in France, a mysterious case of twitching teens and the woman who took the fall for JPMorgan Chase.

headline: Senators to Return With 5 Days Left and No Clear Fiscal Path
text: WASHINGTON — With just five days left to make a deal, President Obama and members of the Senate were set to return to Washington on Thursday with no clear path out of their fiscal morass even as the Treasury Department warned that the government will soon be unable to pay its bills unless Congress acts.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Protecting Medical Records and Santa’s Naughty List
text: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. See more here.

headline: How Much Is That Pop Star in the Window?
text: An older singing star, past her prime, walks into an empty, down-home radio station, the place where it all began. The janitor assumes she’s just another visitor. She reflects on how she got her start, became a star and lost something along the way.

headline: Quirks of the Game: N.B.A. Schedule Short-Circuits Rivalries
text: When the Knicks beat the Brooklyn Nets, 100-97, on Dec. 11 on a Jason Kidd 3-pointer it seemed like the battle for the city had just gone up a notch. “The N.B.A. has to be loving this,” Knicks Coach Mike Woodson said after the game.

headline: In Performance: Brandon J. Dirden
text: Brandon J. Dirden as Boy Willie in the Signature Theater’s revival of August Wilson’s “Piano Lesson.”

headline: New Year’s in Times Square Goes Digital
text: TimesCast Media+Tech: Song apps to keep the party going. | A conversation with Allure’s 85-year-old plastic surgery editor, Joan Kron. | A look at the social media tied to the ball drop.

headline: Potent Winter Storm Moves East After Pouncing on Wide Area of the Country
text: A powerful winter storm that spawned tornadoes in the Deep South and brought Christmas Day snow to Dallas moved east on Wednesday, bringing blizzard conditions in Indiana and Ohio, severe thunderstorms to the Southeast and snow, driving rain, high winds and travel snarls to the Northeast.

headline: Car Buyers Lack Interest in Electric Cars, Study Says
text: Mainstream car shoppers are simultaneously ignorant and apathetic about plug-in electric vehicles. That’s the essential finding of a new study from the Indiana University School of Public and Environmental Affairs. The study, which is based on a survey of 2,300 adult drivers in 21 large American cities in fall 2011, is a snapshot of driver sentiment 18 months ago.

headline: NBC’s Display of a 30-Shot Gun Magazine Prompts a Police Inquiry
text: WASHINGTON — The Metropolitan Police Department said on Wednesday that it had opened an investigation into whether NBC and David Gregory, the host of “Meet the Press,” broke the law when Mr. Gregory displayed a high-capacity gun magazine during an interview on Sunday with the vice president of the National Rifle Association.

headline: How the Cloud Changes Software Consulting
text: Moving to the cloud isn’t just changing the way businesses work by adding more collaboration. It changes the consulting businesses that actually sell most of the software used by business.

headline: Words Well Worth a Picture
text: Screenplay excerpts from “Argo,” “Moonrise Kingdom,” “Silver Linings Playbook” and “This is 40.”

headline: Hidden Passions, Visible in Clothes
text: THE shock of infidelity among the aristocracy of 19th-century Russia was the theme of Tolstoy’s “Anna Karenina.” So while audacious, it makes a certain kind of sense that the director Joe Wright’s film adaptation (written by Tom Stoppard) would be so willfully unfaithful to the book, let alone to the fashions of the day. Can you believe that Anna? Who does she think she is, flaunting about in all that Chanel jewelry before Coco was even born? Actually, what the lead characters wear in this telling has less to do with Cossack hats and astrakhan than with a style all its own — one based primarily in the extravagantly feminine lines of 1950s couture, reflecting a different period of promise. Think of Balenciaga, not Bolshoi

headline: On Thursday, a Bowl Date; After That, Uncertainty
text: As the ball traced an arc toward the sideline, and the clock ticked down, college football seemed to hold its breath.

headline: Scene City
text: A sold-out reunion party for Bar d’O in New York City.

headline: Carrying a Torch for Bar d’O
text: ALL sorts of crazy things happen when the drag performer Joey Arias does a show. During much of the 1990s, Mr. Arias presided over a Weimar-esque show at Bar d’O, a lounge on Bedford Street where he performed in various states of undress and seemed to channel Billie Holiday from beyond the grave.

headline: Our Best Holiday Tech Gifts
text: 11:24 a.m. | Updated with more tech gifts.

headline: The Gift of After-Hours Medical Care
text: A new study shows that people who have after-hours access to their doctor use the emergency room less.

headline: Tiger Cubs on the Prowl in Russia’s Far East, and Elsewhere
text: The Wildlife Conservation Society is reporting that this year has seen significant progress in safeguarding tigers and some of their last havens in Russia, Thailand and India — three countries where the endangered species still has a solid base from which populations could expand if protections increase. The organization today released this image, taken by an automated camera last year in eastern Siberia.

headline: Newly Released Books
text: In this month’s new novels, characters fight against significant barriers to emotional connection. A young woman falls in love with a suicidal quadriplegic, a troubled brother and sister build a secret life, and a bitter old man turns vampiric to put a spring back in his step.

headline: Hedge Fund Seeks Ouster of SandRidge Energy’s Board
text: A New York hedge fund filed papers with federal securities regulators on Wednesday seeking to oust the board at SandRidge Energy, the latest salvo in its continuing campaign against the struggling Oklahoma City oil and gas company.

headline: The Soundtrack to Your Life, With a Stream of Discoveries
text: Gone is the heyday of the vinyl record. The cassette tape is all but forgotten. Even the CD is losing its relevance; my children are amused by the idea that a little silver disc has music on it.

headline: Pogie Awards for the Brightest Ideas of 2012
text: Good evening, and welcome to The Dalles, Ore.! Here in the cafetorium of the James A. Garfield Middle School, we meet every year for the biggest event in technology: the Pogie awards!

headline: FreshDirect Goes Dark After a Domain Name Glitch
text: It was a blue Christmas for FreshDirect, the Long Island City-based company that delivers groceries to homes throughout New York City and its suburbs. For a significant chunk of the holiday, visitors to the company’s Web site reported finding only a generic placeholder for sites whose domain names are out of date — or out of whack.

headline: Compromising Dolls and Pink Panthers
text: “A New Novel,” the current exhibition at Luxembourg & Dayan gallery, is not for the squeamish. The upper floors of the gallery’s town house on East 77th Street in Manhattan contain several dioramalike installations inhabited by stuffed doll figures who, to judge from all the pills and drug paraphernalia strewed around, have been on an extended binge.

headline: Near Tokyo, a Minimalist House on a Mountain Slope
text: A two-bedroom crescent-shaped house outside Tokyo is on the market for $2.1 million.

headline: House Hunting in ... Japan
text: MINIMALIST HOUSE WITH MOUNT FUJI VIEWS OUTSIDE TOKYO

headline: Looking for Opportunity Where Few Others Invest
text: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia — Investors started poking around for deals here five years ago, as the war-torn country began to move past its legacy of genocide and coups. When the global financial crisis struck, Cambodia’s fast-growing economy crashed and the dollars flowing from abroad evaporated.

headline: Homes for $1.5 Million
text: Properties in Atlanta, New Hampshire and New Mexico.

headline: What You Get for ... $1.5 Million
text: ATLANTA

headline: CDs Know That Ears Have Eyes
text: MOST of us think we know where fine art roosts: museums, galleries, studios, maybe the stray subway car. But one of the more unexpected places to find striking, thought-provoking art, year in and year out, is on the album covers of ECM Records.

headline: A Little Extra Power When You Need It
text: Smartphones are convenient, until they run out of power. To help provide an extra jolt of juice, MyCharge has introduced a line of rechargeable power banks that are compatible with a variety of devices.

headline: Photo Replay: Dec. 26
text: A view of the day in sports, including Premier League soccer and cyclo-cross in Belgium.

headline: Light Reading: How the Kindle Paperwhite Works
text: Amazon and Barnes & Noble added lighting systems to their newest readers, the Kindle Paperwhite and the Nook Simple Touch, to make it easier for people to read in the dark.

headline: Tasting Fame Again, Tweet by Tweet
text: IN the 1990s, Sally Jessy Raphael was the doyenne of daytime television, a bespectacled redhead whose mild, auntish mien belied the sensational tabloid fodder that her syndicated talk show was built upon.

headline: The Curator of the ‘Brooklyn Look’
text: THIS is probably the understatement of the year, but the time when the phrase “Brooklyn look” at best conjured Tony Manero’s white pantsuit is long past. For one thing, the look is decidedly feminine. For another, it’s more about day-to-day coping and nesting than peacocklike display.

headline: Pasolini’s Legacy: A Sprawl of Brutality
text: “It is only at our moment of death that our life, to that point undecipherable, ambiguous, suspended, acquires a meaning.” So said the filmmaker Pier Paolo Pasolini in a 1967 interview. The idea that death defines a person has seldom been more vividly illustrated than in the case of Pasolini, whose extraordinary life and work are invariably seen through the prism of his gruesome end.

headline: Her Story, Give or Take a Few Lines
text: IN her modernist Upper East Side co-op, Joan Kron talks enthusiastically about new ideas she has for Allure magazine, where she is an editor-at-large covering her chosen subject, plastic surgery. She wants to turn a couple into documentaries, a storytelling technique she picked up after recently auditing a film class. After a recent knee surgery, she looks forward to regularly climbing back into her favorite pair of black kitten-heeled Jimmy Choo’s.

headline: Your Best Meals of 2012, International Edition
text: A few hours ago we published a selection of your #bestmeal2012 tweets that was limited to meals eaten in New York City. (Pete Wells’s list of the best new restaurants in New York this year can be found here.) The tweets below name restaurants scattered far beyond the five boroughs.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Nigeria and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Nigeria, Syria and Mexico.

headline: East of the East River, Room for Competition
text: Compared with a decade ago, when Bird largely flew solo, many upscale Brooklyn boutiques now compete for coveted brands.

headline: Dynamic Former Netanyahu Aide Shifts Israeli Campaign Rightward
text: JERUSALEM — Naftali Bennett is not a serious contender to be Israel’s next prime minister. He has never held elective office, and the faction he represents currently fills five or seven of Parliament’s 120 seats, depending on how you count.

headline: A Widow Finds That Debt Is a Stubborn Companion
text: One song is about a man giving up cigarettes too late in life. Another consists of a teenager lying to her parents about the plot to “My Friend Irma Goes West,” a Martin and Lewis comedy, because she didn’t go to the movies at all but has been in a parked car with her boyfriend. (Mom and Dad buy the lie.) And then there are lines like, “No one absolves failure.”

headline: Coca Licensing Is a Weapon in Bolivia’s Drug War
text: TODOS SANTOS, Bolivia — There is nothing clandestine about Julián Rojas’s coca plot, which is tucked deep within acres of banana groves. It has been mapped with satellite imagery, cataloged in a government database, cross-referenced with his personal information and checked and rechecked by the local coca growers’ union. The same goes for the plots worked by Mr. Rojas’s neighbors and thousands of other farmers in this torrid region east of the Andes who are licensed by the Bolivian government to grow coca, the plant used to make cocaine.

headline: Art Larsen, Quirky Tennis Champion, Dies at 87
text: Art Larsen, a national tennis champion whose career was marked by eccentricity and cut short by a motor scooter accident that nearly killed him, died on Dec. 7 in San Leandro, Calif. He was 87.

headline: Improving Working Conditions at Foxconn
text: The Fair Labor Association assesses and monitors labor practices at manufacturing plants and recommends improvements. After Apple joined in January, the F.L.A. inspected three huge Foxconn factories in China that make iPads, iPhones and other devices. Inspectors identified 360 specific remediations to address a host of issues. In an August report, the F.L.A. said Foxconn had carried out 284 of those improvements.

headline: Shimmer and Clatter and Howls and Grunts
text: When the New York Philharmonic introduced Contact!, a new and much-needed contemporary-music concert series, in December 2009, the initial thrust was on freshly composed works, largely by Americans. In subsequent seasons Contact! lost focus as older pieces and European composers came to dominate the mix, even if the reasons were understandable.

headline: The Whole Nine Yards About a Phrase’s Origin
text: When people talk about “the whole nine yards,” just what are they talking about?

headline: Toyota Agrees to Settle Lawsuit Tied to Accelerations
text: DETROIT — Toyota Motor agreed on Wednesday to pay more than $1 billion to settle a class-action lawsuit related to issues of unintended acceleration in its vehicles.

headline: Daring With Makeup for New Year’s Eve
text: A few techniques to try to dazzle the holiday parties.

headline: SportAccord World Mind Games in Beijing
text: On many bridge deals one side usually makes a mistake that benefits the opponents. But occasionally both sides play well, as in the diagramed deal from the individual event at the second SportAccord World Mind Games in Beijing this month. It was an excellent battle between West, Disa Eythorsdottir of Huntsville, Ala., and South, Nevena Senior from England.

headline: A General Battles His Own Army
text: According to Fred Kaplan’s new book about Gen. David H. Petraeus and his attempt to re-envision American military strategy, the general had a philosophy about publicity. “I have a ‘Front Page of The Washington Post’ rule,” he told attendees at a counterinsurgency field manual workshop in 2006. “If you don’t want to see something on the front page of The Washington Post, then don’t do it, don’t say it.”

headline: Bolivia Makes Inroads Toward Reducing Coca Production
text: The nation is trying a nontraditional approach to eradicating coca production without violence and without the United States.

headline: In Italy, Shantytowns of Refugees Reflect Paradox on Asylum
text: ROME — The abandoned university building on the outskirts of Rome, colloquially known as Salaam Palace, was once a sparsely populated makeshift shelter where new arrivals from Africa — fleeing war, persecution and economic turmoil — squatted to create their own refuge.

headline: Scouting Report
text: EVENTS

headline: Shopping Snapshots: Dec. 27
text: Four questions for Colleen Sherin, the senior fashion director of Saks Fifth Avenue; Prism, a popular line of sunglasses and swimwear from London, has added handbags; some favorite essentials for a beach-side sojourn.

headline: Tapping Into Parisian Luxury
text: Pierre-Yves Rochon originally designed the Perle faucet for the honeymoon suite at the Four Seasons Hotel Georges V in Paris (he was the interior designer who oversaw the property’s renovation). At a glance, it looks elegant but not particularly flashy. Then you notice the crystal “droplets” covering the faucet’s spout and handles. Rarely has so much bling been used without garish effect. “I was thinking about how, when it rains, drops of water attach to glass on a window,” Mr. Rochon said.

headline: George Nelson Pieces Once Again Meet Their Market
text: By George, they’re back. So-called Miniature chests, designed for Herman Miller by George Nelson, were introduced in 1954. The dainty pieces, which rest on aluminum bases, stayed in production until 1963 — a time when the company was abandoning residential furniture to focus on its office business. Miller has twice tried to revive the Japanese-inspired goods: once in 1994, when it reintroduced its home collection (they failed to sell), and again in 2005 (the chests were made in Asia, and the poor quality of the craftsmanship ultimately doomed the project). Bringing the chests back “is one of my favorite examples of doing the right thing,” said Ben Watson, creative director of Herman Miller, who is resurrecting a number of forgotten items from the company’s archives. This time around, the chests are made in the United States and have the same hand-fitted drawers as the originals. They are available in a wide range of solid woods with white or black metal pulls. The six-drawer chest is $2,809, the nine-drawer chest, $3,192; the optional base, $418. Information: hermanmiller.com/collection or (616) 654-3000.

headline: Making Anyone Feel Beautiful
text: “YOU can sit down, you know,” Veronica Webb told a model who was waiting to be photographed in a cardigan and T-shirt that Ms. Webb had designed. The outfit was part of her first fashion collection, which goes on sale today as an exclusive to the social shopping site OpenSky.

headline: An Architectural Model Maker Is Happy to Shrink Your Home
text: Michael DelPriore of Ryerson Studio makes free-standing, eerily lifelike models of houses, commercial spaces and city parks. With computer programs like AutoCAD available, you might assume that physical models, built shingle by shingle, are passé. But Mr. DelPriore, 56, still does a brisk business, usually for architects, who use his little buildings in client presentations. Recently he opened his practice to commissions from the general public. Now anyone willing to spend upward of $10,000 can have a doll-size version of a real or imagined dream home. From his workplace in Kingston, N.Y., he spoke to a reporter about translating mansions into minis.

headline: Clean Your Plate, if Only to Admire It
text: A new plate is helping to modify eating habits. Control plates, produced by Slim & Sage, are nine inches in diameter and designed with a pattern easily divided into quarters. Two of the quarters are for vegetables; the others for lean proteins and grains.

headline: Why Isn’t This Man Smiling?
text: A HALLMARK of pop art is taking a ubiquitous but overlooked totem of capitalist enterprise and reinventing it. Andy Warhol had the Campbell’s soup can. Claes Oldenburg had the lipstick tube. Nate Lowman, 33, has his: the smiley face.

headline: A Shop That Frames a World of Embroidery
text: Coral & Tusk is a fantastical world of embroidery, with creatures and feathers stitched on napkins, pillows and even gift cards. The force behind the thread is Stephanie Housley, 37, a textile designer who started the company five years ago. “I come from a long line of Appalachian women who did loads of hand work,” she said. “My grandma could make a doll or toy out of anything.” There are plenty of dolls in this 1,200-square-foot space in South Williamsburg, Brooklyn. All began as Ms. Housley’s hand drawings, which she scans, then redraws stitch by stitch in a computer file. The files are sent to India to be machine embroidered, but thanks to Ms. Housley’s method, the finished goods are quirky, with perfectly imperfect stitching that makes each piece look hand-made. Prices range from $10 for a felt charm to $230 for a floor cushion. 109 South Fifth Street (Bedford Avenue), Room 401, Brooklyn; coralandtusk.com or (718) 388-4188.

headline: All of ABC Carpet and Mxyplyzyk on Sale
text: Mxyplyzyk will close its doors at the end of this week, ending 22 years of supplying the West Village with decorative objects. The store’s entire inventory will be up to 50 percent off through Friday; 125 Greenwich Avenue (13th Street), mxyplyzyk.com or (212) 989-4300.

headline: Market Ready
text: Q. I recently bought expensive kitchen appliances. Should I take them with me when I sell?

headline: Best Pop Shows of 2012
text: The pop and jazz critics of The New York Times recall some of their favorite live events of of the year.

headline: Shopping for Calendars
text: Roger Fawcett-Tang, a graphic artist, goes shopping for calendars of the perpetual variety.

headline: Calendars
text: THE world did not end last week, as some had feared it would. But the year will certainly end next week, which means users of old-school analog calendars will need to start anew.

headline: In the London Suburbs, a Home Rebuilt Around a View
text: One glimpse of an unbroken view of sloping farmland was enough to convince a family of their future home’s potential.

headline: Back to Broadway to Play Dress-Up
text: ON a rare morning when rain threatens in Los Angeles, the mist swirls down into the canyon where Albert Wolsky, the veteran costume designer, opens his door for a visitor. Just a few days after his 82nd birthday, he is back at home after finishing up his work on the revival of “The Heiress,” currently playing on Broadway.

headline: Pop’s Big Nights
text: A concert is always more than just a rendering of songs. It’s a musical revamp, a real-time test, a spectacle, a pop-up community, perhaps a dance party or an incipient riot — and, even in the YouTube era, an ephemeral, site-specific experience. Here the pop and jazz critics of The New York Times recall some of their favorite live events of 2012, in order of importance. JON PARELES

headline: Bringing the Countryside Indoors
text: WHEN Sue and David Black first laid eyes on their home 11 years ago, it was potential they saw, not charm.

headline: If You’re Tired of Instagram, Here Are Some Alternatives
text: Instagram has backpedaled furiously from its apparent effort to own all the photographs posted on its site.  But if you are looking for an alternative anyway, there are some.

headline: Kicking a Movie-a-Day Habit, After Four Years in Theaters
text: With the new year approaching, people resolve to kick all sorts of bad habits. Sam Barron is no different – he vows to try to kick his four-year habit of chronic cinema addiction.

headline: An Appetite for Weight Management Tools
text: WHEN I received the results of a routine cholesterol test this summer, I was certain there had been some kind of mistake. I’m young, unstressed and healthy, or so I imagined. I work out, too, and most impartial observers — and some partial ones — would describe me as lean. Plus, I eat a nutritious diet, I swear. So why did my LDL levels surpass my I.Q. — or, for that matter, Einstein’s?

headline: Buffing Up the Butler
text: CAN housework help you live longer? A New York Times blog post by Gretchen Reynolds last month cited research linking vigorous activity, including housework, and longevity. The study, which tracked the death rates of British civil servants, was the latest in a flurry of scientific reports crediting domestic chores with health benefits like a lowered risk for breast and colon cancers. In one piquant study published in 2009, researchers found that couples who spent more hours on housework had sex more frequently (with each other) though presumably not while vacuuming. (The report did not specify.)

headline: ‘Untamed Motorization’ Wraps an Indian City in Smog
text: NEW DELHI — When an acrid blanket of gray smog settled over India’s capital last month, environmentalists warned of health hazards, India’s Supreme Court promised action and state officials struggled to understand why the air had suddenly gone so bad.

text: It was 15 years ago that Ted Turner needed something interesting to say in a speech — and decided, in a rush, to give away $1 billion.

headline: South Africa: Mandela Is Released From the Hospital
text: Nelson Mandela, South Africa’s former president, was released from the hospital late Wednesday, ending a 19-day hospital stay. Mr. Mandela, 94, has been in frail condition for several years. He retired from public life in 2004 and was last seen publicly in 2010, though he receives frequent visits from old friends. He was hospitalized on Dec. 8 and treated for a lung infection; he also had surgery to remove gallstones, government officials said. Mac Maharaj, a spokesman for South Africa’s current president, Jacob Zuma, said that Mr. Mandela would be staying at home in a suburb of Johannesburg and receiving high-level care there. Mr. Mandela was elected in South Africa’s first fully democratic elections in 1994.

headline: Giants’ Shift Highlights Linebackers’ Struggles
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — When the Giants’ linebackers walked into their meeting room one day last week, a universal feeling of surprise quickly spread. Instead of seeing the customary three-linebacker starting lineup that the team used nearly all season, the players saw on their sheets that the Giants were planning to use a different setup against the Baltimore Ravens, one that had four linebackers, including several second-year players, on the field together.

headline: M.T.A. Challenges the City Over Billboard Restrictions
text: For decades the Metropolitan Transportation Authority has subsidized subway and bus fares by selling advertising space on billboards affixed to its elevated train trestles and to the stilts towering over its railroad yards and tracks.

headline: From Tehran to the B Train
text: When I moved to New York City two years ago, I asked my friends here which neighborhood was the safest. “You’ll be fine wherever you live,” they assured me.

headline: Poaching of Jungle Elephants Strikes Gabon
text: Once thought of as a model in protecting elephants from poachers, Gabon faces the same obstacles as other countries.

headline: In Gabon, Lure of Ivory Is Hard for Many to Resist
text: OYEM, Gabon — This lush country, often called a “forest republic,” used to stand proudly apart from its shaky neighbors, like the Democratic Republic of Congo and the Central African Republic, tropical disaster zones where state failure, rebel marauders and loose weapons conspired to spell doom for endangered wildlife.

headline: The Year in Questions
text: If, as Soren Kierkegaard believed, life is best understood backward, then the holidays are an ideal time to attempt to unravel the secrets of our age through an end-of-the-year quiz. Below are more than a hundred questions to ponder over a cup of coffee, with your feet up. For, as Kierkegaard also knew, “Far from idleness being the root of all evil, it is rather the only true good.” (Answers here.)

text: To the Editor:

text: OLYMPIA, Wash. — From the governor-elect on down, through both chambers of the Legislature, a tincture of blue political monoculture drifts through Washington State politics like mist through the pines.

headline: When Prayer Really Counts in Air Travel
text: The call to prayer, a five-times-a-day ritual for strict adherents to Islam, is reaching new heights in Iran.

headline: Hawaii’s Lieutenant Governor to Succeed Inouye
text: HONOLULU — Hawaii’s lieutenant governor, a rising political star here who is unknown on the national scene, will become the state’s next United States senator, filling a leadership vacuum in Honolulu and in Washington after the death of Senator Daniel K. Inouye last week.

headline: The Gun-Game Complex
text: In its bizarre response last week to the shootings in Newtown, Conn., the National Rifle Association heaped blame on “vicious, violent video games” for corrupting young Americans and called them the “filthiest form of pornography.” As it turns out, many of those very games have marketing relationships with the makers of firearms and ammunition, which are also big financial supporters of the N.R.A., through deals that appear to be designed to increase sales of their deadly wares.

headline: For Fire Victims in Upstate Ambush, a Chance to Grieve and Survey the Destruction
text: WEBSTER, N.Y. — The residents of a waterfront neighborhood in this western New York community returned on Wednesday to survey what little remained of their homes for the first time since a man set a fire that destroyed seven houses in a plot to lure and kill emergency responders.

headline: Egypt’s Flawed Constitution
text: Ideally, a new constitution in Egypt would unite citizens around a consensus vision for their country and set a firm foundation for a democratic transition. The Islamist-backed constitution that took effect this week has only exacerbated divisions and left millions of non-Islamists feeling disenfranchised, angry and determined to force changes in the document.

headline: In Sled Hockey, a Slower Pace but Hard Shots and Hits
text: NEWINGTON, Conn. — Back on her wheelchair and in the dressing room with her teammates, Sara Tabor said it had not been such a bad day on the ice. Her team, the Rangers, had lost twice, but she scored a goal after nearly bowling over a goaltender with her sled.

headline: What's 'Just Right' for the Young Reader?

headline: Fiscal Endgame
text: Just before the Christmas break, negotiations on the so-called fiscal cliff ended on an absurdist note. House Republicans not only rejected President Obama’s overly generous budget deal, including his offer to lift the income threshold for higher tax rates to $400,000 a year from $250,000, they also rejected their own leadership’s proposal to raise the threshold for higher taxes to $1 million and to preserve tax breaks for the heirs of multimillion-dollar estates.

headline: Morsi Admits ‘Mistakes’ in Drafting Egypt’s Constitution
text: CAIRO — President Mohamed Morsi of Egypt took responsibility on Wednesday for “mistakes” during the run-up to ratification of the new Constitution and urged Egyptians to appreciate the fierce disagreements about it as a “healthy phenomenon” of their new democracy.

headline: The N.R.A. at the Bench

headline: After 460 Starts, a War Horse’s Last Stand
text: Only four pacers born in the last 40 years have won more races than Tattler’s Jet, but last week it looked as if he, after 460 starts, might miss his final chance to win one more.

headline: Brad Corbett, Who Owned Texas Rangers, Dies at 75

headline: After Christmas, Returns and Relief
text: It is serenaded weeks before it arrives by radio stations and heralded by a monthlong parade of tinsel in nearly every store window in town. It is a date for which gift-givers have scrimped and saved, home cooks have basted and baked, and, perhaps underscoring its significance most of all, for which children have tried to behave.

headline: Yankees Add Insurance in the Outfield
text: The Yankees’ search for a right-handed-hitting outfielder has led them to the former Atlanta Braves outfielder Matt Diaz, who has agreed to a minor league deal with the team and will be invited to spring training, according to a baseball official who has knowledge of the agreement.

headline: Jury Awards $1.17 Billion in Patent Suit
text: Carnegie Mellon University said it was awarded $1.17 billion by a federal jury in Pittsburgh on Wednesday in a unanimous verdict that found the Marvell Technology Group had sold billions of semiconductors using technology developed at the university without a license.

headline: Sneakers and Hope for a Single Mother
text: The biggest clue might have been her right sneaker. The young mother had worn those Nikes every single day for six years, and now her big toe protruded through a hole in the front. As Faven Weinu walked through the rain or snow in Brooklyn, people would “freak out,” but she did not listen to them — she was, as she put it, “disconnected.”

headline: Doctors Warned on ‘Divided Loyalty’
text: WASHINGTON — With hospitals buying up medical practices around the country and seeking to make the most of their investment, the American Medical Association reached out to doctors this week to remind them that patient welfare must always come first and not be overridden by the economic interests of hospitals that now employ doctors in ever-growing numbers.

headline: Balneotherapy Locale
text: Administrivial Do-Gooder Fun Puzzle Alert! “Wordplay” star and debonair constructor-about-town Trip Payne has launched another fun puzzle extravaganza that you can help fund and enjoy. Kick in a little or a lot to enjoy his 12 interconnected puzzles that will be available for your solving pleasure in July of 2013. To find out more, click here.

headline: Elwood V. Jensen, Pioneer in Breast Cancer Treatment, Dies at 92
text: Elwood V. Jensen, a medical researcher whose studies of steroid hormones led to new treatments for breast cancer that have been credited with saving or extending hundreds of thousands of lives, died on Dec. 16 in Cincinnati. He was 92.
