text: The Rangers are a part of the Northeast Sled Hockey League, which holds five games one Sunday per month in Newington, Conn.

headline: Ray Collins of the Mothers of Invention Dies
text: Ray Collins, a singer whose dispute with one guitarist led him to hire another, Frank Zappa, with whom he went on to form the avant-garde rock group the Mothers of Invention, died on Dec. 24 in Pomona, Calif. He was in his middle 70s.

headline: Hobbled by Injuries, Knicks Win on Last Shot
text: PHOENIX — J. R Smith walked on the court and looked up at the scoreboard. It said the game was tied at 97-97, and Smith knew the ball — and the game’s biggest moment — was coming to him. Smith then closed his eyes and bowed his head. He meditated.

headline: Woman Hit by Bus Near Central Park Dies
text: A woman who was hit by a bus while crossing the street near Central Park has died, police said late Wednesday.

headline: Too Young to Have a Heart Attack
text: The foreshadowing escaped me: The night before we left for our summer vacation in Michigan, I accidentally stepped on my Kindle — which, like my heart, I cannot live without — and broke it. Reduced to reading novels on my iPhone, I made the best of it several days later, sitting in a sunroom overlooking Eight Point Lake, where my family gathers each year with friends.

headline: Prius Tops Consumer Reports List of Best New-Car Values
text: Consumer Reports released on Thursday its annual list of Best and Worst New-Car Values.

headline: Delhi Police Deploy Mimes Against Sexual Assault
text: How well Delhi’s police protect women, particularly from sexual attacks, has become an increasingly politicized issue after the Dec. 16 gang rape of a medical student on a moving bus. Protesters outraged over the crime, and the rise in reported rape cases in the city, have been calling for Delhi’s police commissioner, Neeraj Kumar, to step down.

headline: What’s On Thursday
text: NOON (FX) ENEMY OF THE STATE (1998) Will Smith, above, is Robert Clayton Dean, a model citizen who is framed for murder by a rogue government official (Jon Voight) and his team of agents in this conspiracy-filled fever dream, directed by Tony Scott. Gene Hackman is the grizzled retired government operative with the technological know-how who can help Robert clear his name. Janet Maslin, writing in The New York Times, said that while Mr. Scott, “has done popular culture no great favor by pioneering the Simpson-Bruckheimer school of empty but sensation-packed filmmaking, he now looks like a veritable Billy Wilder beside latter-day Top Gunners like Michael (‘Armageddon’) Bay.” She added, “As a grand old man of the thrill-happy genre, Mr. Scott gives this film a fine cast, a modicum of wit on the run and a reasonably human dimension.”

headline: Missing Syrian Official Discussed Defection in Twitter Dialogue, Activist Says
text: As my colleague Rick Gladstone reports, the recent disappearance of Syria’s Foreign Ministry spokesman, Jihad Makdissi, has been followed by unconfirmed reports about his possible defection.

headline: IHT Quick Read: Dec. 27
text: NEWS China began service Wednesday morning on the world’s longest high-speed rail line, from Beijing to Guangzhou — covering a distance in eight hours that is about equal to that from New York to Key West, Florida, or from London across Europe to Belgrade, Serbia. Keith Bradsher reports from Hong Kong.

headline: Prime Minister Singh Warns ‘Business as Usual’ Will Not Work
text: Prime Minister Manmohan Singh addressed a meeting of the National Development Council in New Delhi on Thursday. The meeting was called to finalize a draft of India’s 12th five-year plan (2012-17) that aims for faster, more inclusive and sustainable growth. Mr. Singh emphasized the need to improve gender inequality and said that “business as usual,” will not help achieve high economic growth.

headline: Capturing a Childhood Idyll in France
text: You’re piggybacking on your brother’s shoulders, the wind on your face as you run through the grass (below). You’re messy, climbing, hair astray. You’re belly-down on a swing. Flying.

headline: The S.E.C. at a Turning Point
text: Simon Johnson is the Ronald A. Kurtz Professor of Entrepreneurship at the M.I.T. Sloan School of Management and co-author of “White House Burning: The Founding Fathers, Our National Debt, and Why It Matters to You.”

headline: Squabbles in Garmsir
text: GARMSIR, Afghanistan — “You know, we’re very worried about the future,” Hamid Khan, the telecommunications director in Garmsir, southern Afghanistan, said to Major Thomas McAvoy, the civil affairs officer attached to Kilo Company, Third Battalion, Ninth Marine Regiment. “When Najibullah was president, he also had a plan to take control of the districts and build the government.”

headline: U.N. Envoy Calls for a Transitional Government in Syria
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Lakhdar Brahimi, the international envoy on a mission to Damascus seeking an end to the escalating civil conflict in Syria, said Thursday that a transitional government with full executive authority should be established, perhaps within months, and should rule the country until elections could be held.

headline: After Delhi Rape Victim Leaves India, Questions Raised About Media’s Role
text: On Wednesday night, the entrance of Safdarjung Hospital in New Delhi resembled a carnival, overrun with police officers, eager journalists and curious passersby.  At least two dozen television news vans were staked outside, awaiting the latest word on the condition of the 23-year-old woman who was gang-raped on a Delhi bus last week.

headline: Tebow Expresses Disappointment at Being Called Quitter

headline: The Invisible Ax – People, Profit and Progress on Humanity’s Planet

headline: Putin Signs Bill That Bars U.S. Adoptions, Upending Families
text: MOSCOW —  President Vladimir V. Putin signed a bill on Friday that bans the adoption of Russian children by American citizens, dealing a serious blow to an already strained diplomatic relationship. But for hundreds of Americans enmeshed in the costly, complicated adoption process, the impact was deeply personal.

headline: As Enigmatic as Her Picture
Thursday Reading: The Ultimate Housework Workout
text: Creating the ultimate housework workout, devices to monitor physical activity and eating, the best holiday tech gifts and other consumer-focused news from The New York Times.

headline: Japan Hints It May Revise an Apology on Sex Slaves
text: TOKYO — A top official hinted Thursday that Japan’s newly installed conservative government might seek to revise a nearly two-decade-old official apology to women forced into sexual slavery during World War II, a move that would most likely outrage South Korea and possibly other former victims of Japanese militarism.

headline: Stalemate in Washington Is Eroding Confidence of Consumers
text: For months, consumers have powered spending, while businesses pulled back ahead of the looming fiscal impasse in Washington. Now, as doubts grow about whether the president and Congress can reach a compromise before a year-end deadline, evidence has emerged that consumers, too, are becoming more pessimistic about the economy.

headline: Futurism and Policy
text: As regular readers have noticed, I’ve been spending a fair bit of time recently thinking about issues of long-term growth. Why? Partly just as a break from fiscal cliffery and the endless battle against dumb short-run macro. But it’s also true that the long run matters for policy: given how much public debate focuses on things like the state of Social Security or Medicare in the year 2040, it’s definitely worth trying to figure out what we know or don’t know about what our economy might look like in the year 2040.

headline: SeaWorld Files to Go Public
text: SeaWorld Entertainment, the Blackstone Group-controlled theme park operator famous for its killer whales, filed for an initial public offering on Thursday.

headline: Strong Sales for ‘Cat on a Hot Tin Roof’ With Scarlett Johansson
text: The Scarlett Johansson-led revival of “Cat on a Hot Tin Roof” is off to a strong start on Broadway, grossing $843,215 for its first seven preview performances last week – more money than any of the last three Broadway revivals of the play made in a single week, even after adjusting for inflation. Those revivals starred Anika Noni Rose (in 2008), Ashley Judd (2003) and Kathleen Turner (1990) in the role of Maggie, which Ms. Johansson is playing in the new production, whose box-office sales have benefited from the advent of premium ticket pricing of up to $175 a seat last week.

headline: The Best in Travel
text: From Nicaragua to China, T’s suggestions on what to see and do. See interactive feature >>

headline: Going Beyond Disney in Orlando
text: Quick, name five reasons to go to Orlando. Here are mine: Puerto Rican delicacies, alternative cinema, craft beer, African-American history and psychic readings.

headline: A Perp Walk of Outstanding New York Politicians
text: With 2012 just about over, we in New York have reason to hold heads high. We showed over the past year that we remain a leader when it comes to political corruption. It’s not easy staying at the top of your game. But we New Yorkers proved, once again, that we have what it takes.

headline: Daily Report: Changes Afoot at Electronics Factories in China
text: Shifts in how Apple deals with manufacturers like Foxconn have convinced executives at other electronics companies that they must also overhaul how they interact with foreign plants and workers, Keith Bradsher and Charles Duhigg report on Thursday in The New York Times. These changes may come at a cost to their bottom lines, though, analysts say, probably not so much as to affect consumer prices. As Apple and Foxconn became fodder for “Saturday Night Live” and questions during presidential debates in the last year, device designers and manufacturers concluded the industry’s reputation was at risk.

headline: As Swing Districts Dwindle, Can a Divided House Stand?
text: In 1992, there were 103 members of the House of Representatives elected from what might be called swing districts: those in which the margin in the presidential race was within five percentage points of the national result. But based on an analysis of this year’s presidential returns, I estimate that there are only 35 such Congressional districts remaining, barely a third of the total 20 years ago.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: The New York Daily News: Here come ol’ flattop — the Starbucks coffee cup — with a Lennon-ish message to help talk bickering lawmakers down off the fiscal cliff: “Come Together.” — Patrick Farrell

headline: Someone’s Mom Has Other Identities
text: FOR someone who pretty much worships Laurie Metcalf, Joe Mantello isn’t making her life easy in “The Other Place,” opening Jan. 10 on Broadway. “I used to leave the stage for a total of, like, 10 seconds,” Ms. Metcalf said of her experience in the show. “But we changed that.”

headline: E.P.A. Chief Set to Leave; Term Fell Shy of Early Hope
text: Lisa P. Jackson is stepping down as administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency after a four-year tenure that began with high hopes of sweeping action to address climate change and other environmental ills but ended with a series of rear-guard actions to defend the agency against challenges from industry, Republicans in Congress and, at times, the Obama White House.

headline: Capturing Climate Change Digitally
text: The changing palette of colors in a forest signals more than the arrival of a new season. For those who know how to look, the colors also reveal how much carbon dioxide the trees are absorbing from the atmosphere during photosynthesis, a new study suggests. By analyzing thousands of photographs of a forest canopy less than 40 miles outside London, the researchers were able to estimate carbon uptake over a two-year period based on the leaves’ hues.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Gun Laws May Trip Up NBC, and a Third Act for Some Stars
text: The Washington, D.C., police are investigating whether NBC and David Gregory, the anchor of “Meet the Press,” broke the district’s gun laws during an exclusive interview with Wayne LaPierre of the National Rifle Association, Michael S. Schmidt reported. Mr. Gregory brandished an empty magazine that can hold up to 30 bullets while asking Mr. LaPierre what harm would come from banning such equipment. However, in Washington, possessing even an empty magazine is against the law, and, according to the police, NBC asked for permission to display the magazine and was told that it could not. NBC has declined to comment on the matter.

headline: E.P.A. Chief to Step Down
text: After a tenure that began with bold initiatives but wound down with defensive maneuvers, Lisa P. Jackson is resigning as administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, John M. Broder reports. Her departure comes as many are questioning President Obama’s commitment to dealing with climate change and other environmental problems.

headline: Arnold Schwarzenegger: By the Book
text: The actor, former governor and author of the memoir “Total Recall” says today’s cleaned-up versions of Grimms’ fairy tales are nothing like the horror versions he read as a child.

headline: E-Book Reading Is Up, Study Says
text: “The printed page/ was just half a millennium’s brief wonder,” theorized John Updike in a late poem. Exactly when the old order will be completely overthrown is in some dispute, however.

headline: Things I Saw — No. 49
text: Suggestions for what you’d like Jason to see and draw may be sent to thingsisaw@nytimes.com.

headline: Four Tips for Taking Frosty Photos
text: As a beginning photographer, Mark Theriot’s best source of subjects were to be found at the nearby Mississippi River. “Having nothing else to shoot, it drove me outside,” he said. In time he developed into a noted outdoor photographer, specializing in pictures of birds, and especially eagles.

headline: Libraries See Opening as Bookstores Close
text: At the bustling public library in Arlington Heights, Ill., requests by three patrons to place any title on hold prompt a savvy computer tracking system to order an additional copy of the coveted item. That policy was intended to eliminate the frustration of long waits to check out best sellers and other popular books. But it has had some unintended consequences, too: the library’s shelves are now stocked with 36 copies of “Fifty Shades of Grey.”

headline: On the Block: 1956 Lancia Aurelia B24S Spider
text: It’s a groaner, but the story underlines how little exposure Americans have had to this revered European brand: A proud owner of a Lancia Aurelia pulled into a gas station and was asked, “What kind of car is that?”

headline: Betrayed While Asleep, Afghan Police Die at Hands of Their Countrymen
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — A wave of betrayal has left at least 17 Afghan policemen dead in the past 10 days — all killed in their sleep, at the hands of those close to them.

headline: For Dead Whale of Breezy Point, Necropsy and Beach Burial
text: Updated, 5:28 p.m. | On the windswept beach at Breezy Point on Thursday afternoon, the researcher cut a small, raw cube out of the side of the giant whale, deposited the morsel in a vial of formaldehyde and screwed the cap shut. It was a messy job.

headline: Thanks, Mom, for Not Telling the World I Pulled a Knife on You
text: I don’t remember what my mother and I were fighting about, but I do remember the moment when I pulled out a knife. I was 15, and we were arguing about something. As is often the case with adolescent fights, it was probably about something ridiculous, like my outfit.

headline: The Music They Made
text: A sound collage featuring a sampling of the musicians who died in 2012.

headline: The Music They Made
text: Welcome to the fifth annual installment of The Music They Made, a sound collage featuring the musicians who died in the past year. As in past versions, a few (entirely coincidental and random) themes emerged in the mix for 2012. We find a statistically improbable number of divas (Whitney, Etta, Donna, Chavela), two of the greatest soul bassists ever to record — and more sitar than you would expect, all of it sounding as fresh as the day it was played. The artists were young and old, famous and belatedly famous. You can play the full versions of the songs sampled above on Spotify.

headline: Hello, This Is Your Gift Card Calling
text: 4:38 p.m. Updated /  To add comment from GameStop.

headline: Another Day, Another Year-End List
text: In most parts of life, the calendar marks the passage of time, with the end of the year prompting people to pause and reflect on the year past, then resolve to make resolutions that won’t make it out of January. In journalism, the flipping of the calendar pages means only one thing: lists. And sports journalism is always right out there at the front of the pack of lists. Want the 12 surprising moments of the year in sports. Check. Breakout athletes of the year? How ‘bout 30 of them? A string of memories from the minds of a dozen or so of The Times’s writers? Got ‘em!

headline: City Hopes Money Grows From Fallen Trees
text: Talk about making lemonade out of lemons. Hurricane Sandy toppled hundreds of trees throughout the metropolitan area, including many in the New York City-owned watersheds along reservoirs in Westchester County. Instead of discarding the downed trees or burning them, the city is selling them.

headline: In Flurry of Activity, Only Muted Hope for Fiscal Deal
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama will meet with Congressional leaders on Friday, and House Republicans summoned lawmakers back for a Sunday session, in a last-ditch effort to avert a fiscal crisis brought on by automatic tax increases and spending cuts scheduled to hit next week.

headline: Image of the Day: Dec. 27
text: On a cold winter day in Allahabad, Uttar Pradesh, a vendor sells hot tea and milk.

headline: A Factory Upgrade
text: TimesCast: Bolivia’s unorthodox approach to the drug war. | Working conditions at China’s electronics factories examined firsthand.

headline: The Unfulfilled Promise of ‘Promised Land’
text: I recently attended a Manhattan screening of “Promised Land,” a new feature film written by and starring Matt Damon and John Krasinski that aims to examine America’s natural gas drilling boom as a case study in “what happens when real people and real money collide,” as Krasinski explained in publicity materials.

headline: Broadway to Pay Tribute to Charles Durning and Jack Klugman
text: Broadway theaters will honor two acclaimed actors on two consecutive evenings, dimming their lights at 8 p.m. on Thursday in memory of Charles Durning, and again at 8 p.m. on Friday in recognition of Jack Klugman, the Broadway League said on Thursday.

headline: Game Theory: The Awkward Adolescence of Gaming
text: Jenn, Chris, Stephen and Friends,

headline: Monitoring Mandela and the Soul of a Nation
text: PLETTENBERG BAY, South Africa – After almost three weeks of treatment for a recurrent lung infection, Nelson Mandela, the 94-year-old icon of South Africa’s triumph over apartheid, was discharged from a hospital late Wednesday. But a terse statement from his physicians saying he would not return immediately to his remote, rural home at Qunu in the Eastern Cape region raised questions that his family and associates sought to answer a day later.

headline: Rebels Are Advancing Toward Capital of Central African Republic
text: JOHANNESBURG — Rebels on Thursday inched closer to the capital of the Central African Republic, one of Africa’s most fragile states, threatening to topple an elected government that has had an unsteady grip on power for nearly a decade.

headline: Steinway Decides to Keep the Keys of Its Kingdom
text: The corporate owner of the piano maker Steinway & Sons says the company is no longer up for sale. In a news release issued Wednesday, the company – Steinway Musical Instruments Inc. – said that in July 2011 it began studying the possible sale of itself or its band instrument division. Several expressions of interest came in but the company decided against them. It also said it was shutting down a possible deal to sell the band unit to an investor group led by two board members.

headline: A ‘Sexual Musical,’ Now Middle-Aged
text: A FEW weeks ago The New York Times reported that the sexually frank 1974 musical revue “Let My People Come” will be revived this winter for eight Fridays at the Underground, a bar just south of Columbia University. According to the producer, John Forslund, the original lyrics and sketches will be revised and updated, and while the revival will feature “far less nudity than the original,” there will still be ample opportunity to see cast members, both male and female, in the buff.

headline: In Performance: Brandon J. Dirden of ‘The Piano Lesson’
text: August Wilson’s play “The Piano Lesson” is about a family at odds over the fate of an intricately carved piano with a multigenerational history. In this scene, Boy Willie, played by Brandon J. Dirden, explains why he wants to sell the instrument, much against the wishes of his sister. The play continues through Jan. 20 at the Signature Theater.

headline: Accountants Skirt Shareholder Lawsuits
text: The accountants who service publicly traded companies are likely to have something to be thankful for this year: shareholders are not filing federal securities fraud lawsuits against them.

headline: Speaking August Wilson’s Words Can Change You
text: “THE blue coats,” the actor Brandon J. Dirden whispered as he sat down for an interview in the cafeteria of The New York Times. Eating dinner at nearby tables were groups of uniformed workers who were catering an event that night. It was only a few years ago that Mr. Dirden wore the same ultramarine outfit, in the exact same building, dreaming of the stage instead of treading it.

headline: Three Mothers, One Bond
text: WE found out by text message. “Don’t get on the plane. The birth mother is unsure.”

headline: Future Inequality, According to the CBO
text: Aha: in its long-term assessment of Social Security (pdf), the CBO makes its assumptions explicit. Kudos to them for doing this, by the way; even if you disagree, it’s helpful to know how they arrive at their conclusions.

headline: Bolivia’s Unorthodox Approach
text: The Times’s William Neuman discusses how Bolivia’s experiment has led to a significant drop in coca plantings.

headline: Lenore Norman, a Quiet Force for Landmarks Preservation, Dies at 83
text: If you love New York City’s architectural heritage, you owe a debt of gratitude to Lenore Norman. Chances are, you didn’t know that. She would have been pleased.

headline: Where’s That Picasso? An App Can Help
text: For every interest, there is an app to help you find out where to enjoy it. Like cigars? Cigar Boss will tell you where to buy habaneros. Do you ski? There are too many guides to resorts to count. But art is a little harder to locate with your smartphone. It is this gap that the makers of the popular app Art Authority seek to fill. They have added a more location-focused app called Art Alert to steer you to famous works.

headline: Ingrates and Clumsy Guests
text: My husband and I have nine grandchildren ranging in age from 10 to 22. They are all wonderful. We live at a distance; so every year, we send each of them Christmas and birthday gifts. We love shopping for them and try to choose things they will enjoy. But we never hear a peep back. Not a single thank you. Ever. It’s as if the gifts disappear into a black hole. But isn’t commanding thanks awkward?

headline: For Rosemary’s Chef, Great White Whale Was an Octopus
text: As any great songwriter (Leonard Cohen, for example) can tell you, some songs arrive in the flash of a few inspiration-dense minutes, while others crawl toward completion over the course of many (often maddening) years.

headline: Gay Republicans Take Out Ad Criticizing Hagel
text: The White House may not be making any more announcements about President Obama’s new national security team this week, but that hasn’t stopped the anti-Chuck Hagel drumbeat.

headline: Obama Returns to Washington, With Bo
text: President Obama returned to the White House on Thursday to resume efforts to end a partisan impasse on a fiscal deal without his wife and daughters, who remain on vacation in Hawaii. His only companion: the family dog, Bo.

headline: Suddenly Reeling, the Nets Fire Their Coach
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — It was 30 months ago that the images rose in Midtown Manhattan, a blue-tinted mural of an international hip-hop icon and a Russian billionaire, under the audacious heading “The blueprint for greatness.”

headline: Bank C.E.O.’s on Thinning Ice
text: At least one of the three big bank chief executives to survive the financial crisis could be without a job by the end of 2013.

headline: Deep Down, He Wants to Help
text: “I’m not a bad guy,” Steve Butler insists, and one of the reasons “Promised Land” works is that he’s right. Played by Matt Damon (who wrote the screenplay with John Krasinski), Steve, a corporate predator who is also a true believer in his company’s cause, is both the apparent villain and a magnet for the audience’s sympathy.

headline: In Bronx Gym, Man Who Went Astray Leads Youths on Straight Path
text: On a recent night in the South Bronx, Fernando Laspina peeked out the front window of El Maestro and Juan Laporte’s Boxing Gym and saw a cold, steady rain falling on the dimly lighted, rugged streets of his troubled youth.

headline: Planning Obama's Second Inauguration
text: Senator Charles E. Schumer of New York discusses the preparations for President Obama's second inauguration on January 21, 2013.

headline: Instantly Yours, for a Fee
text: Ivy Wu did not immediately need the navy lace cocktail dress she ordered the other day. But when a representative from Shoptiques, an e-commerce site, arrived at her Midtown Manhattan office with the dress only hours after Ms. Wu, 26, had placed her order, “I was really impressed that it was here,” she said.

headline: Sanchez Is Back as Starter for Finale
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — A mere four months, not four epochs, have passed since Mark Sanchez had his finest game of the season, throwing three touchdown passes in a 48-28 victory against Buffalo that left the entire Jets organization giddy.

headline: ‘Cool Quilts’ in Prospect Park
text: The excitement of the youngest members of the Miser’s household, in the days and weeks leading up to Christmas, is a joy to behold. What’s not quite so wonderful, once the gifts have been unwrapped and assimilated, the food consumed and the tree disposed of, is the task of keeping those little minds and bodies occupied until school starts up again.

headline: A Stiletto Workout? It Can Be Done
text: “YOU’RE going to a stiletto class?” my husband balked. “That sounds like a lawsuit waiting to happen.”

headline: Flooding Is ‘Worse Than Normal’ in Storm-Hit Communities in New Jersey
text: Storm weary coastal communities in southern New Jersey awoke to more flooding on Thursday, with high tide bringing waters that lapped the bumpers of fire trucks and sent debris and at least one refrigerator floating down submerged streets.

headline: Instagram Flap Shows Confusion Over Control of Content
text: The ruckus (now lawsuit) over whether Instagram would use your pictures to make money has drawn new attention to an unresolved battle of the Web era: Who owns your stuff online?

headline: A Pay Cut for Tim Cook? Not Really
text: This year, Apple became the most highly valued public company in history and generated $156.5 billion in revenue — nearly 50 percent more than in 2011. So how much did Timothy D. Cook, the company’s chief executive, take home?

headline: Drinking, Driving, Teenagers and New Year’s Eve
text: “If they’re old enough to serve in the military, they should be old enough to drive.”

headline: Tap Served With Brass Punch
text: Maurice Hines can’t stop moving. Even when relatively stationary from the waist up, this effusively good-natured dancer, choreographer and singer, who recently turned 69, shuffles his feet, rotates his legs and twitches with an uncontainable urge to swoop and tap. You might say he is driven by a compulsion to swing.

headline: South Asia Through Modernist Binoculars
text: “Radical Terrain” is the last of three small, carefully judged, back-to-back exhibitions in the series Modernist Art From India at the Rubin Museum of Art. How lucky New York is to have a museum willing and able to do such shows, unfamiliar in content but large with history. If we relied on our big institutions, which so often spoon-feed us what we already know, we would be unaware that India even had a modern art, never mind one of variety and complexity.

headline: Aamanns-Copenhagen
text: Inside the Danish restaurant that is rebooting an endangered food tradition: the smorrebrod.

headline: Morsels of Denmark, Anchored by Earthy Bread
text: When the original Aamanns opened in Copenhagen in 2006, locals embraced it as an invigorating reboot of an endangered food tradition: the smorrebrod, or open-face sandwich. As Mile End in Brooklyn has reinvented the Jewish deli, and Parm in NoLIta reworked the Italian-American sandwich shop, Aamanns took up an institution that had become neglected and synthetic, re-engineered it with traditional methods and good ingredients, then served it up proudly with a side of modern design.

headline: CBS Broadcast of Kennedy Center Honors Draws 8 Million Viewers
text: CBS’s broadcast of the Kennedy Center Honors, a 35-year holiday tradition for the network, attracted more than eight million viewers on Wednesday, easily outdrawing its competitors for the night.

headline: New Credit Card Fees Possible but Unlikely
text: Some retailers will soon have the option of charging extra fees to customers who pay with credit cards, as a result of a legal settlement in an antitrust lawsuit involving MasterCard, Visa and the big card-issuing banks.

headline: ‘Snow Fall’ Tells a Story About an Avalanche and a Newspaper’s Digital Progress
text: With its spectacular graphics and photography, and its beautifully written narrative, “Snow Fall: The Avalanche at Tunnel Creek” was a compelling project, even for those who might not have been particularly interested in the topic.

headline: Joan Kron and Plastic Surgery Journalism
text: Joan Kron, an editor at Allure magazine, discusses how she got into plastic surgery journalism.

headline: Porsche Wins Dismissal of Hedge Fund ‘Short Squeeze’ Lawsuit
text: A New York State appeals court dismissed a lawsuit brought by hedge funds against Porsche on Thursday, handing the German automaker a big victory in the long-running legal battle over its attempted takeover of Volkswagen.

headline: Car Factories Offer Hope for Spanish Industry and Workers
text: MADRID — Despite the economic gloom that has enshrouded it since the onset of the global financial crisis, Spain has at least one industrial bright spot: The country and its skilled, if underemployed, work force have once again become a beacon for European carmakers.

headline: Swift Holds On to Top Spot in a Big Week for Music Sales
text: Taylor Swift held on to the No. 1 spot on the Billboard chart for a sixth week, beating releases by T.I. and Bruno Mars, as well as the “12-12-12” charity album, in one of the biggest sales weeks of the year for the music industry.

headline: Deal Unlikely Before Fiscal Deadline
text: Lawmakers return to Washington from the Christmas recess with only days left before the United States economy goes over the so-called fiscal cliff.

headline: Iranian Leader Fires Woman From Cabinet
text: Iran’s president on Thursday dismissed his health minister, the only woman to serve in the cabinet since the 1979 Islamic Revolution, after she publicly criticized the government’s response to acute shortages of medicine imports, an indirect consequence of the Western sanctions imposed on the country.

headline: Unwrapped After Christmas, a Tenor
text: When, close to midnight on Wednesday, the American tenor Bryan Hymel appeared for his curtain call at the end of the Metropolitan Opera’s performance of the Berlioz epic “Les Troyens,” the entire cast lined up onstage and applauded along with the audience during the prolonged ovation. This gesture from the singers seemed not just a welcoming tribute to a young colleague making his Met debut on short notice in the daunting role of Aeneas. The cast members, especially the beaming mezzo-soprano Susan Graham, who was again a vocally sumptuous and alluring Dido, seemed genuinely grateful to Mr. Hymel for saving the day by giving an impassioned and confident performance of a heroic role that dominates this formidable French opera.

headline: Underbelly of a Brotherhood
text: The reliance of our government on the National Guard to pick up the slack in war zones — and the subsequent weakening of our ability to respond to homeland disasters — is a fertile topic that movies so far have neglected to exploit. And though “Allegiance” dips a toe in that water, this well-acted debut feature from Michael Connors (a former Army captain) is too limited in ambition and scope to satisfy our expectations.

headline: Vying for Fluency in Many Languages
text: Trisha Baga must feel as if she had died and gone to heaven. Her poetically frowzy installations of video projections, paintings, sculptures and scattered objects can be seen now in two New York museums — in a lobby gallery solo show at the Whitney Museum of American Art and in “New Pictures of Common Objects,” a group show at MoMA PS 1 — and she has a sprawling exhibition at Greene Naftali in Chelsea, a gallery admired by the art world cognoscenti. A New York resident, she also had solo shows in London and Munich in 2012. And she is only 27.

headline: Suburban Sprawl
text: There’s a touching paradox in the first chapter of Jami Attenberg’s caustic, entertaining and bighearted new novel, “The Middlesteins.” Edie, 5 years old and 62 pounds, is already too solid, in her mother’s estimation, too big for her age. But how can her mother not feed her, when she and her husband feel that food is “made of love, and love . . . made of food”? How can these parents deny Edie life-giving nourishment when Edie’s father, a Jewish immigrant from Ukraine, nearly starved on his journey to Chicago and has never been able to get enough to eat since? Even though it’s clear that young Edie suffers under her own weight — she huffs and puffs up the stairs “like someone’s gassy old uncle after a meal” — her mother can’t refuse her the liverwurst and rye bread she loves. This is a Jewish mother after all, and those of us who’ve had one know that the message, when it comes to food, is always have a little more. It’s an attitude that comes not just from love, but also from fear; a history fraught with disaster and hunger gives rise to the feeling that one must always be prepared. Therefore, bubbeleh, have another matzo ball.

headline: Wheelies: The Social Media Edition
text: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

text: Here are some of the more interesting items that the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web recently. See more here.

headline: City Agency Warns of Local Fiscal Problems Ahead
text: Whatever happens in Washington as the deadline for a fiscal deal approaches, New York City is facing some daunting financial topography of its own in the coming year and beyond, the city’s Independent Budget Office warned on Thursday.

headline: ‘Chicago Fire’ Episode Hits Too Close to Home for Webster, N.Y.
text: 5:29 p.m. | Updated An NBC station in upstate New York expressed regret on Thursday for televising a repeat of “Chicago Fire,” a network drama about firefighters, that bore resemblances to a real-life Christmas Eve shooting there.

headline: Has the Fat Lady Finally Sung?
text: With Richard Wagner turning 200 on May 22, what better way for the venerable Teatro alla Scala in Milan to celebrate than to open its season this month with his “Lohengrin”?

headline: 36 Hours in El Paso, Tex.
text: SITUATED at the intersection of Texas, Mexico and New Mexico, El Paso is a city with a distinct flavor. It juxtaposes authentic Mexican culture with a growing hipster scene, and though it’s one of the largest cities in Texas, it still often ends up as a mere pit stop on I-10. Once the storied heart of the Old West (and playground of Billy the Kid), El Paso has recently gained much of the big-city feel of its neighbor across the border, Ciudad Juárez. It has come into its own with new theaters, restaurants and nightclubs, many of them transplants from its sister city, the epicenter of the Mexican drug war.

headline: Views of El Paso, Tex.
text: From a chic restaurant in a strip mall to prickly pear mimosas in the desert, take a tour of this Texas town.

headline: Cats and Coffee in Seoul
text: If you like your caffeine with a feline theme, you’ll be right at home in Seoul, where a number of quirky cafes have sprung up.

headline: Unusual Auction Lots, Some With Sad Histories, Head for Public View
text: In a year of good and bad stewardship of antiques, museums opened that are devoted to handbags, gelato artifacts and the 1970s band Cheap Trick, and museums closed and sold off displays of wax figures, farm equipment and bicycle memorabilia. The best news of 2012 is that six major auction lots, brought back from warehouse stints and the brink of decay and dispersal, are now headed for public view:

headline: In a Weak Market for Mergers and Acquisitions, Signs of Strength
text: Paul T. Schnell has worked on some of the biggest mergers announced this year, a period in which, he says, the business of buying and selling companies is in the doldrums.

headline: Woman Posed as Aunt of Newtown Victim to Commit Fraud, the F.B.I. Says
text: A Bronx woman who the police say posed as a relative of a boy killed in the mass shooting at Sandy Hook Elementary School in order to solicit donations was arrested on Thursday and charged with lying to federal agents.

headline: Five Days Until the Fiscal Deadline
text: TimesCast Politics: The treasury secretary warns the U.S. will reach its borrowing limit on Monday. | The implications of the fiscal deadline on personal finances. | Planning Obama’s inauguration.

headline: In Boost to U.S. Plans, BBC World News Is Added to Time Warner Cable
text: 9:16 a.m. | Updated In a sign of progress for its push to get on cable and satellite systems across the United States, the BBC World News channel is now available in about 10 million homes that subscribe to Time Warner Cable.

headline: Seeing a Movie Over the Holidays? Best to Find a Comfy Seat
text: LOS ANGELES — The top three movies at the box office have a combined running time of 8 hours and 11 minutes — but who’s counting?

text: Wild yeast adds funkiness and hints of tropical fruit to beer.

headline: Native Talents, Shrugging at Europe
text: The Whitney Museum is New York’s go-to institution for the crazy-quilt history of early- and mid-20th-century American art, and its new permanent-collection display, “American Legends: Calder to O’Keeffe,” is one of its best in years. It features 15 artists, each represented by concentrated clusters of work that in some cases amount to mini-career retrospectives and that together create an immersive sense of the vitality of the prewar period.

headline: Empty Pages in a Show Filled With Words
text: Ed Ruscha has never been particularly precious about print. For him books — even his own artist’s books — have always been disposable. His breakout work, “Twenty-Six Gasoline Stations,” was a photo essay that looked more like a user’s manual; it set the tone for much Conceptual art and was followed by other, equally deadpan compendiums (“Every Building on the Sunset Strip,” “Nine Swimming Pools”).

headline: All the Fizz in a New Year of Culture
text: THE year may not be over yet, but sometimes it is hard to tamp down the enthusiasm of critics, reporters and editors for what’s aesthetically ahead. In picking their favorite possibilities for 2013, writers for The New York Times have identified a high-octane cast in “Parsifal” at the Metropolitan Opera, a celebration of Cambodian culture, a series of major video game releases and a sizzling dose of televised Bacon, as in the actor Kevin.

headline: A Nod to New Amsterdam
text: FOR years it has been the odd man out, the bad penny, a brutalized little 1830s brick house at 19 South William Street, plopped onto one of the most picturesque blocks downtown. Now a recent renovation has given this longtime party pooper a steampunk air in the midst of a riot of Flemish and Tudor revival architecture.

headline: The After-Studio Apartment
text: AFTER living in assorted roommate situations, Brian Landman bought his first apartment seven years ago. He paid $245,000 for a standard-issue studio in a postwar co-op building on East 35th Street in Murray Hill. His monthly maintenance was in the mid-$700s.

headline: Jamming Ritually
text: “Cascade to the rhythms, open up your mind/Cut loose from the furious snakes, unwind,” the Disco Biscuits sang in “Digital Buddha,” a song that popped up as excerpts in both their sets on Wednesday night at the Best Buy Theater. That’s as good a mission statement as any for this long-running jam band. The Disco Biscuits were starting their regular year-end stint in New York City, including three more Best Buy shows and New Year’s Eve at the Theater at Madison Square Garden. It’s a familiar and welcome ritual, complete with lasers flashing grids and canopies over the dancing crowd and videos traversing sci-fi geography as the band stays busy with its instruments. The musicians have to be listening to one another intently; often, they stay in the shadows.

headline: Neighborhood Joint: El Sabroso
text: Tony Molina, the owner of El Sabroso, in the garment district of Manhattan, greets each customer with “How are you, my friend?” before rattling off the day’s menu.

headline: Songs and Laughs for the New Year’s Eve Countdown
text: PEOPLE don’t go out on New Year’s Eve in anticipation of a great new year. They go out to erase 300-some-odd days of demons and to squeeze in a few more before the ball drops and forces reassessment. It’s a night in which everyone gets a free pass for misbehavior, because the next morning, society insists that you’re born anew.

headline: Secret’s Out: No-Frills Lunch Is Served Here
text: “Look closely or you’ll miss it.”

headline: Promoting Foreman Grills With a Weight-Loss Contest
text: JUST in time for the New Year’s resolution season, George Foreman Cooking is introducing an elaborate marketing campaign that uses a weight-loss contest to promote the grill brand’s appliances.

headline: ‘Dead Accounts’ to Close on Broadway
text: “Dead Accounts,” Theresa Rebeck’s play starring Katie Holmes and Norbert Leo Butz, will close on Sunday, Jan. 6 at the Music Box Theater, the show’s producers announced on Thursday. When it closes the show will have played 27 previews and 44 regular performances.

headline: New Video of Fatal Shooting at West Bank Checkpoint Shows Officer’s Final Shot
text: Sarit Michaeli, a spokeswoman for the Israeli human rights group B’Tselem, wrote to The Lede on Thursday to draw our attention to the fact that more video of a fatal shooting at a checkpoint in Hebron this month has been posted online.

headline: Lawmakers Look to Boost Guns in School
text: While the federal government and some states ponder more rigorous gun control laws after the shootings at a Connecticut elementary school, some Texas legislators have taken the opposite approach. They have emphasized what they see as a need to make firearms more available, and their discussions have included increasing access to guns for teachers and other school personnel.

headline: Blogging Up the Race for Speaker
text: ​​Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a column for The Tribune.

headline: Seattle Player Wins Appeal of Drug Test
text: The Seattle Seahawks’ Richard Sherman, one of the N.F.L.’s best cornerbacks, on Thursday won his appeal of a positive test for performance-enhancing drugs and will not be suspended.

headline: ’80 Murder Confession Raises Calls to Require Police to Record Interrogations
text: LIVINGSTON, Tex. — Max Soffar slurred his words in 1980 as he confessed to shooting two teenagers while robbing a Houston bowling alley, a confession that can be heard over the hisses and crackles of an audiotape. Only two hours of at least 26 hours of questioning over three days were recorded, according to the police officers who were at the interrogation.

headline: A Plea From the Admissions Office to Go for the ‘Dangerous’ Essay
text: Daniel Grayson is the associate director of undergraduate admissions at Tufts University in Medford, Mass.

headline: GTT ★
A Price Tag for the Gowanus Cleanup
text: The Superfund cleanup of the Gowanus Canal in Brooklyn is expected to cost $467 million to $504 million and will require dredging the 1.8-mile waterway to remove contaminated sediment, the federal Environmental Protection Agency said on Thursday.

headline: The Year in Pop
text: The critics Jon Pareles, Jon Caramanica and Ben Ratliff discuss the year’s biggest pop trends, and those that will be reshaping the genre for years to come.

headline: Fontella Bass, 72, Singer of ‘Rescue Me,’ Is Dead
text: Fontella Bass, the singer whose 1965 hit “Rescue Me” was an indelible example of the decade’s finest pop-soul, died on Wednesday in St. Louis. She was 72.

headline: One-Stoplight Town Seeks Just One Mayor
text: LITTLE MOUNTAIN, S.C. — Wanted: a mayor for this tiny South Carolina town.

headline: Russia: Ex-Official Called in Graft Case
text: Russian investigators have summoned a former defense minister, Anatoly E. Serdyukov, for questioning on Friday in a corruption case involving the sale of land formerly owned by the military to a private company. The police say the federal government lost $233 million in the case, one of several high-profile investigations into corruption under way in Moscow this winter.

headline: Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf, U.S. Commander in Gulf War, Dies at 78
text: Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf, who commanded the American-led forces that crushed Iraq in the 1991 Persian Gulf war and became the nation’s most acclaimed military hero since the midcentury exploits of Generals Dwight D. Eisenhower and Douglas MacArthur, died on Thursday in Tampa, Fla. He was 78.

headline: Developers of Wind Farms Run a Race Against the Calendar
text: WASHINGTON — Forget about parties, resolutions or watching the ball drop. To Iberdrola Renewables, New Year’s Eve will mean checking on last-minute details like the data connections between 169 new wind turbines in New Hampshire, Massachusetts and California and its control center in Portland, Ore.

headline: Illinois: Chicago Schools Accused of Discrimination
text: The Chicago Teachers Union filed a suit in federal court on Wednesday charging that the Chicago Public Schools discriminate against African-American teachers and staff members in selecting schools for “turnaround,” in which faculty and staff members are dismissed and replaced. The lawsuit alleges that the district selects schools with a high percentage of African-American teachers for turnaround, while taking no action against other similarly performing schools. More than half the 347 tenured teachers who were terminated by the district in recent turnarounds were African-American, the lawsuit said, although black teachers make up less than 30 percent of the district’s tenured teaching staff.

headline: Is Growth Over?
text: The great bulk of the economic commentary you read in the papers is focused on the short run: the effects of the “fiscal cliff” on U.S. recovery, the stresses on the euro, Japan’s latest attempt to break out of deflation. This focus is understandable, since one global depression can ruin your whole day. But our current travails will eventually end. What do we know about the prospects for long-run prosperity?

headline: The 2012 Sidney Awards, Part II
text: Sixty years ago, scientists believed that schizophrenia was caused by emotional conflict with the patient’s parents. A cold mother would deliver conflicting messages of hope and rejection and drive her child into madness.

headline: Closing Loopholes Isn’t Enough
text: REPUBLICANS in Congress say they will do anything rather than raise tax rates. Apparently, that includes rushing headlong over the fiscal cliff and throwing the economy into a possible recession.

headline: The Short Life of the Camel Corps
text: The Civil War featured many dazzling innovations: ironclads, hot-air balloons, the Gatling gun. But if armored warships and more powerful guns pointed to the future of warfare, another innovation, hailed at the time as a forerunner of combat to come, certainly did not: the United States Army’s Camel Corps.

headline: Republicans Must Support Public Financing for Contraception
text: Washington

headline: Putting ‘the Choke’ Further in the Past
text: If there was a subtext to the Nets’ firing of Avery Johnson two days after Christmas, P. J. Carlesimo had been around long enough to recognize the plot lines sooner than most. He starred in an earlier version of the movie, but long before the classic coach-killing caper became a more spurious whodunit of backdoor maneuvers.

headline: The Battle for Aleppo
text: As winter descends, the fighting’s direction has shifted in favor of the rebels, but it is unclear whether they can maintain an organized campaign.

headline: Battle for Syrian City Lays Both Sides’ Weaknesses Bare
text: ALEPPO, Syria — The sniper walked through the rubble near this city’s front lines. He was searching for another spot from where he might catch a Syrian soldier in his rifle scope’s cross hairs.

headline: Matsui, Star in Two Continents, Is Retiring
text: Like the United States, Japan has its own baseball royalty, and the princes are high school players drafted by the Yomiuri Giants. Being chosen by the hallowed Giants — Japan’s equivalent of the Yankees, the Lakers and the Cowboys combined — does not guarantee success. But the princes who succeed on and off the field are all but certain to be anointed kings.

headline: Gerry Anderson, 83, Dies; Made Futuristic Puppets
text: Gerry Anderson, a British filmmaker who transformed old-fashioned puppets into futuristic action heroes in the 1960s in the hugely popular children’s show “Thunderbirds,” and later cast real people in series including  “U.F.O.” and “Space: 1999,” died on Wednesday in Oxfordshire, England. He was 83.

headline: Michigan: Law on Cities in Crisis Is Signed
text: Weeks after Michigan voters repealed a law that gave emergency managers sweeping control over the state’s most financially troubled cities, Gov. Rick Snyder, a Republican, signed a new law on Thursday determining how the state will handle cities headed into crisis. As with the old law, the new law allows appointed emergency managers to take broad steps like discarding labor contracts, but also allows local officials to find other options.

headline: An Affront to Michigan Women
text: Despite clear public support for women’s reproductive rights, Michigan’s Republican-controlled Legislature used the just-ended lame-duck session to ram through harmful measures eliminating insurance coverage of abortions and imposing medically unnecessary regulations on providers of safe and legal abortion care.

headline: Iran’s Slowing of Enrichment Efforts May Show It Wants a Deal, Analysts Say
text: WASHINGTON — By subtly putting its hands on the brakes of its uranium enrichment efforts, Iran may be signaling that it wants to avoid a direct confrontation over its nuclear program, at least in the near term, according to United States and other Western officials.  The action has also led some analysts to conclude that Iran’s leaders are showing signs that they may be more interested in a deal to end the nuclear standoff with the West.

headline: A Tougher Assault Weapons Ban
text: New legislation proposed by Senator Dianne Feinstein in response to the Newtown, Conn., murders would provide a far more effective ban on military-style assault weapons than the loophole-riddled law that lapsed in 2004.

headline: Massachusetts: Markey Seeking Senate Seat
text: Representative Edward J. Markey will run for Senator John Kerry’s vacant seat, The Boston Globe reported Thursday. Mr. Markey, a Democrat, is one of the first to bid for the seat since President Obama nominated Mr. Kerry last week to be secretary of state. First elected to Congress in 1976, Mr. Markey, 66, has been particularly active on environmental issues. He co-sponsored the climate bill to reduce heat-trapping gases that passed the House in 2009 before stalling. Mr. Kerry is expected to be confirmed, opening up the seat he has held for 28 years. The special election is expected to take place in May or June.

headline: Time to Confront Climate Change
text: Four years ago, in sharp contrast to the torpor and denial of the George W. Bush years, President Obama described climate change as one of humanity’s most pressing challenges and pledged an all-out effort to pass a cap-and-trade bill limiting greenhouse gas emissions.

headline: Do We Still Need Libraries?
text: What are libraries for, and how should they evolve?

headline: Along Coast, Hurricane Left Housing Market in Turmoil
text: John Vento knew exactly how much his home was worth. The retired New York City police officer put his two-family house in the New Dorp Beach area of Staten Island on the market for $580,000 in February. Soon after, he refused an offer of $510,000.

headline: 22 Police Officers Kidnapped in Attacks on Pakistani Posts
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — The Pakistani Taliban kidnapped at least 22 policemen after coordinated attacks on multiple security check posts in northwestern Pakistan on Thursday, Pakistani officials said. Two policemen were reported killed in related gun battles with the militants.

headline: Man Admits to Smuggling Asian Fossils of Dinosaurs
text: The description accompanying Lot 49315 at Heritage Auctions in May was striking: a “superb Tyrannosaurus skeleton,” a remnant of a vanished animal that “ruled the food chain of the ancient flood plains that are today’s Gobi Desert.”

headline: NYU Langone Reopens for Surgery as Its Recovery Moves Ahead
text: NYU Langone Medical Center opened its doors to surgical patients on Thursday, almost two months after Hurricane Sandy overflowed the banks of the East River and forced the evacuation of hundreds of patients.

headline: Summoned Back to Work, Senators Chafe at Inaction
text: WASHINGTON — Senators bade hasty goodbyes to families, donned ties and pantsuits in lieu of sweat pants and Christmas sweaters and one by one returned to the Capitol on Thursday to begin the business of doing nothing in particular.

headline: Will Japan Unapologize to ‘Comfort Women’?
text: The New York Times’s Tokyo bureau chief, Martin Fackler, writes that Japan’s new (and former) prime minister, Shinzo Abe, and his conservative government may revise Japan’s 1993 apology for forcing thousands of women to be sex slaves in the service of Japanese soldiers during World War II.

headline: With Focus on Unity, China Embraces Its Pre-Communist Past
text: GUANGZHOU, China — It was 1926, not long after the fall of the Qing dynasty, and much of China had been divided among warlords. In the south, leaders of the young Kuomintang mustered an army. At its head rode Chiang Kai-shek, who called to his side officers he had helped train, and together they marched north to take down the warlords, one by one.

headline: 2 Men in Court on Charges They Aided Sri Lankan Terrorists
text: Two men extradited from Canada on charges of supporting a Sri Lankan rebel group that has been designated a foreign terrorist organization by the United States were ordered held without bond Thursday during an appearance in Federal District Court in Brooklyn.

headline: Suit Settled Over Claims of Sex Abuse at Poly Prep
text: An elite Brooklyn private school agreed to settle a lawsuit brought by former students accusing the school of covering up decades of sexual abuse of hundreds of boys by a star football coach.

headline: Once 7-1, a Playoff Shoo-In Is Struggling Just to Get In
text: LAKE FOREST, Ill. — In one sentence Wednesday afternoon, Bears Coach Lovie Smith spoke of the playoffs.

headline: Slain in Their Sleep, Afghan Police Are Betrayed by Their Own
text: The fear of insider attacks has been an even bigger concern for Afghan security forces than it has been for NATO and American forces, The Times’s Rod Nordland wrote on Friday.

headline: Unemployment Deepens Storm’s Loss as Businesses Stay Closed
text: In the Rockaways, none of the 450 employees of the Madelaine Chocolate Company will receive a paycheck this week. Until a few days ago, the floor of the company’s 200,000-square-foot complex was a muddy, sludgy, chocolaty mess, and its factory has temporarily closed. Outside, foiled Santas and candy roses lay victim to the hurricane.

headline: Turkish Journalist Accused of Terrorist Plot Is Freed Pending Trial
text: ISTANBUL — A court in Istanbul released Soner Yalcin, a prominent journalist, from prison on Thursday after he had spent nearly two years behind bars, charged with plotting to overthrow the government with 12 other defendants.

headline: Rare Choreography of Cooperation for Riders Caught Between an F and an M
text: They toil in a city of haggard indifference and missed connections, where the simplest task can devolve into a competitive sport.

headline: Frank Calabrese, Chicago Mob Hit Man, Dies at 75
text: Frank Calabrese, also known as Frankie Breeze, a Chicago loan shark and hit man responsible for at least 13 murders, died in prison on Tuesday in Butner, N.C. He was 75.

headline: It Can Go From Liquid to Frozen
text: FRIDAY’S PUZZLE — This being Friday, we have no theme to discuss, so let’s get right to what’s nice about this late-week puzzle.

headline: Giants Hope Rushers, and Offense, Can Reclaim Early Form
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Tom Coughlin said it would take some “soul searching” from the Giants this week to right a ship sinking toward a long and lonely off-season.

headline: Man Pushed to His Death Under Train in Queens
text: A young woman pushed a man to his death under an oncoming train at the 40th Street-Lowery Street subway station in Sunnyside, Queens, on Thursday evening, law enforcement authorities said.

headline: The Equestrian Federation Speaks Out
text: The equestrian organization’s chief executive, John Long, offered his views on the Mandarino case and the broader issues it raises for the sport.

headline: Felton’s Broken Pinkie Reshuffles the Lineup for the Knicks
text: SACRAMENTO — Raymond Felton was the first player to leave the Knicks’ locker room after a thrilling, last-second 99-97 victory over the Phoenix Suns on Wednesday night. As Felton swung the door open, a loud chorus of cheers and laughter could be heard as teammates high-fived one another.

headline: General Schwarzkopf, American Commander, Dies
text: Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf, who commanded the American-led forces that crushed Iraq in the 1991 Persian Gulf war, has died.

headline: Islamists’ Harsh Justice Is on the Rise in North Mali
text: BAMAKO, Mali — Moctar Touré was strapped to a chair, blindfolded, his right hand bound tight to the armrest with a rubber tube. A doctor came and administered a shot. Then Mr. Touré’s own brother wielded a knife, the kind used to slaughter sheep, and methodically carried out the sentence.

headline: Pacer Finishes 2nd in His 461st and Final Start
text: Tattler’s Jet did not finish his career in the winner’s circle, but he showed characteristic toughness in a sea of mud and snow Thursday at Monticello Raceway. A 14-year-old gelding, he overcame a poor trip to finish a fast-closing second in the 461st and last start of his remarkable 12-year career.

headline: Jumping for Show
text: Records show horses competing at equestrian events have tested positive since 2010 for substances like cocaine, antipsychotics and depressants.

headline: Carbon Taxes Make Ireland Even Greener
text: DUBLIN — Over the last three years, with its economy in tatters, Ireland embraced a novel strategy to help reduce its staggering deficit: charging households and businesses for the environmental damage they cause.

headline: Firefighters’ Attacker Didn’t Hide Past Killing, a Neighbor Says
text: The man who ambushed firefighters in western New York before fatally shooting himself was not shy about discussing his role in a previous killing, neighbors said Thursday.

headline: Sudden Death of Show Pony Clouds Image of Elite Pursuit
text: Early on the morning of May 26, Kristen Williams and her daughter, Katie, arrived at a barn on the grounds of the Devon Horse Show, where elite competitors in full dress have entertained spectators for the last century on Philadelphia’s Main Line.

headline: Neediest | Foster Care to Fatherhood
text: Anthony Pantoja grew up shuttling among foster care, group homes and the streets. Today he is a college student, and a father.

headline: Father, 21, Seeks to Provide the Life He Never Had
text: In his moments alone, Anthony Pantoja found only temporary sanctuary, so his pencil provided a more reliable means of escape.

headline: Cliff Osmond, Prolific Character Actor, Dies at 75
text: Cliff Osmond, a prolific character actor on film and television, most notably in a run of Billy Wilder comedies, died on Dec. 22 at his home in Los Angeles. He was 75.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Former Pitcher Sentenced for Attempted Murder Is Reportedly Released
text: The former All-Star reliever Ugueth Urbina was released from a Venezuelan prison Saturday after serving five and half years of a 14-year sentence for the attempted murder of several workers at his family’s ranch in October 2005, according to several reports from Venezuela.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Friday, Dec. 28, 2012
text: I didn’t realize how much I didn’t want to be here until I got here.

headline: What’s On Friday
text: 10 P.M. (HBO2) COLLATERAL (2004) Jamie Foxx is Max, a taxi driver who picks up Vincent (Tom Cruise, above left, with Mr. Foxx), a man visiting Los Angeles to meet with clients. Max soon discovers that Vincent’s “clients” are court witnesses he wants to kill on instructions from a drug dealer (Javier Bardem). Max is then forced to drive Vincent from one assignment to the next. Mark Ruffalo plays the detective who follows the trail of bodies left in their wake. Writing in The New York Times, Manohla Dargis said that this thriller, directed by Michael Mann, “is about a lot of different things, about how Los Angeles lights up at night, how cars become prostheses of ourselves and how driving with the radio on can be bliss.” She added: “But as with all of Mr. Mann’s movies, ‘Collateral’ is finally about men and work, and about how being a man is itself a kind of job.”

headline: Delhi Gang Rape Patient Has Brain Injury and Is Fighting for Life, Doctors Say
text: The medical condition of the 23-year-old woman who was raped by several men and thrown off a moving bus on Dec. 16 is worse than previous reports had indicated, according to the Singapore hospital where she is being treated.

headline: IHT Quick Read: Dec. 28
text: NEWS Even as the world makes plans to recapture northern Mali by force, the Islamists who rule the region show no qualms about continuing their harsh application of Shariah law. At least 14 amputations have been performed since the takeover last spring, and Islamists have warned that others “will soon share the same fate.” Adam Nossiter reports from Bamako, Mali.

headline: Debating the Death Penalty for Rape in India
text: A gang rape in Delhi has revived the debate about which crimes merit the death penalty in India, as calls for justice for the victim have quickly morphed into demands that the six suspects in police custody be executed.

headline: Babies, Beasts and the Bizarre From Times Contests Past
text: A dog, standing tall and proud on its hind legs, pushes a wicker carriage along a sidewalk. Inside, a spotted rabbit plays the role of infant. The two actors stare directly into each other’s eyes.

headline: Week 17 Matchups: Sound and Fury, Signifying Something
text: Through a 17-week N.F.L. season, there are certain players who stand out each week as the most interesting story line for their team. With many of the playoff teams already decided, we chose this week to take a look at the players who stood out, not only on the field but off it.

headline: App Smart Extra: The Melodies Linger On
text: Streaming music, and streaming “radio” apps like Pandora and Spotify, were the topics of this week’s App Smart column. They let you listen to music you do not necessarily have in your own collection. They can also be an excellent way to break out of a musical rut and discover new sounds.

headline: United States Lags in Alzheimer’s Support
text: This month, the United States Senate Special Committee on Aging released a report examining how five nations — the United States, Australia, France, Japan and Britain — are responding to growing numbers of older adults with Alzheimer’s disease and dementia.

headline: China Toughens Its Restrictions on Use of the Internet
text: HONG KONG — The Chinese government issued new rules on Friday requiring Internet users to provide their real names to service providers, while assigning Internet companies greater responsibility for deleting forbidden postings and reporting them to the authorities.

text: NEW YORK — It is possible to think of the American political conversation today as a big argument about the nature, meaning and value of work.

headline: An Industry’s Future, Blowing in the Wind
text: As I note in Friday’s paper, construction of new wind farms is going to grind to a halt with the end, at least temporarily, of two wind power subsidies. What’s next?

headline: Game Theory: The Passion Behind ‘Wreck-It Ralph’
text: I grew up when video games were a brand-new form of entertainment. I remember seeing Pong for the first time and thinking it was the cheapest animated show I had ever seen. Once I realized that it was an interactive game and that I could control what was happening on the screen, I was captivated. A love affair was born.

headline: Russian Acquittal Escalates Human Rights Feud With U.S.
text: MOSCOW — A judge issued an acquittal on Friday of the only official to have gone to trial in Russia in the case of Sergei L. Magnitsky, a lawyer whose death in prison three years ago inspired the United States Congress to pass a law addressing human rights abuses in Russia.

headline: Friday Reading: Going Beyond Disney in Orlando
text: Going beyond Disney in Orlando, retailers trying same-day delivery, on not owning a smartphone and other consumer-focused news from The New York Times.

headline: A Double Shot of Misunderstanding
text: One of the enduring fantasies of the pundit class – most dramatically demonstrated by the ludicrous Politico piece on What Insiders Know – is that all we need to fix our economic problems is to get the great and the good together and bypass those pesky elected officials. Business leaders, in particular, are presumed to have the know-how to deal with all the important issues.

headline: Woman Sought After 2nd Fatal Shove Onto Subway Tracks This Month
text: Like so many busy New Yorkers in a hurry to get where they have to go, Sunando Sen peered out over the tracks on an elevated subway stop in Queens on Thursday evening, anxiously awaiting the next train.

headline: Daily Report: Online Retailers Push Same-Day Shipping
text: This holiday season, same-day shipping replaced free shipping as the new must-have promotion for e-commerce companies, Stephanie Clifford and Claire Cain Miller report in Friday’s New York Times. Same-day shipping is logistically complicated and money-losing — and may not even be a service that consumers want or need, analysts say. But retailers big and small are willing to take the risk. Even the Postal Service has introduced a same-day option for retailers. And the reason is simple: fear of Amazon.com.

headline: Moscow Urges Peace Talks on Reluctant Syrians
text: LONDON — Russia has pushed itself to the forefront of efforts to resolve the Syrian crisis with an end-of-year diplomatic flurry aimed at bringing the Damascus regime and the mainstream opposition to the negotiating table.

headline: Pearson to Take Stake in Nook Unit
text: 8:35 p.m. | Updated

headline: The Breakfast Meeting: Tighter Internet Rules in China, and ‘Thunderbirds’ Creator Dies
text: New rules issued by the Chinese government Friday will make it easier to monitor who is using the Internet and tamp down some of the vibrant discourse on the country’s Twitter-like microblogs, Keith Bradsher reported. That discourse in recent weeks has publicized sexual and financial scandals that have led to the resignations or dismissals of at least 10 local officials, as well as accounts in Bloomberg News and The New York Times about the wealth of the country’s top leaders. The rules, which come with much greater legal force than earlier regulations, require Internet users to provide their real names to service providers, while assigning Internet companies greater responsibility for monitoring what appears online. The government also included a mandate for businesses in China to be more cautious in gathering and protecting electronic data.

headline: Russia Calls for Meeting With Syrian Opposition
text: MOSCOW — Russia has shown a burst of diplomatic energy before talks here on Saturday with the United Nations envoy on Syria, perhaps seeing a chance for a breakthrough that would temper the criticism it has drawn in the West and the Arab world during the course of the nearly two-year-old Syrian conflict.

headline: Policy Implications of Capital-Biased Technology: Opening Remarks
text: I’ll be writing more about this in weeks to come, but I guess I’d better say something right away about the implications of a declining labor share in GDP. Again, the data so far look like this:

headline: Environmental Taxes in Ireland
text: Taxes on garbage and fossil fuels are part of Ireland’s novel strategy to shrink its debt.

headline: Suspect in Subway Killing
text: A surveillance video released by the New York Police Department shows a woman suspected of killing a man by pushing him into the path of a subway train on Dec. 27, 2012.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: Reuters: According to China’s state news agency, Xinhua, the government will soon enact a set of much stricter food safety laws, partly prompted by a new round of testing of KFC chickens. “Abysmal” is the word used to describe the government’s record on preventing food-borne illness and adulterations …

headline: The Versatility of Spinach
text: Spinach goes well with all kinds of foods. It’s also a green that is easy to find year-round. As Martha Rose Shulman writes in this week’s Recipes for Health:

headline: Nets Coach Undone by a Fast Clock
text: The Nets, you might have noticed, are in a big hurry. Yes, they got their shiny new arena, annexed an entire borough of New York City as their territory, all but exhausted themselves scrubbing their image of all traces of New Jersey and years of losing and, worse, years of irrelevance. Which is why they were in such a frantic state after losing 10 of 13 games that in the time it took for their star player to pull his coach-sinking snit out of his bag of tricks, Avery Johnson went from coach of the month in November to N.B.A. road kill in December

headline: I’ve Just Seen a Fake: Beatles and Presley Top List of Most-Forged Autographs
text: You might want to double-check your beloved autographed copy of “Magical Mystery Tour” and be certain it was signed by Paul McCartney and not, say Pete McCourtney, or you’ll be looking like quite the fool on the hill. A ranking of the year’s most-forged celebrity autographs puts the Beatles near the top of that list, alongside performers like Elvis Presley and Michael Jackson, as well as notable individuals like John F. Kennedy and Neil Armstrong, Reuters reported.

headline: The Great Smog of China
text: LONDON — My mornings in my home in Beijing always follow the same routine. Wake up. Make coffee. Check Air Quality Index online. Feel faintly depressed.

headline: Motherlode’s Greatest Hits, 2012 Edition
text: What do the readers of a blog subtitled “Adventures in Parenting” like? Relatable parents, writing about the broader questions of being a parent — but with some bling, please.

headline: Youth Killed by Hit-and-Run Truck Driver in Queens
text: 9:46 p.m. | Updated An 11-year-old boy was killed by a hit-and-run dump-truck driver in Jackson Heights, Queens, on Friday morning, the police said.

headline: Delhi Rape Victim’s Condition Deteriorates
text: The Singapore hospital treating the 23-year-old woman who was raped by several men in a moving bus on Dec. 16 in Delhi issued the following statement on Friday:
