text: Updated, 11:50 a.m. | Hold onto your iPhones!

headline: Mergers That Benefit Market Structure
text: Larry Tabb is the chief executive of the Tabb Group, a financial markets research and strategic advisory firm, and TabbForum, a capital markets community Web site.

headline: Great Footage! And Jets Notice
text: Havard Rugland does not have the pedigree one might expect for someone who has become an Internet sensation for kicking a football. He knows next to nothing about the sport. Just ask him to name the quarterback of the New England Patriots or the Denver Broncos.

headline: On Our Radar: ‘Promised Land’
text: Writing in The Times, A.O. Scott praises “Promised Land,” Gus Van Sant‘s new film about the battle over fracking, as a film that “works,” mainly “by putting character ahead of story” and “inviting the actors to be warm, funny and prickly.” At the paper’s Dot Earth blog, however, Andrew C. Revkin suggests that the film “may not satisfy many people,” not least because its main characters “too often border on caricature.” For those interested in learning more, check out this video of a Times Talks event in which the paper interviewed Mr. Van Sant and Matt Damon, who stars in the film. And this feature focuses on Mr. Damon’s screenwriting collaboration with John Krasinski. [The New York Times]

headline: The Wayward Essay
text: In its quality of attention and faith in the salvific power of the right words in the right order, the essay resembles nothing so much as a secular prayer. That, at least, was the original point. The essay has proved wayward, which has been the great secret to its longevity.

headline: Bouquet Garni
text: Does the term “bouquet garni” intimidate you? Don’t let it! Melissa Clark shows why.

headline: Basic Cooking Starts With Stew
text: IF you read enough 19th-century novels, you’re likely to run into the description of the ever-bubbling stew pot. It’s the caldron at the ready to feed a famished family, a parade of visitors, the hungry vicar on his afternoon stroll or whatever other literary stereotype comes to call.

headline: The Music They Made, Spotified
text: For the past five years, I’ve been putting together a video feature to accompany the magazine’s annual The Lives They Lived issue. The sound collage, called The Music They Made, features samplings of songs from musicians who died in the past year. If you want to play the full songs featured in this year’s video — and why wouldn’t you! — you can use the Spotify playlist below.

headline: Handled With Care
text: I have been here many times before. Not to this particular library but to others like it. Some have been on college campuses, others in private homes. Some have sprawled through many rooms, including the bathroom; others were confined to a single space. One had no windows; another overlooked a lake. Most were crowded. All were dusty.

headline: Paperback Row
text: ZONA: A Book About a Film About a Journey to a Room,  by Geoff Dyer. (Vintage, $15.) In Andrei Tarkovsky’s 1979 film “Stalker,” two Russian intellectuals are guided by a tormented fool to a post-apocalyptic government-­restricted area called the Zone. (Within the Zone lies the so-called Room, where innermost hopes are revealed and even realized.) In Dyer’s vivid analysis, he watches himself watching the film, contemplating his own desires and what he considers to be “the most distinctive feature of Tarkovsky’s art: the sense of beauty as force.”

headline: Editors’ Choice
text: MARMEE & LOUISA: The Untold Story of Louisa May Alcott and Her Mother,  by Eve LaPlante. (Free Press, $26.) Alcott’s toiling, much put-upon mother was the complex core of “Little Women”; LaPlante’s dual biography attempts to save her from invisibility.

headline: Up Front
text: Siri Hustvedt has long explored the intersections and interplay of science and storytelling. Her study of neuropsychoanalysis in “The Shaking Woman; Or, A History of My Nerves” was inspired by Montaigne, and her novels are peopled by deeply philosophical painters, poets and psychiatrists. At the moment, she’s just completed another novel and is preparing a lecture on hysteria to present to a neurophysiology conference.

headline: The Rope, the App and Van Gogh in Amsterdam
text: AMSTERDAM—Consolation for disappointed art lovers who arrive in this city and realize that the Van Gogh Museum is closed for renovation: Follow the red braided rope.

headline: Shock to the Senses
text: Since his first extraordinary work, “Migraine,” was published in 1970, the neurologist Oliver Sacks has been writing a particular kind of medical literature. His detailed explications of a single patient’s symptoms, his emphasis on the subjective experience of illness, his willingness to share stories from his own life and his references to medical texts from earlier centuries are not only atypical of how most neurologists work today, they defy the status quo. And yet, Sacks’ work is part of a long tradition of descriptive, narrative, case-oriented medical writing he has himself called “romantic.”

headline: This Week’s Movies: Dec. 28
text: This week, Times critics look at Tom Hooper’s “Les Misérables,” Quentin Tarantino’s “Django Unchained” and the documentary “West of Memphis.” See all of this week’s reviews here.

headline: Approaching the Fiscal Deadline
text: TimesCast: Amid a flurry of activity, time is running out for a deal on taxes. | Keeping Ireland green with carbon taxes. | How doping came to the equestrian world.

headline: Strays
text: “Not many things are better than a kitten.”

headline: Crimes Without Punishment
text: It might seem surprising that only now — 14 years after José Saramago won the Nobel Prize in Literature and two years after his death — is this major novel, first published in Portugal in 1980, appearing in English translation. Then again, politically radical fiction is often a tough sell in our market. While Saramago was an outspoken member of his country’s Communist Party (“Marx was never so right as now,” he remarked at the outset of the recent global financial crisis), in his best-known work his politics are embedded in allegory or fantasy, allowing readers to view them as loosely humanist or to overlook them entirely. Not so with “Raised From the Ground.” Still, what’s apt to strike readers of this book is not so much that it’s radical but that it’s topical. “What kind of world,” it asks, “divides into those who make a profession of idleness and those who want work but can’t get it”? The novel even ends with descriptions of a kind of Occupy movement — though one with higher stakes — as peasants take over farm estates whose owners have relocated rather than pay their workers a living wage.

headline: Must Win
text: The “season with a high school team” genre has proved particularly durable since Buzz (then H. G.) Bis­singer’s “Friday Night Lights” became the touchstone some two decades ago, generating its own branded feature film, television series and follow-up e-book. It set the standard for countless similar tales, most notably Michael Lewis’s “Blind Side” and the Academy Award-­winning documentary “Undefeated.”

headline: Coming of Age in Rochester
text: In his first novel, “Maverick Jetpants in the City of Quality,” the Rochester native Bill Peters depicts his hometown as a city in decay, haunted by past glories and racked by vandalism. The narrator, Nate, is about to turn 21. He lives with his mother and her current squeeze, “Fake Dad No. 3.” Mostly, he drifts and looks for work in a somewhat desultory fashion. His ambition, such as it is, is to join his best friend, Necro (né Andrea: “Everyone in Rochester is Italians”), at Kodak, the firm that made Rochester famous. But it’s 1999, and the prospects are bleak for old-fashioned companies like Kodak and for Rust Belt cities like Rochester, whose nickname hasn’t been “City of Quality” since the 1960s.

headline: Stage Manager
text: Writing in his memoirs, Tennessee Williams remembers paying a visit to Thornton Wilder after the New Haven opening of “A Streetcar Named Desire” (1947). Wilder — then at the height of his eminence, having won Pulitzers for both “Our Town” (1938) and “The Skin of Our Teeth” (1942) — dismissed Williams’s latest effort with the air of one “delivering a papal bull,” as Williams put it. A “lady” like Stella, Wilder declared, would never marry a “vulgarian” like Stanley Kowalski. “This character,” Williams reflected of his colleague at the time, “has never had a good lay.” With the perspicacity that would lead him to become, arguably, our greatest postwar playwright, Williams had pretty much hit the nail on the head.

headline: They Get Around
text: Joyce E. Chaplin faces a challenge in “Round About the Earth.” She’s written a 535-page history of circumnavigation, from the voyages of Ferdinand Magellan (1519-22) to the Dutch teenager Laura Dekker (2011-12), which is to say the history of a highly conceptual and antiquated exploit. We all sense that encircling the planet is — or was — quite a feat. But a feat of what, exactly? Today it’s possible to book a round-the-world air ticket simply by tapping a smartphone. After Magellan’s expedition did it the first time, one wonders if there’s any sense in recording all those who came after.

headline: Soviet Dreams
text: A superstitious tradition, meant to protect children from vengeful spirits, persists in Spanish-­speaking countries — naming babies for the opposite qualities that benevolent parents might be expected to wish upon their offspring. Parents who want their daughters to lead joyful lives might name them Dolores (“sorrows,” “pain”) or Soledad (“loneliness”). A boy might be called Tristán (“the sad one”). But Andrey Platonov, the beleaguered Soviet writer who died in 1951 of tuberculosis (contracted from his son, who had been infected in Stalin’s gulag), seems to have pursued the reverse strategy when, in the mid-1930s, he began work on an allegorical novella entitled “Happy Moscow,” to see whether it was “objectively impossible” to write a bona fide “Soviet” work of fiction.

headline: Rogues’ Gallery
text: Isabella Stewart Gardner was decidedly eccentric. She walked lions, not dogs; drank beer, not sherry; and bathed opposite improving maxims rather than wallpaper patterns. (Some were more ominous than others: “Secret of two, secret of God; secret of three, secret of all.”) Such behavior made her reputation, though it was her magnificent art collection, assembled with the help of the young Bernard Berenson, that won her lasting fame. In 1903, Gardner opened her Venetian-style gallery — then called Fenway Court — to the city of Boston, enriching generations to come.

headline: Secret Loves
text: Near the end of the title story in “My Escapee,” Corinna Vallianatos’s taut and delicate collection, the resident cat at a rest home, the pet meant to comfort and slow “the hammering of an unhealthy heart,” dies in the lobby. White heads gather around Algebra’s corpse to sigh and accuse. One woman collapses and is denounced as a fake. “Don’t pretend you loved that cat,” Ginny, the main character, says. To which the woman’s husband replies: “She loved the thought of her. She truly did.”

headline: A World of Color
text: If only Titian had left us the scathing letters and soul-baring sonnets of his contemporary Michelangelo, whose image as a tortured genius has enchanted biographers since the Renaissance. In their place we have just a smattering of Titian’s business correspondence and a few official statements. His friendship with the ferocious satirist and pornographer Pietro Aretino is the stuff of speculation. So too are his relations with the models and companions who appear in masterpieces like the “Venus of Urbino,” which transforms one of Venice’s highest-priced courtesans into a goddess of love, taunting us with her half-smile while resting her hand in a forbidden realm.

headline: Destination: Wellness
text: SO I’m sitting in a hotel in upstate New York with my feet in a bucket of warm water charged with electricity when it suddenly hits me that maybe “getting well” wasn’t going to be as much fun as I thought it was going to be.

headline: Wellness, A to Y (the Z for Zen Is Silent)
text: Not only is wellness a tough one to define, but its terminology can be equally impossible to interpret. Here is a helpful rundown of some of the terms, attractions and techniques in the land of the well.

headline: Hitting the Wellness Circuit
text: Sculpture and healing, massage and mineral baths, on a quest to demystify wellness tourism.

headline: A Fish With Nowhere to Hide
text: Luiz Rocha, the curator of ichthyology at the California Academy of Sciences, writes from Belize, where he conducts research on the social wrasse, one of the world’s most endangered fish.

headline: For Some, the Slopes. For Her, the Cheese.
text: LET’S get this straight up front: I’m no skier. But when my French sister-in-law and her athletic husband, who hails from Grenoble (he basically grew up on skis), suggested we meet up for a slopeside family reunion in France last January, I was just as elated as my ski-obsessed husband and children.

headline: Sichuan’s Tibetan Corner, Outside of Time
text: HIGH on the Tibetan plateau, a few dozen red-robed monks of the Lhagang Monastery sat facing one another, rocking back and forth as they chanted with faces turned upward, to the heavens.

headline: Restaurant Report: Belcampo Meat Co. in Larkspur, Calif.
text: Though rich in dining options, San Francisco is not quite as besotted with all things meat as other major American cities. New York has the Spotted Pig and Swine; Los Angeles has Animal and Lazy Ox. But the Bay Area, perhaps still under the thrall of flower children grown gray, has yet to welcome a meat temple of its own. Belcampo Meat Co., a restaurant and butcher shop that opened in November in Larkspur, 30 minutes north of San Francisco, aims to change that.

headline: Letters to the Editor
text: Literary Manhattan

headline: Weekend Fare
text: A free tasting of winter ales from France paired with cheeses will be featured on Saturday from 1 to 4 p.m. at Ideal Cheese shop, 942 First Avenue, in Midtown East.

headline: Exit Lines
text: MY father spoke to his college roommate every day for 50 years. Though the two lived in different states, 800 miles apart, they were business partners, sounding boards and friends. Then one day my father called and his friend wasn’t there. He had died the night before of a terminal illness, which he had never told my father about. The two never said goodbye.

headline: Nadal Crosses Off Australian Open as Illness Is Added to Injury
text: Rafael Nadal’s comeback has been postponed again after six months away from competitive tennis, and this time he said the crux of the matter was not his troublesome left knee.

headline: How to Prepare When Next Year’s Tax Rates Are Anyone’s Guess
text: This was the week we were supposed to get a grand bargain. Instead, we got an undignified stalemate.

headline: The Future of Your Taxes
text: In this week’s Your Money column, I tried to make the case that the current brinkmanship in Washington is a bit of a sideshow to a long-term problem that nobody much wants to discuss: we haven’t come close to charging ourselves enough money to pay for all of the things we’ve promised to one another.

headline: Inside the List
text: QUOTING QUENTIN:  Ayana Mathis’s first novel, “The Twelve Tribes of Hattie” — reviewed in next week’s issue, and already anointed by Oprah Winfrey — holds steady at No. 10 in its second week on the hardcover fiction list. Mathis told me recently that she’s become obsessed with Faulkner, especially with this passage from “The Sound and the Fury,” in which Quentin, considering suicide in Boston, sees a black man on the bus and has a moment of fleeting insight: “They come into white people’s lives like that in sudden sharp black trickles that isolate white facts for an instant in unarguable truth like under a microscope; the rest of the time just voices that laugh when you see nothing to laugh at, tears when no reason for tears. They will bet on the odd or even number of mourners at a funeral. A brothel full of them in Memphis went into a religious trance ran naked into the street. It took three policemen to subdue one of them. Yes Jesus O good man Jesus O that good man.”

headline: Chronicling Ballet’s Pain and Passion
text: Henry Leutwyler’s photographs of the New York City Ballet are collected in a new book, and some are on display at the Foley Gallery.

headline: Giving History a Bel Canto Twist
text: WEARING a black dress and clutching a Bible, the mezzo-soprano Joyce DiDonato walked stiffly on the stage of the Metropolitan Opera during a recent rehearsal for Donizetti’s “Maria Stuarda,” which will open on New Year’s Eve and be broadcast Live in HD on Jan. 19. First kneeling, then standing, her aching movements in the final scenes reflected the title character’s physical demise after years of imprisonment.

headline: Special Edition of Chrysler 300 to Honor Motown
text: Chrysler has announced that it will offer a special edition Motown version of the 300 sedan. To be introduced at the North American International Auto Show in Detroit and offered for sale in the spring, the car comes with the blessing of Berry Gordy Jr., Motown’s founder. Mr. Gordy also appears in a new television advertisement publicizing the Motown edition and promoting “Motown: The Musical,” a production based on Mr. Gordy’s life set to open on Broadway in April.

headline: Gay Fathers in Israel, in Real Life and in Sitcoms
text: TEL AVIV

headline: Friends First, Talk-Show Hosts Later
text: LAST year the comedians Nikki Glaser and Sara Schaefer were preparing to record an installment of their weekly podcast, “You Had to Be There,” at Ms. Schaefer’s Brooklyn apartment when Ms. Glaser got a phone call she had been waiting for.

headline: Mad Science and Pop Hits
text: FOR pop 2012 was a year of rewired consensus. A year in which Taylor Swift finally accepted her pop-star birthright, waved casually at country and then bravely entered dubstep. A year in which the critic-consensus R&B star was Frank Ocean, who spent most of the year spilling out feelings and then averting his eyes. A year in which Carly Rae Jepsen suffocated the mainstream and then evaporated. A year in which Psy, a B-list Korean pop star, unleashed a video (and song) that became the first to surpass one billion views on YouTube, redefining virality in pop along the way.

headline: Bryant’s Number Lately Has Been 30 a Night
text: An occasional look at N.B.A. statistics and the players behind them.

headline: Popcast: The Year in Pop Trends
text: This week on Popcast, Times pop critics Jon Pareles, Jon Caramanica and Ben Ratliff discuss larger themes in pop in 2013 — a conversation from which this week’s Arts and Leisure roundtable was adapted.

headline: Book Review Podcast
text: This week, Jami Attenberg discusses her novel “The Middlesteins”; Leslie Kaufman has notes from the field; Maxwell Carter talks about “The Art Forger” by B. A. Shapiro; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host.

headline: Dec. 30 — Jan. 5
text: BEFORE his death on Aug. 6 Marvin Hamlisch had been scheduled to conduct the New York Philharmonic in its annual New Year’s Eve gala. Now the orchestra will toast this composer and conductor in “ONE SINGULAR SENSATION: CELEBRATING MARVIN HAMLISCH,” on PBS stations on Monday at 8 p.m. (Check local listings.)

headline: The Eurozone’s Next Stop
text: The euro zone looks to Asia.

headline: Newspaper on Cape Cod Apologizes for a Veteran Reporter’s Fabrications
text: HYANNIS, Mass. — When an editor at The Cape Cod Times was reading the newspaper last month, she thought an article about the Veterans Day parade from the day before seemed slightly off.

headline: Photo Replay: Dec. 28
text: A view of the day in sports, including cyclo-cross in Belgium and World Cup skiing.

headline: In a Crisis, Humanists Seem Absent
text: Since the Newtown massacre on Dec. 14, the tableau of grief and mourning has provided a vivid lesson in the religious variety of America. An interfaith service featuring President Obama, held two days after Adam Lanza killed 20 children and six adults at Sandy Hook Elementary School in Connecticut, included clergy members and representatives from Baha’i, Catholic, Jewish, Muslim and both mainline and evangelical Protestant congregations.

headline: The View from Wisconsin: In Alvarez They Trust
text: Longtime fans of Stanford might be feeling a bit of déjà vu come Jan. 1 in Pasadena.

headline: Partial Deal With Union Averts a Strike at 14 Ports
text: Dockworkers dropped their threat of an imminent strike against ports from Boston to Houston after their union and shipping companies reached a deal on the main point of their dispute, a federal mediator announced on Friday.

headline: 2012: The Year in Pictures
text: Colum McCann reflects on the images — disturbing, inspired and absurd — that shaped our collective consciousness this year.

headline: Senate Leaders Set to Work on a Last-Minute Tax Agreement
text: WASHINGTON — At the urging of President Obama, the Democratic and Republican leaders of the Senate set to work Friday night to assemble a last-minute tax deal that could pass both chambers of Congress and avert large tax increases and budget cuts next year, or at least stop the worst of the economic punch from landing beginning Jan. 1.

headline: For a Great Salad, Pretend You Are French
text: THERE must be something deep within the collective French psyche that intuitively grasps how to create a good salad. How else can you explain the fact that you can get an excellent one just about anywhere in France? A meal without salad, as a first course or to refresh the palate after the main course, is nearly unheard of there.

headline: Five Years Later, Some Countries Still Lag
text: Five years ago, in the fourth quarter of 2007, the United States economy peaked before what became known as the Great Recession set in. Some countries, China and Australia among them, never saw their economies decline, but most did, and some of the largest economies remain smaller than they were in 2007. The world economy — measured by total gross domestic product in 56 countries for which data are available — is now about 6 percent larger. But share prices have yet to fully recover in most countries.

headline: Some Subway Arrival Times Are Now Just an Apple Device Away
text: Updated, 3:25 p.m. | The Metropolitan Transportation Authority released a smartphone app on Friday that will provide real-time information on subway arrivals for six of the system’s numbered lines and the 42nd Street shuttle.

headline: Book Review Podcast: An Expansive Protagonist
text: This week in The New York Times Book Review, Julie Orringer reviews Jami Attenberg’s “caustic, entertaining and bighearted” new novel, “The Middlesteins,” which stars Edie Middlestein, a woman who is slowly eating herself to death. The book traces the impact of Edie’s problem on the rest of her family. Ms. Orringer writes:

headline: The Sweet Spot | Sweetest of the Year
text: The best moments of 2012 from A. O. Scott and David Carr — “two guys, sitting at a table, talking.”

headline: Tomorrow, It Will Snow, Perfectly
text: The ideal city snowstorm, meteorological Platonists say, blankets the landscape without burying it, beautifies but does not burden, transforms and cocoons without paralyzing or even particularly inconveniencing.

headline: The Sweet Spot: Dec. 28
text: The best moments of 2012 from A. O. Scott and David Carr — “two guys sitting at a table, talking.”

headline: Imagining a Future of Lower Hedge Fund Fees
text: Anticipated publication of this column around 2020:

headline: Past Turmoil Leaves a Lasting Impression on Today’s Investors
text: IF there was one word that applied to investing this year, it was uncertainty.

headline: Ratan Tata, the Man Who Brought Tata to the World
text: Ratan N. Tata, chairman of the Tata Group, retired Friday after over two decades at the helm of India’s largest business conglomerate.

headline: Cara Shepley and Genshi Ezawa
text: CARA SHEPLEY and Genshi Ezawa are keenly aware of just how different they are. Ms. Shepley is a lawyer from Baltimore; Mr. Ezawa is part of a long line of Soto Zen Buddhist priests in southern Japan.

headline: A Coal Sales Ticker Next to a ‘Clean Energy’ Claim?
text: Dec. 29, 12:38 a.m. | Updated below |Electricity, including that generated by coal combustion, has been a boon for humanity. In fact, there’s much truth in the headline on Indur M. Goklany‘s new analysis for the anti-regulatory Cato Institute: “Humanity Unbound: How Fossil Fuels Saved Humanity from Nature and Nature from Humanity.” (I’ll post more on that paper soon, including an interview with Goklany.)

headline: Image of the Day: Dec. 28
text: Dense fog and cold wave conditions hit Delhi.

headline: The Race to Senior Citizenship
text: Over the next two decades, more and more people will turn 65 each day, but the number of new 25-year-olds available to help pay their health care costs will not rise anywhere nearly as quickly.

headline: Headmistress, Jilted Lover, Killer, Then a Force for Good in Jail
text: Jean S. Harris, the private-school headmistress whose 1981 trial for the murder of a prominent Scarsdale, N.Y., physician galvanized a nation with its story of vengeance by a woman scorned, died on Sunday at an assisted-living center in New Haven. She was 89.

headline: Dealing With Uncertainty
text: As Paul Sullivan writes in this week’s Wealth Matters column, 2012 was a year of uncertainty, and it looks as if 2013 will at least begin that way. And with investors’ memories of the collapse in equity markets in 2008 still fresh, financial advisers say they have spent much of the last 12 months trying to get their clients to let go of their fears.

headline: Summing Up a Year in Pictures
text: In 2012, The New York Times brought its print and online readers comprehensive, immediate and intimate visual coverage of news around the world and in the New York region, including: brutal urban warfare in Syria, Hurricane Sandy’s destruction, a hard-fought election victory for President Obama and the mass murder of adults and children at a Connecticut elementary school.

headline: A Female Warrior’s Exploits, Blow by Blow
text: Everything on the stage rumbles during “Mulan the Musical.” And quite a bit off the stage too.

headline: Williams Dismisses View That He Caused Coach’s Firing
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. – Deron Williams claimed responsibility Friday, not for his coach’s firing or any perceived role in it, but for the circumstances that prompted it.

headline: Wheelies: The Promotion Edition
text: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

headline: A People’s Exodus, and a Family’s
text: There seems to be a calendar malfunction with the presentation of “The Last Seder” at Theater Three. The eight-day Jewish December holiday that ended recently is Hanukkah, the Festival of Lights. Passover and its Seder, the traditional meal and retelling of the exodus from Egypt? That’s in the spring.

headline: Graphic Books Best Sellers: Jack Kirby’s ‘Kamandi’
text: Jack Kirby, who died in 1994, was one of the comic-book industry’s most famous creators. Much has been written about his contributions to Marvel Comics — he worked with Stan Lee in creating the Fantastic Four, the Incredible Hulk and the X-Men, among others — and the continuing legal battle in which Mr. Kirby’s family is trying to win the copyright to those figures.

headline: A Long-Closed Park Is Soon to Reopen, Improved Yet Still Hard to Reach
text: All David Shuffler wanted to do when he was 14 years old was play basketball on the street and go to Starlight Park – which despite its name was a dimly lighted, dusty sliver tucked between the Bronx River and the Sheridan Expressway.

headline: A Buildup of Building Permits
text: The good news: Building permits for new developments are back on the rise, which means much-needed apartments should soon follow. The bad news: It still won’t be enough.

headline: The Rental Tide Subsides
text: Apartment rents in New York City have been rising rapidly for several years, but signs are now emerging that the market has hit a speed bump and is finally shifting to a slower gear.

headline: The Sport of Tycoons
text: IT was a year of record-high sales for luxury real estate. But 2012 will also enter the books for its chart-topping listings, as sellers sought to ride the wave of irrational exuberance for trophy properties.

headline: Woman Dies After a Gang Rape That Galvanized India
text: NEW DELHI — As protests grew in India Saturday over the death of a young woman who was raped in Delhi this month by several men in a moving bus, police said her attackers would be charged with murder.

headline: Video Shown of Apparent Execution of Afghan Soldier
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Mohammad Jan’s killers did not even do him the decency of looking him in the eye.

headline: Freedom of Choices
text: I appreciated Glamour’s latest cover story, “500 Ways to Just Be Yourself,” styled with verve by Anne Christensen on the adorable Anne Hathaway. But who’s counting?

headline: Dreams of ‘Open’ Everything
text: Software is not merely about automating every aspect of our lives anymore. Some of its makers want to change the way we all interact, spreading their supposed egalitarian excellence.

headline: Union and N.H.L. to Discuss New Offer
text: After owners made an extensive new proposal, the N.H.L. and the players union agreed Friday to resume bargaining this weekend in a bid to end the 104-day lockout and salvage the 2012-13 season.

headline: Bouquet Garni Basics
text: This week’s video shows how to make a bouquet garni, which basically means tying up a little bouquet of herbs with kitchen string and throwing them in bubbling liquid — a stew or soup (like Scotch broth), or a pot of beans or grains. The herbs give up their flavor to the pot, and tying them up makes them easy to dispose of so you don’t need to pick out thyme branches as you eat.

headline: Childhood, Uncensored
text: LAUREN MYRACLE has been called Satan, a pedophile, and a corrupter of youth, yet her series of books about a trio of Atlanta teenagers, written entirely in text messages, has sold a total of 1.5 million copies. She has been hailed as this generation’s Judy Blume for her candor, but outraged parents have lobbied to ban her books, which tackle topics like erections, that awkward first bra purchase, and clueless flirting that leads one sophomore to have a hot-tub encounter with a teacher. (Spoiler: her BFFs rescue her in the nick of time.)

headline: Frustrations With Robocalls, and the Joy of the Ordinary
text: I LOVE going back over the year and looking at readers’ responses to my column. It provides a perspective I lack when I’m focusing on one column at a time and receiving comments piecemeal.

headline: In a 5-Year Comparison, the U.S. Recovery Fares Well
text: Five years ago, the world economy seemed to be doing fine.

headline: Last Call for a Mumbai Cab
text: The Padmini taxi, a mainstay on Mumbai’s streets for decades, is being phased out as the city modernizes its cab fleet.

headline: Shedding Door Pulls, Mumbai Taxis Rattle Into History
text: MUMBAI, India

headline: Art Insurance Losses from Hurricane Sandy May Reach $500 Million
text: Two months after Hurricane Sandy caused severe flooding in many Chelsea galleries, the bill for the art world’s recovery is shaping up to be hefty. By mid-November, AXA Art Insurance, one of the largest art insurers, estimated that it would be paying out $40 million, and a Reuters report last week quoted industry estimates suggesting that insurance losses for flooded galleries and ruined art may come to as much as $500 million – or the rough equivalent of what the art insurance business takes in each year. That would amount to the largest loss the art world and its insurers have ever sustained.

headline: Stretching Trucks’ Mileage
text: PERHAPS you’ve recently been surprised to drive up behind an 18-wheeler on the Interstate whose trailer doors appeared to be ajar. No need to be alarmed: what you saw was probably one of several attempts at improving the fuel economy of long-haul trucks.

headline: Another Journey Comeback Tour
text: TESTED 2012 Dodge Journey R/T

headline: Oxymoron From Italy: The Civilized Supercar
text: MARANELLO, Italy

headline: Thrilling by the Dozen
text: The F12 succeeds the 599 GTB, assuming the role of Ferrari’s top two-seat grand touring machine.

headline: The Lives They Lived
text: A celebration of the writers, thinkers, athletes, scientists and others who died in 2012.

headline: Anthony Won’t Return to Face Kings
text: SACRAMENTO — Carmelo Anthony will miss his sixth game of the season Friday night when the Knicks play the Sacramento Kings. Anthony, who has a hyperextended left knee, did not participate in the Knicks’ shootaround, but he did appear to be walking better than in the previous two days.

headline: Living In | Chelsea
text: A 27-block neighborhood with a diverse housing stock, from low-slung to high-rise, and affordable to luxury.

headline: Calling Activists and Artists of All Stripes
text: IF West 23rd Street needed putting on a map, a cartographer could perhaps rely on a couple of its pop music landmarks: the Chelsea Hotel, once an inspiration for artists like Leonard Cohen, Bob Dylan and Joni Mitchell (as in her classic “Chelsea Morning”); and, just across the street, the century-old former Y.M.C.A. building that is said to have sparked the Village People’s late-’70s anthem of the same name.

headline: The Week in New York Region Pictures, Dec. 28
text: Subjects include the popular Peppermint Pig candy from Sarasota Springs; Christmas in areas hit hard by Hurricane Sandy; and a finback whale that washed ashore in Breezy Point.

headline: Less Familiar, but Still a SoHo Presence
text: BACK in the late 1960s and the 1970s, when SoHo had the intimacy and cohesion of a small village, nearly everyone knew Shael Shapiro. The slight, gentle architect with a flair for rescuing decaying buildings was a fixture in this onetime center of the city’s art world. Even well into the 1980s, as SoHo began morphing into an outdoor shopping mall, his was a familiar face.

headline: Q & A
text: Liability for Injured Workers

headline: Pakistan to Lift YouTube Ban, as a Viral Video Star Is Welcomed Home
text: Pakistan’s interior minister announced on Friday that the country plans to lift a ban on YouTube that was imposed in September, following violent protests over a crude anti-Islam film uploaded to the site by an Egyptian-American. The government acted to rescind the ban just hours after the star of one of the year’s most popular YouTube videos, a singing Pakistani fishmonger, was given a hero’s welcome upon his return to the city of Lahore from Britain.

headline: The Evolving Style of Michelle Obama
text: A selection of sheaths, prints, gowns and cardigans worn by the first lady.

headline: First in Fashion
text: IT’S a good bet that when Michelle Obama accompanies her husband to his inaugural next month, and later the round of balls, she will not be thinking of her critics or those White House aides who once fretted about the political fallout from her designer fashion. That’s because she has turned the seemingly frivolous into political capital of her own.

headline: A Mountain Goat for Top Poet Perch?
text: If one were establishing the odds of a songwriter being named the United States Poet Laureate, the logical favorite might be Bob Dylan. Or Paul Simon. But what about John Darnielle?

headline: Big Ticket | Sold for $21,450,000
text: Throughout his career as a developer, David Edelstein has had a knack for buying low and selling high, and he has done it again with the Upper East Side town house that he owned with his wife, Susan, at 122 East 70th Street. The five-story brick and limestone house, which they bought for $12.85 million in 2010, sold for $21.45 million, making it the biggest sale of the week, according to city records.

headline: Watching Dancers Grow, as Cultivated by a Daredevil
text: PARIS — On May 22, 1987, two female dancers in green leotards and black tights stood on the empty stage of the Palais Garnier here, in a pool of light. The women, hands on hips, each swiveled a point-shoe tip on the floor idly and glanced up at two golden cherries inexplicably suspended over their heads. Then one gave an almost imperceptible shrug and walked off, and the other began to dance, suddenly galvanized by a rhythmic, electronic crash of sound.

headline: An Illustrated Talk With Maurice Sendak
text: When Christoph Niemann stumbled on a “Fresh Air” interview with Maurice Sendak, wild things started to transpire.

headline: On the Market in the Region
text: A five-bedroom house in Mendham, N.J., and a  five-bedroom French Provincial in Great Neck, N.Y.

headline: On the Market in New York City
text: A Battery Park City condo, an Upper West Side condo and a Park Slope condo.

text: Subjects include the New York City Ballet, Back to Back Theater and the Crossing.

headline: Ancient Arts Center Discovered Under Rome’s Piazza Venezia
text: ROME—Eighteen feet below one of Rome’s most-trafficked junctions is a 900-seat arts center dating back to the second-century reign of Emperor Hadrian, Italian archaeologists have announced.

headline: Friday Night Music: Feist and Mountain Man
text: Yes, it’s early, but I’m fiscally exhausted, and am calling it a day. No particular reason to post this performance; it’s just that I happened to stumble across this wonderful live version of “Undiscovered First”, which I especially like because the performers seem tired and out of it until they start playing, and then you watch the power of the song take over:

headline: Democratic Establishment Voices Support for Markey’s Bid to Succeed Kerry
text: The Democratic ranks are closing behind Representative Edward J. Markey of Massachusetts in the race to succeed Senator John Kerry, who hopes to become secretary of state.

headline: Lawmakers Suggest New Rules to Speed Up Senate Business
text: A bipartisan group of eight senators on Friday proposed a detailed set of Senate rule changes that could speed the legislative process considerably but would stop short of the most dramatic changes to the filibuster that some Democrats are demanding.

headline: Back Finds a Taste of Success With Tijuana Club
text: With the Mexican Apertura set to kick off next week, Club Tijuana left back Edgar Castillo is hoping to build off his success in a championship-winning season in 2012.

headline: On Bended Knee? Not Always
text: WHEN it comes to fevered pitches spoken from the heart, December is truly the month for marriage proposals. With 2012 wrapping up, a year when neither recession nor high wind and water got in the way of those seeking memorable ways of prompting a “yes!” from the targets of their affections, we searched high and low for the most interesting proposals submitted this year to the Weddings/Celebrations pages of The Times.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Kashmir and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Kashmir, New York, Germany and Nepal.

headline: Questions Remain Over Hewlett’s Big Charge on Autonomy Acquisition
text: The $5 billion fight over accusations of improper accounting brought by Hewlett-Packard shows no sign of abating.

headline: BMW Recalling 2,385 Motorcycles for Kickstand Problem
text: BMW is recalling 2,385 of its 2012-13 motorcycles to keep gravity from having its way with them.

headline: Bahrain Detains Officer for Slapping Man
text: Although Bahrain has previously failed to prosecute members of its security forces caught on video shooting unarmed protesters, this week an officer who slapped a man with a baby in his arms was detained after video of the incident attracted wide attention.

headline: At a Gastro Pub, an English Bent
text: THERE is much to like about the Rocky Hill Inn. Tucked into a crossroads kind of town in central New Jersey, the homey spot, with roots back to 1745, draws a local, multigenerational crowd to its bustling tavern and serene dining room.

headline: Small-Plate Offerings in a Spirited Setting
text: CAN a restaurant earn a rating of Don’t Miss if the reviewer had a bad experience on the first of two visits? It can if I am the reviewer and the restaurant is as good as Lula Trattoria in Mineola.

headline: For the 40th Year, Diversity
text: As the Long Island wine industry enters its 40th year in 2013, the conventional notion that merlot is its defining specialty continues to be strongly challenged.

headline: TV Where Too Far Is Never Far Enough
text: “Our big dilemma going into the end of the season is whether we may actually be pushing the envelope too far,” says the protagonist of “The King of Pain,” one of 2012’s most enjoyable novels for anyone who is a fan of reality television or simply likes monitoring the continuing train wreck that its more tawdry regions have become.

headline: Full of Hospitality, and Exuberantly Greek
text: PONTOS TAVERNA, just half a block from the Garden Cinema in downtown Norwalk, is an old-fashioned Greek place, with a family atmosphere that comes straight from the owner. Nikolaos Kiriakidis opened Pontos in April of 2011 with his seven siblings; his father, Teddy (the chef); and his mother, Anna (the hostess). “We worked in other restaurants,” Nikolaos Kiriakidis explained, “and finally decided to open our own.”

headline: Main Facade Intact at Ladies’ Mile Landmark, but Damage Is Serious
text: News of a facade collapse on Tuesday at the former O’Neill & Company dry-goods emporium conjured images of significant architectural loss. This gleaming white facade on the Avenue of the Americas, from 20th to 21st Streets, is among the largest single expanses of ornamental cast-iron in the city. Its signature elements — gold-colored beehive domes at each corner turret and Hugh O’Neill’s name boldly inscribed in the pediment — make it especially memorable.

headline: For 12 Days of Christmas, 6 ‘Brandenburg’ Concertos
text: Almost a year ago Trinity Church announced that it would cut back its remarkable music program. The offerings and their quality had blossomed since the 2010 arrival of Julian Wachner as director of music and arts, but they did not come cheap.

headline: A Taste of Americana, Off the Bone and on Tap
text: When I heard about Holy Smoke, a barbecue spot in Mahopac, from three people — all food connoisseurs — in four days, I knew I needed to check it out. Though it has been around since 2004, it is on a sleepy residential strip of Route 6N, and so has remained somewhat of a secret. Not among local residents, however. And not among the craft beer and barbecue lovers who visit from around the New York City area. Holy Smoke was rocking the first time I went. Diners enter through the no-fuss bar, where, on that visit, people were lined up and crowding around the room’s high-top tables. The proprietor, Chris Casino, was pouring the brews — Holy Smoke has 30 taps devoted to such delicious and artfully named drafts as Tröegs Mad Elf and Southern Tier Old Man Winter, and an impressive lineup of bourbons as well. If you are a Budweiser or wine drinker, however, you are pretty much out of luck (they do offer Sutter Home by the glass).

headline: Home for the Holidays, or Not: The Ultimate Holiday Escape
text: Thank you for your responses to our call for expat holiday posts. We received funny and sad, heart-wrenching and heartwarming posts and comments.

headline: Trying, Desperately, to Lose the Family Baggage
text: Laurel Ollstein, the author of “Esther’s Moustache,” which is playing at the New Jersey Repertory Company in Long Branch, said in an interview recently that her new comedy “has a magic realism quality to it.”

text: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include the popular Peppermint Pig candy from Sarasota Springs; Christmas in areas hit hard by Hurricane Sandy; and a finback whale that washed ashore in Breezy Point.

headline: Beached Whale Buried After Necropsy
text: The necropsy of the emaciated 60-foot finback whale that beached itself at Breezy Point in Queens found lesions in the animal’s stomach and kidneys on Friday, but it is not clear what, if anything, they had to do with the animal’s death, a biologist with the National Marine Fisheries Service said.

text: To the Editor:

headline: Whitman in Washington
text: Among the countless Northerners shocked by the Union defeat at Fredericksburg, Va., in December 1862 was the Brooklyn poet and journalist Walt Whitman. In Whitman’s case the shock was personal: his brother George was among the wounded. He quickly packed his bags and rushed south to the Union position. When Whitman arrived at the field hospital set up in a mansion, he found a scene from hell, watched over by an imposing angel: Clara Barton moved amid screams of surgery, ministering to youths, bandaging the bleeding and soothing the dying with low-spoken words and water.

headline: Sprawling Memphis Aims to Be a Friendlier Place for Cyclists
text: MEMPHIS — John Jordan, a 64-year-old condo appraiser here, has been pedaling his cruiser bicycle around town nearly every day, tooling about at lunchtime or zipping to downtown appointments.

headline: Museum of History & Industry in Seattle
text: A revamped History & Industry Museum has a new home on Lake Union in Seattle.

headline: Ryan Wants to Be Jets Coach for ‘Next 15 Years’
text: In an animated news conference Friday, Jets Coach Rex Ryan vehemently denied a report that he would be looking to leave the team if the owner Woody Johnson did not make off-season upgrades to the offense.

headline: Woman Helped Firefighters’ Killer Get Gun He Used in Ambush, Police Say
text: The police arrested a woman in western New York on Friday who they said helped a man acquire the weapon he is believed to have used to kill two firefighters in an ambush that left two others injured.

headline: Iran: Navy Begins War Games Near Vital Waterway
text: Iran’s naval forces began six days of war games on Friday in the Gulf of Oman near the Strait of Hormuz, the narrow waterway considered vital to international oil tanker traffic. Accounts in the state-run news media said the war games, covering a 400,000-square-mile area, were devised to test combat ships, submarines, reconnaissance methods and a new version of the Thunder surface-to-air midrange missile. The official Islamic Republic News Agency quoted a commander, Rear Adm. Habibollah Sayyari, as saying the exercises were meant to transmit a message of friendship to neighbors and display “the armed forces’ military capabilities.” Iran, which periodically conducts such naval maneuvers, has said it could close the Strait of Hormuz as retaliation for Western sanctions imposed over Iran’s disputed nuclear energy program.

headline: The Taboo of Menstruation
text: Bettiah, India

headline: Place of Prominence for Mr. Met
text: Having gutted their team of veteran players during the off-season, the Mets might be forgiven for trying to usher in someone that fans might recognize. That someone is Mr. Met.

headline: Italy: Departing Leader Backs a New Centrist Coalition
text: Mario Monti, the departing caretaker prime minister, said Friday that he would back a centrist grouping in national elections expected in February. Mr. Monti, left, governed for 13 months before resigning this month. Although he said that he would not be a candidate — as a senator for life, he does not need to run in elections — his statement solidifies him as a de facto third-party leader. Traditionally, political groups have named a candidate for prime minister before elections. The grouping led by Mr. Monti, who in recent days has been endorsed by the powerful Roman Catholic Church, will challenge the center-right leader, former Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi, who has adopted a populist stance critical of the euro; and the center-left leader, Pierluigi Bersani, whose Democratic Party is leading in polls.

headline: Papers Show Rare Friction for Thatcher and Reagan
text: LONDON — The bond between Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher and President Ronald Reagan, both in office in the 1980s, has become a kind of gold standard, showing what the “special relationship” between Britain and the United States can be when their leaders share a political creed.

headline: Vikings Still Trust Their Passer (Often to Hand Off)
text: EDEN PRAIRIE, Minn. — The details sound like a folk song. Minnesota Vikings quarterback Christian Ponder married on a Monday two weeks ago, just across the state line in Hudson, Wis., with no witnesses besides his bride — the ESPN broadcaster Samantha Steele — and the St. Croix County commissioner who presided.

headline: Save Mali Before It’s Too Late
text: Bamako, Mali

headline: Card-Table Romance Brings Marriage
text: Janet Robertson of Timonium, Md., outside Baltimore, and R. Jay Becker of New York City met at the 2011 Summer Nationals in Toronto. Becker proposed on a beach in Bali at sunset on March 1, and they are getting married Sunday at the home of Andrea and Lew Finkel in Jupiter, Fla.

headline: Standing on Tradition While Stretching the Boundaries of Bluegrass
text: The Infamous Stringdusters, who headlined the Bowery Ballroom on Thursday night, have the lineup of a traditional bluegrass band: fiddle, banjo, Dobro, guitar and bass. They played and sang like one, too, with flying fingers and close harmonies, when they took up bluegrass standards like “Orange Blossom Special” or “Deep Ellum Blues.” But in the years since the group emerged from Nashville in 2007, the Stringdusters, like a lot of other young string bands, have ignored purism, applied their virtuosity to untraditional tunes and structures and found a wider audience along the jam-band circuit.

headline: Glimpses of France Through the Centuries
text: “Have you seen a Monet yet?” a visitor in the third gallery of the Wadsworth Atheneum’s cleverly named “Medieval to Monet” show murmured to her friend. She was afraid she’d missed something among the paintings of religious subjects, mythological scenes and extravagantly decked-out aristocrats.

headline: Versions of Sugar Plums
text: How can anyone foresee the career developments of individual ballet dancers? Stand back, and they seem determined by the whims of fate. Close up, fate seems scarcely involved. We all know that intensely human matters contribute: directorial taste, personal talent, discipline, health and character.

headline: Loss of Inouye Means Loss of Clout for Hawaii
text: HONOLULU — No man is an island. But in Hawaii, Daniel K. Inouye sure seems like one.

headline: A Place Comfortable With Boeing, Anarchists and ‘Frasier’
text: SEATTLE — Everything connects. The first commercial aircraft made by Boeing, in 1919, hangs from the ceiling. It has no wheels because it regularly landed on Lake Union here after airmail runs to Canada. You can see that lake through a hole in the floor of this building, a former Naval Reserve Armory that was built out over the water in 1942. And above that hole now rises a commissioned 65-foot-high sculpture made by John Grade from the planks of a century-old schooner that also plied Lake Union.

headline: Eight Are Charged With Chilean Singer’s 1973 Murder After Military Coup
text: SANTIAGO, Chile — Eight retired army officers were charged on Friday with the murder of a popular songwriter and theater director, Víctor Jara, who was tortured and killed days after the 1973 military coup in a stadium that had been turned into a detention center.

headline: Legs and Legends in a Domestic Setting
text: New Rochelle, N.Y.

headline: Senate Passes $60.4 Billion for Storm Aid; Bill’s Fate in House Is Unclear
text: WASHINGTON — The Senate approved $60.4 billion in emergency spending on Friday to pay for recovery efforts in states ravaged by Hurricane Sandy, at one point fending off a Republican bid to reduce the aid package by more than half.

headline: Federal Power to Intercept Messages Is Extended
text: WASHINGTON — Congress gave final approval on Friday to a bill extending the government’s power to intercept electronic communications of spy and terrorism suspects, after the Senate voted down proposals from several Democrats and Republicans to increase protections of civil liberties and privacy.

headline: A Fierce Playmaker Who Shrugs Off Praise
text: CINCINNATI — Choosing his favorite catch as a Bengal would figure to be a strenuous exercise for A. J. Green, what with the one-handed miracle at Kansas City, the double-coverage touchdown against the Steelers and that end-zone fade in Denver all vying with a few other candidates.

headline: Russian Adoption Ban Brings Uncertainty and Outrage
text: MOSCOW — President Vladimir V. Putin on Friday signed into law a ban on adoptions of Russian children by American citizens, apparently blocking the departure from Russia of hundreds of orphans who had already been told that they would soon go home with new parents.

headline: Hurricane Sandy Alters Utilities’ Calculus on Upgrades
text: After Hurricane Sandy wreaked havoc with power systems in the Northeast, many consumers and public officials complained that the electric utilities had done far too little to protect their equipment from violent storms, which forecasters have warned could strike with increasing frequency.

headline: Revisiting Crimes, From the Broker Who Kept a Key, to the Burglar With Bricks
text: In Midtown Manhattan, a door opened, and an empty apartment presented itself. A man entered with a long tool in his hand and got right to work. He had no idea that a small, high-definition camera was secretly recording his movements.

headline: New Effort in Congress to Extend Disputed Farm Bill
text: WASHINGTON — Hoping to stave off the expiration of dozens of farm programs and a return to an antiquated 1949 farm law that could lead to a doubling of the price of milk, Senate and House leaders worked Friday to devise legislation that would extend the current farm bill.

headline: Delhi Rape Victim’s Trauma ‘Too Severe to Overcome’
text: A 23-year-old woman, whose rape in Delhi on Dec. 16 galvanized thousands to protest for better treatment of women, died on Saturday morning. The full statement from Kelvin Loh, chief executive of Mount Elizabeth Hospital, where she was being treated, is below:

headline: A Record Worth Wilting For: Death Valley Is Hotter Than ...
text: FURNACE CREEK, Calif. — For Death Valley, a place that embraces its extremes, this has long been an affront: As furnace-hot as it gets here, it could not lay claim to being the hottest place on earth. That honor, as it were, has gone since 1922 to a city on the northwestern tip of Libya.

headline: Counting Blessings After a Harrowing Storm Escape
text: When Hurricane Sandy hit New York City, Yuliana Oleynik and Stanislav Izgiayev trekked for three miles through flooded streets to deliver their two children to safety. Their son Nicholas, then 10 months, rode atop Mr. Izgiayev’s shoulders, while Ms. Oleynik was responsible for their other child, Isaac, whom she was quite literally carrying: She was seven and a half months pregnant.

headline: Covering J. R. Smith
text: J. R. Smith of the Knicks shows off his 70-plus tattoos.

headline: F.D.A. Clears Anticlotting Drug by Bristol and Pfizer
text: The Food and Drug Administration on Friday approved Eliquis, an anticlotting drug that has been highly anticipated by cardiologists and is expected to be a blockbuster for Bristol-Myers Squibb, which will make the drug, and Pfizer, which will help market it.

headline: Covering J. R. Smith: A Knick Talks About His Tattoos
text: Knicks guard J.R. Smith broke for the baseline Wednesday night, caught the ball and went airborne in one sweeping motion, split his legs in the course of his leap, and drained the game-winner against the Phoenix Suns with a flick of his right wrist while falling into the stands. It was, for sure, a certain kind of body art.

headline: Afghan Prosecutor Faces Criticism for Her Pursuit of ‘Moral Crimes’
text: HERAT, Afghanistan

headline: Still Waiting for Sandy Relief
text: Republicans haven’t made it easy for the Northeast to get the $60.4 billion in aid it needs to recover from Hurricane Sandy. They have objected to the amount — which is considerably less than the $82 billion requested by the region’s governors — and tried to slash it. They have demanded that $3.4 billion of the aid for flood control be offset by spending cuts in other programs. And in the Senate, as on virtually all bills, they filibustered the aid package proposed by President Obama.

headline: Keeping Parolees Out of Prison
text: To cut state corrections costs, which have quadrupled over the last decade to about $52 billion annually, many states are remaking “hair-trigger” parole systems that send large numbers of people back to jail, not for new crimes but for technical violations like failing a drug test or missing an appointment with a parole officer.

headline: Guns and Mental Illness
text: Many years ago, when I was a young reporter at Texas Monthly magazine, I spent the better part of six months in the company of a man who suffered from schizophrenia. His name was Fred Thomas; he was 23 years old; and he had been steadily deteriorating since high school, which is when most men first show symptoms of the disease.

headline: Revival of Hitachi the Company Is a Detriment to Hitachi the City
text: HITACHI, Japan — The biggest annual loss on record by a Japanese manufacturer jolted executives into action at the Hitachi Corporation, the century-old electronics and engineering behemoth that takes its name from this wind-swept industrial city on the Pacific Coast.

headline: In Russia, Exile in Comfort for Leaders Like Assad
text: BARVIKHA, Russia — A few years back, before he settled in this bucolic town in a pine forest near Moscow, Askar Akayev, then the president of Kyrgyzstan, had a very stressful day.

headline: Lottery Numbers
They Have Their Pride
text: SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — Well, you knew it was bound to happen. Someone was going to try to break the quadruple stack, and if you were going to take an educated guess and say that that someone might be Joe Krozel, you’d be correct.

headline: Corrections: December 29, 2012
text: NATIONAL

headline: The Deadly Fantasy of Assault Weapons
text: Adam Lanza shot 20 children and six adults at Sandy Hook Elementary School in Newtown, Conn., using a semiautomatic, military-style assault rifle made by Bushmaster. William Spengler Jr. used the same type of Bushmaster rifle to kill two firefighters last week in Webster, N.Y. The Washington snipers, John Allen Muhammad and Lee Boyd Malvo, also used a Bushmaster in a spree that killed 10 people in 2002.

headline: Former Greek Official Is Said to Have Obstructed Tax Inquiry
text: ATHENS — A former Greek finance minister appeared to be implicated Friday in the tampering of the so-called Lagarde list of Greeks with Swiss bank accounts after prosecutors revealed that three of his relatives had been removed from the list.

headline: 414 Homicides in ’12 Is a Record Low for New York City
text: Murders in New York have dropped to their lowest level in over 40 years, city officials announced on Friday, even as overall crimes increased slightly because of a rise in thefts — a phenomenon based solely on robberies of iPhones and other Apple devices.

headline: Bowl Game Mirrors Season as Rutgers’s Hope Peters Out
text: ORLANDO, Fla. — It was not the type of game that deserved extra plays, but the Russell Athletic Bowl provided them anyway Friday night, going to overtime to produce a 13-10 victory for Virginia Tech against Rutgers, decided by Cody Journell’s 22-yard field goal.

headline: Rape in the World’s Largest Democracy
text: The brutal gang rape of a young woman in New Delhi this month has cast a cold light on how badly India treats its women.

headline: Nets Beat the Bobcats but Pine for Jackson
text: In a quiet moment of a dreary Friday night at Barclays Center, a single voice screeched from the lower bowl, with emphatic desperation.

headline: Dwindling Adoptions
text: When Russia’s president, Vladimir Putin, signed a law on Friday banning the adoption of Russian children by Americans, it brought the issue of international adoptions by United States citizens back into the spotlight.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, December 29, 2012
text: The hour for immediate action is here. It is now.

headline: As Walmart Makes Safety Vows, It’s Seen as Obstacle to Change
text: When Walmart’s chief executive, Michael Duke, appeared at a Council on Foreign Relations meeting in New York this month, a raucous crowd of protesters awaited him. Walmart was confronting reports of bribery in Mexico, a wave of labor demonstrations in the United States and, perhaps most critically, questions about a grisly fire that had killed 112 workers at a Bangladeshi garment factory used by several Walmart suppliers.

headline: The One-Two Punch of Chinese Web Censorship
text: Our colleague Keith Bradsher reports on China’s efforts to tighten the reigns on the Internet, issuing new rules on Friday requiring Internet users to provide their real names to service providers, and giving companies more responsibility to delete forbidden posts and report them to authorities.

headline: What to Expect in New York in 2013
text: The Times’s Metro reporters forecast what will make news in the city and region in the coming year.

headline: Grief and Anger in India After Death of Delhi Rape Victim
text: The death of a 23-year-old woman who came to symbolize the horrible treatment women face daily in India after she was raped by several men on a moving bus prompted sorrow and rage in India on Saturday morning.

headline: Events in Westchester
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

headline: Events in Connecticut
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

headline: Events in New Jersey
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.
