text: NEW YORK

headline: Events on Long Island
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

headline: A Trainer Keeps Up With His Toddler
text: Sunday is the one day of the week when Court Wing, the head trainer and a founder of CrossFit NYC, doesn’t train clients in the high-intensity, boot-camp-style conditioning routine that he describes as a mix of powerlifting, track and field, and gymnastics. That is not to say that Mr. Wing, 44 and a Seattle native, doesn’t work out. His Sundays are usually devoted to “recovery work” — fitness-fan-speak for flexibility and range-of-motion training. He also exercises by chasing his 20-month-old son, Asher, around his apartment in Astoria, Queens, while his wife, Morgan, 36, a social worker, takes a bit of well-deserved rest.

headline: A Wish List for Next Year in New York
text: Although it is hard to recall what we obsessed over before the emergencies of very recent memory, it was, in fact, a long and eventful year in the life and culture of New York City. We fought about teacher evaluations and a plan for the New York Public Library’s central branch to move rarely used books offsite. We watched gleefully as members of the Park Slope Food Co-op squabbled with parliamentary intensity over whether to introduce a boycott of Israeli products.

headline: A Soul Surfer Who Dances With Winter Waves
text: NOW that beach weather has finally rolled round, Banshidhar Medeiros, 59, a factory worker from Queens and a lifelong surfer, can be found paddling out at sunrise on almost any day the surf is up.

headline: What’s On Saturday
text: 11:15 A.M. (Showtime) STARDUST (2007) Charlie Cox is Tristan, a young man desperate to prove that he would do anything to win the love of his lady fair (Sienna Miller), which includes bringing her a falling star that recently crashed near their village. But to reach the star he must travel to the magical realm of Stormhold, where the star takes the form of a human (Claire Danes, above with Mr. Cox). He also encounters a rapidly aging witch, Lamia (Michelle Pfeiffer), and the cross-dressing captain (Robert De Niro) of a flying pirate ship. Directed by Matthew Vaughn and adapted from the graphic novel written by Neil Gaiman and illustrated by Charles Vess, this fantasy tale “barrels forward with a fearless audacity,” Stephen Holden wrote in The New York Times. Mr. Holden found Ms. Pfeiffer’s Lamia to be “as deliciously evil a witch as the movies have ever invented.” He added, “As the embodiment of every vain, wicked stepmother in fairy tale literature mixed with the cauldron-tending crones of ‘Macbeth’ (Lamia is one of three cackling sisters), Ms. Pfeiffer goes for broke with the relish of a star who figures she has nothing to lose.”

headline: A Kaleidoscope of Lights and Crowds
text: Times Square is so crowded, so bright with distractions, that visitors may feel they have walked into an overpopulated and hypercommercial future. But the square’s identity is rooted in the early 1900s, when earlier technologies — the subway and the electric light bulb — made possible its development, from a shabby center for the horse and livery businesses to a hub for news media, entertainment and, increasingly, shopping.

headline: Where Ethnicity Was Fluid
text: IN “Bengali Harlem and the Lost Histories of South Asian America” (Harvard University Press, $35), Vivek Bald, who teaches writing and digital media at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, has produced an engaging account of a largely untold wave of immigration: Muslims from British India who arrived in the late 19th and early 20th centuries.

headline: Answers to Questions About New York
text: Merging Cars and Bikes

headline: Nocturnal Signs, With Character
text: Images from James and Karla Murray’s “New York Nights,” a new book of photos of a vanishing city.

headline: Knicks Fight All the Way Back, Only to Be Blindsided at the Buzzer
text: SACRAMENTO — The Knicks faced a daunting task Friday night when they found themselves down by 27 points in a road game in which they were without Carmelo Anthony, their top scorer, and Raymond Felton, their starting point guard.

headline: The Norwegian Football Wonder
text: Our colleague David Picker writes about Havard Rugland, a Norwegian with a good foot who knew nothing at all about American football, but — thanks to his viral video — has a tryout for the New York Jets football team.

headline: IHT Quick Read: Dec. 29
text: NEWS Officials appealed for calm as protesters gathered after the death of the student who was attacked by a group of men in New Delhi. Heather Timmons and Sruthi Gottipati report from New Delhi.

headline: Protests Across India Over Death of Gang Rape Victim
text: Bring white roses, some suggested. Get angry, some said. Don’t resort to violence, others begged.

headline: France’s 75 Percent Tax Rate Struck Down on Constitutional Grounds
text: France’s Constitutional Council overturned a 75 percent tax rate on incomes above €1 million euros, or $1.3 million, on Saturday.

headline: Six Charged With Murder in India After Rape Victim’s Death
text: NEW DELHI — As protests grew in India on Saturday over the death of a young woman who was raped in New Delhi this month by several men in a moving bus, the police said six men accused of attacking her had been charged with murder.

headline: European Union Plans to Accentuate the Positive in 2013
text: LONDON — With the prospect of more troubles ahead for the European Union in 2013, officials have launched a campaign to remind its 500 million citizens of the benefits of belonging to the 27-nation alliance.

headline: Rex Ryan’s Denials and Latest Jets Drama
text: In retrospect, the New York Post season preview cover with the Jets depicted as clowns might have been understated. Here’s an attempt to sort out the latest drama in Jetsland.

headline: On the Economics and Politics of Deficits
text: Evan Soltas of Wonkblog and Joe Weisenthal of Business Insider both make the same point, in more detail, that I tried to make in my series on ONE TRILLION DOLLARS: the current budget deficit is overwhelmingly the result of the depressed economy, and it’s not clear that we have a structural budget problem at all, let alone the fundamental mismatch between what we want and what we’re willing to pay for that people like to claim exists. Here’s another chart, showing the primary federal balance — that is, not counting interest payments — since 1972 (data from CBO):

headline: Once Upon a Time, 200 Years Later, in Pictures
text: This month marks the bicentennial of the publication of Jacob and Wilhelm Grimm’s “Kinder-und Hausmärchen” — “Children’s and Household Tales,” in English, but more commonly known as Grimms’ Fairy Tales. The collection of stories — “Sleeping Beauty,” “Little Red Riding Hood” and “Rumpelstiltskin” are just a few of the most well known — have been revised, retold, reinterpreted and even Disneyfied so many times over the past two centuries that it’s easy to forget the original tales were a potent mix of the macabre, fantastical and downright creepy.

headline: Russia’s Adoption Ban Plays Politics With Most Vulnerable
text: Even my 7-year-old knows there are some things that you just don’t use as ammunition in an argument.

headline: On Skis, Sharpening a Relationship With Risk
text: I know what I’ve become. The vegan restaurant answers my calls with, “Chakra roll again, Melissa?” The only action my Patagonia jacket gets is walking to Equinox. I pay $14 for a vodka/soda. It has been seven years since I moved to Manhattan from a mountain hiking town of 7,537 people in California. I can’t remember the last time I dug a hole to poop in. I’ve gone city soft.

headline: Insisting on Assad’s Exit Will Cost More Lives, Russian Says
text: MOSCOW — Russia’s foreign minister, Sergey V. Lavrov, said Saturday that there was “no possibility” of persuading President Bashar al-Assad to leave Syria, leaving little hope for a breakthrough in the standoff. He also said that the opposition leaders’ insistence on Mr. Assad’s departure as a precondition for peace talks would come at the cost of “more and more lives of Syrian citizens” in a conflict that has already killed tens of thousands.

headline: Big Dream, Rude Awakening
text: AMHERST, Mass. — Hung from lampposts and tacked to bulletin boards, the maroon and white banners were everywhere this past fall on the pastoral campus of the University of Massachusetts.

headline: Fast Learner’s Newest Lesson Focuses on Self-Preservation
text: ASHBURN, Va. — Almost a year ago, Bill Polian, then the president of the Indianapolis Colts, was scouting players to possibly take with the first overall draft pick. He told the team’s owner, Jim Irsay, that there was no question Robert Griffin III was a can’t-miss player, perhaps a once-in-a-lifetime prospect, and that either he or Andrew Luck would “lead you to the promised land.”

headline: Finally, Something James Doesn’t Do
text: Occasionally, an N.B.A. player comes so close to perfection in one aspect of the game that he turns his attention to another skill. Think of Wilt Chamberlain leading the league in assists or Michael Jordan eschewing the slam dunk competition for the 3-point contest. For LeBron James, who has conquered virtually every obstacle put in front of him, the next frontier appears to be a complete avoidance of personal fouls.

headline: Senate Seeks Bipartisan Formula to Reach Tax Deal
text: WASHINGTON — Senate leaders and their aides spent Saturday searching for a formula to extend tax cuts for most Americans that could win bipartisan support in the Senate and final approval in the fractious House by the new year, hoping to prevent large tax increases and budget cuts that could threaten the fragile economy.

headline: Matchup: Eagles (4-11) at Giants (8-7)
text: 1 p.m. Eastern, Fox

headline: Matchup: Jets (6-9) at Bills (5-10)
text: 1 p.m. Eastern, CBS

headline: A Discovery, Marooned in Libya’s Revolution
text: As Adam Nagourney reports in The Times, Death Valley is experiencing a burst of civic pride over reclaiming a world temperature record: a 134-degree reading registered on July 10, 1913, at Greenland Ranch in California.

headline: Tynes, Recalling ’06 Chiefs, Knows Giants Aren’t Done Yet
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — For Giants kicker Lawrence Tynes, the feeling of confusion came rushing back quickly. As soon as the final game of the 2006 N.F.L. season was mentioned to him last week, Tynes — who was then with the Kansas City Chiefs — began shaking his head.

headline: Jets’ Fiasco With Tebow Ranks Right Down There
text: Last November, about two hours after Tim Tebow and the Denver Broncos beat the Jets, 17-13, on a last-minute touchdown, paramedics rushed to Denver International Airport. Jets Coach Rex Ryan feared he was having a heart attack.

headline: French Council Strikes Down 75% Tax Rate
text: PARIS — France’s Constitutional Council on Saturday struck down the Socialist government’s plan to impose a 75 percent marginal income tax rate on the wealthy, a measure that figured prominently among the campaign promises of President François Hollande and that had become a divisive emblem of his approach to cutting the budget deficit.

headline: Amish Await Hate Crime Sentences
text: Members of an isolated Amish community in eastern Ohio fear long prison sentences for 16 community members convicted of attacking other Amish and cutting their beards and hair.

headline: Braced for Hardship, an Amish Clan Awaits Sentences in Shearing Attacks
text: BERGHOLZ, Ohio — At their afternoon meeting in a bare farmhouse room, in a circle with infants on their laps and toddlers tugging at their skirts, the women of this breakaway Amish settlement have some most un-Amish matters to discuss.

headline: A Year After Attacks, an Amish Community Grapples With Its Future
text: The insular clan led by Samuel Mullet Sr., who was convicted of hate crimes, is awaiting the sentencing of its members who were convicted in the attacks last year.

headline: Variety: Un Divertente Gioco Acrostico
text: VARIETY PUZZLE — Man, I really hope that title is accurate. It’s supposed to say “A Fun Acrostic,” but you know how online translation services can be. Apologies in advance if I’ve inadvertently insulted anyone’s mother.

headline: Community Says Punitive Cutting of Hair Began as a Reminder to Repent
text: BERGHOLZ, Ohio — More than a year before the violent beard-cutting assaults on outside Amish that brought notoriety and felony convictions to the insular Bergholz settlement, several followers of Samuel Mullet Sr., the clan’s leader, used similar practices on each other.

headline: In Next Scene: A Dark Cloud Lifts
text: CHICAGO — Before he died, Declan Sullivan wrote screenplays. He made short films, played trumpet, loved music and movies, studied business and, in his remaining free time at Notre Dame, videotaped football practice for the Fighting Irish.

headline: N.F.L. Maneuvering Gives TV a Prime Attraction for Prime Time
text: The planning for the final day of the N.F.L.’s regular season began almost three weeks ago, when NBC lobbied the league to let it show the Dallas Cowboys’ game against the New Orleans Saints last Sunday, instead of the Seattle-San Francisco game it was eventually awarded.

headline: A Place to Discover the Next Great Play
text: WITH its new monthly Theater in the Loft series, which kicks off Jan. 13 in the 100-seat Loft at the South Orange Performing Arts Center, the Midtown Direct Rep theater company intends to introduce little-known plays with potential, said Sandy Rustin, one of the company’s two artistic directors, who lives in Maplewood.

headline: Coal Giant Drops Claim That it is ‘the Global Leader in Clean Energy Solutions’
text: Peabody Energy, the biggest private-sector coal company in the world, has removed the claim that it is “the global leader in clean energy solutions” from its home page. The two images below show the shift (sometime between Dec. 19 and Dec. 29), with the claim now reading that the company is “the global leader in clean coal solutions”:

headline: Woman Is Charged With Murder as a Hate Crime in a Fatal Subway Push
text: A 31-year-old woman was arrested on Saturday and charged with second-degree murder as a hate crime in connection with the death of a man who was pushed onto the tracks of an elevated subway station in Queens and crushed by an oncoming train.

headline: Winter’s Deadly Bite Returns to Refugee Camps of Kabul
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — The snow that fell on a refugee camp in Kabul last week left thick powder piled voluptuously on the sagging roofs of huts and skinny tree branches, turning the squalor into a winter wonderland. The mistake of a toddler named Janan was to play in it.

headline: Leaders’ Response Magnifies Outrage in India Rape Case
text: NEW DELHI — India often seems to careen from crisis to crisis, with protests regularly spilling onto the streets over the latest outrage or scandal, a nation seemingly always on the boil. But when things settle, as they inevitably do, little seems to change. Public anger usually cools to a simmer.

headline: Personal Finance Advice, Taken to the Woodshed
text: IT’S rare to come across a realistic and readable book about personal finance. Most are laden with rosy promises, followed by acronyms and turgid advice. Helaine Olen, a freelance journalist, offers an exception with “Pound Foolish: Exposing the Dark Side of the Personal Finance Industry” (Portfolio, $27.95). It’s a take-no-prisoners examination of the ways she says we have been scared, misled or bamboozled by those purporting to help us achieve financial security.

headline: Don’t Just Talk About Change. Show It.
text: I WAS born in 1956. I should have been reading in grade school, but I’m dyslexic — I have trouble reading, writing and spelling — and few people knew much about the condition in those days. My mother realized that something was wrong, but she didn’t know what. She advocated for me at school and told my teachers not to give up on me. I attended five grammar schools because my mother was constantly looking for something to help me. It was a lonely childhood, and I hate to think how I might have ended up if she hadn’t been so supportive.

headline: Progress Where They Make iPhones
text: Apple, whose products the world cannot get enough of, has been justifiably criticized for poor working conditions and low wages at the factories of its chief supplier in China, Foxconn. Now, however, there are signs that all the negative attention, including reports in this newspaper, has caused the companies to make changes, like raising wages, limiting work hours and providing chairs with backs instead of stools at workstations.

headline: Angéline Templier
text: Angéline Templier is a French winemaker at the matriarchal Champagne house of J. Lassalle. She and her mother and grandmother oversee an annual production of 100,000 bottles of artisanal Champagne from their 27 acres in the rural town of Chigny les Roses in northeastern France.

headline: Venezuelan Finds Asylum, and a Career, in New York
text: It is very difficult for Maria Marquez, 33, to talk about her past. She can be specific about certain things, but not many. The danger just feels too real.

headline: Why the Economy Needs Tax Reform
text: Over the next four years, tax reform, done right, could be a cure for much of what ails the economy. Higher taxes, raised progressively, could encourage growth by helping to pay for long-neglected public investment in education, infrastructure and basic research. More revenue would also reduce budget deficits, helping to put the nation’s finances on a stable path. Greater progressivity would reduce rising income inequality, and with it, inequality of opportunity that is both an economic and social scourge.

headline: Drones for South Korea
text: Less than a month after North Korea’s latest missile test, the Obama administration has offered to sell South Korea advanced spy drones so it can keep a closer eye on its northern adversary. The decision raises some concerns, and Congress would be wise to ask a lot of questions before going along, including whether the deal is part of a comprehensive strategy or just a way to penalize North Korea.

headline: So Many Snapshots, So Few Voices Saved
text: I just got my voice back. At least I’m told it’s my voice. A surgeon did a couple of hours’ work on one of my vocal cords, removing a papilloma, and on Christmas Day, after two weeks of silence, I spoke.

headline: Hitting China With Humor
text: Beijing

headline: Conservation Militias Fight Poaching in Kenya
text: The Kenyan government is struggling to win the war in the fight against illegally killed elephants.

headline: To Save Wildlife, and Tourism, Kenyans Take Up Arms
text: ARCHER’S POST, Kenya — Julius Lokinyi was one of the most notorious poachers in this part of Kenya, accused of single-handedly killing as many as 100 elephants and selling the tusks by the side of the road in the dead of night, pumping vast amounts of ivory into a shadowy global underground trade.

headline: How to Read in 2013
text: COME what may in the next 12 months, 2013 has this much going for it: It’s a year without a midterm election, and a year that’s as far removed as possible from the next presidential race. This means that for a blessed 365 days you can be a well-informed and responsible American citizen without reading every single article on Politico, without hitting refresh every 30 seconds on your polling-average site of choice, without channel-hopping between Chris Matthews’s hyperventilating and Dick Morris’s promises of an inevitable Republican landslide.

headline: Things I Saw — No. 50
text: Suggestions for what you’d like Jason to see and draw may be sent to thingsisaw@nytimes.com.

headline: You Can Go Home Again, for an Extra $4,586
text: THE Haggler is always a little reluctant to print air travel nightmare stories, in large part because there are so many of them. And whenever one problem is solved in this space, dozens of new ones show up. So let’s make a rule: By all means, send your travel nightmare story, but only if it is more grueling and costly than the one you are about to read — which, as we shall see, sets the ordeal bar very, very high.

headline: Two Wars Against Cancer
text: MY identical twin sister, Karen, and I have two older brothers. We were raised in Blue Bell, Pa., where my father was a family physician and my mother was a nurse. We spent summers on Long Beach Island, N.J., where both of us were waitresses at a busy seafood restaurant.

headline: The Power of a Hot Body
text: As I waited with a throng of Parisians in the Rambuteau Metro station on a blustery day, my frozen toes finally began to thaw. Alone we may have shivered, but together we brewed so much body heat that people began unbuttoning their coats. We might have been penguins crowding for warmth in Antarctica’s icy torment of winds. Idly mingling, a human body radiates about 100 watts of excess heat, which can add up fast in confined spaces.

headline: Wishful Thinking and Middle-Class Taxes
text: IN the continuing fiscal negotiations between President Obama and House Republicans, both sides have, from the very beginning, agreed on one point: Taxes on the middle class must not rise. But maybe it’s time to reconsider this premise. An unwavering commitment to keep middle-class taxes low could be one reason the political process has become so deeply dysfunctional.

headline: Video Shows Plane Crashing on to Moscow Highway
text: Last Updated, Sunday, 6:10 p.m. A Russian passenger jet overshot the runway at Vnukovo airport near Moscow on Saturday and crashed into a highway, killing at least four people, all of them crew members, the authorities said.

headline: Ratings for Citi Field Bonds Lowered
text: With one glaring exception, the Mets appear to be in cost-cutting mode this winter. Yes, David Wright agreed to an eight-year, $138 million contract this month.

headline: Sure, Big Data Is Great. But So Is Intuition.
text: It was the bold title of a conference this month at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, and of a widely read article in The Harvard Business Review last October: “Big Data: The Management Revolution.”

headline: Conquering Your Fears of Giving Feedback
text: This interview with   Karen May, vice president for people development at Google, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

headline: Beyond the Temporary Fix
text: To the Editor:

headline: Due Diligence, Long Forgotten
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Power of Mad
text: To the Editor:

headline: Fiscal Cliff: Changes Set to Occur if Congress Takes No Action
text: Several tax and spending changes will occur over the next year if the White House and Congress fail to reach a deal to avert them.

headline: Were Obama’s Early Ads Really the Game Changer?
text: Many post-mortems of the 2012 presidential campaign suggest that Mitt Romney erred by allowing President Obama to “define” him early through an advertising blitz in battleground states. Certainly Mr. Obama’s advisers have trumpeted the success of this strategy. A few weeks after the election, a Bloomberg News article about an appearance by the Obama campaign strategist David Axelrod said:

headline: An Idea Promised the Sky, but India Is Still Waiting
text: NEW DELHI — The idea was, and still is, captivating: in 2011, the Indian government and two Indian-born tech entrepreneurs unveiled a $50 tablet computer, to be built in India with Google’s free Android software. The government would buy the computers by the millions and give them to its schoolchildren.

headline: Questcor Finds Profits, at $28,000 a Vial
text: ANAHEIM, Calif.

headline: Notable Opinion Art of 2012
text: The New York Times opinion section commissions at least 30 original illustrations each week, more than 1,500 each year. Our tradition of using art to bring an incisive, witty or provocative perspective on current affairs dates to the creation of the Op-Ed page in 1970, and expanded with the creation of the Sunday Review section (formerly the Week in Review) in 2011. Here is a sampling of illustrations from the past year.

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, Dec. 30
text: As the deadline to avert the automatic tax increases and spending cuts of the so-called fiscal cliff draws near, the Sunday shows feature members of Congress and, most notably, President Obama, who will join NBC’s “Meet the Press.”

headline: Ai Weiwei and the Communist Party, Tormenting Each Other
text: My Sunday column is about the great Chinese artist Ai Weiwei and the challenge he and people like him present to the Chinese leadership. I do think it’s a sign of progress that Ai is today free from prison and able to needle the Party. One of the ways to measure the new leader, Xi Jinping, will be whether Ai is left alone — and whether Liu Xiaobo, the Nobel Peace Prize-winning writer, is released from jail.

headline: Pakistan Lifts, Then Reinstates, YouTube Ban
text: As my colleague Salman Masood reported on Twitter, online rejoicing at the end of Pakistan’s three-month ban on YouTube was short-lived on Saturday, as the government reimposed the ban shortly after it was lifted following reports that copies of a low-budget film mocking the Prophet Muhammad appeared in searches of the site.

headline: Plus Ten
text: SUNDAY’S PUZZLE — How do you decide whether you’ve enjoyed solving a crossword puzzle? I realize that enjoyment is more of a visceral experience than an intellectual one, but I think it’s worth taking a closer look at this thing we do and figuring it out.

headline: Mystery Powder Leads to Evacuations in Greenwich Village
text: A search for narcotics in a Greenwich Village apartment on Saturday morning led to a call to the bomb squad and evacuations after detectives discovered explosive powder, the police said.

headline: A Spending-Limits Bill Serves as a Great Excuse
text: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a column for The Tribune.

headline: Medicaid Waiver Presents Structuring Challenges
text: By year’s end, health care providers across Texas will have submitted proposals to state leaders to transform the way they care for the poor and the uninsured. They have been spurred by a Medicaid waiver Texas officials sought and received in 2011 from the federal government, one that ties financing to cooperation, cost efficiency and better patient outcomes.

headline: Dancing the Apocalypse Away, Extravagantly
text: Elvira Butz, a septuagenarian adventurer who has dived to the Titanic aboard a Russian submersible, trekked solo through the rain forests of Papua New Guinea and searched for meteorites in Antarctica, spent the final minutes of Dec. 21, 2012, the day the Mayans supposedly predicted the world would end, dancing to “Gangnam Style” at the base of a 30-foot replica of a Mayan pyramid built on the shore of Lake Austin.

headline: In Mexico, a New Approach to Stanching Drug Violence
text: NUEVO LAREDO, Mexico — The military tank that had stood at the entrance to this Mexican border city since 2008 was not here on Christmas Eve. Neither was the machine gun turret that pointed down this gritty town’s main street.

headline: Building Congregations Around Art Galleries and Cafes as Spirituality Wanes
text: DALLAS — The mural painted on the side of a building in the Deep Ellum warehouse district here is intentionally vague, simply showing a faceless man in a suit holding an umbrella over the words “Life in Deep Ellum.” Inside there are the trappings of a revitalization project, including an art gallery, a yoga studio and a business incubator, sharing the building with a coffee shop and a performance space.

headline: Smoke but Little Fire After Manhole Blasts in SoHo
text: The explosion echoed in the streets of SoHo on Saturday afternoon as tourists walked along dampened sidewalks and a crowd gathered inside the Fanelli Cafe, one of New York City’s older restaurants.

headline: Pakistan Lifts YouTube Ban, for 3 Minutes
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — A ban on YouTube, which Pakistan imposed after an anti-Islam video caused riots in much of the Muslim world, was lifted Saturday, only to be reinstated — after three minutes — when it was discovered that blasphemous material was still available on the site.

headline: Biden Is Back for a 2nd Run at Gun Limits
text: WASHINGTON — Never much known for restraint, Joseph R. Biden Jr. did not hold back during a presidential primary debate in 2007 when a voter asking about gun rights in a recorded video displayed a fearsome-looking semiautomatic rifle and declared, “This is my baby.”

headline: Drone Spy Wars
text: Al Qaeda and Taliban-supported death squads accuse tribesmen of collaborating with the United States, and often force them to confess on video before executing them.

headline: Drone War Spurs Militants to Deadly Reprisals
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — They are dead men talking, and they know it. Gulping nervously, the prisoners stare into the video camera, spilling tales of intrigue, betrayal and paid espionage on behalf of the United States. Some speak in trembling voices, a glint of fear in their eyes. Others look resigned. All plead for their lives.

headline: A Soul Surfer, in Winter
text: Freezing temperatures cannot keep Banshidhar Medeiros, 59, a meditation student and lifelong surfer from Queens, from finding his bliss in winter waves.

headline: Stunned and Battered, Knicks Need Break
text: The Knicks returned to New York on Saturday physically beaten up and coming off one of their most agonizing losses of the season, a 106-105 defeat to the Kings in Sacramento.

headline: UConn Repays Stanford by Ending Long Streak
text: STANFORD, Calif. — For the viewing public, this was a matchup between the nation’s top-ranked teams. For Connecticut, there was also the small matter of revenge.

headline: Sloshing and Churning, Syracuse Routs West Virginia in Pinstripe Bowl
text: A few years ago, a matchup between Syracuse and West Virginia would have constituted a typical Saturday afternoon Big East game, maybe on a crisp day in October. For 56 years, from 1955 to 2011, they battled that way, always in the regular season.

headline: Coming Soon to Belgian Village, a French Film Idol Fleeing Taxes
text: NÉCHIN, Belgium — The last time a big star lit up this sleepy village of potato fields and rain-drenched pastures was in 1667, when the Sun King, Louis XIV of France, stopped by for the day. But even he may not have created quite the commotion caused by Gérard Depardieu, the celebrated actor, turbulent bon vivant and, since a visit to the mayor’s office here on Dec. 7 to register as a resident, France’s most reviled tax exile.

headline: Halfway Houses Prove Lucrative to Those at Top
text: The Kintock Group, the second-largest operator of halfway houses in New Jersey, is a nonprofit agency that is financed almost entirely by government contracts. But it is run like a well-heeled family business.

headline: Jeffrey Potter, Biographer of Pollock, Dies at 94
text: Jeffrey Potter was an aspiring writer working as a building contractor in the Hamptons in 1949 when he developed a friendship with a gruff, taciturn neighbor who shared his passion for oversized machines like backhoes, bulldozers, dredgers and jacks big enough to lift a house from its foundations.

headline: A Veteran Hangs on to His Title, but a Young Champion Is Dethroned
text: A changing of the guard was anticipated in the top ranks this year. It was the men’s champion, now 43, whom many thought to be vulnerable. But it was the teenage women’s champion who was dethroned.

headline: Nets Talk Over Lunch and Win After Dinner
text: A Russian billionaire and a coaching lifer from Scranton, Pa., walked into a Greek restaurant, providing the setup for a corny punch line or perhaps an agenda for the future of the Nets. Or maybe it was just a lunch.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, Dec. 30
text: We just can’t afford a politically self-inflicted wound to our economy.

headline: Corrections: December 30, 2012
text: INTERNATIONAL

headline: Megan Healey, JC Leston
text: Megan Marie Healey and J Christian Leston were married Saturday in Hicksville, N.Y. Frank Crivello, a Roman Catholic deacon, performed the ceremony at the Church of St. Ignatius Loyola.

headline: Seth Thayer Jr. and Gregory Tinder
text: Seth Alexander Thayer Jr. and Gregory Nelson Tinder were married Saturday at their home in Northport, Me. R. Declan O’Connor, a notary public and a friend of the couple, officiated.

headline: Ryan Murphy, Courtney Jeske
text: Ryan Chandra Murphy and Courtney Aaron Jeske are to be married Sunday afternoon at the Church of the Blessed Sacrament in New York. Msgr. Robert B. O’Connor, the pastor of the church, officiated.

headline: Sara Chidester and Stephen Gould
text: Dr. Sara Janine Chidester and Dr. Stephen Alexander Gould are to be married Sunday at Catlin Gardens, an inn in Slate Hill, N.Y. Cantor Judith K. Steel is to officiate with the Rev. Harold Steindam, a minister of the United Church of Christ, taking part.

headline: Dolores Swirin, Paul Yao
text: Dolores Anne Swirin and Paul Lin Yao were married Monday at the couple’s apartment in Brooklyn. Cantor Lisa B. Segal officiated.

headline: Matthew Sobaski, David Marchi
text: Matthew Christopher Sobaski and David John Marchi were married Thursday in New York. The Rev. Alma Daniel, a nondenominational minister, officiated at the Angel Orensanz Foundation for the Arts.

headline: Allison Rothman, Paul Strachman
text: Allison Elizabeth Rothman and Paul Pinkhas Strachman were married Saturday evening at Liberty Warehouse, an event space in Brooklyn. Rabbi Arthur D. Weiner officiated.

headline: Beth DeWoody and Firooz Zahedi
text: Beth Rudin DeWoody and Firooz Zahedi were married Wednesday afternoon by Patricia Alexander, a Florida notary, at the bride’s house in West Palm Beach, Fla. That evening, Koginka Kamaru Xue, a shaman, led a spiritual ceremony in the same location.

headline: Grace Clawater and Mark Doramus Jr.
text: Rebekah Grace Clawater, a daughter of Hollee Hedge Clawater and D. Wayne Clawater of Houston, was married Saturday in Houston to Mark Christopher Doramus Jr., a son of Laura Laker Doramus and Mr. Doramus Sr. of Little Rock, Ark. The Very Rev. Dr. J. Pittman McGehee performed the ceremony at Christ Church Episcopal Cathedral, of which he is a former dean.

headline: Sasha Rutizer and Jenifer Markowitz
text: Army Capt. Sasha Noel Rutizer and Jenifer Robin Markowitz were married Saturday at the Hillyer Art Space in Washington. Judge Douglas Miles of the El Paso County Court in Colorado received permission from Superior Court of the District of Columbia to officiate. Rabbi Kenneth Block took part in the ceremony.

headline: Trending in Asia in 2012: Our Top 10
text: Our most popular Asia posts of 2012, by the number of readers and/or the number of comments:

headline: How to Blog Asia for the MSM
text: If you’re a close reader of IHT Rendezvous, you’re jonesing for a fix of Mark McDonald right about now. Our peripatetic Asia blogger’s last day writing was Wednesday. He’s moving on to other assignments. We’ll miss him.

headline: Elegy in Neon
text: NEW YORK CITY exists in a perpetual state of reinvention. That is its nature. What was here yesterday is something else today and will be something new again tomorrow. That change sustains the city, imparts it with a vital energy that keeps it from becoming a frozen museum of itself, like Paris or Rome.

headline: Newswallah: Long Reads Edition
text: The end of the year is always a time of reflection for journalists, who look back on the changes and transformations that occurred in the year gone by. In Open Magazine, Manu Joseph describes the rise of the “New Rebel,” the young, educated and affluent person who is angered by the state of the nation.He writes: “Till not so long ago, they were never a crowd except in happy times — a college festival or a rock concert. But now they walk in giant furious swarms, having done their apprenticeship in rebellion under Team Anna last year, holding English placards, abusing the few politicians whose names they know. Nobody’s votebank, orphaned by their own republic, they march to some monument or other to become news.”

headline: Newswallah: Bharat Edition
text: Jammu and Kashmir: The longest rail tunnel in India, which cuts through the foothills of the Pir Panjal mountain range, opened for a trial run on Thursday, the Hindustan Times reported. The 11-kilometer, or 6.8-mile, railway track cost the government 13 billion rupees, or $236 million. It will connect Kashmir to the rest of the country via rail for the first time. The track is expected to be functional next year.

headline: Giants’ Probabilities for Playoffs
text: Under the headline “The Indescribable Collapse of the Incomprehensible 2012 Giants,” Greg Hanlon of CapitalNewYork.com summed up what Giants fans know well:

headline: At Delhi Protest Ground, Talk of Causes Behind Violence Against Women
text: The body of the 23-year-old victim of a fatal gang rape in New Delhi this month was returned to India from Singapore early Sunday, as calls for government action and protests in response to the attack continued to rouse people across India.

headline: Game Theory: The Year of Antisocial Gaming
text: It had been a while since any of my friends had spent significant time together online in Call of Duty or Madden or World of Warcraft or any of the big-budget experiences we knew as multiplayer gaming. Things like deadlines, dinner parties and changing diapers were taking up all of our time. But suddenly, here we were, playing and competing with one another just like the old days.

headline: Day of Seesaw Talks Produces No Accord on Fiscal Crisis
text: WASHINGTON — Senate leaders on Sunday failed to produce a fiscal deal with just hours to go before large tax increases and spending cuts were to begin taking effect on New Year’s Day, despite a round of volatile negotiations over the weekend and an attempt by Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. to intervene.

headline: 2012: The Year in Graphics
text: A selection of graphics and interactives from 2012 with information on how they were produced.

headline: Fisher Island: Paradise Built
text: Three miles off the coast of Miami lies a 216-acre man-made island that has long been home to the rich and powerful. But legal troubles may intrude upon the seclusion residents covet.

headline: Disruptions: The Real Hazards of E-Devices on Planes
text: Over the last year, flying with phones and other devices has become increasingly dangerous.

headline: Several Eras End at One Lower East Side Building
text: The collapse and demolition in 2006 of the First Roumanian-American Congregation synagogue at 89 Rivington Street — the “cantors’ Carnegie Hall” — seemed to have eradicated almost every trace of what was once a large and vibrant Jewish community.

headline: 19 Shiite Pilgrims Bound for Iran Are Killed in Pakistan
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — At least 19 Shiite pilgrims, including four women, were killed Sunday when their convoy of three buses in southwestern Pakistan was struck by a remotely detonated bomb, officials said. At least 25 other people were wounded in the attack in the Mastung district of Baluchistan Province.

headline: In Europe, Focus Begins to Shift to the Speed of a Nascent Recovery
text: SAY what you will about the euro zone’s quarreling policy makers. They can claim at least one achievement during 2012: their common currency still has a heartbeat.

headline: The Hostage Drama Begins
text: It sure looks as if we’re going over the fiscal cliff, but that may be the least of our problems. The debt ceiling is a much bigger and more dangerous issue, and it looks very much as if Republicans are set to destroy the full faith and credit of the United States if they can’t get their way.

headline: ‘The Hobbit’ Holds Lead at Busy Movie Theaters
text: Bloody violence (“Django Unchained”) and dirty actors singing (“Les Misérables”) both intrigued North American movie audiences over the weekend, but it was a furry-footed holdover that claimed the No. 1 spot: “The Hobbit: An Unexpected Journey,” distributed by Warner Brothers, took in a robust $32.9 million, for a new three-week domestic total of $222.7 million.

headline: Afghan Camps Receive Winter Aid, but Officials Say It Isn’t Enough
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — The United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees on Sunday distributed emergency cold-weather supplies to families in a refugee camp where two days earlier a 3-year-old died of exposure to the freezing temperatures.

headline: What’s on Monday
text: 10 P.M. (ABC) DICK CLARK’S NEW YEAR’S ROCKIN’ EVE WITH RYAN SEACREST 2013 Taylor Swift, Carly Rae Jepsen and Neon Trees join Mr. Seacrest, above, in New York to help ring in the new year during this celebration from Times Square. Fergie of the Black Eyed Peas hosts segments from Los Angeles with appearances by Brandy, Flo Rida, Karmin, OneRepublic and Pitbull. “New Year’s Rockin’ Eve Celebrates Dick Clark,” recalling the TV host, who died in April at 82, leads in at 8.

headline: Newtown Shooting the Worst Day of His Presidency, Obama Says
text: President Obama said Sunday that the day of the shooting at Sandy Hook Elementary School in Newtown, Conn., was the worst of his presidency and that he wanted new legislation limiting access to some types of firearms passed within the first year of his second term.

headline: Is Our Austerians Learning?
text: Paul Solman has a post on Greg Mankiw’s attempt at a gotcha over my views circa 2003 on the consequences of deficits. As Solman notes, not only are the situations very different, I’ve also long since acknowledged that I was wrong, and have explained how and why I modified my views as a result. Extra bonus: notice how Mankiw, faced with the failure of his gotcha, immediately tries to claim that he wasn’t actually saying what he was, in fact, saying.

headline: Dr. Rita Levi-Montalcini, Nobel Winner, Dies at 103
text: Dr. Rita Levi-Montalcini, a Nobel Prize-winning neurologist who discovered critical chemical tools that the body uses to direct cell growth and build nerve networks, opening the way for the study of how those processes can go wrong in diseases like dementia and cancer, died on Sunday at her home in Rome. She was 103.

headline: Republicans Consider Changing Electoral Vote Counting to Improve Presidential Odds
text: WASHINGTON — Not too long ago, political analysts assumed the Republicans had a clear advantage in the Electoral College, the system according to which each state, based on population, is given electors that in almost all cases are awarded on a winner-take-all basis, determining who will be the president of the United States. Today, it’s the Democrats who have the edge.

headline: Big Depositors Seek a New Safety Net
text: On the first day of the New Year, $1.5 trillion of bank deposits will lose an unlimited government guarantee that was granted during the financial crisis to assure skittish customers that their cash was safe. For a handful of boutique firms that service banks, it’s a boon for business.

headline: Heavens to Betsy
text: Given this blog’s growing readership, I find it necessary every once in a while to remind people of the rules on commenting. In particular, the Grey Lady is very Victorian; comments containing obscenities will not be posted except through oversight. For what it’s worth, by the way, when I do the moderation myself — which is some of the time — the obscene language seems more common in supportive than critical comments. Hey, I often feel like cursing too. No matter, it’s still forbidden

headline: How to Help
text: The aid organization with the most permanent presence in Kabul’s refugee camps is a respected Afghan group, Aschiana, which also runs schools that provide students with hot lunches. Aschiana’s United States fund-raising branch can be reached at www.aschiana-foundation.org, and their Afghan office is at www.aschiana.com.

headline: Afghan Troop Deaths Rise as Army Expands Its Role
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — The Afghan government has hit a grim record in its quest to take over the country’s security from coalition forces: more than 1,000 soldiers died in 2012, a roughly 20 percent increase from 2011.

headline: Mellower? Maybe, but the Barbs Still Sting
text: To describe Sandra Bernhard nowadays as a mellower version of the comic sniper she used to be is not to say that she has lost her edge. In her monologues on Friday evening at Joe’s Pub, where she is performing a series of end-of-the-year shows, this comedian and singer, now 57 (but looking two decades younger), seemed on top of current trends in music and fashion as ever. And she flung out some choice but unprintable words for the year we are leaving behind.

headline: For Day Laborers, Used to Scraping By, Hurricane Creates a Wealth of Work
text: The day after the storm, Manuel Sinchi, like some other New Yorkers, gathered a few friends, hopped on his bicycle and headed down to badly stricken Coney Island to volunteer his services.

headline: When the Costume Isn’t Enough
text: The title character in “The Bald Soprano,” the absurdist Ionesco play, never shows up, but watch for her at the Metropolitan Opera.

headline: New Year’s Honors From the Queen
text: The fashion designer Stella McCartney (below), the actor Ewan McGregor, the singer Kate Bush and the cartoonist Quentin Blake were among those named to receive New Year’s Honors from Queen Elizabeth II, The Associated Press reported. Ms. McCartney will be recognized for her efforts in creating the Olympic uniforms for the British athletes in the 2012 London Summer Games; Mr. McGregor for his overall work in film; Ms. Bush for her music; and Mr. Blake, perhaps best known for his work on books by Roald Dahl, for his art.

headline: A 17th-Century Genius, a Quack, or Perhaps Both
text: In 2002 the New York Institute for the Humanities organized a symposium under the title “Was Athanasius Kircher the Coolest Guy Ever, or What?“ The highlights of this 17th-century German Jesuit polymath’s sprawling résumé, summed up in John Glassie’s brisk new biography, suggest the question wasn’t completely absurd.

headline: Giants Do Their Part but Miss Out on Playoffs
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — At some point in the coming days, Giants Coach Tom Coughlin plans to find a quiet moment and gather some of his veteran players together to ask them the singular question that will linger for him all winter, spring and summer.

headline: Obama Vows to Fix Flaws Discovered in Benghazi Inquiry
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama, in his most detailed comments on an independent inquiry’s report on the attack against the American diplomatic compound in Libya that killed four Americans on Sept. 11, said Sunday that the security and management flaws identified were “huge problems” that reflected “sloppiness” in how the State Department safeguards its missions abroad.

headline: Richard Rodney Bennett, British Composer, Dies at 76
text: Richard Rodney Bennett, the British composer who in a long, distinguished career moved with ease among classical concert music, jazz and film, died on Dec. 24 in New York, where he had lived since 1979. He was 76.

headline: Philadelphia School District Plans to Close Dozens of Schools
text: PHILADELPHIA — Like many public schools here, University City High School is underused, underfinanced and underperforming.

headline: Analyzing a Deal From Bridge Baron
text: Some players, especially those who give lessons, have an eye for an instructive deal. One is Steve Conrad of Manhasset, N.Y., who teaches on cruise ships and writes math problems for a living.

headline: Jets End Season With a Thud, and More Jolts May Be Coming
text: ORCHARD PARK, N.Y. — A Jets season that was so poor as to be unforgettable ended perhaps the only way it could have, with a dreadful loss Sunday.

headline: A Campaign Seeks to Infuse a Bank With Humanity
text: IN their purest form, banks offer their customers a banal product — a safe place to keep and manage their money. To set themselves apart they advertise myriad services like digital banking and reward programs and rely increasingly on convenient locations, catchy songs or celebrity spokesmen to get the message across.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
text: In observance of the New Year’s holiday, the bond markets will close early at 2 p.m. on Monday. Both the stock and bond markets will be closed on Tuesday.

headline: Economic Reports for the Week Ahead
text: ECONOMIC REPORTS Data to be released this week includes the I.S.M. manufacturing index for December and construction spending for November (Wednesday); ADP employment for December and weekly jobless claims (Thursday); and unemployment for December, the I.S.M. service index for December and factory orders for November (Friday).

headline: 2012: The Year in Culture
text: A look back at performances, exhibitions, films, books, movies and video games.

headline: Religion’s Role in Altruism and Survival
text: To the Editor:

headline: Ride the Waves
text: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — What a fun puzzle with which to end our solving year. I really liked this one, both for its simplicity and for its clever theme. Jeffrey Harris’s puzzle made me smile.

headline: Debate Over Women’s Prayer at the Western Wall
text: To the Editor:

headline: Instead of Gun Control, Try ‘Bullet Control’
text: To the Editor:

headline: Will Turkey Squander Its Opportunity to Lead?
text: Instead of Turkey leading the post-Arab Spring Middle East, Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan is setting a new standard of intolerance. Fourteen months after he touted Turkey as an example for the region, Mr. Erdogan is polarizing politics in his country and squelching dissent.

headline: For a Civilian-Military Dialogue
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Documentary Maker Puts Money on an Oscar Ad
text: SANTA MONICA, Calif. — Steven C. Barber, a filmmaker, was looking at a used Lexus to replace his 2001 Chevy when the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences released its lists of Oscar-eligible scores and songs this month. The music from his documentary, “Until They Are Home,” made both.

headline: In Germany, Merkel’s Main Rival Appears to Stumble From Gaffe to Gaffe
text: BERLIN — Chancellor Angela Merkel’s challenger in next year’s election may have already blurted out his own “binders full of women” gaffe early in the German campaign.

headline: Israel, in Shift, Lets Building Materials Cross Into Gaza
text: JERUSALEM — For the first time in five years, Israel on Sunday allowed 20 truckloads of building materials into Gaza for use by the private sector, according to Israeli and Palestinian officials. One of the first tangible concessions under a cease-fire deal reached after eight days of intensive fighting in November, it signaled a shift in Israel’s approach to the Palestinian enclave.

headline: William Baer Confirmed as Justice Department Antitrust Chief
text: William J. Baer was confirmed by the Senate on Sunday as the government’s top antitrust lawyer, placing him in charge of the Justice Department division that reviews corporate mergers and prosecutes price-fixing cases.

headline: No ‘I’ in His Team, Including Him
text: CHESTNUT HILL, Mass. — The coach called for a bunt, but the 13-year-old batter had other plans. He was the team’s unquestioned star. He would move along the runner with a base hit. Maybe even an extra-base hit.

headline: Catherine O’Neill, Advocate for Women and Children, Dies at 70
text: Catherine O’Neill, whose travels with the International Rescue Committee to refugee camps led her, along with the actress Liv Ullmann and others, to found the Women’s Commission for Refugee Women and Children, died Wednesday in Los Angeles. She was 70.

headline: Maxim Recruits a Readership in Uniform
text: CRAWFORDSVILLE, Ark. — Scaling elevator shafts and sliding through sewers in mud-caked fields at a military training camp here would not be what most people would call a vacation. But for 10 Special Operations soldiers from the Army, Navy, Marines and Air Force, participating in an event called the Maximum Warrior contest, these challenges had a singular aim: to be in Maxim magazine.

headline: Among Top News Stories, a War Is Missing
text: Look closely at the end-of-the-year lists of 2012’s top news stories. What’s missing? The 11-year-old war in Afghanistan and American-led counterterrorism efforts around the world.

headline: Giants’ Focus Shifts to 2013
text: A capsule look at the Giants’ 42-7 win over the Eagles:

headline: Still Hurt, Stoudemire Is Itching to Help Knicks
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — The Knicks’ Amar’e Stoudemire could play for the first time this season on Tuesday against the Portland Trail Blazers. Although his injured knee is not healed, he said, he is ready to do what he can.

headline: Let’s Give Up on the Constitution
text: Washington

headline: Amid Lockout Talks, Shorter Schedule Options Swirl
text: With the clock ticking and options dwindling for playing a truncated schedule to save the N.H.L. season, new bargaining between the league and the players association is expected to open Monday in New York.

headline: Brewing Up Confusion
text: Howard Schultz, the C.E.O. of Starbucks, has a reputation as a good guy, a man who supports worthy causes. And he presumably thought he would add to that reputation when he posted an open letter urging his employees to promote fiscal bipartisanship by writing “Come together” on coffee cups.

headline: U.S. Clears DNA Firm’s Acquisition by Chinese
text: The federal government has given national security clearance to the controversial purchase of an American DNA sequencing company by a Chinese firm.

headline: Has Facebook Ruined Love?
text: Are tweets, status updates and tagged photographs encouraging romance or ruining it?

headline: Huge Child-Support Debt Doesn’t Ensure Time in Jail
text: At first Lisa Sand wanted to see her ex-husband in prison. He had skipped out on making child support payments, missing court dates in Nassau County Family Court before leaving New York and eventually fleeing the country altogether. A fugitive for almost 20 years, he owed Ms. Sand and their two children $1 million.

headline: A Factory on Bicycle Wheels, Carrying Hope of a Better Life
text: MEXICO CITY — The sound of a surprising opportunity rose above the tumult of traffic. “Factory for electronic textiles offering work,” came the message, shouted from a megaphone that sat in the basket of a white bicycle pedaled by Amor Muñoz, an artist in a black jumpsuit. “One hundred pesos an hour!”

headline: Babes in Arms
text: From: David Keene, president

headline: For Liberals in Egypt, a Champion Who Quips
text: CAIRO — As a new Constitution engraves Islam ever more firmly into Egyptian law, a young comic’s escalating battle with a group of ultraconservative television sheiks has become an early skirmish over the application of Islamic law, or Shariah.

headline: Readers Respond to the ‘Armed Society’ Series
text: After the massacre at an elementary school in Newtown, Conn., earlier this month, The Stone published a series of essays that examined the philosophical implications of the use, possession and regulation of weapons. Readers responded with thousands of thoughtful comments. Below is a selection of their writing.— The Editors

headline: Clinton’s Blood Clot Is Located Near Her Brain, Doctors Say
text: WASHINGTON — Doctors treating Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton on Monday said that she suffered a blood clot in a vein between her brain and skull behind her right ear but predicted that she would make a full recovery.

headline: Jane Holmes Dixon, Bishop Who Stared Down Barriers, Dies at 75
text: Jane Holmes Dixon, a former eighth-grade teacher and homemaker who was ordained an Episcopal priest in her 40s and was the second woman to be elevated to bishop in the history of the Episcopal Church, died on Dec. 25 at her home in Washington. She was 75.

headline: Washout at Jones Beach
text: New York State parks officials have a huge job ahead of them in repairing Jones Beach State Park, which was dilapidated before Hurricane Sandy and devastated after, its boardwalk crumpled and its buildings ravaged. The park’s central mall, designed in Robert Moses’ day to evoke an ocean liner, today looks like a ship’s deck after a bad encounter with a very large, cold, floating object somewhere in the North Atlantic.

headline: Lure of Green Cards Brings Big Investments for Remote Resort in Vermont
text: JAY, Vt. — At this remote outpost by the Canadian border, Bill Stenger is overseeing what he says is the biggest economic development project that Vermont has ever seen.

headline: Family of Chinese Regulator Profits in Insurance Firm’s Rise
text: SHANGHAI — Relatives of a top Chinese regulator profited enormously from the purchase of shares in a once-struggling insurance company that is now one of China’s biggest financial powerhouses, according to interviews and a review of regulatory filings.

headline: Owner’s Say on Eagles’ Reid Could Come Soon
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Philadelphia Eagles Coach Andy Reid and the owner, Jeffrey Lurie, are scheduled to sit down soon, probably on Monday morning, to discuss Reid’s employment. For many weeks, it has been widely considered a foregone conclusion that Reid, who has coached the Eagles for the last 14 seasons, would be fired. Several news outlets have reported that Reid was fired Friday.

headline: Engineering a Reversal of Fortune in 2013
text: In business, all years are critical — make a big mistake and you won’t have the chance to make another one. But in the media, wave after wave of transformation mean the coming year is particularly important.

headline: Envoy to Syria Warns of Slide to Hellish Fiefs With Huge Toll
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The international envoy to Syria, Lakhdar Brahimi, drew a grim portrait on Sunday of the country’s future in the absence of a political solution, warning of a state carved up by warlords and a death toll that would rapidly surge, while conceding that there was little sign that the antagonists intended to negotiate.

headline: Green Cards for Vermont’s Kingdom
text: The head of Jay Peak ski resort in Vermont’s Northeast Kingdom is using a federal visa program called EB-5 to weatherproof his resort and kick-start the local economy.

headline: Game Not Known for Ferocity Claims a Casualty Who Was
text: Christie Moore Freel lost count of the nights her husband, Ryan, arrived home from the ballpark with a tale that added to her growing concern over his health.

headline: Two Rookies Who Had Stumbling Starts Achieve Promising Finishes
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — David Wilson did not seem to be aware that the Giants had been eliminated from postseason contention when he began talking to reporters.

headline: In Kabul, Deadly Cold Returns
text: Afghan refugees living in Kabul camps battle deadly cold as winter sets in.

headline: The Military’s Dirty Secret
text: Pentagon officials have long declared their determination to eradicate the military’s notorious culture of sexual violence. To judge from data made public in the last couple of months, they have a long way to go.

headline: No Easy Answers in Mali
text: The extremist Islamist militias that seized control of northern Mali in April have imposed their fanatical beliefs and barbaric punishments on the region’s defenseless people, sending tens of thousands of refugees fleeing into neighboring Mauritania. And they have given sanctuary to notorious terrorist groups like Nigeria’s Boko Haram and Algeria’s Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb, a group that Washington suspects may have been involved in the September attack on the American consulate in Libya.

headline: Settlement Expected on Past Abuses in Home Loans
text: Banking regulators are close to a $10 billion settlement with 14 banks that would end the government’s efforts to hold lenders responsible for foreclosure abuses like faulty paperwork and excessive fees that may have led to evictions, according to people with knowledge of the discussions.

headline: A Broken System for Tracking Guns
text: As President Obama looks to reduce gun violence after the Connecticut massacre through reforms like reinstating the assault weapons ban, he and supporters of sane gun laws in Congress need to be equally serious about strengthening the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives, the beleaguered agency charged with enforcing federal firearm regulations.

headline: Philadelphia Plans to Close Some Schools
text: The strapped school district has proposed an unprecedented downsizing that would close 37 schools by June.

headline: First Responders Mourn an Ambushed Firefighter
text: WEBSTER, N.Y. — Hundreds of firefighters, police officers and other emergency workers from as far away as California, and some from Canada, came to Webster Schroeder High School here in a show of support for Michael J. Chiapperini, 43, one of two volunteer firefighters fatally shot last Monday in an ambush by a gunman who later killed himself.

headline: A Lucrative Stock Sale
text: Relatives of high-ranking Chinese officials have seen impressive returns from shares of Ping An Insurance, a financial powerhouse in China.

headline: No Record for Peterson, but Vikings Will Play On
text: MINNEAPOLIS — Adrian Peterson ran onto the field at the Metrodome on Sunday with two goals: break Eric Dickerson’s N.F.L. single-season rushing record of 2,105 yards and help the Minnesota Vikings clinch an N.F.C. wild-card berth. “I’d be satisfied with both,” he said last week.

headline: After Career in Beauty, Facing Challenge of Failing Vision
text: Kevin Clements once led a glamorous life.

headline: Experts Forecast the Cost of Failure to Compromise
text: Even if President Obama and Republicans in Congress can reach a last-minute compromise that averts some tax increases before Monday’s midnight deadline, experts still foresee a significant drag on the economy in the first half of 2013 from the fiscal impasse in Washington.

headline: N.F.L. Rewind: Week 17
text: Playoff positioning was the story of the day as the regular season drew to a close, and a few records changed hands, too.

headline: Community Center Says It Has Been Told to Cease Its Storm Relief Program
text: People began showing up at the Ocean Bay Community Center in Arverne, Queens, on Sunday morning, braving the harsh cold to collect numbered tickets from a tall, dreadlocked man named Jamal Skrine. As he handed the tickets out, Mr. Skrine told the recipients to return later to pick up food and supplies.

headline: Indian Women March: ‘That Girl Could Have Been Any One of Us’
text: NEW DELHI — Neha Kaul Mehra says she was only 7 years old the first time she was sexually harassed. She was walking to a dance class in an affluent neighborhood of New Delhi when a man confronted her and began openly masturbating.

headline: Chávez Faces New Complications After Surgery

headline: Troubled Past for Suspect in Fatal Subway Push

She was treated by the psychiatric staffs of at least two city hospitals, and caseworkers visited her family home in Queens to provide further help. She was also arrested at least three times, according to the police, twice after violent confrontations.

headline: IHT Quick Read: Dec. 31
text: NEWS Indian women poured their anger into public demonstrations last week, reacting to news of the gang rape of a young woman who had moved to the city from a small village, with a new life in front of her. Many women in India say they are still subject to regular harassment and assault during the day and are fearful of leaving their homes alone after dark. Now they are demanding that the government, and a police force that they say offers women little or no protection, do something about it. Heather Timmons and Sruthi Gottipati report from New Delhi.

headline: The Worse, the Better
text: MOSCOW — I’ve long told myself and anyone else who would listen that things in Russia will get a lot worse before they get better. I have even thought, in accordance with an old dissident adage, that “the worse, the better”: the faster and more cruel the crackdown, the sooner the regime itself will crack. What I did not realize was just how bad “worse” was going to feel.

headline: Ryan Block: Why I’m Quitting Instagram
text: The flap over Instagram’s changing its terms of service has not died down even weeks after its announcement and subsequent partial reversal. People are still arguing whether Instagram’s users will stay loyal to the service. Ryan Block, former editor in chief of AOL’s Engadget and the co-founder of the popular tech community site Gdgt, writes in a guest post for Bits about his reasons for quitting the Facebook-owned service.

headline: In Images: A History of Premier Automobiles
text: The black and yellow Padmini taxi is as identifiable with Mumbai as the Volkswagen Beetle taxi in Mexico City or the once ubiquitous Checker cab in New York. Alternately loathed and romanticized, the Padmini — or some version of it — was produced in Mumbai from 1964 to 2000 by Premier Automobiles. It became a favorite of taxi drivers in the 1970s because it was cheaper, easier to drive and more maneuverable than the tank-like Hindustan Ambassador, its main competition in Bombay, as the city was known then. For the individual motorist, it was attainable and passed for sporty in a tightly controlled automotive industry.

headline: 12 New Year’s Resolutions for Happier Families
text: As I wrote around this time a year ago, I love making New Year’s resolutions. For me, it’s a moment to take stock of where I am, and where I want to be, and of all the things I’ve said I hoped to do and have or haven’t done — and why. The resolutions I fail at are always the ones I didn’t really want to keep.

headline: Tentative Deal Is Reached to Raise Taxes on the Wealthy
text: WASHINGTON — Furious last-minute negotiations between the White House and the Senate Republican leadership on Monday secured a tentative agreement to allow tax rates to rise on affluent Americans, but not in time for Congress to meet its Dec. 31 deadline for averting automatic tax increases and spending cuts deemed a threat to the economy.

headline: On Our Radar: Shell’s Errant Arctic Drilling Vessel

On Saturday, its crew was evacuated by helicopter. [The Anchorage Daily News]

headline: A Roman Numerals Puzzle

headline: Vegan Pantry Dinners for the New Year
text: Here is a New Year’s project for you. Take an inventory of your pantry, freezer, and refrigerator and cook for a week without buying anything except items that you and your children may consume on a daily basis (for me that means bananas). That is what I’m doing this week and I have decided that I will also make my meals vegan.

headline: Warm Lentil Salad With Balsamic Roast Squash
text: This recipe started out as something else. I had in my pantry a bag of mixed sprouted lentils – black, green, and brown. I cooked them with the intention of making dal, but I so liked the integrity of the cooked lentils – green and black lentils remain intact even after they soften – that I didn’t want to mash them. Meanwhile I had roasted some squash with balsamic vinegar. I ended up warming the lentils in a cumin-scented vinaigrette and serving them with the squash.

headline: Copy of Beatles Album With Unusual History Sells for Nearly $20,000
text: When Chris Collins and his sister, Liz Chambers, put their prized copy of the Beatles’ “Please Please Me” album up for auction in early December they expected it to fetch £15,000 (about $24,400). They had reason to be hopeful: the album not only was an original pressing, on the black-and-gold Parlophone label that was discontinued (and replaced with a sleeker, black-and-yellow update) a few months after the album was released, but it is also autographed. But when bidding reached only £12,000 ($19,500), they withdrew the disc. Now the BBC reports that they have sold it privately for the price they had turned down at the auction.

headline: Vegan Pho With Carrots, Noodles and Edamame
text: When I was testing my vegan pho broth for a Recipes for Health series last spring I froze a few containers of the broth; I had forgotten how good it is. I didn’t have some of the traditional ingredients for pho – bean sprouts, cilantro, scallions, green chiles – so I used what I had and it was definitely pho. I used cayenne for heat and a chiffonade of romaine lettuce was a good stand-in for the bean sprouts, crunchy and fresh. Lots of chives stood in for scallions. I did without cilantro or Thai basil but had plenty of Italian basil and mint from my garden.

headline: For Sam and Me, Just Say ‘Knicks’
text: For years I was furious with the New York Knicks for robbing me of what should have been an important part of my relationship with my son Sam growing up.

headline: Rice Bowl With Sweet and Sour Purple Cabbage, Red Peppers and Baked Marinated Tofu
text: I cooked up a pot of Thai purple sticky rice that had been lingering in the pantry, and then decided how I would turn it into a meal. It was too sticky to use for stir-fried rice so I made stir-fried vegetables and oven-baked tofu, and served up rice bowls topped with both. I thought it might be an altogether too purple meal, but it was quickly devoured, and we are all the more anti-oxidant rich because of the anthocyanins in the red and purple foods.

headline: Slow Return for a Former Speakeasy That Crumpled
text: It was a restaurant where F. Scott Fitzgerald had a tryst with a woman in a booth — supposedly. It was a bar with front steps that were built expressly to trip up Prohibition-era policemen who would periodically rush in to spoil the party — maybe. And it had bootlegging tunnels that led from inside the bar far out into the street — probably not.

headline: Looking Into Lopez’s Sudden Resurgence
text: In the two games since Avery Johnson was relieved of his duties as coach of the Nets, Brook Lopez has averaged 29.5 points and 11 rebounds in consecutive Brooklyn wins. In the two victories, Lopez has lived near the rim and shot 68.5 percent from the field while getting to the line 19 times. Essentially, he returned to the All-Star form he showed in the first month of the season as he propelled the Nets to an 11-4 start.

headline: Poets Who Look Death in the Eye
text: The poets C. K. Williams and Cynthia Cruz, at first glance, couldn’t seem more different. Mr. Williams owns a Pulitzer and has published more than 20 books; her latest book is just Ms. Cruz’s second. He casts long, serpentine lines upon the page; she savors the cryptic burst. And Mr. Williams was born into the same 1930s Newark that shaped Philip Roth, while Ms. Cruz came of age in Santa Cruz, Calif., skateboarding and listening to punk.

text: The 2013 Ford Fusion Energi plug-in hybrid has received an E.P.A. certification of being able to achieve the equivalent of 108 miles per gallon in city driving, the automaker has announced.

headline: Conceder In Chief?
text: OK, I’ve had my own sorta-kinda briefing on the apparent fiscal cliff deal, and I’m pretty much with Noam Scheiber. Viewed on its own, it’s a bad and upsetting deal but not as terrible as initial rumors had it. But the strategic consequences are likely to be very bad indeed, and in very short order too.

headline: Promoter Who Revamped Capitol Theater Buys It
text: The concert promoter who revitalized the Capitol Theater in Port Chester, N.Y., this year as a rock music hall has bought that landmark building from its previous owner. The promoter, Peter Shapiro, who is also a partner in the Brooklyn Bowl, said he paid $11.5 million for the 1,800-seat theater, closing a deal on Friday with the previous owner, Marvin Ravikoff.

headline: Worms Produce Another Kind of Gold for Growers
text: SONOMA, Calif. — Under rows of old chicken sheds, Jack Chambers has built an empire of huge metal boxes filled with cattle manure and millions of wriggling red worms.

headline: Where the Melvillean Things Are
text: In last weekend’s Lives They Lived issue, the longtime contributor to the magazine Christoph Niemann sketched a clever, touching tribute to Maurice Sendak. Niemann (self-rendered in a way that recalls Calvin’s father in “Calvin & Hobbes”) recreates an afternoon in 2011 when he listened to the children’s book author being interviewed on the car radio. His drive was taken over by images from Sendak’s work the way Max’s bedroom is overrun by jungle in “Where the Wild Things Are,” with glimpses of Max, wild things, Jennie the dog, Mickey, a couple of bakers.

headline: A Ride in a 1954 Bentley R-Type Sedan
text: In their criticism of Lindsay Lohan for her portrayal of Elizabeth Taylor in Lifetime’s recent “Liz & Dick,” reviewers missed an assured, if brief, appearance by 59-year-old Madame, who came out of semiseclusion to take on the role as conveyance to a cuckold.

headline: Knowing You Carry a Cancer Gene
text: I jogged into the Stanford Cancer Clinic with my boyfriend, the youngest people there by two decades. We stood there sweating and holding hands, a jarring sight in the sickly light.

headline: Sound vs. Noise, and the Elusive Quest for Quiet
text: Mike Goldsmith has assembled a lot of facts about noise, some familiar (trucks are noisy), some worth noting (the Big Bang was silent) and some nearly lost to history: The ill-fated Concorde was so loud that in 1976 Congress banned its landing in the United States (a decision quickly overturned by the secretary of transportation). A fatal crash in 2000 led to the doom of the Concorde entirely.

text: The human brain responds to music in different ways, depending on the listener’s emotional reaction, among other things. Now researchers report that the same holds true for birds listening to birdsong.

text: Wine enthusiasts, consider this: The same grapes from different parts of a vineyard can be quite different.

headline: Big Data: Rise of the Machines

Davenport, who has worked in the fields of knowledge management and analytics for 15 years. Data analytics is the predecessor to Big Data. He knows the context — what’s new and what’s not with Big Data — as well as anyone.
