headline: Youthful Orchestra Abets the Voice of a Clarinet
text: Mozart wrote several remarkable works for the Austrian clarinetist Anton Stadler, his friend and fellow Mason, including the great Quintet for Clarinet and Strings, and the Clarinet Concerto, the last major score Mozart completed, shortly before dying. He was clearly inspired by his colleague’s virtuosity and artistry. From all reports, Stadler could bend a gentle phrase with uncommon delicacy. Johann Schink, a Viennese critic, wrote that he would not have thought it possible for a clarinet to “imitate the human voice so deceptively,” as Stadler did.

headline: Outmaneuvered at Their Own Game, Antivirus Makers Struggle to Adapt
text: SAN FRANCISCO — The antivirus industry has a dirty little secret: its products are often not very good at stopping viruses.

headline: Mourning for Rape Victim Recasts New Year’s Eve in India
text: As my colleague Sruthi Gottipati reports, thousands of protesters marched on Monday in New Delhi, pledging to “take back the night,” as India remained in mourning for the 23-year-old victim of a gang rape who died on Saturday.

headline: The Human Toll of Europe’s Economic Statistics
text: An interactive presentation of how the debt crisis has affected five European countries accompanies this post. We urge you to view it.

headline: ‘We Lost Things and We Can Replace Those Things’
text: ORTLEY BEACH, N.J. — Stefanie Pyper’s last prehurricane memory of her house on Fourth Avenue is one of bliss: the bike ride up to the Lavallette Boardwalk, seeing a school of dolphins in the ocean, the oasis of calm amid the turmoil of raising five children ranging in age from 8 to 18.

headline: Motor Skills May Predict Success in School
text: Poor motor function in childhood may be an important factor in predicting poor academic achievement in adolescence.

headline: The Confusion of Pill Coloring
text: New research suggests that changing the color of a person’s pills — by switching to a generic from a brand name drug, for example — sharply reduces the chances that the patient will continue to take it.

headline: The Life of Pi, and Other Infinities
text: On this day that fetishizes finitude, that reminds us how rapidly our own earthly time share is shrinking, allow me to offer the modest comfort of infinities.

headline: An Environmentalist Weighs the Fallout of Flying
text: I FLY a lot. And honestly, flying now is a means to an end, although I used to enjoy it. It’s not that I hate it or am paranoid. It’s just that it’s a chore.

headline: Mortality: H.I.V.-Positive Smokers Lose More Years to Tobacco Than to the Virus, a Study Says
text: H.I.V. patients who obtain good treatment but who smoke lose more years of life to tobacco than to the virus, a new Danish study has found.

headline: Juggling Diabetes and Cancer
text: Nine years ago, Brenda Gray, a former schoolteacher in North Carolina, discovered she had Type 2 diabetes.

headline: Yankees at Payroll Threshold, at Least for Now
text: On the final day of 2012 the Yankees will coincidentally close out the year at a landmark position in baseball’s payroll standings, the sport’s own fiscal cliff, which will arrive before the 2014 season. It is a spot they expect to revisit again in one year, but for now they are only passing it by.

headline: Coldplay Delivers in the Usual Way
text: Near the end of its allotted time at the Barclays Center in Brooklyn on Sunday night, Coldplay offered up “Fix You,” a vow of encouragement about as earnest and ingenuous as its title suggests. The song opens like a processional hymn and stays in that realm awhile before tipping decisively toward rock grandeur: a cue for Chris Martin, the voice and face and soul of the band, to shrug off any lingering scrap of pensiveness or decorum.

headline: Why Elliott Carter Wasn’t in ‘The Music They Made’
text: Over the weekend, Alex Ross, the New Yorker music critic and author of the excellent books ‘‘The Rest Is Noise: Listening to the Twentieth Century’’ and ‘‘Listen to This,’’ called for a protest against the Times Magazine. He had his reasons: The annual mix I make honoring the musicians who died the previous year did not — once again — include any classical musicians.

headline: Remarks by the President on Fiscal Cliff Negotiations
text: The following is the full text of President Obama’s statement from the White House on the fiscal talks on Monday.

headline: Light Absorption Speeding Arctic Ice Melt
text: The record-setting disappearance of Arctic sea ice this fall was an indication to many climate scientists and ice experts that the pace of climate change was outstripping predictions.

headline: Building a Better Goal Post
text: A look at the manufacturing of a football goal post that, with the push of a button, sinks to the ground in less than a minute.

headline: Irving Azoff to Leave Live Nation
text: Irving Azoff, the executive chairman of Live Nation Entertainment, the concert and ticketing giant, is leaving the company, Live Nation announced on Monday.

headline: Fearing Fighting, Residents Flee Capital of Central African Republic
text: JOHANNESBURG — As efforts to broker a deal to stop a rebel advance failed, residents of the capital of the Central African Republic were packing up their belongings and fleeing into the country’s vast hinterlands, fearing a major battle between government troops and guerrilla fighters.

headline: Albums from Buddy Miller and Jim Lauderdale, and the Max Johnson Trio
text: BUDDY MILLER AND JIM LAUDERDALE

headline: Revisiting a Beatles Archive
text: Henry Grossman took more than 7,000 photos of the Beatles in the mid-1960s. A new book includes about 1,000 of them.

headline: Big Innovations in Football Are Just Past the End Zone
text: In its home opener in 2005, the Central Florida football team ended a 17-game losing streak with an upset of Marshall. Fans swarmed the field and, in a time-honored tradition, tore down one of the goal posts at the Florida Citrus Bowl in Orlando.

headline: New Frontier for Topics in Science: Social Media
text: The largest and most sophisticated rover landed safely on Mars and the world’s most famous Moon visitor died, but the space event that most captured the public’s imagination in 2012 involved a journey to Earth.

headline: The Kardashian Family Grows on Twitter
text: When Kanye West announced on stage last Sunday that his girlfriend, Kim Kardashian, is pregnant, it came as a surprise, not only to the audience, but reportedly also to Ms. Kardashian as well. So how did the Kardashian clan respond? On Twitter, of course, where they offered their congratulations. And sure enough, #kimye was again a trending hashtag. An E! special must be in this baby’s future.

headline: Obama Won New York City, in Case Anyone Was Wondering
text: However this fiscal cliff thing turns out, President Obama can take heart in one piece of news that broke on Monday: he won the election in New York City.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Syria and Elsewhere
text: Photos from Syria, Central African Republic, Gaza Strip, West Bank and India.

headline: Academy Members Get an Extra Day to Vote
text: LOS ANGELES—The Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences has been having a tough time with deadlines: After extending the time limit for the documentary branch to compile its shortlist in the fall, the Academy is now giving all members an extra day to cast their entire Oscar nominating ballots.

headline: The More Things Change, the More a Band Can Do
text: More an apparition than a band, the Golden Palominos have materialized, vanished and reconfigured over the past 30 years, according to the impulses of the drummer Anton Fier, the band’s only constant. The Golden Palominos have been a noise-funk band, a globally tinged pop band, a rock band and a folk-pop band, while their studio albums have featured guest lead vocalists like Michael Stipe of R.E.M. and John Lydon of Public Image Ltd.

headline: Prospecting for Treasure Behind Urban Padlocks
text: I moved into my current apartment in November 2001, on the heels of the Sept. 11 attacks, boxing everything up for a move away from downtown Manhattan to an equally spacious but less forgivingly laid out place uptown. As part of the move I exiled some things to a storage outfit in Nassau County, N.Y., and there the pile rested, a ghost whose existence was proved only by the monthly checks I’ve written ever since.

headline: The Return of the Natives
text: STEVEN and Loraine Summer adore their sons Jason, 20, a junior at the University of Maryland, and Ari, 22, a graduate student at the University of Colorado. When the boys returned home in suburban Denver to visit at Thanksgiving, their parents enjoyed the adult conversation and learning about their sons’ career ambitions and new interests.

headline: Photo Replay: Dec. 31
text: A view of the year’s final day in sports, including basketball in the pros, football in the bowls and bike racing in the snow.

headline: Revis Focuses on Return, One He Hopes Is With the Jets
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — Darrelle Revis was a helpless spectator as the Jets’ season careened out of control.

headline: A Year of Market Gains, Despite Turmoil
text: A year ago, some thought 2012 was destined to be the year that the euro zone — and maybe even the entire European Union — broke up. The banks that supported their governments, and that in turn depended on those same governments for bailouts if they went broke, were deemed to be particularly vulnerable to disaster.

headline: Live From Times Square: New Year’s Eve
text: Thinking about spending the last few moments of 2012 in Times Square? Yes, it’s a New York tradition, the first gathering having taken place in 1904. But for the 2012-13 party, it’s probably already too late.

headline: Chief Justice Prods Congress to Resolve Budget Talks and Control National Debt
text: WASHINGTON — Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. used his year-end report on the federal judiciary to give Congressional budget negotiators a little nudge.

headline: The Beatles, Seen From Unusual Angles
text: When Time magazine first asked Henry Grossman to photograph the Beatles, at their American television debut on “The Ed Sullivan Show” in February 1964, he thought of it as just another assignment — a journey into the realm of teenage fads, and less exciting than the sessions he had done with world leaders, actors and opera singers. Mr. Grossman, who was 27 at the time, preferred classical music; at 76, he still shoots production photos for the Metropolitan Opera.

headline: Actors, Offstage and Off Guard
text: For many actors rehearsal is a place to make mistakes. For Glenn Fitzgerald it’s a place to make art. Starting in 1998, when he took portraits of Nathan Lane and other cast members in Jon Robin Baitz’s “Mizlansky/Zilinsky, or ‘Schmucks,’ ” Mr. Fitzgerald has captured scenes of productions in which he’s appeared.

headline: Worlds in a Snapshot
text: The actor Glenn Fitzgerald talks about photos he’s taken of two shows in which he’s appeared.

headline: Race and Medicine (2 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Recovery After Trauma
text: To the Editor:

headline: Independence for Elderly
text: To the Editor:

headline: Spiritual Landscapes of the Gilded Age
text: In 1880, according to a frequently cited report, 4,000 churches were under construction in the United States. This Gilded Age frenzy of ecclesiastical building created a terrific demand for designers who could make houses of worship that were also theaters of spiritually inspiring beauty. And every church seemed to require at least one spectacular stained-glass window to transport the faithful into imaginary realms of transcendental bliss. The man who most famously fulfilled that need was Louis Comfort Tiffany (1848-1933).

headline: Humpback Whales Seek Pairings Based on Size
text: Going underwater with video cameras and sonar, scientists have gained new insights into the mating behavior of humpback whales.

headline: Playing by Heart, With or Without a Score
text: It would seem that the filmmaker Michael Haneke, who wrote and directed the wrenching and poignantly acted new French movie “Amour,” is swept away by the mystique of a pianist, alone onstage, conveying mastery and utter oneness with music by playing a great piece from memory. The drama of playing from memory is at the crux of a scene involving the elegant French pianist Alexandre Tharaud, who, portraying himself, has a small but crucial role.

headline: Seasoned With Invention and Irreverence
text: ONE school of criticism holds that chefs should faithfully honor any cuisine they pilfer. But there’s an equally valid case for bold, fearless theft. A good pickpocket does not waste time with introductions.

headline: Thirty Acres
text: This restaurant challenges your sense of geography, starting with its location.

headline: Added In or Left Out, Fees Remain the Focus
text: IN a move being watched by competitors, American Airlines is experimenting with a new pricing option that eliminates the potential penalty fee for changing flights for customers who pay a little extra for a basic coach ticket.

headline: A Podcast That Has Old-School Smarts
text: In 2012 I spent more time with comedy podcasts than I did with sitcoms and talk shows combined. It’s not something I would recommend to everyone.

headline: Found Moments
text: The actor Glenn Fitzgerald takes photos of shows in which he appears.

headline: Piazza, the Marlin, And a Shared Fixation
text: One is a corporate lawyer from Southern California with few hobbies and only the mildest interest in sports. The other is a college student from Miami who is less than half his age and has amassed a stash of memorabilia that matches his love of baseball.

headline: A Luminous Kingdom, Awaiting on a Blustery Night
text: BOSTON — What’s new about Boston Ballet’s new “Nutcracker” is the expensive part: scenery and costumes, both by Robert Perdziola. The dances and the story appear largely the same. This is a shrewd way for any company to proceed: take a production and keep building it. On the day I arrived here, The Boston Globe reported that the production’s attendance and revenues were up.

headline: Enjoying the New Year’s Holiday
text: Dresden, Germany, the home of Volkswagen’s Transparent Factory, is also the site of a spectacular New Year’s Eve fireworks display. So we’ll take this opportunity to wish everyone a Happy New Year and to remind you that drinking and driving don’t mix. We’ll be off on Tuesday but back with you on Wednesday. If you’re behind the wheel, stay safe and sober.

headline: Marveling Over a Marlin
text: Jerry Dworkin of Irvine, Calif., is on the chase to collect all of the 120-plus Mike Piazza Florida Marlins trading cards issued between 1998 and 2005.

headline: 12 Foreign Stories From 2012 Worth Revisiting
text: There were hundreds of memorable foreign stories from Times correspondents in 2012. Here is a sampling of 12 from across the world in chronological order.

headline: Announcing the Latest Big Thing
text: These past few weeks, every media outlet on the Internet, from Vogue to CNN, has been commemorating the hottest trends of 2012: donating to Kony 2012, taking placenta pills, wearing peplums, compulsively watching the Weather Channel. The lists go on and on.

headline: The Emancipation of Abe Lincoln
text: ONE hundred and fifty years ago, on Jan. 1, 1863, Abraham Lincoln presided over the annual White House New Year’s reception. Late that afternoon, he retired to his study to sign the Emancipation Proclamation. When he took up his pen, his hand was shaking from exhaustion. Briefly, he paused — “I do not want it to appear as if I hesitated,” he remarked. Then Lincoln affixed a firm signature to the document.

headline: How Many Slaves Work for You?
text: New Brunswick, N.J.

headline: After Crispy Pig Ears, 10 Trends for 2013
text: IN our newly omnivorous nation, restaurant trends often have the same viral spread and short life span as boy bands — witness 2011’s crispy pig ears and sea buckthorn berries. Eating around the country on reporting trips in 2012, I saw food lovers everywhere embracing new interpretations of farm-to-table and nose-to-tail as fast as they came along.

headline: Hurting Knicks Uncertain of Tuesday’s Lineup
text: The Knicks are stepping carefully into the new year, not quite sure just who will be on the court and who will be sitting and watching, when they take on the Portland Trail Blazers at Madison Square Garden on Tuesday night.

headline: Pursuing a First Win in the Bowls Since 1949
text: EVANSTON, Ill. — From the sidelines at a recent practice, Northwestern Coach Pat Fitzgerald looked as if he could have been a player. Fitzgerald, a baby-faced 38-year-old, wore a black, long-sleeved T-shirt and black shorts that revealed muscular calves. He was a bundle of energy, sprinting from player to player during drills, bumping chests and shouting encouragement. Only his clipboard and whistle gave him away.

headline: Bond Craze Could Run Its Course in New Year
text: The big story in the markets this year was not about stocks.
